Title: What do I like about Amsterdam?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This is a frequently asked question when I first meet people or talk with friends. I usually give a quick answer that comes to mind, but Iâ€™ve never really thought it through. Sunday night is the perfect time to do just that!
Among all the big cities Iâ€™ve visited, Amsterdam has a unique vibe that you canâ€™t find in others. While places like New York, Taipei, Paris, London, and Munich are filled with tall, modern buildings, Amsterdam stands out with its distinctive charm, where the houses are typically not very tall and are built with red bricks, reflecting the cityâ€™s rich culture. Additionally, you can easily reach a canal every few minutes on foot, adding a natural touch to the urban landscape.
Unlike point 1, this isnâ€™t unique to Amsterdam, but itâ€™s still a significant factor in why I enjoy living here. I donâ€™t drive and donâ€™t have a license, which would be a major inconvenience in places like California, where everything is spread out and requires a car. In Amsterdam, however, the excellent public transport system allows me to easily reach shopping centers, my office, and even the suburbs. This is definitely a big plus for me.
I didnâ€™t realize how convenient Amsterdam is until I visited other countries. Since moving here almost a year ago, I havenâ€™t used any cash and I havenâ€™t even withdrawn any cash. Iâ€™m personally very against using cash and avoid it as much as possible. In Amsterdam, I donâ€™t even have to try. Even at traditional markets, vendors accept cards, and itâ€™s rare for anyone to ask for cash. This is definitely a great plus!
Amsterdam is crowded compared to other cities in the Netherlands, but it still feels slower and less busy than many other major cities worldwide. People often bike or take public transit, resulting in less polluted air and a fresher atmosphere. This contributes to a cozy, slower-paced feel throughout the city. After 5 PM, stores close, so if you donâ€™t plan to dine out, you can unwind and rest instead of engaging in a busy nightlife that sometimes creates more subtle mental stress.
Similar to other top countries, Amsterdam attracts talent from around the world. However, Amsterdam feels more inclusive, which is reflected in the language people are willing to use. If you enter a shop and give a small hint that you are an English speaker (for example, I usually start with a higher-pitched â€œHiâ€ instead of â€œHoiâ€ or â€œHalloâ€ ğŸ˜†), they will easily switch to English. Itâ€™s also easy to make expat friends, as many people move here for work and are open to meeting new people.
If youâ€™ve ever visited Amsterdam, what do you like about it?
--
--
Hi there :) I'm from Taiwan and moved to Amsterdam in 2023 to experience a different life. I write about my journey and reflections on work and life.

Title: Reflections in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Amsterdam undeniably ranks among the worldâ€™s most beloved destinations. Its captivating architecture and enormous intricate canal network weave a spell, effortlessly enchanting visitors. This welcoming city embraces tourists with open arms, boasting a population remarkably fluent in English, making independent exploration as a Non-Dutch speaking foreigner possible. Renowned for its safety and visual splendor, Amsterdam always offers a lot of experiences to pique travelerâ€™s curiosity.
As an Indonesian, my perception of the Netherlands is layered with historical complexity. Our predecessors endured immense suffering in their fight for independence started in the 16th century, a struggle etched in collective memory for three and a half centuries.
Yet, a chance encounter with a veteran of the Dutch Military Aggression (1947) several years ago offered me a profound perspective. His words, â€œThe first to apologize is the bravest. The first to forgive is the strongest. The first to forget is the happiest,â€ resonated with me deeply, despite language barriers. He recounted facing Dutch forces in Malang, his villageâ€™s devastation by explosions and fire, forcing him and his family to seek refuge in Pasuruan, East Java.
It took him almost seventy years to learn to forgive. He told me that he realized that lingering anger only fueled the bitterness, perpetuating a vicious cycle, and as a Christian, he believes God wonâ€™t like it. â€œTransferring this anger to future generations betrays the spirit of a warrior and my Christian faith,â€ he emphasized.
On an afternoon walk in Amsterdam two years ago, all of a sudden my gaze drifted upwards, landing on the word â€œMalangâ€ on the front face of an old building on the street of Ververstraat 30, Amsterdam. In that instant, my mind went back to a conversation years ago. In my mind, the veteranâ€™s words echoed: â€œThe first to forgive is the strongest. The first to forget is the happiest.â€ A long pause punctuated my journey before I resumed walking eventually.
As the cool canal breeze whispered and the afternoon sun cast a peaceful glow, I stood before the former historical VOC (Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie / Dutch East India Company) building. Today, facing its weathered facade, I wonder if fear can truly be measured in bricks and mortar. I stood still and in silence, I prayed: â€œMay peace bless all veterans who fought for freedom, and may peace always be with these two countriesâ€.
Forgiveness, I realized, truly fosters peace.
This Amsterdam trip resonated deeply, transcending mere sightseeing. It became a gateway, revealing two divergent paths: the darkness of hatred and the luminous expanse of peace.
The warmth of Amsterdamâ€™s locals during my two-day visit surprised me. Interactions with locals flowed easily, shattering preconceived notions of a â€œfierceâ€ city. Instead, I discovered a welcoming community steeped in rich history. It was undoubtedly a personal transformation rooted in the unexpected warmth of the city.
Like a painter smoothing past lines, time erases distinctions. Amsterdam and Batavia, the Netherlands and Indonesia, are no longer bound by the rigid constraints of their shared history. Peace has become the guiding hand, paving the way for understanding and connection.
Thank you for reading.
--
--
1
NL-based Indonesian geologist and mining engineer. Passionate about preserving nature. Former trail runner. Currently doing MSc at TU Delft.

Title: So, Youâ€™re Visiting Amsterdam?
Content:

Share
Iâ€™m a grandmother (â€œOma in Dutchâ€) and have been living here for a little over the past two years. Iâ€™ve had several friends visit me from overseas and from other countries, and taking them to â€œsee the sightsâ€ has been an educational experience for me as well. My recommendations below are written from my point of view as a 68-year-old with somewhat limited mobility and also as a grandmother who enjoys doing things with the grandkids. Wherever Iâ€™ve included links, they are places Iâ€™ve visited and experiences Iâ€™ve enjoyed. None of my links are affiliate links.
The City of Amsterdam is full of so many enjoyable things to see and do that itâ€™s a good idea to make a plan for your visit based on several factors, including your budget, the timing and duration of your stay, your physical capabilities, your interests, and most important of all, whether or not you are comfortable riding a bicycle.
The weather needs to be considered. Bring rain gear if youâ€™re coming in the winter or early spring (or any time of the year). If itâ€™s still winter, you will probably be best off with layers, but make sure to bring at least one item that will serve as a windbreaker.

Title: Visiting Amsterdam like a Local and a Tourist
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Travel tips from Locals and Tourists
I love Amsterdam. Itâ€™s a beautiful city with such a relaxed vibe (and not for the reasons you might think). Thereâ€™s an understated confidence about it â€” a city that knows itâ€™s great, but doesnâ€™t have to shout it from the historical rooftops.
Itâ€™s one of my favorite cities and hope to go back again (and again). For my first visit, I went for 4 nights. 3 was plenty of time to see everything, but 4 made it more relaxing. Besides buying museum tickets, I didnâ€™t plan too much before and gave myself a lot of time to explore (which basically meant taking pictures of every canal a million times). I would start each day at a museum, then would wander (eat, shop, pictures) for the rest of the day. This worked out perfectly.
Suggested length of visit: 3â€“5 days
I suggest staying along or near the Canal Ring (Grachtengordel) in the city center or near Museumplein (a large public space surrounded by a lot of museums). Two of my favorite hotels in Amsterdam:
The HoxtonI love this brand of hotels anywhere in the world â€” they encompass hipster millennial chic at its best. This location was once the Mayorâ€™s home and is a combination of 5 canal houses. They also offer the Hoxton breakfast bags (one of my favorite Hoxton features!). Itâ€™s in the middle of the central part of the city right along the Canal Ring. Itâ€™s also really close to the Anne Frank House and near a lot of shopping and tourist hotspots.
Hotel JL No76This boutique hotel and quiet neighborhood had a cozy, home away from home vibe. Itâ€™s near Museumplein, which made the proximity nice for visiting the museums each day. The location also made it convenient for wandering other parts of the city and itâ€™s not as touristy at night, which made for a nice, local escape.
Stroopwafel. Cheese. Apple Pie. What more could you want? Hereâ€™s a list of some of the favorite restaurants and foods from my trip.
Winkel 43I sat outside and watched the world go by while having an awesome slice of Dutch apple pie with a dollop of cream. Basic at its best.
Foodhallen (Resident tip)Large modern food hall with a local, energetic, and youthful vibe. Itâ€™s also in a more local neighborhood away from the standard tourist fare.
Stroopwafel Everywhere and addictive. Youâ€™ve been warned. I bought a few bags at a local market to bring home.
PoffertjesDutch mini pancakes. So cute and tasty. Found at restaurants and street markets everywhere.
FEBOThis might seem random, but youâ€™ll see these â€˜automatâ€™ food shops are all over the city. You drop some money in the machines and out comes the â€˜fast foodâ€™. An interesting experience to say the least. Croquettes are kind of their thing, but my favorite item is their soft serve ice cream â€” which you have to purchase from a human behind the counter and then they will bring it to you. Old school.
Dutch Cheese Shops These touristy cheese shops are everywhere. Not sure why I didnâ€™t realize Dutch cheese was a thing until I visited (ummm like Gouda), but with most cheese, itâ€™s worth a sample and a purchase. De Kaaskamer, the Amsterdam Cheese Company, or the Old Amsterdam Cheese Store are some good options to visit.
Belgian Fries / Frites Yes, itâ€™s not Belgium, but the Frites are still delicious. There are a bunch of shops â€” some touristy, some not. Stop and have some frites in a paper cone with a tasty dipping sauce or toppings â€” best eaten cleanly with a fork.
Cafe De Klos (Resident tip)This is not Dutch food, but amazing BBQ. Can be a bit of a wait and I suggest paying with cash, but worth a shot if youâ€™re nearby. The food comes with a side of sarcastic staff. If you canâ€™t handle the heatâ€¦
Tosti (Resident tip)Essentially a grilled cheese with ham (or not). No specific spot, keep an eye out and try one if you see it.
Door 74Great speakeasy cocktail bar with the standard difficult to find entrance. Itâ€™s also listed as one of â€˜The Worldâ€™s 50 Best Barsâ€™ (if youâ€™re into that sort of thing). Look into making a reservation via phone ahead of time.
Albert HeijnLocal grocery chain. Great for basics and snacks during the trip (itâ€™s also where I bought my Stroopwafels).
MuseumpleinA lot of the cityâ€™s major museums surround (literally one right next to another) this massive park-like public space in the center of the city. Staying near here makes museum hopping very convenient. This is also where youâ€™ll find the main â€˜Iamsterdamâ€™ letters, which makes it a major gathering place for tourists.
RijksmuseumThe â€˜mainâ€™ museum in Amsterdam and a must see. Itâ€™s at the edge of the â€˜Museumpleinâ€™ and has a few notable works like Rembrandtâ€™s largest and most famous painting The Night Watch and one of Van Goghâ€™s colorful self portraits.
Van Gogh MuseumI love Van Gogh, so this was a must for me. If you like him too, you should check this out for a deep dive into his life and work.
Stedelijk Museum This is the modern art museum, but I only recommend if you have time and youâ€™re a fan of modern art.
Anne Frank HouseIt goes without saying that this is a must while in Amsterdam. It is a quiet and reflective experience. I had my own unique takeaways, and hopefully you will have yours too. Be sure to purchase your timed-entry ticket ahead of time (they sell out fast, so buy right after you book your flight). I recommend going when it first opens so itâ€™s not as crowded.
Bloemenmarkt â€” Amsterdam Flower Market I love flowers, so Iâ€™m always excited to visit a flower market (I need to go back to the Netherlands during tulip season!). This â€˜floatingâ€™ market located on the Singel canal features shop after shop with flower bouquets, trinkets and souvenirs. Itâ€™s cute, but very touristy. I bought some wooden tulips and took a lot of photos of flowers.
DAM square and Royal PalaceThe is really the heart of central Amsterdam and a very touristy area. Depending on your activities and walking paths, youâ€™ll probably walk by this area often. There is also a lot of shopping in the area â€” from everyday to fancy.
Canal Boat TourI did the Friendship Amsterdam tour (recommended by a Resident) and loved it. I was afraid this might be too touristy, but taking a canal boat tour was recommended by a lot of locals. The tour departs from the Red Light District and is a fun way to see the city, canals, and bridges. I even made some new friends on the tour, how appropriate.
Red Light DistrictLocated in the De Wallen neighborhood, this was the only part of the city that felt seedy and unsafe, for obvious reasons. As recommended by locals, donâ€™t go here alone at night.
Shopping StreetsThere are adorable shops all over the city. Some of my favorite streets for shopping include Leidsestraat (smaller shops), Nieuwendijk & Kalverstraat (bigger chain stores on either side of DAM square), Damrak (busy touristy street with a lot of shops and food, near the main train station).
In Amsterdam there are 165 canals and 2500 bridges (!), so itâ€™s safe to say you probably wonâ€™t see them all. However, there are some cute, key canals and bridges in the city center you should check out.
The CanalsThe Canal Ring was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2010 and has four main canals: Singel, Herengracht, Keizersgracht, and Prinsengracht. These 4 canals essentially make a partial concentric U shape. The outer parts felt more local to me and the further into the center I went, the more touristy it felt. There are also what I like to call â€˜mini canalsâ€™ like Leliegracht, Oudezijds Voorburgwal, and Reguliersgracht that connect to the larger ones and are just the cutest. The whole area is quintessentially Amsterdam with beautiful and historically significant Dutch houses, boathouses, bikes, and bridges.
The BridgesLekkeresluis Brug bridge is my favorite and makes for a great photo op. The others on my favorite list include Sint Jansbrug (a footbridge crossing the Oudezijdsvoorburgwal canal), Torensluisbrug (Amsterdamâ€™s original Tower Bridge, and the oldest and widest), Magere Brug (a bridge with a lot of lights, saw on the canal tour), Blauwbrug (a fancy, French-like bridge).
LanguageHallo (hah-loh) â€” HelloAlsjeblieft (ahl-shuh-bleeft) â€” PleaseBedankt (ba-dankt) â€” ThanksDank je (dahnk-yuh) â€” Thank YouDank je wel (dahnk-yuh-vehl) â€” Thank You Very MuchJa (yah) â€” YesNee (nay) â€” NoNee Dank je (nay-dahnk-yuh) â€” No Thank YouDag (dahk) â€” Bye (have a nice day)Doei (doo-ee) â€” Bye (simple bye)Vaarwel (var-vel) â€” Goodbye
TransportationI took a bus to and from the airport right into the city center. A lot of people also take trains to/from the airport. The city transportation is mostly trains/trams, buses, cabs and of course bikes. Other than taking transportation to/from the airport, I walked the entire time â€” not even a cab or car service. I didnâ€™t attempt a bike â€” seemed a bit chaotic. But overall itâ€™s super easy city to navigate no matter your transportation preference.
Money Since The Netherlands is in the EU, their currency is (surprise!) the Euro. I mostly used my credit card (no international fee card) and some euro (probably no more than 10 euro a day). Of course the amount of cash you need depends on your daily budget. I appreciate that the world is using more credit cards, makes traveling to countries with different currencies a lot more seamless.
The X X XYou will see this everywhere. Itâ€™s a symbol of Amsterdam, and not for the risque Red Light District. It actually comes from Amsterdamâ€™s coat of arms. So there you have it.
View and add all Resident Tourism Amsterdam locations to your Google Map here.
Visit residenttourism.com for more travel inspiration. Sign up for our newsletter here to receive inspiration in your inbox.
Safe travels!
--
--

Title: From the City of the Sun to Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hello everyone! My name is Davi, and Iâ€™m a security engineer at Zivver.
Can you believe itâ€™s been about eight months since I made the leap from the sunny shores of Natal, Brazil, to the charming canals of Amsterdam, Netherlands? Time flies when youâ€™re on an adventure!
Iâ€™m here to tell you a little bit about how this move was and give a glance at the past 8 months of my life.
My girlfriend and I always dreamed about living abroad, and Amsterdam was one of our main options. Of course, it was hard to leave a lot behind â€” all the friends and family and everything that we were used to â€” but we always like to look at the glass half full. Especially now when itâ€™s so much easier to call family and friends and also travel to visit each other.
We arrived in Amsterdam during the summer, and it was an amazing start! Very sunny, and the weather is not so different from our home city. Of course, adjusting to life in a new country hasnâ€™t been without its challenges. Navigating the Dutch language, adapting to different customs and traditions, and even just figuring out the best way to get around town has had its moments of frustration. But each challenge has been an opportunity for growth, and Iâ€™ve learned so much, experienced a lot of great moments, and created amazing memories and friendships.
Amsterdam has welcomed me with open arms, and Iâ€™ve fallen head over heels for this beautiful city. From its picturesque streets lined with historic buildings to its diverse and vibrant culture, every day feels like a new adventure waiting to unfold.
Also, we love to travel, and now that we are living in Europe, we can easily travel here and know all the places that we dreamed about.
Moving is challenging, but having a team to support you during this chapter of your life is amazing! From the People teamâ€™s help with everything to get settled until the quick tips and offers to help from everyone on the team during lunches and talks were outstanding. All the Zivvies really cared about me since the first day and how my partner and I were doing.
With a team like this, itâ€™s easier to accomplish things, and speaking for the Security Engineering team, we accomplished a lot these last months. Zivver is a security company, so everyone from all the departments is concerned about security, and they offer amazing support for all the initiatives of our team.
In our team, we have some routine tasks like audits, investigating alerts and new vulnerabilities, and assessing security risks in our products and partners as well. But also, we have a lot of time to build things and improve our processes and tooling. Every 4 months, we plan together what we need to improve, and we plan our main initiatives for that term, and then we get it done!
A little bit more about our team, we are 4 in the Security team: Chris Stanley and I as security engineers, Walter Kovacevic as our security and privacy officer, and Nadine Hoogerwerf as our CISO. We work together a lot and also with different teams inside Zivver. We have a Weekly to discuss some topics and ideas and we have a lot of autonomy and freedom to organize our week and our tasks.
Speaking for the engineering side of our team, Chris and I wear many hats and we need to change them sometimes, which for me is very fun! Sometimes we need to respond to incidents and other times we need to do an internal security assessment where we try to exploit our own applications to find security issues and when we find them, we work with the responsible teams to fix them.
We work with a lot of certifications too, because we are a security company we need to prove to our customers that we are following the best practices in the market. So now and then we need to work together with auditors and gather evidence and this is done within the team depending on the certification we also need support from other teams as well like Infrastructure and internal IT.
This term, for example, we were able to improve our detection and response and also our vulnerability management process efficiency. It was very challenging for us; it involved a lot of new concepts and tools, but in the end, it was totally worth it, and we learned a lot. During this improvement, we even saved about 50% with our security cloud costs and tools.
Besides that we also work on the security culture of Zivver, so we try our best to share our knowledge with our colleagues. In fact, this month we are also starting our security champions program and it is very promising! Weâ€™ll start with the engineering team, and improve their security technical knowledge which is very valuable not only for us as a company but also for them as professionals.
From our 4 key values, the one that sums up the last 8 months for me is Be all in, not only in Zivver but in my life as a whole.
When we talk about being all in, itâ€™s not about working a lot and being busy all the time; here at Zivver, the work-life balance is a must, and you see this example from everyone, since the onboarding, the message was very clear not only from the Peopleâ€™s team but from everyone: â€œGo live and travel! Travel here in Europe is cheaper!â€. Well, the message was received!
Now letâ€™s talk about what Be All In is. Itâ€™s to be engaged and passionate about what you are doing and during your day-to-day. It is about really caring about your teammates and how everyone has cared about me since my first day. Itâ€™s to care about our customers and partners during our day-to-day work and keep them in mind when we are doing something. Itâ€™s about a can-do attitude embracing challenges and learning from them.
And to be a security engineer in Zivver you definitely need to be all in! As I said before, here we need to wear different hats which sometimes can be hard to switch context. Also, the security field can be overwhelming with new vulnerabilities and attack techniques growing and being discovered every day, but together we are rocking it and evolving one step at a time.
As we all know, technology is always changing and we need to keep our minds sharp and learn new things all the time. Here at Zivver, we have a lot of time to study and improve ourselves technically and personally. This work-life-study balance that I have is very important to me because it keeps me happy and effective and allows me to solve problems a lot more efficiently.
Finally, being all in is also knowing what to focus on and prioritize, this way we can focus on what matters because we canâ€™t do everything, and thinking this way itâ€™s easier to achieve the work-life-study balance. Thatâ€™s what be all in is and this is a lesson that Iâ€™ll bring with me for the rest of my life.
As I continue to settle into life here in Amsterdam, Iâ€™m filled with gratitude and happiness for the experiences Iâ€™ve had and the people Iâ€™ve met along the way. From exploring the city and bustling markets to tasting delicious stroopwafels and bitterballen, every day is a reminder of just how lucky I am to have this experience.
And to anyone out there considering taking a leap of faith and embarking on their journey, my advice is simple: go for it. You never know what incredible experiences await you on the other side.
--
--

Title: Amsterdam is not London
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
11
Listen
Share
â€˜How does Amsterdam compare to London, now that youâ€™ve lived there for two years?â€™
Wait, my dad is asking me an open ended question? Instead of offering his unsolicited opinion, heâ€™s curious about mine? I close my laptop, welcoming a discussion. â€˜Itâ€™s very different,â€™ I start enigmatically.
â€˜Really? At least the weather is the same, right.â€™
Here we go again. The true source of my Amsterdam flat deposit: the â‚¬1 I got for every time someone found out that I used to live in London, and told me that at least I didnâ€™t have to get used to the weather.
â€˜No! Itâ€™s not! Itâ€™s worse. Itâ€™s ten times worse. London is just overcast all year round. Amsterdam has this constant wind and rain, and gusts that push you off your bike, and showers that hit you across your faceâ€¦â€™ I sigh, but can I blame my dad, though?
Heâ€™s got a fair assumption. The one I had made before I moved here, together with a bunch of other assumptions I didnâ€™t question. About all the things I had found in London that I was going to find in Amsterdam, too.
Of course I wanted a difference, I wanted a change. Before I moved, I had thought long and hard about all possible aspects in which these two cities would be different. But, as I described before, you canâ€™t expect that a change will bring all the difference you were hoping for, and none that youâ€™ll be disappointed by. You embrace them both and thatâ€™s how you fall in love with a city.
And so, as I boarded a KLM City Hopper for a mere 1 hour flight from one Northern-European capital to another, little did I know about all the things Iâ€™d found in London that I was not going to find in Amsterdam at all. The things I was leaving behind.
Letâ€™s get it out of the way since itâ€™s probably the most contentious opinion: Amsterdam is White. Or rather, itâ€™s racially segregated.
Sure, thereâ€™s about 180 nationalities living in the Amsterdam area and non-Dutch inhabitants are a majority (source). After the Dutch, the biggest population groups come from Morocco, Suriname, Turkey and Indonesia (source). And sure, if you move to Amsterdam â€” or the part that is usually referred to as Amsterdam â€” you will meet people from all over the world. However, this world will include places like Germany, Italy, Spain, South Africa and the USA. To really notice other races other than Caucasian, youâ€™ll need to take a trip to the end of the metro line, like Nieuw West, Bijlmer, or my home, Noord. Although Noord has many faces: my home is actually in the gentrified new built area, the whitest neighbourhood Iâ€™ve lived in since leaving Poland.
I still notice the predominant Whiteness, but barely. It struck me in my first month: looking around in public spaces downtown and spotting just a few People of Colour, usually expats from Asia. I remember the first time we went for team drinks and how it didnâ€™t feel right that in a crowded pub in the centre, everyone looked kind of the same. Now it feels normal.
I blend in with the majority, so the populationâ€™s homogeneity doesnâ€™t bother me, unless I consciously remind myself about it. And thatâ€™s scary.
Only now do I realise the magical freedom of Londonâ€™s racial and ethnic diversity. Not one set of rules on how to look and behave. Everyone stands out, so everyone blends in.
Nowadays, the closest I can get to that experience is to cycle back to the outskirts of Noord, where I used to live with my flatmate to save money for my own place. In the Middle-Eastern shops in Banne Buiksloot I get herbs, chillies, and a reality check.
Dutch people do use spices, which is commendable in a European country. They benefited from colonial culinary influence, just like the Brits. Their own cuisine is unremarkable, barring cheese and bitterballen, just like the British cuisine, barring shortbread and battered fish. For lunch, theyâ€™re satisfied with a broodje kaas, just like the British are fine with a sausage roll. Youâ€™d think Amsterdamâ€™s and Londonâ€™s food scene would be comparable, and yet, London wins big time.
The UK won the culinary game thanks to one contestant: India. India is bigger, older and more diverse than Indonesia and Suriname, and its cuisine is richer. The Brits have proudly adopted Indian curry as one of their national dishes, not different to a Sunday roast and available at every corner. In the Netherlands, on the other hand, people get an Indonesian take-away every now and then, and no tourist comes here to try famous Surinamese restaurants.
India aside, the British colonial past lasted longer and spanned across a larger territory than the Dutch. This means more immigrants, more influence, more variety. More food stores and restaurants, in fact, every imaginable restaurant you may want to try. You donâ€™t get a great selection of non-European restaurants in Amsterdam, and thatâ€™s not just because itâ€™s a smaller city than London. Itâ€™s because itâ€™s a less diverse one. There are a lot of restaurants, theyâ€™re just not that varied: good luck finding something Burmese or Jamaican, for example, but if youâ€™re happy to settle for Italian, youâ€™ve got all the choice in the world. Well, in Italy.
In Amsterdam I cook more. If you want something more exciting than pizza or noodles, you have to pay a lot, which didnâ€™t used to be the case in London. What really rubs me up the wrong way, though, is spending 25 euros on a dish and getting terrible service.
I arrived in Amsterdam just after Covid. Iâ€™ve heard that the pandemic caused a shift in the service industry, not that I had a comparison to how it had been before. In my first months, I went out a lot, trying to get to know the city and people. Initially I thought I was just unlucky. Then I realised Iâ€™d rather learn cooking than go through the same story yet another time:
Waiting 20 minutes to order, after youâ€™ve waved down the waiter like an aircraft marshal;The waiter, who generally not only doesnâ€™t care, but also doesnâ€™t know much, is unsure if they still have the dish, so they disappear for another 10 minutes;Waiting 45 (Iâ€™m not lying) minutes to get your order because all the take-away drivers have priority;Getting a wrong order;Waiting God knows how long to pay, before following the waiter around the restaurant until they Shut Up and Take Your Money.
There are, of course, restaurants with good service, just like in London there are restaurants with bad service. Itâ€™s about what your default expectation should be. In Amsterdam, donâ€™t expect much.
That post-Covid shift in the service industry is said to have driven away cheap immigrant labour, leaving the students as the only available workforce. Other population groups canâ€™t support themselves from service jobs in this expensive city. Not that in London you could easily pay rent while working in hospitality. But you could at least legally share a flat.
The relocation package I got from my company included help in finding a flat from a real estate agent. In my orientation call with Piet, I said that I wanted to spend about 1000 euros for a room. Piet said that for this price I should look for a garage.
(This, by the way, is what happens when Dutch service culture and Dutch directness collide).
I tried explaining that I didnâ€™t need a whole flat for myself, that I wanted to share with another â€œprofessionalâ€, as they call them. Itâ€™s impossible, asserted Piet, after he finally understood what I meant. But now I wasnâ€™t getting it. How was it impossible for employed adults to share a flat? Thatâ€™s what I did for 8 years in London! Nou, ja, shrugged Piet,
(to clarify, neither was it a video call, nor did I know Dutch body language back then, but now I can totally imagine the typical lack-of-empathy Dutch shrug accompanying Pietâ€™s statement:)
Amsterdam is not London.
Indeed, if a landlord in Amsterdam isnâ€™t prejudiced against renting a flat to sharers (which they mostly are), a bigger barrier is the need for a permit.
The whole topic of the flat sharing ban, preference for couples and ubiquitous fake relationships for the sake of a rental contract is so fascinatingly infuriating that I will spare it a separate article. For now, letâ€™s just say that Amsterdamâ€™s progressiveness ends when unrelated, romantically uninvolved adults want to share a flat.
Progressiveness comes in many shapes and Amsterdam claims to have them all. Itâ€™s the capital of the first country to legalise gay marriage. A city where you can use services of self-employed, tax paying, legal sex workers. Where you can enjoy naked saunas, a vibrant queer scene and underground kink raves. But you canâ€™t get tested for an STI.
In Amsterdam, men who have sex with men can get a free test twice a year through an organisation called Man Tot Man. Other than that you have to go through a GP to order a test, and â€” this is what the Netherlands and the UK have in common â€” the healthcare system is designed to discourage frivolous requests of people who arenâ€™t visibly dying, and deny silly things like prevention.
One thing that the Netherlands could learn from puritan Britain is commitment to sexual health. The clinics in London, which are free and donâ€™t even ask for your insurance, offer all kinds of contraception, testing and consultations. You can walk in, but you can also order an STI test online, do it at home and send back by free post. If you havenâ€™t tested for more than a few months, the system will send you a text message to encourage a check-in.
The London system sounds impressive, even utopian. Itâ€™s easy to forget that it should be a standard in a big city which claims the sex-positive, progressive label.
I might have assumed that Amsterdam was going to be as international, vibrant and progressive as London, and as a result, I might have assumed that cultural activities would be the same, too. Theyâ€™re not. This is not due to Amsterdam being smaller or more boring. Itâ€™s because it has a dominant culture: the Dutch culture. The culture expressed by a language which about a quarter of Amsterdamâ€™s residents prefer not to speak, to no fault but their own. (Something I mentioned in this and this article).
If you donâ€™t need the language for work or social life, youâ€™re not going to learn it to go to the theatre. But what happens in the meantime is that you donâ€™t go to the theatre at all.
There is a good English-speaking cultural program in Amsterdam. Iâ€™d assumed there would be and hands down, there is. But it is a minority, and that makes a difference. If you choose not to learn the language, you narrow yourself to the English-speaking material, which is produced with a typical expat in mind. But then again, if you donâ€™t choose to learn the language but have the time and money to go to the theatre, maybe you are a typical expat.
You choose not to learn the language because you donâ€™t need it for your job, and before you know it, itâ€™s harder for you to switch jobs, because you havenâ€™t learned the language. Would Dutch-speaking jobs interest you anyway? If you worked in a metropolis like London, youâ€™re used to a dynamic job market, with top-tier multinationals, hot start-ups and everything in between. Of course, you wonâ€™t have that in a smaller city where English isnâ€™t the official language.
Itâ€™s not rocket science, yet I didnâ€™t think that through. Like many people who have spent a few tiring years in a huge city, I was fixated on the â€œquality of lifeâ€ and didnâ€™t investigate what this move could do to my career in the long run. Now that my company announced possible layoffs, I realise that what suits me in Amsterdam is just a handful of jobs: the expat jobs.
Expat is a word I learned when I came to Amsterdam (and described that process here). Earlier, I was first an immigrant, then a Londoner. Just anyone that lives in London, wherever theyâ€™re from, whatever their background. Hardly anyone comes from London, and if they do, all it takes for them to leave their roots behind is to change districts. A friend of mine is from Germany and his wife is from France. They decided to buy a flat and start a family in London, rather than come back to one of their countries of origin, which many couples in their situation would do.
â€˜London is the only place where I feel like Iâ€™m not just visitingâ€™, said my friend before I left. â€˜Youâ€™ve made London your city. Bear in mind that when you leave, you will be a visitor again, in Amsterdam and in London.â€™
A lot depends on your choices and values (I used dating to exemplify this in my last 2 articles). You can be a settler: aim to â€œget naturalisedâ€ by learning the language, the culture, the local people. Tie your future to the place. Or, you can be a nomad and â€œsee how it goesâ€.
It may just be my perception, but in Amsterdam that second group stands out to me more. There is a transient feeling to the international crowd in the Netherlands, which can be tied to a very tangible reason, namely a policy. A lot of people come here with a five year plan. Theyâ€™ll stay as long as they can benefit from the countryâ€™s tax break, the Thirty Percent Ruling.
Of course, I knew about the ruling before moving here, but I didnâ€™t anticipate its significance both to expatsâ€™ individual choices, and Dutch peopleâ€™s popular opinion. Far from being a formality, this policy is a multi-layered subject that I want to cover next time.
These are the categories I run through to answer my dadâ€™s question (barring the sexual health clinics. It didnâ€™t seem relevant).
â€˜Thereâ€™s no way of saying which city is better. It depends on the period of life you find yourself in and your priorities,â€™ I concluded. But I could tell that my dad didnâ€™t want a research paper, he wanted an opinion. A verdict. For that, he resorted back to a â€œyes or noâ€:
â€˜But do you like Amsterdam?â€™
â€˜Thatâ€™s a whole different question! I love it.â€™
â€˜You shouldâ€™ve started off with that.â€™
Again, heâ€™s got a point. But if I just say that Amsterdam is a great city, Iâ€™d miss all the rich details that I fell in love with, including the ones Iâ€™m disappointed by.
--
--
11
A cultural anthropologist looking at Amsterdam and London

Title: A Trippy Tale: Four Days in Amsterdam with Truffles, Museums, and Questionable Choices
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When my wife and I decided to spend four days in Amsterdam, we had no idea we were signing up for a whirlwind of art, history, culinary delights â€” and the most hilariously weird truffle-induced adventure of our lives. Buckle up, dear reader. This is a tale of laughter, paranoia, and stencils.
We landed early, bright-eyed and full of ambition. First stop? The Rijksmuseum, where we pretended to be art enthusiasts while secretly just looking for a cafÃ© to fuel up. After a marathon walk through Dutch masterpieces, we checked into our hotel, Citiez. A quick nap later, we were ready for our nighttime mission: investigating the mystical â€œmagic mushrooms.â€
Turns out, there are no mushrooms involved â€” just truffles packed with psilocybin. The folks at the Magic Mushroom Gallery were incredibly informative, guiding us like sherpas into the psychedelic unknown. We selected our strains like wine connoisseurs: Atlantis for me, Golden Teachers for my wife. The instructions were clear: eat after breakfast, avoid acidic drinks, and prepare for an â€œenhancedâ€ experience. Challenge accepted.
Our second day was a deep dive into history at the Anne Frank Museum. The atmosphere was poignant, the stories heartbreaking, and the experience humbling. By nightfall, we had a serious discussion: tomorrow was the big day. We laid out our plans like we were preparing for a moon landing.
The day began innocently enough with a hearty breakfast, because apparently truffles and empty stomachs donâ€™t mix. We set off for Zaanse Schans, home to picturesque windmills, endless green fields, and, unbeknownst to us, our impending adventure into trippy absurdity.
The truffles? Surprisingly un-mushroomy. We paired them with chocolate as instructed and waited. And waited. For an hour, nothing happened. Were we scammed? Was this just overpriced trail mix? My wife and I were starting to draft a mental Yelp review when suddenly, she started giggling.
And then it hit us.
We became the embodiment of joy, laughing at everything: the grass, the birds, even the windmills seemed to be winking at us. We found a bench and plopped down, marveling at the universe like two philosophers whoâ€™d skipped the study and gone straight to enlightenment.
As we sat there, the rhythmic movement of ducksâ€™ necks caught my attention. They bobbed gracefully, picking food off the ground, and it was, in that moment, the most profound thing Iâ€™d ever seen. â€œLook at them,â€ I said, barely holding back laughter. â€œSo synchronized. Like natureâ€™s backup dancers.â€ Surprisingly she was also looking at the same thing. Lol.
Then my wife dropped a spiritual bomb. â€œYou know,â€ she said, staring into the distance, â€œhuman existence isâ€¦ so small. Look at us â€” tiny, tiny things compared to everything else.â€ She waved her hand in a sweeping gesture, possibly at the universe, possibly at the ducks. â€œItâ€™s like weâ€™re just little dotsâ€¦ floating in a cosmic something.â€ Also, I remember she mentioned, we are so small that we donâ€™t exist as well. â€œWe are not there!â€
I nodded sagely, pretending to understand, though I was mostly thinking about how small we are. People walking by gave us curious looks, probably wondering if we were okay. We werenâ€™t. But we were happy. When my wife followed up her cosmic realization with â€œDo we look weird?â€ between uncontrollable giggles, I lied through my teeth: â€œNo, weâ€™re fine.â€
Spoiler: we werenâ€™t fine. It was definitely time to relocate.
Inside the Zaans Museum, things gotâ€¦ creative. There was a stencil activity for visitors, which we attacked with the fervor of Picasso on a sugar rush. Never had stenciling felt so profound. We spent ages there, convinced our art could rival the Rijksmuseum collection.
Then came the binoculars. Who knew you could laugh hysterically while looking at a windmill through magnification? My wife declared it a portal to another world. I believed her.
At one point, a receptionist appeared, and paranoia kicked in. Sheâ€™s watching us, we thought. Why is she here? We imagined her radioing the Truffle Patrol to haul us out. Naturally, we did what any reasonable people would do: fled to next section of museum, the Verkede Experiece: biscuit factory exhibit.
But there she (the receptionist) was again! Or was it? We couldnâ€™t decide. It felt like a Scooby-Doo episode where the villain keeps showing up wherever you run. We bolted for the bus stop, laughing all the way.
Mid-museum session, my wife entered her spiritual guru era. Staring (maybe) deeply at a random art piece (probably a windmill blueprint), she turned to me with the wisdom of a thousand lifetimes and declared, â€œYou know, everyoneâ€™s perspective is different. What I see might not be what you see. What I think might not be what you think. But when perspectives align, thatâ€™s when true connection happens.â€
She said it so profoundly, I half-expected a beam of light to shine down, followed by monks chanting in the background. I nodded sagely, as if her words had unlocked the mysteries of the universe, while secretly wondering if sheâ€™d start charging other museum visitors for enlightenment sessions or may be a ted talk.
Back in Amsterdam central, the streets became a kaleidoscope of lights and laughter. We stumbled into an Argentine restaurant and ordered grilled prawns and salmon, which tasted like the food of gods. Fueled by our meal, we wandered into the Moco Museum. Modern art on truffles? Chefâ€™s kiss. Every piece seemed alive, whispering existential secrets and bad jokes.
We capped the night watching locals ice skate, marveling at their skills and wondering if skating while tripping would be genius or disastrous. Spoiler: we didnâ€™t try.
Our last day started strong with a hearty hotel breakfast. We checked out, feeling accomplished, and boarded a canal cruise. Big mistake.
While Amsterdamâ€™s canals are beautiful, sitting on a crowded slow-moving boat was the antithesis of the adventurous spirit weâ€™d cultivated. We spent the entire ride critiquing ourselves for this bad choice, trying to find amusement in the audio guideâ€™s monotone narration and our own sarcastic commentary.
Luckily, the day was redeemed by an amazing Chinese meal and an early arrival at Schiphol Airport, where we reminisced about the past four days of art, history, and hilarity.
Amsterdam gave us more than we could have asked for. From the solemn history of Anne Frankâ€™s house to the surreal hilarity of truffles at Zaanse Schans, it was a trip filled with unforgettable experiences.
Moral of the story? Life is better with laughter, adventure, and maybe just a little bit of psilocybin. Just donâ€™t let the receptionist catch you.
Thanks for reading! Cheers!
--
--

Title: 2 hours of Take In and Let Go in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Our luggage and other heavy things have all been stashed in an L-size locker at Amsterdam Centraal. Sweet! Aww, my inner child jolted as soon as we exited Amsterdam Centraal. At the same time, my eyes caught a lady skipping happily toward someone who seemed to be waiting for her. A display of simple human happiness. I thought momentarily, â€˜Wow, there are so many people here!â€™ It seems the weekend atmosphere had contributed to the crowd. And that crowd! This sight quickly reminded me how â€˜internationalâ€™ this city â€” or country â€” is.
Stepping out of the square, the tram rails are lined right up next to the road. The way they weave together looks a bit messy on the asphalt. Iâ€™ve seen similar setups in other places, but I still find it a bit tricky to wrap my head around all these different modes of transportation crammed together. I prefer things to be a little plainer.
To cross the road, I found myself a bit disoriented at first; I wasnâ€™t sure if there was a designated area for crossing. Later that day, Bu Jeannie used the phrase â€˜Indonesian way.â€™ Sekar and I, after observing the traffic situation, also mentioned it and joked about doing it the â€˜Indo way.â€™
Weâ€™ve got Google Maps in hand. We try to be wise with our batteries. We want to use Sekarâ€™s phone for navigation and my phone for taking pictures. The direction is facing the city: headingâ€¦

Title: Visiting Amsterdam and Riding a Bike When You Havenâ€™t Ridden Since Childhood
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
(This story can also be found on my personal blog site www.eatbikeexplore.com)
Amsterdam is often known as the bicycle capital of the world. If you are an advocate of active transportation, there are some YouTubers and bloggers praising Amsterdam for their bike friendliness. BicycleDutch and NotJustBikes come to mind. However, if you are visiting Amsterdam and wanting to ride a bike but havenâ€™t since childhood, I can imagine it can be intimidating. I donâ€™t blame people from North America traveling to Amsterdam and being fearful of riding a bike. If you normally donâ€™t ride, itâ€™s a difficult adjustment. My guess is if you are visiting Amsterdam from North America, you MIGHT hop on a bike for an afternoon as a novelty, but then go back to what you are comfortable with. Most people from North America drive. And most people from other parts of the world probably do not have the bicycling culture like the Dutch or Danish. Itâ€™s like if youâ€™re not used to taking public transit in your home country, you might shy away from taking public transit when you travel. Youâ€™ll opt for the Hop On Hop Off buses, using ride share or joining a tour group. All are fine, but I would say you are missing out on a uniquely Dutch experience by not taking a bike to get you around townâ€¦and riding it as often as possible.
So what is it like riding a bike in Amsterdam? Here are some tips from my experience for visiting Amsterdam and riding a bike if you havenâ€™t ridden since childhood. If you are used to riding consistently as an adult, especially if your bike is your transportation, then you shouldnâ€™t have a problem riding in Amsterdam. The learning curve shouldnâ€™t be too steep.
Otherwise, you will probably be â€œthatâ€ tourist that doesnâ€™t know the rules of riding. Thereâ€™s plenty of websites that go more into detail on the rules of riding. Iâ€™m not going to get that detailed. Instead, I will touch on some basics of what it must feel like riding if you havenâ€™t ridden a bike since forever.
If you are â€œthatâ€ tourist and want to get on a bike, then here are some of my suggestions for â€œpeople who normally donâ€™t ride a bike but want to in Amsterdamâ€.
First, get away from the city center, especially if you are visiting during the summer months where tourism is at its peak. It can get packed with people on bikes, on foot, cars and tour buses. The center of the city also seems to have less separated bike paths, so youâ€™re riding close to other drivers. Thereâ€™s also vans parked in the bike lanes, so youâ€™ll need to navigate around them by safely moving around other riders and drivers. Plus, youâ€™ll want to be careful crossing the tram tracks as bicycle tires can get caught in it and you will fall.
Find a hotel, hostel, Airbnb, etc outside of the city center that also rents bikes. You donâ€™t have to go too far out but just far enough for you to practice. When I went there, I stayed near Vondel Park. My place rented bikes which was convenient and Vondel Park is a great place to practice riding around.
In the US (and I assume itâ€™s similar in other countries), I notice beginner riders tend to weave around a lot and often ride really slow. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with that, but if you want to ride on the bike paths in Amsterdam, youâ€™ll need to practice not weaving around so much and to ride faster. Basically, if you wouldnâ€™t drive your car weaving from lane to lane, then you shouldnâ€™t do that on a bike. Anyways, Vondel Park would be a good place to reintroduce yourself to the bike. Lots of people ride through here to get to their destination so youâ€™ll see lots of riders. But the paths are wide enough for the locals to go around you as youâ€™re starting off.
My biggest advice to those wanting to hop on a bike for the first time is donâ€™t just randomly stop in middle of a bike path because you saw this cool cafe or bar or some interesting mural. Please pull off to the side of the bike path so you donâ€™t block anybody or cause a crash. There is a 100% chance someone is riding right behind you. And just like driving, you donâ€™t just stop in the middle of the road because you saw something cool off to the side. So donâ€™t do that on a bike either.
My next advice is to use hand signals and turn your head to make sure itâ€™s clear before you decide to turn, stop or slow down. Watch how the locals use hand signals. But all you need to do is slightly bend your right arm outwards to show you are turning right and slightly bend your left arm outwards to show you are turning left.
Thereâ€™s no need to extend your entire arm out when you need to turn. By doing that, youâ€™ll most likely smack someone riding next to you. This of course goes back to turning your head so you know who is around you.
Once you get comfortable riding around in the park, you can move onto neighborhood streets and separated bike paths outside of the city center.
Amsterdam has lots of bicycle signals, so make sure you pay attention to the signals.
Intersections can also be tricky because youâ€™ll need to know when to yield and when not to yield. Pay attention to the â€œshark teethâ€ symbols on the ground.
The good thing about being on a bike is even if you are uncertain on what to do, everybody can still move around each other and usually not cause a crash. People can usually read your body language on a bike and youâ€™ll be able to do the same the more your ride.
Itâ€™s not like being in a car, where you are unable to see the person driving. In a car, you canâ€™t predict what the people next to you will do. But itâ€™s easier on a bike because you can see the entire person.
One thing I also noticed is that drivers and cyclists will look for any open space to squeeze in (which to me is a bit reminiscent of NYC). There were a couple of drivers that came rather close to me in the city center. I noticed two types of license plates in Amsterdam. The yellow and the blue plates. I had a close pass with a blue license plate driver. I later overheard those are the taxi and delivery drivers? So I guess it makes sense they are more aggressive (even though they shouldnâ€™t be)?
And you know that saying â€œpractice makes perfectâ€? The more you ride, the more youâ€™ll get the hang of how things are done. And riding a bike in Amsterdam is absolutely amazing! Itâ€™s just not something you can experience in the US. Bikes really provide the freedom that cars do not (despite car ads from the last 100 years proclaiming driving is freedom). You donâ€™t need a helmet when riding, so you truly can feel the â€œwind in your hairâ€.
And one final tips. Remember where you parked your bike. Take a photo or video of where you parked and the surrounding area. A lot of bikes look similar and they are often jammed together.
And once you get the hang of this, you can ride to grab coffee or a beer. Ride to a park or museum. Youâ€™ll soon discover how easy it is to navigate the city by bike. And how many more places you can see without having to pay for the tram, Uber or follow a guided tour. With a bike, you can have the freedom to explore local neighborhoods, cafes and restaurants that might not be in a guide book.
I canâ€™t wait to go back and ride again and I hope if youâ€™re reading this and planning a trip there, you will want to ride as much as possible while you are there.
--
--
Iâ€™m usually walking, biking or on public transit exploring locally and globally.

Title: Hallo Amsterdam!
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--

I idly watched tiny droplets of moisture licking at the planeâ€™s wings as cotton wool clouds and sparkling sunbeams made way for a sea of green and grey, followed by a seemingly-endless taxi along the runway. Almost as soon as Iâ€™d left the UK, I was in Amsterdam for a springtime mini break. The grey skies above did nothing to dull my spirit as I muddled through the train system and took a final, deep breath of city air. Thatâ€™s right. After a pretty hefty hiatus from Medium, Iâ€™m back â€” and accompanied by tales from a small European country known as The Netherlands in April 2025.
As I left the station, I was hit instantly with the lingering aroma of marijuana, coupled with street music and a relentless stream of bicycles. Weaving through tiny streets, the constant bang bang bang of my suitcase wheels on the cobbles grew more comforting than annoying. Finally, after a few wrong turns, I could see the sign for my hostel just up ahead.
I had a little time to kill and so resolved to head out on foot. I ended up down a major shopping street, but resisted the urge to pop into the large Primark. Scatteredâ€¦

Title: How I Worked and Played in Amsterdam: A Travel Diary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We curate & disseminate outstanding stories from diverse domains to create synergy. Inquiries: https://digitalmehmet.com/ Subscribe to our content marketing strategy: https://drmehmetyildiz.substack.com/

--
6
Listen
Share
Have you ever imagined immersing yourself in one of the worldâ€™s most dynamic and thrilling cities, all while advancing your career? This is the story of my remarkable journey.
As a young software engineer employed at a reputable multinational company in India, the opportunity to embark on a two-month onsite assignment in Amsterdam was nothing short of a dream come true. The mere thought of exploring Europe had always danced at the periphery of my aspirations, yet, as someone from India, such an adventure often felt distant and financially out of reach.
But I persevered, putting in the hard work and dedication necessary to secure this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Finally, the moment had arrived when I could set foot in Amsterdam, and I was filled with boundless gratitude for having reached this significant milestone. Now, let me share with you the captivating journey that unfolded, as I discovered the cityâ€™s perfect blend of work and play, and why it has become a place Iâ€™ll cherish forever.
One electrifying week before the grand adventure, I embarked on a whirlwind of preparations. With a fresh haircut and meticulous grooming, I was ready to step into the unknown. The day of departure finally dawned, and my parents joined me for a heartwarming farewell at the airport. The excitement in the air was palpable as I embarked on a journey I had been eagerly awaiting.
The flight seemed to stretch on, but the moment we touched down at Amsterdam Schiphol Airport, I was immediately captivated by the cityâ€™s breathtaking beauty. The sight was a feast for the senses, a stunning welcome to this new chapter in my life. My heart raced with anticipation as I hopped into a sleek Tesla taxi. The streets were teeming with high-end cars, and the buzz around Tesla was infectious. Riding in one was nothing short of a thrilling adventure, marking the exhilarating start of my Amsterdam odyssey.
I arrived at my home around 5 p.m., and it was already dark outside. I had never experienced this in India, where the sun sets much later. My friend and I were so excited to be in Amsterdam that we decided to make dinner and go to bed early so that we could wake up early the next morning and start exploring.
I was nervous on my first day at the office in Amsterdam. I had never been to the city before. But as soon as I walked in, I was greeted by warm smiles from my new colleagues and clients.
My Indian colleagues introduced me to everyone, including my Dutch clients. I was immediately struck by how friendly and welcoming everyone was. My client even asked me about my journey to Amsterdam and how I was settling in.
At lunchtime, I went out with my senior colleagues, we had a delicious meal together. We talked about everything from what we needed to settle in, to the Dutch culture, and some places to travel. I felt so comfortable and at ease.
By the end of the day, I had made a lot of new friends in the office and learned a lot about the company and the city. I was so grateful for the warm welcome I had received.
Through the days, I effortlessly adapted to the Amsterdam culture and people, and I also explored the cityâ€™s many attractions. I was captivated by Amsterdamâ€™s distinctive beauty. My personal experience revealed five compelling reasons why Amsterdam stands out as an exceptional destination for both work and leisure:
Canals that Captivate: Amsterdamâ€™s intricate network of canals is a sight to behold, earning it the nickname â€œVenice of the North.â€ The reflection of gabled houses in the still waters, along with charming bridges and tree-lined streets, creates a picturesque scene that is reminiscent of a fairytale. For example, the Prinsengracht Canal is home to many beautiful 17th-century houses, while the Keizersgracht Canal is known for its elegant mansions. The canals are also a great place to spot boats and people-watch.
Historical Charm: Amsterdamâ€™s well-preserved architecture stands as a testament to its rich history. As you stroll through the city, youâ€™ll encounter stunning 17th-century buildings, each with its own unique character and story, offering a glimpse into the cityâ€™s past. For example, the Anne Frank House is a poignant reminder of the cityâ€™s role in World War II, while the Royal Palace is a magnificent example of Dutch Baroque architecture. The cityâ€™s canals are also lined with historic buildings, such as the gabled houses of the Jordaan neighborhood.
Cultural Diversity: The city is a melting pot of cultures, and this diversity is reflected in its art, food, and people. From world-class museums like the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum to vibrant neighborhoods like De Pijp, thereâ€™s a cultural richness that adds to the cityâ€™s allure.
Laid-back atmosphere: Amsterdam has a relaxed and easy-going atmosphere. I appreciated the friendly demeanor of the locals, as it was quite common for strangers to exchange warm greetings with smiles. In all my travels to various countries, I had never witnessed such a welcoming attitude towards strangers.
Diverse workforce: Amsterdam has a diverse workforce, with people from all over the world living and working in the city. This diversity makes for a vibrant and exciting work environment.
Bicycle-Friendly Bliss: Amsterdamâ€™s flat terrain and extensive network of cycling lanes make it a cyclistâ€™s paradise. The sight of countless bicycles whizzing past historic sites, parks, and picturesque canals is not only beautiful, but it is also an embodiment of the cityâ€™s eco-friendly ethos. Conveniently, there are bicycle pumps attached to some bicycle areas for filling tires.
Amsterdam is a foodieâ€™s paradise, with a wide variety of restaurants and dishes to choose from, whether youâ€™re looking for a quick bite or a leisurely meal. I sampled some of the cityâ€™s most famous dishes, including:
Poffertjes: Small pancakes often served with powdered sugar, fruit, or syrup.Stroopwafels: Thin waffles filled with sweet syrup.Stamppot: Traditional Dutch mashed potatoes with vegetablesErwtensoep: Popular Dutch pea soup, also available in vegetarian versions.
My love for the delicious waffles was only surpassed by my visit to Zaanse Schans, Amsterdamâ€™s old town, where I sampled a variety of delectable cheeseses. I promise you, they were incredibly tasty!
My two months in Amsterdam were an unforgettable experience. I had the opportunity to work on a challenging project, meet new people from all over the world, and explore a beautiful and vibrant city. I also had the chance to travel to other parts of Europe, which was a dream come true.
Iâ€™m so grateful for the opportunity I had to live and work in Amsterdam. It was an experience that has changed me for the better. I made lifelong friends, learned new things, and created memories that will last a lifetime.
When it was time to leave, I was sad to say goodbye to my new friends and the city I had come to love. But I know that I will return one day. Amsterdam has a special place in my heart, and I canâ€™t wait to go back and explore more.
Vincent van Gogh once said, â€˜Amsterdam is a city of dreams, and I am a dreamer.â€™
I couldnâ€™t agree more. Amsterdam is a city that inspires creativity and imagination. Itâ€™s a city where anything is possible. If youâ€™re looking for a city that will challenge and inspire you, Amsterdam is the place for you.
I hope that this blog post has given you a glimpse into my experience in Amsterdam. If youâ€™re ever thinking about visiting this amazing city, I highly recommend it!
ğŸ“šThank you for reading! If you enjoyed my stories, consider following me and giving this post a â€˜ğŸ‘â€™ to show your support. Your engagement and comments inspire me to keep sharing more stories with you
--
--

Title: Amsterdam Unfiltered: A Weekend of Unexpected Adventures
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The Dutch have the philosophy, â€˜If what you are doing is not harming anyone but you, then what is the problem?â€™
We got to Amsterdam on Thursday and checked into Clink Hostels, and right away it felt like we were walking onto a college campus. The lobby was live â€” people from all around the world were playing games, talking, listening to live music, and getting us ready for the weekend. We put down our bags and headed into town. Like other college students, our first stop was the Red Light District. As we walked along the canals, we were amazed at what we witnessed. We were not used to this in the United States. Having taken it all in, we stopped for some fries at a local diner and headed home for the night.
Friday morning, we ferried over the water for breakfast and sampled a stroopwafel â€” a famous thin waffle with caramel in the middle. They were so good we ended up buying the whole pack to take back home to the US. We strolled the streets a little more and got ready for our next adventure, a canal tour.
Imagine 24 of us crammed on a boat with an open bar â€” it was fun, to say the least. The vibe was great, we rode down the canal in great company. The music was loud, so we traded the risk of seasickness for dancing. It was worth it. The city itself became a background of ancient buildings and bridges, but the thing that defined the moment was the music. The way I see it is in this culture, you kind of just go with the flow. You never know what to expect, just like the music.
We grabbed dinner after the tour at Ciao Bella, a local pizza place that was ideal for the night ahead of us. We headed to Escape, one of the largest clubs in the city, and abruptly, we were immersed in Amsterdamâ€™s nightlife. We stood up front row to the DJ and took it all in. It was normal music that you would hear at a club, but something was different. The crowd was a lot more into it, and everybody was feeling the music. The DJ stood there leading the crowd, feeding off the crazy energy coming from them. I could finally see why Amsterdam was renowned as such a party city. Somewhere along the early morning, we ended up at a McDonaldâ€™s. And I have to say â€” Amsterdamâ€™s McDonaldâ€™s? Better than Barcelonaâ€™s. It did the trick before we finally crashed for the night.
Saturday, we woke up and discovered we had the day to ourselves. We walked around and ended up in Amsterdamâ€™s center. We took pictures of the national monument and learned about its history. After a few more hours of touring, we found a bar that caught our eye. The bartenders werenâ€™t regular bartenders â€” they were entertainers. They were singing along to every song at the top of their lungs. The first song that came on that I will never forget was â€œGetting Away with Itâ€ by James. And for some reason, it felt completely appropriate. Amsterdam is a city of challenging norms, living in the moment, and doing the unexpected. Inside this bar was the perfect atmosphere to witness the city in person.
The day turned into another night, and we were back in the district at the Red Light Bar, a staple hangout where we played pool and watched some Premier League soccer. People continued to pile in until finally, it was too packed. We bar-toured up the strip, each with its own interpretation of Amsterdamâ€™s style. Some blasted classic rock, while others played house music, but each one of them told a story.
By the end of the trip, we were ready to go. We realized that a weekend in Amsterdam was just right â€” no longer. The city was crazy and awesome at the same time. From the sound of a club to the ring of a bar song, to the energy on the canal, every sound in this city served a purpose. Overall, Amsterdam exceeded our expectations and gave us a weekend to remember.
If you enjoyed this adventure, make sure to follow me for more! Iâ€™ll be sharing another exciting destination next week, so stay tuned â€” you wonâ€™t want to miss it. Thanks for reading, and see you in the next blog!
--
--
Exploring the world through music while studying abroad in Barcelona. Sharing stories on how different cultures express themselves through sound.

Title: Best things to do in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
happy, unique, goofy
1 week (or forever if you can)
Wow! I honestly love Amsterdam so much! The people seem so at ease with life and It is a very liberal spiritual place. Everyone is very open minded and accepting of anyone.
Amsterdam is mainly Dutch people so a lot of the people are very tall and blond. Another thing to consider is prostitution, weed, and psychedelics such as truffles are legal despite this everyone seems incredibly responsible and people seem to keep a good balance of life in Amsterdam. It really is the happiest and most open minded place Iâ€™ve been to so far and thatâ€™s why it is my favorite place so far.
Right from Amsterdam Central you can take a free ferry that will take you to NDSM and it takes about 5â€“10 mins to get there and the Ferry comes constantly I honestly felt like I never had to wait for one. NDSM is a hip urban area with lots of cool graffiti and hip restaurants to check out. Not to mention the interesting places you can stay at like the Crane hotel oh and you can also bungee jump from it, if you decide to. The area also has lots of special events such a music festivals, flea markets, and movie nights. Its a great place to check out and Its not too crowded so itâ€™s nice getting away from all the people in the main area.
This may be one of my favorite museum trips that I have gone on so far. I really liked that it focused on one artist throughout, and I felt like I really got to see Van Goghâ€™s life and how it affected his art. I have to say I am a HUGE Van Gogh fan, I really love his brush strokes and his bright use of color. I felt like I got pulled into every single painting diving into each brush stroke and seeing the lines up close then pulling back to see the full picture that he created. I donâ€™t know how he did it but he made each scene look so serene and stylized.
I need to also mention the sensory room where each room you get the senses that Van Gogh was feeling throughout his life. I thought it was so creative because I truly felt like I was living and seeing the things that Van Gogh felt.
I mean you honestly canâ€™t go to Amsterdam without going to the Red Light District at least once. Walking through the red light district you canâ€™t take any photos. You basically see women in windows with red lights above them in their underwear standing or sitting, and they kind of look bored or like their busy looking at their phone. It was an interesting experience but one to definitely check out and experience once.
One of the most unforgettable experiences I have had so far, Aâ€™dam lookout is where you go on the top of one of the buildings and there are these 2 electric swings that basically swing you back and fourth for about 2 mins. It was seriously such a magical feeling I honestly felt like I was on top of the world and flying for a second. I will admit it was really scary because you are so high up and you look down and donâ€™t see anything right under you but it is one of the things that you canâ€™t really forget because you just feel so much.
The canal tour is so worth it, you basically just go down the canals throughout the city, it is so fun to see all the little boat houses right on the canals.
I personally really liked the Mocco museum because it had more urban graffiti artists such Banksy, icy & slot, Koons and Warhol. They also had a 3D installation room where you walk into a room in the style of Lichtenstein (which is the bright comic book style with bold colors and lines throughout). The museum is not that big but I kind of like that, your not overwhelmed by all of the art and you can engage in each and every one. Each piece had a strong statement about freedom and freedom of expression.
I checked out multiple psychedelic shops (there were many) and these 2 stood out the most to me.
Kokopelli was very informal and the staff really knew their stuff and loved to talk about it, they sold lots of other interesting things such as Brazilian herbs to help with lucid dreaming. Or seeds that you can grow and eat for different types of needs. They even had an area where you can sit and take your shrooms if you decide to buy it from them.
Alien Visitors s a fun small raver type of shop, with techno music playing and neon fluorescent items throughout the store. I ended up buying a really cute black shirt with some green neon print designs down the middle. It wasnâ€™t too crazy with the designs like how some raver shirts can get a little tacky when its overplayed and I really love the pattern on it.
--
--
My goal is to share my journey, experiences and designs with you. I try to bring in a unique perspective into everything I see.

Title: Hereâ€™s why I chose Amsterdam over Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Today marks five years since I moved from my country to Europe, gradually settling into the vibrant life of Amsterdam. This year is my second year in the Netherlands and five years in Europe overall. This milestone feels like the right moment to reflect on the journey so far. Iâ€™m grateful for the personal and professional growth along the way â€” itâ€™s been quite a journey. I first landed in Berlin, but soon after, COVID hit, and finding a job was a real challenge during that time. After gaining experience living in Berlin, I wanted to see if there was a better place before fully committing to Germany, so I decided to look for opportunities outside of Berlin. Eventually, I found a job in Amsterdam. As things slowly started to recover, the war began, adding another layer to the experience.
My connection with Berlin runs deep. Iâ€™ve had a long relationship with the city since my early 20s, when a few of my friends moved there from St. Petersburg and helped me explore Berlin from within. The city quickly became a familiar and vibrant part of my life, with friends and unforgettable experiences. I met my boyfriend just before moving there myself (now my husband) which made the transition even more meaningful. Berlin was more than just a place to live! :) It felt like a second home. Being there was a dream come true in a natural and seamless way.
Our move to Amsterdam was driven by curiosity and a sense of uncertainty about our future in Germany. It takes a lot of effort to fully integrate there and to acknowledge the challenges of living in Germany. Here in the Netherlands, Iâ€™ve found a country that values directness, innovation, out-of-the-box thinking, and problem-solving â€” a motivating environment that has enabled me to grow both professionally and personally.
Sometimes, I feel like a character in Atlas Shrugged, navigating a landscape that mirrors Germany today â€” a system entangled in endless layers of rules, bureaucracy, reluctance to change, and a fear of moving forward that places increasing demands on companies. Germany feels like a perfect analogy to the world described in the book, where innovation is stifled by rigid structures and a lack of forward thinking. In contrast, the Netherlands represents a refreshing example of how things should operate, with efficiency, innovation, and a practical approach to problem-solving that brings real results.
Having spent years in the digital industry, focusing on process optimization, self-service, and enhancing customer experience, Iâ€™ve developed a unique perspective on understanding challenges and identifying opportunities. The Dutch approach to digital transformation, with its emphasis on innovation and efficient governance, aligns closely with my values in creating effective systems and customer-centric solutions. This kind of forward-thinking approach isnâ€™t something I found at a national level in Germany. I know many entrepreneurial people working hard to drive change, but Germany requires significant structural shifts to address the crises ahead. Neglecting change and innovation will make it increasingly difficult to overcome these challenges.
My journey began in Berlin, where I experienced Germanyâ€™s intense focus on rules, processes, and seemingly endless layers of bureaucracy. In Amsterdam, I discovered a dynamic, flexible mindset, where people think outside the box â€” and, most importantly, where people, companies, and even bureaucracies focus on solving problems, not creating more. Both countries have their strengths, yet the Netherlandsâ€™ agility and commitment to achieving real outcomes â€” not just outputs â€” have made me fall in love with the country and see hope for Europeâ€™s future.
As I look back on these five years, Iâ€™m excited about what lies ahead. Amsterdam has become more than just a place to live! Itâ€™s a community that drives my curiosity and keeps me moving forward. I look forward to continuing this journey, bringing fresh perspectives to the digital industry, and helping to solve the challenges that await us all in Europe.
