Title: Fun Facts and Must Do Things in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Stories about surviving on Earth.

--
Listen
Share
I recently traveled to Amsterdam and cannot wait to share my experience with you. It has so much to offer and is one of my favorite cities. Since this is the perfect time to visit Amsterdam, I am sharing with you the must do things in Amsterdam and as well as some interesting facts about the lively city.
Did you know?1) Amsterdam derived its name from the Amstel River.2) There are 165 Amsterdam canals that combine for a length of over 100 kilometers. The Canal Ring became part of the UNESCO World Heritage list in 2010.3) Amsterdam has more bridges than Venice. How difficult is that to believe? But there are only, in fact, 409 bridges connecting Veniceâ€™s canals. Amsterdam actually has 1,281 bridges, three times as many as Venice!4) There are approximately 2,500 houseboats in Amsterdam.5) The tilted houses are called dancing houses. The soil was so swampy that they had to build on stilts and that caused them to wobble and sink into the river.6) The number of bicycles in Amsterdam is more than the number of people living in the city.7) Amsterdam has approximately 20 times more tourists throughout the year than the locals.8) Amsterdam is one of the top 25 safest cities in the world and also one of the top 15 cities known for its high standard of living. Who would have thought, with all the marijuana and prostitution?9) A study reveals that Dutch men are the tallest people in the world.10) Amsterdam lies below the sea level and is among the top five coffee consuming cities in the world.11) Amsterdam Stock Exchange is the oldest stock exchange in the world.12) Same-sex marriage is legal in Amsterdam. The Netherlands was the first country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage.
How to travel around Amsterdam
The best way to explore the city is either on a bike or on foot. Even if you only pedal around for a few hours, riding a bike is an essential Amsterdam experience. There are over 800,000 bicycles in Amsterdam. Thatâ€™s more bikes than people! The city also has a flat landscape, which makes cycling so much more fun and enjoyable, and is also one the worldâ€™s most cycle-friendly cities with separate cycling paths throughout the entire city. You can also use public transport such as buses, trams, and metros, which are very well connected in the entire city.
Best time to go to Amsterdam
The city is always buzzing with tourists year round, particularly being busier from April to September because it is warmer in those months. I traveled in April and it was extremely busy, but I had a great time. It would be ideal to book your stay ahead of time if you are going to travel in the peak tourist season as almost everything gets booked.
Here is a list of the must do things in Amsterdam:
2) Canal cruise â€” Besides providing a stunning backdrop to the cityâ€™s historical center, floating down Amsterdamâ€™s canals is one of the most memorable ways to discover the cityâ€™s sights and attractions. Whether youâ€™re a first-time or frequent visitor, everything in Amsterdam seems a bit more magical when viewed from a boat.
Most canal cruises take around an hour, which gives you an opportunity to explore Amsterdamâ€™s UNESCO protected Canal Ring and discover plenty of interesting facts about the city along the way. There are various tours operating on the water and you could pick up one quite easily as per your location and requirements.
3) Explore museums â€” Amsterdam is home to over 50 museums, exploring the diversity of history, art, culture, and educational fun. There are museums to suit everyoneâ€™s interest. Some of the most famous museums are Van Gogh Museum, Rijksmuseum, and Anne Frank House.
4) Go beer tasting â€” Amsterdam is the home of the Heineken headquarters. The Heineken experience is a must see for all visitors. I had a great experience where they showed the brewing process, innovations, ingredients used, etc., and at the end of the tour also gave two free beers. Some other interesting breweries that I would also recommend are Brouwerij de Prael, Brouwerij â€˜t IJ, and Butcherâ€™s Tears.
5) Food, bars, and pubs â€” Amsterdam is well-known around the world as a city of indulgences. Here is a list of famous Dutch food you have to try:Stroopwafel â€” consists of a syrup filling sandwiched between two thin waffles. (Best when hot). Try the one at Banketbakkerij Lanskroon or Albert Cuyp Market.Dutch Cheese â€” They are absolutely amazing and cannot be missed. Try them at the Cheese Factory or Henri Willig Cheese shops for a guided experience, or at Reypenaer Proeflokaal or the Cheese Museum.Patat or Frites (Dutch Fries) â€” These are a must-have with the lip-smacking sauces. One of my absolute favorite places for this food is Vleminckx Sausmeesters.Poffertjes â€” You can buy these little fluffy pancakes from any street market or vendor.
Some of the other famous eating spots are Winkel 43 for apple pie, Ice Bakery by Nutella, bars in Nieuwmarkt, Pancake Bakery next to the Anne Frank Museum, De Zotte Cafe in Leidseplein, and Van Stapele Koekmakerij for the chocolate cookies.
Noorderlicht Cafe, in the north, is a nice restaurant. You will have to take a ferry across the Ij to NDSM Werf. This ferry is free to use. Also, there are many amazing restaurants and bars in the north that are definitely worth a try and usually unexplored. There are really cute and cozy restaurants in Jordaan, too, which are hidden gems. Some other really good restaurants to try are Frits (burgers), BAK (organic restaurant), Pazzi (best pizza place in town), De Struisvogel (three-course menu), The Lobby Nesplein (Amazing food and wines. Ask for â€œhet vieze boekjeâ€ (Dirty Book), which they have in their special wines).
Try a hipster cafe. They believe in ugly is beautiful and cook with all those fruits and vegetables that would have been rejected just because they were not the perfect shape or size. It is a fun experience. You could try CafÃ© de Ceuvel, Cafe Brecht, Smokinâ€™ barrels, etc.
The Top deck of the Science Center NEMO is a great place to chill and enjoy magnificent views of the city as well as Floor 17 at the Ramada Apollo Hotel, Sky Lounge at Doubletree by Hilton, Hannekes Boom (an eclectic hangout on the banks of OOsterdok), Edel (a fairy-lit hideaway in De Baarsjes), and other small pubs near the canals. If youâ€™re into hardcore clubbing, then visit Jimmy Woo nightclub, Supperclub, Suzy Wong, Paradiso, Melkweg, AIR Amsterdam, and Sugarfactory.
If you are looking for a Michelin star experience, then try Ciel Bleu. Make reservations in advance at the restaurants in Amsterdam in order to avoid any disappointments, as most of them are pre-booked.
6) Shopping â€” Amsterdam has amazing places to shop and something for everyone. If youâ€™re looking for high-street brands like H&M and Zara go to the busy Kalverstraat. If local boutiques interest you, then head to The Nine Streets. These nine cobbled streets connect the main canals between Leidsegracht and Raadhuisstraat. For high-end shopping, head to De Bijenkorf or Magna Plaza Shopping Centre (previously a post office) located behind Dam Square.
7) Explore the local neighborhoods â€” Amsterdam-Centrum: The Red Light District, Jordaan, The Nine streets and the Canal Ring, Leidseplein, or visit the Blijburg Beach.â€“ Dam Square area: Itâ€™s the center with Madame Tussauds and other museums.â€“ Take a photo with the IAMSTERDAM letters or hang around the flea market in that area.â€“ Noord: A free ferry from the Central Station will take you to this district which has the cityâ€™s coolest architecture, fun hangout spots by the water and exciting festivals.â€“ De Pijp: A great mix of culture, cafes, and cuisine. Do visit the Albert Cuypmarkt here.â€“ Bos en Lommer and De Baarsjes: Itâ€™s famous for their multicultural crowd and popular terrace bars.
8) Parks â€” Parks are at the heart of Amsterdam culture. Every time the sun is out you will see the locals packing up the disposable barbecue and heading down to their nearest garden.If you like visiting parks do not miss to check out Vondelpark, the most famous park in Amsterdam with an open air theater and concerts in the summer. Some other interesting parks are Erasmuspark and Rembrandtpark.
9) Day trips â€” If you have time then it would be exciting to venture out and take day trips to Volendam, Marken, Zaanse Schans (working windmills), countryside, Delft, The Hague, and Rotterdam. Each of these places is unique and has something to offer you.
10) Visit a market in Amsterdam â€” Whether youâ€™re looking to buy or try some local delicacies or just soak up the atmosphere, visiting one of the many markets in Amsterdam is a unique and unforgettable experience. Markets selling everything from antiques to books to artisan food to vintage clothes are held all over the city every day. Some of the most popular Amsterdam markets include the Albert Cuypmarkt in De Pijp (Mon.-Sat.) Lindengrachtmarkt in the Jordaan (Saturdays), and the Waterlooplein Market (Mon.-Sat.).
11) Visit coffee shops â€” A trip to Amsterdam wouldnâ€™t be complete without visiting the coffee shops there. Some of the famous coffee shops are The Bulldog, Mellow Yellow, Original Dampkrings, and Grey Area.
--
--
Stories about surviving on Earth.

Title: Amsterdam, 2024: A Cityâ€™s Cigar Culture Fading Into Smoke
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Combining the timeless pursuit of meaning (legacy) with the boundless freedom to explore (latitude). A guide for men charting their own paths through the art of living wellâ€Šâ€”â€Štravel, craftsmanship, rituals, enduring ideas, and the finer things in life.

Featured
--
3
Listen
Share
Amsterdam used to mean something to cigar lovers. Or so Iâ€™d readÂ¹. The stories painted a picture of cigar lounges that werenâ€™t just places to smoke, but sanctuaries â€” spaces where a man could light up, lean back, and let the world turn without him for a while. The kind of places that made you feel like a part of something.
But the Amsterdam I found wasnâ€™t that.
I arrived in 2024 chasing those stories. Before my trip, Iâ€™d done the usual research, looked up the names that still carried weight in cigar circles. P.G.C. Hajenius â€” a name spoken with reverence, a temple to tobacco since 1826 , P.G.C. Hajenius, one of the oldest cigar shops in the world â€” was the first on my list. Its Art Deco interior, legendary humidor, and the ghosts of cigar lovers whoâ€™d passed through its doors made it a destination in itself.
But my planning led to discoveries I hadnâ€™t expected. A few phone calls, a dive into the cityâ€™s laws, and the truth hit home: Amsterdamâ€™s cigar lounges were no longer what theyâ€™d been. The 2008 smoking bans had started the slow dismantling, and the 2020 regulations had finished the job, leaving even the likes of Hajenius a shadow of its former selfÂ². By decree of Dutch law, every cigar lounge in Amsterdam was snuffed out as of January 1, 2022 â€” a quiet funeral for a once-thriving cultureÂ³.
I couldnâ€™t bring myself to go. Not because I was afraid of disappointment, but because thereâ€™s a point where preserving the memory of something becomes more important than confirming its absence. I didnâ€™t want to see that grandeur stripped down, repurposed into some polite, sterile shell. Maybe one day Iâ€™ll go â€” not to chase what was, but to see what remains. But this trip wasnâ€™t the time for that.
Instead, I focused on the present. I had one day left in Amsterdam, and I wasnâ€™t about to waste it wallowing in nostalgia for a past Iâ€™d never lived. Thatâ€™s how I found myself at Cigaragua.
Cigaragua isnâ€™t a place trying to recreate the golden age of cigar lounges. It doesnâ€™t have the leather armchairs, the paneled wood, or the ghosts of old men swapping war storiesâ´. Instead, itâ€™s defiantly modern. Clean. Unapologetically Nicaraguan.
The shopfront is subtle, but its presence is bold, standing as a rare holdout in a city thatâ€™s lost its love for cigars. Thereâ€™s no room to linger â€” not because they donâ€™t want you to, but because the city doesnâ€™t. Amsterdam has no place anymore for the kind of slow, social rituals that make cigars more than just tobacco. Cigaragua has turned their cigar room into an extra storage space because of this.
What Cigaragua does have is quality. Their selection is a celebration of Nicaraguaâ€™s best â€” a curated homage to a country thatâ€™s made itself synonymous with craftsmanship in the cigar world. The staff know their stuff, too. They donâ€™t just sell cigars; they respect them.
I walked out with two: the Sobremesa BrÃ»lÃ©e Blue, a cigar that would later redefine my idea of a dessert cigar, and the Perdomo Double Aged 12-Year Vintage Connecticut, with its flawless construction and pedigree of aged tobaccos.
I didnâ€™t smoke them in Amsterdam. This city, for all its indulgences, no longer felt like a place for that kind of moment. But thatâ€™s another story: Two Cigars, Two Journeys: a Prelude to Nicaragua
Walking through Amsterdamâ€™s streets, itâ€™s impossible to ignore its contradictions. The air is thick with the scent of cannabis, rolling out of coffee shops without apology. The red-light district glows like a beacon, a carnival of curiosity and hedonism. This is a city that markets its indulgences with pride â€” except, apparently, for cigars.
The hypocrisy isnâ€™t just glaring â€” itâ€™s comical. You can sit in a coffee shop and light up a joint without a second thought, but a cigar in a lounge? Thatâ€™s where the line is drawn. Amsterdam hasnâ€™t turned its back on vice; itâ€™s just decided which kinds of indulgence are acceptable. And cigars, with their air of refinement, their association with slow, thoughtful leisure, have been left out in the cold.
Iâ€™m not shocked by Amsterdamâ€™s decadence. Iâ€™ve seen enough of the world to know that people will always find ways to indulge. I donâ€™t judge it. But I do call out the hypocrisy â€” the selective morality that lets one kind of smoke flow freely while stamping out another.
For all the disappointment I felt, Cigaragua gave me hope. Itâ€™s not trying to reclaim the past or fight the tide of change. Itâ€™s simply standing firm, celebrating the craft and the culture that cigars represent.
Maybe Amsterdam will come around. Maybe, one day, the pendulum will swing back, and the city will remember what itâ€™s lost. And maybe, when that day comes, Iâ€™ll walk through the doors of P.G.C. Hajenius â€” not chasing the past, but ready to face whatever remains. Until then, Iâ€™ll carry the memory of what Amsterdam could have been, and the promise of what it still might become.
Because even in a city thatâ€™s turned its back on cigars, thereâ€™s still room for moments that remind you why they matter. And sometimes, thatâ€™s enough.
â€” â€” Footnotes â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” Â¹ Iâ€™ve read a number of pieces about Amsterdamâ€™s cigar legacy, such as this one: https://www.cigarinspector.com/cigar-library/amsterdams-cigar-lounges/
Â² Only after having checked into my hotel in Amsterdam, I started catching up on updates, including this curious insight: https://www.zigarren.zone/en/netherlands-bans-cigar-lounges/But the subject has been covered much earlier, a good example is this 2017 micro-document by David Fuller: Banning Tobacco in Cannabis Cafes?
Â³ On the subject of cigar lounges being banned: The new law that came into force on January 1, 2022 regarding cigar lounges is not directly aimed at the few cigar lounges, but rather at the large commercial buildings that have smoking areas. Unfortunately, cigar lounges are also affected by this change. They will therefore also had to close.
â´ Had I traveled to Amsterdam few years earlier, I would have been able to experience Cigaragua when it hosted a cigar lounge. In fact I was looking forward to it, after having seen information such as this piece from 2019: https://www.cigaraficionado.com/article/where-to-smoke-cigaragua-amsterdam
--
--
3
Combining the timeless pursuit of meaning (legacy) with the boundless freedom to explore (latitude). A guide for men charting their own paths through the art of living wellâ€Šâ€”â€Štravel, craftsmanship, rituals, enduring ideas, and the finer things in life.

Member-only story

My love for Amsterdam was ignited when I met some friendly Dutch fans at a soccer World Cup match.
This was the year 2010 when South Africa hosted the Soccer World Cup.
The energy and friendliness of the Dutch planted the seed that left me wanting to visit Amsterdam.
Just their warm energy had me drawn to them.
My visit to Amsterdam was everything I expected and much more.
Just like in the soccer match, the people I came into contact with, in Amsterdam were warm and friendly.
Being around people with this energy always leaves me on a natural high. My heart feels at peace.
Waking up each morning and exploring the city was always a fun adventure.
Public transport is extremely reliable and efficient. I did a lot of walking in Amsterdam. I also rented a bicycle.
I love cycling!
Cycling in the streets of Amsterdam was a uniquely different experience.

Title: 5 Reasons Amsterdam is The Best Choice For New Travelers
Content:
Sign up
Sign in

Sign in
Member-only story

It is hard to believe that it has already been over a year since I first left the country. I have spent my whole life with a passion for travel but up until last year I was spending all of my time and funds on hopelessly driving or flying from one side of the country to the other.
Donâ€™t get me wrong I love the views in the US but I always wanted to get some stamps in my passport and really experience different cultures and what else the world had to offer!
I spent as much time as I could traveling last year and after experiencing 8 different countries in those 12 months, I have finally come to the conclusion on my answer for the question I get all the time, â€œWhere should I go first?â€
With a smirk on my face I enthusiastically reply â€œAmsterdam!â€
Most people are scared or nervous about what to expect when they leave the country for the first time and for good reason. There are so many things to consider like:
what kind of currency do they use?
Is it safe?
How will I get around?
What language do they speak?
These are all valid questions that I ask every time I begin planning my next adventure and something that everyone should look into beforeâ€¦

Title: Amsterdam, Netherlands // Why a different state of mind?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Here for the travel advice and not to read my life story? Jump to Travel Recommendations for the tl;dr [too long; didnâ€™t read] to plan your trip to Amsterdam now!
I felt giddy as my flight touched down. I was passing through the city somewhat incidentally. My end destination was Portugal but it was cheaper to fly through Amsterdam first. So I stretched my layover into a three-day trip. This gave me one day to recover from jet lag and a solid two days in Amsterdam to explore.
Amsterdam is one of those cities proceeded by its reputation. Personally, it has loomed large in my imagination for decades. A place where prostitution is not only legal but flaunted. Where weed, magic mushrooms, and who knows what else was accessible long before even medical clinics were open back home in California. A place where kids going to what at the time I considered â€œrealâ€ or four-year colleges would go to spend a semester abroad. It seemed like such an exciting and luxurious opportunity. One that I could only dream of as I worked my way through community college as a waitress to supplement my scholarships and financial aid.
I wanted to ride a bike around and meet new people from all over the world. Wear cozy sweaters and do drugs in coffee shops and bars. The fact that this was exactly how I was already spending most if not all of my time right at home in San Francisco and Oakland did not make it seem any less exotic.
By the time I finally had the chance to make that pilgrimage, I was in a very different state of mind. I spent my two days in Amsterdam on history and art tours. Taking in the old buildings and even older paintings. Trying new foods such as stroopwaffle (yay!) and pickled herring (nay).
Amsterdam is expensive! Hotels, hostels, and Airbnbs are all expensive. I ended up staying at CityHub Amsterdam, a capsule hotel. Overall, it was a good experience. I donâ€™t really spend time in the hotel when I am traveling so this was a good option for me. It was clean and quiet. I loved the location. There was even a street market right outside where I stopped every morning for a fresh squeezed juice during my stay.
Back to top
I donâ€™t have much in the way of tips for this trip. It is easy to move through the city and everyone speaks English. The one thing I want to mention is, watch out for bikes! There is a lot of bicycle traffic and one sure-fire way to get cursed out from an otherwise friendly and easygoing local population is to cross the bike lane without looking.
Back to top
Start your day with a free walking tour! This is a great way to start your trip, especially if you are short on time. I recommend taking one the first day to help you get oriented. Free Walking Tours Amsterdam is the one I went with. I took the classic tour, but they have several other options to chose from depending on your interest. There are also many, many other options to choose from when selecting a free walking tour.
This style of tour is available all over Europe. I have even started seeing them in some places in Latin America as well. They typically last 2â€“3 hours. Your guide will give you some historical context for the city and show you the main sights within walking distance. The tours are indeed free, but the guides are only paid through tips. Have cash on hand to fork over at least â‚¬5-â‚¬10 once the tour is over.
Back to top
Consider grabbing lunch or dinner at this trendy food hall. It is modeled after a concept that has taken the world by storm. Foodhallen is one building with many different stalls inside that offer different types of cuisine. You can order from any one that catches your fancy and grab a spot amidst the communal seating.
Back to top
In the evening, I recommend heading over to NDSM. This cultural hotspot is a collection of contemporary art studios and rotating exhibitions in a giant converted warehouse. You may catch a music show or a performance. There are also a few places to eat while on that side of the river.
The easiest way to arrive is to take the F4 ferry from Amsterdam Central Station. It is free and runs every 15â€“30 minutes. Be sure to hop back on before the ferry service ends at midnight.
Back to top
There are so many different options to choose from, but Rijksmuseum is the crown jewel of museums in Amsterdam. This one is a must-see for any visitor. You can purchase your timed entry tickets the day of, but I recommend buying them a day or two before if you are on a strict schedule and need to be at the museum at a specific time. I also recommend coming here first and then exploring some of the other must-sees in the city such as the Van Gough Museum or the Anne Frank House Museum.
Back to top
All that wandering around and viewing of those giant Renaissance paintings of food in varying states of decay is bound to make you hungry. After visiting Rijksmuseum it is just a short jaunt to Albert Cupstraat Markt. This market stretches several blocks and includes giftable wares, flowers, and most importantly, traditional Dutch cuisine. Be sure to try the stroopwafels, pickled herring, bitterballen (meatballs), and patat friet (french fries).
The market is open 9:30 am-5:00 pm every day except Sundays.
Back to top
The Central Park of Amsterdam is worth strolling through on foot or by bike and is close to both Rijksmuseum and Albert Cuypstraat market. Itâ€™s a beautiful place to stop and take a rest on one of the many benches lining the park paths before continuing on with your busy day.
Back to top
No stay in Amsterdam would be complete without a stop at the famous Red Light District. Locals hate it, tourists love it. If you are visiting, I think you have to go at least to see it. There are even historical tours during the day for the faint of heart. Itâ€™s easy to find a burlesque show, sex show, or just head out on your own to experience the scene at night.
If you do go in the evening, be prepared to witness the true spectacle, the endless parade of bachelor or â€œstagâ€ parties crowding the street. You will mostly see women in windows soliciting their wares as you walk the streets, which is to say, themselves. I enjoyed watching the full spectrum of how these women interacted with the passing crowd. Some were dancing, some were trying to entice potential customers with a flirty, joking manner. The most conventionally attractive were visibly bored, doom scrolling on their phones and awaiting their next client without having to put in much effort.
Back to top
I was traveling alone for this trip, so I didnâ€™t have the wild adventure I might have otherwise. But as I get older and wiser, I canâ€™t help but grow in my appreciate of the quieter side of cities and life itself. The joys of earlier mornings, sans hangover. Trying new foods, even if it is for the first and last time. And most importantly, whether it be through observing classical art or observing my fellow tourist on their worst behavior, always learning something new whenever I have the opportunity.
--
--
1

Title: Guide for Black Travelers in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Exploring Amsterdam as a black traveler was a fantastic experience. The city has a lot to offer in terms of its history and culture, especially for people interested in racial significance. or black travelers. Amsterdam offers a unique opportunity to explore the rich tapestry of its history and culture, with several places of racial significance to discover. In this blog, weâ€™ll delve into the vibrant and multicultural aspects of Amsterdam, offering recommendations on places to visit and things to do that resonate with the cityâ€™s diverse heritage. Here are some easy-to-understand things to do and places to visit:
The Heineken Experience: The Heineken Experience might not be directly about race, but itâ€™s a cool part of your Amsterdam adventure.You can learn about Dutch culture by exploring how Heineken beer is made and the Heineken brewery can help you understand Amsterdamâ€™s ties to the rest of the world. An interesting fact I learned was that America is responsible for 30% of Heinenkin sales.
Amsterdam was such an incredible experience, especially a great place for black travelers. You can learn a lot about the cityâ€™s history by visiting The Black Archives and going to the Keti Koti Festival. Plus, you can try delicious foods from all over the world and meet the Afro-Surinamese community, making your trip even more special. When you plan your visit, keep these ideas in mind to enjoy Amsterdamâ€™s diversity and inclusive atmosphere. The city is ready to welcome you and share its past and future with you!

Title: The Doâ€™s and Donâ€™ts of Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Clueâ€™s in the name really, itâ€™s an exciting insight into the mysteries of the infamous Red Light District. This museum gives you all the juicy and hush hush secrets of the industry. Here are some reasons why it should feature on your itinerary:
Â· For one, its location is a former 17th century brothel in the centre of the Red Light District (how much more authentic can you get?!)
Â· It provides personal stories and accounts of prostitutes whoâ€™ve worked in Amsterdam throughout the years; some are extremely emotional and hard hitting.
Â· You can sit in a Red Light Window (which is a fab photo op!) and visit the room of a girl who worked at the brothel for 7 years.
Â· It has the last prostitution office in Amsterdam (everything in there is still untouched!).
Â· Itâ€™s on the cheap side! If you go to a tours and tickets shop which are located around Amsterdam or book online in advance its further discounted.
Businesses in the Red Light District do not allow people to take photos. You most likely will have your phone confiscated. Youâ€™re putting yourselves at risk if you try! Staring isnâ€™t banned but, understandably, the women donâ€™t like it. Some are very smiley and open, others more reserved. I saw a girl use a curtain to cover her face when a group of tourists wouldnâ€™t stop gawping. Although sometimes itâ€™s difficult not to look, donâ€™t be disrespectful or excessive!
If youâ€™re a history lover, like myself, I imagine this biographical museum would tell the perfect story of arguably the most renowned holocaust victim. I say â€˜imagineâ€™â€¦ because we didnâ€™t manage to get in! From 9am-3.30pm the museum was reserved for people who had booked online. From 3.30pm a GIGANTIC queue formed which was at least 3 hours long, at which point we abandoned the idea and went to grab a pint.
My advice is DO buy tickets online if you want to visit without the hassle. Plus, Iâ€™m aware tickets online sell out quickly so book asap!
Like â€˜The Red Lights Secrets museumâ€™, it is anything but boring! From giant penises to an automated farting flasher â€¦ itâ€™s great for a giggle and fab if you like art thatâ€™s a little out of the box! Itâ€™s also cheap as chips (literallyâ€¦thereâ€™s a chip shop across the road which is more expensive) It only costs $5!
Itâ€™s a cool photo opportunity and if youâ€™re athletic enough you can climb on the giant letters (note I chose not to!)
This is probably one of my greatest regrets of the trip. EVERYONE and I mean everyone travelled by bike. We decided to walk pretty much everywhere and it resulted in extremely blistered feet. Although walking is beneficial sometimes (at night or if youâ€™re exploring) Iâ€™d say biking is the more fun and efficient option. There are places to hire bikes dotted around Amsterdam, they arenâ€™t hard to come by. Although do be careful if you do go on a bike because people cycle like they are competing at a velodrome, which leads perfectly to my next point.
I had a few close shaves whilst obliviously standing in a lane attempting to navigate myself. They can be quite discrete, so just be on the lookout.
Lots of people hire out bikes purely to cycle round this serene environment (and it is quite big so if you want to see all of it, biking is probably the way to go). On a sunny day, itâ€™s full of people listening to music, having picnics and lazing about on the grass. Itâ€™s incredibly beautiful and a relaxing pit stop from the business of the city centre.
This 22-floor tower is a bar/restaurant and gives an amazing 360Ëš birdâ€™s-eye view of Amsterdam. Drinks are a little on the pricey side but remember, youâ€™re paying for the experience as well- itâ€™s a second to none vantage point and the cocktails are huge! Also, if you are a bit of a daredevil, Aâ€™DAM lookout- â€˜Over the Edgeâ€™ is Europeâ€™s highest swing. You get to swing 100 metres above the ground right at the top of the building (fair to say I was not tempted).
Generally, alcohol is expensive, so pre-drinks are essential and supermarket prices arenâ€™t bad for a bottle of wine or a few cans! This capital is obviously known for its cannabis culture and wide range of coffeeshops (which are just as common as bars). Prices are much cheaper so itâ€™s a sound alternative- when in Rome, do as the Romans do (Or in this case, when in Amsterdam, do as the Dutch do!) â€¦
Like most cities the further into the city centre you go the more expensive things become. This is the case for both food and drink. Some of the best bars and eating places were scattered on the outskirts! Check out the map at the bottom of this post for a few ideas!
The great thing about Amsterdam is the diversity and element of surprise around each corner. Whether itâ€™s exploring the Red Light District, coffeeshops, museums or just strolling by the gorgeous canals, itâ€™s impossible to be bored so allow yourself to wander and take it all in!

Two nights in London was plenty. I wanted to end on a high note, and Iâ€™d done just that. I wasnâ€™t going to top the previous night. Plus, it was a waste of money staying there. I needed to get on the Euro. Given the short distance, and my desire to buy weed for the trip, Amsterdam was the obvious choice.
I took the Stena Line Ferry on Joannaâ€™s recommendation. The cost wasnâ€™t included in my Eurorail package, but for $30 it seemed well worth it to travel in comfort. If nothing else, it was a good excuse to drink and chain smoke indoors for 5 hours.
When I boarded, I was struck by how mall-like the interior was. It felt more like a cruise ship than a ferry. There were movie theaters, restaurants, bars, even shopping. There may have been a casino too, but I could just be imagining that because the place felt so much like one. After scoping out the ship, I found myself a comfortable leather chair near the bar and plopped myself down. I ordered a Guinness and swallowed two Adderall. Then, I removed my journal, and made my plans for Amsterdam:
- Coffee shops (buy lots of weed)
- Shrooms
- Find good bar
- Sex w/ prostitute?
For the rest of the ride, I read from the single book Iâ€™d brought on the trip, Hunter Thompsonâ€™s Fear and Loathing in America, a compilation of letters that Hunter wrote and received between the years of 1968â€“1976.Itâ€™s essentially an account of his life, told through correspondence. The book was 800 pages and weighed a few pounds. I almost didnâ€™t bring it because of the extra heft it added to my backpack, but I knew it would come in handy for long travel days. Plus, I needed to stay sharp. Hunter was my North Star at the time, for good or ill. I admired his brashness and eye for bullshit. He was also a prodigious drug user whilst still being a terrific writer and honorable man. I wanted to be him in every way. Iâ€™d never felt that way about any other author or person, and still havenâ€™t.
The ferry dropped us off at the Amsterdam Centraal train station at 2pm, amid the most perfect spring day. The sun was beaming down, and everyone seemed happy. Are people happy because theyâ€™re in Amsterdam, or do happy people just gravitate there, making it so? Hard to tell. Sounds like a chicken/egg situation. Speaking of which, Iâ€™ve always wondered if people weigh more because of their genes or because their caloric intake is higher, and they work out less. Like, if you took two people who eat and workout the same amount but oneâ€™s family has been fat for generations (like mine) and the other skinny, would they end up weighing the same exact amount? That may not be a chicken/egg situation but itâ€™s in the same ballpark. I digress.
Before looking for a hostel, I wanted to get high, so I went in the first â€œcoffee shopâ€ I saw. Now would be a good time to describe the difference between coffee shops in America and coffee shops in Amsterdam. They look the same for the most part, except in Amsterdam, some sell weed. Pretty simple. I think they call them â€œcoffee shopsâ€ because it sounds more dignified than â€œweed stores,â€ though thatâ€™s what they are.
I ordered a pre-roll and a latte. If cocaine and heroin together is a speed ball, weed and coffee together is more like a curveball. Part of me felt demure, sitting there smoking a joint by myself in a cafÃ©. The other part though, was high as bollocks and VERY paranoid. The American penal system was so ingrained in me that my Pavlovian response to being high was an intense fear of the police. I kept reassuring myself that I wasnâ€™t breaking the law, but I couldnâ€™t shake the fear of being arrested. You donâ€™t realize youâ€™re paranoid amidst the paranoia. If you did, you wouldnâ€™t be paranoid.
On my walk to find a hostel I couldnâ€™t stop laughing at the ridiculousness street names. I wrote some of my favorites down in my journal. I also made up some of my own. See if you can guess which are which (I canâ€™t even remember):
- Brouwersgracht
- Hosenlendinvein
- Princeneiland
- Amsterveenseweg
- Grunarpeilveg
- Einelpenilhar
- Brouwersgracht
The hostel I chose was a far cry from The Flying Pig, the â€œitâ€ place Iâ€™d read about in my research. The Flying Pig was the most popular hostel for people my age (still is) because they had a weed smoking section in the common area where you could rent pipes and bongs. There was a communal element there, one I was not looking for. I donâ€™t like being a part of groups and try to avoid it whenever possible. I want to do what I want to do, not what â€œusâ€ wants to do. â€œUsâ€ is always some lame compromise. I, instead, went with an off-brand hostel, one that catered to an older, more laid-back crowd. When I booked it online, the picture made it look like a nondescript Holiday Inn Express. It was a little off the beaten path, but not too far from the action. It looked clean, calm, and quiet, just what I was looking for.
When I got there, it did seem both clean and calm. But, to my surprise, I heard a jackhammer. When I checked in, I inquired, and the manager told me there would be construction every day from 9am-5pm.
Manager: Will that be a problem?
Me: No. I plan to be out during those hours every day. Thanks for letting me know.
Thatâ€™s how I am, I thank people who inconvenience me. Iâ€™ve always been way too accommodating, even to my own detriment. I try to save the world one favor at a time. This wasnâ€™t even a favor though. Who was I helping? The hostel? Whatâ€™s wrong with me?
When I got up to my room, there was a man jackhammering five feet from my window. Iâ€™d never been that close to a jackhammer before. It sounded like a gunfight, like the one from Heat. What a fucking insane shootout. A ten-minute gun battle in the middle of Los Angeles? They mustâ€™ve had to shut the entire city down to film it. I wonder how much it cost. â€” Wait, what am I doing? Sorry. So, I got out of there and vowed to never be back between the hours of 9am-5pm
I still had an hour to kill before I could return. So, the mission again, was weed. This time to buy quantity. After 5 minutes of walking, I found a place called Coffee Shop Bob Marley. The brand is global. From the outside, it looked exactly like youâ€™d think it would, Jamaican flag, pictures of Bob, Wailers albums. The inside had an island vibe, like Sammy Hagar designed it. De whole ting was airy. I promise not to say that again.
When I entered, I was greeted by an old budtender who looked exactly like Willy Nelson, all the way down to the bandana. From his voice I could tell he was an ex-pat. He handed me a Trapper Keeper-style three ring binder. In it were plastic pages with little slots for what traditionally would have been baseball cards. Instead of cards though, each quadrant contained a gram of weed, along with a short description about the type of high you could expect (e.g., purple haze: mellow, euphoric). It was the first time Iâ€™d seen such a professional set up and I was blown away. Iâ€™d smoked weed daily for 5 years but had never seen anything like that before. Remember in Half Baked, when Thurgood sees the weed room at the laboratory and fucks the air in elation? That was me.
After much consideration, I selected 3 indica strains and paid Willie 60 Euros for the 10.5-gram purchase, a good deal anywhere in the world at that time.
Me: May I light up in here?
Willy: Of course. The smoking room is in back.
The smoking room was just a small, curtained off area with a few high-top tables. A Bob Marley music video played on the television that hung on the wall. I put my bag on the table and removed a grape White Owl cigar that Iâ€™d brought with me from America. At the time I was still smoking blunts and I wanted to â€œrepresentâ€ my â€œcultureâ€ while in Europe. How stupid. What I didnâ€™t consider, was that Iâ€™d barely smoked the previous two weeks while in New York. And, though I smoked a hash spliff the previous night in London, my tolerance was still low. Drug tolerance must ALWAYS be considered. Regardless, I went ahead and rolled a 2.5-gram monster of Afghan Kush.
There were two other people in the room with me, a couple, who both appeared to be in their 30â€™s. They were smoking out of a pipe and laughing. When I dumped the guts of the blunt into a garbage bin near the wall, they began staring in my direction. They didnâ€™t say anything, but I could tell they were interested in what I was constructing. I was proud of my blunt rolling skills and wanted to put on a show for them, so they could see how we did it in the states. I considered myself an ambassador.
After licking the blunt closed, I sparked my lighter, running the flame along the paper to dry it out. Then, I lit it, taking a deep drag and coughing slightly. The couple, again, glanced my way. I looked in their direction, smiled, and kept smoking like a real cool dude.
About halfway through the blunt, I realized Iâ€™d made a huge mistake, and that I was not cool at all. In fact, I was hot, sweating bullets, actually. And I was overcome with dizziness. I could tell the couple wanted to check on me, they just werenâ€™t sure if it was their place to do so. I mean, I mustâ€™ve known what I was doing, right? You donâ€™t just roll a blunt like that if itâ€™s your first time smoking weed.
My equilibrium was totally askew. I gripped the small, circular table in front of me like I was Greco Roman wrestling with it. I had to say something before it was too late.
Me: My name is Sam. Iâ€™m from America. If I die, my momâ€™s phone number is in my â€” -
Then I passed out and fell on the floor.
When I came to, Bob Marleyâ€™s I Shot the Sheriff was playing on the tv. The couple was hovering over me, disturbed, their highs obviously ruined. Willy was concerned too, standing over me with a bottle of water. I didnâ€™t even know how long Iâ€™d been out.
Willy: We were scared, man. Glad youâ€™re ok. We donâ€™t even allow cigars in here.
Lady: That was so scary.
Other Lady: Hereâ€™s your ID. We found it in your bag. Weâ€™re from America too.
Me: Wellâ€¦Thatâ€™s just perfect.
I grabbed my ID from the lady, along with the remainder of the blunt. Then, I ran out with my tail between my legs, knowing Iâ€™d rather be dead than ever show my face in there again. There would be no Redemption Song for me.
On my way back to the hostel, I passed what looked to be the weirdest food establishment Iâ€™d ever seen. It reminded me of a Grayâ€™s Papaya, a hot dog chain in New York, in that there was no seating inside. In fact, there was nothing at all inside. It looked to be just an empty room, like an American check cashing place. Yet, it smelled like fast food. It was too weird to not investigate.
When I went in, I thought I was tripping out. I was still very high and woozy from the fall, but I was pretty sure I was standing inside a life-sized vending machine. The walls were lined with rows and rows of slots where hot food was kept. I knew there must have been a kitchen in the back where everything was prepared, but I didnâ€™t see one, nor could I hear one. The only sign of human life was the hand of an employee replenishing the stock after a sale. I didnâ€™t love the impersonality of it all, but I had to admit it was ingenious.
The idea must have seared itself into my brain because I opened a take-and-go food establishment in Chicago only 7 years later. It failed. In fact, I got sued. I donâ€™t want to talk about that, though.
I put my credit card in and pressed the cheeseburger button twice. The slot unlocked and I removed my burgers, which were still delightfully warm. I went over to a bench and enjoyed them while watching a few kids play tag. I realized we were only a block from the Red-Light District. I wondered if they knew about what went on over there. I imagined they did, but were probably cool about it.
â€¦
I awoke from a much-needed night of sleep at 8:00am, which allowed me to get some free breakfast before the jackhammering started. After getting my plate of fruit and toast, I sat down near the television that played the BBC news on a loop. I loathed American news, but the BBC version didnâ€™t bother me all that much. It was almost pleasant to watch. What we have in America can hardly be called news. Itâ€™s just commercials for dick pills with raving lunatics spliced in between.
From my seat, I could see that it was drizzling outside. My plans for the day though, were iron clad. No amount of rain was going to keep me from tripping on mushrooms. I was going to trip; it had been written, in my journal.
Iâ€™d done mushrooms a handful of times before, with experiences ranging from spiritual bliss to utter madness, but I always learned something about myself in the process, and that was the most important thing to me. Doing them alone wasnâ€™t an issue for me either, I preferred it. I didnâ€™t like getting caught up in other peopleâ€™s trips, literally and figuratively.
When I entered the Smartshop, I was greeted by the kind of guy youâ€™d think would be running a psychedelic mushroom store, long hair, flannel shirt, monk vibes. They call them â€œsmart shopsâ€ the way they call weed stores â€œcoffee shopsâ€. Iâ€™ve always found that to be telling. Those are delicate, non-fear inducing terms. Maybe, so when kids walk by, they create positive association instead of negative ones. Itâ€™s the Pavlovian response thing again. In America we have â€œGun Storesâ€ not â€œSafety Shopsâ€. Think about it. Rather crude, if you ask me.
Clerk: How may I help you?
Me: Can you please advise me on which mushrooms I should take, and the quantity?
Clerk: Of course. That is exactly what I am here for. Have you done psilocybin before?
Me: Yes, maybe 10 times.
Clerk: Ok, let me walk you through what we have.
He took me over to a glass case with about 10 varieties of mushrooms, some wet, some dry, all of them unique in shape and color. He walked me through their different levels of potency and their array of effects.
Me: How about something in the medium-strength level?
Clerk: Sure. Would you like to see visuals?
Me: Yes, please.
Clerk: I suggest 1 to 2 grams of the High Hawaiian variety, dried.
Me: Will they make me laugh?
Clerk: Ooohhh yeah.
I paid him 10 Euros and exited the Smartshop with my mushrooms. I walked over to the canal and found an unoccupied bench and dried a small spot for myself. It was drizzling the perfect amount, like a mist. I took the mushrooms out of my bag, along with a banana Iâ€™d saved from breakfast and a bottle of water. Then I said my usual pre-hallucinogen prayer.
â€œLord, please look after me during this trip.â€
Once I had the mushrooms down and the nausea passed, I sat back and read my book until the words no longer looked like words, maybe 30 minutes. Thatâ€™s when the laughing started. EVERYTHING was funny. I spent 10 minutes laughing at my shoes because I thought they looked like chili dogs. Then it was the word â€œwanker.â€ I couldnâ€™t stop saying it. â€œOy ye wankerâ€, â€œAye wanker, quit ya wankingâ€, â€œBloody, scheming wanker.â€ That shit was KILLING me. I thought Iâ€™d written and entire, perfected comedy bit. As you can see, I did not do that. I was having a ball though.
Then, down the canal a few hundred yards away, I saw a tourist boat slowly approaching. There were 20 or so passengers on the small boat, and all of them were Asian. They looked so happy to me, with their big visors and smiling faces. I was overcome with the urge to connect with them. I stood up and waved my arms, yelling to them as they passed.
â€œHelllloooooo!!! Welcome to Amsterdam!!!â€
They waved back jubilantly, while I cry-laughed like a maniac, waving and yelling in their direction as they passed by my bench.
â€œEnjoy your staaayyyy!!â€
I greeted 8 boats-worth of people over a 2-hour period. For nearly my entire trip, I worked as a volunteer civil servant for a city Iâ€™d only been in two days. Amsterdam is special that way. Before leaving my post, I wrote in my journal:
Iâ€™D WORK ANY JOB IN THIS CITY
I walked back to the hostel soaked; my feet pruned from the rain. What I needed more than anything was a peaceful place to come down and dry off. When I got to my room, I was delighted to find none of my roommates there, a rare occurrence in a 4-person room. I toweled off and hung my clothes on the edge of the bunk before getting into my bed to reflect and relax. I couldnâ€™t have felt calmer, laying there. My heart was pure, and my thoughts, loving.
Then the jackhammering started. Iâ€™d completely forgotten about it. And this time, because of the mushrooms, it sounded even louder and more menacing than before. I still had three hours to kill, but my only jacket was soaked, along with my shoes, so I just laid there with a pillow over my face, laughing at the ridiculousness of the situation.
Mushrooms never fail to humble you.
â€¦
I woke up the next day to more rain. My tentative plan had been to go to Vondelpark, the largest, and most popular park in Amsterdam, but that was now out of the question. I wasnâ€™t willing to get drenched again. So, I went to write in a, you guessed it, coffee shop. I drank cafÃ© mochas and smoked spliffs with my pinky up like a dignified gentleman. In my journal, I noted my surroundings:
- Everyone is elegant. Nothing dressy, but all timeless looks. Bright, mismatching outfits, silly in the best way.
- Bikes, even in the rain.
- What does everyone do for work? Maybe theyâ€™re all architects. Thatâ€™s why the houses are so unique, everyone builds their own.
- Expensive looking umbrellas in the bin â€” â€” In America theyâ€™d be stolen.
I left when the rain turned to sun and wondered around for a short time before stumbling on a cute, outdoor market that sold flowers and other local delicacies. I bought an onion and herring sandwich along with a waffle,admittedly an odd combination. It brought back memories of my Bubbie, whoâ€™d loved both. Seeing me holding them at the same time wouldâ€™ve given her a good chuckle. Sheâ€™d probably ask, â€œWhat is it, my birthday?â€ I missed her dearly, especially in that moment. My father loved waffles too, but I wouldnâ€™t give him the satisfaction of thinking of him. Plus, the image of my dad eating 30 waffles is not a pleasant memory to conjure up.
After finishing my meal, I went in my pocket for dessert, 20mg of Adderall. My mom told me my Bubbie took uppers in the 60â€™s, when it was prescribed to housewives as a weight loss drug. I bet her grandma was a speed freak too, drinking that Coca Cola with actual cocaine in it. Time is a flat circle, no matter how much we tried to deny it.
I needed to charge up, and without sleep, Adderall was the best way to do that (even with sleep, for that matter). I was on a mission to find a bar that evening. And not just a bar for the night, but one I could call home in future visits. I still had a month left in my trip and knew Iâ€™d be back to Amsterdam, so I needed to have a reliable place to hang my hat. Bars are that important to me. I canâ€™t just go any old place to drink willy nilly. I need a home base, somewhere I feel comfortable, where they know my name. Cue the song.
I had no clue where I was going to find it, but I knew Iâ€™d know it when I saw it (the same way pornography was defined by the Supreme Court in 1964). It took some walking, but then I stumbled upon what was undoubtablythe place. I was standing at the corner of Nieuwebrugsteeg and Warmoesstraat, right where Warmoesstraat turns into Sint Olofspoort. Iâ€™m not joking. I looked up and there it wasâ€¦ The perfect bar. The sign under the awning read: â€œH. Murrayâ€™s Barâ€. Next to it was a smaller sign that read â€œAnno 1619â€. It looked to be more of a house than a bar. From the outside it could be mistaken for someoneâ€™s living room. Through the window, I could see a long-haired Golden Retriever sitting inside. A bar dog is a surefire sign of a good bar. If itâ€™s good enough for a dog, itâ€™s good enough for me.
I entered like I was returning home.
Me: Hi. Iâ€™m Sam.
Neil: Hello, friend. Iâ€™m Neil. Thatâ€™s Lilly (pointing to the dog). And thatâ€™s Norman (pointing to the only other man in the bar).
Me: Hello gents. May Iâ€¦?
Norman: Pull up a seat, Sam.
Me: Iâ€™ll have what Normanâ€™s having.
Always drink what the house drinks. It will endear you to the crowd. For me, that only backfires when the house drink is Sambuca. I hate Sambuca. It tastes like a Christmas tree. Or Malort, donâ€™t even get me started on the Chicago bars that push that lighter fluid on their clientele. Monsters.
We got to talking and time got to flying, the way it does when youâ€™re around good people. Norman told me about his time in Berkley, about how he knew Tim Leary, Tom Wolffe and the Merry Pranksters (look them up), people Iâ€™d only known from books like The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test. We shared the same sense of humor too. When he told me his favorite comedian was Steven Wright, I knew we were cut from the same cloth, only a generation apart. Steven Wright is one of the more obscure, odd comedians; real dry and wordy. He can make you laugh in less than ten words. I told him to look up Mitch Hedberg. I didnâ€™t bother telling him how Mitchâ€™s death contributed to my quitting stand-up, or that I even did stand-up at all. I just enjoyed listening and being a guest.
I wish I remembered more of that night, but thatâ€™s how it goes sometimes. Iâ€™ve always found sacrificing memory for fun to be a fair trade. Not everything has to be remembered and documented with a picture. I donâ€™t remember most of the best times of my life and Iâ€™m just fine with that. The last memory I have of that night is Norman pulling out an ounce of loose weed from his jacket pocket and slapping it on the bar. We must have smoked a joint that knocked me out completely. I probably threw up before they called me a cab, but thatâ€™s just an educated guess (Iâ€™ll give you 2/1 odds that I puked though).
â€¦
I awoke to jackhammering the next morning. The sound was so loud I thought it was coming from the inside my head. When I took the pillow off my face, the construction guy was staring at me from outside my window.If thereâ€™s a more terrible way to wake up when youâ€™re hungover, or sober for that matter, Iâ€™ve never experienced it. I popped up like a jack-in-the-box and ran out like my hair was on fire. I still had my clothes on from the night before, which made my escape easier. Fuck a shower, I needed to get out of there.
While I was scarfing down cold eggs and toast in the lobby, I checked my pockets and counted the money I had. It was the same exact amount as when Iâ€™d gone out the night before. John Mulaney had a joke about coming home with MORE money than he went out with, and this wasnâ€™t that, but it was close. Neil didnâ€™t even charge me. I couldnâ€™t recall his kind gesture, but I was sure I hadnâ€™t just left without paying. I mean, I was pretty sure. When wasted, Iâ€™m more inclined to try and pay twice than I am to skip out on the bill. One time in New Orleans, I paid my tab, then sat there trying to pay my tab four more times. The bartender threw me out.
I caught some highlights from the NCAA Menâ€™s March Madness tournament on the BBC which made me feel odd. In years past I would have been watching every game, but this time it felt like insignificant news from a distant land.
After finishing my breakfast, I headed out to do some wandering. I hit a few bookstores, but mainly I just walked, soaking in the surroundings and smoking. I had more than enough weed, but I still stopped in coffee shops to see their product line. Each store was unique, and I just couldnâ€™t get enough of being inside places that sold legal weed. I live in California now and the novelty still hasnâ€™t worn off.
As night rolled around, I found myself in a bar, drinking Irish Whiskey, not my usual. I donâ€™t know exactly where I was, but I do know it was right by the Red-Light District. THAT Iâ€™M SURE OF.
As I got drunker my loneliness began to transform into horny rage. When my erection grew, I knew the decision was being made for me. It was time.
I walked the entire length of the Red-Light District multiple times, perusing the ladies, to find the perfect date for the next 30 minutes. Iâ€™m trying to be tactful here by saying â€œdateâ€. â€œVictimâ€ sounds too graphic even though thatâ€™s kind of what it felt like.
I have always been a very discerning shopper, that time being no different. The women all had their own room where they sat, positioned toward the outer sidewalk. By just looking in you could see the entire layout. They were all similar; a bed in the corner, a small nightstand, presumably for keys or other knickknacks that may interfere with the coitus, and a few mirrors. Everything was red, the lights, the bed, the carpet, even the exterior. Like white is the safest car color, I think red makes the most fucking. Itâ€™s behavioral science.
All the women were objectively gorgeous, much more gorgeous than the sex workers I saw in Tijuana a few months prior. They werenâ€™t beaten down either, figuratively speaking. They looked confident, even proud, like hard working small-business owners. Some of them werenâ€™t even dressed scantily and gave off a â€œtake it or leave itâ€ vibe, which I dug. There were no pimps in sight either. Just the ladies and their red rooms.
With each trip down the corridor, I narrowed my selection. Itâ€™s like I was hosting my own NCAA elimination tournament in my brain, only I was pitting lady against lady, with the winner advancing to the next round. Now, I realize what I was doing was waiting for one of them to pick me. If I was going to victimize one of these women, I wanted her to at least feign interest first.
One did. She was white, with long, dark brown hair, and weighed about 150 pounds. She curled her index finger and invited me in, licking it between curls. I was sold.
When I went in, I met the pimp. He may not have been a pimp, but he held the money like a pimp does. And, probably for the best. I gave him 50 Euros and he gave me a single condom. He didnâ€™t say a word. Then, he opened the door to the red room.
Lady: Iâ€™m Tonya. Whatâ€™s your name?
Me: Iâ€™m Sam. (I forgot you can lie in those situations.)
Her bubbliness was gone. Now, she was working. Sheâ€™d already caught her fish; the rest was just fileting.
Lady: Bed or standing?
Me: Uhhh, standing.
She turned around and faced the dresser, gripping the top of it with her hand. She pulled her black panties down and began to prepare herself with one hand, the other braced on the dresser. I took my pants down as well, following her lead. Luckily, I was already prepared. Iâ€™d been prepared since I was in the bar an hour ago.
Lady: Ok, ready.
I tore open the condom and put it on. Then, I inserted myself into her.
She moaned. I gained confidence. I started to go faster, and she moaned more, my confidence growing stronger yet.
I took my left hand and slapped her ass cheek. As soon as I did, the pimp came bursting in.
Pimp: NO, NO, NO! NONE OF THAT!
He was pissed.I looked over at him to apologize for my lapse in judgment, and while doing so, ejaculated into the condom I was wearing, while inside of Tonya. I knew I was jizzing. He knew I was jizzing. I knew he knew I was jizzing.
We both jumped back.
Pimp: Ok, thatâ€™s it youâ€™re done.
Me: But I didnâ€™t even cum.
He pointed to my shriveling dick.
Pimp: Yes, you did.
I had no recourse. There was jizz in the condom and I couldnâ€™t remove it in his presence, causing a smoking gun, â€œGotcha!â€ type of situation. So, I waited until he left the room. I used my eyes to tell him that I was a coward and would pack up and leave expeditiously. He understood, given his experience.
As I got dressed, Tonya started doing a crossword puzzle. She wasnâ€™t paying any mind to me whatsoever. She was on her own time now, and she planned
--

Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

Title: What makes Amsterdam so diverse and progressive compared to the United States?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The Netherlands has proven to be home to a very diverse group of people in my short time here. While researching I found that the US is technically more diverse but given how much larger of a country it is than the Netherlands, different nationalities, cultures, and races tend to be more spread out and isolated as a result. I have been to many large cities in the US (New York, Washington DC, Miami, Detroit, etc.) and while they are all diverse to an extent, it always seems there is one dominant culture or nationality in each city. This is why to me Amsterdam is a true cultural blend with people having heritages from all over the world and potentially living in the same city block. This made me question why the US is like this and how Amsterdam seems so much more diverse than the US even though it statistically is not.
The simple answer is because of the Dutch themselves and their acceptance of immigrants and refugees. The Dutch have, for centuries, been a safe haven of sorts to people from European, Middle Eastern, or Asian countries and this has led to a high number of immigrants fleeing their home country for Amsterdam. The Dutch advocate heavily for inclusion instead of immigration which has allowed these immigrants to feel safe and comfortable in Amsterdam which in turn leads to them staying and starting families. This is enhanced by the fact that they have a labor migration program that helps skilled workers migrate to the country in order to work. This has the effect of also solving holes in the employment market by filling jobs that are most necessary with immigrants who possess those skills. The most recent â€œMulti-year Policy Plan for Social Issuesâ€ spanned the years 2015â€“2018 and focused on anti-discrimination, LGBTQ+ rights, and empowering women. These are all issues the US is just now starting to even address let alone solve.
These factors all relate to the 20th and 21st century and the Netherlands has been around for much longer than that, so things have been trending this way for a long time. The Dutch built an empire through trading in the â€œGolden Eraâ€ which was the 16th and 17th centuries, and this was what, unknown to them, got the ball rolling on making Amsterdam so diverse. The addition of colonies started the trend of immigrants leaving for Amsterdam whether it was under their own free will or not did not affect the outcome. The outcome was that many people from South America, The Caribbean, Indonesia, and India ended up residing in Amsterdam throughout the 17th and 18th centuries.
The Netherlands relied heavily on trade which brought foreigners from other countries to the ports of Amsterdam and Rotterdam. These foreigners were trading with the Dutch, not immigrants from one of their many colonies in this time period. Many of these foreigners became immigrants over time whether for profit, the culture, or whatever reason. In turn, this resulted in an even larger influx of immigrants than that of individuals coming from a colony. Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, this would continue and be more focused on specialization. The Dutch needed people with different skills, and they didnâ€™t care where they came from, how they talked, or what they looked like. The opportunities of the city of Amsterdam were too enticing to some and this is a major factor in my observation of dense clusters of diversity in the city.
The opportunities didnâ€™t stop at just the jobs though, the Netherlands is home to many prestigious schools and universities which also has a role. People do not just immigrate to Amsterdam for jobs, many do it for education. However, when the job and educational opportunities are combined, along with the respect Dutch citizens have for immigrants, people are more likely to completely emigrate to the Netherlands. A lot of foreigners in the US are not immigrants and live in the US on school or work Visas. The negative view Americans have on immigrants results in many of them going back to their home country after their Visa expires. The Netherlands provides them with a home away from home in a sense and ultimately more immigrants chose to stay. Policy: Diversity â€” City of Amsterdam

Title: Changing desires in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Day 44 â€” Amsterdam
I am sitting here on my tiny balcony. The air still feels crisp and humid because of last nightâ€™s rain. There is no doubt, I am back in Holland.
Back in Holland after 3 years of travelling around as a digital nomad.
But for the very first time, I donâ€™t feel an immediate urge to pack my bags and hop back on another plane. Something needs to change first.
When I started my solo trips around Europe a few years ago, I was terrified that I would constantly feel alone. The mere thought of dining alone in restaurants, going to parties where I knew no one, or feeling lost in an unknown city, freaked me out.
And the alternativeâ€”approaching people and socialisingâ€”was even scarier.
But life is different now. I doubt if I will ever lose my moments of social awkwardness, but I made a habit of throwing myself into new situations. I learned how to surf, tried to learn how to dance and turned strangers into close friends.
Living a cliche digital nomad lifestyle. Yet, I am somewhat done with it. It feels like I finally graduated.
Donâ€™t get me wrong. I live a privileged life. I love the adventure, the novelty, the thrill and there is nothing quite like connecting with new people. I love new stories, waiting to be unpacked.
However, the biggest downside of a nomadic life is â€” no surpriseâ€” the fact that everyone leaves again. I know now that it is possible to build deep connections within weeks, sometimes even hours. To cry, laugh and share life stories together.
But maintaining them is a different story. Itâ€™s almost impossible to stay close while being separated by different time zones. Especially for a terrible Whatsappâ€™er like myself.
I struggle with the need to always build new deep connections from scratch. I struggle with friends â€” or myself leaving after a few months. I donâ€™t want that no more. Again, something needs to change.
For years, my biggest desire has been freedom, the freedom to travel and explore the world. But slowly I am witnessing my desires change. Does my longing for freedom still outweigh the struggle of often missing close friends and family?
How do I balance freedom with maintaining deep, long-lasting connections? I canâ€™t simply take my loved ones with me.
Or can I?
Well, I am going to give it a try.
In the upcoming period, I will record conversations with those around me, wherever I am. Much like interviewing famous podcast guests.
Allowing us to dive deeper than casual small talk, and hopefully resulting in an album of conversations â€” souvenirs for when our paths diverge again.
The goal is not to share them publically and rack up millions of downloads. Quite the opposite. I can be a DJ without a crowd. I am recording these conversations to get to know the people in my life better, explore their stories, and to laugh and create lasting memories.
I donâ€™t know if we will like it. But trying is the only way to find out. Trying to lean into whatever excites me, intrigues me, into what I consider meaningful.
And this idea definitely feels meaningful to me.
I am sitting here on my balcony staring at the sky. The sun slowly breaks through. I am feeling the energy of trying something new.
Letâ€™s go.
â€” -During the upcoming period, I will record some podcasts and I am looking for cities to settle instead of always travelling around.
â€œKnow when it is time to move on, know when you graduated.â€
--
--
Currently more active on Substack. Simply loves writing about everything that amazes me. Tries to be honest, personal and vulnerable. All on a personal note.

Title: An Anxious Adventure in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In a life-first, I went on two holidays this year! Iâ€™ve never felt like such a jet-setter, exploring Europe with my friends, staying in the most luxurious hotels that a student budget can buy. My first trip this summer was to Cyprus, and was less adventure and more â€˜letâ€™s lie in the sun with a book and a cocktailâ€™. This time, I was ready to throw relaxation out of the window and hit the cobbled streets of the Netherlandsâ€™ capital.
Amsterdam has a reputation as the chillest of cities, perhaps in part due to its â€˜coffeeshopsâ€™, but this reputation is an absolute lie. I have never been so stressed as I was walking out of Amsterdam Centraal Station in rush hour, only to accidentally stumble into the bike swarm. Everyone riding bikes may be great for the environment, but itâ€™s not great for helpless pedestrians who end up jumping into canals to avoid oncoming cyclists. Everyone from 10-year-old boys to little old grandmas is on their bike, and red lights seem to be considered â€˜optionalâ€™. I found myself muttering â€œgreen man means goâ€ every time I crossed a road, just to try and reassure myself that I wasnâ€™t about to end up tangled in someoneâ€™s handlebars.
I am of the opinion that Amsterdam should no longer be known as the chillest city, but the fittest one. Firstly, everyone is very physically fit. Cycling everywhere and eating loads of herring seems to have made everyone slim. It probably also helps that theyâ€™re all about a foot taller than me, making them look even more beautiful and elven. Beyond physical fitness, everyone is just cute. Me and my highly stylish friend Alethea, featured above, found ourselves doing constant double-takes. The men of Amsterdam put the balding football lads of England to shame. In Amsterdam 45 seems to be the new 20, and they swan around looking tall and handsome on their bikes. I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s the bikes, the pretty scenery, or the weed, but something in Amsterdam clearly keeps you young.
Despite the apparent fountain of youth properties of herring, neither of us indulged. My excuse was being vegetarian, and Aletheaâ€™s was that she didnâ€™t want fish breath that repulses everyone within a mile radius. As our canal cruise guide said: â€œA herring a day keeps the doctor away, two keeps everyone away.â€. That isnâ€™t to say we didnâ€™t sample some other typical Amsterdam delights. Our first stop was FEBO, a fast-food place where you can get hot snacks out of vending machines. There were all sorts of croquettes or meaty options, but we went for KaasoufflÃ© (cheese thatâ€™s breaded and fried). After our grease-fest lunch was complete, we also had to grab some Poffertjes, little Dutch pancakes which I love. It seems that the key to authentic poffertjes is to absolutely slather them in icing sugar and butter, which raised no complaints from me.
Although we seemed to spend most of our time wandering aimlessly through the Jordaan, I did also manage to take in Amsterdamâ€™s famous museum quarter. Alethea had already been to the Van Gogh Museum last year, so I went on a little solo adventure to see the work of one of my all-time favourite artists. The paintings were amazing, but Iâ€™m a speedy museum viewer so I had the whole place scoped out in an hour or so. Once my whistle-stop tour was finished, I had to take the obligatory photo in front of the digital Van Gogh wall, with an expression of extreme regret as everyone stared at me trying to take my selfie. No museum trip is complete without postcards, so I treated myself to a few of my favourite paintings.
Our final night saw us relaxing in a BBQ grill (yes, an odd choice for a vegetarian, I am aware) after our original restaurant choice was full of intimidatingly beautiful and cool Amsterdam youths. It was a lovely end to the trip, with great cider and slightly weird Asian-style nachos. Iâ€™m so glad I finally had the opportunity to tick Amsterdam off my travel bucket list. It doesnâ€™t have the same soft spot in my soul as London does, but itâ€™s very scenic and the perfect place to go if youâ€™re looking to find yourself a gorgeous cycling boyfriend. The 8 hours of trains back to England the next day was rough, especially as I battled a bad case of man flu, but all in all, it was a pretty great adventure.
Next stops on my travel bucket list: Italy, India, and Ireland. Iâ€™m on a mission to tick off the 3 Is in 2020, so stay tuned.
Originally published at https://assortedramblingsblog.wordpress.com on September 27, 2019.
--
--
Feminist, mental health advocate, Netflix obsessed.
