Title: No more messy nights â€” the Amsterdam party is over
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I moved to Amsterdam, 24 years ago, there were innumerable comments along the lines of: â€œOh yeahâ€¦ Amsterdam, eh?! EH?!! Nudge-nudge, wink-wink, EH?!!â€.
To the uninformed I was relocating to a cesspit of iniquity, a European Gomorrah of rampant drug taking and prostitutes for sale in the windows of every street. Everything, people supposed, a single man in his early thirties could desire. Except it wasnâ€™t. Because Amsterdam wasnâ€™t â€” and isnâ€™t â€” like that at all.
Yes, the notorious red light zone de Wallen (â€œthe wallsâ€) exists, with its women â€” most probably sex-trafficked â€” sat in illuminated windows looking bored while awkward men leer at them from the outside. And, as you walk through quaint backstreets, the barely disguised whiff of weed tickles the nostrils as it pours out of semi-legal coffee shops. However, this is just a tiny slice of Amsterdam, one of the jewels of Europe, with its Instagramable canals, medieval architecture, vibrant culture and a history and charm matched only by the likes of Paris, Seville or Prague.
I am naturally biased, having once lived in or near Amsterdam for the better part of a decade, as well as being a frequent visitor for almost 30 years. To some extent, too, the seedier side isnâ€™t as bad as it could be (ditto, Hamburg and its somewhat cartoon-like Reeperbahn), but I get where the city authorities, and indeed the Dutch government, are coming from in wanting to clean it up.
Conscious of this reputation, tourists are even being discouraged from visiting the de facto Dutch capital, though this was initially a measure to cut down on overcrowding. An environmental measure was also introduced to cap flights arriving at Schiphol, Amsterdamâ€™s massive, seven-runway international air hub, which this year alone has reduced the number of flights from the UK by 22% compared with pre-Covid travel. The Netherlands Tourism Board has even been actively promoting places alternatives like Eindhoven â€” a city I know well from my career at Philips, which was founded there.
But with the exception of football nerds wishing to see the PSV Stadion, or the even more niche interest of the Philips lightbulb museum, Eindhoven is largely a â€˜company townâ€™ with little to offer tourists compared to the cultural riches of Amsterdamâ€™s Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum, the Anne Frank House, the canals or the Negen Straatjes (â€˜nine streetsâ€™), not to mention its wealth of cross-culture cuisines.
Amsterdam has always been one of the most welcoming cities in Europe, in one of the worldâ€™s happiest nations, according to research by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. But those same people are understandably tired of the stag-weekenders who spend their time in the city getting drunk, fighting outside bars and urinating in canals (before then falling in), or swaggering about the red light zone leering at its most unfortunate residents.
This has now been reflected by an online campaign specifically targeting 18â€“35-year-old British men, with one ad showing a young man being arrested and put in a cell with the atypically Dutch-blunt caption: â€œSo coming to Amsterdam for a messy night? Stay away.â€
In recent years the city has made efforts to combat the vice industry (believed to be controlled by a combination of rival Turkish and Albanian organised crime), both to cut down on the sex tourism as well as the exploitation of vulnerable women. The drugs trade, run by the same gangs, has long been associated with this, with politicians arguing that the liberal experiment, dating back to the 1970s, which legitimised cannabis use as long as it is sold in limited quantities in coffee shops, has failed. Weed sales have been regarded as a gateway to sales of harder narcotics, all with associated criminality invariably leading to violence.
When I moved to Amsterdam in 1999 moves were already in place to tackle drug tourism, prompting a national ban on the sale of magic mushrooms and an increased regulation of cannabis sales, and aimed at striking a balance between tourism and public safety. Simultaneously, concerns about sex tourism and human trafficking prompted initiatives to regulate prostitution and improve the working conditions of sex workers. There were also measures to reduce the visibility of the red light district, with an effort to redevelop Amsterdamâ€™s central neighbourhoods by encouraging new businesses to move into streets previously dominated by the sex and drug industry.
Sustainable tourism has also been promoted, with a campaign calling for tourists to â€œEnjoy & Respectâ€ Amsterdam, and embrace its rich cultural artistic heritage rather than its seedier attractions. However, in also addressing both â€˜over-tourismâ€™ and sex/drug visitors, businesses relying on tourist euros have expressed their concerns at any effort to drive down undesirabled, especially in the wake of Amsterdamâ€™s post-pandemic recovery.
It is, then, a dilemma. Amsterdam â€” like everywhere else â€” suffered greatly from Covid travel bans and lockdowns, as the cityâ€™s hotels, bars, restaurants and shops saw business plummet. The campaign against young male Brits is targeted, but it is hard yet to gauge whether it will be either effective in achieving its aims, or detrimental to the local economy.
As a champion of Amsterdam, however, anything which can successfully eradicate cityâ€™s â€œnudge-nudge, wink-winkâ€ association, and works to enhance and embrace its unique identity is a good thing.
The city is more than simply a living museum, but its heritage â€” dating back to the 13th century when a small fishing village was established along the Amstel River â€” is more than worthy of protection. This is the city that was at the heart of the Dutch Golden Age in the 18th century, becoming a trading hub, with the construction of its famous ring of canals earning it the â€œVenice of the Northâ€ nickname. Its commercial and artistic foundations are still to be celebrated, either in the traditions established by the Dutch East India Company, one of the worldâ€™s earliest multinationals (and the genetic origin of the Netherlandsâ€™ global business outlook), the foundation of one of the worldâ€™s first stock exchanges â€” the â€œBeursâ€ (although Belgiumâ€™s Bruges lays claim to the oldest, its bourse), not to mention the work of Rembrandt and Vermeer during that same era.
There are those who see the see the discouragement of tourists looking to have the wrong kind of good time as being to Amsterdamâ€™s financial detriment, not to mention to the detriment of its charm. But, just as New York â€” established as New Amsterdam â€” cleaned itself up in the early 1990s to its immeasurable benefit as a tourist destination, Amsterdamâ€™s crackdown on Brits seeking to exploit its underbelly will go a long way to lessen the profile of that reputation. It will surely only enhance what those like me who know it, know it to be the real Amsterdam.
--
--
Journalist-turned-corporate communications leader keeping his hand in writing with the blog Where Are We Now? and its musings on music, culture and more.

Title: Solo in Amsterdam: a trip report
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My vision when I agreed to volunteer with U.Gent was not to spend a ton of time in cities, but I had a weekend to myself and thought that traveling might be a better use of my time than remaining in the home city. So I decided to go to Amsterdam. Its appeal to me was greater than that of Paris, the next-nearest major city. Following my positive experience day-tripping to Bruges, the idea was to have a chilled out weekend in a well-touristed place, where most sights would be accessible and friendly to English-speakers. Legal weed was a cherry on top. The weekend wound up being far from relaxing, but I gained some largely superficial impressions of the city, and learned more lessons on spur-of-the-moment traveling.
The journey began in Antwerp, the city thatâ€™s hated by Belgians the same way that Boston is hated by other New Englanders. According to residents it is â€œTHE cityâ€, and the rest of Belgium just serves as parking. Iâ€™d made a note to not visitâ€¦. but all trains to the Netherlands route you through Antwerp so I had no choice in that matter. The Antwerp train station precipitates the start of what feels like a real European adventure to the Other Low Country. Itâ€™s three levels of rails stacked one on top of the next. The surface level is vaulted in an expansive glass arc of windows and decorated with enough marble and carved stone to impress all of the inferior non-residents arriving to its port. The atrium between the two sides of tracks plunges all three stories underground where itâ€™s cold like a cave. This is the level reserved for the long distance trains. I squint up at the glasswork far above. Here it is dark save for pulses of neon blue light on the pillars. I understand that Gentians see this place as stuck up, but the train station makes me believe it actually is modern and cool. I feel like Gretel wandering into the deep woods in this vast place in a little starry summer dress and a bag on my side.
Iâ€™m told by a man on the train that Amsterdam â€œis not the Netherlandsâ€. Itâ€™s like Antwerp in the sense that everyone who actually lives in the country hates it. I am not deterred but a little more curious as to what Iâ€™ll find there. International travel is uneventful within the Schengen region of the E.U. and there was no indication of when we crossed the border of Belgium into the Netherlands.
The buildings are like a solemn box of chocolates (or tombstones), all blacks and dark browns with white window frames. This contrasts the sandier and whiter Low Citites of Gent and Brugge. Itâ€™s like the city is perpetually bracing for a terrible storm, or a long-dark winter. The barges and houseboats are stoically shaped, not flashy or fun. Itâ€™s beautiful, but looks at home in cloudy weather and rain. This aesthetic contrasts with the most famous decorative themes of the region: tulips and painted porcelain tiles (interestingly, both imported from Persia in the days of the Ottoman Empire). I like to think the cultural obsessions with these things were precipitated in part by the otherwise complete colorlessness of the city landscape. Certainly both tulips and tiled surfaces are natural fits with the damp, mild temperatures of the region. I like that the city uses the abundant water and flatness for transportation by boat and bicycle. It feels integrated with its surroundings.
Iâ€™d like to say that these were my first impressions of the city, but they were not. My first impression was of the second-largest crush of tourists Iâ€™ve ever seen after Times Square. The downtown streets are fraught with people wandering aimlessly, stopping dead in their tracks and struggling with ungainly loads of luggage and bags. Thereâ€™s a huge difference between this behavior in diffuse, manageable situations and at this scale. I find it really stressful, especially as I attempt to find a bike, an affordable place to sleep last-minute, and finally some orientation to the city. There is a telling lack of thru-traffic that suggests the locals aggressively avoid the historic downtown. I turn my first corner in the narrow alleys between the dark brick buildings and come face to face with three head shops, side by side. There are some young-looking burnouts on cushions gazing at the street from an open-air cafe, sitting beneath a canopy of Far-East-looking scarves. Clouds of pot smoke roll onto the street. I question the authenticity of everything I see. Thereâ€™s no speaking among tourists: a man and woman loudly drawl to one another in North Carolinan accents, then politely nod and bow to me in an attempt to silently indicate they want to get by. I sense that everyone here speaks English but we are unwilling to assume it of each other.
Amsterdam appears to be the European equivalent of Las Vegas as a destination for epic bachelor/ette parties. Small herds of men or women (exclusively single gender groups) trawl by, dressed in matching t-shirts or costumes. Usually one of their numbers is dressed even more ridiculously than their companions: fur coats, fake breasts, and several animal onesies among the sightings. There was a lot of broken glass on the ground, and some of those twelve-person bicycle tour carts that have a keg in the middle.
The boats on the canals appeared to carry a possibly more local crowd. Although there were barges of well-behaved tourists, some aboard for city history and others for wine and cheese, there were other smaller private barges cruising the downtown. These hummed with loud music, full of assorted young men and women looking for all the world like an Abercrombie and Fitch ad. Their leisure time was on display for all as they crawled by just below street-level.
The Red Light district really is everything that its depictions in crappy movies have promised. There were even actual red lights! The first time I saw a prostitute in a window I thought she was a poorly-dressed mannequin until she moved. In Amsterdam there seems to be a culture that is defensive of the sex workersâ€™ rights, privacy and respectful of their profession. I wondered whether I was supposed to give them a nod of solidarityâ€¦ although none were bothering to make eye contact with female passersby. Turns out white lingerie really pops under UV light. I walked by some fascinating shops â€” leather and rubber clothing boutiques; lingerie and toys suitable for every kind of body; sex shows; and an overabundance of racy souvenir shops that touted glassware, cannabis ice cream (no psychoactive effects, it just happens to contain cannabis) and some truly alarming postcards. I can only imagine what would happen if you turned a group of 18â€“19 year-old Americans loose over here. Everything, every vice is available and visible in shop windows. It strikes me that rule-breaking and drug theory by word-of-mouth is a large part of the novelty of American illicit-substance culture. How many wannabe Dharma Bums and Gonzo Journalists would become disillusioned if they could just pop into a shop and purchase mind-altering substances from a professional?
A couple years ago the Netherlands proposed a ban on visitors purchasing recreational drugs. Store owners and residents protested, claiming that the subsequent influx of illegal dealers would cause far worse problems for their urban areas. So now, any person over 18 can purchase whatever they want at dispensaries and koffieshops, the latterâ€™s marijuana distributing license indicated with a subtle green and white sticker in the front window. There were formal and handwritten signs scattered throughout the red light district discouraging the purchase of drugs from street dealers. The signs the same vocabulary you might expect on a sign discouraging people from feeding the squirrels: â€œThey are violent and aggressiveâ€. There were similar signs prohibiting the use of hard drugs.
Drug dispensaries were situated abreast of all other shops in the historic downtown (and, I assume, are scattered throughout the city in lower densities). They seem to keep marijuana separate from places that sell other recreational drugs. I found the reading material on the counters of these dispensaries to be fascinating for its professional and informative tone: each variety of MDMA or psychedellic mushrooms was listed with the exact potency, chemical content and characteristics as well as all potential risks. Some stores had small lounges in the back stocked with incense and picture books.
The koffieshops I investigated ran the gamut from seedy underground dives to quiet and pleasant airy street-level establishments â€” they all do sell coffee, anyhow â€” but no alcohol. The strains of weed available were presented like a wine list, with variety names displayed next to a series of smiley faces indicating their characteristics. A joint costs about $3.75 USD.
Late at night I saw a crowd gathering around the front window of a pub: just inside were about seven raucous French or Italian men, all wearing surreal Mr. Bean masks and posing for photos by the streetwalkers below. I walked into a club filled with blacklight and guys and girls with glow-painted faces. Heavy fog was provided by the abundance of assorted smoke. It could have been a music video. At midnight I followed a crowd of â€œWoo girlsâ€ away from the center of town towards where Iâ€™d left my bike (itâ€™s impossible to cycle in the tourist district). All wore matching pink tutus and pink and black striped socks. There were several open bottles of wine and liquor between them and they would periodically rally to shriek â€œWOOOOOOâ€ while doodling over the sidewalks like bees through a field. Street performers, cafe-diners and other pedestrians would WOOOO back, or playfully swerve towards them.
The best part of my just-over-24 hours in Amsterdam was my late night bike ride out to my hostel. The tourist clots disappeared once free from the Red Light district, although chatter from isolated cafes and clubs wafted from the buildings. I rode along the Amstel on a bricked bike path. It was, like every other bicycling experience here, supremely flat and smooth. I cruised along silently, the clamor and stimulation of the perpetual tourist party fuzzing to white noise as I contemplated the stern facades of buildings now bathed in flat orange lamplight. The river was smooth and black and the barges were moored until morning. The night air was cool so long as I maintained some speed, and I saw more pedestrians than cars in the shadowy black and orange side streets. I began to imagine the mode of transportation suitable for this dream-world Amsterdam and found I was at a loss â€” nothing short of boats piloted through the air, animated serpentine dragons and other space-bending means seemed appropriate. It was a still, and magical time and I felt like any number of impossible things could happen in such an environment.
Morning breaks over Amsterdam and Iâ€™m unsure of what Iâ€™ll do. The rain is on â€œsoakâ€ setting outside and it strikes me as appropriate weather for this land of heavy black bicycles, heavy black rivers, heavy black boats and heavy, precariously forward-drooping black buildings. The desperation of yesterdayâ€™s fight to secure housing and maintain personal space is behind me: after the otherworldly spectacle of Midnight Amsterdam I slept heavily in an unexpectedly dark, quiet and clean location. Unfortunately my quest for good breakfast leads me inevitably to a tourist cafe. The Low Countries do not go out for breakfast. The streets are deserted until about noon, and I use the solitude to poke around residential neighborhoods. Their canals are swollen with fresh rain. Wisteria was made for a black brick facade in such an environment. I drift like a balloon on the breeze into the cityâ€™s little Tulip Museum. It feels homemade despite its slick graphics, and is very apparently curated by people who geek out about rare tulips in the same way that others might revere rare birds or cars. The section on wild tulips makes a compelling case for visiting Kazakhstanâ€¦ a very compelling case. On the street I pass a squinty-eyed guy in a marijuana-leaf print windbreaker and sweatpants, leaning against the rail of a canal bridge and providing apparently unhelpful information to his girlfriend, who is staring blankly at the screen of a phone.
Thereâ€™s a postcard of some of the cityâ€™s graffiti: the iconic portrait of Anne Frank in black and white, bedecked with a colored hipster scarf. My interpretation of the artistâ€™s message is that if she were around today, sheâ€™d be invited to be a part of their crew. I wonder when some of the buildings will finally slump over into the street, when the city stopped being a major port, so many questions unanswered as a result of my own lack of research. I head to the city library, a great five or six-storied structure on the waterfront with the best view of the historic city (all skyscrapers are relegated to the outskirts). The library is an awesome building, with creative, modern architecture, fun reading nooks with curtains and space-age chairs, art installations and interpretive material. Some books are in Dutch, others in English. There is an installation about a proposed plan to renovate the downtown historic district. Amsterdam fears â€œThe Venice Syndromeâ€: having a downtown economy so reliant on tourists that there is no longer means for residents to survive. They reference New York (never forgoing an opportunity to mention that originally it was New Amsterdam) as a city that is modern, vital and still remains a tourist destination. I admire the cityâ€™s fight to reclaim its downtown. On my way out Iâ€™m interviewed by several schoolgirls who claim to be doing a project for their English class. They tell me some riddles whose punchlines are somewhat lost in translation. I pass a flock of tourists, mesmerized by a tiny 3D printer at work in a shop window. I consider the myriad other technologies and symbols of progress that have been on display in these shops since the construction of the city. Perhaps there is a future for this place not entirely rooted in its past.
Lessons learned:
-You canâ€™t wait til day-of to book a Couchsurfer destination or a hostel on a weekend.
-When things start going wrong in an unfamiliar environment, eat something. Or have a coffee. Or both.
-Donâ€™t second guess expenditures once theyâ€™ve been made.
-Research the cost of getting to and from your destination and adjust your expectations of further costs from that number.
-Being alone and female invites lots of attention from strangers. In other places this has been fine, but in Amsterdam I felt like I could get lost down a crack in the crowded tourist party. Related: If you think you might want to do anything edgy, bring someone else.
-Either research the good spots in advance or go on the advice of othersâ€¦ but do one. Especially for areas with cultural significance (as compared to just wilderness significance, which Iâ€™d argue is more amenable to uninformed interpretation).
Under what conditions would I return to Amsterdam?
-At night, especially at night in the snow for the aesthetic experience
-If I could avoid the crowded Red Light District unless friends and I had explicit plans to be there
-If Iâ€™d read some more history, particularly literature, about the somber maritime town
-If I had a map of the anonymous sculpturework squirreled away around the city, and other hidden treasures.
Honestly, you might be better off with Gent. Older, less somber, same amount of bikes and almost as many canals, but no herds of tourists and instead, a vital city. No pot either, but eyyy. Perhaps I too am learning to appreciate the shadow of the local steeple.
--
--
Conservation, women, adventure â€” not necessarily in that order.

Title: Amsterdam: So Many Bicycles
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

An art and photography publication focused on visual narrative in storytelling.

Member-only story
--
9
Share
If you are at all familiar with Amsterdam youâ€™ll know that one of the main sources of transportation is the bicycle. Whether youâ€™ve been there yourself, or seen it in movies and TV shows, bicycles are one of the main characters of the city.
If you are a pedestrian, as you wander the streets itâ€™s quite a feat to stay out of the way of those who are on two wheels. It is not always easy.
Thankfully they have bells on their bikes and they are not afraid to use them!
As a photographer, the bikes make it easy to find little scenes within the areas you wander. They make a great subject and help tell the story of Amsterdam in your photos.
--
--

Title: Business Trip to Amsterdam in 7 Shots
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
From the end of March to the beginning of April, I was on a business trip to the companyâ€™s headquarters in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
The first week was primarily to attend the company event, and the second week was to get trainings. Besides the fixed agenda, there was almost always something cool that kept me busy.
In this article, I will share the highlights of the trip.
At the company event, there were multiple sessions where peers from each team went up on the stage to present their teamâ€™s updates and insights.
Not only was it a great opportunity for new joiners like myself to get a holistic understanding of the company, but it was also almost shocking how excellent of public speakers they all were.
During my stay, I challenged myself to go out with someone I donâ€™t know every day after work (and completed the challenge).
When the company and industry is growing so fast, I feel inclusivity and knowing who to reach out to for the right information play a crucial role in assisting oneâ€™s performance.
Starting my stay as Europe switched to the summer time clocks, I enjoyed watching the sun rise in the morning from my 5th-floor hotel room.
The lines of brick houses and a spider web of waterway that runs in-between the lines gave such exotic vibes.
One Thursday after work, my colleagues and I decided to take a ride into a forest. We rented a bike by the central station and got on the way for about an hour.
I have two things to say about the dutch bikes. One â€” I was not expecting to back-pedal for brakes so it took me a moment to learn how to stop without causing a scene. Two â€” they are not Asian-legs friendly. After lowering the seat as far as it allowed, I was still tiptoeing to reach the pedals.
After the hour ride, we arrived at the park with full of cherry blossom.
As I was expecting to miss the cherry blossom season in my hometown Tokyo, it was certainly a pleasant surprise.
The morning after I landed in Amsterdam, I visited a CrossFit box near one of the headquarter offices. As such an exercise is becoming a key in my productive days, it was important that I find a place in Amsterdam as well.
Except, some pieces of the equipment were made so tall for me (like the bars for pull ups) that I could not reach without placing a box to step on. That was embarrassing.
It is an honor to be introduced to such an intelligent and generous group of people. The fact that I am in a place that allows me to learn from them and grow together with them brings nothing but pure excitement and motivation.
It was merely my 6th week in at the company, however, the company has made me feel welcome. I am excited to be part of their journey!
--
--
ğŸ“•Published author of Behind the Uniform Skirt. Here to document my journey as a writer with you.

Title: 5 Underexplored Areas in Amsterdam: For If You Just HAVE to Visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I already wrote a piece about the tourism industry in Amsterdam and how itâ€™s completely out of control. So, my first recommendation is to definitely go to other Dutch cities if you can. However, Iâ€™m still torn by the fact that I love my adopted city and hope that others can experience and fall in love with it in much the same way that I did.
Most tourists never go out of the Center (Centraal) area of Amsterdam. While there are certainly cool canals, beautiful architecture, and a ton of historical monuments, the Center is just one small part of the incredibly varied tapestry that is this beautiful city.
So, if you absolutely HAVE to visit Amsterdam, consider easing the tourism crisis by finding a hotel in or exploring one of these areas.
My absolute favorite area of Amsterdam. Green is the operative word here as there are trees and parks EVERYWHERE! Go to Oosterpark, with a huge open green space, some interesting sculptures, and the National Slavery Monument (commemorating the end of slavery in the Netherlands). Oh, itâ€™s also right behind the Tropenmuseum (Tropical Museum), which was originally created to showcase and educate Amsterdammers on The Netherlandsâ€™ colonial properties overseas but has been turned into a way for the Dutch to grapple with and better understand this bloody history. Itâ€™s definitely not perfect but theyâ€™re trying much harder than a number of other museums (*cough* British Museum *cough*).
Also in Amsterdam Oost is the Dappermarkt, one of the several excellent outdoor markets around Amsterdam. Itâ€™s open Tuesday â€” Saturday and has delicious food, clothing, and just about anything you could ever want with some really good prices.
De Plantage is a set of islands perched between Amsterdam Oost and Centraal. Itâ€™s notable for the beautiful architecture, trees and parks everywhere, as well as HORTUS and ARTIS. HORTUS is the Royal Botanical Gardens and has a great collection. Honestly, while ARTIS is nice, unless you have kids, there are much better (and cheaper) zoos to go visit in other cities.
This area is definitely one of the most underexplored AND undervalued parts of Amsterdam. Think Brooklyn before it got overly gentrified (but itâ€™s on its wayâ€¦). Noord used to be considered a working-class area, with shipyards, docks, and factories. In the second half of the 20th Century much of that industry began to move out, especially as Amsterdam moved from being a regional town to a world-class city. Eventually, Amsterdam figured out that there was a huge underdeveloped area just north of Central Station (which makes it a great place to stay when youâ€™re visiting *hint hint*). Today, you can still see remnants of that history, as most of the industrial areas were repurposed to house various enterprises.
While you wonâ€™t see any historic canal houses, this side of Amsterdam showcases the â€˜alternative, counter-cultureâ€™ heritage that the city is known for. Notable things to see are the Boatel, a cruise ship fully repurposed as a hotel, Cafe De Ceuvel, a start-up eco village made of old houseboats, working to clean up a former boatyard and promote environmentalism, and the monthly flea market at NDSM Wharf.
The De Pijp district of Amsterdam was originally known for being like Amsterdam Noord is now, working-class homes and businesses that eventually gentrified. Except, thatâ€™s already fully happened now. De Pijp is fully 100% gentrified. Not to say that there arenâ€™t fun things to do, just that youâ€™re going to find about 3 gluten-free, vegan, holistic, non-GMO jackfruit pulled pork/burger places for about every person who lives there. There is so much dining but often at slightly higher prices (and more Americanized) than what youâ€™ll usually pay in other areas of Amsterdam.
The big star attraction of De Pijp is the Albert Cuypmarkt, the largest outdoor market in Amsterdam. This is the big one and it is super-impressive. Weekdays are mostly vendors selling tourist things but Saturday is the best day for a visit, with real Amsterdammers coming to do their shopping.
Other fun things to do include taking a load off in Sarphatipark, one of Amsterdamâ€™s most impressive parks, heading to the Heineken Experience to see the original brewery, or walking over to Museumplein to visit the Van Gogh or Rijksmuseum (book tickets ahead of time). Ok, technically Museumplein isnâ€™t in De Pijp but itâ€™s right next door so Iâ€™m counting it.
This area is characterized by big, old 19th century warehouses, lovingly restored to become housing/event space/bars, etc. This entire area used to be for loading and unloading all kinds of cargo ships, especially once Amsterdam Central Station was built, which changed some of the harbor space.
Stop by De Gooyer, one of the few windmills still located within the Amsterdam city limits and have a drink next door at Brouwerij â€˜t IJ, the first microbrewery in Amsterdam. Located in a converted bathhouse, its logo is an ostrich with a large egg, which is a Dutch pun. IJ (pronounced like ai) is a well-known river in Amsterdam which also sounds like ei, the Dutch word for egg.
Also while youâ€™re here, take a stroll down Czaar Peterstraat, a beautiful tree-lined boulevard with cute shops and fun places to stop. Itâ€™s one of my favorite streets because itâ€™s just so peaceful, you canâ€™t believe youâ€™re still in Amsterdam.
In the summer, walk down to the Marineterrein. Part Dutch naval base, part public access swimming pool, this area is one of the more interesting areas in the city. While part of the Marineterrein is a fully-functioning military base (DO NOT TRESPASS!), a small part has been opened up along the water. Signs are very clear and gates are incredibly obvious. You can enter from the south entrance at Kattenburgerstraat or from the north entrance at the Kommandantsbrug (near Mediamatic). Come for one of the closest areas to Centraal where you can both swim and grab food/drinks at the conveniently-located bar. Definitely a hidden gem.
Anyway, thatâ€™s all I have for right now! Stay tuned for more travel tips and please consider helping to ease the Amsterdam tourism crisis by staying or visiting these other areas of town!
--
--
Trans bisexual woman living in The Netherlands

Title: Adventure in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam is a gorgeous city with beautiful canals and architecture. I was lucky enough to explore it this summer with my mom and my grandparents.
When my mom and I arrived, we took a taxi to the hotel. It was a Tesla. The driver said that soon, most taxis in Amsterdam would be Teslas, to help the environment. We checked in at the Pulitzer hotel, which was made up of 6 canal houses.
The first thing we did was walk around. The Pulitzer was situated on a canal, near the city center, so there was lots to see. First, we visited the Tulip Museum. Tulips used to be a very valuable item in the Netherlands. The best tulips could be sold for almost as much as a house!
Then we stopped for a snack at Pancakes. Amsterdam. Dutch pancakes were kind of like French crepes. They were delicious. After our pancakes, we walked back to the hotel and asked for directions to Momo, a sushi restaurant. It was a 2o minute walk. We had sushi and steamed fish for dinner.
The next day we did the Flowers of Amsterdam Tour with Hanneke. We went to a flower factory and saw flowers being carried away for auctioning and exportation. Next we went to a rose grower. There were rows of roses and each of them smelled fantastic. There were also lots of animals. Fish and turtles in a pond, chickens, and kittens.
After, we went to the town of Haarlem and explored. We had lunch and went to the oldest science museum in the Netherlands. When we got back, we met my grandparents and had delicious Thai food for dinner.
At 10:00am the next day, we had a small group tour about Jewish history. It was pretty long and not very fun, in my opinion. It was a lot of lecturing from our tour guide. We learned a lot, but it was boring. Then late in the afternoon, we went on a boat for a tour of the canals. It was relaxing and enjoyable.
We had another tour with Hanneke at the Rijksmuseum, an art museum. We saw a variety of different painting from different artists, the highlight being the Night Watch, by Rembrandt. We ate lunch at the Rijksmuseum. Then we were supposed to take a painting class but they switched the location on us and we couldnâ€™t make it.
Then we took the tram to the The Royal Concertgebouw and saw the Robeco Jazzclub show. It was my first Jazz show and I thought it was pretty good. We had Chinese food for dinner at Chang-i.
The next day we went relaxed and went shopping at the 9 streets. We didnâ€™t really do much.
In the early morning, we did a photo shoot on the streets of Amsterdam. It was fun and we got great pictures. Next we went to the Anne Frank House. It was amazing how they hid for so long in such a tiny space. Then at night, we went back to the Concertgebouw and saw a string quartet. They did cool things with their instruments and had a dog machine and lights.
The next day was the Amsterdam Pride Parade. It went on for hours. Boats on the canal paraded by filled with crowds of people dressed up and flourishing signs. The horde of people watching screamed and shouted. It was chaotic.
The next day, we went to Schiphol Airport and flew home.
--
--

Title: Mobility in Amsterdam: How the Bicycle City Becomes Electric
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Next Level German Engineering: Where innovation meets tradition. The Porsche technology hub to create tomorrow.

--
Listen
Share
As beautiful as the view of Amsterdamâ€™s canals with the beautiful brick houses around them is, they cause many problems regarding mobility. The narrow alleyways alongside the small canals have only one lane, which leads to traffic jams. A mixture of commuter and delivery traffic, as well as crowds of tourists, quickly congest the picturesque alleyways. The consequences are far-reaching: In a study by the environmental organization Milieudefensie, the European limit for nitrogen oxide was exceeded on no fewer than four roads in Amsterdam in 2016. On the street Stadhouderskade, which runs right through the city, they measured the highest value across the country.
Since then, the city of Amsterdam implemented various projects to tackle the problem including new regulations and the switch to electric mobility.
The title of the initiative â€œAmsterdam electricâ€ shows as simple as clearly where the city is heading in the coming years. Amsterdam is already recognized as a bicycle city and is now set to become a global figurehead for electric mobility. The purchase of electric cars has been subsidized for years now, along with a steadily growing network of charging points (already the best in the world according to the Urban Mobility Index) and a change in the type of engine in taxi and delivery traffic.
Especially for taxis, Amsterdam wants to become a European role model for electric mobility. Currently, 650 e-taxis are already on the roads, which corresponds to a share of 16 percent â€” and the trend is rising. Anyone who wants to spontaneously drive electrically through the streets of Amsterdam can use one of the 350 electric cars from car-sharing provider Share Now. By the way, the switch to electric drives applies equally to land and water: by 2025, all gasoline and diesel-powered boats are to be banned in the city center.
Eventually, the plan is not limited to the drive of the cars, but to reduce the private cars on the street in general. Bit by bit they will disappear from the cityscape. Currently, 1,500 parking spaces are being removed annually until 2025 and will be used to widen sidewalks, create more green spaces or make more space for bicycles. Be it for cycle paths or for bicycle parking lots, which the bicycle city always lacks. After all, there are streets in Amsterdam which have ten times more cars than bicycles.
Just under 60 percent of Amsterdamâ€™s residents ride their bicycles every day and take advantage of the excellent infrastructure that already exists. But here too, growth demands new measures. Over the past 20 years, the proportion of cyclists in the city has risen by a proud 40 percent. To ensure that the Dutch capital can continue to live up to its reputation as a cycling city, the network of cycle paths is constantly being expanded and improved. In addition, in the near future, the construction of large-scale cycle paths across the city will make cycling even more attractive as an alternative to the car, even for longer distances.
In comparison to other metropolises, however, you will look in vain for stationless bikes and e-scooters in Amsterdam for spontaneous app rental. They are simply prohibited. On the one hand, the traffic in the narrow alleys along the canals probably does not get along too well with badly parked bikes and scooters. Additionally, the authorities are afraid that those rental bikes and scooters will be found in the water as it happened in Paris.
The most important part of public transport in Amsterdam is the tram, which runs through the city on 14 lines and a total of 200 kilometers of track. The number 2 line, which has been described by National Geographic as one of the most beautiful tram lines in the world, has recently gained particular prominence. For more than 110 years, the tram has been running along the main artery of the city, connecting the top sights of Amsterdam. If at some point you get aching muscles after extensive testing of the cycle paths, you only need a day ticket and you can treat yourself to the full Amsterdam experience.
Markus Herrmann is a blogger, author and member of the successful podcast â€œGÃ¤steliste Geisterbahnâ€. For Porsche, he is testing the mobility level of the Back 2 Tape metropolises in Europe.
The project â€œBack 2 Tapeâ€ is a cooperation between the Porsche Newsroom and music journalist Niko Backspin. It follows the tracks of hip hop in Europe. All further information on this project can be found in the Porsche Newsroom.
An important note: Markusâ€™ trip through Europe as well as â€œBack 2 Tapeâ€ were produced before the outbreak of COVID-19. Porsche, Backspin and the involved agencies and artists are aware of their social responsibility and advise against such a trip at this time out of consideration for the health and well-being of all people.
--
--
Next Level German Engineering: Where innovation meets tradition. The Porsche technology hub to create tomorrow.
Thereâ€™s more to Porsche than sports cars // #NextVisions is a platform about smart technologies and the people that drive our digital journey.

Title: How I discovered Amsterdam, the city behind the touristic veil
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The first time I saw Amsterdam, like most people, I got swept away in a sea of touristic elements. I couldnâ€™t see past them. I didnâ€™t know how.
Iâ€™m not alone in that. Many people never get to know the true Amsterdam, the city that build the tourism, and that is now being transformed by its own creation.
The historical city center and the areas in its direct vicinity are being transformed to serve the economic needs of this particular demographic: shops, hotels, airbnbâ€™s and bars. Unfortunately due to the steep rise in prices, local producers are relocating or closing their doors as big name brands are sweeping in depersonalizing the character that started it all.
Some say this is bad, others say this is the natural order of things. The city is evolving based on the present social, cultural and economic developments and we must embrace that. Either way, for the time being, there are still enough elements of the original character to be discovered and experienced.
To make it clear, when I talk about the original character of the city, I am referring to more than just historical elements. There are many newer developments or redevelopments of the past that preserve the creative, bold, artistic, outspoken yet intimate character of the city.
So how did I finally meet Amsterdam? By volunteering for Open Monumentendag Amsterdam, in English: Amsterdam Heritage Days.
European Heritage Days is a cultural event that takes place in 50 countries across Europe. For the two days of the second weekend of September, an impressive number of monuments open their doors to the general public. Some, such as museums or cultural institutions, are indeed accessible also throughout the rest of the year. However a large number of them, such as private homes or offices are open to the public only during this particular event.
In The Netherlands, the event is called Open Monumentendag and it is a really big affair, both for the organisation as well as for the ever growing audience. Each city organizes events, tours and lectures. Massive numbers of volunteers participate every year in order to make sure each location is taken care of and, my favorite thing ever, many children participate as junior guides providing visitors with beautiful explanations. The only downside, for my point of view is that as a volunteer you only get to see that one city. To see another one, Iâ€™d have to give up volunteering for that year or choose to help another city.
I have been part of this amazing project for a couple of years now. It is one of my most favorite weekends of the year and it has provided me with a few special moments. The first time I participated I was rather afraid to go out there and deal with the crowds, so I opted for the desk role. Half way through the weekend we ended up one person short, so I had to get out there. The very moment that turned things around and jolted me to see the beauty of the event was when I arrived at one of the big locations in the center of the city. At the entrance of the monument the line was â€¦ big. Really big! There wasnâ€™t any way for me to pass through and get to the organizers inside. So I stopped. And as I stood there, unsure of how to proceed further, some of the people noticed my T-shirt (we all get special T-shirts to show we are part of the event). The news spread and in a matter of seconds the entire row moved one step to the right so I could pass. After the initial shock and surprise, I felt rather cocky about it! My very own 15 minutes of fame. Ha! Ha! Ha! But in all seriousness, that showed me how people feel about this event and the level of interaction that is attained despite the fact that most visitors donâ€™t know one another.
As a tourist one often ends up thinking that the center of the city is the most representative image. And while it is full of architectural and historical treasures, Amsterdam is much more complex than that. A city is made by its people. A city expresses itself through its people and their expression and implicitly through its residential and public areas. Touristic locations have a tendency to drown the local spirit. So the way to understand a city is to go further and search for unadulterated local life and surroundings. Now, Amsterdam itself as a major touristic and international hub has by now integrated some of its internationality in its layers. Thus its local flavor is a rather unique one.
My personal experience includes discovering neighborhoods of Amsterdam School architecture of an extraordinary charm, a luxury lounge of royal class at Amsterdam Central, a large variety of Art Deco, treasures hidden in plain sight, a cat cafe (Bonus. Not part of the event.), an amazing array of windows, giving directions to an American tourist who comes to the event on a yearly basis, walking through the narrowest passage in the city and so much more!
The personal experience of discovering a city outside of standard tourism adds to the connections and memories we make. And so, you should have your own story of meeting a city and that should ideally happen in your own time and style. That is why I have no plan for you, no instructions and no list of fancy museums to see. I will leave you however, a few of the places that surprised me and their experience.
The Crane Building
The Crane Building might sound like a modern exuberance, but the crane has been there since 1957. It is the only crane to have survived the Second World War bombings.
It is now famous for the three story apartment that can be rented for quite the price. It has made the news more than once, for more than being an interesting sightseeing point and it has a truly amazing view.
The apartment is an interesting experience. Though I would not recommend it during cold times as some of the circulation between floors is external and the steps are not for the fainted heart. It is also surprisingly spacious particularly when compared to the matchboxes presently advertised due to the high demand during this housing crisis.
The Mercatorbuurt
Probably the most impactful element for me, as an architect, was the unexpected combination of elegance and cosines of the architectural style Amsterdam School. Neighborhoods such as the Mercatorbuurt arenâ€™t your usual touristic attractions. There are no weird or famous museums. There are however incredible details and hidden elements in every facade.
Iâ€™ve been rediscovering in many of my recent trips the impressive level of craftsmanship in brick work that older Dutch architecture had reached. The more I look at new and modern facades, the more I wonder how did that get lost. And ironically I already know the answer. Budget wise it is much easier to build a plain facade than to actually create an intricate brick design on its facade. But how much did we lose in terms of character and beauty? Now, donâ€™t get me wrong, Iâ€™m not advocating discarding modern architecture. I believe however, that reviving and adapting this traditional element can only be beneficial for present time Dutch architecture.
The Elephant Ally
De Oliphantsgang, in English, The Elephant Ally is a narrow path between two buildings leading to The Golden Tulip. I know, itâ€™s just a small and narrow alley. But I really loved the fancy name, the unassuming door, the texture of the walls as well as the surprise of the interior garden on the other side.
The Golden Tulip is the name of the house found on the location of the oldest brick house in Amsterdam. Due to its bad condition, the house has been disassembled and completely rebuilt in 1993. It presently houses the National Musical Instruments Fund, known for the fact that it gives talented musicians the possibility to loan high quality musical instruments.
Amsterdam Noord
I jumped over the â€œpondâ€ to meet Amsterdam Nood (Amsterdam North) for the very first time in my third year as a volunteer. Presently, the only way to get there is a ferry, travelling on a strict schedule and at a fast pace. No worry though, they are working on it.
Many cities developed on the line of a river have first made use of one side and only moved across once new buildings would have been located too far from the center. So, I assumed, Iâ€™m sorry Amsterdam! that was also the case of Amsterdam and that its northern area was a rather new development with recent architecture. Boy, was I wrong! It is full of old, beautiful, brick, cozy, intimate architecture.
Tuinpark Buitenzorg
The oldest allotment park in the city Tuinpark Buitenzorg forms together with its neighboring forest W.H. Vliegenbos, an important ecological zone rich in biodiversity.
Compared to other allotment parks that I have visited, this one had a completely different character. The explosion of vertical green meant each plot was a little bit of a surprise. Every little house had its own personality and all the plots were carefully maintained.
Unfortunately the waiting list for such a lovely piece of nature is at the moment 15 years.
This article is not sponsored. It is a summary of my experience as a volunteer for several years. If youâ€™d like to know more about the Amsterdam event and and keep current with its details you can do so either on the main website or on their Facebook page. Similarly you can find pages for the event taking place in other cities around The Netherlands as well as in 50 other countries across Europe.
--
--
Architect | The Netherlands | Social and cultural anthropology aficionado â€” Discussing residential architecture on www.archi-re.com

Title: Amsterdam â€” A Prelude
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
3 different trips of varying lengths, right from 4 hours to 7 days has given me a good insight into this amazingly vibrant city.
For all those thinking this post is gonna be about the coffee shops, red light district and other decadence that this city has come to be known for, I would suggest you head else where. In my eyes, the city is so much more than the chaos of Dam Square, the drunken debauchery at Leidseplein or the feverish squeals of teenage boys at seeing the red light district for the first time. Donâ€™t get me wrong, those areas are not to be missed and do head out into town and hop into the nearest bar to down your glass of the Dutch Genever but then make sure to uncover the actual appeal of the city too.
So here are my top things to do in Amsterdam.
This is the best advice I received a couple of years back from a friend. If you truly want to explore the city and get a feel for it, thereâ€™s no better way than to actually experience living in it. Iâ€™ve spent time in 2 different hostels, an Airbnb apartment, and a Hotel at Amsterdam in various neighborhoods and if I had one single advice to give to anyone heading to Amsterdam, this would be it. Do not, by any given means, no matter what it takes, stay in the center of town. The center is buzzing with people from all across the world, the vibe is electric, the feel amazing and the experienceâ€¦ well, not exactly Amsterdam. Unless you want to see 10 groups of men celebrating their bros last few days as a bachelor by dressing him up in a frock.
If you get the chance, stay just outside the center. The city is not large and is very well connected by trams and the metro. You can easily find an amazing hotel or apartment in areas like Jordaan, De Pjip or even Amsterdam Noord (a 5 min ferry ride away). Every neighborhood has something different to offer and you can choose your stay based on your interests. The iAmsterdam website gives a quick look at the various neighborhoods here
One of my favorite ways to chill in Amsterdam is to just sit by the canals and watch the city at work. Every canal has something different to offer, few are used extensively for transport, while some others are used by the tourist boats and some others are used just for the houseboats. None the less the canals are extremely calming and you can get to learn a lot of the cities nuances through them.
Some of my favorite places in Amsterdam are also right next to the canals. Check out Waterkant (Outdoor 1 on map) if you are looking for a great place to spend the evening with a couple of beers and some great company.
A visit to Amsterdam is incomplete without a visit to the flower market (Experiences -4 on map). If you have spent any amount of time in the city you would already know of their obsession with plants. Every house has a myriad of blooms popping out from every window and balcony. Even the boats are usually covered with tons of potted plants and it does not stop there. Once you enter the houses, restaurants, hotels or even a pub, you are sure to find a plant on your table or next to your bedside.
I absolutely adore the country for this obsession and make it a point to spend some time at the flower market. Though a little touristy and overpriced compared to some of the other shops I have found in smaller markets and towns, it is a great place for anyone to take in the diversity that the city has to offer in terms of people, plants, culture and even food. From tiny succulents to age old Bonsais, you can find it here.
If you are visiting during the spring, the market will be filled with Tulips of every single color imaginable. Trust me when I say this, it can cause a color overload and you with thank the gods that the sky is dull and dreary.
Not visiting in the spring, you can still pick up Tulip buds to take home with you. Unlike the Tulip mania period when a single bulb could sell for millions, these bulbs are quite reasonable and from what Iâ€™ve heard through friends, have a pretty decent success rate. Make sure your country allows you to carry them in though. The shopkeepers usually know the rules for most countries, just ask.
If you have time, visit Keukenhof gardens but only if you can deal with crowds and havenâ€™t blinded yourself with all the color yet.
The garden is open to visitors only during the Tulip festival which lasts a couple of months and the team takes an entire year to landscape and maintain the gardens for this showing. You will be amazed by the variety of Tulips and other flowers showcased here. Be sure to get there early to avoid the crowds and carry some food, the stores there can be a bit pricey.
If you are lucky and visit at the right time, the tulip fields close to Keukenhof are supposed to be breathtaking. We were ready to get away from the crowds and the overdose of beauty and therefore decided to skip out on the fields that were almost bare by the time we got there.
Amsterdam is filled with great choices for food. Being a tourist hotspot you can find every type of food and drink that you would want. Hereâ€™s a quick list of Doâ€™s and Donâ€™t that I would suggest.
Check my recommendations for places to eat on the map.
The city is filled with amazing architecture, beautiful bridges, and stunning museums. Keep your eyes open, you will be amazed by what the city has to offer. A stroll through the city will take you past some of the prettiest sights you would have seen in ages.
Amsterdam has quickly become one of my favorite places to visit due to the huge variety of experiences it offers. This post is far from complete and just a quick look at the city. Hopefully to be followed up with more.
Follow me on Instagram to stay updated.
Looking for prints or have a project in mind? Write to me here
Check out my recommendations for places to visit. Click the icon on the top left to open up all the layers.
Originally published at Lenscape.
--
--
Brand Strategist | Product Mentor | Growth Wrangler www.lenoldvaz.com

Title: From Amsterdam, With Love
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A publication for expats, former expats, and soon to be expats and their adventures around the world.

Member-only story
--
3
Share
Traveling has always been a big part of my life, especially now living in Ireland â€” All European countries are â€œliterallyâ€ a quick flight away!
We went for a quick getaway, arriving on a Thursday evening and leaving on a Sunday morning. Two full days was all it took to fall in love, of course, the amazing sunny weather contributed. However, the diversity of people walking around, mixed with the thriving culture only made exploring the streets that much more exciting.
Skipping all museums on this trip but one (we ainâ€™t got no moneyâ€¦and weâ€™ll be back), day one started with a free walking tour hosted by local Dutch guides. Unaware of just how educational and fun the tour was going to be, time flew by as we learned about the history of Amsterdam. All our trips will now begin with walking tours â€” they gave us the BEST advice on what to do and what to see. Such as the difference between Coffeeshops and Cafes! (important information as tourists, people!)
For lunch, we attempted following the directions we received from our tour guide and ended up finding the best little place for the famous Dutch cone fries.
--
--

Title: Do Amsterdam a different way
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There is so much more to Amsterdam than coffee shops and the red light district, yet for some reason people still come to the city and barely scratch the surface! With affordable flights from Europe and soon a three-hour train from London, Amsterdam is more accessible than ever. Even after living in the Netherlands for half a year, I still feel like there is so much more to see, but hopefully this guide will give you a few off-the-beaten-track ideas.
Friday evening: Youâ€™ve stepped off the plane from your after-work-flight, and have dropped your bags at your boatstay on the canals of Dam, now youâ€™re hungry and eager to get out and about. Luckily, a unique ramen experience awaits you: Men Impossible. You need to book in advance, because Atsushi, the guy who owns, cooks, hosts, serves and entertains this fine establishment, doesnâ€™t want guests to feel rushed, so limits the amount of covers per evening. This little restaurant is beautifully decorated, with one large, communal table that encourages conversation and connection.
Friday drinks: Youâ€™re full of delicious ramen, and feel like a nightcap. This is where you want to avoid the raucous tourists and just chill out with some locals. Cafe Gollem is one such place, offering a selection of 200 different beers with a great, relaxed atmosphere and real, Dutch patrons.
Saturday morning: Wake up, grab a coffee and a bagel, and head into Dam square for the free walking tour! The people who take you really love doing their job, and the tour is fun, informative and touches on a great array of historical moments in Amsterdamâ€™s history.
Saturday lunch: After the tour, you might want to eat something a little more refined than the chips (save those for later), and what better way to warm yourself up than a delightfully spicy Indonesian lunch at Sampurna? Opposite the flower market, the decor is dark and cosy, with statues and shell decorations that tinkle while you eat traditional food that reminds you what a rich and diverse society Amsterdam really is.
Saturday Afternoon: Walking off your meal through the flower market and enjoying the tulips and bulbs, you feel like doing something a bit different. How about visiting a cat sanctuary, on a boat? In the 1960â€™s, Mrs v. Weelde acquired a barge opposite her apartment, and filled it with the catâ€™s sheâ€™d been rescuing for years. Now you can visit it and stroke the cats, learn about their mission and donate some food or toys for the resident felines!
Saturday Dinner: Get yourself over to Taste Before You Waste, for a donation based, food-waste dinner that will nourish your body and soul. The philosophy is simple: they save food that would otherwise have been dumped, and turn it into a delicious dinner that you pay as much as you are able for. The money raised goes to continuing their efforts and improving food education.
Saturday Evening: Time to go back to the boat stay, have a disco nap and get ready for a big night out. There are some great bars where you can drink and bars where you can dance, but if youâ€™re looking to party, head to de School and literally lose yourself on the dry-ice filled dance floors until the early morning. It has a random door policy so donâ€™t be deterred if you see people in the queue being turned away, just be cool, calm and polite, and youâ€™re sure to make it.
Sunday Brunch: Youâ€™re probably feeling pretty tired from last night, so ease yourself into the day with brunch at Pluk: the food is Instagram worthy, not too busy and has a calming, monochrome decor that will keep you grounded until youâ€™ve got some food in you.
Sunday Afternoon: Youâ€™ve filled your tummy and youâ€™re ready to explore a bit of culture before you leave. Jump on the train and a bus to Zaanse Schans to see some real life windmills that are still sawing wood, crushing spices and grinding flour. Walk around the reclaimed land and feed the goats and chickens, taste cheese and hot chocolate in the little village and get some great pictures of old Dutch life. Each of the working mills offers a guided tour and little museums which tell you about their history and modern-day purpose.
A whirlwind weekend in Amsterdam that has hopefully shown you a few different sights to the ones you saw when you were inter railing at eighteen. I hope you enjoyed your trip!
--
--
Writer. Researcher. Editor. Based in Berlin.

Title: Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We finally made it into Amsterdam on a typically blustery, cold and drizzly Dutch day. We tried to keep our expectations lowâ€”not because of the magnificent city, but because we were traveling with a two-year-old and an almost-4-year-old. For those of you whoâ€™ve done this, or anything like it, you already know itâ€™s the kind of thing you set low expectations for. For those of you who havenâ€™t done it or donâ€™t have kids, now you know.
And ultimately, it was indeed a modest little visit. Just the sort of thing we were hoping for, really. We got a very reasonably priced room at the Rho Hotel right off Dam Square, which is about as good a location as can be got, unless you count the proximity to the Red Light District, which is itself really only a problem when youâ€™re traveling with the aforementioned young children.
Our room was tiny but full of amazing light (more on that below) and otherwise really cute. If you wind up needing a room in the middle of Amsterdam, try room 216 at the Rho and you wonâ€™t be disappointed.
Cat was able to make the visit productive by picking up a terrific new backdrop at a local photography shop. We started the next day (after the Rhoâ€™s entirely satisfying free breakfast) with a boat ride around Amsterdamâ€™s infinite network of canals. I was amazed by how fun and interesting this ride was. It made me reflect on (and rethink) how dedicated I am to avoiding â€œtouristyâ€ things on my visits to European cities becauseâ€¦why? because I donâ€™t want to be designated a â€œtourist?â€ Because I think itâ€™s in some way beneath me?
Iâ€™ve been to Amsterdam many times and had never even considered taking one of these tours before. I want to do it all the time now. Itâ€™s pretty, relaxing, and edifying all at once. Especially so in this instance as we basically had the whole boat to ourselves.
That was pretty much our tripâ€™s designated activityâ€”weâ€™re keeping expectations low, remember (and as I write that I realize how absurd it is to characterize a boat trip throughout Amsterdamâ€™s canals as reflecting low expectations). The rest of our time was spent walking aroundâ€”including a walk to the Rijksmuseum (but not a visit inside), and dinners at the Bier Fabriek, and Cafe van Kerkwijk, both a short walk down Nes Street from our hotel. (Both restaurants are heartily recommended, but especially Cafe van Kerkwijk).
By the next morning, the long advertised foul weather was finally upon us and we headed more or less straight for Amsterdam Centraal and a train back to Leiden (and a bus back to Wassenaar). Verdict: the trip was a success! After we got home, we headed over for a visit to the apartment of Harry Reis and Ellen Nakhnikian for a fun little dinner party. The party confirmed what I have always thought: Cold, shitty weather is a fine prelude to good friends, good food, and good beer.
Have I mentioned that the weather has been cold and shitty? Itâ€™s mostly okay with me, actually, because itâ€™s also been beautiful. Seriously, riding home after picking up Veronica yesterday, the sky was Wagnerian.
Tonight, we all watched a short documentary on the common belief of artists all over the worldâ€”for centuriesâ€”that there is something unique about â€œDutch lightâ€â€”that the Dutch sky is so full of moisture (which causes a lot of refraction), so open by the flat landscape, and so saturated with water all over the place (which reflects a lot of light back up to the sky), that itâ€™s just different than other places.
Without having seen this documentary, and in at least one previous blog post, I have felt certain that something like this was going on. There is a strange beauty here that is hard to compare to other places, and I like it.
Even so, my documentary on the Netherlands wouldnâ€™t be about the Dutch light so much as the Dutch wind, which is fierce, hard to predict, and, when it does strike, unrelenting. For the first time in my life I have had to pull my bike over and rest for a while because of a murderous headwind. Pedaling in a way that can only be described as pathetic, I could barely break walking speed and was growing exhausted besides, so I gave up for a while, watched the world blowing by, walked on a little, sang a song to my girl.
In these moments, I have found an odd little crutch that I use to get myselfâ€”and my kids, when they are on the bike with meâ€”through it. None of us likes it when the wind gets that bad, and there is a temptation to really, really hate the experience. All of which can, Iâ€™ve found, be kept at bay by singing an old John Denver song called, appropriately enough, Windsong. This song was on an album we had when I was a kid, and good or bad, its lyrics and tune are practically carved onto my brain. The trick, in making the Dutch wind a little more bearable when it is peeling the skin off your face, is to sing this song at the top of your lungs, shoutingly, angrily, like the words are weapons for fighting the elemental forces threatening to sweep you away. Approaching the song the way Denver does would be ridiculous under these circumstances. And of course, we only sing it at all when the wind is really bad.
Next post: Mystic Truths
Previous Post: Getting Around
--
--

(British spelling)
I finally landed in Amsterdam after a nightmarish flight from Tallinn. The extremely loud volume of the pilotâ€™s announcement was hurting my ears.
â€œLadies and gentlemen, welcome to Amsterdam. We have to taxi for ten minutes. Please, remain seated until the seat belt announcement is off. Thank you.â€
His voice sounded distorted. I had to cover my ears with both my hands. I had forgotten to bring any earplugs with me. In the past, I used to carry several pairs of earplugs conveniently distributed in all my bags.
â€œIt seems I have forgotten everything about my travel essentials.â€
Whilst blaming myself for my oversight I took the obligatory photos of aircrafts. Flashbacks from my last time in Amsterdam began to pop up into my head, uninvited.
My previous time in Amsterdam was nine years ago. Time really flies, doesnâ€™t it? It was May 2015. I was attending a conference for the electronics supply chain industry. I was writing about the conference and the latest news for electronics supply chain professionals for EBN (Electronics Business Network), now EPS News.

Title: Amsterdam: Art, Photography and Type
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Weekly blog posts by Creatives from VBAT, on different topics related to Retail, Branding, Packaging, Innovation and Design in and around Amsterdam.

--
Listen
Share
Written by Craig BerryCreative Intern at VBAT
Recently I had 2 friends from the UK come to Amsterdam to visit and I wanted to show them the city I have been living in for the last 5 months and all that is great about it. I could easily have taken them to the bigger tourist attractions such as the Heineken Experience, the Anne Frank House, the Rijksmuseum and so on. But I wanted to share my pieces of local knowledge which I have picked up on so far and also find and explore new places in the city for myself.
Firstly we visited the Stedelijk Museum which although yes, it is one of those big tourist attractions, as one of the worldâ€™s best museums with a great collection, the 3 of us as intrepid young designers could not escape its allure. I myself went recently to visit the Willem Sandberg exhibition although this had since finished but in its place was a great exhibition celebrating 100 years of â€˜De Stijlâ€™. For those who donâ€™t know, De Stijl was a revolutionary art and design movement in the early 20th century (1917â€“1931) with artists like Mondrian and van Doesburg at the centre of it producing work that they saw as a reduction of form and colour choosing to mostly use vertical and horizontal shapes only using black, white and primary colours.
The exhibition itself covered these characteristics of the movement by showing these well known names tied to De Stijl â€” there was Piet Mondrianâ€™s â€˜Compositionâ€™ pieces and Gerrit Rietveldâ€™s â€˜Red and Blue Chair, these people built the aesthetic of the movement with the other pieces on show by artists and designers who have/had been inspired by them. There was Ellsworth Kelly with â€˜Red Blue Rockerâ€™ in the shape of a folded geometric circle. Roy Lichtensteinâ€™s huge piece â€˜As I Opened Fireâ€™ a painting produced using the same reduced colour palette. Also here was a strong piece by the collective â€” General Idea called â€˜InfeÂ©ted Mondrianâ€™ where they parodied the artist, copying the composition but replacing the yellow colour with a more toxic green to address the AIDS crisis which General Idea focused a lot of their work on and a comment on the dominance of De Stijl. The exhibition is part of a longer project marking 100 years of De Stijl and hopefully I can visit more of it as I see it as one of the great commanding art and design movements which is still prevalent today.
The next day we took the boat over the River IJ to NDSM, described as â€˜a rugged shipyard to a creative hotspotâ€™. The â€˜creative cityâ€™ is a historical remainder of the largest shipyard in the city and has become a haven for all people interested in creativity and art with something for everyone to admire. What stood out to us was the main NDSM building/warehouse, now a hub for studios and restaurants; the outer walls still adorned with the original painted sign. The letters on the 2 sides read â€œNetherlands Shipbuilding Companyâ€™ and â€˜Nederlandsche Dok en Scheepsbouw Maatschappijâ€™ with each letter painted on heavily in white, with little consistency in letter styles but following some sort of grid. We were motivated to photograph the letters and digitise them to produce a display font with all of its inconsistency and variety as a homage to the building, as designers it was impossible for us to not look at this and be amazed and inspired.
We also found a great bar in the NDSM area â€” Pllek, built out of old shipping containers a huge glass window looking out onto the IJ and the cold Dutch winter air. We stayed here for a while, chatting and chilling. Drinking a few beers whilst some live music played. A really cool find and as the Dutch might say, it was â€˜gezelligâ€™.
I got the following Monday off work to continue our quest around the city and we ended up at the FOAM photography museum (Fotografiemuseum Amsterdam) to check out the Hiroshi Sugimoto exhibition â€” Black Box. An overview of the Japanese artistâ€™s work which covered his major series. There was a lot of variety in what was on show but the works which really stood out to me were â€˜Lightning Fieldsâ€™ and â€˜Theatresâ€™ because of the processes which were used to make them. â€˜Lightning Fieldsâ€™ are images where there is no camera involved, they are made by channelling electricity over photo paper and exposing it. The marks left behind are incredible and the size of the prints makes for a visually strong image. â€˜Theatresâ€™ are a series of images where the artist photographed empty theatre halls, the exposure length of each photograph dictated by the length of a feature film, so each image is brighter or darker than the other. They create these ghostly like images of the room with a solid white image on the theatre screen which is almost sinister like to look into as you are surrounded by these images. The rest of the museum is also great as well as the inside of the building, it is one of the canal houses on the Keizersgracht and inside it is a series of winding rooms and dimly lit hallways: easy to get lost â€” which we did.
Finally throughout the few days we were walking around I had prepared a map that documents some of the great historical and innovative typographic signs that exist through the city. I was inspired by David Quayâ€™s type tour with us back in the warm summer time in September and using these places as well as my own findings we wandered around as I pointed out these great relics, most of them with some story to tell.
My personal favourite was this piece by Dutch artist Piet Parra on the Tuinstraat. A huge wall mural near a school and kids park which reads: â€œIk speel in de stad met alles wat er bestaatâ€ â€” I play in the city with all that exists. I just love how the letters flow from one to the next and also Parra has a unique style which fits the city perfectly.
If you enjoyed reading this, please click ğŸ’š â€œRecommendâ€ below. This will help to share the story with others.
Follow VBAT on Twitter | Like us on Facebookwritten by Craig BerryCreative at VBATedited by Connie FluhmePR at VBAT

Title: Amsterdam: A Vibrant & Unforgettable City
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Experience the vibrant and unforgettable city of Amsterdam! Discover its iconic canals, historic architecture, and vibrant culture. Explore world-renowned museums and neighborhoods, indulge in delicious cuisine, and soak up the energy of this incredible city.
Amsterdam is a city that holds a special place in my heart. From the moment I arrived, I was struck by the cityâ€™s vibrant energy and charm. It was unlike any other place I had ever been, with its winding canals, charming architecture, and bustling streets. It is now easily one of my favorite cities on the planet.
I will dive deep into everything you need to know about this vibrant city, from its top tourist attractions to its unforgettable hidden gems. Whether planning your first visit to Amsterdam or are a seasoned traveler looking for a new adventure, this article is your ultimate resource for all things Amsterdam. So pack your bags, grab your camera, and get ready to experience the magic of this vibrant and unforgettable city.
Amsterdamâ€™s history dates back to the 12th century when a small fishing village was established on the banks of the River Amstel. By the 14th century, the village had grown into a thriving port city, and in 1300, it was granted city rights by the Bishop of Utrecht.
