Title: â€œAmsterdamâ€ (2022)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Entertaining conspiracy in the land of the one-eyed King.
Three cinema trips ago, and in the second week of October of a year that is ending just hours away from when I pen these brief words of appreciation, I was leaving my local cinema in the company of my beautiful son when I happened upon the above poster for Amsterdam and immediately remarked to all within earshot: this will be a stunner of a film. As is so often proved correct within my own particular one-eyed kingdom, I was indeed right, and director David O Russellâ€™s tenth big screen cinematic affair was a conspiratorial treat. Not as accomplished perhaps as his 1999 epic Three Kings or Silver Linings Playbook over a decade later or my particular favourite in his cinematic cannon, 2013â€™s American Hustle, but I loved Amsterdam for a multitude of reasons and hopefully for differing and surprising reasons than your own.
Returning for just a moment to that film poster and my proclamation of its coming greatness as a film as my son and I ambled away from Halloween Ends in early October, whilst he was nonplussed by my soothsaying future review the cinemaâ€™s â€œGreeterâ€ wasnâ€™t as she confessed (a) sheâ€™d seen and loved an advance copy of the film and (b) sheâ€™d already bagged the poster I was referring to as she too liked it and as a perk of the job, she can buy any unreserved film posters for a knockdown price. I was of course envious as Iâ€™m a childish film fan at heart and am so often taken in by a good poster and so it was, finally, on 29th December in a year finishing in a mere few hours from now, that I watched Amsterdam expectantly awaiting a gem of a film that didnâ€™t arrive but which was replaced by something wholly surprisingly and unexpectedly different.
Since seeing the film poster in early October Iâ€™d seen not a trailer nor a sneak peak or any written reviews whatsoever. I still havenâ€™t. I watched this film without even the most basic of a premise or blurb which, according to The Matrix Movie Bible at www.imdb.com proclaims Amsterdam to be:
â€œIn the 1930s, three friends witness a murder, are framed for it, and uncover one of the most outrageous plots in American historyâ€.
Had I known this before time I would of course have been expecting the obvious real-life conspiracy being laid out before us and with the introduction of Robert De Niro in his notable cameo role, however it was even more pleasing for your humble narrator to call out this conspiracy ahead of cinematic time, way before the introduction of De Niro and way before those closing credits that rather soured the ending to an otherwise brilliantly engaging film.
Go see the credits for yourself. Itâ€™s all there for a one eye wishing to see.
But rather remarkably, arguably the greatest untold and unsaid conspiracy of all time is laid out within this gem of a film and should you be unaware of General Smedley Butler, his book â€œWar is a Racketâ€, the request placed upon him to lead a Fascist revolution in the United States of America exactly a century ago or his multitude of revealing quotes attributed to him later in life, treat yourself to a real conspiracy in a world absent of them according to our Overlords in charge of the all seeing eye.
Five paragraphs in and not one word about the film? Par for my cinematic course. There are never any major spoilers here. Just a human reaction to an artform I revere like no other. But returning to the film poster once again and itâ€™s a veritable whoâ€™s who and ensemble collection of character actors and actresses of our generation, all of whom produce intriguing, spirited and fiercely individual performances. In poster order we have Margot Robbie playing arguably a dual character if not definitely a dual personality as she flits from secretive war nurse to artist and much more in league with the love of her life, World War I veteran and now New York lawyer in the guise of John David Washington. Chris Rock is an awkwardly outspoken World War I veteran too and best friends with Washington whilst back in a New York of 1933 and fifteen years since the end of the Great War, we find Anya Taylor-Joy as a rather prissy and controlling wife of Rami Malek whilst Zoe Saldana excels as a medical examiner.
Pleasingly as well as perhaps unfairly, I saw the Mike Myers character of a British spy stepping right out of the Quentin Tarantino character created for him in 2009â€™s Inglourious Basterds and the screen time he shares with Michael Shannonâ€™s American spy is a bizarre joy. Timothy Olyphant is a hitman. Andrea Riseborough a socially climbing and grasping estranged wife. Taylor Swift hangs up the singing microphone for a small cameo role and Matthias Schoenaerts and Alessandro Nivola complete the poster roll of acting talent as two ridiculously cartoonish bungling New York detectives.
Which just leaves your star of a conspiratorial show:
â€œBert Berendsenâ€ (Christian Bale) World War I veteran and now ostensibly a fringe outsider doctor and medical practitioner, Berendsen has seen the devastation of war and the human casualties he now tries in vain to treat. The carnage of human war is writ large on the returning veterans unable to stop shaking from what was termed then as â€œShell Shockâ€ but is now flowered and mired in the newspeak language of â€œPost Traumatic Stress Disorderâ€, but Berendsen is also somewhat of an expert in the art of facial and body disfigurement having lost and left an eye in France at the very end of the war. Forming a â€œpactâ€ with the nurse who saved him and nursed him back to health (Margot Robbie as â€œValerie Vozeâ€) and his best friend and also recovering veteran (John David Washington as â€œHarold Woodmanâ€), Berendsen breaks the pact to return to his medical calling in New York and the estranged wife from an estranged family who distrust him enormously.
As ever, Christian Bale is wonderful in a central role arguably only he or Sam Rockwell could truly play and pull off with such aplomb. Often framed with a querying and quizzical head tilt to the side and always with long, lingering shots on a character trying desperately to piece together the puzzle before him, David O Russell deserves enormous credit for writing such a character as well as guiding and directing him into life in league with Bale.
â€œA lot of this really happenedâ€, so proclaims the very first frame of the film before we journey backward and forward, from 1930â€™s New York to France in 1918 and back again, as a tapestry is slowly woven around a huge cast of characters embroiled or otherwise in the greatest untold (and dare not spoken about) conspiracy of all time. Thereâ€™s an arguable heroâ€™s tale component to the story alongside the conspiracy but with heavy emphasis on the returning veterans Iâ€™m hoping the deliberately shocking human aftermath of war resonates deeply with everyone.
Thereâ€™s a â€œCommittee of 5â€ and â€œThe Great Nation Societyâ€ and with a bending of the truth and some plot contrivances combining with a stellar cast, I rather enjoyed Amsterdam and recommend it to you.
Postscript
I first read about this Fascist coup to topple a sitting USA President to install a military dictatorship in the late 1990â€™s so itâ€™s only taken a quarter of a century since then to arrive on the big cinema screen. I still havenâ€™t seen or read any reviews of the film but Iâ€™d wager it gets panned. Big time!
Iâ€™d also wager than no-one of any mainstream substance brings up the conspiracy despite itâ€™s centennial anniversary and the implications this may have had for the world at large.
But then again, conspiracies donâ€™t exist, do they?
Silly me.
Thanks for reading. Just for larks as always, and always a human reaction rather than spoilers galore. My three most recently published film articles are linked below or thereâ€™s well over 100 blog articles (with 300+ individual film reviews) within my archives from which to choose:

Title: Visit These 5 Places in Amsterdam Before You Die â€” Part I
Content:

Hoy! The capital of the Netherlands holds a special place in my heart. Never have I liked a big city as much as Amsterdam. It booms with people from all over the world, the standard of living is exquisite, and there are so many bike lanes! Find yourself wandering around Amsterdam, taking in the canals, the houses among them, the marvelous new architecture, and experiencing this small but beautiful country.
Get yourself the real deal: A fresh Stroopwafel on a market. This is so good; I cannot even describe it. Stroopwafels are a traditional dutch pastry; a doughball with spices and cinnamon gets baked into the Wafel. The thought of the smell when it comes out waters my mouth! It then gets cut open, and a thick sirup, the Stroop, is put onto it, and tadaa, you have yourself a heavenly tasting dessert. Orâ€¦

Title: An American in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I have never seriously considered the expat life: Iâ€™m too fond of deep-fried foods and the convenience of driving to supermarkets that sell everything I need. But after spending four days in Amsterdam, I may have to reconsider my attachment to American soil. Amsterdam is without a doubt the most beautiful city Iâ€™ve ever seen â€” I think itâ€™s even more picturesque than Paris. Almost every street is divided by a canal dotted with houseboats, and the brightly colored buildings with tall windows lean gracefully over the streets and canals. Bridges are sprinkled with flower boxes, and the scent of flowers, food, and other herbs wafts into the streets.
I stayed about 30 minutes outside of the city at Lucky Lake Hostel on Lake Vinkeveen. Lucky Lake is more than just a hostel: it is a community, where travelers from all over the world eat breakfast together in a converted bus, kayak the lake together, or unwind at night together in the lounge. Painted camper trailers, small cabins, tents, and hammocks form a ring around the property, with a block of gender-neutral showers and toilets (those absurdly progressive Dutch!) in the center, campground-style. Staff members or guests cook big dinners every night in the outdoor kitchen, and anyone can chip in for a share of the food. Guests and staff actually hang out in the lounge at night to play cards or the guitar, creating a sense of community that many hostels advertise but very few actually deliver. It was truly the experience of a lifetime.
The lake was a three-minute walk from my camper door. On my first day, I joined a couple of friends I made on the shuttle and rented kayaks for â‚¬3/hour to explore the waters. We paddled our way through a maze of canals and tiny houses with tinier boats until we reached the lake. The water was so clear you could almost see the bottom, and we saw more sailboats and kayaks than motorboats.
Later that day, I decided to take the hostel shuttle into the city to walk around and see what I could discover. I found that the Dutch way of life is perhaps the most relaxed in the world: they grow tulips and marijuana, ride bicycles, and eat fresh cheese and chocolate-covered waffles. All the people I met were very laid-back and pleasant, even more so than the Belgians. So thatâ€™s why the Dutch are consistently recognized as the happiest people in the world!
Amsterdam is truly a city of bicycles. It has more bicycles than people and more bike lanes than streets. Itâ€™s very pleasant to hear the tinkle of thousands of bells and to see so many people cycling their way through the city (it must be the Dutch secret to staying fit despite eating lots of waffles). Pro tip: donâ€™t walk in the bike lanes! I was crossing a bike lane when I saw this really cool Dutch bookstore out of the corner of my eye. I decided midway across the street to check it out and changed direction, only to collide into a passing bicycle. My phone flew out of my hands across the street, and my body scraped its way along the cobblestones until I ended up on my side. The cyclist, who was only a few years older than I am, had fallen off his bike, and he rushed over to help me up. He very kindly checked me for any injuries and even recommended the bookstore when he heard what had distracted me. I guess Dutch amicability knows no bounds.
My friends know that I am somewhat of a crazy cat lady, and Amsterdam definitely provided the feline interaction Iâ€™ve missed on my travels. I visited De Poezenboot (â€œThe Catboatâ€), a floating cat sanctuary on one of Amsterdamâ€™s canals. The lovely houseboat is home to dozens of stray cats who have learned to love living on the water. For someone like me who misses her own cats dearly, itâ€™s positively sublime to visit a place where I can play with friendly cats for as long as I like. Later, I toured KattenKabinet, a museum specializing in artwork featuring cats. They have paintings by artists such as Rembrandt and Manet, as well as sculptures and posters by less famous artists. They even have a couple of real cats hanging around the museum for artistic inspiration!
Normally I would save my culinary experiences for a food post, but I have to rave about the food in Amsterdam. My diet consisted mostly of cheese and waffles: needless to say, I was well-satisfied. There is a cheese shop selling fresh local cheese on almost every corner in Amsterdam, and the best part is that they all offer free samples! I wandered from shop to shop, trying slices of every cheese and every fig spread offered. I literally made a meal out of free cheese samples.
The Dutch are famed for their stroopwafels, which are thin waffles cemented together by caramel syrup. They sound delicious, and Iâ€™m a little ashamed to say that I never tried one. My sweet-tooth hopelessly indulged in the perhaps less-authentic but more delectable chocolate-covered waffles.
Oh. My. God. I may never be able to eat at Waffle House again after feasting on these things. I ate one every day: chocolate-covered waffles, white chocolate-covered waffles, caramel-covered waffles. So many waffles, and so much tastebud explosion. They were usually topped with yummy things like marshmallows, butterscotch chips, or Oreos, too.
Whether you like amazing food, beautiful rural countryside, or a charming and vibrant city with flowers everywhere, Amsterdam will take your breath away. It is easily my favorite city so far. Weâ€™ll see if it can be surpassed by my next stop â€” Berlin!
--
--

Today is the beginning of my month-long, Amazing Amsterdam Adventure.
I will be on my own this month, and I have decided to pretend I am a tourist who managed to find a beautiful apartment in Amsterdam for a month.
The first day of my fakecation began appropriately with transportation challenges. I helped my daughter and family get to the train station, and it was a bit more challenging than anticipated to get all those bikes and the dog across town to Central station, never mind onto a train.
I left them outside and then got very lost on my way home â€” at one point, my GPS tried to send me into the canal. Fortunately, I made it to the apartment. Now, after a hard day of traveling, I am beginning this adventure.
I hope you join me.
You can read more about my plans in the piece below.

Title: For Matt: thoughts on Amsterdam and Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I decided Iâ€™ll write a bit about the two cities I just visited during my French school break, partially because my British friend Matt (shoutout number three if heâ€™s counting!) encouraged me to keep writing about urban planning. So here I am.
Amsterdam is very interesting with its urban planning â€” some might call it â€œthe Meccaâ€ of urban planning because of how idealized it is by many urbanists. The most popular urbanism YouTube channel is Not Just Bikes, who moved to Amsterdam because of its reputation. But what is it really like?
I would imagine the tourist experience is much different from the habitant experience, even more than other cities. This is because while the prioritization of biking is helpful for locals, it can be difficult for a newbie to get a handle on. As you walk around the city, there can be so much to look out for as a pedestrian. Watch out for the bikes! Watch out for the tram! Watch out for the cars! Itâ€™s a complex ecosystem, and if you arenâ€™t paying attention, it can be easily overwhelming.
I did love the trams in Amsterdamâ€™s city center. Metros can go faster underground, but the experience of a tram above ground, where you can simply hop on and look out the window at the city, is delightful. However, I noticed that the trams and metro have a tap-in and tap-out system, which Iâ€™m not a fan of. In New York, you use your ticket to get on the subway, but you can get off wherever you want and you do not have to rescan the ticket. This is much easier for riders. My friends and I were sometimes scrambling to take out our ticket again and rescan to exit the train.
I get the sense that in Venice people actually use their canals for transportation, but in Amsterdam this does not seem to be the case. There are tours on the canal, but not a lot of regular folks using the canal to navigate the city. The bikes are everywhere. I donâ€™t know how I underestimated the number of bikes when I knew how bike-crazy Amsterdam is, but I underestimated them.
There are a few things I prefer about Paris, a place Iâ€™ve been to many times and am more familiar with. The sidewalks are wider in Paris than in Amsterdam. There are also a lot more terraces/outdoor seating in Paris, which is always welcoming and enjoyable for tourists and locals. Amsterdamâ€™s meager outdoor seating was always just a few tables outside, whereas in Paris there can be huge terraces with many tables for people to simply plop down and order a coffee. Relaxed cafÃ© culture in France is simply unbeatable. In comparison, with its smaller streets and a lack of outside seating, Amsterdam is always keeping things moving. Itâ€™s a faster pace but itâ€™s also exciting and keeps you turning down the next corner.
There are a few key neighborhoods in Amsterdam. The 9 Streets neighborhood is very beautiful with varying architecture and canal views, but much of the ground floor establishments were expensive shops. Again, I wouldâ€™ve liked an outdoor cafÃ© to sit and take things in rather than feeling like I couldnâ€™t linger. I found the Jordaan neighborhood to be more residential (I could literally look into rich peopleâ€™s houses because of their big, open windows) but just as architecturally interesting. The Red Light District felt the most touristy. Itâ€™s really just one street, a couple blocks long, with sex workers in the windows and â€œcinemas.â€ We walked up and down it once, but there wasnâ€™t much for our group to do there.
Athens has a few popular neighborhoods as well â€” Plaka and Psyri. I found Plaka to be touristy in some parts and desolate in others. Maybe this is just my experience. I really liked Psyri â€” I had multiple meals in that area and found something going on down every street. Cars in Athens are interesting â€” they attempt to go down any street they can fit in. I was sitting outside at a cafÃ© and a car squeezed through the small street less than two feet away from me. There is a lack of signaled crosswalks in Athens. Most of the time people just cross the street whenever possible through traffic. That is less than ideal.
But I would not say Athens isnâ€™t walkable. I walked all over the city center while I was there and only took the metro a few times to get to faraway locations. When I did take the metro, it was fairly reliable but not the cleanest. One thing I did like about the Athens metro was that they had signs showing which direction the escalators were going so that you could easily navigate where you needed to go to get out. I havenâ€™t seen that in a metro before, but it was helpful.
Athens is the furthest south Iâ€™ve been in Europe and the sunshine was welcome after months of rainy winter in France. One thing I noticed is all of the solar panels! Many apartment buildings had multiple solar panels at the top, maybe 6 feet long by 4 feet wide. In contrast, when I took the Eurostar train to Amsterdam, I noticed that Belgium and the Netherlands had a lot of wind turbines. Northern part of Europe, more wind, it makes sense.
This was a great trip with two cities I really wanted to see this year, so Iâ€™m proud of myself and feeling very fulfilled.
--
--
In grad school. Writing so that I can blab about my interdisciplinary interests: politics, philosophy, urban planning, travel, rural America, etc.

A City of Surprises and Endless Possibilities.
No city compares to Amsterdamâ€™s diversity. Every time I visit, I discover something new that I never knew existed. Itâ€™s like joining an adventure each time, with surprises waiting around every corner.
And I love it.
This year, Iâ€™ve had the opportunity to visit Amsterdam two times, and each experience has been unique each time.
The first visit was with my family. We were a large group, which made it challenging to please everyone. So, my daughter and I quickly decided to return on our own. (So we did, a couple of weeks later).
During our first visit to Amsterdam, we decided to play tourists. And what better place is there than to visit The Royal Palace?
This palace is best known for being where the King and Queen of the Netherlands stand and wave to the people on various occasions.

Title: Beautiful Amsterdam, Built on Poles: Who would pay if it all fell down?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

TedxAmsterdam

--
Listen
Share
Beautiful Amsterdam / Built on Poles/ Who would pay if it all fell down?
â€“Old Dutch nursery rhyme translated
Since early times, the houses in Amsterdam have been built on wooden foundation piles[i] that are driven deep into the clay, peat, and water until they reach the first layer of solid sand. Even some of the trees in Vondelpark are supported on wooden piles to keep them from sinking into the marshy ground.
How long can a wooden pile remain in the ground before it has to be replaced?
300 years? 80 years? Until next week? The answer depends on many variables:
Quality of the sand layer
In Amsterdam, the first layer of sand lies approximately 12 meters below the surface. However, the quality of the sand layer is not consistent throughout the city. In some areas, the first sand layer is thinner than normal or missing entirely. As a result, the houses in these areas sink at an abnormal rate, and the foundations have to be replaced faster.
The top of the wooden foundation pile should be below the lowest expected water level. If part of the pile reaches above the water, it will be subject to insect attacks and decay. A problem is that the water level under Amsterdam isnâ€™t always stable. For instance, it can drop during long periods of drought. Or a sewer pipe can develop cracks, allowing the ground water to flow into the pipe and be carried away. As a result, the water level drops.
On the other hand, if the water level rises too high, as sometimes occurs after a heavy rain, the Amsterdam cellars and crawl spaces fill up like bathtubs.
Construction projects can also interfere with the water level. An example is the incident on the Vijzelgracht in 2008 during work on the new metro station. A leak in the dam wall at a depth of 60 meters caused water and sand to stream into the pit. Part of the sand layer that was supporting the wooden foundation piles of the nearby houses washed away, causing extensive damage to the structure of the houses.
Spruce is less vulnerable to damage from bacteria than pine. Since around 1970, piles made from pine are prohibited from use. Concrete and steel piles are often used in present day construction.
The visible signs are slanted floors, cracks in the walls, doors and windows that stick, and broken front steps. The charming crooked roofline of Amsterdam is actually a symptom of unstable foundations.
If a foundation that is in poor condition is not repaired in time, the wooden piles will need to be replaced. No homeowner wants to get this news. A new foundation can easily cost 100,000 euro. Furthermore, the floor may need to be opened up, thereby making the house unlivable for some time.
In recent years, the housing corporations have been replacing the wooden piles under their properties with concrete piles.[ii] For example, Ymere is replacing the decayed pine piles in the Van der Pek neighborhood â€” a costly investment. However many houses that are at risk are privately owned.
The condition of the old wooden piles will only worsen in the coming years, so the question is: who will pay?
[i] Referred to as poles in the nursery rhyme.
[ii] Palen onder Amsterdam verpulveren
Credits and Sources:
Gemeente Amsterdam Background on Foundations
The Challenges of Building Amsterdamâ€™s New Metro Line
Written by Barbara Austin.
Categorized as Amsterdam.
Tagged with amsterdam, Infrastructure.
Originally published at tedx.amsterdam on September 24, 2015.

Sangam and I visited a place called Aâ€™dam Lookout in Amsterdam. Itâ€™s a high platform where you can see an amazing view of the city. Youâ€™ll see the old part of the city, the busy port, and the special Dutch landscape with its canals, which are recognized as important by UNESCO. They also have a cool exhibition and a free audio tour that tells you about Amsterdamâ€™s past and culture. Aâ€™dam Lookout is on the top of the Aâ€™dam Tower in Amsterdam North.
We got tickets for Aâ€™dam Lookout and hopped on the elevator. We were really excited to see the city view from the tower. As the elevator went up, the colors changed constantly, and it looked absolutely amazing.
When we reached the top of the tower, the city view was incredible. Even though it was windy and a bit chilly, we still had a great time enjoying the view.

Title: Top 10 Must-Do Activities In Amsterdam: Fall In Love With The Netherlandsâ€™ Capital City
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Hi there!
Welcome to a cityscape with unique merchant houses, intersected by numerous canals. Amsterdam is a lively city with a rich cultural scene and 800 years of history.
Forget about the typical tourist traps.
I will tell you the best things you can do for the first time there to feel fabulous.
Stay with me so you donâ€™t miss anything.
Here we go with the Top 10 Must-Do Activities In Amsterdam:
Cycling isnâ€™t just a mode of transportation in Amsterdam.
Itâ€™s a way of life!
With over 800,000 bicycles in the city â€” more than its human population â€” Amsterdam is often called â€˜The Cycling Capital of the Worldâ€™.This is owed to the cityâ€™s flat terrain and extensive network of bike routes.
Experience the city alongside locals on two wheels.
I am sure that you will love Amsterdamâ€™s cycling culture:
www.dutchamsterdam.nl
Grab your saddle and pedal through Amsterdamâ€™s bike-friendly streets.
You will enjoy passing by historic landmarks and picturesque canals.
Try to choose a sunny day or be prepared to cycle in the rain, as is often the case there!
The city of Amsterdam has a unique network of canals stretching to the west and south of the historic old town. The project was initiated during the late 16th and early 17th centuries.
It consists of the reclamation of swampland and the construction of concentric arcs of canals.
The canals, along with radial waterways and streets, showcase the cityâ€™s rich history. Now you have a chance to enjoy its beauty and heritage!
Find more information here:
whc.unesco.org
I had the opportunity to step into the evolution of Jordaan.
Once a humble working-class enclave, it has now transformed into Amsterdamâ€™s hippest neighborhood!
Here, you can stroll along streets lined with art galleries, vintage boutiques, and bars.
Amsterdamâ€™s Nine Streets, nestled behind the Royal Palace on Dam Square, attract both locals and tourists alike:
www.iamsterdam.com
Lose yourself along the cobblestone streets and peaceful canals of Amsterdamâ€™s historic district!
Now, get ready for a journey through time. In just 40 minutes, youâ€™ll zip through 400 years of history, starting from a swampy area.
The best part? This museum tells how Amsterdam, a city built on water, came to be:
grachten.museum
The museum itself is housed in a jaw-dropping building on the Herengracht.
Once youâ€™re inside, grab an audio guide and settle in.
Before you know it, the lights dim, and bam! Youâ€™re whisked back to 1600, smack dab in the middle of Amsterdamâ€™s golden age.
But wait, thereâ€™s more! This museum isnâ€™t just about history.
Itâ€™s also about the cityâ€™s vibrant life.
The dollâ€™s houses are straight out of the past and snippets from cult classic movies.
Yeah, itâ€™s that cool.
Ever wondered what itâ€™s like to live on a houseboat? Well, nowâ€™s your chance to find out!
Step aboard the Woonboot Museum, a cozy floating museum housed in a converted cargo ship from 1914:
houseboatmuseum.nl
You can sip tea and enjoy cake while lounging in retro armchairs.
But thatâ€™s not all â€” Amsterdamâ€™s houseboat scene is a unique way of life. Dive deeper into its story at the Boat Museum of the Canals.
Located on the famous Prinsengracht, this museum offers a glimpse into Amsterdamâ€™s aquatic past and present.
Learn about the evolution of houseboats, canal history, and more.
After all, where else can you get a firsthand look at life on the waterways?
Explore one of Amsterdamâ€™s most powerful historical sites, the Anne Frank House.
Enter the hidden annex where Anne Frank and her family sought refuge during World War II.
Here, youâ€™ll uncover the truths of the Holocaust:
www.annefrank.org
In this museum, you will see Anneâ€™s actual diary and other relics.
I was inspired by the lasting message of courage and hope.
Experience the world of art at the famous Van Gogh Museum.
You will see the largest collection of Vincent van Goghâ€™s masterpieces!
This museum provides a close look into the life and art of the iconic Dutch painter:
www.vangoghmuseum.nl
Admire his lively paintings, sketches, and personal letters, witnessing the journey of his artistic brilliance.
Dive into centuries of Dutch art and history at the legendary Rijksmuseum:
www.rijksmuseum.nl
Discover masterpieces by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and other masters, highlighting the richness of Dutch culture.
From stunning paintings to decorative arts and more, the Rijksmuseum invites you now.
As soon as I walked into the Heineken Brewery, the delightful aroma of hops surrounded me.
Exploring the breweryâ€™s vats and vintage equipment, I discovered the story of Heinekenâ€™s beginnings and their dedication to brewing excellence:
www.heinekenexperience.com
No wonder itâ€™s my favorite beer!
The tasting room was a highlight for me.
With every sip, I savored the essence of Heinekenâ€™s craftsmanship. Heineken truly deserves its high regard in the brewing world.
Do you enjoy this beer as much as I do?
As the sun dips below the horizon, Amsterdam ignites with exciting nightlife.
The Red Light District, famous for its legalized prostitution, is a must-see spot and that caught my eye too:
amsterdamtickets.tours
I wandered through lively streets with friends, enjoying its unique vibe.
But thereâ€™s more to see in the district than just its reputation. Amongst the buzzing nightlife, youâ€™ll discover a fascinating mix of history, culture, and cutting-edge experiences.
Explore cozy cafes, trendy bars, nightclubs, and live music spots.
Amsterdam offers endless possibilities for nighttime adventures.
Whether youâ€™re into groovy beats or prefer a chill night with locals, the city promises unforgettable experiences until the early hours.
Ready to dive in?
Photo by Boudewijn Boer on Unsplash
In conclusion, Amsterdam invites adventurers with its captivating mix of past, present, and excitement.
Whether youâ€™re gliding along its famous canals or diving into its rich art scene, this city has something for everyone.
So, what are you waiting for?
Get ready for an epic adventure through Amsterdamâ€™s beating heart!
What are some of the other best things you did in Amsterdam? Please share in the comments!
--
--
2

Today is the 7th day of my August Amsterdam Adventure, and I went to the Rijksmuseum, the National Museum of the Netherlands. The Museum has published extensive information about it online.
I spent two hours looking at only a fraction of the work on exhibit and am looking forward to doing more of a deep dive this month into the art available to residents and tourists in the Netherlands. Todayâ€™s visit included works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Van Gogh, among many others.
I will be visiting the Van Gogh Museum later this month, as well as the Fabrique des LumiÃ¨res exhibit of the Dutch Masters, and I will write a lot more about them. I will be keeping a travel log about my adventures here:

Title: Itâ€™s a spoiler. Amsterdam by Ian McEwan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Literature. Book Reviews. Essays.

--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam by Ian McEwan certainly isnâ€™t the first novel in the history of literature that deals with moral hypocrisy in a corrupted society, nor is it the last. But the way McEwan deals with it, the approach, the focus â€” it is all so fresh (even now, in 2015) and remarkable. The narrative instance doesnâ€™t criticize and doesnâ€™t even laugh at those characters. Instead, we, the readers, are encouraged to take the protagonists seriously. There is no bare sarcasm, only the finest irony, essential to characterization and plot. McEwan is a master of the free indirect style. We are in the charactersâ€™ heads, thinking their thoughts, afraid of their fears. We are worried that Clive will end up just like Molly. And there is Vernon with his feeling of non-existence, which is a postmodernist moment, for he certainly does not exist until someone reads the novel.
The introductory setting is hilarious. Two middle-aged guys are attending an ex-loverâ€™s funeral. The ex-lower was a kind of femme fatale clichÃ© of the XX century. The sound of the name, Molly Lane, somehow recalls Molly Bloom. There is, also, at least, one more ex-lover of hers, and her husband. They are all connected in various ways, but the existence of Molly deepens those connections. The first two guys are friends and, which is more important, they give us the first two points of view. They are the good guys. According to them, the husband is stupid and possessive. The third lover, a politician, is an enemy of the previous three.
The language of the novel is extraordinary. Characterization is delicate and minutious.
So, we have two bad, and two good guys. And then Vernon appears to be quite immoral and without human principles. Nevermind. There is Clive, with his moral superiority. He is the one who really loved Molly, who deeply misses her, and who doesnâ€™t even want Vernon to publicly humiliate the arch-enemy, by publishing his photos in women's clothes, taken by Molly, and provided by her husband. We also read a long and rather pathetic passage about how Clive had always been a so much better friend to Vernon than he was to Clive.
Just a few pages later, this morally superior guy goes hiking, in search of inspiration, and then witnesses an act of violence, perhaps a murder, and just walks away, because, for godâ€™s sake, he has the symphony to write!
After less than half of the novel, there is no good protagonist left for us to feel empathy for. But, instead of becoming boring, the novelâ€™s plot starts to accelerate, preventing you from letting it from your hands before youâ€™ve read the very last page of it.
The main plot triggers are behind us by now. Clive and Vernon have made a pact: if one of them gets ill the way Molly did, the other will arrange euthanasia abroad. After that, theyâ€™ve had the first, but crucial, argument in the history of their friendship. It is about embarrassing photographs of Foreign Minister, Julian Garmony, which were about to be published in the magazine that Vernon runs.
Now comes a deus ex machina â€” and the first spoiler to Vernonâ€™s plan. A new character, the Ministerâ€™s wife, gives a press conference, which turns things upside down. On the sudden, it is not the politicianâ€™s head urgently needed on a plate, but Vernonâ€™s.
Vernon and Clive are mad at each other, as they both feel betrayed. They start to hate each other and, in the end, mutually arrange a murder in Amsterdam, where the grand premiere of Cliveâ€™s symphony is about to be performed.
It is Mollyâ€™s husband who, followed by now ex-Foreign Minister, buries them all. The most of his wifeâ€™s former lovers are dead, and now he recalls memories of Vernonâ€™s wife, who used to be wild. He is about to call her for a dinner. So, who is laughing now?
We are. At this moment, I canâ€™t recall any other piece of prose in which the death of the main characters produces such a comical effect. It is even not morbid humor; it is just humor, and it is great.
Ian McEwan won the Man Booker Prize for Amsterdam in 1998.
--
--
Literature. Book Reviews. Essays.
I write about books in many ways and forms. | Twitter: @Booksist | Upwork: https://goo.gl/qXvCZ6

Title: Iâ€™m here for the tax break
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
7
Listen
Share
Itâ€™s my third year in the Netherlands. Or, as we Highly Skilled Migrants like to say, year 3 out of 5.
When I arrived in 2022, as full of enthusiasm about the future as the whole newly reopened post-Covid world, the border officer asked me how long I was planning on staying. â€˜Maybe forever!â€™ I replied with a broad smile. (Coming from the UK, I was still used to the image of public officials as banterous teddy bears). Then, I marched straight into the Dutch winter.
I was proud to have intentionally chosen a new country to live in and determined to be happy. As it happens, reality proved to be more complex and less controllable, and not just because of the weather. The job was actually worse than my previous job in London. The housing market was broken beyond understanding. The friendships were effortful and shallow. The relationship I started turned long distance.
And thatâ€™s okay. Thatâ€™s how you fall in love with a city, through a journey of joys and disappointments. You will survive, grow and thrive, as long as you have a guiding principle. Mine, as many other expats in Amsterdam, has always been:
At least stay until the end of the ruling. Then you can always leave.
The Dutch government calls it a â€œfacilityâ€ or â€œreimbursementâ€ as if trying to hide its own intentions. But when you fill any legal forms here, the literally translated question they ask you is â€œAre you enjoying the 30% ruling?â€. I surely am, thank you very much. Thatâ€™s the purpose of it â€” itâ€™s an incentive. A tax scheme from 1964, according to which Highly Skilled Migrants donâ€™t pay taxes on 30% of their salary, as well as wealth tax for shares, savings and properties they have abroad. The aim is to compensate them for the cost of moving countries.
Much has changed to this program since its introduction 60 years ago. Firstly, the definition of Highly Skilled Migrant has blurred, from someone with a specific expertise needed in the Netherlands, to someone that earns more than roughly â‚¬70k per year. Secondly, the duration of the tax advantage shortened from 10 to 8 to 5 years. And finally, just a year ago, the percentage of tax-exempt salary has decreased. Just like Milka has been gradually replacing cocoa with palm oil and Uniqlo has added polyester to their T-shirts, the Dutch government, too, has diluted its concentration of a promised land.
Between 2010 and 2022, the number of expats in the Netherlands nearly tripled, reaching about 70 thousand. The incentive to attract skilled labour has clearly worked. But instead of celebrating this with a champagne and liquorice candy, officials in the Hague have started to scale back the program. Soâ€¦ attracting expats is now a bad thing?
I think the Dutch government finally realised that itâ€™s neither good nor bad, but itâ€™s complicated.
Learning the local opinions from personal anecdotes and discussions, as well as Dutch media and online forums, I can confirm that the policy has more resonance than a simple reimbursement that it claims to be.
One thing I love about the Dutch is how hard it is to annoy them. It takes a group of stoned British lads disregarding the cyclist's path to cross that barrier. Even then, the worst that happens is a Dutchie elbowing the tourist so that they trip, while they couldâ€™ve run them over and still win in any Dutch court (since cyclist paths are sacred and bikes always have priority).
Bottom line is, the Dutch are easy-going people, not precious about things. Thatâ€™s why very often their opinion about the 30% ruling goes along the lines of: â€œit doesnâ€™t affect me, so why would I careâ€, â€œthe policy is there to use it, so let expats use itâ€, or even: â€œitâ€™s not right to envy someone when I already have a good lifeâ€. Besides, apparently expats are polite and their culture doesnâ€™t bother others.
The neutral attitude can trend towards solidarity and even enthusiasm. Some Dutch people say that their country is too small to keep its economic importance without highly skilled migrants. Expats bring knowledge, innovation and jobs: they are the reason that multinational companies are not afraid to have an office in the Netherlands, which in turn creates jobs for the locals. Everybody benefits.
The â€œeverybody benefitsâ€ argument is important for Dutch people, who value equality and are proud of it. Thatâ€™s why to some, it seems unfair that they may earn the same as their expat colleagues, but take less pay home, based just on their origin.
Still, this group is not hostile to the expats. Theyâ€™re disappointed that the government facilitates unfair pay by effectively subsidising companies. If companies want to attract talent, they should just offer higher pay to everyone, to make up for the high cost of living in Holland. Some people even argue that the ruling allows companies to suppress salaries.
Then thereâ€™s the smallest and most extreme camp. Expats overcrowd big cities, donâ€™t learn the language, donâ€™t contribute to the community, and donâ€™t intend to stay. Make them pay back the cash if they leave within 5 years after their ruling ends.
Which leaves some expats confused, becauseâ€¦ wasnâ€™t that the plan all along?
Here I can speak in the first person: we know that we are seen as a contingent workforce. A touch of variety to the local fauna & flora, fertilising the economy as we hop from country to country in search of nectar. As long as most of us donâ€™t stay, weâ€™re not an invasive species.
The point of a fixed-term incentive is to get as much out of the workforce as possible in their productive years, without having to provide for them in old age.
Shortening and diluting of the ruling in the last years proves this point. Highly Skilled Migrants are still incentivised to come, they are still needed. But they are also welcome to leave.
Similarly, an argument can be made that itâ€™s fair not to pay full taxes if you havenâ€™t relied on the country before reaching a productive age.
A Highly Skilled Migrant contributes to the economy from day one. No public money has been invested in their healthcare and education.
Contrary to the locals, though, they need to take the cost and risk of relocating, and so it would seem fair that they are compensated for it. They donâ€™t have a home in the new location and their pension takes a hit. This means that applying wealth tax to their foreign properties or savings wouldnâ€™t be fair either.
Among the expats there is also a radical camp. High cost of living, high taxes, expensive health care, crap weather â€” you shouldnâ€™t even be questioning why I need an incentive to be here, they say.
Like with the hostile locals, this is a small camp. The majority of Highly Skilled Migrants are just happy to receive the ruling and not make a song and dance about it. Just like the Dutch see them: expats are polite and their culture doesnâ€™t bother others.
Some of the Highly Skilled Migrants will grow roots, if they happen to keep a good job, find a flat, meet friends and partners. Others will see how it goes, and if it doesnâ€™t go great, after five years they will have one less reason to stay.
But during those first five years, nobody knows which is which, including the expats themselves. And so, the best plan is to stay put. Invest, but not so much to tie yourself down. Find friends, but maybe just other expats who are easy to connect with. Learn a bit of language. Keep checking out LinkedIn for jobs in other cities.
Do a little taster of how itâ€™s like to live here, so that in five years, when you suddenly earn 1k less per month, you can make an informed decision if itâ€™s worth staying.
In those five years, expats can be accused of making a poor effort at integrating, but the setup doesnâ€™t encourage it, either.
Donâ€™t get me started on the language, since Iâ€™ve mentioned it so many times. Itâ€™s not pretty or easy to pick up, has little value outside of this small country, and has to be learned in oneâ€™s spare time and out of own pocket. Sure, thatâ€™s what the tax break is for, but if itâ€™s up to an individual to decide, realistically they will have other priorities in their budget.
The institutions who need and can afford Highly Skilled Migrants are multinational companies. Their employees will work in a group of other expats and their skill will be niche enough to only be relevant to another multinational company. As a result, itâ€™s unrealistic for such a person to think about switching to a Dutch business.
Iâ€™ve described at length what itâ€™s like to make friends and date as an expat. The social circle is not just your friends and partners, itâ€™s also the community around you and even wider, the strangers you meet every day. And this wider Dutch community, just like Iâ€™ve described, is characterised by the prevalent sentiment of: â€œIâ€™m not affected, so I donâ€™t mindâ€. The easy-going character of the locals allows them to ignore the expats, for good and bad. Even if internally they are annoyed by the cash that expats get, they wonâ€™t make a big deal out of it, and just get on with their life.
On the plus side, this unbothered attitude promotes a peaceful coexistence. On the downside, it kills any curiosity in the Dutch about the expats and any motivation in the expats to fit with the Dutch.
I hear it in the uninterested, short smalltalk in polite English from any Dutch person I meet. It can be translated to: I get it, youâ€™re one of the passing expats, coming here to have a good life for a few years and contribute to the economy. Iâ€™ll leave you be.
I sometimes wish they shouted back at me in their native language, as it would happen in Paris, Barcelona or even Berlin. It would mean: I want you to integrate! If you choose to live here, I need you to be a part of this community!
But no, they donâ€™t need us to integrate, they understand we probably wonâ€™t. They assume we probably wonâ€™t. They just donâ€™t care if we do or not.
That attitude of indifference in the Dutch, a very indirect and unplanned consequence of the 30% ruling, is the real reason for the transient character of Amsterdam.
Itâ€™s a city where everyone assumes that you may just be on a grown-up exchange program, so by absorbing the local atmosphere, you start to believe that yourself.
Eventually, when your ruling runs out, if you decide that itâ€™s worth it to graduate from a nomad to a settler, you will likely settle outside of Amsterdam anyway. Maybe youâ€™ll look for more space, more greenery, maybe youâ€™ll want to hear Dutch on the streets and contribute to the community. Most likely, youâ€™ll just be fed up with Amsterdam property prices, which have gone up a lot in the last few years, similarly to the number of Highly Skilled Migrants.
The Dutch attitude of â€œthe 30% ruling doesnâ€™t affect me, so I donâ€™t have an opinion about itâ€ ends when their house search starts. Without a doubt, they will find it very hard to buy a property, and at the same time, they will meet many foreigners who are to do it. And now they wonder: does the tax break for expats really not affect me? Or if an expat with spare cash didnâ€™t overbid on the house I wanted, maybe it wouldâ€™ve been mine?
And thatâ€™s how the expats, who are apparently polite and whose culture doesnâ€™t bother others, have apparently caused the housing crisis in Amsterdam. But thatâ€™s a topic for next time.
medium.com
--
--
7
A cultural anthropologist looking at Amsterdam and London

Title: The Nuxt Web â€” Vue Amsterdam Conference 2022 Summary series â€” Eighth Talk
Content:

Welcome! Happy to see you in the seventh part of my Vuejs Amsterdam Conference 2022 summary series, in which I share a summary of all the talks with you.
You can read my JSWorld Conference 2022 Summary series (in four parts) here, where I summarized all the first dayâ€™s talks. You can also find the previous Talks of the Vue Amsterdam conference 2022 in my blog.
After two and a half years, JSWorld and Vue Amsterdam Conference were back in Theater Amsterdam between 1 and 3 June, and I had the chance to attend this conference for the first time. I learned many things, met many wonderful people, spoke with great developers, and had a great time. On the first day the JSWorld Conference was held, and on the second and third days, the Vue Amsterdam.
The conference was full of information with great speakers, each of whom taught me something valuable. They all wanted to share their knowledge and information with other developers. So I thought it would be great if I could continue to share it and help others use it.
At first, I tried to share a few notes or slides, but I felt it was not good enough, at least not as good as what the speaker shared with me. So I decided to re-watch each speech, dive deeper into them, search, take notes and combine them with their slides and even their exact words in their speech and then share it with you so that what I share with you is at least at the same level as what I learned from them.
Everything you read during these few articles is the result of the effort and time of the speaker itself, and I have only tried to learn them so that I can turn them into these articles. Even many of the sentences written in these articles are exactly what they said or what they wrote in Slides. This means if you learn something new, it is because of their efforts.
Last but not least, I may not dig into every technical detail or live codings in some of the speeches. But if you are interested and need more information, let me know and Iâ€™ll try to write a more detailed article separately. Also, donâ€™t forget to check out their Twitter/Linkedin.
Here you can find the program of the conference:
www.jsworldconference.com
Sebastien Chopin â€” Co-Founder of Nuxt
Our mission at @nuxtlabs is to provide the best Developer Experience to deliver the best User Experience for your end users. We are doing this with Nuxt for six Years now.
Nuxt is a web framework for creating any kind of Vue app. That means you can do:
Since the beginning of Nuxt in October 2016 it has been downloaded about 46M times on npm, has 300k live websites, and 18k GitHub contributors.
This is a hello world bundle size comparison between Nuxt 2 and Nuxt 3:
One of the reasons Nuxt 3 is so much smaller is that itâ€™s tree shakable, like Vue 3. So if you donâ€™t use a feature, it will not be included in the bundle.
The Next equivalent bundle size is around 80kB.
In that Nuxt 3 JS bundle, 25.3kB are from Vue, and the 8.7kB left includes:
Edge Side Rendering â€” also named JavaScript containers by Ryan Dahl â€” is the capability of running JavaScript at the CDN nodes somewhere around the world close to the end user.
The advantages:
Some of the Edge computing providers right now:
Nuxt Content is a Nuxt module that reads Markdown, YAML, CSV, and JSON files in the content/ directory to create a powerful data layer for your application and Content V2 is out now with more features.
Whatâ€™s coming for Nuxt 2.X:
Whatâ€™s coming for Nuxt 3.0:
I hope you enjoyed this part and it can be as valuable to you as it was to me.
Over the next few days, Iâ€™ll share the rest of the talks with you. Stay tunedâ€¦

Title: Amsterdam Adventure Itinerary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A Bowl Full of Lemons is a publication that is focused on the lessons learned from the pandemic and the ways in which our lives have changed. The focus will always be on moving forward with joy while honoring the loss and challenges of the past.

Member-only story
--
Share
This month I am engaged in an experiment. Normally I spend a lot of time with my family, who live only a few doors away from my apartment in Amsterdam. However, they are on a month-long adventure to Great Britain, leaving me on my own. Rather than feeling sorry for myself, I am creating a monthâ€™s worth of exciting touristy plans where I am going to pretend to be a tourist in my own city.
I havenâ€™t developed a full itinerary yet. Today, August 1st, I helped my family get to the train station, then came home and relaxed after several days of helping them pack for their own adventure, which consists of biking all over Great Britain and camping for a good portion of that time.
I am also getting started on creating a calendar. I am going to publish the first draft of it, which will consist of a few plans Iâ€™ve made in advance by necessity, such as making reservations for the Van Gogh Museum and my oncologist appointment, which was scheduled six months ago. I will add activities as they ariseâ€”some of which will be pre-planned, and some will be scheduled the way I most enjoy things: on the fly, depending upon my mood and the weather.
There are a number of things I donâ€™t want to miss, such as going on a canal cruise or visiting some of the lessâ€¦
--
--
A Bowl Full of Lemons is a publication that is focused on the lessons learned from the pandemic and the ways in which our lives have changed. The focus will always be on moving forward with joy while honoring the loss and challenges of the past.
Writer, poet, gardener, life-long learner, warrior for children, lover of faerie, freedom, and joy. From a long line of badass women. She/her/hers

Title: Exploration of Amsterdam.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Amsterdam is one of the most mysterious cities I have ever visited. Each time you believe youâ€™ve witnessed everything, a mere stroll around the corner reveals that youâ€™ve scarcely glimpsed its true essence.
Its history is marked by episodes of violence, stardom, and war. That can be seen in the buildings in the city. The old buildings bring stories from the past, while the new buildings show the path to the future.
Iâ€™ve frequented Amsterdam on several occasions, mainly for shopping. The shops in my hometown pale in diversity compared to the offerings in Amsterdam.
In 2022, I journeyed to Amsterdam with dual objectives: to experience my first boat ride and explore (as Iâ€™d heard) the largest Rituals store in Europe.
Navigating the canals was a first for me. Would it mirror the majesty portrayed in films? When the opportunity arose, I eagerly seized it!
Spoiler Alert: The experience fell short of the cinematic majesty.
Nonetheless, it proved to be a beautiful and enjoyable tour. Our guide shared historical insights, and I captured a series of photographs:
--
--
Curious about people, growth, and the little things in life. I write to reflect, connect, and understandâ€”not just the world around me, but the world within.

Title: What Amsterdam and Dubai Taught Me About UX
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Cities and their spaces are designed experiences â€” weâ€™re just not always aware weâ€™re users. Within these spaces, we encounter countless touchpoints â€” physical, emotional, and social â€” all shaping the way we experience them.
With a background in product design and professional experience in UX, Iâ€™ve always understood user experience as something holistic, more than digital interactions. But during a recent trip to Amsterdam and Dubai, I noticed something deeper: cities themselves are designed experiences.
Walking through these two very different cities made me reflect on how much urban design and service design overlap. From the ease of getting around to the emotional tone a space creates, I started seeing each city as a living system â€” one with its own user flows, pain points, and design choices.
In this article, I share some of those observations from my personal experience and the UX lessons I took from them.
My trip began in Amsterdam â€”a city where user experience extends beyond screens, shaping how people move through their environment every day. One of the first things I noticed was how bikes arenâ€™t treated as a leisure activity or exercise, but as the primary means of getting around. People bike everywhere, even to nightclubs.
Back home in Portugal, cycling is more of a weekend activity â€” something for fitness or family outings. In Amsterdam, itâ€™s everyday life. That difference struck me, not just because it was unfamiliar, but because it revealed something deeper: how infrastructure shapes behavior, and how behavior, over time, becomes culture. The flat terrain, narrow streets, and widespread bike infrastructure all work together to make biking the most natural choice.
Design made it easy. Culture made it normal.
As I walked alongside the canals, passing locals on their bikes or stepping out of houseboats, I began to understand something about pace and emotional design. The layout of the city encourages slowness. Not in the sense of inefficiency, but in presence. The kind of design that makes you look around more, breathe slower, take things in. Amsterdam moves differently â€” both physically and emotionally. The environment isnâ€™t just designed for mobility; itâ€™s designed for human connection.
One small detail that caught my eye â€” and kept coming back to me â€” was something I might have overlooked if I hadnâ€™t asked about it. I noticed strange hooks jutting out from the top floor facades of the narrow houses. Curious, I brought it up to the friend travelling with me, who had already been to Amsterdam and explained that these are centuries-old fixtures for moving furniture and goods through windows. The buildings are too narrow, the staircases too tight, and so people developed an outside-in system. A centuries-old solution to a simple but real problem:
â€œHow do you get your couch into a house with stairs too small and steep to carry it up?â€
Itâ€™s a quiet example of design under constraint. Faced with tight architecture (partly shaped by historic tax laws), people innovated through a humble, mechanical workaround. What struck me most is that itâ€™s still used today. It reminded me of a moment in Urbanized, the documentary by Gary Hustwit, where itâ€™s mentioned how the most meaningful urban innovations often come from the bottom up â€” citizens adapting space to fit real needs.
The second and final part of the trip was spent in Dubai. If Amsterdam felt spontaneous and human-scale, Dubai felt curated â€” like someone was handling it for me.
Getting around wasnâ€™t just about driving â€” it was about being moved. From valet parking to full-service fuel stations where we never had to leave the car, every step of the journey felt taken care of.
Across both service and transport, I noticed a pattern: the city was designed to require less from me. Less friction. Less effort. Fewer choices to make. I could compare it to a seamless user journey where each step is thoughtfully designed, with no critical pain points.
In UX, we talk about reducing cognitive load and anticipating needs. In Dubai, it felt like that idea was everywhere. From how you moved to how you were received, the environment kept stepping in for you before you even realised what you needed.
As I settled into Dubai, it became immediately clear that the city was designed with an extraordinary level of attention to detail. In fact, it was so present that I almost didnâ€™t realise it at first.
It wasnâ€™t just that Dubai was clean â€” it was that someone was always cleaning it. From mall bathrooms to rooftop clubs, I saw staff quietly maintaining the space, constantly resetting it. And thatâ€™s when it hit me: it wasnâ€™t just about upkeep; it was an integral part of the user experience.
Most people only notice cleanliness when itâ€™s absent. In Dubai, it was so proactive and seamless that it became a continuous, visible signal of care. There was a sense that the space was always ready for you, that someone had already anticipated your needs. This wasnâ€™t just about hygiene; it was about creating a sense of psychological safety, comfort, even luxury. Cleanliness here didnâ€™t just make the space more pleasant; it made you feel valued. It told you: your experience matters. Everything was designed to make you feel supported, reducing mental load so you could simply exist in the moment without worry.
It reminded me of how digital services work in the background â€” updating, syncing, backing up â€” without you having to lift a finger. You donâ€™t see it, but it builds a foundation of trust by keeping everything running smoothly. In Dubai, this same principle applied to the physical environment, where every detail felt carefully planned to keep things effortless.
Behind this seamless experience, of course, is a larger system of labor and structure. Dubaiâ€™s focus on high service standards relies on a workforce of trained individuals, which are migrant workers. Their work enables this constant care, and itâ€™s important to acknowledge that the experience of ease and luxury is held up by a whole infrastructure designed to support it.
As a tourist, everything felt designed to be easy, polished, and thoughtful. Not just functionally, but emotionally. It was the kind of design that made you feel cared for, without even realising it.
On a final note, the most striking aspect of my travel experience was how I was addressed. I was consistently greeted with â€œmadamâ€. It wasnâ€™t just politeness. It was a signal â€” a small, repeated gesture that carried emotional weight.
Youâ€™re seen. Youâ€™re respected. Youâ€™re valued here.
And what struck me was how consistent it was. Whether I was at a humble restaurant or shopping, the tone didnâ€™t change. The same level of care and attention showed up everywhere. That consistency created something rare: a shared emotional tone across different service levels.
In a way, this mirrored what Iâ€™d already been feeling in Dubai: that the city was designed not just to function well, but to make you feel looked after. The details werenâ€™t loud â€” but they added up. And sometimes, all it takes is a single word to shape the emotional tone of an entire place.
Luxury in Dubai is easily accessible. The views are framed just right, designed to impress and soothe. You got the sense that someone had considered how you might feel at every turn.
Of course, none of this is accidental. Dubaiâ€™s focus on aesthetics and hospitality is a cornerstone of its identity. The city markets itself on these experiences. It is curated â€” carefully and deliberately â€” to feel seamless. But even knowing that, it still worked. What stayed with me wasnâ€™t the imposing skyline or luxury touches, but the quiet signals of care: a clean space, fuel stops anticipating needs, and a respectful â€œmadamâ€ at every place. It reminded me that thoughtful environments â€” digital or physical â€” arenâ€™t just designed for function. Theyâ€™re designed to shape how we feel.
In Dubai, that feeling was clear: youâ€™re being looked after. It was frictionless, anticipatory, and emotionally consistent. A good experience designed end to end.
Looking back, itâ€™s clear how deeply our environment shapes our experience â€” often in ways we donâ€™t even realise. Whether through frictionless mobility systems, services that anticipate needs, or subtle cues that build trust and emotional safety, thoughtful design operates on many levels at once.
What surprised me most was that, in a place known for innovation and cutting-edge tech, it wasnâ€™t the digital interfaces that left the strongest impression. It was the experience of navigating the city itself â€” the people, the spaces, and the seamless care in every interaction.
Great user experience â€” whether in a product or physical space â€” isnâ€™t just about usability. Itâ€™s about how we feel while interacting with it: confident, cared for, at ease.
This trip reminded me that UX and service design extend far beyond screens. Every touchpoint â€” human, digital, or physical â€” shapes the journey. And in the best cases, that journey feels seamless â€” not because itâ€™s invisible, but because every detail works in harmony to support the user.
A note on context
The perspective in this article comes from my experience visiting Amsterdam and Dubai as a tourist. While my time in Amsterdam was shaped by exploring the city on my own, in Dubai I stayed with people who live there. That experience gave me a different kind of access â€” more immersive and seamless â€” which naturally shaped how I experienced and noticed the city.
--
--
Goal-oriented and curious UX Designer with multinational experience. Seeking an entry-level position to drive customer and business value.

When I woke up the next day I knew I was cooked. Iâ€™d wanted to go to Italy, but that wasnâ€™t realistic anymore. My engine was puttering. Plus, I was almost out of Adderall. I only had 4 pills left, enough for one more day and a plane flight. So, by that math, I had one more night left.
Using the hostel computer, I booked a one-way ticket from Amsterdam to Oâ€™hare for the following day at 5pm (17:00). I also booked new lodging for my final night. It was an outdoor campy-type place about 20-minutes away from the city center. On their website, it looked more like a trailer park than a hostel. There were no amenities other than the communal grills, firepits, and bathrooms. It was definitely weird, but I didnâ€™t mind weird, so I rolled the dice, hoping for a day of peace and quiet. I had a lot of notes to go through and memories to piece together, and that seemed like the perfect place to do it, away from the world, on mushrooms, in a trailer. Thatâ€™s what Hunter Thompson would have done to make sense of a romp of that magnitude, and Hunter was my North Star.
After checking out of the hostel and saying goodbye to Karim, I went to take care of one last errand. What do you do when youâ€™re completely exhausted and need a little extra pep that speed canâ€™t give you? You buy shoes, of course. The right pair of shoes can give you super powers. Throw in a haircut, and you can defeat an army.
Before passing out at the concert, I remembered noting that Raekwon had on a snazzy pair of blue and red Nike Dunks. Thatâ€™s probably what planted the seed. Plus, my brown low-top Converse were mangled and nearly unwearable. So, I set out on a mission to find the perfect pair of life-saving shoes to propel me through the rest of the trip.
After an hour of searching, I was just about to give up, when I saw them in the window of a skate shop. I immediately knew they were the ones. I stood staring at them like Wayne from Wayneâ€™s World did with his dream guitar. They looked like beautiful chocolate covered bananas, immaculate, and completely in line with my style, other than the 130 Euro price tag. They were emergency medical shoes though, so cost be damned. (Insurance should really cover fly shoes).
I paid the guy right after lacing them up and gave him my old Converse to toss. I felt like a new man. I was ready for whatever the next 24 hours had to throw at me.
After buying some mushrooms (I still had a ton of weed left), I checked out of my hostel, called a taxi, and headed to the trailer park. Saying goodbye to Amsterdam wasnâ€™t easy, which made the ride a little emotional for me. Throughout my hectic 6-week trip, Amsterdam had been my home base, a place where I always felt comfortable. For some reason I just fit in there. The city opened their arms for me â€” Willy Nelson, Karim, the bouncer at the Melkveg, Neil, even the pseudo-pimp who chose to spare my lifeâ€” they all looked out for me at a time when I needed it most. I felt so grateful to all of them.
I saw hippies before I even got out of the taxi, which made me uneasy. (For someone who doesnâ€™t like jamband music, I find myself around people who do quite often.)
â€œDonâ€™t worry about the hippies,â€ I told myself, â€œ youâ€™re motherfucking John McEnroe.â€
I wanted to get into the mushrooms before the sun went down, so as soon as I familiarized myself with the trailer and the surrounding area, I got right to it. Iâ€™d purchased the same style of mushrooms I had before. Iâ€™m that way with everything. If I like something, I will continue with it until it burns me, be it restaurants, people, or socks. I always get out when the gettin ceases to be good.
I took them around 5pm and wandered around in my flip flops, waiting for them to kick in. When they did, they kicked in hard, like a mule or the DEA. I took the same amount as the last time, but for some reason I was 10 times as high. When I went back into my trailer to gather myself, the exact opposite happened. I completely freaked out. My vision wasnâ€™t right. I had no clue what was going on. I grabbed a pen and wrote, â€œEVERYTHING IS REDâ€. There was a mirror in the trailer, and I made the mistake of staring into it. DO NOT make that mistake during a bad trip. During a good trip, maybe, but never during a bad one.
The mirror was firey red and my face was peeling off. Blood was dripping from my chin, it was a horrifying scene. There was also this awful sound, like the kind you hear when someone presses the red emergency button at a nuclear power plant. My brain was in crisis.
I splashed water on my face in an attempt to tamp down the flames, but it didnâ€™t work, so I started removing my clothes. They had bad juju all over them, and they needed to go.
As I was taking my pants off I looked down. Thatâ€™s when it hit me.
â€œIâ€™m not wearing my shoes! What the fuck was I thinking!?â€
As soon as I put them on, my vision went back to normal, and the blaring alarm in my head stopped. To make sure I wasnâ€™t losing my mind (I was absolutely losing my mind), I took them off again. Everything turned red. I put them on once more. No red.
Then, I heard a knock at the door.
â€œOH SHIT,â€ I whispered, tossing on a new shirt.
If youâ€™ve ever taken hallucinogens, you know a knock at the door is the last thing you want to hear. The sound itself is paralyzing. Anything can be behind that door, and I mean ANYTHING. There are no limitations to what the brain can conjure.
Then, there was a second knock.
They werenâ€™t going to give up, I could feel it in my bones. I had to open the door and face my fears. Most trips, in some way or another, are about facing your fears.
I walked over to the door and placed my hand on it to see if I could feel any weird vibrations. Nothing.
Then I grabbed the knob and turned it slowly, hoping the person had already left. When I opened the door I was greeted by a smiling, shirtless hippie with dreadlocks.
â€œHey, sorry if I scared you, man. Iâ€™m Liam. I wanted to invite you to join the group. Weâ€™ve got a fire going and weâ€™re just jamming out. Itâ€™s pretty chill.â€
While I tried to comprehend the words he was saying, he began staring down at my feet intently.
â€œThose shoes. Theyâ€™re amazing,â€ He said, slowly.
â€œTrust me, I know. Iâ€™m really high on mushrooms and they just saved my life,â€ I told him, just as slowly.
â€œHa, sounds intense. Iâ€™m on mushrooms too. We all are.â€
Before I could tell him I didnâ€™t do well in groups, Liam walked me over and started introducing me.
â€œThis is Sam. Heâ€™s really high. Be nice to him.â€
â€œSweet shoes,â€ one of them said. â€œThey look like chocolate covered bananas.â€
â€œThey do, donâ€™t they?â€ I said, enjoying my inside joke.
We hung out for a few hours. They played their guitars while I just stared into the fire. We didnâ€™t talk much, but it was nice. No one felt the need to fill the air with bullshit. We just utilized the good vibrations to enjoy our own thoughts. The red was a long lost memory, and the fire didnâ€™t scare me one bit.
When the drugs started wearing off I thanked the guys for their company and made the walk back to my trailer to call it a night. To be safe, I kept my shoes on inside. I wasnâ€™t going to make the same mistake twice. Lying in bed, I grabbed my notebook and a pen.
A+ in group setting
Was Johnny Mac a hippie?
AM I A HIPPIE?!
I stayed in bed until noon the next day, relaxing in silence and smoking joint after joint. I felt terrible about wasting weed and I still had a quarter ounce left that I didnâ€™t want to just leave in my trailer. If Iâ€™d seen anyone on the property other than the manager I would have given it to them, but I didnâ€™t. When the cab driver picked me up, I could tell he wasnâ€™t an option either, so I just stuffed the remainder into my pants pocket, assuming Iâ€™d be able to give it away at the airport.
After the cab dropped me off, I stood right in front of the exit, next to the â€œNo Weed Past This Lineâ€ sign, and held the baggie in my open hands. â€œFree weed, get your free weed. Take as much as you want. Free weed here,â€ I yelled like a peanut vendor. People just walked right past me though, one after the other. I was in disbelief. No one wanted free weed. Every 20-something that I stopped declined. Some said they had their own, while others declined based on strain preference.
â€œThese snobby bastards,â€ I thought.
I stayed as long as I could, smoking cigs, and advertising my goods. After an hour of embarrassment I gave up and threw it in the garbage (just like the stand-up comedy fliers I used to pass out in exchange for stage time). I was pissed off for the first time since Iâ€™d been in Amsterdam. It wasnâ€™t the weed thing, I was just irritable. I didnâ€™t want to go home. Home was where the problems were, where that awful basement was and all those terrible memories. I had no place else to go though. It was my momâ€™s or nothing, at least for a little while.
And just like that, my trip was over. I felt trapped again.
The flight home was anxiety filled. Instead of reading or writing I just sat there and stewed. Iâ€™d quit comedy, graduated college, left to find myself, and returned to the same exact spot, completely clueless about what to do next. The only thing I knew was that stopping to mourn and take care of myself was not an option. I had to keep running, no matter the cost.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

Title: Escaping Amsterdam, Visiting The Surprising Texel Island
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
So, you are visiting The Netherlands? Donâ€™t get stuck in Amsterdam- visit Texel! You will love it, and here is why.
Texel Island can be found in the North Eastern part of The Netherlands and is one of the five Wadden Islands, also known as the West Frisian Islands, where many city dwellers have chosen to escape the busy lifestyle and settle on this thriving yet peaceful island. The word â€œwaddenâ€ refers to the mudflats that appear with the ebb and flow of the tide. You are just there in under two hours from Amsterdam Schiphol airport by car â€” including the ferry.
Some even call it the â€œIbiza of The Netherlandsâ€ which underlines the relaxed attitude by the locals and the existence of many beach clubs.
Here it is: my 5 favourite spots!
This area is part of National Park the Dunes of Texel and has an open connection with the North Sea. Wander around and discover the many creeks The Slufter has. Great for hikes, bird watching â€” over 80 species breed here every year.
The most northern part of the island had a giant stretchy beach with a pretty lighthouse built in 1863. This makes up for long evening sunset strolls. If you are in a sporty mood you can climb the inside of the historic lighthouse by day.
My favorite place for breakfast in the lovely unofficial capital of Texel â€” Den Burg. They offer free coffee or tea with a paid breakfast if you order before 10.53am â€” random, ha! Around the open kitchen you will find all types of sourdough bread, wonderful sweet pastries and lightly roasted coffee. Must visit. Location link (Google Maps) | Website
Visiting with kids? They will love Ecomare which educates and shows how they care for seals of all kinds. Donâ€™t miss out on the daily seal feed every morning.
Location link (Google Maps) | Website
When I visit Texel I often go to this place. Get the best strawberries locally grown and picked here! If you are into it, you can wander around in the food gardens and pick your own vegetables and fruits for a small fee. You can also get buy local products here and take it with you before you depart to the ferry.
Website
Yay, this was my very first Medium post! If you love this story, make sure to Subscribe.
--
--
Content maker. Traveller. Husband. Writer. www.wilbertkramer.nl
