Title: Atlassian Connect Week 2017 Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Hi, Iâ€™m Serhat from OpsGenie. I recently had the chance to go to Atlassianâ€™s Connect Week event. I will try to share my experience at this amazing event.
I arrived in Amsterdam on Saturday afternoon and had the chance to visit lots of great places like the Van Gogh museum, the Rijksmuseum, the Heineken Experienceâ€¦
On Monday morning, I went to Atlassianâ€™s Amsterdam office at around 9:00 AM. There were many friendly people at the door who greeted me. I introduced myself and got my Atlassian Connect Week event t-shirt; then I went to the meeting area, where we had standup meetings throughout the week.
Luke Kilpatrick from Atlassian welcomed us, and everyone started introducing himself/herself. After the introductions, there were presentations about JIRA, Confluence, JIRA Service Desk, and others. I learned a lot about Atlassian products on Monday. At the end of the day, there was a happy hour event where I met great guys from all over the world. We talked about lots of things, including what our companies do and what our plans were for the weekâ€¦
I will not go into the implementation details, but during the Connect week, I mainly worked on our HipChat Add-On updates together with Nick Turskyi from HipChat. On Tuesday, I completed one of our prime goals of providing an option to simplify HipChat messages that go into the room. Now, our messages are collapsible and donâ€™t take so much space in the chat room, but they still show all the details when you extend the message or click the message to see all the details in the sidebar. Itâ€™s been implemented in a backward compatible way so that current customers who love the way it was can still use it the same way.
Wednesday started with a standup meeting where everyone said what they were working on and shared any problems they encountered. During the day, I scheduled meetings with JIRA, JIRA Service Desk and Confluence teams. There were lots of useful ideas on how to improve our current applications and add new ones to provide a complete workflow using Atlassian tools.
I added an unacknowledge action option to the HipChat sidebar. Now, users can unacknowledge their alerts â€” in addition to acknowledging and closing them â€” without leaving the HipChat room.
At the end of the day, Atlassian organized a trip to the Amsterdam Museum. It was a great trip, and we learned a lot about Amsterdam. After the trip, there was another happy hour next to the museum. After all that, we felt a bit hungry and decided to explore Indonesian food at Kantjil.
On Thursday, I had a meeting with a UI/UX team and got feedback on our HipChat Add-On. I implemented action buttons for the alert list view in the chat sidebar that makes executing actions faster. I also worked on implementing an add note action option, using HipChat dialogs. It was nearly done, but it could not be released (because of a bug). Thursday was intensive, because the next day would be our demo day!
Friday was our demo day, and I had the chance to present information about our product and about what I accomplished during the week. Many great companies shared their products and proved the strength of the Atlassian platform.
It was truly a great week in Amsterdam!
I met with developers from all over the world, learned a lot about their products, exchanged ideas, explored Amsterdam, and developed great Atlassian add-ons.
Take a look, below, at some of my other pictures from this wonderful week.
Oh: special thanks to Michael Lauricella from Atlassian, Nick Turskyi from HipChat, Hector Urtubia and Matt Pizzimenti from Olark, Nic from Fugue, and Brandon from PingPilot. This week would not have been as great without you guys!
Originally published at www.opsgenie.com.

Title: Moving to Amsterdam is Brutal, here is my experience after one week.

Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story

Share
Two weeks ago I decided Amsterdam would be my place to settle, hoping finally this would be the place for me and even though I had been warned by my peers and colleagues, I did all my homework, studied the market and told myself that it couldnâ€™t be as hard as finding an apartment in China, where everybody just spoke Mandarin to do so.
I was extremely wrong, the market here is insane, maybe because we are in a post-covid season and the city is blooming with tourism, perhaps is the interest younger people have towards trying the so-called â€œlegal drugsâ€, it might be due to the high season rental as schools and Universities are starting again or simply just a slip from the Dutch government when considering housing options for everybody.
The reality is that thousands of people are competing on a daily basis to find an apartment, a room or at least a long-term stay without paying a kidney and a half for it.
I got an Airbnb type of apartment via Expedia, it was a great deal for one week, only paying 917â‚¬ after my Genius 30%â€¦

Title: How is Amsterdam for a Young Adult
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Iâ€™ve been more time as an adult in Amsterdam, than in my home country. In Amsterdam, there are many options for everything. But be careful. Itâ€™s so very easy to get lost in Amsterdam. For me Amsterdam is stressful.
Study
In Amsterdam, you will find all sorts of studying careers, and people are very free on choosing. Many Dutch people drop out in the first or second program because â€œthey donâ€™t like itâ€. And is very normal to try different things. Education is many times in English. However I would say that education can be very stressful because itâ€™s a bit chaotic and challenging at the same time. You have to do everything by yourself, and teachers are more mentors than teachers. Itâ€™s like you never can really relax, and you have to think a LOT in every subject, because education here priorities thinking by yourself, they absolutely infinitely 100% hate things â€œby the bookâ€ (typical Dutch). Of course, you meet people from everywhere. Your colleagues are from everywhere. It can be stressful, especially if you come from cultures where â€œeverything is organizedâ€, where you know what you really gonna learn, where grades matter a lot, where everything has a specific linear way of being. In Amsterdam simply things are free.
Informality
Here no one likes any form of formality. Everything must be informal by default. No one absolutely no one cares about formal clothing, and genuinely everyone will hate that. Itâ€™s notâ€¦
--
--
Cultural animal living in a social experiment

Title: Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam moves. People walk briskly, bikes fly past, trams glide along their rails. Everyone seems to have a place to be, a purpose to fulfill. And yet, despite the chaos â€” bikes weaving through pedestrians, cars stopping and starting, boats slipping quietly through the canals â€” thereâ€™s a strange kind of order. No honking, no shouting, no visible frustration. Just movement. It feels like watching a symphony with no conductor, a city that somehow just knows how to keep itself in rhythm.
I sit by a restaurant window and watch it all unfold. The rain-speckled glass blurs the edges of passing figures, turning them into something out of a painting. I catch glimpses of them â€” sharp jawlines, loose scarves, hands tucked into the pockets of long coats. I find myself romanticizing over every woman that walks by, assigning them stories theyâ€™ll never know theyâ€™ve been given. Sheâ€™s on her way to meet a friend. Sheâ€™s heading home after a long day at work. Sheâ€™s just as lost in thought as I am.
And then there are the couples. The ones who share a cigarette outside a cafÃ©, the ones who lean into each other on their bikes, the ones who donâ€™t need words to fill the space between them. I am content here, alone, but I canâ€™t help but envy them. Amsterdam is beautiful on its own, but I imagine it would be even better when shared.
The Dutch language wasnâ€™t a necessity â€” I couldâ€™ve gotten by just fine without it â€” but Iâ€™m glad I learned it anyway. Even simple exchanges feel like small victories, a way of stepping further into this place instead of just passing through it. And the food? The beer? It all just sits better. Thereâ€™s a freshness to it, a simplicity. I donâ€™t leave meals feeling sluggish, just satisfied.
Maybe thatâ€™s the feeling Iâ€™ll take home with me â€” not just the admiration, not just the longing, but the quiet contentment of being here. The realization that I donâ€™t have to understand how everything works to appreciate that it does.
--
--
Just a place to keep my thoughts. Maybe you can relate to them.

Title: Amsterdam Is Laying Down a Model for What Tourism Should Look Like After COVID
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Research and opinion articles from scholars based on their more academic research published in â€œTourism Geographies: an International Journal of Tourism Space, Place and Environmentâ€

--
Listen
Share
By Johannes Novy
When COVID hit the Netherlands in 2020, Amsterdam emptied of visitors overnight. Long-term residents, inured to the permanent noise and litter and tourists peeing in the streets, welcomed the newfound tranquillity. The pandemic, they told the Washington Post, was â€œa blessing in disguiseâ€.
COVID has offered a rare, if not unique chance to address tourismâ€™s enduring problems. From how people reach destinations to how tourism is managed within the cities it floods, not to mention the way its benefits and costs are distributed to local communities, the burden of overtourism has long been a concern.
Amsterdammers arenâ€™t the only city dwellers to perceive the current pause as a much needed relief. From Kyoto to Venice, residents see a return to pre-pandemic tourist numbers as a threat, not a promise.
For years, weâ€™ve been told that tourism needs to be sustainable, without much consensus on what sustainable tourism looks like. COVID, meanwhile, has seen the term â€œresilienceâ€ become a go-to for industry insiders and policymakers. But what exactly is resilient tourism? And can it make our cities any more socially and environmentally responsible? Can it make them any better to live in?
Broadly conceived as the ability to manage adversity, resilience is touted as an essential quality for coping with uncertainty and change, stress and shock. As trends go, resilience isnâ€™t new. It was Time Magazineâ€™s environmental buzzword of the year in 2013. It has since become one of the dominant tropes in contemporary debate on everything from island studies and child psychology to urban disaster risk reduction.
The pandemic has of course brought global tourism to a virtual standstill. In 2020, 1 billion fewer international trips were made to tourist destinations than in 2019. Up to 120 million jobs were threatened. So thinking about how this industry, which previously supported one in ten jobs worldwide, might cope with the stress and shock of COVID is no bad thing.
However, critical geographers and political sociologists alike have warned that the concept of resilience is in danger of becoming as empty a notion as sustainability. It has its roots in ecological and engineering thinking, wherein it refers to the ability to return to normal ï¼ to a state of equilibrium â€” after a period of adversity. Critics argue though that, in the social world, we deal not with equilibrium structures, but constant flux.
In a city, there is no normal state to return to. And those affected by natural hazards â€” a coastal mega-city prone to flooding, say â€” were vulnerable to begin with. Returning to an original state is therefore as undesirable as it is impossible. Instead, cities adapt.
More broadly, resilience thinking is deemed inherently conservative. With the emphasis it places on bouncing back, it is underscores reactive and short-term solutions. These distract from the need to address the root causes of major challenges such as climate change.
It is also not as harmless a theory as it may seem. When politicians insist that investing in a more resilient city is plain common sense, they often downplay issues of power and inequality. New Orleans is a case in point. Rebuilding after hurricane Katrina in 2005 came at enormous social cost, when the city privileged economic gain over the needs of marginalised communities.
Resilience is nonetheless an elastic concept, and it is increasingly associated not only with the ability to bounce back after a setback, but also to bounce forward â€” to a new and better state. The UK governmentâ€™s slogan â€œ Build Back Betterâ€, has become the mantra for a myriad post-COVID ambitions, particularly with regard to tourism.
That said, as travel restrictions are lifted and the cruise ships return to Veniceâ€™s St Markâ€™s Square, mere weeks after the Italian government promised they wouldnâ€™t, it looks like this golden opportunity to rethink tourism has been lost.
Governments generally seem more interested in a return to business as usual than in thinking about how much tourism we can actually afford. Calls to come up with a fairer, less exploitative model have, at best, been met with a muted political response. Governments appear loath to discourage business trips, despite climate scientists advocating for less air travel, because they bring in money.
Any attempt to make tourism truly resilient, however, has to go further than short-term economic recovery. It has to address the tourism sectorâ€™s carbon footprint and its injustices and ethical quandaries.
In this respect, Amsterdam presents an interesting model. COVID has accelerated the implementation of several measures under consideration well before the pandemic took hold. The city has adopted ordinances that variously prevent souvenir shops from displacing local businesses, developers from turning residential spaces into holiday lets, and new hotels from being built.
Elsewhere, it has hiked up the tax tourists pay for overnight stays and introduced measures to reduce the so-called incivilities (littering, public urination) they unthinkingly leave behind.
More broadly, it has become the first city ever to embrace British economist Kate Raworthâ€™s doughnut economics model for sustainable development. This theory centres on the environment and the basic needs of its citizens as opposed to economic growth. The council has pledged to use it as a guideline for all future policies that govern urban life â€” from emissions regulations to fixing the cityâ€™s housing crisis.
It is still too early to say whether these efforts will pay off. Without a similarly bold rethink, though, more residents will likely rebel against the touristification of their communities. If, on the other hand, more cities follow the Dutch capitalâ€™s example (as Copenhagen, Brussels, Dunedin in New Zealand and Nanaimo in Canada are reportedly doing), the idea of a real bounce forward might indeed apply.
Originally published at https://theconversation.com on June 16, 2021.
Readers might also be interested in this news article also published on June 16, 2021:
www.schengenvisainfo.com
Johannes Novy â€” Senior Lecturer in Urban Planning, School of Architecture and Cities, University of Westminster
Johannes Novy does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.

Title: 2 hours of Take In and Let Go in Amsterdam
Content:

Sign up

Our luggage and other heavy things have all been stashed in an L-size locker at Amsterdam Centraal. Sweet! Aww, my inner child jolted as soon as we exited Amsterdam Centraal. At the same time, my eyes caught a lady skipping happily toward someone who seemed to be waiting for her. A display of simple human happiness. I thought momentarily, â€˜Wow, there are so many people here!â€™ It seems the weekend atmosphere had contributed to the crowd. And that crowd! This sight quickly reminded me how â€˜internationalâ€™ this city â€” or country â€” is.
Stepping out of the square, the tram rails are lined right up next to the road. The way they weave together looks a bit messy on the asphalt. Iâ€™ve seen similar setups in other places, but I still find it a bit tricky to wrap my head around all these different modes of transportation crammed together. I prefer things to be a little plainer.
To cross the road, I found myself a bit disoriented at first; I wasnâ€™t sure if there was a designated area for crossing. Later that day, Bu Jeannie used the phrase â€˜Indonesian way.â€™ Sekar and I, after observing the traffic situation, also mentioned it and joked about doing it the â€˜Indo way.â€™
Weâ€™ve got Google Maps in hand. We try to be wise with our batteries. We want to use Sekarâ€™s phone for navigation and my phone for taking pictures. The direction is facing the city: headingâ€¦

Title: Hallo Amsterdam!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
I idly watched tiny droplets of moisture licking at the planeâ€™s wings as cotton wool clouds and sparkling sunbeams made way for a sea of green and grey, followed by a seemingly-endless taxi along the runway. Almost as soon as Iâ€™d left the UK, I was in Amsterdam for a springtime mini break. The grey skies above did nothing to dull my spirit as I muddled through the train system and took a final, deep breath of city air. Thatâ€™s right. After a pretty hefty hiatus from Medium, Iâ€™m back â€” and accompanied by tales from a small European country known as The Netherlands in April 2025.
As I left the station, I was hit instantly with the lingering aroma of marijuana, coupled with street music and a relentless stream of bicycles. Weaving through tiny streets, the constant bang bang bang of my suitcase wheels on the cobbles grew more comforting than annoying. Finally, after a few wrong turns, I could see the sign for my hostel just up ahead.
I had a little time to kill and so resolved to head out on foot. I ended up down a major shopping street, but resisted the urge to pop into the large Primark. Scatteredâ€¦

Title: My Recommendations from 5 Weeks in Amsterdam!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I first visited Amsterdam in March for less than a week and absolutely loved it! I connected with new family members, made friends, and saw all of the incredible attractions of the city. The city is gorgeous, with endless canals and narrow streets. Everyone bikes, and people put a lot of effort into keeping the city beautiful and full of flowers. Itâ€™s also a diverse, young city, which creates a great community for newcomers. Plus, the everyday fashion in Amsterdam is incredible. Everyone always looks put together, especially in the city center. Unsurprisingly, the clothing stores are beautiful and curated to classic European style. If youâ€™re visiting Amsterdam, dress to impress!
There is so much to love about Amsterdam, which is why I decided to rent a house for about five weeks in Linjden, Amsterdam. Linjden is southwest from the city center, suburban, quiet, and I always felt safe! Just two minutes away from my house was a cute goat farm, and two minutes away from that one was another (smaller) goat farm. The more I explored the area, the more goats I found! My house was on Hoofdweg, which was the perfect neighborhood to go for long walks in. The only downside is that it typically takes an hour to get into the city (30 minute tram ride), and it is a 30 minute walk to the nearest grocery store. Of course, you can always rent a bike.
I spent most of my time enjoying the suburbs of Amsterdam, but I was able to explore a significant part of the city as well. In March, I already visited most of the tourist attractions, so I was able to relax and revisit my favorites. Below, I have listed some of my top places and recommendations that can help you when visiting Amsterdam!
Sightseeing & Experiences:
Food:
Desserts:
Museums:
Queer bars:
Thrift/Vintage Stores:
I hope that this list of recommendations is helpful if you visit Amsterdam!
During my five weeks here, several friends from home visited me. My three friends from the US visited during my first week, which was mostly a disaster. Traveling with groups can be difficult, but Iâ€™m still glad that they visited me! I would happily travel with any of them again. Then later in my trip, my friend from college, Danicia, and her girlfriend stayed with me for a few nights. I have not seen Danicia since my freshman year of college at UConn and now she is living in Germany!
A couple of months ago in Dublin, I met Ariane and she was planning on coming to Amsterdam with a friend. When that plan didnâ€™t work out, I offered her a place to stay at my house in Linjden. We went to MOCO, ate sushi, took a canal tour, and had a drink at Black & Blue on Reguliersdwarsstraat. The next day, we visited the Anne Frank House, ate pancakes, and walked to the Royal Palace. We also went to Cafe Saarein for some beers and a couple games of pool, and then had a stroopwafel at Van Wonderen. Later in the evening in the Red Light District, we had dinner at an Argentinean restaurant and drinks at Cafeâ€™t Mandje. It was a busy, amazing couple of days!
Throughout my trip, I was able to visit some family members that I first met in March. I grabbed lunch with my cousin, Gosia, and my younger cousin, Indra, visited for a day. From TripBff (a travel app), I also met Diena and her friends, who were all solo travelers. During the second half of my time in Amsterdam, I hung out with a new friend, Isa, a few times and we explored some great restaurants together. I am so glad that I was able to meet some new and old friends here!
Amsterdam is a great city that I highly recommend visiting. As always, please reach out if you want solo travel tips or other recommendations!
--

Title: How I Worked and Played in Amsterdam: A Travel Diary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We curate & disseminate outstanding stories from diverse domains to create synergy. Inquiries: https://digitalmehmet.com/ Subscribe to our content marketing strategy: https://drmehmetyildiz.substack.com/

--
6
Listen
Share
Have you ever imagined immersing yourself in one of the worldâ€™s most dynamic and thrilling cities, all while advancing your career? This is the story of my remarkable journey.
As a young software engineer employed at a reputable multinational company in India, the opportunity to embark on a two-month onsite assignment in Amsterdam was nothing short of a dream come true. The mere thought of exploring Europe had always danced at the periphery of my aspirations, yet, as someone from India, such an adventure often felt distant and financially out of reach.
But I persevered, putting in the hard work and dedication necessary to secure this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Finally, the moment had arrived when I could set foot in Amsterdam, and I was filled with boundless gratitude for having reached this significant milestone. Now, let me share with you the captivating journey that unfolded, as I discovered the cityâ€™s perfect blend of work and play, and why it has become a place Iâ€™ll cherish forever.
One electrifying week before the grand adventure, I embarked on a whirlwind of preparations. With a fresh haircut and meticulous grooming, I was ready to step into the unknown. The day of departure finally dawned, and my parents joined me for a heartwarming farewell at the airport. The excitement in the air was palpable as I embarked on a journey I had been eagerly awaiting.
The flight seemed to stretch on, but the moment we touched down at Amsterdam Schiphol Airport, I was immediately captivated by the cityâ€™s breathtaking beauty. The sight was a feast for the senses, a stunning welcome to this new chapter in my life. My heart raced with anticipation as I hopped into a sleek Tesla taxi. The streets were teeming with high-end cars, and the buzz around Tesla was infectious. Riding in one was nothing short of a thrilling adventure, marking the exhilarating start of my Amsterdam odyssey.
I arrived at my home around 5 p.m., and it was already dark outside. I had never experienced this in India, where the sun sets much later. My friend and I were so excited to be in Amsterdam that we decided to make dinner and go to bed early so that we could wake up early the next morning and start exploring.
I was nervous on my first day at the office in Amsterdam. I had never been to the city before. But as soon as I walked in, I was greeted by warm smiles from my new colleagues and clients.
My Indian colleagues introduced me to everyone, including my Dutch clients. I was immediately struck by how friendly and welcoming everyone was. My client even asked me about my journey to Amsterdam and how I was settling in.
At lunchtime, I went out with my senior colleagues, we had a delicious meal together. We talked about everything from what we needed to settle in, to the Dutch culture, and some places to travel. I felt so comfortable and at ease.
By the end of the day, I had made a lot of new friends in the office and learned a lot about the company and the city. I was so grateful for the warm welcome I had received.
Through the days, I effortlessly adapted to the Amsterdam culture and people, and I also explored the cityâ€™s many attractions. I was captivated by Amsterdamâ€™s distinctive beauty. My personal experience revealed five compelling reasons why Amsterdam stands out as an exceptional destination for both work and leisure:
Canals that Captivate: Amsterdamâ€™s intricate network of canals is a sight to behold, earning it the nickname â€œVenice of the North.â€ The reflection of gabled houses in the still waters, along with charming bridges and tree-lined streets, creates a picturesque scene that is reminiscent of a fairytale. For example, the Prinsengracht Canal is home to many beautiful 17th-century houses, while the Keizersgracht Canal is known for its elegant mansions. The canals are also a great place to spot boats and people-watch.
Historical Charm: Amsterdamâ€™s well-preserved architecture stands as a testament to its rich history. As you stroll through the city, youâ€™ll encounter stunning 17th-century buildings, each with its own unique character and story, offering a glimpse into the cityâ€™s past. For example, the Anne Frank House is a poignant reminder of the cityâ€™s role in World War II, while the Royal Palace is a magnificent example of Dutch Baroque architecture. The cityâ€™s canals are also lined with historic buildings, such as the gabled houses of the Jordaan neighborhood.
Cultural Diversity: The city is a melting pot of cultures, and this diversity is reflected in its art, food, and people. From world-class museums like the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum to vibrant neighborhoods like De Pijp, thereâ€™s a cultural richness that adds to the cityâ€™s allure.
Laid-back atmosphere: Amsterdam has a relaxed and easy-going atmosphere. I appreciated the friendly demeanor of the locals, as it was quite common for strangers to exchange warm greetings with smiles. In all my travels to various countries, I had never witnessed such a welcoming attitude towards strangers.
Diverse workforce: Amsterdam has a diverse workforce, with people from all over the world living and working in the city. This diversity makes for a vibrant and exciting work environment.
Bicycle-Friendly Bliss: Amsterdamâ€™s flat terrain and extensive network of cycling lanes make it a cyclistâ€™s paradise. The sight of countless bicycles whizzing past historic sites, parks, and picturesque canals is not only beautiful, but it is also an embodiment of the cityâ€™s eco-friendly ethos. Conveniently, there are bicycle pumps attached to some bicycle areas for filling tires.
Amsterdam is a foodieâ€™s paradise, with a wide variety of restaurants and dishes to choose from, whether youâ€™re looking for a quick bite or a leisurely meal. I sampled some of the cityâ€™s most famous dishes, including:
Poffertjes: Small pancakes often served with powdered sugar, fruit, or syrup.Stroopwafels: Thin waffles filled with sweet syrup.Stamppot: Traditional Dutch mashed potatoes with vegetablesErwtensoep: Popular Dutch pea soup, also available in vegetarian versions.
My love for the delicious waffles was only surpassed by my visit to Zaanse Schans, Amsterdamâ€™s old town, where I sampled a variety of delectable cheeseses. I promise you, they were incredibly tasty!
My two months in Amsterdam were an unforgettable experience. I had the opportunity to work on a challenging project, meet new people from all over the world, and explore a beautiful and vibrant city. I also had the chance to travel to other parts of Europe, which was a dream come true.
Iâ€™m so grateful for the opportunity I had to live and work in Amsterdam. It was an experience that has changed me for the better. I made lifelong friends, learned new things, and created memories that will last a lifetime.
When it was time to leave, I was sad to say goodbye to my new friends and the city I had come to love. But I know that I will return one day. Amsterdam has a special place in my heart, and I canâ€™t wait to go back and explore more.
Vincent van Gogh once said, â€˜Amsterdam is a city of dreams, and I am a dreamer.â€™
I couldnâ€™t agree more. Amsterdam is a city that inspires creativity and imagination. Itâ€™s a city where anything is possible. If youâ€™re looking for a city that will challenge and inspire you, Amsterdam is the place for you.
I hope that this blog post has given you a glimpse into my experience in Amsterdam. If youâ€™re ever thinking about visiting this amazing city, I highly recommend it!
ğŸ“šThank you for reading! If you enjoyed my stories, consider following me and giving this post a â€˜ğŸ‘â€™ to show your support. Your engagement and comments inspire me to keep sharing more stories with you

Title: Best things to do in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
happy, unique, goofy
1 week (or forever if you can)
Wow! I honestly love Amsterdam so much! The people seem so at ease with life and It is a very liberal spiritual place. Everyone is very open minded and accepting of anyone.
Amsterdam is mainly Dutch people so a lot of the people are very tall and blond. Another thing to consider is prostitution, weed, and psychedelics such as truffles are legal despite this everyone seems incredibly responsible and people seem to keep a good balance of life in Amsterdam. It really is the happiest and most open minded place Iâ€™ve been to so far and thatâ€™s why it is my favorite place so far.
Right from Amsterdam Central you can take a free ferry that will take you to NDSM and it takes about 5â€“10 mins to get there and the Ferry comes constantly I honestly felt like I never had to wait for one. NDSM is a hip urban area with lots of cool graffiti and hip restaurants to check out. Not to mention the interesting places you can stay at like the Crane hotel oh and you can also bungee jump from it, if you decide to. The area also has lots of special events such a music festivals, flea markets, and movie nights. Its a great place to check out and Its not too crowded so itâ€™s nice getting away from all the people in the main area.
This may be one of my favorite museum trips that I have gone on so far. I really liked that it focused on one artist throughout, and I felt like I really got to see Van Goghâ€™s life and how it affected his art. I have to say I am a HUGE Van Gogh fan, I really love his brush strokes and his bright use of color. I felt like I got pulled into every single painting diving into each brush stroke and seeing the lines up close then pulling back to see the full picture that he created. I donâ€™t know how he did it but he made each scene look so serene and stylized.
I need to also mention the sensory room where each room you get the senses that Van Gogh was feeling throughout his life. I thought it was so creative because I truly felt like I was living and seeing the things that Van Gogh felt.
I mean you honestly canâ€™t go to Amsterdam without going to the Red Light District at least once. Walking through the red light district you canâ€™t take any photos. You basically see women in windows with red lights above them in their underwear standing or sitting, and they kind of look bored or like their busy looking at their phone. It was an interesting experience but one to definitely check out and experience once.
One of the most unforgettable experiences I have had so far, Aâ€™dam lookout is where you go on the top of one of the buildings and there are these 2 electric swings that basically swing you back and fourth for about 2 mins. It was seriously such a magical feeling I honestly felt like I was on top of the world and flying for a second. I will admit it was really scary because you are so high up and you look down and donâ€™t see anything right under you but it is one of the things that you canâ€™t really forget because you just feel so much.
The canal tour is so worth it, you basically just go down the canals throughout the city, it is so fun to see all the little boat houses right on the canals.
I personally really liked the Mocco museum because it had more urban graffiti artists such Banksy, icy & slot, Koons and Warhol. They also had a 3D installation room where you walk into a room in the style of Lichtenstein (which is the bright comic book style with bold colors and lines throughout). The museum is not that big but I kind of like that, your not overwhelmed by all of the art and you can engage in each and every one. Each piece had a strong statement about freedom and freedom of expression.
I checked out multiple psychedelic shops (there were many) and these 2 stood out the most to me.
Kokopelli was very informal and the staff really knew their stuff and loved to talk about it, they sold lots of other interesting things such as Brazilian herbs to help with lucid dreaming. Or seeds that you can grow and eat for different types of needs. They even had an area where you can sit and take your shrooms if you decide to buy it from them.
Alien Visitors s a fun small raver type of shop, with techno music playing and neon fluorescent items throughout the store. I ended up buying a really cute black shirt with some green neon print designs down the middle. It wasnâ€™t too crazy with the designs like how some raver shirts can get a little tacky when its overplayed and I really love the pattern on it.
--
--
My goal is to share my journey, experiences and designs with you. I try to bring in a unique perspective into everything I see.

Title: Hereâ€™s why I chose Amsterdam over Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Today marks five years since I moved from my country to Europe, gradually settling into the vibrant life of Amsterdam. This year is my second year in the Netherlands and five years in Europe overall. This milestone feels like the right moment to reflect on the journey so far. Iâ€™m grateful for the personal and professional growth along the way â€” itâ€™s been quite a journey. I first landed in Berlin, but soon after, COVID hit, and finding a job was a real challenge during that time. After gaining experience living in Berlin, I wanted to see if there was a better place before fully committing to Germany, so I decided to look for opportunities outside of Berlin. Eventually, I found a job in Amsterdam. As things slowly started to recover, the war began, adding another layer to the experience.
My connection with Berlin runs deep. Iâ€™ve had a long relationship with the city since my early 20s, when a few of my friends moved there from St. Petersburg and helped me explore Berlin from within. The city quickly became a familiar and vibrant part of my life, with friends and unforgettable experiences. I met my boyfriend just before moving there myself (now my husband) which made the transition even more meaningful. Berlin was more than just a place to live! :) It felt like a second home. Being there was a dream come true in a natural and seamless way.
Our move to Amsterdam was driven by curiosity and a sense of uncertainty about our future in Germany. It takes a lot of effort to fully integrate there and to acknowledge the challenges of living in Germany. Here in the Netherlands, Iâ€™ve found a country that values directness, innovation, out-of-the-box thinking, and problem-solving â€” a motivating environment that has enabled me to grow both professionally and personally.
Sometimes, I feel like a character in Atlas Shrugged, navigating a landscape that mirrors Germany today â€” a system entangled in endless layers of rules, bureaucracy, reluctance to change, and a fear of moving forward that places increasing demands on companies. Germany feels like a perfect analogy to the world described in the book, where innovation is stifled by rigid structures and a lack of forward thinking. In contrast, the Netherlands represents a refreshing example of how things should operate, with efficiency, innovation, and a practical approach to problem-solving that brings real results.
Having spent years in the digital industry, focusing on process optimization, self-service, and enhancing customer experience, Iâ€™ve developed a unique perspective on understanding challenges and identifying opportunities. The Dutch approach to digital transformation, with its emphasis on innovation and efficient governance, aligns closely with my values in creating effective systems and customer-centric solutions. This kind of forward-thinking approach isnâ€™t something I found at a national level in Germany. I know many entrepreneurial people working hard to drive change, but Germany requires significant structural shifts to address the crises ahead. Neglecting change and innovation will make it increasingly difficult to overcome these challenges.
My journey began in Berlin, where I experienced Germanyâ€™s intense focus on rules, processes, and seemingly endless layers of bureaucracy. In Amsterdam, I discovered a dynamic, flexible mindset, where people think outside the box â€” and, most importantly, where people, companies, and even bureaucracies focus on solving problems, not creating more. Both countries have their strengths, yet the Netherlandsâ€™ agility and commitment to achieving real outcomes â€” not just outputs â€” have made me fall in love with the country and see hope for Europeâ€™s future.
As I look back on these five years, Iâ€™m excited about what lies ahead. Amsterdam has become more than just a place to live! Itâ€™s a community that drives my curiosity and keeps me moving forward. I look forward to continuing this journey, bringing fresh perspectives to the digital industry, and helping to solve the challenges that await us all in Europe.

1980 ~ Amsterdam, the Netherlands
Our expectations were not high when we finally entered the Eighties. The economic recession was underway; nine percent of the Dutch workforce was unemployed â€” including most of my friends. The Cold War raged over our heads, principally between the United States and the Soviet Union, and we assumed our territory would end up being the eventual nuclear battlefield. It looked like the somber adage of the Punk movement- No Future â€” would become a reality.
In the lesbian anarchist artsy milieu of hippies, squatters, punkers, musicians, and thieves, which was my habitat, our feeling was: â€˜Letâ€™s make it to 1984 first.â€™
Our life as lesbians is interwoven with a hippie background, anarchist Emma Goldmanâ€™s adage â€˜If I canâ€™t dance to it, itâ€™s not my revolutionâ€™, and the motto of another radical, Jill Johnston, â€˜All women are lesbians except those who donâ€™t know it yetâ€™. The energy of the punk movement is in our hairstyles, the fashion of New Wave in our jackets and shoes, and the political consciousness of the womenâ€™s movement in the spaces we claim give those threatening times a dynamic twist.
Right after our old Queen Juliana announced her abdication, the slogan: Geen woning geen kroning, No Housing No Crowning â€” is scrawled all over the cityâ€™s walls. This ominous message comes from the squatting movement. The die has been cast. We donâ€™t love her daughter Beatrice yet, who will be crowned Queen on April 30 at a party for nobility, royalty, and other rich folks. Amsterdam has changed from a free port to an impenetrable fortress where you need a pass to walk through the streets, and the noise of helicopters hovering over the city for days drives us crazy. I donâ€™t live in a squat; Iâ€™m not precisely adventurous that way. I pay proper rent and work as a cook in the Melkweg. But I do support the causes of the squatters: It seems criminal to leave buildings vacant. Speculation with scarce space means that buildings are left empty for years. Amsterdam looks like a rotting set of teeth because of the holes.
On Leap Day of the year 1980, I am sitting in the womenâ€™s cafe Saarein with a lezzy from Bologna, Italy, whom I met (through the informal International Lesbian Network. We toast our friendship and the International Lesbian Solidarity with espresso and Genever when the door is pushed open. A group of ruggedly dressed when women enter the cafÃ©. Their eyes are shining with excitement. â€˜We wonâ€™, they sing. A woman with a red-yellow Mohawk holds a transistor radio at her ear, tuned to Radio Stad, a local radio station. A large group of squatters chased off three platoons of Riot Police; in the Vondelstraat, â€˜The hillbillies couldnâ€™t handle it anymore,â€™ a triumphant voice shouts, Police officers are summoned from all over the country, to stop the squatters. Within ten minutes, theyâ€˜re chased out. The gals order beer and keep repeating the story of the inglorious retreat of the policemen under a shower of rocks.
A line has begun to form for the bathroom. Women enter in groups and come out with a wild look in their eyes, snorting. On the flush tank lies a cleanly wiped pocket mirror. The downstairs group has gathered to go and support the squatters. They want the cafÃ© to close and all of us to join them. After fierce deliberation, the cafÃ© stays open and promises to refer new women to the place of action. We decline the invitation. We have something else to do. We are going to an opening.We are going to an opening. Our friend Karen Kverneness from Seattle sells confection art in her shop, Art Something, on Herengracht. The art is stacked on shelves and a few large display tables like in a regular store.
Tonight, a new series from New York has arrived. Karen sells leather files with a safety pin stuck through them for twelve guilders and thirty cents apiece.â€™Betty goes punk,â€™ it says, cut-out newspaper letters. A straight-looking girl has photographed herself with punk bands from New York City.
The cream of the lesbian crop and other art freaks are feasting on American onion soup yogurt dip, flown-in bagels with cream cheese, root beer, and Four Roses bourbon. A blond, short-shaved nightingale in a menâ€™s suit stands behind a black box with a keyboard. Touching only one key, she plays a rhythmic chord. It sounds cheerful and fresh. Her voice is like a gift from heaven, and we listen breathlessly.
At KKâ€™s party, people sympathize with the squatters, but no one else wants to go and look, so the Bolognesi and I walk together through a bleak and empty Vondelpark to the Vondelstraat.
The atmosphere on Constantijn Huygensstraat is surreal. The bridge is full of loose paving stones, and barricades are on the corner of Roemer Visscherstraat. There is no triumphant frenzy here â€” more like a terse tension. From the front of the squatted house hangs a police cap as a trophy.
A group of boys talk persistently to a drunken friend who hangs back, babbling. But most of the dialog is inaudible to us. A group of intertwined figures sits beside an oil lamp, listening to a small transistor radio. A boy who wears heavy winter clothes and a black helmet stops us. â€˜What are you here for?â€™ â€˜To look, I answer. â€œWe have no place for busybodies.â€™ He turns around to indicate that he is done talking. From the group of people, one figure detaches. I recognize Tilt, a woman I know from the women cafÃ©. She climbs over the barricade and walks with us for a while.â€ Theyâ€™re excited, the men. The testosterone is racing through their veins. They expect the riot police, and they want to fight. Boys will be boys.â€She jabs me in the side.â€ I understand them. My testosterone is licking me, too,â€™ she continues, â€œand tickling me as well. I want to have sex. We only let people in weâ€™re sure of. If you want to fight with us, you are welcome, but you â€” you, old hippie you â€” violence is not your thing.â€She is right. My heart is hippy. We shake hands, Tilt slaps us on our shoulders, and we hear her crooked laugh as she walks away.

Title: Fun Facts and Must Do Things in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Stories about surviving on Earth.

--
Listen
Share
I recently traveled to Amsterdam and cannot wait to share my experience with you. It has so much to offer and is one of my favorite cities. Since this is the perfect time to visit Amsterdam, I am sharing with you the must do things in Amsterdam and as well as some interesting facts about the lively city.
Did you know?1) Amsterdam derived its name from the Amstel River.2) There are 165 Amsterdam canals that combine for a length of over 100 kilometers. The Canal Ring became part of the UNESCO World Heritage list in 2010.3) Amsterdam has more bridges than Venice. How difficult is that to believe? But there are only, in fact, 409 bridges connecting Veniceâ€™s canals. Amsterdam actually has 1,281 bridges, three times as many as Venice!4) There are approximately 2,500 houseboats in Amsterdam.5) The tilted houses are called dancing houses. The soil was so swampy that they had to build on stilts and that caused them to wobble and sink into the river.6) The number of bicycles in Amsterdam is more than the number of people living in the city.7) Amsterdam has approximately 20 times more tourists throughout the year than the locals.8) Amsterdam is one of the top 25 safest cities in the world and also one of the top 15 cities known for its high standard of living. Who would have thought, with all the marijuana and prostitution?9) A study reveals that Dutch men are the tallest people in the world.10) Amsterdam lies below the sea level and is among the top five coffee consuming cities in the world.11) Amsterdam Stock Exchange is the oldest stock exchange in the world.12) Same-sex marriage is legal in Amsterdam. The Netherlands was the first country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage.
How to travel around Amsterdam
The best way to explore the city is either on a bike or on foot. Even if you only pedal around for a few hours, riding a bike is an essential Amsterdam experience. There are over 800,000 bicycles in Amsterdam. Thatâ€™s more bikes than people! The city also has a flat landscape, which makes cycling so much more fun and enjoyable, and is also one the worldâ€™s most cycle-friendly cities with separate cycling paths throughout the entire city. You can also use public transport such as buses, trams, and metros, which are very well connected in the entire city.
Best time to go to Amsterdam
The city is always buzzing with tourists year round, particularly being busier from April to September because it is warmer in those months. I traveled in April and it was extremely busy, but I had a great time. It would be ideal to book your stay ahead of time if you are going to travel in the peak tourist season as almost everything gets booked.
Here is a list of the must do things in Amsterdam:
2) Canal cruise â€” Besides providing a stunning backdrop to the cityâ€™s historical center, floating down Amsterdamâ€™s canals is one of the most memorable ways to discover the cityâ€™s sights and attractions. Whether youâ€™re a first-time or frequent visitor, everything in Amsterdam seems a bit more magical when viewed from a boat.
Most canal cruises take around an hour, which gives you an opportunity to explore Amsterdamâ€™s UNESCO protected Canal Ring and discover plenty of interesting facts about the city along the way. There are various tours operating on the water and you could pick up one quite easily as per your location and requirements.
3) Explore museums â€” Amsterdam is home to over 50 museums, exploring the diversity of history, art, culture, and educational fun. There are museums to suit everyoneâ€™s interest. Some of the most famous museums are Van Gogh Museum, Rijksmuseum, and Anne Frank House.
4) Go beer tasting â€” Amsterdam is the home of the Heineken headquarters. The Heineken experience is a must see for all visitors. I had a great experience where they showed the brewing process, innovations, ingredients used, etc., and at the end of the tour also gave two free beers. Some other interesting breweries that I would also recommend are Brouwerij de Prael, Brouwerij â€˜t IJ, and Butcherâ€™s Tears.
5) Food, bars, and pubs â€” Amsterdam is well-known around the world as a city of indulgences. Here is a list of famous Dutch food you have to try:Stroopwafel â€” consists of a syrup filling sandwiched between two thin waffles. (Best when hot). Try the one at Banketbakkerij Lanskroon or Albert Cuyp Market.Dutch Cheese â€” They are absolutely amazing and cannot be missed. Try them at the Cheese Factory or Henri Willig Cheese shops for a guided experience, or at Reypenaer Proeflokaal or the Cheese Museum.Patat or Frites (Dutch Fries) â€” These are a must-have with the lip-smacking sauces. One of my absolute favorite places for this food is Vleminckx Sausmeesters.Poffertjes â€” You can buy these little fluffy pancakes from any street market or vendor.
Some of the other famous eating spots are Winkel 43 for apple pie, Ice Bakery by Nutella, bars in Nieuwmarkt, Pancake Bakery next to the Anne Frank Museum, De Zotte Cafe in Leidseplein, and Van Stapele Koekmakerij for the chocolate cookies.
Noorderlicht Cafe, in the north, is a nice restaurant. You will have to take a ferry across the Ij to NDSM Werf. This ferry is free to use. Also, there are many amazing restaurants and bars in the north that are definitely worth a try and usually unexplored. There are really cute and cozy restaurants in Jordaan, too, which are hidden gems. Some other really good restaurants to try are Frits (burgers), BAK (organic restaurant), Pazzi (best pizza place in town), De Struisvogel (three-course menu), The Lobby Nesplein (Amazing food and wines. Ask for â€œhet vieze boekjeâ€ (Dirty Book), which they have in their special wines).
Try a hipster cafe. They believe in ugly is beautiful and cook with all those fruits and vegetables that would have been rejected just because they were not the perfect shape or size. It is a fun experience. You could try CafÃ© de Ceuvel, Cafe Brecht, Smokinâ€™ barrels, etc.
The Top deck of the Science Center NEMO is a great place to chill and enjoy magnificent views of the city as well as Floor 17 at the Ramada Apollo Hotel, Sky Lounge at Doubletree by Hilton, Hannekes Boom (an eclectic hangout on the banks of OOsterdok), Edel (a fairy-lit hideaway in De Baarsjes), and other small pubs near the canals. If youâ€™re into hardcore clubbing, then visit Jimmy Woo nightclub, Supperclub, Suzy Wong, Paradiso, Melkweg, AIR Amsterdam, and Sugarfactory.
If you are looking for a Michelin star experience, then try Ciel Bleu. Make reservations in advance at the restaurants in Amsterdam in order to avoid any disappointments, as most of them are pre-booked.
6) Shopping â€” Amsterdam has amazing places to shop and something for everyone. If youâ€™re looking for high-street brands like H&M and Zara go to the busy Kalverstraat. If local boutiques interest you, then head to The Nine Streets. These nine cobbled streets connect the main canals between Leidsegracht and Raadhuisstraat. For high-end shopping, head to De Bijenkorf or Magna Plaza Shopping Centre (previously a post office) located behind Dam Square.
7) Explore the local neighborhoods â€” Amsterdam-Centrum: The Red Light District, Jordaan, The Nine streets and the Canal Ring, Leidseplein, or visit the Blijburg Beach.â€“ Dam Square area: Itâ€™s the center with Madame Tussauds and other museums.â€“ Take a photo with the IAMSTERDAM letters or hang around the flea market in that area.â€“ Noord: A free ferry from the Central Station will take you to this district which has the cityâ€™s coolest architecture, fun hangout spots by the water and exciting festivals.â€“ De Pijp: A great mix of culture, cafes, and cuisine. Do visit the Albert Cuypmarkt here.â€“ Bos en Lommer and De Baarsjes: Itâ€™s famous for their multicultural crowd and popular terrace bars.
8) Parks â€” Parks are at the heart of Amsterdam culture. Every time the sun is out you will see the locals packing up the disposable barbecue and heading down to their nearest garden.If you like visiting parks do not miss to check out Vondelpark, the most famous park in Amsterdam with an open air theater and concerts in the summer. Some other interesting parks are Erasmuspark and Rembrandtpark.
9) Day trips â€” If you have time then it would be exciting to venture out and take day trips to Volendam, Marken, Zaanse Schans (working windmills), countryside, Delft, The Hague, and Rotterdam. Each of these places is unique and has something to offer you.
10) Visit a market in Amsterdam â€” Whether youâ€™re looking to buy or try some local delicacies or just soak up the atmosphere, visiting one of the many markets in Amsterdam is a unique and unforgettable experience. Markets selling everything from antiques to books to artisan food to vintage clothes are held all over the city every day. Some of the most popular Amsterdam markets include the Albert Cuypmarkt in De Pijp (Mon.-Sat.) Lindengrachtmarkt in the Jordaan (Saturdays), and the Waterlooplein Market (Mon.-Sat.).
11) Visit coffee shops â€” A trip to Amsterdam wouldnâ€™t be complete without visiting the coffee shops there. Some of the famous coffee shops are The Bulldog, Mellow Yellow, Original Dampkrings, and Grey Area.

Title: My Adventures in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Sammyâ€™s Travel Space is your place for motivation, inspiration, and upliftment for everything regarding travel! We are dedicated to uplifting your drive, naturing your creativity, and sparkling your spirit.

Member-only story
--
10
Share
My love for Amsterdam was ignited when I met some friendly Dutch fans at a soccer World Cup match.
This was the year 2010 when South Africa hosted the Soccer World Cup.
The energy and friendliness of the Dutch planted the seed that left me wanting to visit Amsterdam.
Just their warm energy had me drawn to them.
My visit to Amsterdam was everything I expected and much more.
Just like in the soccer match, the people I came into contact with, in Amsterdam were warm and friendly.
Being around people with this energy always leaves me on a natural high. My heart feels at peace.
Waking up each morning and exploring the city was always a fun adventure.
Public transport is extremely reliable and efficient. I did a lot of walking in Amsterdam. I also rented a bicycle.
I love cycling!
Cycling in the streets of Amsterdam was a uniquely different experience.
--

It is hard to believe that it has already been over a year since I first left the country. I have spent my whole life with a passion for travel but up until last year I was spending all of my time and funds on hopelessly driving or flying from one side of the country to the other.
Donâ€™t get me wrong I love the views in the US but I always wanted to get some stamps in my passport and really experience different cultures and what else the world had to offer!
I spent as much time as I could traveling last year and after experiencing 8 different countries in those 12 months, I have finally come to the conclusion on my answer for the question I get all the time, â€œWhere should I go first?â€
With a smirk on my face I enthusiastically reply â€œAmsterdam!â€
Most people are scared or nervous about what to expect when they leave the country for the first time and for good reason. There are so many things to consider like:
what kind of currency do they use?
Is it safe?
How will I get around?
What language do they speak?
These are all valid questions that I ask every time I begin planning my next adventure and something that everyone should look into beforeâ€¦

Title: Six years in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
9
Listen
Share
I was sitting in Naples airport waiting for my flight back to Amsterdam after my New Yearâ€™s holiday. People were coming and going with their usual murmur, and the loudspeakers were announcing things in Italian that my mind, despite understanding, ignored. I looked at all the faces, searching for a familiar one that made me feel at home. I must admit that at that point, I had already spent quite some months wondering about the meaning of â€œhomeâ€. What was home? Where is your house if youâ€™ve left your country, and your family did as well?The people around me were dragging their suitcases, their inflatable pillows, their children. Suddenly, a voice crept into my thoughts; it was the loudspeaker saying in Dutch that the flight 4091 with destination Amsterdam was going to leave on time. Strange, I thought, that Dutch has my attention and Italian doesnâ€™t.
Five years and nine months ago, I started writing a piece called â€œThree Months in Amsterdam.â€ It took me so long to finish it (like all ideas that spring up from the back of my mind and I marinate without cooking) that spring passed, and the piece had to be retitled â€œSix Months in Amsterdam.â€ Knowing myself, not so bad. Itâ€™s not six months anymore; itâ€™s six years, plus a few more winters and springs.
In practical and numerical terms, my life in the Netherlands can be summed up as 1 pandemic, 4 houses, 11 roommates, 3 jobs, 7 months of unemployment, a few gyms, 5 stolen bicycles, a few hundred acquaintances, a handful of friends, 22 or 23 romantic platonic crushes, 3 bike crushes, 1 Dutch boyfriend (ex-boyfriend), and a ton of questions.
Living in the Netherlands is something I choose every day, especially on winter days, pedaling through the rain and against the wind is where love is tested. Itâ€™s easy to choose Amsterdam in spring, when the streets are filled with flowers planted by the city (oh my taxes look so pretty!) and the cherry trees are blooming in the forest. When the streets are filled with happy people, sipping white wine while sitting on the sidewalk, young people (!) playing jeu de boule at the park, and the barbecue my neighbor and I make on the sidewalk with meat he brought on one of his flights to Argentina and passed through customs with dubious techniques.Itâ€™s easy to choose Amsterdam in summer, with the sidewalks already decorated with the chalk drawings of the neighborhood children, when the heat is 25 degrees, and you get ice cream at work. When the team returns to play volleyball at the park, and I can pedal around the city with my floral dress blowing in the wind, on my way to jump into a canal or to put my bike on my sister's and brother-in-lawâ€™s boat for a ride after work. Amsterdam in summer is a playground among gardens of happiness.
When winter comes, the story is different; the city becomes quiet, calm. Itâ€™s a bit of a relief not to have to leave the house every day, to make a winter plan, to learn something new, to buy candles because they make the night more cozy, or like Dutch people say gezellig. No one writes to go to the park anymore, unless itâ€™s those two autumn days when all the trees in Vondelpark are a different color. No, when winter comes and the sky is gray, itâ€™s not so easy to choose the Netherlands; even my freckles disappear. When winter comes and no one sees the sun for 20 days, doubts also arise: Why do I choose to live in this place? Am I always going to live in the shade under an overcast gray sky?
The key to escaping the existential emptiness that the lack of sun brings is nothing more and nothing less than to leave. Yes, leave. If privilege allows, all migrants try to escape. I go to see my parents and my brother in Spain, to the mountains in France, to some island where â€œcloudsâ€ is not a topic of conversation. I escape on Wednesdays to my comedy club to make strangers laugh, or to be entertained by my comedian friends, I escape between the keys of a piano I canâ€™t play or take refuge at the gym.
Perhaps the strangest thing about having migrated six years ago is that my family also left Argentina, and we live spread across three countries in Europe. Sometimes I like to say weâ€™re reverse colonizing, a TEG in real time. I also like when people ask me about my parents, to say: â€œTheyâ€™re in a better placeâ€ and then clarify that they live in Spain as well as one of my brothers. That they adapted to other latitudes and now say words like â€œmajoâ€ and â€œguapaâ€, that they occasionally have a whole leg of ham at home, that they like to have bread with tomato for breakfast, that they eat eggs with chips and meat at 10 am and they go out for tapas and to see their friends at the bar.
That they also maybe sometimes wonder where home is.
A few years ago, I had two Argentinian brothers, but now I have a half-Spanish brother and a half-French brother, who has blended into the culture spectacularly. This includes having a French accent when he speaks English, which confuses my friends in Amsterdam, a lot lot. On the other hand, my brother-in-law, who used to be Argentinian, is now Argentinian-Dutch, and beyond what the papers say, he loves to eat bitterballen with beer and if you ask me, that should be worthy of a Dutch nationality. Sometimes I ask my sister if she suspected that her life would be like having dinner at 6 p.m. and that every plan would include a bicycle, if she ever suspected how difficult it would be for her to make new friends in this place.
I wonder if I, too, should be given a Dutch passport after having carried things in my bike like a desk and chair on a single trip, a case of beer, a Dutchman, a small tree, a computer screen, and a coat rack. Perhaps it would be worth it of a Dutch passport my new ability to set boundaries, to be incredibly direct, to ask everyone to pay their share after inviting people for dinner at my house, to have events planned six months in advance and to own that raincoat that opens like a tent so your legs donâ€™t get wet when you pedal.Would my love for Dutch urbanism and design, and my fondness for those classic Dutch songs by Andre Hazes that sound like a grandmotherâ€™s ballad, deserve a Dutch passport?
Sometimes loving a country that isnâ€™t your own feels a lot like cheating on a loved one. Forgive me, Argentina, I didnâ€™t know I was going to fall in love. I still think of you on rainy afternoons, on barbacueless Sundays, and when I notice my friends growing old so far away.
But donâ€™t wait up for me.
If itâ€™s any consolation, the truth is that I miss things: the culture, the sun, the alfajores, the ParanÃ¡ River, my friends, some parts of my extended family. Then I open Twitter and see what the drama of the day in the country is. I go to eat empanadas at a little argentinian paradise called La Reinita, I listen to â€œAdios Noninoâ€, which is the song my friend Fede always listens to, and the tango makes me melancholic, which is the only emotion that goes well with it. I think about Messi more than Iâ€™d like to admit, and I carry a little Argentinian flag on the back of my phone so I donâ€™t forget that other place I love and has given me so much.
But despite the wonders I can say about my life in Amsterdam after so many years the fantastic becomes familiar, and what keeps me here, I have to admit, are my friends. What I would do without the love of these people, I donâ€™t know. Theyâ€™re living their own migration experience, and from different places, we share something that is common to all.
I landed at Amsterdam Airport after a few hours of travel. Stepping off the plane, I felt an immediate and unexpected relief at the familiarity of the airport: how tall the people were, hearing people speaking Dutch, the friendly voice on the loudspeakers announcing the trains. Then I knew it: my house is here and my home as well.
--
--

Title: Amsterdam, Netherlands // Why a different state of mind?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Here for the travel advice and not to read my life story? Jump to Travel Recommendations for the tl;dr [too long; didnâ€™t read] to plan your trip to Amsterdam now!
I felt giddy as my flight touched down. I was passing through the city somewhat incidentally. My end destination was Portugal but it was cheaper to fly through Amsterdam first. So I stretched my layover into a three-day trip. This gave me one day to recover from jet lag and a solid two days in Amsterdam to explore.
Amsterdam is one of those cities proceeded by its reputation. Personally, it has loomed large in my imagination for decades. A place where prostitution is not only legal but flaunted. Where weed, magic mushrooms, and who knows what else was accessible long before even medical clinics were open back home in California. A place where kids going to what at the time I considered â€œrealâ€ or four-year colleges would go to spend a semester abroad. It seemed like such an exciting and luxurious opportunity. One that I could only dream of as I worked my way through community college as a waitress to supplement my scholarships and financial aid.
I wanted to ride a bike around and meet new people from all over the world. Wear cozy sweaters and do drugs in coffee shops and bars. The fact that this was exactly how I was already spending most if not all of my time right at home in San Francisco and Oakland did not make it seem any less exotic.
By the time I finally had the chance to make that pilgrimage, I was in a very different state of mind. I spent my two days in Amsterdam on history and art tours. Taking in the old buildings and even older paintings. Trying new foods such as stroopwaffle (yay!) and pickled herring (nay).
Amsterdam is expensive! Hotels, hostels, and Airbnbs are all expensive. I ended up staying at CityHub Amsterdam, a capsule hotel. Overall, it was a good experience. I donâ€™t really spend time in the hotel when I am traveling so this was a good option for me. It was clean and quiet. I loved the location. There was even a street market right outside where I stopped every morning for a fresh squeezed juice during my stay.
Back to top
I donâ€™t have much in the way of tips for this trip. It is easy to move through the city and everyone speaks English. The one thing I want to mention is, watch out for bikes! There is a lot of bicycle traffic and one sure-fire way to get cursed out from an otherwise friendly and easygoing local population is to cross the bike lane without looking.
Back to top
Start your day with a free walking tour! This is a great way to start your trip, especially if you are short on time. I recommend taking one the first day to help you get oriented. Free Walking Tours Amsterdam is the one I went with. I took the classic tour, but they have several other options to chose from depending on your interest. There are also many, many other options to choose from when selecting a free walking tour.
This style of tour is available all over Europe. I have even started seeing them in some places in Latin America as well. They typically last 2â€“3 hours. Your guide will give you some historical context for the city and show you the main sights within walking distance. The tours are indeed free, but the guides are only paid through tips. Have cash on hand to fork over at least â‚¬5-â‚¬10 once the tour is over.
Back to top
Consider grabbing lunch or dinner at this trendy food hall. It is modeled after a concept that has taken the world by storm. Foodhallen is one building with many different stalls inside that offer different types of cuisine. You can order from any one that catches your fancy and grab a spot amidst the communal seating.
Back to top
In the evening, I recommend heading over to NDSM. This cultural hotspot is a collection of contemporary art studios and rotating exhibitions in a giant converted warehouse. You may catch a music show or a performance. There are also a few places to eat while on that side of the river.
The easiest way to arrive is to take the F4 ferry from Amsterdam Central Station. It is free and runs every 15â€“30 minutes. Be sure to hop back on before the ferry service ends at midnight.
Back to top
There are so many different options to choose from, but Rijksmuseum is the crown jewel of museums in Amsterdam. This one is a must-see for any visitor. You can purchase your timed entry tickets the day of, but I recommend buying them a day or two before if you are on a strict schedule and need to be at the museum at a specific time. I also recommend coming here first and then exploring some of the other must-sees in the city such as the Van Gough Museum or the Anne Frank House Museum.
Back to top
All that wandering around and viewing of those giant Renaissance paintings of food in varying states of decay is bound to make you hungry. After visiting Rijksmuseum it is just a short jaunt to Albert Cupstraat Markt. This market stretches several blocks and includes giftable wares, flowers, and most importantly, traditional Dutch cuisine. Be sure to try the stroopwafels, pickled herring, bitterballen (meatballs), and patat friet (french fries).
The market is open 9:30 am-5:00 pm every day except Sundays.
Back to top
The Central Park of Amsterdam is worth strolling through on foot or by bike and is close to both Rijksmuseum and Albert Cuypstraat market. Itâ€™s a beautiful place to stop and take a rest on one of the many benches lining the park paths before continuing on with your busy day.
Back to top
No stay in Amsterdam would be complete without a stop at the famous Red Light District. Locals hate it, tourists love it. If you are visiting, I think you have to go at least to see it. There are even historical tours during the day for the faint of heart. Itâ€™s easy to find a burlesque show, sex show, or just head out on your own to experience the scene at night.
If you do go in the evening, be prepared to witness the true spectacle, the endless parade of bachelor or â€œstagâ€ parties crowding the street. You will mostly see women in windows soliciting their wares as you walk the streets, which is to say, themselves. I enjoyed watching the full spectrum of how these women interacted with the passing crowd. Some were dancing, some were trying to entice potential customers with a flirty, joking manner. The most conventionally attractive were visibly bored, doom scrolling on their phones and awaiting their next client without having to put in much effort.
Back to top
I was traveling alone for this trip, so I didnâ€™t have the wild adventure I might have otherwise. But as I get older and wiser, I canâ€™t help but grow in my appreciate of the quieter side of cities and life itself. The joys of earlier mornings, sans hangover. Trying new foods, even if it is for the first and last time. And most importantly, whether it be through observing classical art or observing my fellow tourist on their worst behavior, always learning something new whenever I have the opportunity.
--
--

Title: Is Amsterdam a nice city to live in?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
2
Share
Time flies â€” itâ€™s been almost a year since I moved from Prague, Czechia, to Amsterdam, The Netherlands.
I loved Prague, but Amsterdam quickly captured a special place in my heart. It feels like home here. And thanks to the rare combination of calmness and just enough excitement, Iâ€™ve decided to stay here a little longer and build a stable base.
This is my analysis of how it is to live in Amsterdam. Based on ten criteria, I evaluated the quality of life in Amsterdam. Please note that this article is based on a combination of facts and statistics, but mainly on personal experiences.
Since the introduction of the Safe Cities Index, a report from The Economist Intelligence Unit, Amsterdam was always in the top 10 safest cities globally. In the 2021 report, Amsterdam was in second place on personal security, just behind Copenhagen.
I can see why Amsterdam consistently ranks that high. It feels incredibly safe here. A walk in the middle of the night? No problem. A late-night bicycle ride through the park? Donâ€™t worry. I go running daily (often late at night) andâ€¦
