Share
â€œYour body is not a temple, itâ€™s an amusement park. Enjoy the ride.â€
-Bourdain
The ferry dropped us off at the Amsterdam Centraal train station at 2pm, amid the most perfect spring day. It looked like a real-life Truman Show, the way everyone was smiling and laughing without a care. Even the pigeons looked happy, chilling by the canal, generously sharing food.
It made me wonderâ€¦
Are people happy because theyâ€™re in Amsterdam, or do happy people just gravitate there, making it so? Hard to tell. Sounds like a chicken/egg situation. Speaking of which, Iâ€™ve always wondered if people weigh more because of their genes or because their caloric intake is higher, and they work out less. Like, if you took two people who eat and workout the same amount but oneâ€™s family has been fat for generations (like mine) and the other skinny, would they end up weighing the same exact amount? I ask because Iâ€™ve always felt predisposed to fatness due to my dadâ€™s genes.
Before looking for a hostel, I wanted to get high, so I went in the first â€œcoffee shopâ€ I saw. Now would be a good time to describe the difference between coffee shops in America and coffee shops in Amsterdam. They look the same, except in Amsterdam, some sell weed. Pretty simple.
I ordered a pre-roll and a latte. If cocaine and heroin together is a speed ball, weed and coffee together is more like a curveball. Part of me felt demure, sitting there smoking a joint by myself in a cafÃ©. The other part though, was high as fuck, and VERY paranoid. The American penal system was so ingrained in me that my Pavlovian response to being high was an intense fear of the police. No matter how much I reassured myself that I wasnâ€™t breaking the law, I couldnâ€™t shake the fear of being arrested. You donâ€™t realize youâ€™re paranoid amidst the paranoia. If you did, you wouldnâ€™t be paranoid.
*
On my walk to find a hostel I couldnâ€™t stop laughing at the ridiculousness of the street names. I wrote some of my favorites down. I also made up some of my own. See if you can guess which are which. I canâ€™t even remember myself.
- Brouwersgracht
- Hosenlendinvein
- Princeneiland
- Amsterveenseweg
- Grunarpeilveg
- Einelpenilhar
- Brouwersgracht
The hostel I chose was a far cry from The Flying Pig, the â€œitâ€ place Iâ€™d read about in my research. The Flying Pig was the most popular hostel for people under 30 (still is) because it has a weed smoking section in the common area where they have pipes and bongs to rent. There was a communal element, one I was not looking for. I donâ€™t like being part of groups and try to avoid it whenever possible. I want to do what I want to do, not what â€œusâ€ wants to do. â€œUsâ€ is always some lame compromise. Instead, I went with an off-brand hostel, one that catered to an older, more laid-back crowd. When I booked it online from London, the picture made it look like a nondescript Holiday Inn Express. It was a little off the beaten path, but not too far from the action. It seemed clean, calm, and quiet, exactly what I wanted.
When I checked in, it did seem both clean and calm. But, to my surprise, I heard jackhammering. When I inquired, the manager told me there would be construction every day from 9am-5pm. I thanked him and went up to my room.
Thatâ€™s how I am, I thank people who inconvenience me. Iâ€™ve always been way too accommodating, even to my own detriment. I try to save the world one favor at a time. I could have very easily found another hostel that didnâ€™t have Jackhammering, but that, somehow, in my mind, would have been considered breaking a commitment. The hostel was probably struggling because of the jackhammering, and I wanted to help. I know, thatâ€™s crazy.
When I got up to my room, there was, in fact, a man jackhammering five feet from my window. It sounded like the gunfight from Heat. So, I turned right around and got out of there.
On my way down I saw the Manager again.
Manager: Sir, how is your room?
Me: Perfect. Thank you.
I still had an hour to kill before the jackhammering stopped, so I set out to buy weed, enough to last at least a week. After 5 minutes of walking, I stumbled upon a place called Coffee Shop Bob Marley. From the outside, it looked exactly like youâ€™d think it would, Jamaican flag, pictures of Bob, Wailers albums. It was corny, but it would do. Afterall, they had weed for sale.
When I entered, I was greeted by an old budtender who looked exactly like Willie Nelson, all the way down to the bandana. From his voice, I could tell he was an American ex-pat. He handed me a Trapper Keeper-style three ring binder. In it were plastic pages with little slots for what traditionally would have been baseball cards. Instead of cards though, each quadrant contained a nugget of weed, along with a description (e.g. purple haze: mellow, euphoric). It was the first time Iâ€™d seen such a professional setup, and it blew me away. Iâ€™d smoked weed daily for 5 years but had never dreamt of such a variety. Iâ€™d hit the motherload.
After much consideration, I selected 4 indica strains and paid Willie 60 Euros for the 14-gram purchase, an amazing deal anywhere in the world at that time.
Me: May I light up in here?
Willy: Of course. The smoking room is in back.
The smoking room was just a small, curtained off area with a few high-top tables. A Bob Marley music video played on the television hanging on the wall. I put my bag down and removed a grape White Owl cigar that Iâ€™d bought before leaving London. At the time I was still smoking blunts and I wanted to â€œrepresentâ€ my â€œcultureâ€ while in Europe. Ha. What I didnâ€™t consider, was that Iâ€™d barely smoked the previous two weeks in New York. And, though I smoked a few hash spliffs the night before in London, my tolerance was still lower than usual. Regardless, I went ahead and rolled a 2.5-gram monster of Afghan Kush.
There were two other people in the room with me, a couple, who both appeared to be in their 30â€™s. I couldnâ€™t hear their voices, but I assumed they werenâ€™t from America. I did that with everyone who wasnâ€™t traveling in a group. Thereâ€™s just something about Americans, we love traveling in guided groups. Very rarely did I see a duo of American travelers, let alone a solo one. When I dumped the guts of the blunt into a garbage bin near the wall, they stared in my direction. They didnâ€™t say anything, but I could tell they were interested in what I was constructing. I was proud of my blunt rolling skills and wanted to put on a show for them, so they could see how we did it in the states. I considered myself an ambassador.
After licking the blunt closed, I sparked my lighter, running the flame along the paper to dry it out. Then, I lit it, taking a deep drag and coughing slightly. The couple, again, glanced my way. I looked back at them, smiling like a cool dude.
About halfway through the blunt, I realized Iâ€™d made a huge mistake. I wasnâ€™t cool at all. In fact, I was sweating bullets and overcome with dizziness. I could tell the couple wanted to check on me, they just werenâ€™t sure if it was their place to do so. I mean, I mustâ€™ve known what I was doing, right? You donâ€™t just roll a blunt like that if itâ€™s your first time smoking weed.
My equilibrium was totally askew. I gripped the small, circular table like we were Greco Roman wrestling. I had to say something before it was too late.
Me: My name is Sam. Iâ€™m from America. If I die, my momâ€™s name is Audrey â€”
Then I passed out and fell off my chair.
When I came to, Bob Marleyâ€™s I Shot the Sheriff was playing on the tv. The couple was hovering over me, disturbed, their highs obviously ruined. Willie was concerned too, standing over me with a bottle of water. I didnâ€™t even know how long Iâ€™d been out.
Willy: We were scared, man. Glad youâ€™re ok. We donâ€™t even allow cigars in here.
Lady: That was so scary. Why would you try smoking that whole blunt?
Me: You know what blunts are?
Guy: Of course. Weâ€™re from America too.
*
On my way back to the hostel, I passed what looked to be the strangest food establishment Iâ€™d ever seen. It reminded me of a Grayâ€™s Papaya, a New York hot dog chain I loved, in that there was no seating inside. In fact, there was nothing at all inside. It was just an empty room, like an American check cashing place. Yet, it smelled like fast food. It was too weird to not investigate.
When I went in, I thought I was tripping out. I was still extremely high and woozy from the fall, but I was pretty sure I was standing inside a life-sized vending machine. The walls were lined with rows and rows of slots where hot food was kept. There must have been a kitchen in the back where everything was prepared, but I didnâ€™t see one, nor could I hear one. The only sign of human life was the hand of an employee replenishing the stock after a sale. I didnâ€™t love the impersonality of it all, but I had to admit it was ingenious.
My dad would have loved to have access to a place like that, where he could anonymously buy food without the judgement of a cashier. Itâ€™s just you and the food, no interaction whatsoever, perfect for an addict.
I was enjoying my burger on a nearby bench, when off in the distance I saw the glow of the Red-Light-District. Until that point, Iâ€™d thought the name â€œRed-Light-Districtâ€ just referred to the illicit activities that went on there, I didnâ€™t know it was a literal description of the place. It looked like a devilish carnival, the dope dealers being the carnies, and the ladies, the rides. Young adults, mostly backpackers, lined the outskirts, trying to get up the nerve to make the plunge. â€œHow pathetic,â€ I thought to myself. â€œI canâ€™t believe Iâ€™d wanted to do this.â€
*
March 26, 2006
After a wonderful night of stoned sleep, I woke up to my alarm at 8:45am, which left me the perfect amount of time to shower, eat, do laundry, and get to the Smart Shop right when it opened. They call places that sell mushrooms â€œsmart shopsâ€ the way they call weed stores â€œcoffee shopsâ€. Iâ€™ve always found that to be telling. Those are delicate, non-fear inducing terms. We donâ€™t have â€œsafety storesâ€ in America, we have â€œGun and Ammoâ€ shops. Rather crude, if you ask me.
Iâ€™d done mushrooms a handful of times before, with experiences ranging from spiritual bliss to utter madness, but Iâ€™d always learned something about myself in the process, and that was the most important part. Wait, thatâ€™s not totally true. Sometimes, I just spend 4 hours in the bathroom trying to wipe pee that isnâ€™t there off my pants. A psychologist would have a field day with that one.
When I entered the Smartshop, I was greeted by the kind of guy youâ€™d think would be running a psychedelic mushroom store, long hair, flannel shirt, monk vibes.
Clerk: How may I help you?
Me: Can you please advise me on which mushrooms I should take, and the quantity?
Clerk: Of course. That is exactly what I am here for. Have you done psilocybin before?
Me: Yes, maybe 20 times.
Clerk: Ok, let me walk you through what we have.
He took me over to a glass case with about 15 varieties of mushrooms, some wet, some dry, all of them unique in shape and color. He walked me through their different levels of potency and their array of effects.
Me: How about something in the medium-strength level?
Clerk: Sure. Would you like to see visuals?
Me: Yes, please.
Clerk: I suggest 1 to 2 grams of the High Hawaiian variety, dried.
Me: Will they make me laugh?
Clerk: Ooohhh yeah.
I paid him 25 Euros and exited the Smartshop with my mushrooms. Then, I walked over to the canal. There was a light mist, so I found an unoccupied bench and dried a small spot for myself. I took the mushrooms out of my bag, along with a banana Iâ€™d saved from breakfast and a bottle of water. Then I said my usual pre-hallucinogen prayer. â€œLord, please look after me during this trip. And please, please donâ€™t let me think I peed my pants.â€
Once I had the mushrooms down and the nausea passed, I sat back and read my book until the words no longer looked like words, maybe 30 minutes. Thatâ€™s when the laughing started. EVERYTHING was funny. I spent 10 minutes laughing at my shoes because they looked like chili dogs. Then it was the word â€œwanker.â€ I couldnâ€™t stop saying it. â€œOy ye wankerâ€, â€œAye wanker, quit ya wankingâ€, â€œBloody, scheming wanker.â€
Down the canal a few hundred yards away, I saw a tourist boat slowly approaching. There were about 20 or so passengers, all of them Asian. They looked so happy, with their big visors and smiling faces. I was overcome with the urge to connect with them. I stood up and waved my arms, yelling to them as they passed.
â€œHelllloooooo!!! Welcome to Amsterdam!!!â€
They waved back jubilantly, while I cry-laughed in the rain like a maniac, yelling in their direction as they passed by my bench.
â€œEnjoy your staaayyyy!!â€
I greeted 8 boats-worth of people over a 2-hour period. For nearly my entire trip, I worked as a volunteer civil servant for a city Iâ€™d just arrived in. You never know where hallucinogens will take you.
I walked back to the hostel soaked; my feet pruned from the rain. What I needed more than anything was a peaceful place to come down and dry off. When I got to my room, I was delighted to find none of my roommates there, a rare occurrence in a 4-person room. I toweled off and hung my clothes on the edge of the bunk before getting into my bed to reflect and relax. I couldnâ€™t have felt calmer, laying there. My heart was pure, and my thoughts, loving.
Then the jackhammering started up. Iâ€™d completely forgotten about it. And this time, because of the mushrooms, it sounded even louder and more menacing than before. My trip was turning dark, and I had to make a move. Either go down and watch the BBC in the lobby, which would inevitably end up in conversation, or spend the next hour showering.
I went with the shower.
*
March 27, 2006
I came to the next morning, feeling exfoliated, if nothing else. My clothes were dry, finally, so I set out to find an outdoor market where I could buy an extra pair of cheap pants in case I found myself in a similar situation again. In America, we call them swap meets. Theyâ€™re the same thing, just with a bad name.
When I was on my way out, I saw the manager.
Manager: Sir, how has your stay been?
Me: Perfect. Thank you. Is there an outdoor market where I can buy pants and food?
Manager: The Albert Cuyp Market would be the place.
To his credit, it was the place. Within 10 minutes of being there I bought a pair of cheap sweatpants, an onion and herring sandwich, and a crepe. I am perhaps the only person in history to purchase those 3 exact items at once. I wanted to experience the local delicacies though, and figured I could knock em out in one fail swoop. The meal brought back memories of my Bubbie, who I missed dearly. She loved herring and crepes (separately). Seeing me holding them at the same time wouldâ€™ve given her a good chuckle. Sheâ€™d probably ask, â€œWhat is it, my birthday?â€ My father loved crepes too, but the image of him eating 30 crepes is not a pleasant memory to conjure up.
After finishing my meal, I went in my pocket for dessert, 20mg of Adderall. My mom told me my Bubbie took uppers in the 60â€™s, when they prescribed it to housewives as a weight loss drug. I bet her grandma was a speed freak too, drinking that Coca Cola with actual cocaine in it.
I needed to charge up, and without sleep, Adderall was the best way to do that (even with sleep, for that matter). I was on a mission to find a bar that evening. And not just a bar for that night, but one I could call home in future visits. I still had a month or so left in my trip and knew Iâ€™d be back to Amsterdam, so I needed to have a reliable place to hang my hat. Bars are that important to me. I canâ€™t just go any old place to drink willy nilly. I need a home base, somewhere I feel comfortable, where they know my name. Like the Commonwealth.
I had no clue where I was going to find it, but I knew Iâ€™d know it when I saw it (the same way pornography was defined by the Supreme Court in 1964). It took some walking, but then I stumbled upon what was undoubtably the place. I was standing at the corner of Nieuwebrugsteeg and Warmoesstraat, right where Warmoesstraat turns into Sint Olofspoort. Iâ€™m serious. I looked up and there it wasâ€¦ The perfect bar. The sign under the awning read: â€œH. Murrayâ€™s Bar.â€ Next to it was a smaller sign that read â€œAnno 1619.â€ It looked to be more of a house than a bar. There was even a Golden Retriever in the window, standing with itsâ€™ paws on the sill. A bar dog is a surefire sign of a good bar. If itâ€™s good enough for a dog, itâ€™s good enough for me.
I entered like I was returning home.
Me: Hi. Iâ€™m Sam.
Neil: Hello, friend. Iâ€™m Neil. Thatâ€™s Lilly (pointing to the dog). And thatâ€™s Norman (pointing to the only other man sitting at the bar).
Me: Hello gents. May Iâ€¦?
Norman: Pull up a seat, Sam.
Me: Iâ€™ll have what Normanâ€™s having.
Always drink what the house drinks. It will endear you to the crowd. For me, that only backfires when the house drink is Sambuca. I hate Sambuca. It tastes like Christmas tree water. Or Malort. Donâ€™t even get me started on the Chicago bars that push that lighter fluid on their clientele. Monsters.
We got to talking and time got to flying, the way it does when youâ€™re around good people. Norman told me about his time in Berkley, about how he knew Tim Leary, Tom Wolffe and the Merry Pranksters, people Iâ€™d only known from books like The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test, and Hunterâ€™s Hells Angels. We shared the same sense of humor too. When he told me his favorite comedian was Steven Wright, I knew we were cut from the same cloth, only a generation apart.
Steven Wright is one of the more obscure, odd comedians; real dry, great word economy. He can make you laugh in less than 20 words.
â€œA lot of people are afraid of heights. Not me, Iâ€™m afraid of widths.â€
â€œI think itâ€™s wrong that only one company makes the game Monopolyâ€
I told him to look up Mitch Hedberg, but didnâ€™t bother telling him how Mitchâ€™s death contributed to my quitting stand-up, or that I even did stand-up at all. I couldnâ€™t have done that without crying, so I just listened and enjoyed being a guest.
I wish I remembered more of that night, but thatâ€™s how it goes sometimes. Iâ€™ve always found sacrificing memory for fun to be a fair trade. Not everything has to be remembered and documented with a picture. I canâ€™t recall most of the best times of my life and Iâ€™m just fine with that.
*
March 28, 2006
They started jackhammering bright and early the next day. Still half-drunk, wearing my clothes from the prior night, I darted down to the lobby to get breakfast before it ended. While scarfing down cold eggs and toast, I checked my pockets and counted the money I had. It was the same exact amount Iâ€™d gone out with the night before, along with a few grams of unfamiliar loose weed. John Mulaney has a joke about blacking out and coming home with more money than he left with, and thatâ€™s exactly what happened to me. Neil didnâ€™t even charge me. He mustâ€™ve denied my attempts at tipping too, because every dollar was still in my wallet. I couldnâ€™t recall his kind gesture, but I was sure I hadnâ€™t just skipped out on my tab. I mean, I was pretty sure. When Iâ€™m blacked out, Iâ€™m more inclined to try and pay twice than I am to skip out on the bill. One time in New Orleans, I paid my tab, then sat there trying to pay my tab again, four more times. The bartender eventually threw me out.
Some hair of the dog seemed in order. â€œHair of the dogâ€ means â€œAlcohol.â€ They used to rub it on dog wounds. The way itâ€™s colloquially used now is to say, â€œyou canâ€™t get hungover if you stay drunk.â€ I still had about an hour before the intense hangover would take hold, and figured a large quantity of Adderall and drinks could fend it off.
I found a nearby Irish Pub and ordered a shot and a beer. Realizing I was American, the bartender tested me before serving me.
Bartender: Do you like George Bush?
Me: Heâ€™s a cunt.
Bartender: Guinness and Jameson coming right up.
I drank and gobbled pills the whole afternoon and into the early evening, until I could hardly see straight. Bender mode, engage.
Letâ€™s talk about benders for a minuteâ€¦ During 24 hour-plus drinking benders, your brain swells to the point you can barely remember who or where you are. You become erratic, uncontrollable. For no reason at all, you push over garbage cans, rip signs out of the ground, and piss on walls. And youâ€™ll fuck anything with a pulse. You become possessed. And the choice remainsâ€¦ Give up and succumb to the impending hangover or continue on with disregard for all human decency. Either way, youâ€™re fucked.
I marched on. After leaving the bar, I bought a 20oz Heineken and brown bagged it on my walk to nowhere. At least I thought I was going nowhere. My subconscious had a different idea though. I didnâ€™t realize it at first, but I was retracing my steps from the previous day. My boozed soaked brain was leading me to the very place my sober brain found disgusting. I didnâ€™t even realize where I was going until I saw the glowing red lights.
*
I walked the entire length of the Red-Light District multiple times, prowling amongst my fellow creeps, trying to find the perfect lady. I have always been a very discerning shopper, that time being no different. I didnâ€™t just want any random lady; I wanted one who showed interest in me. God, thatâ€™s pathetic.
The women all had their own room where they sat, positioned toward the outer sidewalk. The ones who were â€œbusy workingâ€ had their large window covered with a red curtain. The others, who were â€œwaiting for work,â€ had their curtains drawn, allowing you to see the entire layout of the room. They were all similar; a bed in the corner, a small nightstand, presumably for keys or other knickknacks that may interfere with the coitus, and a few mirrors. Everything was red, the lights, the bed, the carpetâ€¦ Like white is the safest car color, I think red makes for the most fucking.
All the women were objectively gorgeous, much more gorgeous than the sex workers I patronized in Tijuana the prior summer. They were hideous. And they robbed me. I donâ€™t want to talk about that though. These ladies werenâ€™t beaten down, figuratively speaking. They looked confident, even proud, like hard working small-business owners. Some of them werenâ€™t even dressed scantily and gave off a â€œtake it or leave itâ€ vibe, which I dug. There were no pimps in sight either. Just the ladies and their red rooms.
With each trip down the corridor, I narrowed my selection, like I was hosting my own March Madness tournament, pitting lady against lady, with the winner advancing to the next round.
The eventual winner was white, with long, dark brown hair, and weighed about 150 pounds. She curled her index finger and invited me in, licking it between curls with the effort of a champion.
Inside, I met the pimp. He may not have been a pimp technically, but he held the money like a pimp does. And probably for the best. I gave him 50 Euros and he gave me a single condom. He didnâ€™t say a word. Then, he opened the door to the red room.
Tonya: Iâ€™m Tonya. Whatâ€™s your name?
Me: Iâ€™m Sam.
I forgot I could lie.
Her bubbliness left. Now she was working. Sheâ€™d already caught her fish; the rest was just fileting.
Tonya: Bed or standing?
Me: Uhhh, standing.
I feared I might pass out if I lied down
She turned around and faced the dresser, gripping the top of it with her hand. Pulling down her black, lace panties, she began to prepare herself with one hand, the other braced on the dresser. I took my pants down, following her lead.
Lady: Ok, ready.
I tore open the condom and put it on. Then, I inserted myself.
When she moaned, I gained confidence. I started to go faster, and she moaned more, my confidence growing stronger yet. I took my left hand and slapped her ass cheek.
Thatâ€™s when the pimp came bursting in.
Pimp: NO, NO, NO! NONE OF THAT!
He was pissed. I looked over at him to apologize for my lapse in judgment, and while doing so, ejaculated into the condom I was wearing. I knew I was jizzing. He knew I was jizzing. I knew he knew I was jizzing.
We both jumped back.
Pimp: Ok, thatâ€™s it youâ€™re done.
Me: But I didnâ€™t even cum.
He pointed to my shriveling dick.
Pimp: Yes, you did.
I had no recourse. There was jizz in the condom and I couldnâ€™t remove it in his presence, causing a smoking gun, â€œgotcha!â€ type of situation. So, I waited until he left the room, then I got dressed, alongside Tonya.
Me: So, Tonya. Thank you very much.
Tonya: (doing a crossword puzzle) Yeah, whatever.
Me: Have a good rest of your evening.
*
March 29, 2006
I woke up the next morning wreaking of vomit. Iâ€™d gone to a bar to cement my blackout after having sex with Tonya, but unfortunately, I wasnâ€™t able to drink enough to forget I came while looking into another manâ€™s eyes. I guess thatâ€™s the type of memory no amount of alcohol can erase. To this day, I still see his face . I like to think he still sees mine too and were forever cosmically connected through semen.
I knew Iâ€™d be back, but I had to get the hell out of Amsterdam, pronto. I needed a reset. I couldnâ€™t fall deeper into depravity so early in the trip. I had to pace myself if I wanted to survive another 2 weeks on the road.
After showering (I know, Iâ€™m disgusting for not having showered the night before. Get off me), I headed to the train station and looked at the big board to see what my options were. Paris was appealing but I wasnâ€™t mentally prepared to take an 8-hour train ride. That would have left far too much time to reflect on the previous night. So, when I noticed the option to take a 4-hour bullet train, I jumped at the chance and made a reservation for the 11am departure.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

I heard the conductorâ€™s announcement as we approached Rotterdam train station â€” â€œWatch out for pickpockets!â€ We had nothing valuable in our pockets, I thought. The thieves would be disappointed if they picked OUR pockets.
We had barely arrived in Amsterdam two days prior, but we jumped right into action. There was too little time and too much to see. Our American employers werenâ€™t sympathetic to our desire to see the world, and our European or Aussie friends werenâ€™t helping when they flaunted their five-day stay at a place and uncertain departure. We heard that all of Europe shut down in August. What?! What if I got appendicitis?
Jet lag is for wusses and we are biased for action. We have to be. We got our bearings during the first evening in Amsterdam so upon our return from Belgium, we would have an optimized route to tackle our must-see list. The day before, we wandered through Delft and Leiden while keeping an eye on the watch. Thank goodness for the Netherlandsâ€™ robust train system and the manageable size of the country. Those little towns were charming even in the rain and vendors in the open market didnâ€™t complain, so why would we?

Title: My First Impression of Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The place where essays, journal prompts, reflections, day-to-day experiences, and deep thoughts are shared and celebrated. Diary writers from all walks of life, and every corner of the world tell their experiences one thought at a time, in a classic diarist style.

--
14
Listen
Share
Back in July of 2023, I flew into Amsterdam to start my new life. Amsterdam was going to be it for me. The magical canals, the tulips, the summer sun.
It was the place to be.
I understood there was a lot of weed in Amsterdam, Iâ€™m not a user but Iâ€™ve never been bothered by other peoples choices as long as thereâ€™s no pressure for me to partake.
I was excited â€” Iâ€™d heard so many good things about the Dutch culture, theyâ€™re friendly and community minded, they love flowers, and are some of the happiest people on earth.
I was convinced that I would step into Amsterdam and say, â€œthis is my home,â€ and live here happily for the rest of my life.
I know, I set very realistic expectations for myself.
I did not own a jacket. The wind whipped you like a smoothie, what more can I say, Iâ€™d just arrived from Spain and I was cold.
I ate a sausage roll and felt like I was back at home, then I was annoyed because right next door was a salad bar I hadnâ€™t noticed. I walked out the door, caught a taxi and asked them to drive me to my hostel.
They said, â€œThis is not a good area.â€
Iâ€™ve heard that so many times. Itâ€™s a tradition of mine to book a dodgy hostel the first night in a new country â€” never on purpose.
I hopped out of the taxi, payed the million bucks, and headed on in. The reviews had been good; they provided all meals if you wanted them too (and can pay for it), the common area was social with table tennis and pool and a bar.
All of this was true, and the staff were lovely. The only problem was everyone was buzzed. Is that the right slang?
Everyone checking in was out of it. Not like theyâ€™d taken a few puffs at a concert â€” they were not there at all. Had I walked into a hostel or a hospital?
The only problem was everyone was buzzed.
I checked in and was treated like I was also very out of it. I went to my hostel room, dumped my bag and decided to go exploring.
I enjoyed a walk through a lovely park, I was stopped by a guy who tried to get a lot of personal information from me and I assertively said, â€œIâ€™m going to leave now.â€ Which I was quite proud of myself for doing.
I found another lovely park but it was filled with homeless people, and people on drugs. I left pretty quick.
I sat down at a restaurant and tried to get some food in me, and a cool drink. It wasnâ€™t hot but sometimes you have to fake it till you make it.
Pro Tip: If youâ€™re ever alone and feel less than 100%, you need to eat. Even if youâ€™re not hungry, just pick at something.
So I ordered with a grumpy waitress, and tried not to cry as I thought about how all my dreams had been crushed in just a few hours. I was alone in a scary city. I had walked for about three hours and hadnâ€™t made it to the Anne Frank House like I wanted, instead I was tired, scared, and the most alone Iâ€™d ever felt.
While sitting at this cafÃ© fighting back tears I remembered I was in complete control of my life, choices, and actions. So I looked up hostels elsewhere. I had been told to go outside of Amsterdam and explore little towns, so I thought Iâ€™d do that.
I looked on booking.com and picked the cheapest hostel with at least an 8/10 rating. The place was advertised to be quiet, along a canal, and within walking distance to a conference centre. The complete opposite to my vibe but I was tired and I thought itâ€™d be worth a shot.
I caught a taxi back to my hostel, contacted home, and went to bed with a very early alarm set for the morning.
The next day was the start of my overseas adventure, I just didnâ€™t know it yet.
Have you ever been in a situation where you felt uncomfortable?
Have you ever felt unsafe in a new city?
Check out this weekâ€™s topic for my The Netherlands Diaries column too!
medium.com
Do you have something to write about you think would be welcomed here at The Diarist? Check out the submissions page â€” letâ€™s see it! Follow The Diarist for some griping diary entries, by your favourite Diarists.

Title: Why Amsterdam?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
New Yorker living/working in Amsterdam
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
If itâ€™s both terrifying and amazing then you should definitely pursue it â€” Erada
I didnâ€™t wake up one day saying, okay I am going to work abroad. I started looking for a new job about two months after my current company at the time, Aereo, lost their case at the Supreme Court. I was perusing the job boards and kept coming across the job post UX Designer at Booking.com.
Since I have started working, two years ago, I have been anti-corporation / anti-big team. The first job that I had after college was at a company called Pingg, a start up with a team of 10 people. I absolutely loved my time and the people at Pingg. Pingg was bought by a big corporation and many things that I loved about the start up life changed. After a couple of months, I moved on to Aereo. I knew taking the job was risky because they were involved in legal battles, but I thought it was worth the risk. I believed in the companyâ€™s mission, liked the team, and was happy to be back in the start up world. Unfortunately 3 months into my new job, we were shut down by the Supreme Court.
I stayed at Aereo for 5 months after we were shut down. There were some glimmers of hope here and there, but nothing concrete. After a while, I felt like I was wasting my time. I wanted to be learning and working, not just sitting on my hands.
So after doing some interviews, I finally manned up and applied for the UX Designer job at Booking.com. Even though it was a large corporation, there was one paragraph in the job post that really stood out to me:
Our guiding principle is that by helping our users we help our business. As a designer in our Front End team youâ€™ll be a key part of the idea generation process, working in a small startup-like group which takes full ownership of their part of our platform. Youâ€™ll work with developers, product owners, copywriters and user researchers to conceive, analyse, hand code & test your ideas.
This is exactly what I like to do. I love starting with an idea and following that idea from creation to production. On the first phone interview, I made sure to ask if this was really the way that they worked. After the first interview, I already started to have anxiety. Am I really doing this? Am I really applying to a job in a different country? Well after another phone interview, and an in-person interview in Amsterdam, I am really doing this.
So did Amsterdam have anything to do with the job? Yes of course, but not until after I decided I actually liked the job itself. I have always liked the idea of taking a couple of years and living and working abroad but never thought that I would actually do it. Originally I thought that if I lived abroad it would be in London. I studied abroad in London and absolutely loved it. But, London is a lot like New York: major city, cabs, native language of English, a lot of the same stores and food.
In Amsterdam, I am hoping to get a very different cultural experience. Hopefully I will learn a new language, experience a different culture, try new food, get around on a bike, and travel throughout Europe. I am young and have nothing keeping me here in New York right now. I am definitely sad about leaving New York / America and I will obviously miss my family and friends, but it is the perfect time to take this opportunity. If I had this opportunity and did not take it, I know that in 10 years, or even in a month, I would look back at this missed opportunity and kick myself.
Originally published at amsterdam.alexakaminsky.com on October 29, 2014.

Title: Amsterdam, 2024: A Cityâ€™s Cigar Culture Fading Into Smoke
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Combining the timeless pursuit of meaning (legacy) with the boundless freedom to explore (latitude). A guide for men charting their own paths through the art of living wellâ€Šâ€”â€Štravel, craftsmanship, rituals, enduring ideas, and the finer things in life.

Featured
--
3
Listen
Share
Amsterdam used to mean something to cigar lovers. Or so Iâ€™d readÂ¹. The stories painted a picture of cigar lounges that werenâ€™t just places to smoke, but sanctuaries â€” spaces where a man could light up, lean back, and let the world turn without him for a while. The kind of places that made you feel like a part of something.
But the Amsterdam I found wasnâ€™t that.
I arrived in 2024 chasing those stories. Before my trip, Iâ€™d done the usual research, looked up the names that still carried weight in cigar circles. P.G.C. Hajenius â€” a name spoken with reverence, a temple to tobacco since 1826 , P.G.C. Hajenius, one of the oldest cigar shops in the world â€” was the first on my list. Its Art Deco interior, legendary humidor, and the ghosts of cigar lovers whoâ€™d passed through its doors made it a destination in itself.
But my planning led to discoveries I hadnâ€™t expected. A few phone calls, a dive into the cityâ€™s laws, and the truth hit home: Amsterdamâ€™s cigar lounges were no longer what theyâ€™d been. The 2008 smoking bans had started the slow dismantling, and the 2020 regulations had finished the job, leaving even the likes of Hajenius a shadow of its former selfÂ². By decree of Dutch law, every cigar lounge in Amsterdam was snuffed out as of January 1, 2022 â€” a quiet funeral for a once-thriving cultureÂ³.
I couldnâ€™t bring myself to go. Not because I was afraid of disappointment, but because thereâ€™s a point where preserving the memory of something becomes more important than confirming its absence. I didnâ€™t want to see that grandeur stripped down, repurposed into some polite, sterile shell. Maybe one day Iâ€™ll go â€” not to chase what was, but to see what remains. But this trip wasnâ€™t the time for that.
Instead, I focused on the present. I had one day left in Amsterdam, and I wasnâ€™t about to waste it wallowing in nostalgia for a past Iâ€™d never lived. Thatâ€™s how I found myself at Cigaragua.
Cigaragua isnâ€™t a place trying to recreate the golden age of cigar lounges. It doesnâ€™t have the leather armchairs, the paneled wood, or the ghosts of old men swapping war storiesâ´. Instead, itâ€™s defiantly modern. Clean. Unapologetically Nicaraguan.
The shopfront is subtle, but its presence is bold, standing as a rare holdout in a city thatâ€™s lost its love for cigars. Thereâ€™s no room to linger â€” not because they donâ€™t want you to, but because the city doesnâ€™t. Amsterdam has no place anymore for the kind of slow, social rituals that make cigars more than just tobacco. Cigaragua has turned their cigar room into an extra storage space because of this.
What Cigaragua does have is quality. Their selection is a celebration of Nicaraguaâ€™s best â€” a curated homage to a country thatâ€™s made itself synonymous with craftsmanship in the cigar world. The staff know their stuff, too. They donâ€™t just sell cigars; they respect them.
I walked out with two: the Sobremesa BrÃ»lÃ©e Blue, a cigar that would later redefine my idea of a dessert cigar, and the Perdomo Double Aged 12-Year Vintage Connecticut, with its flawless construction and pedigree of aged tobaccos.
I didnâ€™t smoke them in Amsterdam. This city, for all its indulgences, no longer felt like a place for that kind of moment. But thatâ€™s another story: Two Cigars, Two Journeys: a Prelude to Nicaragua
Walking through Amsterdamâ€™s streets, itâ€™s impossible to ignore its contradictions. The air is thick with the scent of cannabis, rolling out of coffee shops without apology. The red-light district glows like a beacon, a carnival of curiosity and hedonism. This is a city that markets its indulgences with pride â€” except, apparently, for cigars.
The hypocrisy isnâ€™t just glaring â€” itâ€™s comical. You can sit in a coffee shop and light up a joint without a second thought, but a cigar in a lounge? Thatâ€™s where the line is drawn. Amsterdam hasnâ€™t turned its back on vice; itâ€™s just decided which kinds of indulgence are acceptable. And cigars, with their air of refinement, their association with slow, thoughtful leisure, have been left out in the cold.
Iâ€™m not shocked by Amsterdamâ€™s decadence. Iâ€™ve seen enough of the world to know that people will always find ways to indulge. I donâ€™t judge it. But I do call out the hypocrisy â€” the selective morality that lets one kind of smoke flow freely while stamping out another.
For all the disappointment I felt, Cigaragua gave me hope. Itâ€™s not trying to reclaim the past or fight the tide of change. Itâ€™s simply standing firm, celebrating the craft and the culture that cigars represent.
Maybe Amsterdam will come around. Maybe, one day, the pendulum will swing back, and the city will remember what itâ€™s lost. And maybe, when that day comes, Iâ€™ll walk through the doors of P.G.C. Hajenius â€” not chasing the past, but ready to face whatever remains. Until then, Iâ€™ll carry the memory of what Amsterdam could have been, and the promise of what it still might become.
Because even in a city thatâ€™s turned its back on cigars, thereâ€™s still room for moments that remind you why they matter. And sometimes, thatâ€™s enough.
â€” â€” Footnotes â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” â€” Â¹ Iâ€™ve read a number of pieces about Amsterdamâ€™s cigar legacy, such as this one: https://www.cigarinspector.com/cigar-library/amsterdams-cigar-lounges/
Â² Only after having checked into my hotel in Amsterdam, I started catching up on updates, including this curious insight: https://www.zigarren.zone/en/netherlands-bans-cigar-lounges/But the subject has been covered much earlier, a good example is this 2017 micro-document by David Fuller: Banning Tobacco in Cannabis Cafes?
Â³ On the subject of cigar lounges being banned: The new law that came into force on January 1, 2022 regarding cigar lounges is not directly aimed at the few cigar lounges, but rather at the large commercial buildings that have smoking areas. Unfortunately, cigar lounges are also affected by this change. They will therefore also had to close.
â´ Had I traveled to Amsterdam few years earlier, I would have been able to experience Cigaragua when it hosted a cigar lounge. In fact I was looking forward to it, after having seen information such as this piece from 2019: https://www.cigaraficionado.com/article/where-to-smoke-cigaragua-amsterdam
--
--

My love for Amsterdam was ignited when I met some friendly Dutch fans at a soccer World Cup match.
This was the year 2010 when South Africa hosted the Soccer World Cup.
The energy and friendliness of the Dutch planted the seed that left me wanting to visit Amsterdam.
Just their warm energy had me drawn to them.
My visit to Amsterdam was everything I expected and much more.
Just like in the soccer match, the people I came into contact with, in Amsterdam were warm and friendly.
Being around people with this energy always leaves me on a natural high. My heart feels at peace.
Waking up each morning and exploring the city was always a fun adventure.
Public transport is extremely reliable and efficient. I did a lot of walking in Amsterdam. I also rented a bicycle.
I love cycling!
Cycling in the streets of Amsterdam was a uniquely different experience.

Content:

It is hard to believe that it has already been over a year since I first left the country. I have spent my whole life with a passion for travel but up until last year I was spending all of my time and funds on hopelessly driving or flying from one side of the country to the other.
Donâ€™t get me wrong I love the views in the US but I always wanted to get some stamps in my passport and really experience different cultures and what else the world had to offer!
I spent as much time as I could traveling last year and after experiencing 8 different countries in those 12 months, I have finally come to the conclusion on my answer for the question I get all the time, â€œWhere should I go first?â€
With a smirk on my face I enthusiastically reply â€œAmsterdam!â€
Most people are scared or nervous about what to expect when they leave the country for the first time and for good reason. There are so many things to consider like:
what kind of currency do they use?
Is it safe?
How will I get around?
What language do they speak?
These are all valid questions that I ask every time I begin planning my next adventure and something that everyone should look into beforeâ€¦

Title: Six years in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
9
Listen
Share
I was sitting in Naples airport waiting for my flight back to Amsterdam after my New Yearâ€™s holiday. People were coming and going with their usual murmur, and the loudspeakers were announcing things in Italian that my mind, despite understanding, ignored. I looked at all the faces, searching for a familiar one that made me feel at home. I must admit that at that point, I had already spent quite some months wondering about the meaning of â€œhomeâ€. What was home? Where is your house if youâ€™ve left your country, and your family did as well?The people around me were dragging their suitcases, their inflatable pillows, their children. Suddenly, a voice crept into my thoughts; it was the loudspeaker saying in Dutch that the flight 4091 with destination Amsterdam was going to leave on time. Strange, I thought, that Dutch has my attention and Italian doesnâ€™t.
Five years and nine months ago, I started writing a piece called â€œThree Months in Amsterdam.â€ It took me so long to finish it (like all ideas that spring up from the back of my mind and I marinate without cooking) that spring passed, and the piece had to be retitled â€œSix Months in Amsterdam.â€ Knowing myself, not so bad. Itâ€™s not six months anymore; itâ€™s six years, plus a few more winters and springs.
In practical and numerical terms, my life in the Netherlands can be summed up as 1 pandemic, 4 houses, 11 roommates, 3 jobs, 7 months of unemployment, a few gyms, 5 stolen bicycles, a few hundred acquaintances, a handful of friends, 22 or 23 romantic platonic crushes, 3 bike crushes, 1 Dutch boyfriend (ex-boyfriend), and a ton of questions.
Living in the Netherlands is something I choose every day, especially on winter days, pedaling through the rain and against the wind is where love is tested. Itâ€™s easy to choose Amsterdam in spring, when the streets are filled with flowers planted by the city (oh my taxes look so pretty!) and the cherry trees are blooming in the forest. When the streets are filled with happy people, sipping white wine while sitting on the sidewalk, young people (!) playing jeu de boule at the park, and the barbecue my neighbor and I make on the sidewalk with meat he brought on one of his flights to Argentina and passed through customs with dubious techniques.Itâ€™s easy to choose Amsterdam in summer, with the sidewalks already decorated with the chalk drawings of the neighborhood children, when the heat is 25 degrees, and you get ice cream at work. When the team returns to play volleyball at the park, and I can pedal around the city with my floral dress blowing in the wind, on my way to jump into a canal or to put my bike on my sister's and brother-in-lawâ€™s boat for a ride after work. Amsterdam in summer is a playground among gardens of happiness.
When winter comes, the story is different; the city becomes quiet, calm. Itâ€™s a bit of a relief not to have to leave the house every day, to make a winter plan, to learn something new, to buy candles because they make the night more cozy, or like Dutch people say gezellig. No one writes to go to the park anymore, unless itâ€™s those two autumn days when all the trees in Vondelpark are a different color. No, when winter comes and the sky is gray, itâ€™s not so easy to choose the Netherlands; even my freckles disappear. When winter comes and no one sees the sun for 20 days, doubts also arise: Why do I choose to live in this place? Am I always going to live in the shade under an overcast gray sky?
The key to escaping the existential emptiness that the lack of sun brings is nothing more and nothing less than to leave. Yes, leave. If privilege allows, all migrants try to escape. I go to see my parents and my brother in Spain, to the mountains in France, to some island where â€œcloudsâ€ is not a topic of conversation. I escape on Wednesdays to my comedy club to make strangers laugh, or to be entertained by my comedian friends, I escape between the keys of a piano I canâ€™t play or take refuge at the gym.
Perhaps the strangest thing about having migrated six years ago is that my family also left Argentina, and we live spread across three countries in Europe. Sometimes I like to say weâ€™re reverse colonizing, a TEG in real time. I also like when people ask me about my parents, to say: â€œTheyâ€™re in a better placeâ€ and then clarify that they live in Spain as well as one of my brothers. That they adapted to other latitudes and now say words like â€œmajoâ€ and â€œguapaâ€, that they occasionally have a whole leg of ham at home, that they like to have bread with tomato for breakfast, that they eat eggs with chips and meat at 10 am and they go out for tapas and to see their friends at the bar.
That they also maybe sometimes wonder where home is.
A few years ago, I had two Argentinian brothers, but now I have a half-Spanish brother and a half-French brother, who has blended into the culture spectacularly. This includes having a French accent when he speaks English, which confuses my friends in Amsterdam, a lot lot. On the other hand, my brother-in-law, who used to be Argentinian, is now Argentinian-Dutch, and beyond what the papers say, he loves to eat bitterballen with beer and if you ask me, that should be worthy of a Dutch nationality. Sometimes I ask my sister if she suspected that her life would be like having dinner at 6 p.m. and that every plan would include a bicycle, if she ever suspected how difficult it would be for her to make new friends in this place.
I wonder if I, too, should be given a Dutch passport after having carried things in my bike like a desk and chair on a single trip, a case of beer, a Dutchman, a small tree, a computer screen, and a coat rack. Perhaps it would be worth it of a Dutch passport my new ability to set boundaries, to be incredibly direct, to ask everyone to pay their share after inviting people for dinner at my house, to have events planned six months in advance and to own that raincoat that opens like a tent so your legs donâ€™t get wet when you pedal.Would my love for Dutch urbanism and design, and my fondness for those classic Dutch songs by Andre Hazes that sound like a grandmotherâ€™s ballad, deserve a Dutch passport?
Sometimes loving a country that isnâ€™t your own feels a lot like cheating on a loved one. Forgive me, Argentina, I didnâ€™t know I was going to fall in love. I still think of you on rainy afternoons, on barbacueless Sundays, and when I notice my friends growing old so far away.
But donâ€™t wait up for me.
If itâ€™s any consolation, the truth is that I miss things: the culture, the sun, the alfajores, the ParanÃ¡ River, my friends, some parts of my extended family. Then I open Twitter and see what the drama of the day in the country is. I go to eat empanadas at a little argentinian paradise called La Reinita, I listen to â€œAdios Noninoâ€, which is the song my friend Fede always listens to, and the tango makes me melancholic, which is the only emotion that goes well with it. I think about Messi more than Iâ€™d like to admit, and I carry a little Argentinian flag on the back of my phone so I donâ€™t forget that other place I love and has given me so much.
But despite the wonders I can say about my life in Amsterdam after so many years the fantastic becomes familiar, and what keeps me here, I have to admit, are my friends. What I would do without the love of these people, I donâ€™t know. Theyâ€™re living their own migration experience, and from different places, we share something that is common to all.
I landed at Amsterdam Airport after a few hours of travel. Stepping off the plane, I felt an immediate and unexpected relief at the familiarity of the airport: how tall the people were, hearing people speaking Dutch, the friendly voice on the loudspeakers announcing the trains. Then I knew it: my house is here and my home as well.
--
--

Content:

1
Listen
Share
Here for the travel advice and not to read my life story? Jump to Travel Recommendations for the tl;dr [too long; didnâ€™t read] to plan your trip to Amsterdam now!
I felt giddy as my flight touched down. I was passing through the city somewhat incidentally. My end destination was Portugal but it was cheaper to fly through Amsterdam first. So I stretched my layover into a three-day trip. This gave me one day to recover from jet lag and a solid two days in Amsterdam to explore.
Amsterdam is one of those cities proceeded by its reputation. Personally, it has loomed large in my imagination for decades. A place where prostitution is not only legal but flaunted. Where weed, magic mushrooms, and who knows what else was accessible long before even medical clinics were open back home in California. A place where kids going to what at the time I considered â€œrealâ€ or four-year colleges would go to spend a semester abroad. It seemed like such an exciting and luxurious opportunity. One that I could only dream of as I worked my way through community college as a waitress to supplement my scholarships and financial aid.
I wanted to ride a bike around and meet new people from all over the world. Wear cozy sweaters and do drugs in coffee shops and bars. The fact that this was exactly how I was already spending most if not all of my time right at home in San Francisco and Oakland did not make it seem any less exotic.
By the time I finally had the chance to make that pilgrimage, I was in a very different state of mind. I spent my two days in Amsterdam on history and art tours. Taking in the old buildings and even older paintings. Trying new foods such as stroopwaffle (yay!) and pickled herring (nay).
Amsterdam is expensive! Hotels, hostels, and Airbnbs are all expensive. I ended up staying at CityHub Amsterdam, a capsule hotel. Overall, it was a good experience. I donâ€™t really spend time in the hotel when I am traveling so this was a good option for me. It was clean and quiet. I loved the location. There was even a street market right outside where I stopped every morning for a fresh squeezed juice during my stay.
Back to top
I donâ€™t have much in the way of tips for this trip. It is easy to move through the city and everyone speaks English. The one thing I want to mention is, watch out for bikes! There is a lot of bicycle traffic and one sure-fire way to get cursed out from an otherwise friendly and easygoing local population is to cross the bike lane without looking.
Back to top
Start your day with a free walking tour! This is a great way to start your trip, especially if you are short on time. I recommend taking one the first day to help you get oriented. Free Walking Tours Amsterdam is the one I went with. I took the classic tour, but they have several other options to chose from depending on your interest. There are also many, many other options to choose from when selecting a free walking tour.
This style of tour is available all over Europe. I have even started seeing them in some places in Latin America as well. They typically last 2â€“3 hours. Your guide will give you some historical context for the city and show you the main sights within walking distance. The tours are indeed free, but the guides are only paid through tips. Have cash on hand to fork over at least â‚¬5-â‚¬10 once the tour is over.
Back to top
Consider grabbing lunch or dinner at this trendy food hall. It is modeled after a concept that has taken the world by storm. Foodhallen is one building with many different stalls inside that offer different types of cuisine. You can order from any one that catches your fancy and grab a spot amidst the communal seating.
Back to top
In the evening, I recommend heading over to NDSM. This cultural hotspot is a collection of contemporary art studios and rotating exhibitions in a giant converted warehouse. You may catch a music show or a performance. There are also a few places to eat while on that side of the river.
The easiest way to arrive is to take the F4 ferry from Amsterdam Central Station. It is free and runs every 15â€“30 minutes. Be sure to hop back on before the ferry service ends at midnight.
Back to top
There are so many different options to choose from, but Rijksmuseum is the crown jewel of museums in Amsterdam. This one is a must-see for any visitor. You can purchase your timed entry tickets the day of, but I recommend buying them a day or two before if you are on a strict schedule and need to be at the museum at a specific time. I also recommend coming here first and then exploring some of the other must-sees in the city such as the Van Gough Museum or the Anne Frank House Museum.
Back to top
All that wandering around and viewing of those giant Renaissance paintings of food in varying states of decay is bound to make you hungry. After visiting Rijksmuseum it is just a short jaunt to Albert Cupstraat Markt. This market stretches several blocks and includes giftable wares, flowers, and most importantly, traditional Dutch cuisine. Be sure to try the stroopwafels, pickled herring, bitterballen (meatballs), and patat friet (french fries).
The market is open 9:30 am-5:00 pm every day except Sundays.
Back to top
The Central Park of Amsterdam is worth strolling through on foot or by bike and is close to both Rijksmuseum and Albert Cuypstraat market. Itâ€™s a beautiful place to stop and take a rest on one of the many benches lining the park paths before continuing on with your busy day.
Back to top
No stay in Amsterdam would be complete without a stop at the famous Red Light District. Locals hate it, tourists love it. If you are visiting, I think you have to go at least to see it. There are even historical tours during the day for the faint of heart. Itâ€™s easy to find a burlesque show, sex show, or just head out on your own to experience the scene at night.
If you do go in the evening, be prepared to witness the true spectacle, the endless parade of bachelor or â€œstagâ€ parties crowding the street. You will mostly see women in windows soliciting their wares as you walk the streets, which is to say, themselves. I enjoyed watching the full spectrum of how these women interacted with the passing crowd. Some were dancing, some were trying to entice potential customers with a flirty, joking manner. The most conventionally attractive were visibly bored, doom scrolling on their phones and awaiting their next client without having to put in much effort.
Back to top
I was traveling alone for this trip, so I didnâ€™t have the wild adventure I might have otherwise. But as I get older and wiser, I canâ€™t help but grow in my appreciate of the quieter side of cities and life itself. The joys of earlier mornings, sans hangover. Trying new foods, even if it is for the first and last time. And most importantly, whether it be through observing classical art or observing my fellow tourist on their worst behavior, always learning something new whenever I have the opportunity.
--
--

Title: Is Amsterdam a nice city to live in?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
2
Share
Time flies â€” itâ€™s been almost a year since I moved from Prague, Czechia, to Amsterdam, The Netherlands.
I loved Prague, but Amsterdam quickly captured a special place in my heart. It feels like home here. And thanks to the rare combination of calmness and just enough excitement, Iâ€™ve decided to stay here a little longer and build a stable base.
This is my analysis of how it is to live in Amsterdam. Based on ten criteria, I evaluated the quality of life in Amsterdam. Please note that this article is based on a combination of facts and statistics, but mainly on personal experiences.
Since the introduction of the Safe Cities Index, a report from The Economist Intelligence Unit, Amsterdam was always in the top 10 safest cities globally. In the 2021 report, Amsterdam was in second place on personal security, just behind Copenhagen.
I can see why Amsterdam consistently ranks that high. It feels incredibly safe here. A walk in the middle of the night? No problem. A late-night bicycle ride through the park? Donâ€™t worry. I go running daily (often late at night) andâ€¦

Title: The Doâ€™s and Donâ€™ts of Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Clueâ€™s in the name really, itâ€™s an exciting insight into the mysteries of the infamous Red Light District. This museum gives you all the juicy and hush hush secrets of the industry. Here are some reasons why it should feature on your itinerary:
Â· For one, its location is a former 17th century brothel in the centre of the Red Light District (how much more authentic can you get?!)
Â· It provides personal stories and accounts of prostitutes whoâ€™ve worked in Amsterdam throughout the years; some are extremely emotional and hard hitting.
Â· You can sit in a Red Light Window (which is a fab photo op!) and visit the room of a girl who worked at the brothel for 7 years.
Â· It has the last prostitution office in Amsterdam (everything in there is still untouched!).
Â· Itâ€™s on the cheap side! If you go to a tours and tickets shop which are located around Amsterdam or book online in advance its further discounted.
Businesses in the Red Light District do not allow people to take photos. You most likely will have your phone confiscated. Youâ€™re putting yourselves at risk if you try! Staring isnâ€™t banned but, understandably, the women donâ€™t like it. Some are very smiley and open, others more reserved. I saw a girl use a curtain to cover her face when a group of tourists wouldnâ€™t stop gawping. Although sometimes itâ€™s difficult not to look, donâ€™t be disrespectful or excessive!
If youâ€™re a history lover, like myself, I imagine this biographical museum would tell the perfect story of arguably the most renowned holocaust victim. I say â€˜imagineâ€™â€¦ because we didnâ€™t manage to get in! From 9am-3.30pm the museum was reserved for people who had booked online. From 3.30pm a GIGANTIC queue formed which was at least 3 hours long, at which point we abandoned the idea and went to grab a pint.
My advice is DO buy tickets online if you want to visit without the hassle. Plus, Iâ€™m aware tickets online sell out quickly so book asap!
Like â€˜The Red Lights Secrets museumâ€™, it is anything but boring! From giant penises to an automated farting flasher â€¦ itâ€™s great for a giggle and fab if you like art thatâ€™s a little out of the box! Itâ€™s also cheap as chips (literallyâ€¦thereâ€™s a chip shop across the road which is more expensive) It only costs $5!
Itâ€™s a cool photo opportunity and if youâ€™re athletic enough you can climb on the giant letters (note I chose not to!)
This is probably one of my greatest regrets of the trip. EVERYONE and I mean everyone travelled by bike. We decided to walk pretty much everywhere and it resulted in extremely blistered feet. Although walking is beneficial sometimes (at night or if youâ€™re exploring) Iâ€™d say biking is the more fun and efficient option. There are places to hire bikes dotted around Amsterdam, they arenâ€™t hard to come by. Although do be careful if you do go on a bike because people cycle like they are competing at a velodrome, which leads perfectly to my next point.
I had a few close shaves whilst obliviously standing in a lane attempting to navigate myself. They can be quite discrete, so just be on the lookout.
Lots of people hire out bikes purely to cycle round this serene environment (and it is quite big so if you want to see all of it, biking is probably the way to go). On a sunny day, itâ€™s full of people listening to music, having picnics and lazing about on the grass. Itâ€™s incredibly beautiful and a relaxing pit stop from the business of the city centre.
This 22-floor tower is a bar/restaurant and gives an amazing 360Ëš birdâ€™s-eye view of Amsterdam. Drinks are a little on the pricey side but remember, youâ€™re paying for the experience as well- itâ€™s a second to none vantage point and the cocktails are huge! Also, if you are a bit of a daredevil, Aâ€™DAM lookout- â€˜Over the Edgeâ€™ is Europeâ€™s highest swing. You get to swing 100 metres above the ground right at the top of the building (fair to say I was not tempted).
Generally, alcohol is expensive, so pre-drinks are essential and supermarket prices arenâ€™t bad for a bottle of wine or a few cans! This capital is obviously known for its cannabis culture and wide range of coffeeshops (which are just as common as bars). Prices are much cheaper so itâ€™s a sound alternative- when in Rome, do as the Romans do (Or in this case, when in Amsterdam, do as the Dutch do!) â€¦
Like most cities the further into the city centre you go the more expensive things become. This is the case for both food and drink. Some of the best bars and eating places were scattered on the outskirts! Check out the map at the bottom of this post for a few ideas!
The great thing about Amsterdam is the diversity and element of surprise around each corner. Whether itâ€™s exploring the Red Light District, coffeeshops, museums or just strolling by the gorgeous canals, itâ€™s impossible to be bored so allow yourself to wander and take it all in!

Title: What makes Amsterdam so diverse and progressive compared to the United States?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The Netherlands has proven to be home to a very diverse group of people in my short time here. While researching I found that the US is technically more diverse but given how much larger of a country it is than the Netherlands, different nationalities, cultures, and races tend to be more spread out and isolated as a result. I have been to many large cities in the US (New York, Washington DC, Miami, Detroit, etc.) and while they are all diverse to an extent, it always seems there is one dominant culture or nationality in each city. This is why to me Amsterdam is a true cultural blend with people having heritages from all over the world and potentially living in the same city block. This made me question why the US is like this and how Amsterdam seems so much more diverse than the US even though it statistically is not.
The simple answer is because of the Dutch themselves and their acceptance of immigrants and refugees. The Dutch have, for centuries, been a safe haven of sorts to people from European, Middle Eastern, or Asian countries and this has led to a high number of immigrants fleeing their home country for Amsterdam. The Dutch advocate heavily for inclusion instead of immigration which has allowed these immigrants to feel safe and comfortable in Amsterdam which in turn leads to them staying and starting families. This is enhanced by the fact that they have a labor migration program that helps skilled workers migrate to the country in order to work. This has the effect of also solving holes in the employment market by filling jobs that are most necessary with immigrants who possess those skills. The most recent â€œMulti-year Policy Plan for Social Issuesâ€ spanned the years 2015â€“2018 and focused on anti-discrimination, LGBTQ+ rights, and empowering women. These are all issues the US is just now starting to even address let alone solve.
These factors all relate to the 20th and 21st century and the Netherlands has been around for much longer than that, so things have been trending this way for a long time. The Dutch built an empire through trading in the â€œGolden Eraâ€ which was the 16th and 17th centuries, and this was what, unknown to them, got the ball rolling on making Amsterdam so diverse. The addition of colonies started the trend of immigrants leaving for Amsterdam whether it was under their own free will or not did not affect the outcome. The outcome was that many people from South America, The Caribbean, Indonesia, and India ended up residing in Amsterdam throughout the 17th and 18th centuries.
The Netherlands relied heavily on trade which brought foreigners from other countries to the ports of Amsterdam and Rotterdam. These foreigners were trading with the Dutch, not immigrants from one of their many colonies in this time period. Many of these foreigners became immigrants over time whether for profit, the culture, or whatever reason. In turn, this resulted in an even larger influx of immigrants than that of individuals coming from a colony. Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, this would continue and be more focused on specialization. The Dutch needed people with different skills, and they didnâ€™t care where they came from, how they talked, or what they looked like. The opportunities of the city of Amsterdam were too enticing to some and this is a major factor in my observation of dense clusters of diversity in the city.
The opportunities didnâ€™t stop at just the jobs though, the Netherlands is home to many prestigious schools and universities which also has a role. People do not just immigrate to Amsterdam for jobs, many do it for education. However, when the job and educational opportunities are combined, along with the respect Dutch citizens have for immigrants, people are more likely to completely emigrate to the Netherlands. A lot of foreigners in the US are not immigrants and live in the US on school or work Visas. The negative view Americans have on immigrants results in many of them going back to their home country after their Visa expires. The Netherlands provides them with a home away from home in a sense and ultimately more immigrants chose to stay. Policy: Diversity â€” City of Amsterdam

Title: Amsterdam, Van Gogh and the Way Art Changes How We See
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
How a visit to the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam made me see art â€” and life â€” a little differently.
â€œThere are so many people â€¦ who imagine that words are nothing. On the contrary, donâ€™t you think, itâ€™s as interesting and as difficult to say a thing well as to paint a thing. Thereâ€™s the art of lines and colours, but thereâ€™s the art of words that will last just the same.â€ â€” Vincent van Gogh
The Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam wasnâ€™t just another stop on my trip â€” it was an experience that has sat with me long after I left. Walking through the galleries felt like stepping into someoneâ€™s mind â€” chaotic, confusing, beautiful and deeply human. A stark contrast to the sensory overload of the Red Light District. It was a reminder that cities hold entire worlds within them, and this was one I wanted to stay in for a while.
I took my time. My friends, not exactly museum people, humored me the best they could. But I was walking through on my own timeline, looking at every painting, reading every plaque, walking through the life of a man who saw art and color in ways otherâ€™s couldnâ€™t. Iâ€™ve always been drawn to words, to how they hold meaning beyond what we can easily explain. And Van Gogh, for all his beautiful paintings, was also a writer. His letters to his brother Theo were displayed throughout the museum and were filled with thoughts on life, art, struggle that somehow still resonate over a century later.
I think a lot about whether Iâ€™m on the right path, if the choices Iâ€™m making now will lead somewhere meaningful. Van Gogh didnâ€™t have certainty either, but he worked anyway. Thatâ€™s the thing: we donâ€™t get guarantees. We just have to keep moving, creating, learning and hoping that the fire we listen to inside us means something.
Thereâ€™s something about being in a new place, a new country, that sharpens my senses. Colors seem brighter, sounds louder, details more prominent. Travel makes you look closer at the world, but I donâ€™t want to need a plane ticket to notice things. I want to carry that kind of attention with me every day, the way Van Gogh found beauty in the most ordinary things â€” a field, a flower, a patch of sky.
Travel forces you to be okay with not knowing what youâ€™re doing. Iâ€™ve seriously messed up languages, taken the wrong trains and gotten lost in cities with a dead phone where I donâ€™t even know the alphabet. But I figured it out. Thatâ€™s how we learn â€” by doing, failing and trying again. Van Gogh painted relentlessly, even when he doubted himself. I think thatâ€™s how I want to live: always trying, always pushing toward something better.
My friends waited for me while I lingered in the museum, laughing at my obsession but letting me have my moment. Travel is filled with these fleeting experiences, but the people you share them with are what make them real. Iâ€™m slowly learning that home isnâ€™t a town or even a continent â€” itâ€™s the people who let you be exactly who you are, whether thatâ€™s standing in front of a painting for way too long or getting lost in a city together.
I often find myself feeling unsettled, like Iâ€™m searching for something I donâ€™t quite know yet. But then I remind myself that not everything makes sense right away. Van Gogh knew what it felt like to struggle, to wonder if things would ever get better. But he kept going. And I think thatâ€™s all any of us can do: keep going, keep searching, keep trying to make sense of it all.
I left the museum with postcards, a book of his quotes (which inspired this blog) and a feeling I couldnâ€™t quite name. Maybe it was a quiet understanding. Maybe it was comfort. Maybe it was just the realization that, across centuries, across continents, some people just get it.
As I stepped back into the streets of Amsterdam, the world seemed slightly different â€” like I was seeing it through his eyes, noticing the colors a little more, the details I might have otherwise missed. Maybe thatâ€™s the real gift of art, not just what it shows us, but how it changes the way we see everything else.
â€œFor my part I know nothing with any certainty, but the sight of the stars makes me dream.â€ â€” Van Gogh
And maybe, for now, thatâ€™s enough.

Figuring out life abroad one mistake at a time. Journalist, first-time traveler and student trying to make sense of Europe -- and occasionally succeeding!

Title: Changing desires in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Day 44 â€” Amsterdam
I am sitting here on my tiny balcony. The air still feels crisp and humid because of last nightâ€™s rain. There is no doubt, I am back in Holland.
Back in Holland after 3 years of travelling around as a digital nomad.
But for the very first time, I donâ€™t feel an immediate urge to pack my bags and hop back on another plane. Something needs to change first.
When I started my solo trips around Europe a few years ago, I was terrified that I would constantly feel alone. The mere thought of dining alone in restaurants, going to parties where I knew no one, or feeling lost in an unknown city, freaked me out.
And the alternativeâ€”approaching people and socialisingâ€”was even scarier.
But life is different now. I doubt if I will ever lose my moments of social awkwardness, but I made a habit of throwing myself into new situations. I learned how to surf, tried to learn how to dance and turned strangers into close friends.
Living a cliche digital nomad lifestyle. Yet, I am somewhat done with it. It feels like I finally graduated.
Donâ€™t get me wrong. I live a privileged life. I love the adventure, the novelty, the thrill and there is nothing quite like connecting with new people. I love new stories, waiting to be unpacked.
However, the biggest downside of a nomadic life is â€” no surpriseâ€” the fact that everyone leaves again. I know now that it is possible to build deep connections within weeks, sometimes even hours. To cry, laugh and share life stories together.
But maintaining them is a different story. Itâ€™s almost impossible to stay close while being separated by different time zones. Especially for a terrible Whatsappâ€™er like myself.
I struggle with the need to always build new deep connections from scratch. I struggle with friends â€” or myself leaving after a few months. I donâ€™t want that no more. Again, something needs to change.
For years, my biggest desire has been freedom, the freedom to travel and explore the world. But slowly I am witnessing my desires change. Does my longing for freedom still outweigh the struggle of often missing close friends and family?
How do I balance freedom with maintaining deep, long-lasting connections? I canâ€™t simply take my loved ones with me.
Or can I?
Well, I am going to give it a try.
In the upcoming period, I will record conversations with those around me, wherever I am. Much like interviewing famous podcast guests.
Allowing us to dive deeper than casual small talk, and hopefully resulting in an album of conversations â€” souvenirs for when our paths diverge again.
The goal is not to share them publically and rack up millions of downloads. Quite the opposite. I can be a DJ without a crowd. I am recording these conversations to get to know the people in my life better, explore their stories, and to laugh and create lasting memories.
I donâ€™t know if we will like it. But trying is the only way to find out. Trying to lean into whatever excites me, intrigues me, into what I consider meaningful.
And this idea definitely feels meaningful to me.
I am sitting here on my balcony staring at the sky. The sun slowly breaks through. I am feeling the energy of trying something new.
Letâ€™s go.
â€” -During the upcoming period, I will record some podcasts and I am looking for cities to settle instead of always travelling around.
â€œKnow when it is time to move on, know when you graduated.â€
--
