Title: An Ode to Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Before leaving my safe D.C. haven and flying thousands of miles across the Atlantic, my friends who had gone abroad the semester before told me that it changed their lives, how they would go back in a second, and how lucky I was that I had the experience ahead of me. Few people mentioned challenges, or if they did, it was because they had to eat too much rice or had too many crazy nights out. For most people it seemed like their experience in Europe was spent drunk 90% of the time, something I wasnâ€™t particularly searching for in an abroad experience. So I was wholly unprepared when I came to Amsterdam and struggled in many unexpected ways. I hate saying I struggled because I feel so privileged that I could even study abroad and spend four months in Amsterdam. Who complains about getting to live in Europe??? I found myself looking at my Instagram and Facebook photos wondering if my pictures really represented my experience at all. But in the interest of being honest and transparent, I figured it was best not to sugarcoat my experience. Whenever people ask me how my time in Amsterdam is going, my automatic and natural response is to say, â€œAmazing, I love it!â€ when in fact it has not been without obstacles that often left me questioning why I left D.C. at all. Why is our natural response to say what we think people want to hear even if it is far from the truth? Itâ€™s hard to say that you donâ€™t love something, and even harder to admit that you are probably partially, if not fully, responsible for that. Convinced my generation has a fear of mediocrity, I found myself trying to portray my experience in a positive light just to make people think I was having the stereotypical abroad experience. It was definitely difficult writing this because I feel guilty and ungrateful for not loving my time in Europe, for not cherishing every moment. It almost feels socially unacceptable to question anything that should be wonderful. But going abroad was tough, and I wanted to explain the good, bad, and ugly and go beyond my usual rosy response.
I think of myself as a pretty adventurous person, relatively adaptable, and definitely good at taking on new situations, but Amsterdam tested that. I sat in my room after the first week of classes and cried for hours. I felt so alone and isolated. Maybe that was due to the fact that I lived 25 minutes outside the center of the city, or maybe because I had never before lived in a room by myself. Regardless, it was tough. It made me truly appreciate having someone at home to ask you how your day was, or always having someone available to vent to. I pride myself on being strong and independent, but being alone truly tests your sense of self. It wasnâ€™t as much that I was physically alone â€” I had classes every day where I saw plenty of people â€” but I felt emotionally lonely. My mom wasnâ€™t available to talk as much because of the time difference, I didnâ€™t make a lot of friends where I lived, and the friends I made mostly lived in the city, which was a long commute, especially late at night when they all met up. Usually high-spirited and positive, I didnâ€™t feel like myself. The first few weeks were a lot: figuring out the transportation system (aka I hate being late, so getting to class hours early), navigating a dutch grocery store, deciding how comfortable I was biking without a helmet. I struggled with money, weight, exercise, unhealthy food, technology. Every day was a new challenge and new growth.
For me, transitioning to new things has always been pretty easy. My freshmen year at GW I made friends instantly and never felt homesick or alone. Even during my first summer working at camp, I felt like I fit in and made friends effortlessly. But abroad was different. Obviously, I was in an entirely new culture that speaks a language I literally know not a word of, but it was more than that. Living far away without people to help me feel comfortable is definitely difficult in a way I wasnâ€™t expecting. It is easy to say you love alone time until thatâ€™s all you have. I quickly realized that maybe I wasnâ€™t well equipped to go abroad. I donâ€™t really drink or stay out late or enjoy deviating from my routine, so where did that leave me? When I asked some of my friends here why they went abroad, common answers were to get away from their university or a bad relationship or to travel around Europe. Hearing them talk about why they went abroad made me realize that I may have gone for the wrong reasons or because I thought it was something I had to do. I wasnâ€™t trying to get away from anything (other than maybe Trumpâ€™s presidency), I love my friends at GW, and Iâ€™ve already traveled around Europe before, so this wasnâ€™t a first-time experience. I guess the only answer that popped into my mind was that I wanted to see a culture different from my own and to increase my knowledge of the world.
For those of you that donâ€™t know me super well, I love schedules and to-do lists and being busy. As I was talking to my mom on the phone last night, I realized that one of the things I disliked most about being abroad was the free time. I know thatâ€™s crazy, and that I should love having free time, so let me explain. Did you ever read that book about the little girl who has one wish, and her wish is to have Christmas every day? After Christmas happens a few days in a row, she starts to dislike it and not appreciate it as much. She gets a stomach ache from all the candy and doesnâ€™t know what to do with all the presents. Well, that is kind of how I feel about free time. It is great the first few days, but then I just start resenting it. Itâ€™s hard to appreciate something when thatâ€™s all you know. Much of abroad was free time. I have NEVER had this much time to do whatever I want, and it was overwhelming. Learning how to relax was hard, and also really good for me. Most of my friends here thought it was ridiculous that I didnâ€™t enjoy free time, so that made me feel even more guilty about being miserable. As the semester has gone on, Iâ€™ve learned how to make free time busy, which I realize sounds insane. My google schedule now says â€œ 6:15am: Workout; 8:00am: Bike to class; 11:00am: make lunch; 1:00pm: walk around the block; 3:00pm: Read; 6:00pm: Eat dinner; 10:00pm: Bed.â€ As you can see, my life is full of exciting turns.
Whenever people ask me what my favorite part about abroad is, I say the classes. The reaction I get is usually a mix between confusion and maybe a little disgust. The University of Amsterdam has given me three of the best classes of my entire life, with three of the best teachers. I look forward to class every day and canâ€™t wait to do the readings. I asked my Language and Politics teacher if she would go teach at GW because I loved her class so much. I felt intellectually stimulated by my classes and learned so much about the EU and the populist movement from a European perspective. If I didnâ€™t know who Geert Wilders was before Amsterdam, I sure know now. I love that the Netherlands is so progressive and generally prioritizes everyoneâ€™s needs. Their health care system is truly comprehensive and they definitely understand the importance of compromise in governing. There are many things about the Netherlands that I didnâ€™t love, but their political system and progressive policies impressed me. I now understand that prostitution is a profession and that lax drug laws are actually effective when it comes to safety.
I realize most of this essay has been about my struggles with being abroad, but I definitely need to mention all the highlights. Through my introspection on my time in the Netherlands, I have come to the conclusion that my struggles had little to do with Amsterdam or the Netherlands itself. I think I would have struggled in the same way wherever I would have gone (except maybe I would have lived closer to the city somewhere else). First and foremost, I love the city of Amsterdam. Iâ€™m so thankful for the beautiful canals, delicious food (shoutout to dutch pancakes & apple pie), and the biking culture. Biking 30 minutes to school every day was honestly one of my favorite parts. It was so rewarding learning the local biking rules and feeling like a Dutch citizen while navigating trams, tourists, and bikers with headphones. Plus, I have thighs of steel now. I made a list of things I love about the Netherlands as the semester went on, so here is a quick summary:
Iâ€™m not going to lie and say it will be extremely hard to leave. I will definitely be sad to leave this beautiful place and say goodbye to some truly great friends Iâ€™ve made. Being out of Trumpâ€™s America has been an incredible and therapeutic break from reality, but I am ready to come back and resist (well, after my three months in rural Michigan teaching fitness, of course). I sometimes mull over what I am going to say when people ask me how my time abroad was. The classic answer that it was the best four months would be inaccurate. But I feel like telling people how hard it was would be uncomfortable because we are so used to talking about abroad as if it is always incredible and without flaws. Maybe it did change my life in some ways. I think I am much better at being alone, better at relaxing, better at processing my emotions and prioritizing my health and happiness. I think learning how to live in a new culture is an important skill, and I certainly learned a lot more about Europe. Being outside of America for awhile is a good reality check. And I canâ€™t forget to mention the friendships I made. Iâ€™m thankful for Maggie biking to school with me every day, participating in almost every one of my workout sessions, and letting me vent about people stealing my Clif bars. Thankful for Steph for being my travel buddy and pushing me to really evaluate and process my feelings on relationships and family. Thankful for Kerri for being the only person Iâ€™ve ever met who feels the same way I do about alcohol and going out. And thankful for everyone else who has impacted my time abroad and made it infinitely better.
Itâ€™s okay that my time abroad wasnâ€™t perfect or as life-shattering as I was told it would be. And maybe thatâ€™s my own fault. Maybe I should have gone out more or stayed up later. Maybe in 20 years Iâ€™ll regret not forcing myself to go to dark clubs with American music with mostly American students. I very well could regret not being drunk or high for 90% of this experience. It is hard to look back on my four months and ask if there was anything I could have done to make it a better or more positive experience. But I think the most important thing Iâ€™ve learned is how to deal with situations that arenâ€™t ideal. Iâ€™m not always going to have an incredibly supportive and loving roommate (hi Sammi) to ask me how my day was. Iâ€™m not always going to have healthy food options or an accessible gym. Iâ€™m not always going to be in a city that feels natural (aka DC) or that keeps me constantly busy. Life is about dealing with new things that arenâ€™t always what you expect. My mom and dad were the MVPâ€™s of abroad. The time difference (9 hours!!!) was rough, especially because my mom gets off work at 2:30 pm, which is 11:30 pm my time (Iâ€™m definitely asleep by then), but they spent hours telling me that what I was feeling was natural. Itâ€™s okay not to love an experience but make the most of it and learn from it. When I get on the plane tomorrow, I know Iâ€™ll be sad to leave such a beautiful city, and I will certainly cherish the memories. So peace out Sloterpark and the old lady that always flies by me on my long runs around the lake. Peace out Dirk, my grocery store, that has everything but brussels sprouts (my one true love). Peace out to Bike 359, aka the most ratchet and broken bike of all time. Peace out to the Student Hotel, where customer service is definitely not a priority. Peace out to my shared kitchen and the mornings when I come in and the floor is covered in beer and half of my food is gone. Peace out to UvA and the amazing staff and students that made my time in Amsterdam academically amazing. Peace out to Ivy & Bros, aka the cafe that became my home. Peace out Schiphol Airport, where I have spent 90% of my time in the last two months due to traveling 8 (!!!) weekends in a row. Peace out Dam Square, the home of pigeons and high tourists. And finally, peace out Amsterdam, Iâ€™ll miss you.
--
--

Title: Amsterdam: Art, Photography and Type
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Weekly blog posts by Creatives from VBAT, on different topics related to Retail, Branding, Packaging, Innovation and Design in and around Amsterdam.

--
Listen
Share
Written by Craig BerryCreative Intern at VBAT
Recently I had 2 friends from the UK come to Amsterdam to visit and I wanted to show them the city I have been living in for the last 5 months and all that is great about it. I could easily have taken them to the bigger tourist attractions such as the Heineken Experience, the Anne Frank House, the Rijksmuseum and so on. But I wanted to share my pieces of local knowledge which I have picked up on so far and also find and explore new places in the city for myself.
Firstly we visited the Stedelijk Museum which although yes, it is one of those big tourist attractions, as one of the worldâ€™s best museums with a great collection, the 3 of us as intrepid young designers could not escape its allure. I myself went recently to visit the Willem Sandberg exhibition although this had since finished but in its place was a great exhibition celebrating 100 years of â€˜De Stijlâ€™. For those who donâ€™t know, De Stijl was a revolutionary art and design movement in the early 20th century (1917â€“1931) with artists like Mondrian and van Doesburg at the centre of it producing work that they saw as a reduction of form and colour choosing to mostly use vertical and horizontal shapes only using black, white and primary colours.
The exhibition itself covered these characteristics of the movement by showing these well known names tied to De Stijl â€” there was Piet Mondrianâ€™s â€˜Compositionâ€™ pieces and Gerrit Rietveldâ€™s â€˜Red and Blue Chair, these people built the aesthetic of the movement with the other pieces on show by artists and designers who have/had been inspired by them. There was Ellsworth Kelly with â€˜Red Blue Rockerâ€™ in the shape of a folded geometric circle. Roy Lichtensteinâ€™s huge piece â€˜As I Opened Fireâ€™ a painting produced using the same reduced colour palette. Also here was a strong piece by the collective â€” General Idea called â€˜InfeÂ©ted Mondrianâ€™ where they parodied the artist, copying the composition but replacing the yellow colour with a more toxic green to address the AIDS crisis which General Idea focused a lot of their work on and a comment on the dominance of De Stijl. The exhibition is part of a longer project marking 100 years of De Stijl and hopefully I can visit more of it as I see it as one of the great commanding art and design movements which is still prevalent today.
The next day we took the boat over the River IJ to NDSM, described as â€˜a rugged shipyard to a creative hotspotâ€™. The â€˜creative cityâ€™ is a historical remainder of the largest shipyard in the city and has become a haven for all people interested in creativity and art with something for everyone to admire. What stood out to us was the main NDSM building/warehouse, now a hub for studios and restaurants; the outer walls still adorned with the original painted sign. The letters on the 2 sides read â€œNetherlands Shipbuilding Companyâ€™ and â€˜Nederlandsche Dok en Scheepsbouw Maatschappijâ€™ with each letter painted on heavily in white, with little consistency in letter styles but following some sort of grid. We were motivated to photograph the letters and digitise them to produce a display font with all of its inconsistency and variety as a homage to the building, as designers it was impossible for us to not look at this and be amazed and inspired.
We also found a great bar in the NDSM area â€” Pllek, built out of old shipping containers a huge glass window looking out onto the IJ and the cold Dutch winter air. We stayed here for a while, chatting and chilling. Drinking a few beers whilst some live music played. A really cool find and as the Dutch might say, it was â€˜gezelligâ€™.
I got the following Monday off work to continue our quest around the city and we ended up at the FOAM photography museum (Fotografiemuseum Amsterdam) to check out the Hiroshi Sugimoto exhibition â€” Black Box. An overview of the Japanese artistâ€™s work which covered his major series. There was a lot of variety in what was on show but the works which really stood out to me were â€˜Lightning Fieldsâ€™ and â€˜Theatresâ€™ because of the processes which were used to make them. â€˜Lightning Fieldsâ€™ are images where there is no camera involved, they are made by channelling electricity over photo paper and exposing it. The marks left behind are incredible and the size of the prints makes for a visually strong image. â€˜Theatresâ€™ are a series of images where the artist photographed empty theatre halls, the exposure length of each photograph dictated by the length of a feature film, so each image is brighter or darker than the other. They create these ghostly like images of the room with a solid white image on the theatre screen which is almost sinister like to look into as you are surrounded by these images. The rest of the museum is also great as well as the inside of the building, it is one of the canal houses on the Keizersgracht and inside it is a series of winding rooms and dimly lit hallways: easy to get lost â€” which we did.
Finally throughout the few days we were walking around I had prepared a map that documents some of the great historical and innovative typographic signs that exist through the city. I was inspired by David Quayâ€™s type tour with us back in the warm summer time in September and using these places as well as my own findings we wandered around as I pointed out these great relics, most of them with some story to tell.
My personal favourite was this piece by Dutch artist Piet Parra on the Tuinstraat. A huge wall mural near a school and kids park which reads: â€œIk speel in de stad met alles wat er bestaatâ€ â€” I play in the city with all that exists. I just love how the letters flow from one to the next and also Parra has a unique style which fits the city perfectly.
If you enjoyed reading this, please click ğŸ’š â€œRecommendâ€ below. This will help to share the story with others.
Follow VBAT on Twitter | Like us on Facebookwritten by Craig BerryCreative at VBATedited by Connie FluhmePR at VBAT

Content:
Sign up

Member-only story

Experience the vibrant and unforgettable city of Amsterdam! Discover its iconic canals, historic architecture, and vibrant culture. Explore world-renowned museums and neighborhoods, indulge in delicious cuisine, and soak up the energy of this incredible city.
Amsterdam is a city that holds a special place in my heart. From the moment I arrived, I was struck by the cityâ€™s vibrant energy and charm. It was unlike any other place I had ever been, with its winding canals, charming architecture, and bustling streets. It is now easily one of my favorite cities on the planet.
I will dive deep into everything you need to know about this vibrant city, from its top tourist attractions to its unforgettable hidden gems. Whether planning your first visit to Amsterdam or are a seasoned traveler looking for a new adventure, this article is your ultimate resource for all things Amsterdam. So pack your bags, grab your camera, and get ready to experience the magic of this vibrant and unforgettable city.
Amsterdamâ€™s history dates back to the 12th century when a small fishing village was established on the banks of the River Amstel. By the 14th century, the village had grown into a thriving port city, and in 1300, it was granted city rights by the Bishop of Utrecht.

Title: â€œAmsterdamâ€ (2022)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Entertaining conspiracy in the land of the one-eyed King.
Three cinema trips ago, and in the second week of October of a year that is ending just hours away from when I pen these brief words of appreciation, I was leaving my local cinema in the company of my beautiful son when I happened upon the above poster for Amsterdam and immediately remarked to all within earshot: this will be a stunner of a film. As is so often proved correct within my own particular one-eyed kingdom, I was indeed right, and director David O Russellâ€™s tenth big screen cinematic affair was a conspiratorial treat. Not as accomplished perhaps as his 1999 epic Three Kings or Silver Linings Playbook over a decade later or my particular favourite in his cinematic cannon, 2013â€™s American Hustle, but I loved Amsterdam for a multitude of reasons and hopefully for differing and surprising reasons than your own.
Returning for just a moment to that film poster and my proclamation of its coming greatness as a film as my son and I ambled away from Halloween Ends in early October, whilst he was nonplussed by my soothsaying future review the cinemaâ€™s â€œGreeterâ€ wasnâ€™t as she confessed (a) sheâ€™d seen and loved an advance copy of the film and (b) sheâ€™d already bagged the poster I was referring to as she too liked it and as a perk of the job, she can buy any unreserved film posters for a knockdown price. I was of course envious as Iâ€™m a childish film fan at heart and am so often taken in by a good poster and so it was, finally, on 29th December in a year finishing in a mere few hours from now, that I watched Amsterdam expectantly awaiting a gem of a film that didnâ€™t arrive but which was replaced by something wholly surprisingly and unexpectedly different.
Since seeing the film poster in early October Iâ€™d seen not a trailer nor a sneak peak or any written reviews whatsoever. I still havenâ€™t. I watched this film without even the most basic of a premise or blurb which, according to The Matrix Movie Bible at www.imdb.com proclaims Amsterdam to be:
â€œIn the 1930s, three friends witness a murder, are framed for it, and uncover one of the most outrageous plots in American historyâ€.
Had I known this before time I would of course have been expecting the obvious real-life conspiracy being laid out before us and with the introduction of Robert De Niro in his notable cameo role, however it was even more pleasing for your humble narrator to call out this conspiracy ahead of cinematic time, way before the introduction of De Niro and way before those closing credits that rather soured the ending to an otherwise brilliantly engaging film.
Go see the credits for yourself. Itâ€™s all there for a one eye wishing to see.
But rather remarkably, arguably the greatest untold and unsaid conspiracy of all time is laid out within this gem of a film and should you be unaware of General Smedley Butler, his book â€œWar is a Racketâ€, the request placed upon him to lead a Fascist revolution in the United States of America exactly a century ago or his multitude of revealing quotes attributed to him later in life, treat yourself to a real conspiracy in a world absent of them according to our Overlords in charge of the all seeing eye.
Five paragraphs in and not one word about the film? Par for my cinematic course. There are never any major spoilers here. Just a human reaction to an artform I revere like no other. But returning to the film poster once again and itâ€™s a veritable whoâ€™s who and ensemble collection of character actors and actresses of our generation, all of whom produce intriguing, spirited and fiercely individual performances. In poster order we have Margot Robbie playing arguably a dual character if not definitely a dual personality as she flits from secretive war nurse to artist and much more in league with the love of her life, World War I veteran and now New York lawyer in the guise of John David Washington. Chris Rock is an awkwardly outspoken World War I veteran too and best friends with Washington whilst back in a New York of 1933 and fifteen years since the end of the Great War, we find Anya Taylor-Joy as a rather prissy and controlling wife of Rami Malek whilst Zoe Saldana excels as a medical examiner.
Pleasingly as well as perhaps unfairly, I saw the Mike Myers character of a British spy stepping right out of the Quentin Tarantino character created for him in 2009â€™s Inglourious Basterds and the screen time he shares with Michael Shannonâ€™s American spy is a bizarre joy. Timothy Olyphant is a hitman. Andrea Riseborough a socially climbing and grasping estranged wife. Taylor Swift hangs up the singing microphone for a small cameo role and Matthias Schoenaerts and Alessandro Nivola complete the poster roll of acting talent as two ridiculously cartoonish bungling New York detectives.
Which just leaves your star of a conspiratorial show:
â€œBert Berendsenâ€ (Christian Bale) World War I veteran and now ostensibly a fringe outsider doctor and medical practitioner, Berendsen has seen the devastation of war and the human casualties he now tries in vain to treat. The carnage of human war is writ large on the returning veterans unable to stop shaking from what was termed then as â€œShell Shockâ€ but is now flowered and mired in the newspeak language of â€œPost Traumatic Stress Disorderâ€, but Berendsen is also somewhat of an expert in the art of facial and body disfigurement having lost and left an eye in France at the very end of the war. Forming a â€œpactâ€ with the nurse who saved him and nursed him back to health (Margot Robbie as â€œValerie Vozeâ€) and his best friend and also recovering veteran (John David Washington as â€œHarold Woodmanâ€), Berendsen breaks the pact to return to his medical calling in New York and the estranged wife from an estranged family who distrust him enormously.
As ever, Christian Bale is wonderful in a central role arguably only he or Sam Rockwell could truly play and pull off with such aplomb. Often framed with a querying and quizzical head tilt to the side and always with long, lingering shots on a character trying desperately to piece together the puzzle before him, David O Russell deserves enormous credit for writing such a character as well as guiding and directing him into life in league with Bale.
â€œA lot of this really happenedâ€, so proclaims the very first frame of the film before we journey backward and forward, from 1930â€™s New York to France in 1918 and back again, as a tapestry is slowly woven around a huge cast of characters embroiled or otherwise in the greatest untold (and dare not spoken about) conspiracy of all time. Thereâ€™s an arguable heroâ€™s tale component to the story alongside the conspiracy but with heavy emphasis on the returning veterans Iâ€™m hoping the deliberately shocking human aftermath of war resonates deeply with everyone.
Thereâ€™s a â€œCommittee of 5â€ and â€œThe Great Nation Societyâ€ and with a bending of the truth and some plot contrivances combining with a stellar cast, I rather enjoyed Amsterdam and recommend it to you.
Postscript
I first read about this Fascist coup to topple a sitting USA President to install a military dictatorship in the late 1990â€™s so itâ€™s only taken a quarter of a century since then to arrive on the big cinema screen. I still havenâ€™t seen or read any reviews of the film but Iâ€™d wager it gets panned. Big time!
Iâ€™d also wager than no-one of any mainstream substance brings up the conspiracy despite itâ€™s centennial anniversary and the implications this may have had for the world at large.
But then again, conspiracies donâ€™t exist, do they?
Silly me.
Thanks for reading. Just for larks as always, and always a human reaction rather than spoilers galore. My three most recently published film articles are linked below or thereâ€™s well over 100 blog articles (with 300+ individual film reviews) within my archives from which to choose:
medium.com
medium.com
medium.com

Title: A Canadianâ€™s guide to moving to Amsterdam on the Working Holiday Visa (aka, with no job)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
20
Listen
Share
*** Since the time of this writing, the laws around the Working Holiday Visa have changed. On October 1, 2018 the Dutch government decided to start cracking down on the types of work you can do with this visa, limiting it to incidental work (nothing full-time). This means that in order to move here and start working, you will unfortunately have to find a job that will sponsor a highly-skilled migrant visa. ***
A little bit of background
To give this post some context, I want to start with sharing some background on me and my story of moving to the Netherlands on the working holiday visa. My name is Dave, and Iâ€™m a 24 year old Canadian (or Canadese, according to my Dutch residency card) who moved from Toronto to Amsterdam in September, 2017 with my girlfriend Madi (also Canadese). Prior to moving, we were both living in Toronto and working in our first post-grad jobs. I was in sales at a software startup, and Madi was working in retail buying at the Hudsonâ€™s Bay Company.
Although we were really enjoying our lives in Toronto, we always shared the dream of living and working abroad â€˜at some pointâ€™. What I started to realise as our time in Toronto progressed was that finding this â€˜pointâ€™ was inevitably going to become more challenging. When would we both be at the same point in our careers where we would be comfortable with dropping everything and just leaving? Next thing you know, itâ€™s 2, 3, 5 years later and all of your friends are getting married, buying houses etc. and the idea of moving just becomes too daunting. Life happens.
Luckily, the â€˜pointâ€™ presented itself to Madi and I in spring of 2017. My company had just been acquired by a large tech company based in San Francisco, and many key members of the team were moving down to the US in the process (myself not includedâ€¦damn Trump). Madi was already in between jobs at the time, so we decided that this was our chance. We decided we were moving. We didnâ€™t know where at that point, but weâ€™re not the type to overthink decisions when they feel right. So despite having little semblance of a plan and strategy, I gave my notice at work the next day.
Why I wanted to write this
During the months leading up to our move we spoke with a handful of fellow Canadians who had moved to Amsterdam in the past, but the conversations were always more focused on living in Amsterdam rather than practical tips for moving. This was because most of the people we spoke with had moved for jobs (aka they were sponsored on a highly skilled visa), so a lot of the immigration admin was taken care of by their respective companies and they were landing in a fairly comfortable position.
We are on the more adventurous/reckless side so we decided to quit our respective jobs in Toronto and take a leap of faith. Maybe weâ€™re just lazy and didnâ€™t do enough digging (actually, highly likely), but we found it disappointing that there was no â€˜one stop shopâ€™ post where we could find all of the common pitfalls to avoid. We vowed that once we had made our move and semi-settled we would document all of our mistakes on the world wide web in the hopes of saving someone else a bit of stress or a few bucks.
So, to be clear, this post is intended as a mini survival guide to help folks who are moving to the Netherlands without a job and taking advantage of the working holiday visa (although certain advice will be universal). We are also Canadian, so some of the immigration content is specific to that context.
These are the main mistakes that we made in the process. If you are in a similar situation to us and are planning on moving to Amsterdam, my hope is that you can avoid making the same ones.
TL;DR
Make them well in advance of your move!!! Ideally, do this before you book your flight to come here so that you can hit the ground running. You need two appointments:
Visa â€” this appointment is with the IND. It can be at any IND office in the Netherlands, so if you are on the phone with someone and they are saying thereâ€™s nothing in Amsterdam, ask them to check other cities. We ended up going out to Den Hague for ours (after a week of calling every day to check for cancellations) because we could get in about a month ahead of our scheduled appointment in Amsterdam.
Registration â€” the Dutch government likes to keep tabs on you, so before you can get a job and earn any money you need to register and get your BSN (of course it stands for Burger Service Number, welcome to Holland). You must schedule your registration appointment with the city that you plan on living in, so for this one youâ€™re limited to a certain number of offices. If youâ€™re moving with a job sponsorship, thereâ€™s a special office for you that Iâ€™m sure is efficient and lovely. If youâ€™re a pleb like us, you will need to book your appointment at one of the Amsterdam city offices (see the list, here).
What we didâ€¦.
Rather than dedicating some time and effort to visa research like any rational person would, Madi and I lollygagged around for the summer after quitting our jobs. We knew there were appointments, but we very naively assumed we could book them within two weeks of our flight. Our flight was September 6 and when I called for a registration appointment the earliest they had was October 18â€¦
Get immigration documents organised ASAP
Start the process of legalising your birth certificate right now. For your registration appointment, you need a legalised birth certificate. This means that you have to physically send it to your federal government, they give it a thumbs up and a stamp, then you physically send it to the Dutch Embassy, and they also give it a thumbs up and a stamp. Fun process, right? You might even have to get a new birth certificate before starting the stamping process, but double check that for your case. More about this here.
What I didâ€¦.
When I finally got around to serious research regarding Dutch immigration (two weeks before our flight), I figured out that we needed to do this. It was one of many, â€˜Oh fuckâ€™ moments in my research phase. We ended up having to get special birth certificates issued for this purpose, and express ship them to a service in Ottawa (capital of Canada) that specialised in this kind of thing. They physically took them to these offices in Ottawa for us and got the stamps and express shipped them back. This is who we used. Of course because you are in a tight spot and they know it they absolutely hose you on price, I think with shipping and everything we spent $500+ getting two pieces of paper stamped.
Have a place to stay
When you land in Amsterdam, youâ€™re going to want to have a place to stay set up. The last thing youâ€™re going to want to do after a long-haul flight is carry your bags around from door-to-door. Ideally, you can find a relatively cheap Airbnb or hostel room. Then once youâ€™re here you can explore the city a little bit and hit the Facebook groups hard looking for a longer term room or apartment rental in a good neighborhood.
What I didâ€¦..
In this case, we totally lucked out, and it probably saved out entire move from turning into a complete flop. About a month before we moved Madi and I were introduced to a couple at a summer BBQ who had lived in Amsterdam for 25+ years and knew a ton of people here. They then connected us with a couple who happened to have an empty garden house that they offered for us to stay in when we arrived. Looking back, I wonder what we would have done if this intro didnâ€™t surface. It was another one of those really important things that we were taking the â€˜ignorance is blissâ€™ approach to. Oh well, sometimes things just work out!
Start looking for jobs
The Dutch hire slow because itâ€™s way harder to fire people here than in North America. Itâ€™s not uncommon to go through 3â€“5 interviews before receiving an offer, which takes a long time if youâ€™re doing 1 interview per week. So itâ€™s important to start conversations early and set yourself up for success when you move.
Set up a few Amsterdam job alerts for the type of role you will be looking for when you land. If you have a good idea of what you will be looking for, I would try to sort that out and get a focus before moving.
I think the best place to start is LinkedIn, and you could add in Angelist if youâ€™re looking for a role at a startup. Make sure your resume is up to date* and start proactively applying or direct messaging people at companies you find interesting and get a conversation started. You will probably have a hard time getting to a job offer from abroad, but at least you can get some coffee chats lined up for when you arrive.
* Make sure your location is Amsterdam, otherwise people might be confused as to why youâ€™re applying. The Dutch also include their DOB/age in the info section.
Shamelessly ask for connections
Leverage your network to source some connections. We found that when people found out we were making such a radical move they really went the extra mile to introduce us to anyone they knew in Amsterdam. Some of them were super random, but you never know whoâ€™s going to know someone who knows someone that has an awesome place theyâ€™re renting out for super cheapâ€¦
TL;DR
Get a bike
Do this your first or second day in Amsterdam. As you will see, itâ€™s the way people get everywhere here. Once you have a bike, the city totally opens up and no place is more than 15â€“20 minutes away. Bikes also get stolen like crazy here, so I would advise getting a fairly cheap second hand one to start. You will see a TON of options if you put â€˜bike shopsâ€™ into Google Maps, or you can try the Waterlooplein flea market (more here). I got mine there and paid 90 euro with two locks included. Swapfiets is another great bike membership service that is totally hassle-free, which Madi joined after her first bike got stolen.
Get a prepaid SIM
Another day one task. Connectivity is super key; youâ€™re going to need plenty of Google Maps to navigate this semi-circle city. Pop into any Vodafone or Tele2 store and grab a prepaid sim card. You can get them pretty cheap, I think we had 3 GB of data and 30 minutes of calling for 20 euro per month.
Youâ€™ll need to keep renewing your prepaid for at least 3 months because of a funny rule. To prevent fraud, phone companies here donâ€™t let you set up an auto-renew phone plan until you have had a Dutch bank account for at least 3 months. So that means you need to a) get your BSN, b) open a bank account, and c) wait 3 months from that day to get a real phone plan. Oh, the Dutch and their systemsâ€¦
Make Chrome your default browser
While we are on the note of phones, I would highly recommend setting Chrome as your default web browser on your computer and mobile. Chrome will auto-translate Dutch sites for you, which is really helpful when youâ€™re exploring and trying to find business hours etc. If itâ€™s not auto-translating, you should be able to toggle that feature on in settings.
Hustle for a job
Once you are boots on the ground itâ€™s time to start networking pretty aggressively. I would recommend dedicating a few hours a day to putting in job applications and continuing to message people and set up conversations.
In addition, you can now start hitting up networking events and making in-person intros. There are quite a few on the Meetup app, which is pretty popular here. You can also check the websites for the coworking spaces* in town to see what they have going on.
*TQ, Impact Hub and WeWork are great places to start looking.
I personally went the more traditional route as I find networking events pretty painful. I focused on applying/messaging on LinkedIn and the intros I had received from friends, former colleagues etc. I ended up getting my current job from a cold email I had sent before moving. It took a while to materialize (about 3 months), but 5 interviews later I got an offer!
Get a bank account (I recommend ING)
A lot of grocery stores and certain checkout lines donâ€™t take cash, so itâ€™s important to set up a bank account quickly for convenience. NOTE: You must have already done your immigration appointments and have your BSN to open up an account.
Dutch service is terrible in general, but I was pretty shocked when we went to set up bank accounts here. We went into three ABN AMRO branches and they all told us we needed to book an appointment for one or two weeks later. They were literally pushing our business away.
The first ING we walked into (located here), we went right up to the counter and opened up two accounts within 15 minutes. Now, that was probably partly because they were experiencing a lull in the day, but I find everything about ING more pleasant. Their website is in Dutch, but they have a great app in English. We havenâ€™t had any trouble with them so far.
Weâ€™re creeping up on the 5 month mark in Amsterdam now. Overall, weâ€™re loving the city. There are still moments where Iâ€™m biking around and I have to remind myself that we actually live here now. The architecture and people are so unique and quintessentially European that it can feel quite surreal.
We scored an awesome 3-month rental that we found on this Facebook group. January 2018 marks our final month in this current rental, and we are moving into another 3-month rental (a houseboat!!!) that we found on the Facebook marketplace. Facebook is a great place to look for rentals to avoid paying fees, but you really have to be on it and persistent to beat out the competition. After this next rental, we are hoping to settle into a longer-term place in the Oud-West area.
I am 2 months in to my job here at a local startup and really enjoying it, and Madi is in some really promising conversations with a few creative agencies here. She was offered a job around the same time that I got mine, but decided to hold out for something that felt like a better fit.
Now weâ€™ve transitioned into the phase where weâ€™re settling into a routine, trying to make new friends, and planning our next weekend trip around Europe ;)
Weâ€™ve just crossed the year mark in the Netherlands, and this post is now the first thing on Google when you search â€˜Canadian moving to Amsterdamâ€™. The internetâ€™s pretty cool.
Weâ€™re settling in for our second winter here, currently in a long term apartment in the Westerpark area. Weâ€™re both working full time in central Amsterdam, and have agreed that we probably have one of the most picturesque commutes in the world. Luckily, my work has sponsored me on the highly skilled visa (and Madi as a registered partner) so weâ€™re in the clear deportation-wise. One thing that has come up a few times from people reaching out about this article is the ability to work for the same company beyond 12 weeks on the working holiday program. In my case, I had no issue with this, but I have heard of a few people running into some trouble. My advice would be to make sure that the companies youâ€™re talking to are cool with bringing you on with that visa and there wonâ€™t be any surprises down the line. You should also make sure to discuss the eventual move to the highly skilled visa.
If you have any further questions about moving to the Netherlands (from Canada), or you just want someone to grab a beer with once youâ€™re here, please respond to this article in the comments!
--
--

Title: An American in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I have never seriously considered the expat life: Iâ€™m too fond of deep-fried foods and the convenience of driving to supermarkets that sell everything I need. But after spending four days in Amsterdam, I may have to reconsider my attachment to American soil. Amsterdam is without a doubt the most beautiful city Iâ€™ve ever seen â€” I think itâ€™s even more picturesque than Paris. Almost every street is divided by a canal dotted with houseboats, and the brightly colored buildings with tall windows lean gracefully over the streets and canals. Bridges are sprinkled with flower boxes, and the scent of flowers, food, and other herbs wafts into the streets.
I stayed about 30 minutes outside of the city at Lucky Lake Hostel on Lake Vinkeveen. Lucky Lake is more than just a hostel: it is a community, where travelers from all over the world eat breakfast together in a converted bus, kayak the lake together, or unwind at night together in the lounge. Painted camper trailers, small cabins, tents, and hammocks form a ring around the property, with a block of gender-neutral showers and toilets (those absurdly progressive Dutch!) in the center, campground-style. Staff members or guests cook big dinners every night in the outdoor kitchen, and anyone can chip in for a share of the food. Guests and staff actually hang out in the lounge at night to play cards or the guitar, creating a sense of community that many hostels advertise but very few actually deliver. It was truly the experience of a lifetime.
The lake was a three-minute walk from my camper door. On my first day, I joined a couple of friends I made on the shuttle and rented kayaks for â‚¬3/hour to explore the waters. We paddled our way through a maze of canals and tiny houses with tinier boats until we reached the lake. The water was so clear you could almost see the bottom, and we saw more sailboats and kayaks than motorboats.
Later that day, I decided to take the hostel shuttle into the city to walk around and see what I could discover. I found that the Dutch way of life is perhaps the most relaxed in the world: they grow tulips and marijuana, ride bicycles, and eat fresh cheese and chocolate-covered waffles. All the people I met were very laid-back and pleasant, even more so than the Belgians. So thatâ€™s why the Dutch are consistently recognized as the happiest people in the world!
Amsterdam is truly a city of bicycles. It has more bicycles than people and more bike lanes than streets. Itâ€™s very pleasant to hear the tinkle of thousands of bells and to see so many people cycling their way through the city (it must be the Dutch secret to staying fit despite eating lots of waffles). Pro tip: donâ€™t walk in the bike lanes! I was crossing a bike lane when I saw this really cool Dutch bookstore out of the corner of my eye. I decided midway across the street to check it out and changed direction, only to collide into a passing bicycle. My phone flew out of my hands across the street, and my body scraped its way along the cobblestones until I ended up on my side. The cyclist, who was only a few years older than I am, had fallen off his bike, and he rushed over to help me up. He very kindly checked me for any injuries and even recommended the bookstore when he heard what had distracted me. I guess Dutch amicability knows no bounds.
My friends know that I am somewhat of a crazy cat lady, and Amsterdam definitely provided the feline interaction Iâ€™ve missed on my travels. I visited De Poezenboot (â€œThe Catboatâ€), a floating cat sanctuary on one of Amsterdamâ€™s canals. The lovely houseboat is home to dozens of stray cats who have learned to love living on the water. For someone like me who misses her own cats dearly, itâ€™s positively sublime to visit a place where I can play with friendly cats for as long as I like. Later, I toured KattenKabinet, a museum specializing in artwork featuring cats. They have paintings by artists such as Rembrandt and Manet, as well as sculptures and posters by less famous artists. They even have a couple of real cats hanging around the museum for artistic inspiration!
Normally I would save my culinary experiences for a food post, but I have to rave about the food in Amsterdam. My diet consisted mostly of cheese and waffles: needless to say, I was well-satisfied. There is a cheese shop selling fresh local cheese on almost every corner in Amsterdam, and the best part is that they all offer free samples! I wandered from shop to shop, trying slices of every cheese and every fig spread offered. I literally made a meal out of free cheese samples.
The Dutch are famed for their stroopwafels, which are thin waffles cemented together by caramel syrup. They sound delicious, and Iâ€™m a little ashamed to say that I never tried one. My sweet-tooth hopelessly indulged in the perhaps less-authentic but more delectable chocolate-covered waffles.
Oh. My. God. I may never be able to eat at Waffle House again after feasting on these things. I ate one every day: chocolate-covered waffles, white chocolate-covered waffles, caramel-covered waffles. So many waffles, and so much tastebud explosion. They were usually topped with yummy things like marshmallows, butterscotch chips, or Oreos, too.
Whether you like amazing food, beautiful rural countryside, or a charming and vibrant city with flowers everywhere, Amsterdam will take your breath away. It is easily my favorite city so far. Weâ€™ll see if it can be surpassed by my next stop â€” Berlin!
--

Today is the beginning of my month-long, Amazing Amsterdam Adventure.
I will be on my own this month, and I have decided to pretend I am a tourist who managed to find a beautiful apartment in Amsterdam for a month.
The first day of my fakecation began appropriately with transportation challenges. I helped my daughter and family get to the train station, and it was a bit more challenging than anticipated to get all those bikes and the dog across town to Central station, never mind onto a train.
I left them outside and then got very lost on my way home â€” at one point, my GPS tried to send me into the canal. Fortunately, I made it to the apartment. Now, after a hard day of traveling, I am beginning this adventure.
I hope you join me.
You can read more about my plans in the piece below.

Title: My Amsterdam Trip
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam had been in my dreams for a long, long time. The trip was something I started planning and preparing for months before it actually happened. Last week, I finally visited the city, and it took my breath away.
Getting to Amsterdam from the Schiphol airport (AMS) is fast and effortless: you can ride a bus (â‚¬6 and 15 minutes to the Amstelveen bus station) or a train (â‚¬4.30 and 20 mins to Amsterdam Centraal), or take an Uber (â‚¬20â€“25 and roughly 15 minutes).
The place I lived at is located not in Amsterdam itself, but in the suburban town of Amstelveen. The moment I got off the bus, I was astonished by the quiet and peaceful neighborhoods of Amstelveen. As I was going to find out later, the whole town is just like that: filled with two- to three-story houses, divided by narrow streets, and with bike lanes on every single street.
I arrived on October 31st, which gave me a chance to see how Amstelveeners celebrate Halloween (if they even do). What I saw gave me a sense of community in Amstelveen: people dress up their houses with fake spider webs, carve pumpkins, and place baskets with candies outside so that anyone (primarily kids) can have them whenever they want.
If goes without saying that local grocery stores had bunch of Halloween food, like these â€œpumpkinâ€ profiteroles.
Another thing that indicated strong community in Amstelveen was the leisure center (called Randwijck Markt) which doubles as a coworking area in the daytime and a club in the evening, where residents gather to share stories, sing, and discuss town matters. A nice lady who works there invited me to see whatâ€™s inside and have a cup of coffee, but I had things to do, so I politely declined the invitation.
Moving on to Amsterdam itself, the first time I saw the city was through the subway trainâ€™s window. Train 51 can take you from the suburban town of Amstelveen to Amsterdam Centraal (Central Station) in about 20 minutes. You see, Amsterdam is not a big city, compared to Rome or Paris.
As you approach the downtown, you first travel through business districts with a lot of office buildings that have names of well-known companies sparkling on their roofs. I havenâ€™t been to those districts, so itâ€™s hard to tell what it feels like to work in Amsterdam.
The city core looks and feels just like in the photos Iâ€™d seen on the web before the trip.
Amsterdam Centraal is the starting point for many Amsterdam visitors.
Like Venice, Amsterdam is divided by countless canals. Unlike Venice, those canals donâ€™t show up in random places-thereâ€™s certain logic: just compare the map of Amsterdam with the one of Venice.
Dull and rainy days are a usual thing for the city.
Amsterdamâ€™s architectural style appeals to me.
The city is absolutely full of bike riders. Theyâ€™re everywhere, and sometimes it gets pretty dangerous, especially if youâ€™re not used to them sneaking all around.
If I were asked to name a city that offers the best selection of food, Iâ€™d undoubtedly name Amsterdam. Compared to all the places Iâ€™ve visited over the past couple of years, Amsterdam gives you the biggest choice of different styles and cuisines. From traditional burgers-and-fries fast food to pizza to Turkish doner to spiciest Asian dishes-Amsterdamâ€™s got you covered.
Amsterdam houses many museums and other points of interest: from the Rijksmuseum to the Anne Frank Huis to the Torture Museum to the Museum of Prostitution.
Museumplein (Museum square) is located between three museums: the Rijksmuseum, Van Gogh Museum, and Stedelijk Museum.
Nightlife in Amsterdam is as various as the cityâ€™s food. The infamous Red-light district (De Wallen) houses countless bars, clubs, and brothels (although the latter looked like a joke).
Amsterdamâ€™s Vondelpark is one of the largest and best-known parks in the city. Itâ€™s a classic public park, as seen in most other cities Iâ€™ve been to. And yes, it has bike riders everywhere.
Street art is not rare to see, even in remote neighborhoods.
And in the evening, the city appears in a whole new light (literally).
Amsterdam showed itself to be a comfortable city for living, with plenty of opportunities for leisure and entertainment, and various work options (at least if you work in IT). If I had to choose between living in the city of Amsterdam and the suburbs, Iâ€™d probably opt for the latter for its quiet streets (once again, Iâ€™m not a fan of big cities).
Originally published at https://www.ym.dev on November 11, 2018.

Title: For Matt: thoughts on Amsterdam and Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I decided Iâ€™ll write a bit about the two cities I just visited during my French school break, partially because my British friend Matt (shoutout number three if heâ€™s counting!) encouraged me to keep writing about urban planning. So here I am.
Amsterdam is very interesting with its urban planning â€” some might call it â€œthe Meccaâ€ of urban planning because of how idealized it is by many urbanists. The most popular urbanism YouTube channel is Not Just Bikes, who moved to Amsterdam because of its reputation. But what is it really like?
I would imagine the tourist experience is much different from the habitant experience, even more than other cities. This is because while the prioritization of biking is helpful for locals, it can be difficult for a newbie to get a handle on. As you walk around the city, there can be so much to look out for as a pedestrian. Watch out for the bikes! Watch out for the tram! Watch out for the cars! Itâ€™s a complex ecosystem, and if you arenâ€™t paying attention, it can be easily overwhelming.
I did love the trams in Amsterdamâ€™s city center. Metros can go faster underground, but the experience of a tram above ground, where you can simply hop on and look out the window at the city, is delightful. However, I noticed that the trams and metro have a tap-in and tap-out system, which Iâ€™m not a fan of. In New York, you use your ticket to get on the subway, but you can get off wherever you want and you do not have to rescan the ticket. This is much easier for riders. My friends and I were sometimes scrambling to take out our ticket again and rescan to exit the train.
I get the sense that in Venice people actually use their canals for transportation, but in Amsterdam this does not seem to be the case. There are tours on the canal, but not a lot of regular folks using the canal to navigate the city. The bikes are everywhere. I donâ€™t know how I underestimated the number of bikes when I knew how bike-crazy Amsterdam is, but I underestimated them.
There are a few things I prefer about Paris, a place Iâ€™ve been to many times and am more familiar with. The sidewalks are wider in Paris than in Amsterdam. There are also a lot more terraces/outdoor seating in Paris, which is always welcoming and enjoyable for tourists and locals. Amsterdamâ€™s meager outdoor seating was always just a few tables outside, whereas in Paris there can be huge terraces with many tables for people to simply plop down and order a coffee. Relaxed cafÃ© culture in France is simply unbeatable. In comparison, with its smaller streets and a lack of outside seating, Amsterdam is always keeping things moving. Itâ€™s a faster pace but itâ€™s also exciting and keeps you turning down the next corner.
There are a few key neighborhoods in Amsterdam. The 9 Streets neighborhood is very beautiful with varying architecture and canal views, but much of the ground floor establishments were expensive shops. Again, I wouldâ€™ve liked an outdoor cafÃ© to sit and take things in rather than feeling like I couldnâ€™t linger. I found the Jordaan neighborhood to be more residential (I could literally look into rich peopleâ€™s houses because of their big, open windows) but just as architecturally interesting. The Red Light District felt the most touristy. Itâ€™s really just one street, a couple blocks long, with sex workers in the windows and â€œcinemas.â€ We walked up and down it once, but there wasnâ€™t much for our group to do there.
Athens has a few popular neighborhoods as well â€” Plaka and Psyri. I found Plaka to be touristy in some parts and desolate in others. Maybe this is just my experience. I really liked Psyri â€” I had multiple meals in that area and found something going on down every street. Cars in Athens are interesting â€” they attempt to go down any street they can fit in. I was sitting outside at a cafÃ© and a car squeezed through the small street less than two feet away from me. There is a lack of signaled crosswalks in Athens. Most of the time people just cross the street whenever possible through traffic. That is less than ideal.
But I would not say Athens isnâ€™t walkable. I walked all over the city center while I was there and only took the metro a few times to get to faraway locations. When I did take the metro, it was fairly reliable but not the cleanest. One thing I did like about the Athens metro was that they had signs showing which direction the escalators were going so that you could easily navigate where you needed to go to get out. I havenâ€™t seen that in a metro before, but it was helpful.
Athens is the furthest south Iâ€™ve been in Europe and the sunshine was welcome after months of rainy winter in France. One thing I noticed is all of the solar panels! Many apartment buildings had multiple solar panels at the top, maybe 6 feet long by 4 feet wide. In contrast, when I took the Eurostar train to Amsterdam, I noticed that Belgium and the Netherlands had a lot of wind turbines. Northern part of Europe, more wind, it makes sense.
This was a great trip with two cities I really wanted to see this year, so Iâ€™m proud of myself and feeling very fulfilled.
--
--
In grad school. Writing so that I can blab about my interdisciplinary interests: politics, philosophy, urban planning, travel, rural America, etc.

Title: Abroad in Amsterdam
Content:
In Amsterdam, the summer really is lovely (unlike NYC). The temperature hovers around high 60sâ€Šâ€”â€Šlow 80sâ€¦
In the past 2 weeks Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time at the airport. A little too much time if you ask my travelâ€¦
Iâ€™m not a fan of big national holidays. July 4th, New Years, Labor Dayâ€¦There is always a lot of hype to it and it never lives up to oneâ€™sâ€¦
Itâ€™s been 5 weeks and time has really flown! I started on this exciting project at work, I am starting to make friendsâ€¦
After three weeks, and a day after my NY lease expired, I can finally say that I have a home. Not just an apartment but a home. Theâ€¦

Title: Exploring Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
1
Share
A City of Surprises and Endless Possibilities.
No city compares to Amsterdamâ€™s diversity. Every time I visit, I discover something new that I never knew existed. Itâ€™s like joining an adventure each time, with surprises waiting around every corner.
And I love it.
This year, Iâ€™ve had the opportunity to visit Amsterdam two times, and each experience has been unique each time.
The first visit was with my family. We were a large group, which made it challenging to please everyone. So, my daughter and I quickly decided to return on our own. (So we did, a couple of weeks later).
During our first visit to Amsterdam, we decided to play tourists. And what better place is there than to visit The Royal Palace?
This palace is best known for being where the King and Queen of the Netherlands stand and wave to the people on various occasions.

Title: Urban Planning in Amsterdam
Content:
