Title: Visiting Amsterdam and Riding a Bike When You Havenâ€™t Ridden Since Childhood
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
(This story can also be found on my personal blog site www.eatbikeexplore.com)
Amsterdam is often known as the bicycle capital of the world. If you are an advocate of active transportation, there are some YouTubers and bloggers praising Amsterdam for their bike friendliness. BicycleDutch and NotJustBikes come to mind. However, if you are visiting Amsterdam and wanting to ride a bike but havenâ€™t since childhood, I can imagine it can be intimidating. I donâ€™t blame people from North America traveling to Amsterdam and being fearful of riding a bike. If you normally donâ€™t ride, itâ€™s a difficult adjustment. My guess is if you are visiting Amsterdam from North America, you MIGHT hop on a bike for an afternoon as a novelty, but then go back to what you are comfortable with. Most people from North America drive. And most people from other parts of the world probably do not have the bicycling culture like the Dutch or Danish. Itâ€™s like if youâ€™re not used to taking public transit in your home country, you might shy away from taking public transit when you travel. Youâ€™ll opt for the Hop On Hop Off buses, using ride share or joining a tour group. All are fine, but I would say you are missing out on a uniquely Dutch experience by not taking a bike to get you around townâ€¦and riding it as often as possible.
So what is it like riding a bike in Amsterdam? Here are some tips from my experience for visiting Amsterdam and riding a bike if you havenâ€™t ridden since childhood. If you are used to riding consistently as an adult, especially if your bike is your transportation, then you shouldnâ€™t have a problem riding in Amsterdam. The learning curve shouldnâ€™t be too steep.
Otherwise, you will probably be â€œthatâ€ tourist that doesnâ€™t know the rules of riding. Thereâ€™s plenty of websites that go more into detail on the rules of riding. Iâ€™m not going to get that detailed. Instead, I will touch on some basics of what it must feel like riding if you havenâ€™t ridden a bike since forever.
If you are â€œthatâ€ tourist and want to get on a bike, then here are some of my suggestions for â€œpeople who normally donâ€™t ride a bike but want to in Amsterdamâ€.
First, get away from the city center, especially if you are visiting during the summer months where tourism is at its peak. It can get packed with people on bikes, on foot, cars and tour buses. The center of the city also seems to have less separated bike paths, so youâ€™re riding close to other drivers. Thereâ€™s also vans parked in the bike lanes, so youâ€™ll need to navigate around them by safely moving around other riders and drivers. Plus, youâ€™ll want to be careful crossing the tram tracks as bicycle tires can get caught in it and you will fall.
Find a hotel, hostel, Airbnb, etc outside of the city center that also rents bikes. You donâ€™t have to go too far out but just far enough for you to practice. When I went there, I stayed near Vondel Park. My place rented bikes which was convenient and Vondel Park is a great place to practice riding around.
In the US (and I assume itâ€™s similar in other countries), I notice beginner riders tend to weave around a lot and often ride really slow. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with that, but if you want to ride on the bike paths in Amsterdam, youâ€™ll need to practice not weaving around so much and to ride faster. Basically, if you wouldnâ€™t drive your car weaving from lane to lane, then you shouldnâ€™t do that on a bike. Anyways, Vondel Park would be a good place to reintroduce yourself to the bike. Lots of people ride through here to get to their destination so youâ€™ll see lots of riders. But the paths are wide enough for the locals to go around you as youâ€™re starting off.
My biggest advice to those wanting to hop on a bike for the first time is donâ€™t just randomly stop in middle of a bike path because you saw this cool cafe or bar or some interesting mural. Please pull off to the side of the bike path so you donâ€™t block anybody or cause a crash. There is a 100% chance someone is riding right behind you. And just like driving, you donâ€™t just stop in the middle of the road because you saw something cool off to the side. So donâ€™t do that on a bike either.
My next advice is to use hand signals and turn your head to make sure itâ€™s clear before you decide to turn, stop or slow down. Watch how the locals use hand signals. But all you need to do is slightly bend your right arm outwards to show you are turning right and slightly bend your left arm outwards to show you are turning left.
Thereâ€™s no need to extend your entire arm out when you need to turn. By doing that, youâ€™ll most likely smack someone riding next to you. This of course goes back to turning your head so you know who is around you.
Once you get comfortable riding around in the park, you can move onto neighborhood streets and separated bike paths outside of the city center.
Amsterdam has lots of bicycle signals, so make sure you pay attention to the signals.
Intersections can also be tricky because youâ€™ll need to know when to yield and when not to yield. Pay attention to the â€œshark teethâ€ symbols on the ground.
The good thing about being on a bike is even if you are uncertain on what to do, everybody can still move around each other and usually not cause a crash. People can usually read your body language on a bike and youâ€™ll be able to do the same the more your ride.
Itâ€™s not like being in a car, where you are unable to see the person driving. In a car, you canâ€™t predict what the people next to you will do. But itâ€™s easier on a bike because you can see the entire person.
One thing I also noticed is that drivers and cyclists will look for any open space to squeeze in (which to me is a bit reminiscent of NYC). There were a couple of drivers that came rather close to me in the city center. I noticed two types of license plates in Amsterdam. The yellow and the blue plates. I had a close pass with a blue license plate driver. I later overheard those are the taxi and delivery drivers? So I guess it makes sense they are more aggressive (even though they shouldnâ€™t be)?
And you know that saying â€œpractice makes perfectâ€? The more you ride, the more youâ€™ll get the hang of how things are done. And riding a bike in Amsterdam is absolutely amazing! Itâ€™s just not something you can experience in the US. Bikes really provide the freedom that cars do not (despite car ads from the last 100 years proclaiming driving is freedom). You donâ€™t need a helmet when riding, so you truly can feel the â€œwind in your hairâ€.
And one final tips. Remember where you parked your bike. Take a photo or video of where you parked and the surrounding area. A lot of bikes look similar and they are often jammed together.
And once you get the hang of this, you can ride to grab coffee or a beer. Ride to a park or museum. Youâ€™ll soon discover how easy it is to navigate the city by bike. And how many more places you can see without having to pay for the tram, Uber or follow a guided tour. With a bike, you can have the freedom to explore local neighborhoods, cafes and restaurants that might not be in a guide book.
I canâ€™t wait to go back and ride again and I hope if youâ€™re reading this and planning a trip there, you will want to ride as much as possible while you are there.
--
--
Iâ€™m usually walking, biking or on public transit exploring locally and globally.

Content:

I idly watched tiny droplets of moisture licking at the planeâ€™s wings as cotton wool clouds and sparkling sunbeams made way for a sea of green and grey, followed by a seemingly-endless taxi along the runway. Almost as soon as Iâ€™d left the UK, I was in Amsterdam for a springtime mini break. The grey skies above did nothing to dull my spirit as I muddled through the train system and took a final, deep breath of city air. Thatâ€™s right. After a pretty hefty hiatus from Medium, Iâ€™m back â€” and accompanied by tales from a small European country known as The Netherlands in April 2025.
As I left the station, I was hit instantly with the lingering aroma of marijuana, coupled with street music and a relentless stream of bicycles. Weaving through tiny streets, the constant bang bang bang of my suitcase wheels on the cobbles grew more comforting than annoying. Finally, after a few wrong turns, I could see the sign for my hostel just up ahead.
I had a little time to kill and so resolved to head out on foot. I ended up down a major shopping street, but resisted the urge to pop into the large Primark. Scatteredâ€¦

Have you ever imagined immersing yourself in one of the worldâ€™s most dynamic and thrilling cities, all while advancing your career? This is the story of my remarkable journey.
As a young software engineer employed at a reputable multinational company in India, the opportunity to embark on a two-month onsite assignment in Amsterdam was nothing short of a dream come true. The mere thought of exploring Europe had always danced at the periphery of my aspirations, yet, as someone from India, such an adventure often felt distant and financially out of reach.
But I persevered, putting in the hard work and dedication necessary to secure this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Finally, the moment had arrived when I could set foot in Amsterdam, and I was filled with boundless gratitude for having reached this significant milestone. Now, let me share with you the captivating journey that unfolded, as I discovered the cityâ€™s perfect blend of work and play, and why it has become a place Iâ€™ll cherish forever.
One electrifying week before the grand adventure, I embarked on a whirlwind of preparations. With a fresh haircut and meticulous grooming, I was ready to step into the unknown. The day of departure finally dawned, and my parents joined me for a heartwarming farewell at the airport. The excitement in the air was palpable as I embarked on a journey I had been eagerly awaiting.
The flight seemed to stretch on, but the moment we touched down at Amsterdam Schiphol Airport, I was immediately captivated by the cityâ€™s breathtaking beauty. The sight was a feast for the senses, a stunning welcome to this new chapter in my life. My heart raced with anticipation as I hopped into a sleek Tesla taxi. The streets were teeming with high-end cars, and the buzz around Tesla was infectious. Riding in one was nothing short of a thrilling adventure, marking the exhilarating start of my Amsterdam odyssey.
I arrived at my home around 5 p.m., and it was already dark outside. I had never experienced this in India, where the sun sets much later. My friend and I were so excited to be in Amsterdam that we decided to make dinner and go to bed early so that we could wake up early the next morning and start exploring.
I was nervous on my first day at the office in Amsterdam. I had never been to the city before. But as soon as I walked in, I was greeted by warm smiles from my new colleagues and clients.
My Indian colleagues introduced me to everyone, including my Dutch clients. I was immediately struck by how friendly and welcoming everyone was. My client even asked me about my journey to Amsterdam and how I was settling in.
At lunchtime, I went out with my senior colleagues, we had a delicious meal together. We talked about everything from what we needed to settle in, to the Dutch culture, and some places to travel. I felt so comfortable and at ease.
By the end of the day, I had made a lot of new friends in the office and learned a lot about the company and the city. I was so grateful for the warm welcome I had received.
Through the days, I effortlessly adapted to the Amsterdam culture and people, and I also explored the cityâ€™s many attractions. I was captivated by Amsterdamâ€™s distinctive beauty. My personal experience revealed five compelling reasons why Amsterdam stands out as an exceptional destination for both work and leisure:
Canals that Captivate: Amsterdamâ€™s intricate network of canals is a sight to behold, earning it the nickname â€œVenice of the North.â€ The reflection of gabled houses in the still waters, along with charming bridges and tree-lined streets, creates a picturesque scene that is reminiscent of a fairytale. For example, the Prinsengracht Canal is home to many beautiful 17th-century houses, while the Keizersgracht Canal is known for its elegant mansions. The canals are also a great place to spot boats and people-watch.
Historical Charm: Amsterdamâ€™s well-preserved architecture stands as a testament to its rich history. As you stroll through the city, youâ€™ll encounter stunning 17th-century buildings, each with its own unique character and story, offering a glimpse into the cityâ€™s past. For example, the Anne Frank House is a poignant reminder of the cityâ€™s role in World War II, while the Royal Palace is a magnificent example of Dutch Baroque architecture. The cityâ€™s canals are also lined with historic buildings, such as the gabled houses of the Jordaan neighborhood.
Cultural Diversity: The city is a melting pot of cultures, and this diversity is reflected in its art, food, and people. From world-class museums like the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum to vibrant neighborhoods like De Pijp, thereâ€™s a cultural richness that adds to the cityâ€™s allure.
Laid-back atmosphere: Amsterdam has a relaxed and easy-going atmosphere. I appreciated the friendly demeanor of the locals, as it was quite common for strangers to exchange warm greetings with smiles. In all my travels to various countries, I had never witnessed such a welcoming attitude towards strangers.
Diverse workforce: Amsterdam has a diverse workforce, with people from all over the world living and working in the city. This diversity makes for a vibrant and exciting work environment.
Bicycle-Friendly Bliss: Amsterdamâ€™s flat terrain and extensive network of cycling lanes make it a cyclistâ€™s paradise. The sight of countless bicycles whizzing past historic sites, parks, and picturesque canals is not only beautiful, but it is also an embodiment of the cityâ€™s eco-friendly ethos. Conveniently, there are bicycle pumps attached to some bicycle areas for filling tires.
Amsterdam is a foodieâ€™s paradise, with a wide variety of restaurants and dishes to choose from, whether youâ€™re looking for a quick bite or a leisurely meal. I sampled some of the cityâ€™s most famous dishes, including:
Poffertjes: Small pancakes often served with powdered sugar, fruit, or syrup.Stroopwafels: Thin waffles filled with sweet syrup.Stamppot: Traditional Dutch mashed potatoes with vegetablesErwtensoep: Popular Dutch pea soup, also available in vegetarian versions.
My love for the delicious waffles was only surpassed by my visit to Zaanse Schans, Amsterdamâ€™s old town, where I sampled a variety of delectable cheeseses. I promise you, they were incredibly tasty!
My two months in Amsterdam were an unforgettable experience. I had the opportunity to work on a challenging project, meet new people from all over the world, and explore a beautiful and vibrant city. I also had the chance to travel to other parts of Europe, which was a dream come true.
Iâ€™m so grateful for the opportunity I had to live and work in Amsterdam. It was an experience that has changed me for the better. I made lifelong friends, learned new things, and created memories that will last a lifetime.
When it was time to leave, I was sad to say goodbye to my new friends and the city I had come to love. But I know that I will return one day. Amsterdam has a special place in my heart, and I canâ€™t wait to go back and explore more.
Vincent van Gogh once said, â€˜Amsterdam is a city of dreams, and I am a dreamer.â€™
I couldnâ€™t agree more. Amsterdam is a city that inspires creativity and imagination. Itâ€™s a city where anything is possible. If youâ€™re looking for a city that will challenge and inspire you, Amsterdam is the place for you.
I hope that this blog post has given you a glimpse into my experience in Amsterdam. If youâ€™re ever thinking about visiting this amazing city, I highly recommend it!

Title: Amsterdam Unfiltered: A Weekend of Unexpected Adventures
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The Dutch have the philosophy, â€˜If what you are doing is not harming anyone but you, then what is the problem?â€™
We got to Amsterdam on Thursday and checked into Clink Hostels, and right away it felt like we were walking onto a college campus. The lobby was live â€” people from all around the world were playing games, talking, listening to live music, and getting us ready for the weekend. We put down our bags and headed into town. Like other college students, our first stop was the Red Light District. As we walked along the canals, we were amazed at what we witnessed. We were not used to this in the United States. Having taken it all in, we stopped for some fries at a local diner and headed home for the night.
Friday morning, we ferried over the water for breakfast and sampled a stroopwafel â€” a famous thin waffle with caramel in the middle. They were so good we ended up buying the whole pack to take back home to the US. We strolled the streets a little more and got ready for our next adventure, a canal tour.
Imagine 24 of us crammed on a boat with an open bar â€” it was fun, to say the least. The vibe was great, we rode down the canal in great company. The music was loud, so we traded the risk of seasickness for dancing. It was worth it. The city itself became a background of ancient buildings and bridges, but the thing that defined the moment was the music. The way I see it is in this culture, you kind of just go with the flow. You never know what to expect, just like the music.
We grabbed dinner after the tour at Ciao Bella, a local pizza place that was ideal for the night ahead of us. We headed to Escape, one of the largest clubs in the city, and abruptly, we were immersed in Amsterdamâ€™s nightlife. We stood up front row to the DJ and took it all in. It was normal music that you would hear at a club, but something was different. The crowd was a lot more into it, and everybody was feeling the music. The DJ stood there leading the crowd, feeding off the crazy energy coming from them. I could finally see why Amsterdam was renowned as such a party city. Somewhere along the early morning, we ended up at a McDonaldâ€™s. And I have to say â€” Amsterdamâ€™s McDonaldâ€™s? Better than Barcelonaâ€™s. It did the trick before we finally crashed for the night.
Saturday, we woke up and discovered we had the day to ourselves. We walked around and ended up in Amsterdamâ€™s center. We took pictures of the national monument and learned about its history. After a few more hours of touring, we found a bar that caught our eye. The bartenders werenâ€™t regular bartenders â€” they were entertainers. They were singing along to every song at the top of their lungs. The first song that came on that I will never forget was â€œGetting Away with Itâ€ by James. And for some reason, it felt completely appropriate. Amsterdam is a city of challenging norms, living in the moment, and doing the unexpected. Inside this bar was the perfect atmosphere to witness the city in person.
The day turned into another night, and we were back in the district at the Red Light Bar, a staple hangout where we played pool and watched some Premier League soccer. People continued to pile in until finally, it was too packed. We bar-toured up the strip, each with its own interpretation of Amsterdamâ€™s style. Some blasted classic rock, while others played house music, but each one of them told a story.
By the end of the trip, we were ready to go. We realized that a weekend in Amsterdam was just right â€” no longer. The city was crazy and awesome at the same time. From the sound of a club to the ring of a bar song, to the energy on the canal, every sound in this city served a purpose. Overall, Amsterdam exceeded our expectations and gave us a weekend to remember.
If you enjoyed this adventure, make sure to follow me for more! Iâ€™ll be sharing another exciting destination next week, so stay tuned â€” you wonâ€™t want to miss it. Thanks for reading, and see you in the next blog!
--
--
Exploring the world through music while studying abroad in Barcelona. Sharing stories on how different cultures express themselves through sound.

Title: Best things to do in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
happy, unique, goofy
1 week (or forever if you can)
Wow! I honestly love Amsterdam so much! The people seem so at ease with life and It is a very liberal spiritual place. Everyone is very open minded and accepting of anyone.
Amsterdam is mainly Dutch people so a lot of the people are very tall and blond. Another thing to consider is prostitution, weed, and psychedelics such as truffles are legal despite this everyone seems incredibly responsible and people seem to keep a good balance of life in Amsterdam. It really is the happiest and most open minded place Iâ€™ve been to so far and thatâ€™s why it is my favorite place so far.
Right from Amsterdam Central you can take a free ferry that will take you to NDSM and it takes about 5â€“10 mins to get there and the Ferry comes constantly I honestly felt like I never had to wait for one. NDSM is a hip urban area with lots of cool graffiti and hip restaurants to check out. Not to mention the interesting places you can stay at like the Crane hotel oh and you can also bungee jump from it, if you decide to. The area also has lots of special events such a music festivals, flea markets, and movie nights. Its a great place to check out and Its not too crowded so itâ€™s nice getting away from all the people in the main area.
This may be one of my favorite museum trips that I have gone on so far. I really liked that it focused on one artist throughout, and I felt like I really got to see Van Goghâ€™s life and how it affected his art. I have to say I am a HUGE Van Gogh fan, I really love his brush strokes and his bright use of color. I felt like I got pulled into every single painting diving into each brush stroke and seeing the lines up close then pulling back to see the full picture that he created. I donâ€™t know how he did it but he made each scene look so serene and stylized.
I need to also mention the sensory room where each room you get the senses that Van Gogh was feeling throughout his life. I thought it was so creative because I truly felt like I was living and seeing the things that Van Gogh felt.
I mean you honestly canâ€™t go to Amsterdam without going to the Red Light District at least once. Walking through the red light district you canâ€™t take any photos. You basically see women in windows with red lights above them in their underwear standing or sitting, and they kind of look bored or like their busy looking at their phone. It was an interesting experience but one to definitely check out and experience once.
One of the most unforgettable experiences I have had so far, Aâ€™dam lookout is where you go on the top of one of the buildings and there are these 2 electric swings that basically swing you back and fourth for about 2 mins. It was seriously such a magical feeling I honestly felt like I was on top of the world and flying for a second. I will admit it was really scary because you are so high up and you look down and donâ€™t see anything right under you but it is one of the things that you canâ€™t really forget because you just feel so much.
The canal tour is so worth it, you basically just go down the canals throughout the city, it is so fun to see all the little boat houses right on the canals.
I personally really liked the Mocco museum because it had more urban graffiti artists such Banksy, icy & slot, Koons and Warhol. They also had a 3D installation room where you walk into a room in the style of Lichtenstein (which is the bright comic book style with bold colors and lines throughout). The museum is not that big but I kind of like that, your not overwhelmed by all of the art and you can engage in each and every one. Each piece had a strong statement about freedom and freedom of expression.
I checked out multiple psychedelic shops (there were many) and these 2 stood out the most to me.
Kokopelli was very informal and the staff really knew their stuff and loved to talk about it, they sold lots of other interesting things such as Brazilian herbs to help with lucid dreaming. Or seeds that you can grow and eat for different types of needs. They even had an area where you can sit and take your shrooms if you decide to buy it from them.
Alien Visitors s a fun small raver type of shop, with techno music playing and neon fluorescent items throughout the store. I ended up buying a really cute black shirt with some green neon print designs down the middle. It wasnâ€™t too crazy with the designs like how some raver shirts can get a little tacky when its overplayed and I really love the pattern on it.
--
--
My goal is to share my journey, experiences and designs with you. I try to bring in a unique perspective into everything I see.

Title: Hereâ€™s why I chose Amsterdam over Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Today marks five years since I moved from my country to Europe, gradually settling into the vibrant life of Amsterdam. This year is my second year in the Netherlands and five years in Europe overall. This milestone feels like the right moment to reflect on the journey so far. Iâ€™m grateful for the personal and professional growth along the way â€” itâ€™s been quite a journey. I first landed in Berlin, but soon after, COVID hit, and finding a job was a real challenge during that time. After gaining experience living in Berlin, I wanted to see if there was a better place before fully committing to Germany, so I decided to look for opportunities outside of Berlin. Eventually, I found a job in Amsterdam. As things slowly started to recover, the war began, adding another layer to the experience.
My connection with Berlin runs deep. Iâ€™ve had a long relationship with the city since my early 20s, when a few of my friends moved there from St. Petersburg and helped me explore Berlin from within. The city quickly became a familiar and vibrant part of my life, with friends and unforgettable experiences. I met my boyfriend just before moving there myself (now my husband) which made the transition even more meaningful. Berlin was more than just a place to live! :) It felt like a second home. Being there was a dream come true in a natural and seamless way.
Our move to Amsterdam was driven by curiosity and a sense of uncertainty about our future in Germany. It takes a lot of effort to fully integrate there and to acknowledge the challenges of living in Germany. Here in the Netherlands, Iâ€™ve found a country that values directness, innovation, out-of-the-box thinking, and problem-solving â€” a motivating environment that has enabled me to grow both professionally and personally.
Sometimes, I feel like a character in Atlas Shrugged, navigating a landscape that mirrors Germany today â€” a system entangled in endless layers of rules, bureaucracy, reluctance to change, and a fear of moving forward that places increasing demands on companies. Germany feels like a perfect analogy to the world described in the book, where innovation is stifled by rigid structures and a lack of forward thinking. In contrast, the Netherlands represents a refreshing example of how things should operate, with efficiency, innovation, and a practical approach to problem-solving that brings real results.
Having spent years in the digital industry, focusing on process optimization, self-service, and enhancing customer experience, Iâ€™ve developed a unique perspective on understanding challenges and identifying opportunities. The Dutch approach to digital transformation, with its emphasis on innovation and efficient governance, aligns closely with my values in creating effective systems and customer-centric solutions. This kind of forward-thinking approach isnâ€™t something I found at a national level in Germany. I know many entrepreneurial people working hard to drive change, but Germany requires significant structural shifts to address the crises ahead. Neglecting change and innovation will make it increasingly difficult to overcome these challenges.
My journey began in Berlin, where I experienced Germanyâ€™s intense focus on rules, processes, and seemingly endless layers of bureaucracy. In Amsterdam, I discovered a dynamic, flexible mindset, where people think outside the box â€” and, most importantly, where people, companies, and even bureaucracies focus on solving problems, not creating more. Both countries have their strengths, yet the Netherlandsâ€™ agility and commitment to achieving real outcomes â€” not just outputs â€” have made me fall in love with the country and see hope for Europeâ€™s future.
As I look back on these five years, Iâ€™m excited about what lies ahead. Amsterdam has become more than just a place to live! Itâ€™s a community that drives my curiosity and keeps me moving forward. I look forward to continuing this journey, bringing fresh perspectives to the digital industry, and helping to solve the challenges that await us all in Europe.

Content:

We were talking the other day about how untypical it has been to revisit a country youâ€™ve had the chance to travel before. I mean, there are a few exceptions (for work Maeghan would travel to certain cities each year for conferences) but to visit a city you went to when you were in your 20s and then revisit 7 years later is a pretty cool experience.
Maeghan came to the Netherlands during college and has family scattered across the small country. She remembers having little money and being nervous to travel on her own without some sort of direction. But this time around, weâ€™ve been lucky to make friends while traveling, had the time to mature as travellers and that makes visiting the same places in a totally different mindset is pretty awesome.
After some time in Amersfoort, we visited Utrecht and Amsterdam and got to indulge in some super fun stuff.
Oh, we also learned a lot about the Netherlands. 1) Maeghan was brought up calling it Holland. Turns out, there is an interesting reason why (Watch the CPG grey video to explain) 2) This country is tiny and so easy to get around in comparison to most of the other places weâ€™ve visited 3) Everything and everyone is awesome here. So you should visit â¤
See more on our website www.alittledetour.cağŸŒâœˆï¸ğŸ‘«
We celebrated Maeghanâ€™s birthday in Amersfoort and she was totally spoiled. After the early gift of Balloon rides in Cappadocia, we got to tour around where her grandparents lived and grew up and had a awesome dinner at a jazz pub near by with family.
So these are house boats. People buy the spot on the water and build a house that is anchored there. We were kind of mind blown, some of these house boats are super modern!
We had a jam-pack planned Saturday in Amsterdam. It started with Maeghan trying to be cool like all the young kids and get her ear pierced (she felt very hardcore), then strolling through some markets and craft beer stores as it was Zwanze Day (A special beer event from one of Oliâ€™s favorite breweries) until we reached our final destination at a concert, The Pineapple Thief, that Oli had been looking forward to for weeks!
We made some Canadian friends from Newfoundland dat the bar and talked all about living and traveling abroad, and how crazy of a place Amsterdam can be!
The demographic of attendees was older, so there was no pushing, no garbage on the floor, lots of space and really nice people all around! What a way to enjoy a concert! :P
The next day, Banksy had one of his famous pieces auctioned off and to everyoneâ€™s surprise, he had it self- shred upon purchase. So Oli felt very relevant after learning all about Banksy.

Hoy! The capital of the Netherlands holds a special place in my heart. Never have I liked a big city as much as Amsterdam. It booms with people from all over the world, the standard of living is exquisite, and there are so many bike lanes! Find yourself wandering around Amsterdam, taking in the canals, the houses among them, the marvelous new architecture, and experiencing this small but beautiful country.
Get yourself the real deal: A fresh Stroopwafel on a market. This is so good; I cannot even describe it. Stroopwafels are a traditional dutch pastry; a doughball with spices and cinnamon gets baked into the Wafel. The thought of the smell when it comes out waters my mouth! It then gets cut open, and a thick sirup, the Stroop, is put onto it, and tadaa, you have yourself a heavenly tasting dessert. Orâ€¦

Title: An American in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I have never seriously considered the expat life: Iâ€™m too fond of deep-fried foods and the convenience of driving to supermarkets that sell everything I need. But after spending four days in Amsterdam, I may have to reconsider my attachment to American soil. Amsterdam is without a doubt the most beautiful city Iâ€™ve ever seen â€” I think itâ€™s even more picturesque than Paris. Almost every street is divided by a canal dotted with houseboats, and the brightly colored buildings with tall windows lean gracefully over the streets and canals. Bridges are sprinkled with flower boxes, and the scent of flowers, food, and other herbs wafts into the streets.
I stayed about 30 minutes outside of the city at Lucky Lake Hostel on Lake Vinkeveen. Lucky Lake is more than just a hostel: it is a community, where travelers from all over the world eat breakfast together in a converted bus, kayak the lake together, or unwind at night together in the lounge. Painted camper trailers, small cabins, tents, and hammocks form a ring around the property, with a block of gender-neutral showers and toilets (those absurdly progressive Dutch!) in the center, campground-style. Staff members or guests cook big dinners every night in the outdoor kitchen, and anyone can chip in for a share of the food. Guests and staff actually hang out in the lounge at night to play cards or the guitar, creating a sense of community that many hostels advertise but very few actually deliver. It was truly the experience of a lifetime.
The lake was a three-minute walk from my camper door. On my first day, I joined a couple of friends I made on the shuttle and rented kayaks for â‚¬3/hour to explore the waters. We paddled our way through a maze of canals and tiny houses with tinier boats until we reached the lake. The water was so clear you could almost see the bottom, and we saw more sailboats and kayaks than motorboats.
Later that day, I decided to take the hostel shuttle into the city to walk around and see what I could discover. I found that the Dutch way of life is perhaps the most relaxed in the world: they grow tulips and marijuana, ride bicycles, and eat fresh cheese and chocolate-covered waffles. All the people I met were very laid-back and pleasant, even more so than the Belgians. So thatâ€™s why the Dutch are consistently recognized as the happiest people in the world!
Amsterdam is truly a city of bicycles. It has more bicycles than people and more bike lanes than streets. Itâ€™s very pleasant to hear the tinkle of thousands of bells and to see so many people cycling their way through the city (it must be the Dutch secret to staying fit despite eating lots of waffles). Pro tip: donâ€™t walk in the bike lanes! I was crossing a bike lane when I saw this really cool Dutch bookstore out of the corner of my eye. I decided midway across the street to check it out and changed direction, only to collide into a passing bicycle. My phone flew out of my hands across the street, and my body scraped its way along the cobblestones until I ended up on my side. The cyclist, who was only a few years older than I am, had fallen off his bike, and he rushed over to help me up. He very kindly checked me for any injuries and even recommended the bookstore when he heard what had distracted me. I guess Dutch amicability knows no bounds.
My friends know that I am somewhat of a crazy cat lady, and Amsterdam definitely provided the feline interaction Iâ€™ve missed on my travels. I visited De Poezenboot (â€œThe Catboatâ€), a floating cat sanctuary on one of Amsterdamâ€™s canals. The lovely houseboat is home to dozens of stray cats who have learned to love living on the water. For someone like me who misses her own cats dearly, itâ€™s positively sublime to visit a place where I can play with friendly cats for as long as I like. Later, I toured KattenKabinet, a museum specializing in artwork featuring cats. They have paintings by artists such as Rembrandt and Manet, as well as sculptures and posters by less famous artists. They even have a couple of real cats hanging around the museum for artistic inspiration!
Normally I would save my culinary experiences for a food post, but I have to rave about the food in Amsterdam. My diet consisted mostly of cheese and waffles: needless to say, I was well-satisfied. There is a cheese shop selling fresh local cheese on almost every corner in Amsterdam, and the best part is that they all offer free samples! I wandered from shop to shop, trying slices of every cheese and every fig spread offered. I literally made a meal out of free cheese samples.
The Dutch are famed for their stroopwafels, which are thin waffles cemented together by caramel syrup. They sound delicious, and Iâ€™m a little ashamed to say that I never tried one. My sweet-tooth hopelessly indulged in the perhaps less-authentic but more delectable chocolate-covered waffles.
Oh. My. God. I may never be able to eat at Waffle House again after feasting on these things. I ate one every day: chocolate-covered waffles, white chocolate-covered waffles, caramel-covered waffles. So many waffles, and so much tastebud explosion. They were usually topped with yummy things like marshmallows, butterscotch chips, or Oreos, too.
Whether you like amazing food, beautiful rural countryside, or a charming and vibrant city with flowers everywhere, Amsterdam will take your breath away. It is easily my favorite city so far. Weâ€™ll see if it can be surpassed by my next stop â€” Berlin!
--

Today is the beginning of my month-long, Amazing Amsterdam Adventure.
I will be on my own this month, and I have decided to pretend I am a tourist who managed to find a beautiful apartment in Amsterdam for a month.
The first day of my fakecation began appropriately with transportation challenges. I helped my daughter and family get to the train station, and it was a bit more challenging than anticipated to get all those bikes and the dog across town to Central station, never mind onto a train.
I left them outside and then got very lost on my way home â€” at one point, my GPS tried to send me into the canal. Fortunately, I made it to the apartment. Now, after a hard day of traveling, I am beginning this adventure.
I hope you join me.
You can read more about my plans in the piece below.

Title: For Matt: thoughts on Amsterdam and Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I decided Iâ€™ll write a bit about the two cities I just visited during my French school break, partially because my British friend Matt (shoutout number three if heâ€™s counting!) encouraged me to keep writing about urban planning. So here I am.
Amsterdam is very interesting with its urban planning â€” some might call it â€œthe Meccaâ€ of urban planning because of how idealized it is by many urbanists. The most popular urbanism YouTube channel is Not Just Bikes, who moved to Amsterdam because of its reputation. But what is it really like?
I would imagine the tourist experience is much different from the habitant experience, even more than other cities. This is because while the prioritization of biking is helpful for locals, it can be difficult for a newbie to get a handle on. As you walk around the city, there can be so much to look out for as a pedestrian. Watch out for the bikes! Watch out for the tram! Watch out for the cars! Itâ€™s a complex ecosystem, and if you arenâ€™t paying attention, it can be easily overwhelming.
I did love the trams in Amsterdamâ€™s city center. Metros can go faster underground, but the experience of a tram above ground, where you can simply hop on and look out the window at the city, is delightful. However, I noticed that the trams and metro have a tap-in and tap-out system, which Iâ€™m not a fan of. In New York, you use your ticket to get on the subway, but you can get off wherever you want and you do not have to rescan the ticket. This is much easier for riders. My friends and I were sometimes scrambling to take out our ticket again and rescan to exit the train.
I get the sense that in Venice people actually use their canals for transportation, but in Amsterdam this does not seem to be the case. There are tours on the canal, but not a lot of regular folks using the canal to navigate the city. The bikes are everywhere. I donâ€™t know how I underestimated the number of bikes when I knew how bike-crazy Amsterdam is, but I underestimated them.
There are a few things I prefer about Paris, a place Iâ€™ve been to many times and am more familiar with. The sidewalks are wider in Paris than in Amsterdam. There are also a lot more terraces/outdoor seating in Paris, which is always welcoming and enjoyable for tourists and locals. Amsterdamâ€™s meager outdoor seating was always just a few tables outside, whereas in Paris there can be huge terraces with many tables for people to simply plop down and order a coffee. Relaxed cafÃ© culture in France is simply unbeatable. In comparison, with its smaller streets and a lack of outside seating, Amsterdam is always keeping things moving. Itâ€™s a faster pace but itâ€™s also exciting and keeps you turning down the next corner.
There are a few key neighborhoods in Amsterdam. The 9 Streets neighborhood is very beautiful with varying architecture and canal views, but much of the ground floor establishments were expensive shops. Again, I wouldâ€™ve liked an outdoor cafÃ© to sit and take things in rather than feeling like I couldnâ€™t linger. I found the Jordaan neighborhood to be more residential (I could literally look into rich peopleâ€™s houses because of their big, open windows) but just as architecturally interesting. The Red Light District felt the most touristy. Itâ€™s really just one street, a couple blocks long, with sex workers in the windows and â€œcinemas.â€ We walked up and down it once, but there wasnâ€™t much for our group to do there.
Athens has a few popular neighborhoods as well â€” Plaka and Psyri. I found Plaka to be touristy in some parts and desolate in others. Maybe this is just my experience. I really liked Psyri â€” I had multiple meals in that area and found something going on down every street. Cars in Athens are interesting â€” they attempt to go down any street they can fit in. I was sitting outside at a cafÃ© and a car squeezed through the small street less than two feet away from me. There is a lack of signaled crosswalks in Athens. Most of the time people just cross the street whenever possible through traffic. That is less than ideal.
But I would not say Athens isnâ€™t walkable. I walked all over the city center while I was there and only took the metro a few times to get to faraway locations. When I did take the metro, it was fairly reliable but not the cleanest. One thing I did like about the Athens metro was that they had signs showing which direction the escalators were going so that you could easily navigate where you needed to go to get out. I havenâ€™t seen that in a metro before, but it was helpful.
Athens is the furthest south Iâ€™ve been in Europe and the sunshine was welcome after months of rainy winter in France. One thing I noticed is all of the solar panels! Many apartment buildings had multiple solar panels at the top, maybe 6 feet long by 4 feet wide. In contrast, when I took the Eurostar train to Amsterdam, I noticed that Belgium and the Netherlands had a lot of wind turbines. Northern part of Europe, more wind, it makes sense.
This was a great trip with two cities I really wanted to see this year, so Iâ€™m proud of myself and feeling very fulfilled.
--
--
In grad school. Writing so that I can blab about my interdisciplinary interests: politics, philosophy, urban planning, travel, rural America, etc.

In the past 2 weeks Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time at the airport. A little too much time if you ask my travelâ€¦
Iâ€™m not a fan of big national holidays. July 4th, New Years, Labor Dayâ€¦There is always a lot of hype to it and it never lives up to oneâ€™sâ€¦
Itâ€™s been 5 weeks and time has really flown! I started on this exciting project at work, I am starting to make friendsâ€¦
After three weeks, and a day after my NY lease expired, I can finally say that I have a home. Not just an apartment but a home. Theâ€¦

Title: Urban Planning in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam, the capital of the Netherlands, is renowned for its picturesque canals, historical buildings, and vibrant cultural life. With such a rich history, it is a place I have found stunning. However, its urban planning and architecture have evolved significantly over the past century, balancing preserving historical charm and embracing modern sustainability principles. This intricate dance has led to notable successes and challenges in creating thriving communities harmonizing with the city's natural geography and cultural ethos.
Amsterdamâ€™s urban planning has always been influenced by its unique geography. The cityâ€™s layout, characterized by concentric canals known as the â€œGrachtengordel,â€ was initially designed in the 17th century during the Dutch Golden Age. This historic planning emphasized functionality and aesthetics, creating a beautiful and practical cityscape. However, as the city grew, new challenges emerged, requiring innovative solutions to accommodate a growing population while preserving the area's historical integrity.
In the 20th century, Amsterdam faced significant urban development pressures. The post-war period saw a surge in modernist architecture, focusing on efficiency and functionality. However, this often came at the expense of the cityâ€™s historical character. The construction of high-rise buildings and large-scale infrastructure projects sometimes clashed with the traditional low-rise, dense urban fabric that defined Amsterdam.
One of Amsterdamâ€™s significant successes in urban planning has been integrating modern sustainable practices with historical preservation. The city has implemented policies prioritizing the adaptive reuse of old buildings, converting them into modern residential and commercial spaces while maintaining their historical faÃ§ades. This approach not only preserves the cityâ€™s cultural heritage but also reduces the environmental impact of new construction.
Amsterdamâ€™s Eastern Docklands is a shining example of how thoughtful urban planning can transform an industrial area into a vibrant, sustainable community. Once a bustling hub for maritime trade, the docklands fell into disuse by the mid-20th century, leaving vast expanses of derelict land. The redevelopment of this area in the late 20th and early 21st centuries showcases how innovative urban planning can successfully integrate historical elements with modern living requirements.
The Eastern Docklands project began in the 1980s to convert the obsolete industrial space into a mixed-use residential and commercial district. Unlike the high-rise developments in other parts of the world, the Eastern Docklands favored medium-rise buildings, typically between 3 to 7 stories, which complemented the traditional Amsterdam skyline. This approach ensured that new developments did not overshadow the historical city center and preserved the human-scale urban fabric characteristic of Amsterdam.
The planning process was highly inclusive, involving architects, urban planners, and the community. The result was a series of distinct neighborhoods, each with its unique architectural style yet harmoniously integrated into the overall urban landscape. The Borneo-Sporenburg area, for example, features innovative row houses with private gardens and public spaces that encourage social interaction. The Java and KNSM islands blend modern architecture with maritime heritage, creating visually striking and functionally diverse neighborhoods.
One of the critical successes of the Eastern Docklands redevelopment is its emphasis on sustainability and community-oriented design. Green roofs, solar panels, and energy-efficient building practices are standard in the new constructions, significantly reducing the area's environmental footprint. Public spaces, parks, and waterways were carefully integrated into the design, providing residents with ample recreational opportunities and enhancing the areaâ€™s aesthetic appeal.
The docklandsâ€™ design also prioritizes walkability and cycling, aligning with Amsterdamâ€™s broader commitment to sustainable urban mobility. Extensive cycling paths and pedestrian-friendly streets encourage residents to use bicycles and walk, reducing reliance on cars and contributing to a healthier, more connected community.
Furthermore, the Eastern Docklands redevelopment incorporated a mix of housing types, including affordable housing units, to ensure a diverse population. This inclusivity fosters a vibrant community where people from different socio-economic backgrounds can live, work, and socialize.
The success of the Eastern Docklands redevelopment lies in its holistic approach to urban planning. By respecting the areaâ€™s historical context, prioritizing sustainability, and involving the community in the planning process, the project has created a thriving, dynamic district that serves as a model for urban redevelopment worldwide. The docklands have become a sought-after residential area known for its quality of life, architectural innovation, and harmonious integration of the old and new.
The lessons learned from the Eastern Docklands can be applied to other urban redevelopment projects. Emphasizing mixed-use developments, sustainable practices, and community involvement are critical strategies for transforming underutilized areas into vibrant urban spaces. As cities worldwide grapple with sustainability and urban growth issues, the Eastern Docklands is a testament to what can be achieved through thoughtful, inclusive urban planning.
Another success story is the cityâ€™s extensive cycling infrastructure, which has been integrated into urban planning to reduce car dependency and promote a healthier lifestyle. Amsterdamâ€™s network of bike paths and cycle-friendly policies have made it one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world, significantly lowering urban pollution and enhancing the quality of life for its residents.
Brandevoort, a neighborhood in the Dutch city of Helmond, is a remarkable example of modern urban planning that successfully integrates traditional architectural styles with contemporary living standards. Designed to resemble a conventional Dutch village, Brandevoort blends the charm and aesthetics of historical townscapes with the functionality and sustainability required for modern urban living. This neighborhood has become a benchmark for new urbanism in the Netherlands, illustrating how thoughtful design can foster a sense of community and enhance the quality of life.
The development of Brandevoort began in the late 1990s with a clear vision: to create a new residential area that respects and reflects the rich architectural heritage of the Netherlands. The planners and architects drew inspiration from historical Dutch towns, incorporating features such as narrow streets, gabled roofs, and picturesque canals. This traditional aesthetic fosters a sense of familiarity and belonging among residents, attracting visitors who appreciate its quaint charm.
However, Brandevoort is not just about replicating the past; it seamlessly integrates modern sustainability practices into its design. The neighborhood includes energy-efficient buildings, green spaces, and robust infrastructure for cycling and walking, reducing reliance on cars. Using sustainable materials and renewable energy sources further underscores the commitment to creating an environmentally friendly community. These efforts not only enhance the quality of life for residents but also contribute to broader environmental goals.
One of the standout features of Brandevoort is its focus on fostering a strong sense of community. The layout of the neighborhood encourages social interaction and community engagement. Central squares, local shops, schools, and recreational facilities are strategically placed within walking distance for most residents, promoting a vibrant regional economy and a close-knit community atmosphere.
Integrating mixed-use buildings allows for a blend of residential, commercial, and recreational spaces, ensuring Brandevoort remains lively throughout the day. This mix of functions supports local businesses and provides residents convenient access to amenities, reducing the need for long commutes and encouraging local engagement.
Moreover, Brandevoortâ€™s urban design includes a variety of housing types to accommodate different demographics, from young families to retirees. This diversity enhances the community's social fabric, making it a dynamic and inclusive place to live.
Brandevoortâ€™s success lies in its ability to harmonize the old with the new, creating a nostalgic and forward-thinking community. The neighborhoodâ€™s design principles offer valuable lessons for urban planners and developers. Brandevoort demonstrates that modern urban developments can be functional and beautiful by prioritizing sustainability, community, and aesthetics.
Brandevoort, a neighborhood in the Dutch city of Helmond, is a remarkable example of modern urban planning that successfully integrates traditional architectural styles with contemporary living standards. Designed to resemble a conventional Dutch village, Brandevoort blends the charm and aesthetics of historical townscapes with the functionality and sustainability required for modern urban living. This neighborhood has become a benchmark for new urbanism in the Netherlands, illustrating how thoughtful design can foster a sense of community and enhance the quality of life.
The development of Brandevoort began in the late 1990s with a clear vision: to create a new residential area that respects and reflects the rich architectural heritage of the Netherlands. The planners and architects drew inspiration from historical Dutch towns, incorporating features such as narrow streets, gabled roofs, and picturesque canals. This traditional aesthetic fosters a sense of familiarity and belonging among residents, attracting visitors who appreciate its quaint charm.
However, Brandevoort is not just about replicating the past; it seamlessly integrates modern sustainability practices into its design. The neighborhood includes energy-efficient buildings, green spaces, and robust infrastructure for cycling and walking, reducing reliance on cars. Using sustainable materials and renewable energy sources further underscores the commitment to creating an environmentally friendly community. These efforts not only enhance the quality of life for residents but also contribute to broader environmental goals.
One of the standout features of Brandevoort is its focus on fostering a strong sense of community. The layout of the neighborhood encourages social interaction and community engagement. Central squares, local shops, schools, and recreational facilities are strategically placed within walking distance for most residents, promoting a vibrant regional economy and a close-knit community atmosphere.
Integrating mixed-use buildings allows for a blend of residential, commercial, and recreational spaces, ensuring Brandevoort remains lively throughout the day. This mix of functions supports local businesses and provides residents convenient access to amenities, reducing the need for long commutes and encouraging local engagement.
Moreover, Brandevoortâ€™s urban design includes a variety of housing types to accommodate different demographics, from young families to retirees. This diversity enhances the community's social fabric, making it a dynamic and inclusive place to live.
Brandevoortâ€™s success lies in its ability to harmonize the old with the new, creating a nostalgic and forward-thinking community. The neighborhoodâ€™s design principles offer valuable lessons for urban planners and developers. Brandevoort demonstrates that modern urban developments can be functional and beautiful by prioritizing sustainability, community, and aesthetics. This thoughtful integration of past and present and a commitment to sustainable living make Brandevoort a model for future urban developments, ensuring vibrant and resilient communities.
Despite these successes, Amsterdam has faced challenges and failures in its urban planning journey. One of the significant issues has been the tension between development and preservation. The drive for modernization and expansion sometimes led to the demolition of historically substantial buildings, sparking public outcry and resistance. For instance, the construction of the Bijlmermeer, a high-rise housing project in the 1960s, was initially hailed as a modernist triumph but soon became a symbol of urban failure due to poor design and social isolation.
The Bijlmermeer, commonly known as Bijlmer, was conceived in the 1960s as a utopian vision of modern living in Amsterdam. Designed by architect Siegfried Nassuth, Bijlmer was planned as a high-rise residential area to embody modernist architecture and urban planning ideals. Its innovative hexagonal layout and extensive green spaces aim to provide a harmonious, efficient, and socially integrated environment. However, the reality diverged sharply from these aspirations, leading to challenges and failures that ultimately transformed Bijlmer from a symbol of modern utopia to one of urban dystopia.
The design of Bijlmer was heavily influenced by the principles of Le Corbusier and the modernist movement, which emphasized clean lines, functional living spaces, and the separation of different urban functions. The area was planned with a clear distinction between pedestrian and vehicular traffic, vast open spaces, and high-density residential blocks meant to foster a strong sense of community. The high-rise buildings were intended to provide spacious apartments with ample natural light and views of the surrounding greenery.
Despite its innovative design, Bijlmer faced significant challenges from the outset. The timing of its construction coincided with changing housing preferences in the Netherlands. By the time Bijlmerâ€™s first residents moved in during the late 1960s and early 1970s, there was a growing preference for low-rise, single-family homes over high-rise apartments. This shift in housing demand led to difficulties in attracting residents to Bijlmer.
Moreover, the social and economic composition of Bijlmerâ€™s population deviated from the plannersâ€™ expectations. Initially intended to attract middle-class families, the area became home to a diverse population, including many immigrants and low-income households. The high concentration of disadvantaged groups, coupled with a lack of adequate social infrastructure and employment opportunities, contributed to social isolation and economic hardship.
Initially praised for its innovation, the architectural design soon revealed several practical flaws. While theoretically ideal for community building, the vast, monotonous concrete structures often felt impersonal and alienating. The separation of pedestrian pathways from road traffic, though meant to enhance safety, resulted in labyrinthine walkways breeding grounds for crime and vandalism. The large open spaces, initially envisioned as communal areas, needed to be more utilized and better maintained, further contributing to a sense of neglect and decay.
Maintenance issues exacerbated these problems. The sheer scale of the high-rise buildings made upkeep expensive and challenging. As the area aged, the lack of proper maintenance led to deteriorating living conditions, with frequent reports of broken elevators, water leaks, and general disrepair. This decline in the physical environment mirrored the social challenges, reinforcing a negative feedback loop that further stigmatized the area.
Bijlmerâ€™s failure can be attributed to a combination of design flaws, changing social dynamics, and inadequate planning for the socioeconomic realities of its residents. The high-rise utopia envisioned by its planners did not account for the human need for more intimate, human-scale environments. The grand, impersonal architecture failed to foster the sense of community it aimed for, leading instead to social isolation and alienation.
Extensive redevelopment efforts were undertaken in the 1990s and 2000s in response to these challenges. Many of the original high-rise buildings were demolished and replaced with low-rise housing, and significant investments were made in improving infrastructure, public spaces, and social services. These efforts aimed to address the underlying issues of social segregation and economic disparity while preserving some elements of the original vision.
The story of Bijlmer offers critical lessons for urban planners and architects. It underscores the importance of flexibility in urban design, the need to adapt to changing social preferences, and the necessity of integrating social and economic planning with architectural innovation. Bijlmerâ€™s experience highlights that successful urban environments must balance visionary design with practical, human-centered considerations. As Amsterdam continues to evolve, the lessons from Bijlmerâ€™s ambitious but flawed experiment serve as a cautionary tale and a guiding framework for future developments.
Social engineering in urban planning, particularly during the mid-20th century, often led to the creation of monolithic housing estates that did not cater to the social and cultural needs of the residents. These projects sometimes resulted in social segregation and failed to create cohesive communities.
Today, Amsterdamâ€™s urban planning is guided by sustainability, inclusivity, and community engagement principles. The city moves from top-down social engineering approaches towards more participatory planning processes. This shift recognizes the importance of working with nature and local communities to optimize urban living.
Modern projects focus on enhancing green spaces, improving public transportation, and creating mixed-use developments that combine residential, commercial, and recreational spaces. For example, the Zuidas district, also known as the â€œFinancial Mile,â€ is being developed as a mixed-use area with a strong emphasis on green buildings and sustainable infrastructure.
Amsterdamâ€™s urban planning reflects a delicate balance between preserving historical character and embracing modernity. By prioritizing sustainable practices and community-oriented development, the city continues to evolve in a way that respects its rich heritage while addressing contemporary needs. This approach ensures that Amsterdam remains a vibrant, livable city that harmonizes with its natural and cultural environment.

I spent 3 days and 2 nights in Amsterdam.
I really do think anyone can enjoy travelling on a budget without it being extremely restrictive as long as you have a plan in place. In my opinion, Amsterdam is an extremely beautiful city, definitely much more expensive than some other cities in Europe eg Berlin, Prague, and Dublin but it is nonetheless worth a visit.
The iconic buildings, riverbanks and bridges make it truly picturesque. The buildings in some streets remain a protected UNESCO world heritage.
Here is basically what I did and how much I spent:
Flight: Ryan air â€” â‚¬38 (Dublin to Amsterdam). Quite a steal if you ask me.

Train to the city: â‚¬5.7 (Amsterdam Schiphol Airport to Amsterdam City Centre which is around a 30 minutes journey)

Title: Amsterdamâ€™s Sharing Cities Roundtable: Going Deeper
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Earlier this week Bloomberg published an article about a meeting of multiple cities in Amsterdam last month â€œto forge an alliance in response to Airbnb and Uber.â€ This headline misses the mark; it is both misleading and glosses over what actually happened. I should know: I was at the meeting.
The Global Sharing Cities Roundtable was conceived by the City of Amsterdam several months ago, as an opportunity for cities who are leading efforts to understand and promote the sharing economy worldwide. Participant cities ranged from Seoul, whose Sharing City initiative dates back to 2012 and includes everything from a city-owned space sharing platform to investment of public funds in more than 50 sharing economy initiatives, to Copenhagen, whose sharing economy strategy is linked to its goals for sustainability and the circular economy. Of course, Amsterdam played a leading role â€” as Europeâ€™s first self-declared sharing city, home to numerous sharing economy enterprises and a fresh approach to policy reform.
Airbnb and Uber were discussed at the roundtable. But to be clear: the roundtable was not â€œaboutâ€ them. The purpose of the roundtable was for cities to meet each other â€” the overwhelming majority of them had never been in contact before â€” and to engage in blue-sky thinking about the sharing economyâ€™s potential.
True, Amsterdamâ€™s innovative approach to policy reform for homesharing and short-term rentals was one topic discussed, due to popular demand by other cities. But it was only one topic. Dozens of other topics were also part of the agenda. Ridesharing and ridehailing were another popular topic, though ironically Uber itself barely came up. Rather, more time was spent on brainstorming how the sharing economy can link with waste reduction initiatives, serve to rethink delivery of public services, engage youth and elderly, and potentially help tackle a wide range of other social problems for cities worldwide. The Bloomberg article misses the mark in failing to detail â€” or even acknowledge â€” this much broader agenda.
I was honored to be invited as the only non-city employee. (For full disclosure, I have advised several of the cities in attendance.) Bloomberg reached out to interview me but did not follow through in doing so. Meanwhile, none of the people quoted in the interview were at the meeting. With all due respect, this falls short of what I would expect from one of the worldâ€™s most esteemed publications.
The sharing economy is about much, much more than Airbnb or Uber. We should know that. It is extremely frustrating to see the media focus disproportionately on what is but one piece of a much larger pie. It is increasingly easy to single out one or two companies, but by doing so, we are missing the forest for the trees â€” and missing a much bigger opportunity.
April Rinne is an independent advisor to sharing economy companies, governments, policy makers and investors worldwide. She is a Young Global Leader at the World Economic Forum and an inveterate globetrotter (93 countries and counting).

I have lived in the Netherlands for nearly four years now, the past two in Amsterdam. Because I moved here during the pandemic and then was sick quite a bit for the last year, I havenâ€™t done as many of the touristy things as I might have liked.
Starting August 1st, things are about to change.
My family lives on the same block as I do, but they are going away this year for August. That means I will be on my own in my beautiful apartment.
I have decided to pretend that I am in a beautiful vacation apartment in a city I donâ€™t know well and act like a tourist. I will visit museums and gardens, take a canal tour, and do anything that seems fun. I will probably even take some of my own advice:
medium.com
And, of course, I will regularly write about it, so stay tuned!

Title: Beautiful Amsterdam, Built on Poles: Who would pay if it all fell down?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

TedxAmsterdam

--
Listen
Share
Beautiful Amsterdam / Built on Poles/ Who would pay if it all fell down?
â€“Old Dutch nursery rhyme translated
Since early times, the houses in Amsterdam have been built on wooden foundation piles[i] that are driven deep into the clay, peat, and water until they reach the first layer of solid sand. Even some of the trees in Vondelpark are supported on wooden piles to keep them from sinking into the marshy ground.
How long can a wooden pile remain in the ground before it has to be replaced?
300 years? 80 years? Until next week? The answer depends on many variables:
Quality of the sand layer
In Amsterdam, the first layer of sand lies approximately 12 meters below the surface. However, the quality of the sand layer is not consistent throughout the city. In some areas, the first sand layer is thinner than normal or missing entirely. As a result, the houses in these areas sink at an abnormal rate, and the foundations have to be replaced faster.
The top of the wooden foundation pile should be below the lowest expected water level. If part of the pile reaches above the water, it will be subject to insect attacks and decay. A problem is that the water level under Amsterdam isnâ€™t always stable. For instance, it can drop during long periods of drought. Or a sewer pipe can develop cracks, allowing the ground water to flow into the pipe and be carried away. As a result, the water level drops.
On the other hand, if the water level rises too high, as sometimes occurs after a heavy rain, the Amsterdam cellars and crawl spaces fill up like bathtubs.
Construction projects can also interfere with the water level. An example is the incident on the Vijzelgracht in 2008 during work on the new metro station. A leak in the dam wall at a depth of 60 meters caused water and sand to stream into the pit. Part of the sand layer that was supporting the wooden foundation piles of the nearby houses washed away, causing extensive damage to the structure of the houses.
Spruce is less vulnerable to damage from bacteria than pine. Since around 1970, piles made from pine are prohibited from use. Concrete and steel piles are often used in present day construction.
The visible signs are slanted floors, cracks in the walls, doors and windows that stick, and broken front steps. The charming crooked roofline of Amsterdam is actually a symptom of unstable foundations.
If a foundation that is in poor condition is not repaired in time, the wooden piles will need to be replaced. No homeowner wants to get this news. A new foundation can easily cost 100,000 euro. Furthermore, the floor may need to be opened up, thereby making the house unlivable for some time.
In recent years, the housing corporations have been replacing the wooden piles under their properties with concrete piles.[ii] For example, Ymere is replacing the decayed pine piles in the Van der Pek neighborhood â€” a costly investment. However many houses that are at risk are privately owned.
The condition of the old wooden piles will only worsen in the coming years, so the question is: who will pay?
[i] Referred to as poles in the nursery rhyme.
[ii] Palen onder Amsterdam verpulveren

Gemeente Amsterdam Background on Foundations
The Challenges of Building Amsterdamâ€™s New Metro Line

Share
Sangam and I visited a place called Aâ€™dam Lookout in Amsterdam. Itâ€™s a high platform where you can see an amazing view of the city. Youâ€™ll see the old part of the city, the busy port, and the special Dutch landscape with its canals, which are recognized as important by UNESCO. They also have a cool exhibition and a free audio tour that tells you about Amsterdamâ€™s past and culture. Aâ€™dam Lookout is on the top of the Aâ€™dam Tower in Amsterdam North.
We got tickets for Aâ€™dam Lookout and hopped on the elevator. We were really excited to see the city view from the tower. As the elevator went up, the colors changed constantly, and it looked absolutely amazing.
When we reached the top of the tower, the city view was incredible. Even though it was windy and a bit chilly, we still had a great time enjoying the view.
--
--

Today is the 7th day of my August Amsterdam Adventure, and I went to the Rijksmuseum, the National Museum of the Netherlands. I had the opportunity to see the famous painting â€œThe Night Watch,â€ which is undergoing restoration, a process being documented every step of the way. The Museum has published extensive information about it online.
I spent two hours looking at only a fraction of the work on exhibit and am looking forward to doing more of a deep dive this month into the art available to residents and tourists in the Netherlands. Todayâ€™s visit included works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Van Gogh, among many others.
I will be visiting the Van Gogh Museum later this month, as well as the Fabrique des LumiÃ¨res exhibit of the Dutch Masters, and I will write a lot more about them. I will be keeping a travel log about my adventures here:
