Title: Tot Ziens Amsterdam!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In a few hours, I will no longer be an Amsterdammer. I will take a plane that will carry me away of this city where I landed almost three years ago, knowing no one. At that time, I could not imagine that the city that felt so cold and flat, will feel so warm and containing, will feel so much like home.
Wherever I go, being an Amsterdammer would subject me to bursts of envy: too much sexual freedom, too much legal weed, people would say. The truth is that Amsterdam is much more than its red light district and its coffee shops. Amsterdam is a place where culture, charm, coziness, openness and nonchalance merge together in a beautiful bond. If I were to compare Amsterdam to a woman, this woman would be easygoing, busy enjoying everything that life brings her way, so much in peace with herself and her imperfections, a woman who is too good to be true.
Few months after settling in in Amsterdam, the Amsterdam vibe started to get into me. I started to shift from someone who is over-thinking and over-planning to someone who enjoys the present and lets life flow, trusting that everything will fall into place. I started to overcome my shyness and introvert character and to open myself to new experiences and relationships. I started to think beyond myself and my 9 to 5 job, and to share with Amsterdammers their sheer interest in topics like sustainability, environment and social inclusion. Last but not least, Amsterdam taught me to take care of myself, of my emotional and physical well-being, and to always seek balance and harmony.
I owe to Amsterdam a lot of the small and big changes that happened to me during the past years: Practicing yoga, relying on a bike for movement, sharing my home with strangers, reflecting on my passion and life mission, engaging in impact-driven initiatives and communities, saying what I think even when it is in contrast with what people expect, embracing failure and turning it into fuel, feeling confident talking about my failures and vulnerabilitiesâ€¦ I owe to Amsterdam the person I became today, someone who is much happier and looking forward to life than the person I was three years ago.
Thank you Amsterdam for everything! I will miss the times when a bike ride through your canals was enough to erase any sadness and to clear my thoughts. You were so kind to a stranger like me. You were the coziest home I ever had far away from home.
--
--
Citizen of the world| Techie| Occasionally a Stand-up Comedian.

Title: Explore the Legacy of Amsterdam: Travel Recs for the History Girlies
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
In the mornings, there was still a slight chill in the air despite it being late June. In Amsterdam, the sun came up too early and went back down too late, and I was struggling to adjust to this new sleep schedule. By the time the sun went down completely at ten or eleven at night, it would be hours until I felt tired enough to actually sleep, and still would be up too early for comfort. This routine heavily affected my circadian rhythm.
Despite being the worldâ€™s sleepiest girl in Amsterdam, I could enjoy the slow living that the Dutch are accustomed to. I took long walks in the mornings around the canals, listened to Dutch language lessons while wandering residential neighborhoods, and got to explore the history of the quiet, bustling town I would definitely visit again.
For travelers obsessed with history like I am, Amsterdam is a place steeped in stories and lives you will love to learn from. Hereâ€™s some of my favorite places in Amsterdam to experience the legacy of â€œVenice of the North.â€
--
--
Educator & writer exploring history, travel, & culture abroad. Based in Barcelona, weaving past & present into stories that inspire & inform.

Title: Havenstraatâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAmsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A CFYE curated collection of visual appealing stories on Medium (photography, (street) art, illustration).

--
Listen
Share
In between Amsterdamâ€™s Olympic stadium and a former correctional facility lays the Havenstraat terrain, one of the last rough patches within the cityâ€™s ring-way. Barely subjected to Amsterdamâ€™s fast-paced gentrification, the Havenstraat terrain is an odd collection of barracks, shacks and old tram depots which house businesses, workshops and a tram museum. As the city council has plans to build an apartment complex on the costly ground, chances are this genuine piece of Amsterdam will disappear soon. Dutch photographer Michael Floor decided to capture this eclectic mix of structures, businesses and people before the city has replaced them with something more profitable.
â€œOne guy told me that in the old days, heâ€™d shove the camera in my face, but that there are just too many photographers around the terrain nowadaysâ€
Michael, who lives in the neighbourhood, mostly used the Havenstraat terrain as an alternative to a walk in the park. â€œThe terrain used to be even more secluded, before a bicycle path went through itâ€ Michael explains. The bicycle path, which doesnâ€™t seem to fit any city planning standards, cuts right through the terrain, in between barracks, through a parking lot and over loads of unused rails.
To say that the Havenstraat is an odd sight is an understatement. Hundreds of people bike through it on a daily basis, yet few people seem to know whatâ€™s going on behind the barrack doors.
The Havenstraat owns itâ€™s characteristic architecture to a time where the barracks functioned as coal depot for the trains. As this specific station disappeared when the tracks didnâ€™t got modernised to use electricity, the depots became the ideal place for workshops and businesses who profit from the low rent.
The terrain doesnâ€™t come across as the most hospitable of areaâ€™s and a lot of the business owners, if theyâ€™re present at all, keep to themselves while Michael takes me on a stroll through the terrain. â€œThis must be the only lady who wouldnâ€™t mind if this terrain would be lost, sheâ€™s 70 and ready for retirementâ€ Michael says, pointing to a second hand â€˜stuffâ€™ store at the beginning of the terrain, which I never noticed before. Another thing I never really noticed; the odd, out of place looking, three story high tower structure next to the store. Michael explains to me that itâ€™s an old station watchtower, left to retire at the Havenstraat.
The terrain is full of odd sights and stuff that â€˜American Pickersâ€™ would go crazy over. During our walk, Michael spots several new frames he tries out with his phone as he uses an analogue Mamiya RZ 67 Pro 2 camera for the final pictures. â€œI might have to come back with my actual camera later onâ€.
People tend to keep to themselves around here, which makes portraying the terrain and its people a demanding task. Michael: â€œItâ€™s not a place where you just walk around and snap pictures of everyone. The people here like their privacy and you need to talk to them to get their interest. Some people were fine with me photographing them right away, others had to see me more often before they realized I was doing more than just taking a few quick snaps. One guy told me that in the old days, heâ€™d shove the camera in my face, but that there were just too many photographers around nowadays. He seems to come around though, now heâ€™s seen me more often! I bet I can get a picture of him in the end.â€
We continue to walk into a big depot housing a bazaar with an inventory as eclectic as the terrain itself. Michael has an agreement with the owner so that he can come in and photograph the place every once in a while. When the owner walks by, no big pleasantries are exchanged, just a small nod of acknowledgement as he continues his business.
Itâ€™s quite easy to romanticise a terrain like this, but some of the businesses here are doing more than well. â€œThis store is doing really good and actually has another branch not too far from here (Beethovenstraat / Appololaan)â€ Michael tells me while taking mental frames of the light coming in through the roof.
Usually there are quite a few military vehicles scattered around the terrain, which are owned and maintained by classic military vehicle renovator â€˜Keep them rollinâ€™. A big yellow bus which is characteristic to the Havenstraat terrain, is used as a riding garage.
Continuing our stroll, Michael explains what more interesting businesses house behind the often closed doors; including a renowned harpsichord builder, a special effects studio for movies, a student moving company, a bicycle repairman and multiple garages.
A bit further on we run into the depots that house the Tram museum, including classic trams. The classic trams are still in use and run on a line between the terrain and Amstelveen, mostly for excursionists.
The trams and depots are also used by a theater group, giving small shows that make use of the trams as moving decors.
Following the tram line is a bit of a hidden surprise: City gardens. Hailing from the days of real crisis, where people were giving a peace of land to grow food on, the gardens now offer a place of relaxation for the owners.
Around them, gentrification has slowly started with brand new apartment buildings at one side of the tracks, and a meticulously planned city park at the other side.
Itâ€™s obvious that the city has already been gnawing away at the rough edges of this charmingly authentic terrain. With all the plans for apartment buildings itâ€™s not unthinkable this place will eventually vanish. For now however, business continues as usual.
Michael will continue his series of this terrain and its people, with plans to exhibit them at one point.
When I ask Michael if he thinks itâ€™s a pity this terrain might disappear he answers: â€œA pity, maybe, yes. But seeing the location, it might be inescapable as wellâ€
Kim Nunda, a jailer who has been working at the former correction facility since 1987. The facility has been empty since 1/10/13. New zoning-plan: Unknown
View more of Michael Floorâ€™s work on http://michaelfloor.com
This article was first published on http://cfye.com. We will continue to publish our new articles on Medium, formatted accordingly for your viewing / reading pleasure!

Title: Sunset in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
3
Share
Amsterdam, the Venice of the North. Risen from reclaimed marshland. The city of Rembrandt. The city with the harbor and the cruise ships. The port where the crowds buzz like a beehive. The city where dormant changes can suddenly rear their heads. The city with once the beating Jewish heart. Where once Jewish life flourished and vibrated. The heart brought to a halt by betrayal and murder.
I am sitting on a quiet terrace opposite the Museum Square, right next to Museum Square the Concertgebouw. The sun slowly begins to draw melancholy shadows from people and buildings. The birds of the city migrate over to find a safe roost in one of the surrounding parks. The cars, streetcars and cyclists roll silently by. The rush to be home is marked on the faces.
Amsterdam pulls up to the dinner table. People passing by carry with them a variety of food. Above them the hungry faces. The restlessness of the end of the workday is almost palpable. People and the city are getting ready for the coming evening and night. The poverty of the city is also visible in the form of vagrants, begging and trying to scrape together some money to get something to eat.
The terrace where I am sitting is not full. I like watching people. An sich, man is an evolutionary marvel. The Museum Square I am looking at is lined with museums: the Stedelijk, the Van Gogh, the Moco and a little furtherâ€¦

Title: Speciality Coffee in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Once you start buying beans from a speciality coffee roaster, there is no turning back. For some people the taste of speciality coffee is not like coffee and more like some aromatic tea. Some might not enjoy with this. Because the big coffee chains(hint: Starbucks) and supermarkets coded that burned taste into our tongues. They do this because they cannot sell as fresh as local roasters do and they have to sell the same consistent taste which is the burned coffee taste in this case.
(Originally posted on https://uludagcan.com/2023/01/13/speciality-coffee-in-amsterdam/)
But coffee can have multiple different flavors. There could be multiple factors that affects flavor of the beans such as where the bean grown, other plants around the coffee farm, drying methods and roasting processes. Thatâ€™s why you can see different tasting notes on the packaging of a speciality coffee product. Which is something great. Losing all these with over roasting is a huge shame.
Itâ€™s not cheap. We should admit that. Coffee is an expensive commodity and getting expensive each year. Due to that we can see the reflection on the prices. If you compare a cup of filter coffee or latte price at a speciality coffee house with the big coffee chain, you can see itâ€™s much more expensive at coffee roasters. Or if you compare 500g bag of coffee bean at a supermarket with the bag at roasters, again you can see the price differences. That comes from the quality and the effort that put into quality grown coffee. Those roasters cannot access coffee with cheap prices like big chains. Because of that they have to reflect it into prices. And the coffee farmers are the ones that suffer the most and earn the least in this equation. According to Moyee Coffee, 90% of the total coffee value disappears into the pockets of a handful of large multinationals, which we call Big Coffee. This means that the coffee farmers are left with only 10% of the value. Itâ€™s even worse, because there is nothing is added to this valueâ€“ only 2% of that amount is actual profit. So if you consider all, itâ€™s actually not that expensive.
Netherlands ruined the word â€œcoffeeshopâ€ for me. It is used to be one of my favorite word. â€œGoing to coffeeshopâ€, â€œworking from coffeeshopâ€, â€œgetting a takeaway latte from a coffeeshopâ€. I was using the word excessively. But â€œcoffeeshopâ€ means â€œdrug storeâ€ in the Netherlands. If you ask anyone on the road for the nearest coffeeshop, they will show you the place where you can smoke some weed and get high. So now itâ€™s â€œcoffee houseâ€. Or with a bit more hipster way, â€œcoffee roasterâ€. Iâ€™m getting used to it. If you are visiting Netherlands, especially Amsterdam and if your intention is not the drugs, keep that it in mind ğŸ˜‰
Amsterdam has a really good coffee scene. There are many good quality coffee roasters and coffee houses around. I think itâ€™s one of the two best speciality coffee cities in Europe. The other one is definitely Berlin. During my last two years in the Netherlands I created a list of my favorite coffee houses and roasters. Of course these are not all of them. Itâ€™s impossible to list all but these are mostly the ones that I visited and bought coffee. The ones that I enjoy and suggest with wholeheartedly.
Iâ€™m a bit biased with Bocca to be honest. Itâ€™s my first coffee roaster that I met in Amsterdam and the first one that I buy coffee beans. Even before moving to the Netherlands I bought beans from them. But objectively, they are one of the top coffee roasters in Amsterdam. Coffee is great and their store has a great atmosphere in the heart of the Netherlands. They also have great workshops for people who wants to dive into coffee brewing or making latte art. I took one of them and it was a great experience. Bocca is also selling many coffee making equipments. Even some unique tools like GINA Smart Brewer.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/tuQaThyreSvg8scU8
Even though I havenâ€™t sit and drunk coffee that much at the store, Lot61 is the roaster that I buy most of my beans for home brewing alongside with Bocca. I like the taste of roasting profile and also I found it the best value for money. Their regular blend coffee beans are perfect match for my daily filter coffee machine routine and espresso beans have rich, and bold taste.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/zSjNP1L5kDxkAgqd7
I cannot stress enough how much I like this place. They donâ€™t have their own roasted beans as far as I know. Last time I checked beans were coming from Berlin. But this cafe has small, cozy and warm vibe. Located very close to my favorite street Haarlemmerdijk. With good coffee, nice desserts, foods and hipster people profile, itâ€™s a lovely place. If you are around, definitely stop by Toki.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/8yfFc2qDWeH8vbWf7
Shining star of Bos en Lommerweg. This cafe was one minute walking distance away from my old house in Amsterdam. It was a great location for me to go and takeaway a coffee then walk in Westerpark. I always loved the vibe of FUKU. Nice cafe, good latte and tasty bites. And I know the name sounds like the F@$! word.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/EjcU18pEVL4hZ56V8
Another place where you can find good coffee at west. In between two beautiful parks of Amsterdam, Erasmus and Rembrandt park. I havenâ€™t bought coffee online from them for a while but I was happy with the coffee when I do. What I also like is the cozy interior space.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/Xt7CKBn6xQZPiF1CA
Iâ€™ve been into the store where located in Weteringstraat. Although I donâ€™t have strong opinions about the coffee at Back to Black, I liked the interior. Nice place to hang with friends. Take a cup of latte, eat a croissant, read your book and give some love to the cat that sleeps on the chair.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/a1LoUeBMcAknSyam7
Usually I search on maps before finding a new coffee roaster. But sometimes I just come across a cafe while walking on the streets of Amsterdam. Rum Baba is one of them. I was so happy when I find this roaster. Their colorful interior and delicious beans makes this place a great coffee house. There was not enough space to sit but since itâ€™s located on beautiful Elandsgracht, itâ€™s even better to take a cup coffee from there and walk in Amsterdam. I also recently learned that they have walk-in workshops. Keep following for new ones.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/B92xfJ3PSAYDQ81HA
Do you want Fika in Amsterdam? Then Scandinavian Embassy can be a right place for you. It has spacious and cozy interior. As you might imagine delicious Swedish desserts like cinnamon rolls and cakes. Combine it with coffee and relax. Location is also great. Near Sarphatipark and close to Albert Cuypmarkt.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/WmLKS5T6ZvTEWxvg8
This is another coffee house that I discovered randomly while riding my bike on the crazy traffic of bike lanes. Immediately loved the place. During my visit I enjoyed reading one of the Standart magazine on the shelf and drank my coffee. I remember that I liked the â€œpastel de nataâ€ tart that they serve. Good coffee companion.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/G6zpFncywpMj8RWU9
Almost every month, there is a transaction on my bank account for coffee beans. Itâ€™s one of my fixed costs. Since itâ€™s an expensive purchase, I look for the best value for my money. Along with coffee quality, the smooth online shop experience is also important for me. After trying multiple online stores, I decided on these four roasters for now. Bocca Coffee, Lot61, Wakuli, Manhattan Coffee Roasters. All have good online stores and delivery options. In terms of coffee, I canâ€™t say one is way better than the other but if you want me to pick two favorites, Bocca Coffee and Manhattan Coffee Roasters are the best. But also the most expensive ones. So not every month I can buy from them. I usually distribute my purchases amongst all four of these stores. By the way, I need to mention that Manhattan Coffee Roasters is not from Amsterdam. They are based in Rotterdam. Even though this guide is about Amsterdam, I have to mentioned their excellent quality beans. They are only online store and no cafe to visit so it suits my online buying section. I strongly advise to try.
Among those four, Wakuli is a bit different. They have the best subscription model and best price to be honest. You can easily start your subscription based on your preferred frequency. Weekly, bi-weekly or monthly itâ€™s up to you. If you have too much coffee at home, just skip next delivery. Or suddenly you ran out of coffee, then request for an emergency batch. And if you want to pause your delivery for a while, itâ€™s very easy and convenient to do that. Beautiful online shop, smooth experience. And it combined with good coffee. I highly suggest if you are looking for a coffee subscription service that you can manage based on your budget and schedule.
Of course there are more coffee houses and roasters in Amsterdam. Also in other cities like Utrecht, Rotterdam or Den Haag in the Netherlands. But these are just the ones I experienced and suggest without any hesitation. Please let me know if you know other coffee roasters in the Netherlands. Maybe we can update the guide next year.
--

Title: Donâ€™t let your fear hold you back-one year in Amsterdam.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

My journey as a human being.

--
5
Listen
Share
â€œAre you driven by fear, or passion?â€
August marks the first year since I moved to Amsterdam to begin a new chapter in both my life and career. Reflecting on this journey has brought a flood of complex emotions. Everything seemed to happen in a flash â€” what began as chaos has gradually settled into a rhythm. Now, having gone through the full cycle of ups and downs, I finally know what to expect, both in life and at work.
â€œEverything happens for a reason.â€
I feel fortunate that, in June, a friend shared her experience with spiritual response therapy. After trying it myself, I noticed a significant shift in my energy, and more positive things began to flow into my life.
One of the first changes I noticed was at work, where I became more proactive and positive by making small adjustments in my approach.
While the typical practices â€” like meditation, reading, working out, and cold showers â€” have proven their value to many, myself included, Iâ€™ve found it essential to switch things up from time to time to keep things fresh and inspiring. So, hereâ€™s my updated morning routine
Beyond adjusting my routine, Iâ€™ve experienced a mental shift in how I approach work.
Work will never be done, but people and events come and go.
Inspired by one of my colleagues, Iâ€™ve started making an effort not to skip fun events when they appear on my calendar. Attending these has brought some wonderful moments, like being part of the biggest social event at my company.
â€œWhat are you afraid of? Donâ€™t let your fear hold you back.â€- one of my fav leaders said to me.
I now wanted to cry hahahah as I feel so lucky that Iâ€™ve met lots of incredible people that show me care and warmth and support.
Outside of work, Iâ€™ve also learned valuable lessons from personal relationships:
Hey, so, are you driven by fear or passion now?
Alrighty, a quick reflection.
If you are reading, applauses and comments can encourage me to share more my personal journey! :)

Title: Techiesâ€™ meetup groups in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

random stories of my life

--
Listen
Share
I moved to Amsterdam two months ago. In the first weeks, I asked on twitter what meetup groups I should know in Amsterdam. I was mainly interested in tech, infrastructure, SRE, DevOps related topics. It got quite a few responses from the people in the area. I thought â€œwhy not collecting them in a blog post?â€
Thanks to all who helped me to compose this list by responding to my tweet. Hope to meet you sometime in the future at one of the events!
This is a list in no particular order. It is basically in the order of the responses I got. I am sure you will find the ones you like. :)
Software Circus
There are ~4K people in the group. Only for Feb; I see three evenings planned already! From their about page:
We are a motley crew of dreamers who are unhealthily obsessed with consuming information and changing ourselves and those around us. We love software, tech and anything (from any discipline) that is going to change the world. Apart from our wider focus, we believe that meetups should be a lot of fun where laughing out loud and meeting new people is built in, not an opt-in extra.
Docker Randstad
A lot of people in the group again!
Learn, Collaborate & Dockerize! Meet other developers and ops engineers in your community that are using and learning about Docker. Docker is an open platform that helps you build, ship and run applications anytime and anywhere. Developers use Docker to modify code and to streamline application development, while operations gain support to quickly and flexibly respond to their changing needs. Docker ensures agility, portability and control for all your distributed apps.
Meetinâ€™up at Picnic
Picnic is the company I work for. ğŸ¤“ It is an online supermarket who delivers groceries to your door in a sustainable way. Picnic has a meetup group that holds regular meetups in their office.
Interested in the latest technologies, sharing your passion for code, ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» or just looking for some drinks, ğŸº food, ğŸ• and good company? Youâ€™ve come to the right place! We host regular talks on all things programming with in-house speakers, in our offices, with our very own bar tap and kitchen. What else could you be asking for? ğŸ˜‰
Continuous Delivery Amsterdam
Looks like Amsterdamâ€™s meetup groups are huge!
This Group will bring software people together to share ideas and experience in the domain of Continuous Delivery. Continuous Delivery addresses the entire software delivery pipeline â€” from CI to testing to deployment to release â€” and addresses technology, process and organization. Anything within that domain will be in scope for our Group.
DevOps Amsterdam
Of course, there is one DevOps meetup group in Amsterdam. Surely, I will join them soon!
Bringing together developers and operations people united in a common goal: destroy silos and remove obstacle to deploy and maintain awesome software and reliable infrastructures. Monitoring, continuous integration, packaging and automated deployment will all be covered. Itâ€™s going to be fun too!
PyLadies Amsterdam
Hi PyLadies! ğŸ‘‹
We are a local chapter of PyLadies, we exist to promote diversity and inclusivity in the Python community.
What we do differently:â€¢ we use a hands-on approach: workshops, group discussions, talks about practical experience, mentorshipâ€¢ we go in-depth with one subject per eventâ€¢ we provide a safe community space for marginalized genders who is interested in Pythonâ€¢ we welcome members of all Python proficiency levels
Amsterdam.rb
The Amsterdam based monthly Ruby meetup! http://amsrb.org /@amsrb (https://twitter.com/amsrb)
Dutch Kubernetes/Cloud-Native Meetup
Meet other developers and users of Kubernetes. Kubernetes is Cloud Native Computing Foundationâ€™s orchestrator for containers at scale. It handles scheduling onto nodes in a compute cluster and actively manages workloads to ensure that their state matches the users declared intentions; runs on any cloud and any hardware. Any skill level is welcome; weâ€™re all new to Kubernetes and we want to create an open, welcoming environment for other Cloud Natives.
Elastic User Group NL
This group is for anyone interested in the Elastic open source projects (Elasticsearch, Kibana, Logstash, and Beats, http://www.elastic.co/products) and related topics. We cover search, logging, analytics & data visualization. We welcome talks on any aspect of data exploration.
Nulab Tech Talks Amsterdam
A series of events dedicated to all things tech. With subjects ranging from web development to Artificial intelligence and generative art, the aim of this Meetup group is to bring forward different technologies, perspectives and discourses from industry experts and passionate makers.
Site Reliability Engineering Amsterdam
This meetup is for everyone interested in SRE. We want to share what is SRE and how it fits into the DevOps way of working. How is reliability defined?Why is it an essential aspect of your IT landscape? We will share experiences and ways to integrate reliability in your application design and architecture.
.NET / dotnet Amsterdam meetup
Weâ€™re an Amsterdam based user group, with talks and events aimed at .NET developers. If youâ€™re a developer from Amsterdam, visiting Amsterdam or live close by Amsterdam, then it would be great to see you at one of our meetups.
This group will hopefully provide a hub for Amsterdamâ€™s diverse and thriving developer community to exchange ideas and keep up to date with the latest movements and shifts in software development.
DevSecOps â€” Netherlands
This meetup group is for anyone interested in securing a software development lifecycle (DevSecOps). To deliver secure innovations and shift security left, organizations must commit to changes in skills, culture, technology and processes.
AmsterdamPHP
A english-speaking group for PHP Developers in and around Amsterdam. Our goal is to grow the local community, search for new developers and spread knowledge and resources.
Amsterdam is a very active technology center for the Netherlands, many companies and people from various countries have chosen this area to settle down and start their companies. PHP has a big role in this and for that reason we created a User Group focused on this area and in doing activities in english to acommodate all of these developers.
GOTO Nights Amsterdam
GOTO Nights are free community events brought to you by the GOTO Conference team. GOTO runs Software Developer Conferences each year in four international cities â€” Amsterdam, Berlin, Copenhagen and Chicago.
Tech topics we are passionate about include Programming Languages and Frameworks (mostly back-end), Event-Driven Architecture, Microservices, Machine Learning, AI (& society), The Human Factor of Tech and IoT to name a few.
PyData Amsterdam
PyData is an educational program of NumFOCUS, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization in the United States. PyData provides a forum for the international community of users and developers of data analysis tools to share ideas and learn from each other. The global PyData network promotes discussion of best practices, new approaches, and emerging technologies for data management, processing, analytics, and visualization. PyData communities approach data science using many languages, including (but not limited to) Python, Julia, and R.
Certainly, there are still plenty of meetups that I havenâ€™t heard of. Feel free to answer to this post, I will gladly add them to the list. :)
Cheers,
Busra
--
--
random stories of my life
Note from 2025: A lot changed in my life but I'd like to keep this blog as it is. I now do my own thing called Humans in Systems. Find me at humansinsystems.com

Getting back to Amsterdam was not going to be easy. I had two options, A: spring for a $200 plane ticket or B: spend $0 on a 24-hour train ride. Amsterdam was to be my last hurrah, and I was going to have a proper blowout. I had about $1200 left, which may seem like a lot, but after doing the math, I was going to need every penny:
Hostel (4 nights): $80
Drugs (1/4 ounce Weed & edibles, 3 grams mushrooms): $120
Drinks (pay old tab?): $150-$200
Concert: $50
Plane Ticket: $300-$400
Food (Doner kebabs/Vending machine burgers): $50
80+120+200+50+400+50=900
1200â€“900=300
*No prostitutes
*No cocaine
120mg Adderall
- 4/10 (10mg upon arrival +10mg after dinner)
- 4/11 (10 @ 10am + 15 after dinner)
- 4/12 (10 @ 10am + 20 before concert)
- 4/13 (15 @ 10am + 15 after)
- 4/14 (20mg pre-plane)
I wasnâ€™t snorting yet, but if I had been, the math would have been much more confusing.
If my calculations were correct, I was left with a $300 cushion. Blowing most of it on a plane ticket was out of the question so I braced myself for the inevitable and headed to the Madrid Puerta de Atocha Almundena Grandes Train Station. Honestly, what really mattered was I still had enough Adderall. Sure, I couldnâ€™t take any on the train, but sometimes sacrifices must be made. Not exactly Sofieâ€™s Choice, but I couldnâ€™t remember the last time I had a full day of sobriety. It was not going to be easy.
The train began boarding just after 10am. I headed to my cabin and crashed immediately. By the time I woke up it was past midnight. I tried going back to sleep with the help of Tylenol PM, but it was too late. My body and mind had finally gotten too much rest. All I could do was lay there and wrestle with withdrawal in between bouts of relieving myself to shit water and vomit in the nearby bathroom. My stomach was demolished. Living on alcohol and speed for 5 weeks will do that to you. It wasnâ€™t as bad as in Paris, but it was close.
I had far too much time to think, and thatâ€™s never good because all roads of thought lead me back to my dad. When you hate someone that much itâ€™s hard not to think of them. After some angry sulking, I picked up a pen and wrote him a letter.
Dad,
If thereâ€™s a hell, I know youâ€™re in it. I doubt there is though. Odds are youâ€™re just rotting in your XL coffin, 6 feet below the ground, shrinking down to bone as youâ€™re eaten by worms and maggots. That gives me comfort. If reincarnation is real, you will no doubt come back as a rat, or a shit-eating pig. The god I believe in wouldnâ€™t allow you to treat a child the way you treated me and still prosper. I donâ€™t care how shitty your parents were, or how bad your youth was, thereâ€™s no excuse.
I didnâ€™t cry when you died. All my tears were used up. When people asked if I was sad, I told them the truth, that I was relieved. You lived much longer than you should have, much longer than I wanted you to. I anticipated your death for so many years that it was an emotional letdown when you died. I felt nothing.
I donâ€™t believe anything you ever told me, not a single word. You left me with no wisdom, only anger, along with the bad habits required to suppress it. You gave me nothing besides the ability to spot sadness and pain in others. I can pick an abused person out of a lineup because of you. Some people may see it as a gift. They can have it. I donâ€™t want it anymore.
Iâ€™m reminded of you every time I see someone stuffing their face, every time I smell pee on the street. Iâ€™m reminded of you when I look in the mirror, and when I write my last name. I want you out of my mind, out of my dreams, out of my DNA for good.
You know I quit comedy because of how fucked up I was? I was scared to be on the road because I feared what Iâ€™d do to myself. My two idols, Mitch Hedberg and Hunter Thompson, both died shortly after you. Hunter took his own life, and Mitch ODâ€™d. I would have met a similar fate if I didnâ€™t quit. I know it, and you should too. Iâ€™m a full-time drug addict/alcoholic bordering on an eating disorder. Itâ€™s hard to be with a woman or make friends because I donâ€™t trust anyone. Itâ€™s even hard to masturbate because youâ€™ve made me associate the act with such depravity. This is your legacy. I know someday Iâ€™ll be better, but it wonâ€™t be thanks to you. Iâ€™ll find my own strength. You can stop looking over me now.
Hereâ€™s one last tidbit before I sign offâ€¦ The only thing I kept of yours was your death certificate. There are no pictures, no keepsakes, only proof that youâ€™re finally fucking dead.
Your Son,
Sam
Youâ€™d think writing a letter like that would have given me solace, but it didnâ€™t. I still felt like shit. As the sun was rising, I closed the window curtain to avoid the light. My roommates protested, and after I lost a vote 3â€“1, I had no choice. The curtain was staying open. So, I laid with a pillow over my face, cursing the world and feeling sorry for myself.
Near Rotterdam, about 4 hours from Amsterdam, my bunkmate shook my leg. I looked up, ready to kill him.
Me: What the fuck man?
Bunkmate: You should see this.
Me: I donâ€™t want to.
Bunkmate: You need to.
Outside our cabin window were tulips, seemingly millions of them, more than the average person will see in a lifetime. I thought my eyes were playing tricks on me. The fields went for miles, like a never-ending rainbow had emerged from the soil, a colorful flipbook the likes of which I couldnâ€™t have imagined. It was spectacular.
Was it, in fact, a message from God? Thatâ€™s how I interpreted it. God was telling me to look up and get out of my head; to allow myself to enjoy the worldâ€™s vibrant colors. He was telling me that everything wasnâ€™t black and white, no matter how hard I tried to make it so. There was happiness out there for me, I just needed to keep my head up and my senses open. The past may have been dark, but the future need not be. It was up to me.
I walked out of the train station with a â€œhoney, Iâ€™m homeâ€ posture. It felt so good to be back in Amsterdam. The canals, the bikes, the smilesâ€¦ Nothing had changed. The answer to the chicken/egg question from earlier, I learned, isâ€¦ Amsterdam makes people better. Usually, itâ€™s the people who make the city. In Amsterdam itâ€™s the other way around. Being there is like drinking a joy serum. No matter the emotional state you arrive in, it will improve the moment you enter the city. If you enter as a 4, youâ€™ll tick up to a 7. If youâ€™re a 7, youâ€™ll reach 10. Few cities, if any, can account for such a positive emotional bump.
For the first time, I knew exactly where my hostel was. Changing locations wasnâ€™t even a consideration. Familiarity and reliability are everything, and that place had both. When I got there, the same guy was manning the front desk.
Me: Remember me?
Manager: Yes, sir. Itâ€™s great to have you back.
Me: Is the jackhammering done?
Manager: Yes, it is.
Me: 3 nights then. Cheapest room. If I hear a jackhammer I get a full refund. Deal?
Manager: Sir, there is no more jackhammering. Nor is there bartering.
Me: Deal or no deal?
Manager: Fine. Deal. Or you could just take me at my word.
Me: Iâ€™ve been on the road for 5 weeks; Iâ€™m done taking people at their word.
Naturally, my first stop was a coffee shop, and NOT the Bob Marley one. There was to be no experimenting this time around. So, to be safe, I got 1/8 ounce of each indica strain I felt best on during my previous stay: Strawberry Cough and Trainwreck. The Raekwon concert was in two days, so taking any chances with a new variety wouldnâ€™t have been smart. God forbid I got a panic attack from some weird sativa strain. Not the time or place to be experimenting.
Weed in tow, I grabbed a cab. My old haunt was calling me.
â€œH. Murrayâ€™s Bar, please. Itâ€™s on Sint Olofspoort, right where it turns into Warmoesstraat.â€
As soon as I opened the bar door, Neil shouted my name, and Lilly hopped to for scratches. Norman was sitting in the same seat, stinking of weed. It was like Iâ€™d returned after only going to the bathroom.
Neil: Sam, you look like shit.
Me: So do both of you. Lilly looks beautiful.
Norman: Itâ€™s good to have you back, friend. We knew youâ€™d be back.
Me: How did you know?
Neil: You forgot to pay your tab.
I pulled out a few grams from my weed container and put them on the bar for Norman, along with $80 for Neil to cover my previous tab.
Neil: I was joking. Put that money back in your damn pocket.
Norman: The weed too.
Neil: Youâ€™re on the house tonight.
Norman: And I have 3 joints rolled.
Me: You generous bastards, you.
It didnâ€™t take long before I was drunk and rolling on the ground with Lilly. If thereâ€™s a dog, Iâ€™m on the ground. Itâ€™s that simple. My memory of the night unfortunately stops there. I must have had a good time though, because I woke up on Normanâ€™s couch, covered with a blanket, a puke bucket next to me. The bucket was not filled, thank goodness.
Norman: You were fucked up last night.
Me: Oh yeah?
Norman: You kept dropping your glass and lighting cigarettes in the bar. Those have always been my moves. And you wouldnâ€™t shut up about that concert youâ€™re going to, Raymond or whatever.
Me: Raekwon.
Norman: Yeah.
Me: Did I do anything else?
Norman: You tried to steal Lilly at the end of the night but thatâ€™s about it.
Me: Eh, not too bad.
After our goodbye, as I was on the way out the door, Norman came running over with a book in his hand.
Norman: You said Hunter was your favorite writer. You should have this. Itâ€™s Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail,1972. Itâ€™s his best work.
Me: I donâ€™t know what to sayâ€¦
Norman: No need to say anything. Safe travels, my friend.
I took a cab back to my hostel, feeling better than I should have. Sometimes having ten drinks with the right people can do that. It has something to do with the spiritual component of a hangover outweighing the physical and mental components.
There were still cold eggs and over-cooked sausages left over from breakfast, so I filled up while watching BBC Sports. Phil Mickelson had just won The Masters. I despised him and still do. That phony. It would have bothered me in the past, but sitting there, I didnâ€™t care at all. My mind was on mushrooms.
I went to the same store and saw the same guy. He remembered me right away.
Manager: Dried Hawaiian right?
Me: How did you remember that?
Manager: When I took lunch, I saw you by the canal, waving at the boats. Looked like you were having a good time.
Me: You saw that?
Manager: Yeah, I ate my lunch right next to you. I was surprised you didnâ€™t notice.
Me: Well, Iâ€™ll be damned. Iâ€™ll take 3 more grams.
Two grams were reserved for my final night, and I didnâ€™t want to take any at the concert, as to avoid a meltdown, so I popped the extra one as soon as I left the store. A gram was enough for a fun, riskless high, and the perfect amount for a day soaking up sun in Vondelpark, the most visited park in Amsterdam and a mushroom-takerâ€™s dream. Not as sprawling as Central Park, but just as welcoming, if not more, and stunningly gorgeous.
There were tons of people sprawled about all over the grass, but not so many where I couldnâ€™t find an isolated nook for myself. Everyone was high on something. Or at least thatâ€™s the way it appeared to me. Maybe they were all completely sober and I was projecting. Yeah, itâ€™s probably that. Either way, the vibes were tremendous.
When the mushrooms kicked in, I was laying in the grass, staring up at the clouds, aligned with the universe. I was in exactly the right place at the right time. I was proud of myself, something I hadnâ€™t been for over a year. Iâ€™d navigated Western Europe all by myself (before smartphones) with nothing but wit, instincts, and Mapquest directions. Iâ€™d been a gentleman to Caroline, and everyone else I encountered for that matter, even that cunt Simon. And, I hadnâ€™t gotten arrested or robbed. I was doing much better than Iâ€™d been giving myself credit for.
For the second part of the trip, I laid like a grass angel, listening to my iPod shuffle. A shuffle is great when youâ€™re tripping because each song comes as a surprise you can hardly believe. Your sense of linear time is gone; your brain wants randomness. Plus, your favorite song may turn into your least favorite. You never know. On my trips, I just get in and tell the driver to drive. If you give him a destination, heâ€™s only going to get lost anyway. Might as well let him take you wherever he wants. Sometimes you end up at a carnival, sometimes a funeral. Thatâ€™s the fun of it.
When â€œGlaciers of Iceâ€ came on, I knew that would be the defining song of my trip. Thereâ€™s always one and you know it as soon as it comes on. The song opens with an interlude in which Ghostface, eloquently, talks about shoes.
Yo, I got a crazy idea how to do Clarks nowCheck it out, boom, this is how you freak â€™em, boomYou go get, you go get the cream joints right? BoomNow now, all you, all you dye, is this shit right here, boomAnd this, you know what Iâ€™m sayinâ€™? Any color you wantBut itâ€™d be like, blue and cream, you know what Iâ€™m sayinâ€™?Shit like that, niggas donâ€™t even knowBut, son, word is bond, Iâ€™ma rock niggas this summer.
The lyrics gave me an epiphany. New shoes were exactly what I needed. It wasnâ€™t even a thought before, but now, all of a sudden, they were a necessity. Suddenly my brown converse sitting only a few feet away in the shade looked like they were on their death bed, barely holding on for dear life. Iâ€™d considered their condition before, but never while hallucinating. Their pain and exhaustion were personified. Their glow was gone. After a long, honorable life, they were dying. No more poop accidents, no more torn laces, no more broken backsâ€¦ It was time to rest.
After lacing them properly one last time, I gently held them in my hands for a eulogy. It was very much like the end of The Big Lebowski when Walter and the Dude spread Donnieâ€™s ashes. â€œShoes, you were a good pair of shoes. You loved the outdoors and exploring the streets of New Yorkâ€¦â€ It was a sad moment, perhaps even sadder than my dadâ€™s death, which made me wonder what would have happened if I were high on mushrooms at his deathbed. I was high on weed. Would I have cried, instead of just staring at him indifferently? Would I have comforted him instead of telling him how much hurt he caused me? There was too much hate in my heart to have any perspective at the time. Mushrooms would have removed that hate and allowed me to see clearly. Or I could have lost my mind and ran out of the hospital like a lunatic.
After putting on my slides, I neatly laced up the Converse and placed them in the sun for their final rest like they were fallen soldiers. It was time to find their successor.
Only the perfect pair would do, no discretion, no skimping. So, I set out on foot, still good and high, to scour the city for shoes stores and skate shops. I would have done a Google search but using electronics on mushrooms is near impossible. You get the ick from the whole experience.
For the first 30 minutes I didnâ€™t make it far because I got distracted by a 4-person public urinal. We didnâ€™t have those in America and that confused me. Are we more insecure about our dicks being seen? Would homeless people just end up shitting in them? Do politicians want our cities to smell like pee? Is there a benefit to that? All I had were questions. You stare at a urinal too long though, and people will start to think youâ€™re a pervert, so I had to move on even though I would have been content to stand there all day fleshing out my theories.
You remember in Wayneâ€™s World, the way Wayne looked at his dream guitar through the window of the store, the way he was hypnotized? â€œShe must be mine, oh yes, she must be mine.â€ Thatâ€™s exactly how I felt when I saw my shoes sitting on a display in the window of a skate shop. They were cream Nike Dunks, with brown and yellow stitching. At a glance, you could have mistaken them for chocolate covered bananas. I stood admiring them for so long the salesman came out to ask if I wanted to try them on.
Me: No need. Do you have a 10.5?
Salesman: Let me check. Would you like to come in?
Me: No, I like it out here.
He brought back my size, and I paid him in cash outside the store like we were exchanging money for contraband. Going in would have ruined my vibe. I was thriving under the sun. Like a bear discarding unwanted food from a garbage can, I tore the box open and tossed it. Slowly, I put them on, triggering an instant religious experience. Suddenly, I felt pious, like Iâ€™d just left confessional with a clean slate. They inspired hope. Iâ€™d always heard black people talk about the ecstasy of lacing up a pair of crispy new shoes, but Iâ€™d never experienced it myself, at least not since I was a kid. And never on mushrooms.
That night, to save money, I drank a pint of whiskey and wandered while coming down from my trip. My favorite sex worker was on my mind, so once I was good and drunk, I headed over there, like a murderer returning to the scene of the crime to experience the thrill again. I waved, but she didnâ€™t recognize me. If she had, I may have had a choice to make. A line item can always be crossed out. The pimp surely would have recognized me, but I didnâ€™t see him, thank goodness. Knowing me I probably would have said something like, â€œSorry about the ass slap. I didnâ€™t mean to cause any waves. Can you forgive me?â€ It was for the best that none of us crossed paths again.
I called it a night early, so I wouldnâ€™t be too drunk when I booked my plane ticket. Lord knows I tend to fuck up seemingly simple tasks like buying anything online, even when Iâ€™m sober. I used the hostel computer to compare flight prices, before settling on an American Airlines Flight leaving in 3 days, at 5pm (17 hundred hours). It cost $320. Things were finally working out, so I decided to push my luck and search for a new hostel for my final night in Amsterdam. Mine had been nothing but reliable, but I needed something else, a place where I didnâ€™t have to interact with anyone. I had plenty of notes to go through, along with memories to piece together, and I needed some place calm to do it.
One place, more than any other, caught my eye. It was an outdoor campground 20-minutes from the city center. From the pictures on their website, it looked like shit. It had trailers (like trailer park trailers) and no amenities other than a communal grill, a firepit, and some bathrooms. It was janky, but for some peace and quiet, it seemed like a fair trade. Not to mention it was cheaper than my current hostel. There were no bars to take my money either. Just me, a bottle of whiskey, mushrooms, weed and cigs. I had my supplies; it was time to go to work.
I slept in until almost noon the next morning so I could conserve both money and energy for the concert that night. It was the best sleep I got on the whole trip, perhaps because I slept with my shoes on the bed next to me. I read, drank coffee, smoked spliffs and people-watched for the entire afternoon. When Iâ€™d get overstimulated, Iâ€™d take a short walk along the canal then return to the coffee shop to put more stimulants in my body. I snacked on chocolate cookies and bananas (you see why the colorway appealed to me) while people came and went. They too reminded me of the tulips, with their pastel-colored outfits and quirky glasses. Everything matched because it clashed. That was the style, and really Amsterdam in a nutshell. They embraced differences.
The concert was at 8pm, but lubing up was essential, so I got to the Melkveg early to pound a few beers before heading to the venue. While drinking, I noticed a weed shop across the street. The concert wasnâ€™t starting for another hour, so browsing was in order. My shirt pocket already contained a large joint, but you never know when youâ€™ll need more. Inside, one item caught my eye. I inquired at the counter.
Me: What is a space cake?
Lady: Itâ€™s our strongest edible. Take just a bite at first. It can really knock you out.
Me: Iâ€™ll take one.
Ignoring her advice, I ate half of it. She must have had me confused with an amateur.
The venue was smaller than I expected. With it nearly empty, it felt more like a club than a concert hall. The DJ was intricately spinning Wu-Tang tracks to set the mood for the show, but he may as well have just plugged my iPod in; the set would have been no different. My joint was locked and loaded but smoking it right away wasnâ€™t the move. Waiting for Rae to instruct me was. I found a comfortable place against the wall, just left of the stage, to watch the show away from the gaggle of rabid fans who wanted to rap along to every word and throw their hands in the air on command. The security guards were right next to me too, which, if nothing else, made it a safe spot in case things got hairy. I had it all scoped out to a T.
When Raekwon came out, everyone went fucking nuts, how they do. I can never bring myself to go nuts, no matter how excited I am. A hole in one would probably inspire a fist pump, but I canâ€™t see myself going any further than that. â€œWooHooâ€ is just not in my vocab.
Raekwon: Hellooo, Amsterdam! Let me see you put your weed in the air!
I proudly held my joint up with everyone else.
Raekwon: Now light that shit!
We all did what he said, exhaling at the same time. It looked like a bomb had gone off the way the smoke billowed up towards the ceiling. Bonnaroo couldnâ€™t compare. Aside from my breath being impeded, it was a beautiful moment, everyone connecting through the communal high, our energies aligned. We werenâ€™t just smoking weed; we were basking in the freedom of being able to do so. Afterall, thatâ€™s why we were there.
After a few hits, the oversized joint fell out of my hands like the mug at the end of Usual Suspects. When I went to pick it up, I fumbled it again, along with my lighter. My hands were completely limp. The space cake had taken hold, and my motor skills were gone. Like a heroin addict fresh off a hit, I stood bent over, swinging my arms to gather my lost items. Then, my feet stopped working and I went into full DiCaprio Wolf of Wall Street-mode, clawing at the walls to prevent from falling. My vision was so blurred that Raekwon may as well have been Cedric The Entertainer. I would have had no clue. Even the music made no sense. High does not do it justice. I was in outer space. Laying down was my only option, so I found the closest speaker, climbed atop it, and went directly into fetal position. The vibrations were comforting the way bouncing on your motherâ€™s knee was when you were a baby. I closed my eyes and drifted away.
When I woke up to a bouncer nudging me, the lights were on, and everyone was gone.
Bouncer: We tried to let you sleep as long as we could, but we have to close up now. Can I call you a car? Only in Amsterdam are the bouncers that nice.
Me: When did the show end?
Bouncer: About an hour ago.
The next morning, I checked out of the hostel and grabbed a cab to head to the trailer park. The drive was odd. It looked like we were driving through Nebraska. There were no more flowers, just fields of wild grass and dirt roads. I wondered just where the fuck we were going.
Me: Have you ever taken anyone to this hostel?
Cabbie: I didnâ€™t even know there was anything out here.
There were hippies visible as soon as we pulled in, which made me uneasy. A group of 3 dudes, approached me as soon as I got out of the cab, all of them smelling like patchouli,
Guy: Whatâ€™s up man? We weâ€™re the only ones here. Come hang out. Weâ€™re playing (hacky) sack. Do you smoke weed?
Me: Obviously. Weâ€™re at a trailer park in Amsterdam.
Guy: Good point.
Me: Maybe later fellas. Iâ€™m going to chill in my trailer and relax.
Guy: Ok cool. Weâ€™ll see you later.
The trailer was nicer and larger than I expected. It even had a sink, which was ideal, because that meant Iâ€™d only have to leave the trailer to use the bathroom. The hippies were were across the way, on the other side of the bathrooms, so I had a whole section to myself. A solitary night was almost guaranteed.
I wanted to get into the mushrooms before the sun went down, so as soon as I familiarized myself with the surrounding area, I chewed up the remaining two grams and got right to it. There was a pond only a few hundred feet away, so I waited there for the action to begin. I submerged my feet in the cool water and watched the frogs hop around. The trip began as soon as the â€œribbitsâ€ started to make me laugh. Itâ€™s an inherently funny sound, but at that moment it was goddamn hilarious. The sound was so fun, I started making it myself, trying to mimic them. When they ribbited back, I knew for certain I was one of them. I got down in their posture and did my best to hop around like them. If someone saw me, they no doubt would have called the police, or even animal control. I was out of my mind.
The laughter and lightheartedness came to an end when the sun went down, so I went back to my trailer to buckle up for the rest of the ride. Thatâ€™s when the mushrooms kicked me in the dick. Iâ€™d taken the same amount as last time, but for whatever reason, I was 10 times as high.
Soon, everything turned red. It was like there was a red filter on my eyeballs. Even my skin looked red. I turned the sink on to splash water on my face, but it looked like blood was flowing from the faucet. Then, I looked up at the mirror. DO NOT make that mistake during a bad trip. During a good trip, maybe, but never during a bad one. It was fiery red, and my face was peeling off. Blood was dripping from my chin. And there was this awful sound ringing in my ears, like the kind you hear when someone presses the red emergency button at a nuclear power plant. My brain was in crisis. What I needed to do, I thought, was get naked.
As I was taking my pants off, it struck me that I was still wearing my sandals, not my new shoes. â€œWhat the fuck was I thinking!?â€
As soon as I put them on, my vision went back to normal. The blaring alarm stopped. It was magic. To make sure I wasnâ€™t losing my mind (I was absolutely losing my mind), I took them off again. Everything turned red. I put them on once more. No red.
Then, I heard a knock at the door.
â€œOH SHIT,â€ I whispered, putting my clothes on.
If youâ€™ve ever taken hallucinogens, you know a knock at the door is the last thing you want to hear. The sound itself is paralyzing. Anything can be behind that door, and I mean ANYTHING. There are no limitations to what the brain can conjure.
Then, there was a second knock.
They werenâ€™t going to give up, I could feel it in my bones. My fears were on the other side of that door, and I needed to face them. Most trips, in some way or another, are about facing your fears.
I walked over to the door and placed my hand on it to see if I could feel any weird vibrations. Nothing. Then I grabbed the knob and turned it slowly, hoping the monster had already left. He hadnâ€™t. In front of me was a smiling, shirtless hippie with dreadlocks.
Guy: Sorry if I scared you, man. Iâ€™m Liam. I wanted to invite you to join the group. Weâ€™ve got a fire going and weâ€™re just jamming out. Itâ€™s pretty chill.
Me: Ummmmâ€¦
Liam: Those shoes. Theyâ€™re amazing.
Me: Yeah, they just saved my life.
Liam: How?
Me: Itâ€™s pointless to explain. Iâ€™m on mushrooms.
Liam: Nice. Me too. We all are.
Before I could tell him I didnâ€™t do well in groups, Liam walked me over and started introducing me.
Liam: This is Sam. Heâ€™s really high. Be nice to him.
Guy 2: Sweet shoes. They look like chocolate covered bananas.
Me: Right?
We hung out for a few hours. While they jammed out, I just stared into the fire, listening to the crackling sounds and appreciating the lack of conversation. It brought me back to the University of Iowa, where weâ€™d have bonfires a few times a week, and where Iâ€™d done mushrooms for the first time. It was a time before my mourning started, before the year of death began. I was a different person then, more childlike. I didnâ€™t feel that way anymore. Scars were developing, I was becoming more callous. Iâ€™d always felt like an old soul, but now I was beginning to feel just plain old, or at least like an adult. I knew the trip would be my last blowout before having to go back to face my problems, and Iâ€™d just begun to feel it. Running was no longer an option if I wanted to grow, and I very much did. I just didnâ€™t know how.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

Title: What did I learn at Employer Branding Day 2023 Amsterdam?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
They say never quit chasing the dream!
After two years of effort, I finally could be part of the worldâ€™s largest gathering of employer branding professionals organised by Brett Mitchingtonâ€™s Employer Branding College in Amsterdam (one of my favourite cities).
Employer and Talent Branding is ever-evolving, and the best way to learn is to connect with practitioners. After attending the conference yesterday, I could say this was worth investing time, money and effort. What a brilliant showcase of amazing case studies (no gyaan) of varied organisations and passionate EB professionals. Hereâ€™s a run-down on few of the key learnings I could share with you.
ASML Presentation: Collaboration is key
Nanci (Global Head of Employer Brand at ASML) shared the importance of collaboration in employer branding. While she sat in the comms function, she talked about her work with HR, business, internal comms and brand teams to be successful. Over 10k employees participated in the EVP process, and her key KPIs were brand strength/survey (Universum). She also showcased a good example of an internal career fair as a way to strengthen the brand internally.
Takeaways â€” 1) Collaboration 2) Measure against Key objective. 3) EB is a team play
Activision Blizzard Presentation: Get strategic yet creative
Activision Blizzardâ€™s presentation took us back to building a solid EB vision. Alex and Briana spoke about aligning it for the leadership and business objectives to people strategy. Employee advocacy is all about education, community, resources and gamification. The team shared the breakdown of their content elements and urged the community to build insights around what kind of content works for which TG.
An awesome example of creativity â€” Activision put in an in-game recruitment advertising. Makes sense since a lot of their users may be target candidates. Smart!
Lego Presentation: Playful and Employee driven
Legoâ€™s iconic brand still needed to build an employer brand targeted to the candidates. I loved their brand framework, which clarifies the overall brand strategy. Their EB team also creates various infographics/assets shared with the recruiters for candidate experience. Clicks from the Bricks program attracted user-generated content, which always attracts better engagement than corporate photos.
The crux for me was how aligned their employer brand was to the heart of what Lego stands for. Playful and fun! Kudos to Andrew and Sarah.
Indeed and Glassdoor: Well-Being Score
In the last few years, well-being has become integral to employee experience. Indeed has launched a new well-being score on employersâ€™ profiles, which assigns the scores based on employee reviews regarding Happiness, Purpose, Satisfaction and Stress-free experience. It provides a clear view to candidates if the organisation priortizes well-being and employees resonate with the promise.
More information â€” â€‹â€‹https://www.indeed.com/employers/work-wellbeing
Kaufland Romania: Innovation and Differentiation in EB
Esteraâ€™s presentation was truly differentiated as she passionately discussed diversity, inclusion and equity as part of employer branding. Beyond having created an ACCESS program to hire differently-abled talent, they hosted a hackathon to create an app for their target audience. Using TikTok influencers, they created a campaign to communicate and engage people with hearing impairments. They also opened a supermarket in a world-famous GTA5 game to attract candidates in-game applications. Both of these garnished wow among the audience!
DanceTalk â€” https://cariere.kaufland.ro/diversitate/kaufland-dance-talk.html
Siemens Presentation: Joint ownership of EB
Stefanie from Siemens started her presentation by sharing a long legacy and broad business range Siemens works for. One of the unique things she mentioned was that EB is a joint function between comms and HR. Their EB content always gets much better engagement than business content, which shows the power of peopleâ€™s content.
Impact Metrics â€” 2X time spent on the careers page. The content reached 3 million candidates.
Primark Presentation: Recruitment Marketing Unleashed
Steven and Neil shared some amazing examples of recruitment marketing done by Primark for retail roles. They have created unique job description pages and programmatic job ads for recruitment marketing. Neil also shared integrating employer branding across employee and candidate life cycles.
Mondelez Presentation: Mind the Gap of Internal Branding
Tedâ€™s presentation of Mondelez was one of the stand-out talks for me. Not only was he engaging, straightforward and no-BS, but he also shared an underrated element of employer branding for retaining top talent. He shared a very simple and useful method of measuring EB impact aligned to the external and internal objectives that include social engagement, eNPS scores, hiring/attraction measures and engagement index.
This slide is gold!
Haleon Presentation: Human Experience and Branding
A spin-off from another pharmaceutical giant, starting with no name or purpose. Itâ€™s a human-driven story to build the entire organisation ground up by leveraging human expectations and experience and co-build the org with them. Rhian and the team involved their employees in building the Haleon experience by using surveys and postcards to the leaders and leveraging the passion of their own employees while building the brand.
Power of Partnership CPO and CMO
For long, itâ€™s said that customer and talent are two different target audiences and needs, although this slide sums up why they are aligned in their expectations. Itâ€™s important that marketing and HR needs to align and treat them in equal measure. Simon shared this amazing insight.
How often do your CHRO and CMO talk?
Team LIDL: Candidate & Employee Surveys
Catherine and Antanio shared some nuggets about using candidate and employee surveys to build EVP pillars. They talked about measuring the perception vs reality and identifying gaps as part of EVP or Lidl VP. Itâ€™s an important step to find the balance between reality and inspiration.
EY Presentation: The Balancing Act
Matthew started the presentation by asking which shoes are we wearing. (Literally throwing the shoes as recruiters :D ). Recruiters need to stop self-congratulating themselves for things like hyper-personalized reach. Letâ€™s keep it real. EY, with over 400k employees and 170 EB specialists, have worked hard to build business cases to expand its capabilities. Along with him, Farrah shared various tech initiatives across recruiting and employee life cycles. I am sure Matthew Jefferyâ€™s passionate talk inspired many!
This is how EY leverages tech for talent.
EveryoneSocial: Prioritize Distribution
Cameron spoke about prioritising distribution over content creation. Thanks to the algorithms of big social media firms, distribution has become a big challenge. He shared an interesting case study of Amazon where, by using employee advocacy tools, they solved the distribution problem. He also mentioned that the organic reach is dead and we have to do targeted investing for distribution.
Two simple reasons: People engage with people. Networks prioritise peopleâ€™s content over the brand.
Short Video for Employer Branding: TikTok Tom
Since the rise of short videos, showcasing work culture and office videos has become a #WorkTok trend. Many companies have chosen this tool for engagement and a fun way to show their culture. Tom talked about some examples of organisations letting employees use this medium to share their stories.
Click here to learn more about #WorkTok.
(P.S. The emCee made Tom famous by calling him TikTok Tom)
Employer Branding Leaders and capability-building
In the concluding remarks, Brett talked about the need for employer branding leaders to take ownership of creating capabilities and work with leaders to build strong business cases to make this a full-fledged business function. This is one of the most exciting professions in the world, and responsibility is now with the leaders in the room to transform.
Hereâ€™s the quick framework to build a strong EB function and impact the business.
Huge shoutout to Brett for bringing passionate employer brand professionals under one roof and showing his vision for this profession. Employer Branding is no longer a side hustle TA folks would do, but more organisations are realising the value of employer (talent) brand to the business. After all, if people are the most important asset to the business, attracting and retaining them needs conscious efforts beyond operational talent management and acquisition. Also, a shout-out to Andrea for helping me in the process. I met some amazing folks, and this is my learning content from the conference â€” a real ROI of the trip!
It was lovely to meet you Google Dave!
I sincerely hope that this community grows globally and in India as well. I took a small step to create an EB community in India with over 30 employer brand professionals nationwide. Our conversations give us a sense of belonging and learning and help us to connect/grow together. This profession needs more leadership support beyond a nice-to-have IC person doing everything. If you are an employer branding professional in India, do get in touch with me.
Asta-la-vista #WorldEBDay! Bedankt!
(P.S) Some bonus fun nuggets from the conference where participants had a ball :D
youtube.com
--
--
1
Employer Branding Leader. I write everything about HR, employer branding & life :) Views are personal.
