Title: Frontend Developers Love and Vue.Js Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Vuejs Amsterdam conference was amazing with over 1100 frontend developers and a screen of 180 degrees. It was amazing. The food was incredible, never seen such good catering at an event. They were very long days from 8:50 till 18:30 with 2 breaks of a half hour and a lunch break of an hour and a half. 12 talks per day. Very intense but very cool
The first day was all things frontend so not just Vue.js.
The future of JavaScript bundlers â€” Johannes Ewald â€” webpack core team
This was a great talk on what the future will be like and will we need things like webpack to make sure we can write code the right way and bundle it together. The browsers of course are not ready for this and that is why webpack is so necessary but in the future webpackâ€™s purpose will be different.
New Features of Webpack 5 â€” Sean T. Larkin â€” webpack core team
Sean talked about the changes we are going to see in webpack 5 and how it is going to be really boring as they are doing so much behind the scenes that we will not notice much changes but our build times will be much faster.
Elegance of Movement with reactive Angular Animations â€” Elena Gancheva
This was a nice talk on animations using angular and what not to do so as things come across as natural movements.
You donâ€™t know Microfrontends â€” Luca Mezzalira & Max Gallo
Interesting talk on breaking things down to create micro frontends.
Angular and Webcomponents â€” Ana Cidre and Sherry List
This was a really interesting talk on angular web components that just left everyone thinking oh my god angular why do you make things so complicated. Itâ€™s incredible at how many people dislike angular because itâ€™s just complicated for no reason at all. Still it was a good talk. I think it would put anyone off trying to choose angular over Vue.
Transforming your Web Application into a PWA â€” Why and How? â€” Gijs Weterings
This was a great and interesting talk on service workers and Progressive web apps which is something that is super important right now especially since google added it to the google store and it now has full browser support but it was good to see how easy it is to setup and how the notifications work and that you can only ask the user once to install it on their home screen so you have to time that properly. PWAâ€™s are interesting for the right project but are for sure worth looking into.
The Fresh Jest of Bel-Air â€” Rick Hanlon
This was a great talk on testing with Jest. Jest has come a long way since we started testing it out a year ago. Now I would for sure choose it over Jasmine, Mocha or Chai. Rick showed us some really cool things you can do with it to make your tests cleaner and for sure we should all be doing testing even though most people arenâ€™t as it takes time. Writing tests means less bugs later on. Also when people learn to write tests they think of things from a different point of view so itâ€™s always good to have a team working with tests.
Rest, GraphQL & gRPC â€” David den Toom
This was a great talk on graphQL. I love graphQL and would be so great to work with it. It basically just gives you back what you need from the JSON as opposed to giving you the full JSON like in Rest. Itâ€™s just nice. Perhaps we shall work with it in the future.
What is new with Gatsby.js â€” Kyle Mathews
This was an interesting talk on Gatsby by the creator of Gatsby and seeing how much it has improved. He has done a great job and itâ€™s pretty cool but itâ€™s for react based apps so something I wonâ€™t be using but good to know how it works etc.
What its like to be a full time open source maintainer â€” Evan You â€” Creator of Vue
This was interesting to see what Evanâ€™s life is like as an open source maintainer, how he explains to his family that he gives his work away for free and then people donate money to him so he keeps working on it. Also he talked about how it just happened and then decided to give up his full time job to maintain Vue.js full time.
Automated Scaffolding with Schematics (Angular) â€” Natalia Venditto
This talk left everyone thinking â€˜Seriously angular is there no better way?â€™ It was a good talk on schematics and I can see itâ€™s use case on certain projects so that you set up everything once and then install it so that all projects have the same folder setup and global styles etc but it is a lot of work and something I would really have to test out and play around with before going ahead and using it. Good but complicated but then again thatâ€™s Angular for you.
Day 2 â€” Vue conference
State of the Vuenion â€” Evan You â€” creator of Vue
This was a great talk on the future of Vue and what is being done to make it better. It was also good to see the statics. 700,000 weekly active users, 3.3 million downloads a month on NPM and 461 million hits a month on jsDelivr CDN. Evan also talked about web components in Vue and how the CLI supports building as native Web Components.
Hot Vue â€” Guillaume CHAU â€” Vue.js core team member
This talk was a last minute add in as Sara Drasner was ill and couldnâ€™t make it. It was a great talk on differences between server side rendering, single page applications and static pages and the benefits and differences between them all.
Vue.js for Lâ€™oreal, a case study- Tim Benniks
This was an incredible talk on how Lâ€™oreal are using Vue across all their brands. Their aim is that all brand websites will be on the same platform, will have the same technology stack and will adhere to the same KPIâ€™s. Lâ€™oreal Paris has 60 markets which all need localisations. They deal with RTL, non-latin fonts, different KPIâ€™s, different 3rd party integrations and local market adaptations. Lâ€™oreal Paris â€” no-js version, SEO, mobile first, progressively enhanced, async/lazy, fast. And to do all this they use Vue component files, vue devtools, vuex, vue-cli, cli-plugin-unit-jest, vue-test-utils, webpack wrapped by vue-cli-service, webpack-chain for configuration of site core helix structure, aslant â€” configured by vue-cli. Why Vue? Because it is simple to use.
NativeScript-Vue + ML = The Great MiniBar Challenge: MixoLogy â€” Jen Looper
This talk was really good fun from making cocktails to creating an app with nativeScript Vue and was interesting to see how easy it is to do.
GraphQL + Apollo + Vue.js = Magic â€” Sara Vieira
Great talk on GraphQL with Apollo and Vue. Really love GraphQL and how easy it is to query. For sure one day we will be doing stuff with graphQL.
Media for everyone â€” how to make your Vue Apps accessible for all users â€” Maya Shavin
Great talk on accessibility and how to make your apps more accessible. She showed us how we can use axe-core as a chrome extension to test our sites for accessibility with guidelines of how we can fix things. Also NoCoffee Simulator to test contrasts for people with vision problems.
Desktop Applications with Vue â€” Natalia Tepluhina â€” CTO at Vue Vixens
Interesting talk on how to build desktop applications using Vue. Not something I see us doing any time soon but good to know itâ€™s possible with Vue instead of just ionic.
Designing Components in Vue â€”Damian Dulisz â€” Vue core team member
Great talk on Vue components, how you shouldnâ€™t build them and how you should especially using slots and named slots. It was nice to see the contrast with how easy it is to create clean components and some great examples of slot uses.
Latest news on Vue Vixens
This was a mini talk on how vue vixens has grown ove the year. An initiative to try to get more women into programming by creating workshops etc
Latest news on CodeSandbox â€” Ives van Hoorne â€” Creator of CodeSandbox
This was a mini talk on what is happening next in CodeSandbox a tool for sharing code created by a 22 year old so he could share code with colleagues when he was working remote. Itâ€™s now a very successful project used by millions of people including me. Now he is working on it full-time with an amazing team to make it even better. He is amazing.
Full Stack Vue in the Era of Serverless Computing â€” Nader Dabit â€” Developer Advocate at Amazon Web Service
This was a really cool talk on how you can deploy to Amazon using aws-amplify and how you donâ€™t even need any backend developers because you donâ€™t need any servers. Really really cool.
Phenomenal design patterns in Vue using Vuex with Spiders â€” Jacob Schatz
This was a really cool talk on how to create your forms by building a form builder component kinda like creating your own form components that can be reused with different variations.
Day 3 â€” Vue
How to craft a Vue CLI Plugin â€” Guillaume CHAU â€” Vue Core Team
This was a great talk on how to create a plugin in Vue. Would be cool to do it one day and Guillaume showed us how it is actually quite simple to do.
Static Site Generation is Awesome â€” Alex Kyriakidis and Rolf Haug Vue School
This was a great talk on when you should use static pages instead of a single page application as it is easier to index and crawl and how hidden and visible content is available on initial render. They also talked about asyncData which runs before loading the page component and how to use the generate property to generate dynamic routes.
Everythingâ€™s a plugin: Understanding webpack from the inside out â€”Sean T. Larkin â€” webpack core team member
Sean did a great talk on webpack plugins and how weback is built from plugins, how it builds the graph and how a module gets to the browser with webpack. Really in depth behind the webpack scenes kinda stuff but very interesting.
Make your Vue apps Lighter by being lazy â€” Eduardo San Martin Morote â€” vue core team
This was a really cool talk where Eduardo explained what tree shaking was â€” dead code elimination and how webpack works to eliminate this dead code and how in general to make your apps lighter by lazy loading your routes for example or prefetching certain components.
Empowering Vue with TypeScript, Inversify, Vuex and some other super tools. â€” Quique Fdez. Guerra
This was a great talk by Quique and he really knows his stuff by I have no intentions of using typescript in Vue right now. Who knows in the future but for now I love Vueâ€™s simplicity and adding typescript is just not necessary. Backend developers need types as it is what they are used to and I can see the reasons behind it but am not sure if we all need to be going down that road. But he also talked about Nuxt and universal Vue applications and how they work. Also he gave us some great tips such as making small components, use linting, use conventions for names, doing tests, continuously improving your code and being ready to change everything.
Introduction to Nuxt.js â€” Nuxt explained Visually â€” Gregg Pollack â€” Founder of Vue Mastery
Great talk by Greg on how Nuxt works. I pretty much had already done this course and as I am creating a talk on Nuxt I knew all about this but was good to see how others were not so familiar and also good to know that I am doing everything right.
Nuxt.js 2019 â€” Donâ€™t miss the NEWS! â€” Sebastian Chopin â€” Creator of Nuxt
I had already had a sneak preview to what was coming up in Nuxt from my chat the previous night but was good to hear again and what was impressive was to see the companies that are trusting Nuxt, Adobe, Microsoft, Gitlab, Groupon, Yahoo, Lacoste, Fox News and many many more big companies.
Next Level Jest Testing with Vue.js â€” Roman Kuba
A great talk on testing with just in Vue with some great examples of testing async. Would love to have the time to deep dive into this and write more tests with jest.
Accessibility with Vue.js â€” Callum Macrae â€” Author of VueJS up and running
Great talk by Callum on accessibility by showing us what it was like for a blind person to use the web and how we can improve this and test things by using screen readers to see for ourselves. It really shows how important things like alt tags are or using the correct html semantics like a <button> for a button instead of an <input> or <a> tag for example.
Visualisations using SVG, Canvas, and WebGL in Vue â€” Chris Fritz â€” Vue core team
Really cool talk on using svgs and when you should be using them and what they can do and why you shouldnâ€™t be using CSS for something that an SVG can be used for.
I think I have managed to cover everything that happened during the 3 days in Amsterdam. It was action packed and my highlight was getting to hang out with all the amazing speakers and personally meet Evan You, such an amazing person and so friendly too. It was worth every penny and I will for sure be back at Vuejs Amsterdam and Frontend Developer Love next year.
--
--
1
Head Developer Advocate at Bit (bit.dev)

Title: Discover the Top 10 Must-See Museums in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam is a city brimming with history, culture, and creativity. From world-class art to fascinating science exhibits, the cityâ€™s museums offer something for every interest.
Whether youâ€™re an art lover, history enthusiast, or simply curious about the world, Amsterdam has it all. Hereâ€™s a guide to the Top 10 Museums in Amsterdam, ranked from the most famous down to the hidden gems.
Step into the world of Dutch art and history at the Rijksmuseum, one of the most iconic museums in the world. Home to masterpieces from the Dutch Golden Age, including Rembrandtâ€™s The Night Watch and Vermeerâ€™s The Milkmaid, this museum offers an unparalleled journey through the artistic and historical achievements of the Netherlands. A must-see for art lovers and history buffs alike.
The Van Gogh Museum is an essential stop for art lovers. It houses the largest collection of Vincent van Goghâ€™s work, from his early pieces to his later masterpieces like Sunflowers. This museum offers a comprehensive view of his artistic evolution and troubled life, making it one of the most visited art museums in the world.
The Anne Frank House is a deeply moving and poignant experience. Walk through the actual hiding place where Anne Frank wrote her famous diary during World War II. The museum offers a powerful look into the life of Anne Frank and the horrors of the Holocaust, preserving her legacy and inspiring future generations. Be sure to book tickets in advance as this museum is highly popular.
The NEMO Science Museum is a hands-on adventure that will ignite your curiosity. With interactive exhibits on everything from physics to engineering, this museum makes science fun and engaging. Located on a striking green building by the waterfront, NEMO is an exciting destination for families, school groups, or anyone fascinated by how the world works.
As a historic port city, Amsterdamâ€™s National Maritime Museum delves into the Netherlandsâ€™ rich maritime past. Explore a replica of a 17th-century Dutch East India Company ship, and engage with interactive exhibits that bring the stories of exploration, trade, and naval power to life. Perfect for history enthusiasts and families.
For cinema lovers, the Eye Filmmuseum offers a thrilling deep dive into the world of film. Located on the banks of the IJ River in a striking futuristic building, the museum showcases the evolution of cinema from its early film reel days to modern digital technology. With screenings, immersive exhibits, and a vibrant program of film events, this museum is a haven for film buffs.
Get a fascinating look inside the human body at Body Worlds Amsterdam. This museum features real, preserved human specimens, offering a unique perspective on anatomy, health, and human life. With detailed exhibits on how our bodies function, itâ€™s an eye-opening and educational experience that goes far beyond skin deep.
Located in the heart of Amsterdamâ€™s Red Light District, Red Light Secrets offers an unfiltered look at the world of legalized sex work. Through personal stories and interactive exhibits, youâ€™ll gain insight into the lives of sex workers, the history of the district, and the social dynamics of Amsterdamâ€™s famous red-light culture. A thought-provoking museum thatâ€™s as informative as it is unique.
Micropia takes you into a world most of us canâ€™t see: the microscopic world of microbes. With interactive displays and educational exhibits, Micropia explores the tiny organisms that shape our worldâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom bacteria and viruses to fungi and algae. This museum offers a fascinating, hands-on experience for anyone curious about the invisible forces at play in our everyday lives.
The Amsterdam Toy Museum is a delightful trip back in time, perfect for both kids and adults. This quirky museum features a vast collection of toys from the 19th and 20th centuries, including dolls, trains, and games. Whether youâ€™re revisiting childhood memories or sharing the experience with your little ones, this museum is a nostalgic and fun stop for all ages.
While these museums are fantastic, donâ€™t forget that Amsterdam itself is a living exhibit. Whether youâ€™re strolling along the iconic canals, wandering through historic neighborhoods, or simply savoring a stroopwafel at a local cafÃ©, the cityâ€™s rich history and vibrant culture are all around you. Even if you see all the museums on this list, thereâ€™s still so much to explore in this beautiful city.
Have you checked out any of these museums or discovered hidden gems of your own? Let us know in the comments belowâ€Šâ€”â€Šweâ€™d love to hear your recommendations!
ğŸ’¡Quick Tip: Donâ€™t forget to lock your while you explore the cityâ€™s museums!
--
--

Title: Where Cities Erase, Fields Remember: Through the Amsterdam Exhibition of Anselm Kiefer
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In the rhythm of constant travel, I briefly left Amsterdam before a trip to Madrid. I set aside a few hours for my first in-person encounter with the works of Anselm Kiefer, made possible by a joint exhibition of two neighboring Amsterdam institutionsâ€”the Van Gogh Museum and the Stedelijk Museum.
Until this moment, my acquaintance with his work had been limited to the screen of a laptop.
The space of the first hall instantly strikes you with its monumentality. You feel tiny before this boundless field, which seems to swallow your presence. Walking through the large exhibition halls, step by step, you find yourself amidst endless landscapes that are frightening in their existential emptiness, deep and inconsolable loneliness. These images are materialized by tons of paint mixed with dried grasses, plants, and rusty metal.
The field becomes the leitmotif of his work â€” solitary, marked by bitterness, a place where the most complex collisions unfold; it is more a silent symbol of collective memory than just a landscape. I know well what such a field is, its frosty breath rising from the ground, dry and at the same time waterlogged leaves, suffering from constant temperature changes, snow, rain, and wind. In its original essence, it does not carry the promise of spring or rebirth, only a feeling of cold and dampness.
It is such a field that appears as one of the main images in Larisa Shepitkoâ€™s film â€œThe Ascentâ€ (1977). Her field is a space of suffering and separation. In Shepitkoâ€™s work, the field acts more as a backdrop for testing the human spirit, where the characters face specific moral dilemmas in the extreme situation of war. Their suffering has a more individual and existential character in a direct sense. In Kieferâ€™s work, however, the field is the very embodiment of memory of collective trauma. This is no longer so much about an individual test, but about the burden of history that lies on the shoulders of an entire nation.
The absence of a distant horizon disorients you, creating a sense of immediate presence before this field of emptiness, fear, and human suffering, allowing you to feel this cold. It is incredible to imagine how many secrets and tragedies the field has concealed throughout human history. Since the Neolithic Revolution, it has been both salvation and grave for billions of people. Human flesh not only fertilized the soil for future generations, ensuring their survival, but also became an integral part of this cycle of life and death.
Yellow color is undoubtedly a symbol of farewell, organically woven into the structure of overripe sunflowers that crumble, losing their seeds. Thus manifests not only a farewell to the past but also a premonition of an unknown future, where even in a post-apocalyptic landscape, a spark of hope flickers. Overripe sunflowers also symbolize the inner illness of memory, its fading and inevitable decay, before a new grain of memory can sprout.
Instead, the elements covered in gold look like the last threads of hope for a transition to rebirth and salvation, a kind of reflection of the transcendent in this harsh landscape.
The juxtaposition of Van Gogh and Kiefer in one context and one exhibition space is a bold and, in my opinion, provocative decision. Without a doubt, Anselm Kiefer in his work referred to the legacy of Vincent Van Gogh, perhaps even tracing his paths, however, this does not always justify their unification within the same exhibition space, since their artistic worlds unfold on completely different planes. While Anselm Kiefer is undoubtedly an interesting artist, to place his work alongside that of Vincent Van Gogh, in my view, suggests a curatorial misstep. The ambition of Kiefer is evident in his monumental scale and engagement with weighty themes, but to equate this with the deeply personal and revolutionary vision of Van Gogh feels misguided. Despite this questionable pairing, my focus here remains on exploring the compelling symbolism of the field within Kieferâ€™s specific artistic language.
Van Goghâ€™s field reflects an inner world charged with anxiety, the looming presence of a storm, and a profound emotional weight. In contrast, Kieferâ€™s field is empty, post-apocalyptic; it is a sublimation of the collective unconscious, the result of its traumatic processing by history.
In contrast to Van Goghâ€™s living, full of an inner struggle, Kieferâ€™s field seems frozen in time, as if etching a monument to a collective catastrophe. This contrast is particularly acutely felt against the backdrop of cities, where paved and built-up cities erase individual memory not only through the physical destruction of the old and the construction of the new, but also through the imposition of new narratives that overshadow personal stories. Through the constant regeneration of generations, they layer memories one upon another, accumulating them in a single space where the individual often dissolves into the collective, becoming both everything and nothing. Instead, the field, in its visible emptiness, retains the potential for individual experience of memory. The absence of imposed structures allows one to feel the past on a deeper, almost intuitive level. Where in its emptiness one can see and feel the presence of the past: hear the voices that have disappeared, recall lost things, catch barely perceptible smells. It retains the memory of all, preserves it in its boundlessness, and carries this endless sadness in its silent depth, without imposing specific interpretations.
--
--

Title: My Amsterdam Diaries
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
â€œâ€˜Beautifulâ€™, chorused Adhiraj and Bhumika shortly after returning from their respective trips.
While Adhiraj is still in a trance of the magnificent BMWs and Porsches that gallantly rode on the streets of Amsterdam, Bhumika couldnâ€™t stop crooning over the fact that cityâ€™s Live and Let Live attitude. Meanwhile, Snigdha was thinking hard on how to describe Amsterdam in a single word. â€œFreedomâ€, she finally declared stating that Amsterdam was the best thing that had ever happened to her. She maintains that itâ€™s a free city in the literal sense, as peopleâ€™s expressions are continuously â€˜on the displayâ€™ be it in the form of wall graffiti, street plays or in in the way they tie their hair or wear their clothes and that no one judges anyone no matter what they do.
Bhumika and Snigdha were part of the Photography Trip to Amsterdam and Hamburg while Adhiraj was part of the Visual Arts and Theatre trip to Amsterdam and Berlin. And it seems like all three of them have come back with a suitcase of precious memories to share with us.
â€œIn front of the Van Gogh Museum was this IAmsterdam thingâ€¦Climbing on that and taking pictures was very, very funâ€¦and memorable tooâ€¦â€™cuz there were these street musicians all around and me and my best friend Yaosh, took a lot of videos of those guys! I can still feel the energy around me, with the air soaked in music, the world felt so light and amazing!â€, Adhiraj recalls his â€˜ fondest takeawayâ€™ from the trip.
Super-excited Bhumika couldnâ€™t wait to share a funny experience that she re-lived for us with fondness and a lot of laughter too. â€œOn the street photography assignment, as it was very windy, my friendâ€™s tripod flew and fell on a lady almost dropping her cup of coffee! Unfortunate, it was, but we just couldnâ€™t keep from laughing. The scene was so damn funny. And this annoyed a passerby more who started yelling at us. Poor Michiel (the Culture Fox leader for The Netherlands) was trying to stop us, but we just couldnâ€™t contain ourselves; the laugh was so involuntary and so unhinged.â€
On hearing this Snigdha wondered out loud how funny everything must have seemed to a third person viewing it all from the outside, â€œOn the whole, it seemed like Carmen (CoFounder of Culture Fox and also the trip leader) was the shepherd struggling hard to direct her crazy heard of sheep who were intrigued and highly distracted by the ambiance of Amsterdam! â€¦Oh such a beautiful place it is!!â€
A lot of things about Amsterdam just freaked out these young travelers, in a good way though. Bagpipers, couples wearing pokemon suits along the streets, the fact that the place had more cycles than people itself, the fearless and flamboyant birds ruling the skies, the mystic canals and the shoulder-to-shoulder standing buildings! And despite that fact that Holland had lost a soccer match, they were all busy celebrating!
â€œTraveling is in itself an art and I loved being â€˜in the momentâ€™ at all timesâ€, Bhumika blazoned out loud. â€œWhile other trips make touristy destinations, Culture Fox kept it art-focused. And I discovered the place through art, through photography! I enjoyed the offbeat venues. Mainstream venues would have resulted in mainstream pictures. The trip locations were simply perfect!â€ And saying so she gets lost back in time, â€œOh how much I miss those long winding roads and those long walksâ€¦â€
Yes! Quite evident as it is, these people had a heaven of a time in Amsterdam.
Apart from the funny moments strewn all across the memories of the trip, Adhiraj shared a slightly different experience, â€œit was our free time and we were out there shopping when a lady approached me for some cash. She said she will provide me with its change. I gave her 50 euros but she gave me back 35 and ran away. Such a thing had never happened to me before and yes, the situation did send chills down my spine. Definitely makes me more responsible and aware of my surroundingsâ€
To this Snigdha and Bhumika said that they found the locals quite warm and nice, very steadfast to life as well and a tad bit selfish too. But the fact that they were dedicated to what they had to do, won over the girls.
What about food?
Snigdha says that she could hear bakeries all around Amsterdam screaming to her to feast up. The macaroons lover enjoyed a lovely culinary experience. And the city came with a little learning for her here too, â€œHarder breads are better unlike in India where softer breads are preferredâ€. Bhumika thinks food shouldnâ€™t be given much priority as the place has a lot more to offer than just food although her personal favorite was the Ethiopian cuisine she got to experience; while Burger boy Adhiraj found food good throughout.
â€œBefore taking the trip, I was under the illusion that I knew a lot about photography. But certainly, that wasnâ€™t even a slightest bit true. I learnt a lot of thingsâ€¦about the many advanced modes available in the camera, about panning, and the new styles of photographyâ€¦and there is so much more that I need to learn!â€ Bhumika blurted out, while Snigdha loved the youthful exuberance and zeal of the photographer Kasper Fugslang, â€œI liked the fact that he gave the students the autonomy of experimenting and learning photography themselves. He did not constrain them like other professionals would have. This helped me gain a lot of confidence.â€ Brimming with energy and all ready to put her skills to action, she is determined to take part in the Fotogram photography contest happening next year!
Meanwhile for the artist in Adhiraj; the most exciting part of the trip was the Spray Painting Workshop where he learned about a lot of new cool approach to painting. He painted a wonderful caricature of Mickey and said,â€ it took a lot of time for me to make it, but it was all worth it and I enjoyed myself thoroughly while making it!â€ He is all set to revamp his room and spray-paint the walls, and his ever so supportive parents are much to eager for him to do so as well.
Speaking of the Culture Fox Leaders, Adhiraj describes them as being his friends, cannot stop raving about the dressing sense of Nikhil. Bhumika found Michiel very intelligent and opines that he knows Amsterdam inside-out and that the group loved listening to his stories intertwined with walking the streets of Amsterdam! Snigdha loved Carmen and Marie. â€œI really miss you guysâ€, she states with a teary eyed look on her face!
The trip really brought to life a side of them they never knew existed. Snigdha says she has now become a confident traveler in terms of traveling alone.
Thatâ€™s a sneak peek into Amsterdam through the lenses of a Culture Fox trip. If you would like to be on one such trip yourself â€¦
What are you waiting for? Winter is coming!
--

Title: Amsterdam Revisited
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
The Uncanny is an attempt to look deeper at strange current events, ideas, and trends.
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
I revisited Amsterdam this past week and spent Easter Weekend, along with countless Spaniards, Italians and Germans, in the early spring sun. Last time I was in Amsterdam was in June of 2008 and I went alone for a conference. This time I went with my wife and we lived in a delicious and charming apartment in the Oud West, on Douwess Dekkerstraat, owned by the artist Patty Schilder.
[caption id=â€attachment_222" align=â€alignleftâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Oud West Apartment â€” looking toward Farmers Marketâ€]
[/caption]
From our balcony, looking out over the Buurtcentrum De Havelaar, we gazed at the Baarsjesweg Canal, especially beautiful in the evening when the sun sets and the large barges slowly make their way up and down after a long dayâ€™s work. Two blocks away, in the early morning, the farmers market gathers steam. Here, the true ethnic diversity of the Oud West comes alive â€” Middle Eastern women in their hejabs argue prices with their favorite vendors, breads and cheeses abound, fish and meats, too. The color and smells and sounds are soothing, seductive. There is no excuse here for not eating right. The food is fresh, beautiful. The difficulty is in buying only what you need, something the Dutch are very good at doing, it seems.
[caption id=â€attachment_223" align=â€aligncenterâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Oud West Apartment looking toward canalâ€]
[/caption]
The difference between this trip and my last one is the bicycle. The only real way to experience this culture is on the bike. Though a modern tool, the bike is the heart of Amsterdam. Many consider Amsterdam â€œthe biking capital of Europe.â€ Amsterdam bikers have the right of way, not pedestrians. The flow and energy of this city is dependent upon how well the biking moves the energy along. The Dutch are great bikers, they weave in and out of crowds, move effortlessly through traffic, grinning or smiling and never (apparently) frustrated. This is Amsterdam. Iâ€™ve seen youngsters txting and biking, talking on cells, with passengers, children, sometimes two, one in the rear, the other up front. Much of Amsterdamâ€™s life happens on the bike.
[caption id=â€attachment_224" align=â€alignleftâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Biking in the northâ€]
[/caption]
We rented our bikes from Bike City. The added bonus being that the only hint that this is a rental is written in small, elegant print on the black carry bag on the handlebars: Bike City. Otherwise, the bikes were like all others. Most rental bikes are loud reds or yellows and have huge insignias. Would you want to call attention to yourself like that? We didnâ€™t. We found the best bikes to rent are the 3 speeds with hand brakes. Theyâ€™re comfortable and sturdy. Our first trek took us through the city, to the ferry landing behind Amsterdam Centraal Railway Station, and up through the farmland of the north country all they way to Slot Ilpenstein. We biked through pasture land, in and out of canals. Sheep nearby. The famous Frisian horses, too. And we managed a glimpse of some drafts.
[caption id=â€attachment_225" align=â€aligncenterâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€I Am Amsterdamâ€]
[/caption]
From that day on, we rode everywhere, including another â€œout of the cityâ€ day trip to Haarlem, a municipality and a city in the Netherlands, and also the capital of the province of North Holland, the northern half of Holland. The bicycle lends for a particular order to things, a graciousness and decorum we like to call civilized or civilization. Itâ€™s interesting because if one examines the history of the Netherlands, we see that this living has come at great human cost. Many fell to the strength and power of the mighty Dutch will. The rise of the Dutch Empire is extensive and dramatic. Out of this, comes Amsterdam, an important port city and center of commerce. What we see in Amsterdam today is a result of this history so as we ride through the city and sit comfortably in cafes adjoining canals, we have to weigh the awesome power that began somewhere around the 1540s and that conquered so much. To the victor belongs the spoils is quite evident in Amsterdam. These spoils are Amsterdamâ€™s gift to humanity. But these spoils also bare an awesome responsibility that Amsterdamâ€™s inhabitants are trying to understand. The story is complex.
Perhaps this is why we can describe Amsterdam as an incredibly important human experiment thatâ€™s ongoing. And just maybe, this is why the moral structure of this great little city is experimenting with an unbound secularism founded on an unprecedented egalitarianism, which, in turn, depends upon freedoms of expression and a tolerance for difference. But this is the idealized version, the romantic view. Itâ€™s not surprising, then, that when the world is exhausted by the constant chimes of terror, from the Netherlands explodes the Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy. Itâ€™s also the place where Theo Van Gogh, the great-grandson of Theo van Gogh, the brother of painter Vincent van Gogh, was murdered by Mohammed Bouyeri, a Muslim extremist, after van Gogh, with collaboration from Ayaan Hirsi Ali, released the Anti-Islam film Submission.
[caption id=â€attachment_226" align=â€aligncenterâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Middle Eastern Women in the Oud West, after shoppingâ€]
[/caption]
Amsterdam is not without controversy. It is an extraordinary diverse place; however, diversity brings contention, even among the most enlightened. When differences are thrust together, the potential for an explosion is always present. Before 1965, the Netherlands were totally a monoculture â€” all white Dutch and no threats. This changed with a very liberal immigration policy. Effectively, the society is now segregated. On the streets, we can see the diversity, but where it counts â€” schools, neighborhoods, business and so on, we donâ€™t see it. There is resentment that what Dutch culture was is no longer â€” this is true. The monoculture safety net has been taken away. Now the struggle is different, particularly on religious grounds where the Christian and the Muslim, along with the Jew, have to live side-by-side in a society that is increasingly secular. What is Amsterdam turning into? What is it becoming?
I wonder whether Amsterdam today is the â€œnewâ€ Al Andaluz? It has the makings. Why not, why can it not be the â€œnewâ€ place where the three central religions, Christians, Muslims and Jews, live in relative peace and harmony? Only now we are called upon to protect the Muslim, not the other way around as it was when the Muslim protected the ahl al-dhimma (the people under protection). Maybe the tides have turned, though the challenges and the conflicts are as they were in the period between 711 and 1492. What we donâ€™t want is the devastation and the destruction brought about by the Christian King in 1492 â€” in the name of God and love! Al Andaluz was a beacon of learning, and the city of CÃ³rdoba became one of the leading cultural and economic centers in both the Mediterranean basin and the Islamic world. Why can this not be the fate of the Netherlands, Amsterdam leading the way?
The Amsterdam I see today is in transition, in flux, pained by both its past and its future. But itâ€™s how it negotiates its day-to-day where the mystery and awe exist. The seeds of tolerance are there â€” a young Muslim woman on a bike or a Vespa waiting for a light to change and waiting next to her is a tall Dutch blond, also on her bike, and they look at one another and smile. This is the new Amsterdam.
So perhaps the Dutch are such great bikers because they have been learning to negotiate obstacles all along. Whether by conquering territories for their wealth during the time of the Burghers or changing from a monoculture to an ethnically diverse culture, they have been challenging boundaries â€” national, ethnic and tribal, as well as economic and educational. Amsterdam could be the first small city that will evolve â€” or not â€” according to how well it enables those who reside in the margins of life to exist without threat; where once there was a singular uninterrupted culture, as is evident in the architecture and the museums, now there are only threads that are struggling to keep humanity together. And holding these threads are exiles. Amsterdam is a perfect example of a city of exiles, of histories that come from colonization, and newer ones that come along because they have been following the great human migration for survival, for subsistence.
[caption id=â€attachment_227" align=â€alignleftâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Bikes, Canals, and their Bridges â€” the webâ€]
[/caption]
The Amsterdam of tomorrow will be built on the shoulders of mindfulness and tolerance. And if successful, Amsterdam, as Al Andaluz before it, will hold a noble place in the continuum of great histories that have given humanity, even if for a moment, a ray of hope that we can live together and relish in our differences.
--

Title: Preserving a Golden Time
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
4
Listen
Share
They wander into my dreams âˆ’ now and again: Mario and Rita, head honchos of the Rodos Bar. Holding court, twenty-five-years ago, when I lived the life of a hobo in old Amsterdam. Mario, slightly unhinged in the nicest possible way, was Greek to his toenails. He was blessed with a mop of silver-greying hair and a scraggly beard that touched his barrelled chest as he shuffled about barking at his patrons. He used to make his way from the back room into the bar with gifts of food for one or two emaciated looking regulars. â€˜YAMOS, comrade,â€™ heâ€™d growl. And plonk a dish of Greek grub on to your lap, â€˜Mario say EAT!â€™ A gift from the gods. Diamond geezer.
Time-warped and frazzled, Mario was an exiled maverick; forever paranoid about the long arm of the Greek Generals âˆ’ always in his chair, early evening âˆ’ monitoring. â€˜Mario say OKâ€™ â€˜Marioâ€™s happy now, ERRRR!â€™ â€˜Mario say sit.â€™ A kind and generous man; no mistaking that. His old jukebox blasted out rebellious Cretan Rizitika folk songs and Horeftika dance tunes, as well as Frank Zappa, Joni Mitchell and Thin Lizzy numbers. Weâ€™d all scream along to Zappaâ€™s â€˜Bobby Brownâ€™: â€˜I can take about an hour on the tower of power/As long as I get a little golden shower.â€™ Mario allowed punters to put their own records on the machine if the Greek stuff stayed put. Priceless. What a place! Shebeen heaven â€¦
It was more of a home than a pub to many. Buskers and musicians could store their gear in the back room: Marioâ€™s domain. And theyâ€™d invariably drink their daily takings with Mario and Rita late in the afternoon till the early hours of the following morning. â€˜Mario says OK!â€™ Bliss.
Cult writer Denis Johnson wouldâ€™ve eaten his heart out to have supped in a place as cool as the Rodos Bar âˆ’ Iâ€™m damned sure of that: vagabonds; grifters; whores; ex-whores; wastrels; artists; seamen; travellers; alcoholics; washed up deadheads; Amsterdammers; eccentrics; lost tourists, as well as an astrologer or two! All nations graced its dingy, dark, worn, wooden womb; all were royally nourished. A grubby brass bell hung down from one end of the bar. Once or twice a month, it was pulled with vigour, till it dinged and dinged and dinged. Then an almighty thirsty roar resounded through the place. That sound signified a free drink for everyone. One could only speculate what lucky touch precipitated such an action: A big welfare cheque, perhaps, dropped on someoneâ€™s doormat; a successful drug enterprise that came up trumps; a win on the lottery or horses; an artistic advance; someone about to leave Amsterdam for good; birthdays, christenings and the likes. Anything! Iâ€™ll never forget the sheer joy when that bell chimed, though. Righteous, bro, righteous, as they say nowadays.
Rita was an Amsterdammer and maintained matronly order in all things pertaining to the bar. Hazy demarcation lines, though: Amsterdam style. She had coded scraps of paper concerning bar tabs strewn all over the place. Only she seemed to be able to decipher who owed what, at any given time. In other words, it was organised chaos as regulars had to be reminded what theyâ€™d consumed or who theyâ€™d bought drinks for the night before. A lot of booze crossed that bar and there were always scrambled heads trying to get to grips with their tab.
Of course, Ritaâ€™s feral cat had right of way across the span of the bar: through bottles of Grolsch, vases of flowers, lit candles and tobacco paraphernalia it strutted. The banter and nonsensical exchanges hushed when the cat threaded its way past the barâ€™s animated throng. Rita epitomized the old saying: â€˜how to stay sane in an insane world?â€™ Sheâ€™d sit back on her high stool and take it all in; cool as a cucumber. She dished out reprimands, now and again, to the odd cantankerous drunkard. â€˜Stay quiet or go!â€™ was usually enough. And a background grunt from Mario seemed to cement it. The place was precious to a lot of people. You donâ€™t shit on your own doorstep, do you? That seemed to be the philosophical viewpoint of the Rodos Barâ€™s clientele, during that era.
On Ritaâ€™s birthday the bar resembled a flower market: roses, lilies, sunflower and wildflower bouquets abounded. Vase after vase of flowers lined the bar and tables. Lit candles adorned shelves and nooks. The Rodos Bar would be packed. Session on! A great show of love for her; people used to drop in all night to wish her well. Always a cracking night!
The wrecking ball and gentrification killed the Rodos Bar in 1997. Most of the people alluded to here are now dead including Mario and Rita, God rest their souls.
Thank you Rodos Bar for some of the best nights of my life!

Title: 75 hours in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We all know the power that being in and around nature has on us and the power of nature within us. We are nature, therefore we are at one with nature when we are amongst it. You cannot fight it. Nature and the natural world are our home and we, as humans, innately crave it. The biophilia hypothesis suggests that our intuitive longing to exist in and around greenery and living things is in contrast to the way we live as twenty first century humans â€” which is typically sedentary and indoors. Rekindling a deep relationship with nature makes us feel emotionally, physically and socially more together, more connected, better functioning. If you need evidence to back this up, I have tons of it as a practising organisational psychologist, but more and more Iâ€™m realising that you donâ€™t need the hard evidence â€” simply stepping outdoors, hearing the birds, feeling the rain or rays of sunshine on your skin, being sheltered by a tree, watching that rogue squirrel finding todayâ€™s feast. Thatâ€™s it.
I am coming up to a decade of immersion into the world of biophilia and well-being at work, and was therefore delighted to be invited, along with colleagues from St Monica Trust, to visit health care providers in the Netherlands, where they are already established in embracing the principles of biophilia, sustainable buildings and green health-care. Our northern European cousins have a reputation for leading in health care, social equity, workplace well-being, and other factors, compared to the UK. Think the Buurtzorg approach to health care in the Netherlands, the rise of the four day working week across Europe, Swedenâ€™s Fika time, and Finland topping the 2024 happiness countries index. So, when I was invited along to join the group, I jumped at the opportunity.
So there I was, Monday morning, having leaped across the north sea from Blighty, sitting in a care home meeting room in Amsterdam with a small group comprising our CEO, CFO, two Trustees (a GP and Housing Exec), our Head of Sales and our care home Architect (an external consultant and fellow Cardiffian). If the individuals in this group knew about greenwashing before, the message was fully reinforced on this trip, if they hadnâ€™t known, then the message was heard loud and clear. Thatâ€™s what I like about the Dutch, straight to the point â€” and no beating around the bush (so to speak).
The architects we met talked about dynamic lighting that matches circadian rhythms. They introduced us (me at least) to the idea of â€˜solar eisâ€™, which is a heating and cooling energy system based on ice. We learned that gas is now forbidden in the Netherlands and that heat pumps, ground source and insulation are well used. Our 21st century British brains were encouraged to get our heads around a water system using brown water â€” it may take some persuading but it is truly recycling water â€” and using our wee for fertiliser. I was particularly struck when one architect said that the â€œgoal is to be net positive â€” not less bad, but really goodâ€. We were told about and shown images of tiny houses built like Lego blocks in different styles and units â€” all self sufficient. We heard about mycelium walls that you can eat from and how simply planting trees can support drainage and help keep our increasingly hot and noisy cities cooler and quieter by absorption. Ultimately the message regarding the buildings was about going back to how we used to live and work â€” working with nature and not against it.
From psychological, social and physical well-being perspectives, a number of speakers talked about studies on biophilia and the benefits of connection to nature in relation to rehabilitation and care. Us advocates of biophilia already know about Attention Restoration Theory and how connection with nature builds our cognitive capacity and has untold well-being benefits. Additional learning was in how to design a successful nature based intervention in health care, core factors were adaptability; accessibility; balanced design; wildness and variety; appeal; safety; and privacy. It is essential to collaborate with all stakeholders and users â€” what do people want to see in their green spaces?
We visited stunning gardens and land which were occupied by ancient trees, well-kept gardens, aviaries (mixed reactions), goats, sheep, chickens, rabbits and cows (not all together!). We gained an insight into the Dutch approach to risk â€” choice is key and always the decision of the resident and their families, but essentially the messages are â€” do not be afraid of steps; do not rely on automation â€” for example, let people open windows and doors as they wish; use different types of outdoor ground surfaces and textures for â€˜real worldâ€™ variation and always view the world through the residentsâ€™ eyes. Note the wheelchair friendly benches, outdoor activities and varied walkways. From another perspective we learned how automation and technology are revolutionising access to and provision of care, medical interventions and social needs.
From a workplace perspective, there seemed to be a lot of staff. And thereâ€™s clearly a â€˜thingâ€™ about groups of staff taking lunch together. That is very much not a UK care scenario and Iâ€™d love to learn more about their working cultures for carers.
We took away so many learning points from our Netherlands trip â€” particularly from a buildings and sustainability perspective. What a fantastic opportunity. My colleagues and I also took away a feeling of genuine pride in what we already do well at St Monica Trust in embracing nature for resident wellness â€” for example the incredibly well-kept parkland with ancient trees, rooftop gardens, scented garden, indoor/outdoor shelters and space, and horticultural activities for residents. We always have more to do of course. And from an employee perspective, I personally took away a further drive to encourage, role model and give permission to spend time in and around nature during the working day â€” for well-being, for social connections, for interest, for moments of mindfulness and noticing. These are all essential bits of being alive and being human.
A few days after our trip, back into business as usual at work, one of my fellow Amsterdam trip colleagues messaged me to say Sharon Blackie was talking in Bristol â€” did I fancy it? Did I heck?!! Sharon Blackie writes beautifully about mythology and fairy tales and how they relate to our lives today. She draws upon the human connection (and particularly womenâ€™s connection) with the natural world, the seasons, the landscapes. I am fairly new to her writing and I find her books mesmerising and nurturing.
On a stormy splashy dark mid-week night, in the stunning setting of the Mount Without, a recently and compassionately restored church sitting opposite the hospital on a hill, we soaked up the ethereal tones of Sharon Blackie urging us to embrace lifeâ€™s natural changes through aging, and to notice our own personal evolutions. Itâ€™s important to have the hard evidence for well-being interventions, but to remember that the stories and othersâ€™ experiences and simply noticing matter just as much.
â€œConnection isnâ€™t about nature in our service, a slave to our needs, a commodity for our use, a sticking-plaster for our stresses. Nature isnâ€™t there to provide us with therapy; that isnâ€™t what connection is about. Connection is about love. Enchantment. Wonder. And a necessary and appropriate sense of awe.â€
Sharon Blackie
--
--

March, 2006
Two nights in London was enough for me. I knew my money would go further elsewhere, plus the Michael Jackson music was haunting me. I must have heard Billy Jean once an hour while there. So, I decided to take the Stena Line ferry from London to Amsterdam, based on the recommendation of Jill, the girl Iâ€™d been making out with and rubbing up on the night before. The ferry wasnâ€™t included in my Eurorail package, but for $30 it seemed well worth the price to travel in comfort. When I boarded the ferry, I was struck by how mall-like the vessel was.
There were movie theaters, restaurants, bars, even shoppingâ€¦ There may have been a casino, but I could just be adding that in my mind because the place felt like one. After scoping out the ship, I found myself a comfortable leather chair near the bar and plopped myself down, removing Atlas Shrugged from my bag along with a 10mg Adderall from my pocket.
I swallowed it without water, just as the waiter was approaching. Then, I ordered a Guinness, my daytime drink of choice at the time. By the time he came back it, I was enthralled in the book again. For the next five hours, I barely moved, save to flip a page or order another Guinness. I was lost in the world of the book. â€œShould I have sex with a prostitute tonight?â€ â€œCan you really buy mushrooms in stores there?â€ â€œIs this the best weed Iâ€™ll ever smoke?â€ The thoughts that had been running through my mind earlier now seemed like scattered roaches exposed to light. All I cared about now was Dagny Taggert. She is the main character in Atlas Shrugged. People now associate that book with right wing ideology, but I had a different reading of it.
Adderall had that effect on me. I always liked reading and found it easy to get into the world of a book, but on Adderall, itâ€™s like I was IN THE BOOK, especially with this one. Iâ€™d light cigs and forget about them, leaving a trail of ashes that Iâ€™d discover a half hour later. Then Iâ€™d light another, take a drag, and get lost in the book again. I was devouring it, or maybe it was devouring me.
The ferry dropped us off at the Amsterdam Centraal train station at 2pm, amidst the perfect spring day. The sun was beaming down, and everyone seemed to be happy. Itâ€™s like the chicken and the egg thingâ€¦ Are people happy because theyâ€™re in Amsterdam, or do happy people just gravitate to the place, making it so? Is that like the chicken and the egg?
My hostel was only a few blocks away, smart planning done from London the day prior, so I set course for there to check in and drop off my bag. I intended on getting higher than Iâ€™d ever been and I didnâ€™t want to lug around a large travel bag.
The first thing that struck me on my 3-block walk was how preposterous Amsterdamâ€™s street names are. Brouwersgracht, Princeneiland, Amsterveensewegâ€¦ I assume they made them ridiculous so people are encouraged to giggle while they walk around, because that was the effect it had on me. â€œDo not get lost here.â€ I told myself, imagining the hilarity that would ensue if I had to, God forbid, try to pronounce these names in front of a local.
There were â€œcoffee shopsâ€ everywhere, some appearing to be more coffee-centric, and others more weed-centric. They all served coffee though, and everyone seemed to have a cup. I smelled a few people smoking what smelled like spliffs, weed mixed with tobacco, but that was it. In fact, I remember noting that I smelled more tobacco than weed on that first walk, for what thatâ€™s worth.
I chose a small hostel that advertised itself as a â€œquiet getawayâ€ type, a far cry from the Flying Pig Hostel, which most people traveling around my age would have wanted to stay at. All the comradery stuff was not my bag. The last thing I wanted was to get hooked up with a group of people that Iâ€™d have to accommodate even for an evening. If I met a friend, fine. But that group think nonsenseâ€¦ no thanks. And no, I didnâ€™t want to go to the Van Gough Museum. And I definitely didnâ€™t want to see Anne Frankâ€™s house. Granted, there was a weed cafÃ© inside of the Flying Pig. But my hostel was laid back, and I needed that more than anything. Plus, there was a free breakfast, so I was sold.
When I checked in, the receptionist apologized for the construction that would be taking place from 9am to 5pm every day.
â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™ll be an issue. I plan on being out and about during the days.â€
â€œPerfect. Thank you for understanding.â€
When I got up to my room, I realized what heâ€™d meant. Right outside of our small, 2-bunk room, there was a man with a jackhammer, absolutely blasting away. The noise was so loud I could barely think.
â€œIâ€™m Sam!â€ I screamed at the top of my lungs to a 30-something guy laying on the bottom bunk.
â€œIâ€™m Eric! You mind the top bunk?â€ He screamed back.
â€œNO!â€.
I removed my coat and threw it on the top bunk.
â€œSee you later!â€ I yelled, closing the door, wondering what the hell would possess Eric to spend another second in that room.
I went and checked my bag into a locker, removing the essentials and placing them into a smaller backpack (Adderall, Ipod, water, Atlas Shrugged, notebook, pen, and a banana). Iâ€™d still only slept about 4 hours in the last 3 days, but my adrenaline was still kicking and I felt relatively good. A new city has a way of doing that to you.
The mission now, was weed, and it was an easy mission at that. I exited the hostel, took a right, and just started walking. I went in the first cafÃ© that I saw. Ironically, it was called Coffee Shop Bob Marley. The brand is global, I guess. I was greeted by an old budtender who looked like Willy Nelson, all the way down to the bandana. He handed me a Trapper Keeper-style three ring binder. In it were plastic pages with little slots for what I assumed where supposed to be baseball cards. Instead, each quadrant contained a gram or so of weed, along with a short description that offered insight into what the high would feel like (e.g., purple haze: mellow, euphoric). It was the first time Iâ€™d seen such a set up and I was blown away. Though Iâ€™d smoked weed daily for 5 years, Iâ€™d never encountered such a selection, or even dreamed of it for that matter. Remember when Thurgood and the gang break into the weed room at the laboratory in Half Baked? I wanted to hump the air like he did in that scene. I played it cool though and selected 3 strains, all indica leaning, my favorite. I paid Willie 60 Euros for the 10.5 gram purchase, a good deal anywhere in the world at that time.
â€œMay I light up in here?â€
â€œOf course. The smoking room is in the back.â€
I thanked him and walked around to the back, which was just a small curtained off area with a few high-top tables. Bob Marley music videos played on television that hung on the wall. It was silly, but it would do.
I put my bag on the table and removed a grape White Owl cigar that I purchased in London for just this reason. At the time I was still smoking blunts and wanted to represent my own culture while in Europe. What I didnâ€™t give thought to, was the fact that I had barely smoked for the last 2 weeks while in New York. And, though I smoked a hash spliff the previous night in London, the quality was not the best. Drug tolerance must always be considered. Remember that. Unfortunately my hubris prevailed, and I proceeded to roll a 2.5-gram monster of Afghan Kush.
There were two other people in the room with me, a couple who both appeared to be in their 30â€™s. They were smoking out of a pipe and laughing. When I dumped the guts out of the blunt into a garbage bin near the wall they began staring in my direction. They didnâ€™t say anything, but I could tell they were interested in what I was constructing. â€œMaybe itâ€™s the first time theyâ€™ve seen a blunt being rolled. Put on a nice show for them,â€ I told myself, proud of my talent.
After licking the blunt closed, I sparked my lighter and ran the flame along the wrapper to dry it out. Then I lit it, taking a deep drag and coughing slightly. The couple, again, glanced my way. I looked in their direction, smiled, and kept smoking, trying to stare at the television as to not make them uncomfortable.
I got about halfway through the blunt, when it really hit me. Suddenly, I was overcome with dizziness, something Iâ€™d never experienced from smoking weed before. I was sweating too. The couple was getting concerned. I could tell they wanted to say something, they just werenâ€™t sure if it was their place to do so. I mean, I must know what Iâ€™m doing, right? You donâ€™t just roll a blunt like this if youâ€™ve never smoked weed before.
My equilibrium was gone and now I was gripping the small, circular table like we were engaged in a Greco Roman wrestling match. I knew I had to say something.
â€œMy name is Sam. Iâ€™m from America. If I die, my momâ€™s number is in my bag,â€ I blurted out, before falling off my stool and passing out.
When I came to, Bob Marleyâ€™s I Shot The Sheriff was playing on the tv. The couple was now hovering over me, looking like theyâ€™d just seen the most disturbing scene of their lives. Their highs were ruined. All our highs were ruined, even Willieâ€™s. Even he was now in the back room, worried about me. I didnâ€™t even know how long Iâ€™d been out.
â€œWe were scared, man. Glad youâ€™re ok. We donâ€™t even allow cigars in here,â€ Willy said.
â€œSo much for representing,â€ I thought to myself. I grabbed the remainer of the blunt, wrapping it in a bar napkin and placing it in my pocket. I apologized and left, knowing Iâ€™d rather be dead than show my face in that establishment again.
â€œMy name is Sam. Iâ€™m from Americaâ€¦?â€ I was so ashamed of myself. Obviously, they assumed I was from America. Only an American would go to another country and insist on putting their culture on display like that. â€œFrom now on,â€ I told myself, â€œWe go with the current, not against it.â€
By this time, it was almost 8pm and my exhaustion was catching up with me. With my tail between my legs, I headed back to the hostel for some much-needed rest. On my way back though, I passed what looked to be the weirdest food establishment Iâ€™d ever seen. It reminded me of the Grayâ€™s Papaya hot dog shops in New York, in that there was no seating inside, but this place took it a step further. There was nothing at all inside of this place. Yet, it smelled like fast food. I didnâ€™t really eat fast food, but this was too weird to not investigate.
When I went in, I was struck by the feeling that I was inside a vending machine. The walls were lined with rows and rows of slots, where hot food was kept. There must have been a kitchen in the back where the food was prepared, but I couldnâ€™t see one, nor could I hear one. All I could see was the hand of one of the employees replenishing the stock after an item was purchased, kind of the way you see a hand replenishing milk at the grocery store. â€œWhat a genius idea,â€ I thought to myself. â€œMake the store itself a vending machine.â€ Maybe I was just still really high, or delirious from passing out, but I felt like I had stumbled upon the Pyramids. This idea must have really planted itself in my brain because I opened a take-and-go food establishment only 7 years later.
I put my credit card in and pressed the cheeseburger button twice. The slot unlocked and I removed my burgers, which were still delightfully warm. I went over to a bench and enjoyed them while watching a few kids play tag.
â€œDo they know about the prostitutes?â€ I thought to myself, realizing we were right around the corner from the Red-Light District. â€œProbably.â€
I awoke from a much-needed night of sleep at 9:30am, just in time to get some free breakfast. After getting my plate of fruit and toast I found a seat near the television that played the BBC news on a loop and made myself at home. I loathed the American news, but the BBC version didnâ€™t strike me as being too salacious. It was almost pleasant to watch, and it made me feel like an adult.
I knew exactly where my next destination was: The Smart Shop. Thatâ€™s what they called the Mushroom Store, the most apropos of names. It was only a few blocks away and opened 10am. I could see that it was drizzling outside, but that wasnâ€™t going to change my plans. I was going to trip, it had been written.
Iâ€™d done mushrooms a handful of times before, with experiences ranging from spiritual bliss to utter terrified madness, but Iâ€™d always learn something about myself in the process, and that was the most important part. Doing them alone wasnâ€™t an issue for me either, I preferred it.
When I entered the store, I was greeted by the kind of guy youâ€™d think would be running a psychedelic mushroom store; long hair, flannel shirt, with monk vibes.
â€œHello friend. How may I help you?â€ He asked me, gently.
â€œCan you please advise me on which mushrooms I should take, and how much of them I should take?â€
â€œOf course. That is exactly what I am here for. Have you done psilocybin before?â€
â€œYes, maybe 10 times.â€
â€œOk, well, let me walk you through what we have.â€
He took me over to a glass case with about 10 varieties of mushrooms, some wet, some dry, all of them unique in shape and color. He walked me through their different levels in potency and their array of effects.
â€œHow about something in the medium-strength level?â€ I asked.
â€œSure. Would you like to see visuals?â€
â€œYes, please.â€
â€œI suggest 1 to 2 grams of the High Hawaiian variety, dried.â€
â€œThat sounds good to me.â€
I paid the man, about 10 Euros and exited the Smartshop with my mushrooms. Then, I walked over to the canal and found an unoccupied bench. It was drizzling but the perfect amount, almost a mist. I pulled a banana out of my bag that Iâ€™d saved from my free hostel breakfast, along with a bottle of water. I took the mushrooms out and inspected them.
â€œLord, please look after me during this tripâ€ I said, downing the entire 2 grams and chasing it with a bite of banana.
Once I had the mushrooms down and the nausea passed, I sat back and opened Atlas Shrugged, sinking back into the world on the pages. I read until the words no longer looked like words, maybe 30 minutes. Thatâ€™s when the laughing started. Here I was, sitting alone, staring into a canal, laughing hysterically at nothing at all. Itâ€™s Amsterdam, so people probably had a sense of what was going on, but I didnâ€™t care about anything in that moment.
Then, it happened. I saw a tourist boat approaching slowly in the canal. There were 20 or so passengers on the small boat, and nearly all of them looked to be of Asian descent. They looked so happy, and I was overcome with the urge to connect with them. I stood up and waved my arms as they passed.
â€œHelllloooooo!!! Welcome!!!â€
They waved back jubilantly.
I was in hysterics now, laughing and crying like a maniac, waving and yelling.
Then it passed.
â€œHoly shit, that was fun.â€ I thought. â€œI wonder if there are more of those.â€
I sat, waiting patiently, looking around the bend for the next one, letting my mind drift like ripples in the water below.
I almost exploded with excitement when I saw another boat coming around the bend 15 minutes later. Again, it was carrying Asian tourists. And again, I welcomed them with air kisses and waves.
â€œWelcome friends!! We welcome you to Amsterdam!! Enjoy your stay!!â€
â€œThank you!!â€ They waved back.
At this point the rain had increased to a light downpour. I was soaked, shoes and all. But I had more tourists to welcome, so I stayed at my post, laughing crazily in the rain, welcoming travelers to a country that was not mine.
I did that for 2 entire hours. 8 boats-worth of people were greeted by me that day. Thereâ€™s no other way to explain it; the drugs turned me into a volunteer civil servant for a country that Iâ€™d only been in for two days.
My feet started to prune around 2pm so I ended my shift. I grabbed my bag, which too was soaked, and headed back to the hostel to dry off and relax during my comedown. When I got to my room, I was delighted to find no one else in there to ruin my high. What I forgot about though, was the Jackhammering. outside my window.
The drugs were making my ears even more sensitive to the sound, causing the sound to seem even more comically loud than it had previously, which was already INSANELY loud. I didnâ€™t want to leave though. So, I changed clothes and laid down in my bed. The sound was so loud all I could do was laugh. I laid there, laugh-crying at the ridiculousness of the situation.
â€œMushroomsâ€¦ You did it again.â€
I woke up to rain the next day. My tentative plan had been to go to Vondelpark, the largest park in Amsterdam, and one of the most spectacular in the world. It was one of the few sights I wanted to see while there, but I was unwilling to spend another day soaking wet, so I thought against it. Instead, Iâ€™d decided to spend the day bouncing around from coffee shop to coffee shop, smoking and mingling. This time around, I wanted to roll spliffs to avoid another embarrassing scene, and to stick with my plan of going with the current. I was smoking Parliament regulars because for some reason Parliament Lights werenâ€™t sold in Europe at the time. Youâ€™d think the two would be similar in flavor, but the Regulars were awful. Mixing it with weed, I thought, would be a great way to mask the flavor.
After purchasing a few grams in a random shop, I settled into a small booth and began dumping the guts of my cigarettes out onto the table. Then, I broke down the weed into a more workable state, before mixing the two together in a 1:1 ratio. It took me about 30 minutes, but by the time I was done I had rolled myself 12 spliffs, certainly enough for the day. Pleased with myself, I lit one up and smoked it while enjoying a coffee and Biscoff sidecar. I put the rest back into my pack.
Everyone in the cafe seemed so elegant to me. No one was wearing suits or formal attire, but they all dressed so thoughtfully. Their clothes featured bright, fun colors, and so did their umbrellas, which sat in a small receptacle near the door. They all looked unique. There didnâ€™t seem to be a style of the time either, rather, they all appeared timeless. No one was overweight either, something Iâ€™d always taken note of, given that my father was extremely obese before he died. Most people read the paper, some typed away on computers. I did a little reading from my book but mainly people-watched. It was a delightful afternoon.
Afterwards, I wondered around for a bit amidst the drizzle before stopping to eat a herring sandwich at a little cart overlooking the canal. It made me think of my Bubbie, whoâ€™d long passed. She loved herring and would always try to get me to eat it when I was little. I hated it then but had now grown to love it. And this version, with just pickled fish and onions, was pleasing both my belly and my heart.
After finishing my meal, I went in my pocket for another 10mg Adderall for dessert. Fully recharged, I decided it was time to find a bar. Not just a bar for the evening, but one I could call home in future visits. I still had a month left in my trip and I knew Iâ€™d be back. Bars were that important to me. I canâ€™t just go anywhere, willy nilly. I need a home base, where I feel comfortable.
I walked for a bit before finding myself at the intersection of Nieuwebrugsteeg and Warmoesstraat, right where Warmoesstraat turns into Sint Olofspoort. Iâ€™m not joking. I looked up and saw the most perfect bar Iâ€™d ever seen in my entire life. The sign under the awning read: H. Murrayâ€™s Bar. Next to it was another smaller sign that read â€œAnno 1619â€. There was also the obligatory Heineken Bier sign adorning the doorway, which was situated at the right angle formed by the intersection of the aforementioned streets.
The location made it seem so discrete. It also felt more like an old house than a bar. Even from the outside it looked and felt like I was peering into a someoneâ€™s living room.
Upon entering, I knew Iâ€™d found my spot. The bartender greeted me as soon as I walked in.
â€œHello friend. Welcome.â€
There was a golden retriever laying calmly near the bar that barely noticed my presence.
â€œHello. Iâ€™m Sam.â€
â€œIâ€™m Neil, and thatâ€™s Lilly,â€ he said, introducing me to the pup. â€œAnd thatâ€™s Norman,â€ he said, pointing to the only other man in the bar.
â€œHello gentlemenâ€.
â€œPull up a seat,â€ responded Norman, welcoming me.
â€œDonâ€™t mind if I do. Guinness please.â€
We got to talking and time got to flying, the way it does when youâ€™re in a good bar, surrounded by good people. Norman told me about his time in Berkley, how he knew Tim Leary, Tom Wolffe and the Merry Pranksters, characters that Iâ€™d only known from books like The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test. He was a well-traveled man who knew how to tell a story. I wish I remembered more of them, but the whiskey came out after a few beers and wiped my memory clean. Thatâ€™s how it goes. Sometimes you sacrifice memory for fun. Iâ€™ve always found that to be a fair trade.
My last memory of the night was when Norman pulled out about an ounce of loose weed from his pants pocket, handing me no less than a quarter of it.
â€œI knew I smelled something,â€ I said cheekily.
â€œTry this. I grow it. Youâ€™ll love it.â€
I donâ€™t even know how I got back to my hostel that night, but I made it home safely. I mustâ€™ve walked, but I have no recollection of it whatsoever.
When I woke up the next morning, I felt like death. I checked my pocket and found a decent amount of money. â€œDid Neil even charge me?â€ I wondered.
Before I could spend any more time contemplating the prior nightâ€™s conclusion, the jackhammering started. This time I was not finding any humor in the situation. I reached in my bag and grabbed an Adderall pill from the interior compartment. After showering as quickly as I could, I changed, and headed out, still wobbly.
I went down to saw there was still time to get some breakfast. I was starving, and I knew once the Adderall kicked in that I wouldnâ€™t be hungry for hours, so I took advantage. I had a full plate of pastries and fruit, making sure to stock up on carbs for the day. I watched the BBC news as I ate, and it just so happened they were showing highlights from the NCAA Menâ€™s March Madness tournament, something I certainly would have been keen on in years passed. Now though, it felt like insignificant news from a distant land.
After finishing my breakfast, I headed out to do some wandering. I hit a few bookstores, but mainly I just walked, soaking up the surroundings and chain smoking the spliffs Iâ€™d rolled the day prior. I had more than enough weed, but I still stopped in cafes to see their product line. Each store was unique and I just couldnâ€™t get enough of being inside of stores that sold weed. I live in California now and the novelty still hasnâ€™t worn off.
As night rolled around, I found myself in a bar, drinking Irish Whiskey, not my usual. I donâ€™t know exactly where I was, but I do know it was right by the Red Light District. THAT Iâ€™M SURE OF.
As I got drunker my loneliness began transforming into horny rage. When my erection grew, I knew the decision was being made for me. It was time to experience the Amsterdam sex worker scene.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.
