Title: The Dieline Conference Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Weekly blog posts by Creatives from VBAT, on different topics related to Retail, Branding, Packaging, Innovation and Design in and around Amsterdam.

--
Listen
Share
Written by Craig BerryCreative Intern at VBAT
Last week, thanks to VBAT I was given an entry pass and the opportunity to attend the 2016 Packaging Innovations convention and the Dieline Conference in Zaandam at the Taets Arts & Event Park.
The journey from Amsterdam Centraal to Zaandam was quick and as soon as I stepped out of the station I was in awe of the cityâ€™s architecture. Straight away you see the Hotel Inntel Zaandam â€” which literally looks like a Christmas Disney attraction. Its outer faÃ§ade is a bunch of traditional Dutch houses in blue and green cladding, piled up on one another for 12 storeys. Reading up more about the design of the building I found out it is by WAM â€” a Delft based group who say it wasnâ€™t designed to be shocking and they feel that it fits in place in Zaandam because â€œit uses the architectural language of Zaanstadâ€™. Although this building wasnâ€™t part of the visit to the Packaging Innovations convention it was impossible not to be amazed by it as a non-native.
At the convention I received my pass (which looked official and made me feel official) and started wandering around the exhibits.
It was hard to pinpoint and be exceptionally amazed at any one particular exhibit at first as most of the stuff that was being shown across the convention was somewhat similar in its look and also the way it was being described as i.e. â€˜Some new cardboardâ€™, â€˜a new bag designâ€™, â€˜a new method of sealing containersâ€™ etc.
But once I stopped at the more design related booths it was a lot more interesting.
A really good part was the BNO NEXTpack booth where the products being displayed where much more exciting. Instead of just presenting a new material compound, here were products that actually used some of these new materials and ideas in a real-world application.
The main ones that stood out firstly on their immediate visual impact but later on with their rationale were some Heineken and Jumbo products.
The Heineken products were a series of bottles, cans and glassware that gave the user a real experience across a range of innovative ideas, such as: a bottle with a light up star that reacts to the beat of dance music, a bottle which has a personalised label to connect with the user. Lastly a branded cup that fits on-top of cans and bottles, encouraging and allowing the user to drink responsibly by holding water. Along with these bottles were the VBAT/DBOD designed Heineken light up bottles which was cool to see.
The Jumbo stuff was much more simple but equally as impactful with its visual design. Using simple and basic product shapes: butter, milk and wine but applying the traditional Jumbo yellow all over them with bold 3D letters placed on top of them. A simple idea executed well; although Iâ€™m not sure how practical this is for the shelf.
I attended some of the talks that were taking place on the day. The first one was by Paul Earnshaw, packaging manager from the huge UK supermarket company Tesco. This was insightful as he was explaining how people are able to get their products into Tesco stores and also current food trends that the UK consumers are buying into right now, which also reflect the design, such as â€œretro renaissanceâ€ â€” 70â€™s/80â€™s looking design, â€œhow formal is normalâ€ â€” high cost products packaged in a less formal and affordable way and vice versa and â€œrestless tasteâ€ â€” how consumers want the next food taste all the time. These topics were all interesting to me and I totally understood and connected with what he was saying along with his British humor and jokes. I also shop at Tesco regularly in the UK so Iâ€™ve witnessed these trends.
At the Dieline conference there were a range of talks as well as the chosen designs on display of which had won awards. What I liked here were the cans for â€˜Fort Point Beer Companyâ€™ which were described as â€˜ornately old-fashionedâ€™. They were simply really nice can designs using geometric patterns and illustrations with a single weight line. The colours were also really nice and despite being dull greens and blues they really did pop and attract my attention, further research showed me that the packs and boxes that the cans were transported in were equally as beautifully designed with the same principles.
There were also some talks organised by The Dieline, one was by Leeds based branding agency â€” Elmwood, about design and its role in packaging and how we can really play to all of our senses. It was good but quite word heavy.
My favourite talk however was by PJ (Pieter Jelle Braaksma) from VBAT where he presented the Prophecy whiskey project.
I didnâ€™t know much about this project and the talk was really different from the other talks as it was much more personal and wasnâ€™t just about the beautiful design and final outcome of the bottle â€” the entire process was explained and it made me appreciate the bottle design a lot more than just seeing the final glossy images.
Overall it was good day out and nice to explore and experience a different part of Amsterdam and also to see some great new packaging things. The discipline of packaging isnâ€™t what I am most interested in or directly connected to but I do like seeing these kinds of things and itâ€™s always good to see what the future of any industry is; especially one that we as consumers are a vital part of and get to experience it daily.
If you enjoyed reading this, please click ğŸ’š â€œRecommendâ€ below. This will help to share the story with others.
Follow VBAT on Twitter | Like us on Facebookwritten by Craig BerryCreative at VBATedited by Connie FluhmePR at VBAT
--

Title: TdR Stage 1: Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The first stop is Amsterdam, the Venice of the north. Although Iâ€™ve been to the Rapha store a few times, it was the first time hanging out with folks in the store and a mate visiting from Ye olde Kingdom. Nourished with a hot Chocolademelk with the obligatory slagroom, the visit quickly devolved into ogling up the amazing-looking Rapha x Van Gogh Museum Canyon hanging on the wall.
On a side note, each Rapha Clubhouse has its stash collection and unique emblem representing a local aspect of the host city â€” X Marks the Spot, nine crosses of Saint Andrew in echelon format.
Occasionally, the clubhouses have extremely limited collections borne out of collaborations with local artists or institutions, such as the Van Gogh museum or SaÅ¡a Ostoja. Generally, these tend to fly off the shelves, but now and then, some secret stash locations remain unbeknownst to most â€” head on over to the Van Gogh Museum website for a chance to nab some remaining pieces ;)
How would I rate the Rapha Amsterdam Clubhouse?
Verdict: I would visit again and again
Although not home to a Rapha Clubhouse (yet?), we next headed to Antwerp as a seemingly close-by location for heading to Hoogerheide for the CX World Cup. As it turns out, heading toward the river and old town yields a beautiful experience, whereas turning right takes you into â€œone of the sketchiest suburbs in all of Belgium.â€ Much to the chagrin of my mate, who had initially booked an AirBnB in the latter area only to require police intervention to get his stuff back after canceling his AirBnB over safety concerns.
Freshly rested in a new Airbnb next to the Cathedral of our Lady Antwerp, the only question was:
How do we spend a day in Antwerp? Letâ€™s go to a cycling cafe! How about after that? Itâ€™s Belgium, so a brewery?
The interactive De Koninck Antwerp tour started with a freshly poured Bollecke and was followed by a self-poured Triple Dâ€™Anvers halfway around the museum.
The first response upon seeing a chemistry lab with fully stocked beer fridges by my â€˜started chemistry and decided it ainâ€™t for meâ€™ mate was â€” maybe I should go back to chemistry?
Although Iâ€™d argue that visiting the Clubhouse was the main highlight of the trip, the main event was undoubtedly the CX WorldCup in Hoogerheide. The WC was indeed an â€œinterestingâ€ experience.
Given the course layout, the consensus of the Hoogerheide experience was standing in a cold field to watch a race on TV and occasionally going â€“ oh right, itâ€™s happening behind me.
What made it were the random interactions along the way â€” from hanging out with a belated Flybe-stranded Irishman to trying random beers and food concoctions. The hilarious standout moment was a sudden shriek and forming of space around someone pissing himself while staring straight at the TV, utterly unphased with a beer in hand as the battle between Van Aert and Van der Pool evolved.
One way or the other, the entire trip and its antics can be summed up as
Seems appropriate
Next stop â€” London
--
--
Nomadic research consultant with a penchant for cycling

Title: Dutch the way I like it. A Pinayâ€™s travel guide to Amsterdam, Netherlands
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Dutch the way aha, aha, I like it!
Welcome to a country where sex trade and smoking marijuana is legal. I donâ€™t see it perplexing in a first-world country like the Netherlands. But on the contrary, I am not a fan of both.
I am an enthusiast for riding bikes though and this was definitely something I didnâ€™t miss. Amsterdam is known to be one of the most bike-friendly cities in the world. Highways, streets and alleys offer a space for bike lanes. In fact, it is true that bikes surpass Amsterdamâ€™s human population. There were so many people riding their bikes everywhere that I was more likely to collide with another biker than with a car.
I wonâ€™t elaborate much on food because I had been eating at Subway and satisfied my daily cravings for fresh croissants and ready-made salads and fruits from the supermarket but I tried waffles, jams, and cheese. After all, Dutch people like fried food which I am not fond of and they say they eat warm food only at dinner most of the time because they prefer easy to eat or on-the-go kind of meals such as sandwiches.
I flew to Amsterdam straight from a well-known island destination of the Dutch themselves, the island of Santorini. I was ready for a cooler and even rainy climate and yes it was way too cold for my taste when I arrived but the skies cleared the next day until the end of my stay. What a lucky tropical girl I was! I enjoyed up to 22 to 26 celsius of midday heat. Perfect enough for a tropical girl like me to shed away layer of clothes and show some bare skin.
It would be wise to buy a a travel ticket which gives you unlimited access to trains, trams, and busses within the Amsterdam city centre and its outer region. There are a lot of options to choose from when it comes to tickets so I suggest you check them out early on through this website https://www.iamsterdam.com/en/plan-your-trip/getting-around/public-transport. You can buy these tickets right at the airport. Just look for Iamsterdam booth/store.
I highly suggest you buy the Regional ticket if you are in Amsterdam for more than a day so that you can check out the attractions outside of the city centre such as Zaanse Schans, Haarlem and even Lisse where you can find the famous Keukenhof Gardens. I chose the 3-day Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket which cost 33,50 Euros.
My first day was spent walking around the city centre and getting to know the vibe and the streets, canals and lovely bridges which looked entirely the same at every turn!
The next day was spent seeing the city of Haarlem which is obviously much more relaxed and quiet. It was just all about this place in one day, walking, window shopping, seeing how people live their everyday lives, and watching children bike all the way home from school. I and my bubbly travel buddy, Cassandra, spent more than an hour sipping delicious coffee at a very cozy restaurant located at the corner street. It was a relaxed and amazing day to really get to see and know this part of the countryâ€™s capital.
We enjoyed a day of bike ride! There were many bike shops to rent a bike from but we chose Green Budget Bikes because it was closest to our hostel and it was fortunately the bike shop that offered the cheapest rent. For just 10 Euros, we had the bikes entirely at our disposal for 24 hours. It has three shops around the city and you can find them below.
Here are my TOP THREE picks of interesting tours in Amsterdam. These tours will save you time by avoiding having to fall in line to get tickets.
Like I said, my Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket gave me the freedom to hop on and off trains, trams and busses as I wished. This let me go to Zaandam which was my home base during the rest of my stay. Zaandam is fortunately where Zaanse Schans, a typical old style Dutch neighbourhood, is located. I rented the green bike for 24 hours so I had the chance to take it home with me and take an early morning bike ride to this place before I was required to return it at 1:30 PM at the city centre. This is a very charming town where you can see traditional windmills and enjoy museums that let you see how windmills work and how Dutch people make traditional gouda cheese which Netherlands is known for around the world. There is no entrance fee here. All you need to do is arrive and enjoy the rest of your stay.
Amsterdam is a place where coffee shops legally sell pastries mixed with cannabis. It is a place where it is common to experience the stink or smell of marijuana while you are walking down the street. It is a city where to find the Museum of Prostitution, the Museum of Erotism, Torture Museum or the Museum of Cannabis. These museums may likely give you an impression that Amsterdam is not a safe place but donâ€™t let it dampen your spirits. Because all these are legalised and properly regulated, Amsterdam is safe and has indeed become one of my favourite cities in Europe.
If prostitution is legal, then Red Light District definitely exists and is even a famous spot for tourists. This is a proper place in the city to hire prostitutes who stand behind a glass window while dressed in skimpy clothes. These windows are literally lit with red neon lights at night time when these women are â€œworkingâ€. Here, prostitutes pay taxes, and are offered medical care and protection against discrimination or abuse. It is highly prohibited to take pictures of women at the Red Light District so if you donâ€™t want your vacation to be a mess, keep your camera and phones in your bags. Brothels, sex shops, live showsâ€¦name it. The Red Light District has it. And whatever you may have heard about this place might just be all true.
Speaking of museums, Amsterdam is famous for iconic painters such as Vincent Van Gogh, Rembrandt and many others. Here you will find Van Gogh Museum, Rijksmuseum and Anne Frank House Museum. There is no need to purchase tickets in advance for Van Gogh or Rijksmuseum but if you are keen to see the inside of Anne Frankâ€™s house where she hid for two years during the Nazi regime, then it is best to purchase tickets with your credit card through the AnneFrank website. I chose to skip this because my phone didnâ€™t have the international roaming service from my local phone provider so I couldnâ€™t receive the code sent by my credit card company every time I wanted to purchase something online.
I had the chance to vicariously see the inside of Anne Frankâ€™s house through the movie The Fault in our Stars anyway so it was no longer something to obsess about. It would have been a good experience but I didnâ€™t have a ticket. I rode the bike towards the museum though and I and my travel buddy was outside for a couple of minutes. The house was surprisingly modern from the outside because the building was renovated but as seen in the movie, the inside remained intact as it was in the 1940â€™s.
I am a fan of Van Gogh so I bought a ticket for 18 Euros. I was excited to see his paintings in person and get to know him more through the exhibits inside the museum. Most of Van Goghâ€™s work can be found in this museum except for the famous Starry Night painting which is located in New York at the Modern Museum of Art. It was still worth seeing his lifeâ€™s work from the time when he first practiced painting up until his death at a ripe age of 37. I was happy to feel closer to the incredible but short-lived life of a highly talented and troubled Dutch painter.
Amsterdam is such a beautiful city with beautiful parks and gardens. It was so easy to get lost in time sitting by the bench and watching people. I especially loved this fountain where you can play with the water and risk getting wet if you dare go inside the circle and miss the proper timing. We all felt like kids! It was so refreshing!
Tulip season runs from the end of March until mid May, but the flowers are usually at their best halfway through April. More than 7 million flower bulbs bloom in spring at the Keukenhof in Lisse. I would say that going to Keukenhof was an extraordinary experience. I was glad to never have ignored going to this amazing place. It was unbelievably beautiful. I couldnâ€™t believe my eyes seeing all those blooming colourful flowers everywhere. What a beautiful, beautiful world we live in. Donâ€™t miss this when you are around Amsterdam during spring time. Just donâ€™t you dare miss it.
I would say it felt and looked like heaven on earth.
This country is expensive. Thatâ€™s a given.
It is therefore very important to manage your day wisely to be able to take advantage of the budget you have during your stay. I hope you got some helpful tips and ideas from this blog and find your way to Amsterdam and enjoy Dutch culture to the fullest. Good luck!
--
--
I delight in the unconventional weirdness of the world

Title: Afterthought: Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I love to travel, more specifically I love to travel internationally. If one can be so lucky to visit other countries in their lifetime, do it. For some people, Iâ€™ve learned, this statement is obvious â€” of course you should travel, why wouldnâ€™t you? these people can simply afford to travel without consequence. The idea isnâ€™t even considered an impossibility to some â€” they just plan and go. Theyâ€™ve never known a life without the boundaries of financial difficulties. I say all this as a preemptive statement because I know how lucky Iâ€™ve been, and for as much as Iâ€™ve traveled, Iâ€™ve never taken it for granted. In a sense I want to show my humility in my travels, and in another, Iâ€™m talking directly towards some of the people Iâ€™ve met and known in New York City for whom personal, international travel is an exception, not a privilege, and their influence effects my perspective on travel.
My first time out of the country was in 2000, I was fifteen years old when, with my high school Russian language class, I visited Russia. Collectively, we spent ten days in Moscow and St. Petersburg and the experience was profound for me. Not only did the experience open my eyes to new landscapes, people and architecture (staying overnight at a monastery that was over 500 years old will bring some perspective on whatâ€™s considered â€œoldâ€), but this was pre-9/11, in a world where it was easier to travel internationally. For that, Iâ€™m grateful I was able to see a part of the world before it became even more hostile and suspicious. Seeing a film in a cinema whilst in Russia was not on the itinerary. However, I was able to catch snippets of Once Upon A Time In The West (1968) on a fuzzy television in a hotel room in St. Petersburg, over-dubbed in that monosyllabic Russian voice Iâ€™d come to realize was more common than not in televised films. The sole voice of a man dispersing every line of dialogue that was said in English, in Russian, without inflection or change for characters. As stating, matter of factly, these are the words that are being said in this movie.
From 2000 onwards I wasnâ€™t able to travel internationally for another twelve years, but continuing to see the world was always on my mind. In between that time I used my wanderlust to traverse across the country by way of road trips and destinations to music festivals to: Florida, Mississippi, Georgia, Washington, Missouri, Michigan, California, Tennessee, Texas, Iowa, Wisconsin, Indiana, New York, Illinois, Idaho; and to Canada, Manitoba and British Columbia.
Because of the focus of these essays, serving to regale the memories of going to the cinema, you might think Iâ€™m going to recount my cinematic memories for every one of these states or road trips. No, not entirely. I could go on about my memories of The Oriental Cinema in Milwaukee, or The Music Box Theatre or The Gene Siskel Film Center in Chicago during my college years, but Iâ€™ll keep those for myself. Although the recollections of being independent for the first time and seeing Lost in Translation or The Return of the King in 2003 prove to be warm and comforting, Iâ€™m going to focus elsewhere.
These long-form essays will focus on: Amsterdam and Tangier, with a forthcoming essay on Los Angeles and their cinema scene.
After that twelve-year dryspell of international travel, I was finally able to satiate my desire to leave the U.S., and in the spring of 2012 I traveled to Paris, France and later that summer went to live and work in Amsterdam, Netherlands.
I came somewhat late to completing my higher education. After dropping out of a university I took a gap year, enrolled in a film program at a college in Chicago, then dropped out again after two years. I floundered in my mid-twenties until I finally decided to try one last time to get a degree. I would attend a small, private arts college and study for my BFA in photography. In the third year of every studentâ€™s education at the arts college, part of the curriculum was to engage in an internship for their focus: sculpture, printmaking, painting, graphic design or photography. There were no specifications that ones internship had to be in or around the city we were in (Minneapolis or St. Paul, Minnesota), they simply had to be concerned with ones focus and had to abide by a certain number of hours worked. Since I saw this as an opportunity to take on an internship wherever I wanted, I reasoned my way towards Europe.
Here was my rationale: I didnâ€™t want to fulfill an internship in the Twin Cities, so you expand from there, and realize, I donâ€™t want to be in this region, either. So that crosses off Chicago, St. Louis, Milwaukee, Cleveland. What about the coasts? Would you look towards San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York City or Philadelphia? I reviled both coasts, the binary choice of choosing between East Coast or West Coast still annoyed me then. So where, then? Outside of the country? Yes, thatâ€™s possible. Why not? In Europe â€” Paris, London, where? Well, my grandmother, whom I never got the chance to meet, was from Holland, and supposedly we still have distant relatives there. Maybe this could be an opportunity to experience a part of my heritage Iâ€™ve never known. So, The Netherlands, is it? Yeah, letâ€™s say I want to do my internship in The Netherlands. Where in The Netherlands? Amsterdam, of course.
Over half a year spent in correspondence with different Dutch art galleries proved a success when my desire to intern at an art gallery in Amsterdam was accepted by the Annet Gelink Gallery, in the Jordaan district. Iâ€™d live in Amsterdam-Noord, in an apartment used typically for post-graduate residents at de Appel Arts Centre, or visiting artists, on Oleanderstraat. I found the room a day before I got on the plane, and luckily the setup worked perfect: Iâ€™d walk or bike to the ferry and take it into Centraal Station, and from there meander along the canals, soon formulating a routine and feeling that I was an Amsterdammer. It was a new, exciting, wild, breathtaking experience, being on my own, living and working in a different country.
The owner of the gallery, Annet, when she became aware of my affinity towards films, mentioned something to me about The Eye Filmmuseum, or rather, the â€œspaceshipâ€ on the river which had finally completed construction earlier that year. Iâ€™d noticed this giant, white building that, indeed, looked like a parked spaceship, as I took the ferry to and from my apartment, but I never knew what it was. I was a bit intimidated to approach it, in fact, but now that I knew what I was seeing was a film museum my interest rose and I planned to visit on some weekend.
The summer of 2012 was the return of Wes Anderson, who, in my mind up to that point, had lost his way. With the financial failure of the depressing, bloated The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2005) (his most expensive film at the time, a film which I like, but is too dour to embrace), his follow up, The Darjeeling Limited (2007), was smaller in scale and budget, and, I thought, completely wayward. I was disappointed by some of Andersonâ€™s cultural appropriations and cliched storytelling of rich, white people and their problems seeking out spiritual enlightenment by traveling to India and meeting â€œreal people.â€ Although, what came next, The Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009), was a surprise, an enjoyable animated Roald Dahl adaptation. The film also failed to recoup its production costs at the box office (although, it appears to have had a longer lifespan than most of his films, becoming endlessly re-watchable and used as a perfect example for embracing the autumnal season), and then the idea of Wes Anderson being able to be as creatively wild as his earlier films promised looked dimmer and dimmer with each modest success. That is until 2012 and Moonrise Kingdom,
a film that broke the wheel of Andersonâ€™s seeming listlessness, transitioning between a nascent filmmaker into a professional craftsman, and pointed towards a new direction, a new era.
Walking up the stairs and into The Eye Filmmuseum, Iâ€™m struck by just how beautiful this new modern building is, the contradiction of futuristic design, clean, white angular shapes and rustic, ancient wooden floorboards that rise up and level off as they lead towards the auditoriums. That spacious, relaxed, open lobby is a place to eat or drink at the bar, sit before a film or mull over a film after a screening and look out at the river, and Amsterdam beyond that. Their shop is world class and the programming, I would learn, is monumental. The film collection of the museum itself is one of the oldest and most important in the world, having their formative roots, in the iteration of Nederlands Historisch Film Archief, created in 1946.
Every city should have a film museum. You have your historical art museum, your modern one, even a local art museum â€” most cities have science museums and ones for children, but seldom are there as frequent as those just mentioned, are there film or cinema museums. Why is that? Am I not looking deep enough? Okay, Iâ€™d reason that most cities have a film society (maybe connected to their most prominent university or college), and they screen films at different locations and are a small unit of cinema devotees and film programmers. But if most cities have childrenâ€™s museums, film museums should be up there on cultural priorities, at least. The Eye Filmmuseum was the culmination of 70+ years of collecting, restoring and moving from venue to venue, starting small, finding space in The Reijksmuseum, almost moving its collection to Rotterdam until the government finally intervened and planned its final location in Noord-Amsterdam along The River Ij.
Seeing Moonrise Kingdom with some trepidation at Eye Filmmuseum was spectacular, because my doubts of Andersonâ€™s direction were satiated in that tween love story of 1965. I became obsessed with the film (a film about puppy love, infidelity, unrequited love, sad people told through monotone dialogue delivery), its music became the soundtrack of the summer, it reinvigorated my love of cinema, it made me fantasize about romance, young love (I wonder where my first crush is right now? Still living in Japan?), and the East coast island vibes, rainy nights and quaint forests, lived on in my imagination as the rain fell on The Netherlands.
Cycling through Amsterdam in the rain and listening to Gary & The Playboys or Hank Williams, it felt particularly strange to feel the sensation of a slice of American culture whilst in the lowlands. 8tracks, a music website that would allow one to make a mix online to post and share (the conceit being you could only choose eight tracks on your playlist, instead of infinite songs), collaborated with American Empirical Pictures to release a few playlists on their site. The playlists were credited for each prominent character, as in, Bruce Willisâ€™ Captain Sharp picked these Hank Williams and Buck Owens songs for you to hear, or these are the songs that characterize Cousin Ben, Sam & Suzy, The Bishops, and it made being immersed in the film even more possible.
Being in a different country whose native language wasnâ€™t English was also a trip. Like I said, at this point Iâ€™d only ever traveled to Russia and France. In both instances a trip to the cinema wasnâ€™t on the table, but now here I was in The Netherlands at a cinema. English isnâ€™t the native language of The Netherlands, but everyone speaks English, anyway. Itâ€™s not intimidating to speak English without feeling youâ€™re inconveniencing anyone, or even, to try to learn a few Dutch phrases to order a coffee, a pastry, and dispense some pleasantries. I always try to learn the language of wherever it is Iâ€™m traveling. I want to fit in, I want to be respectful and see how other people live, listen and express themselves. However, since itâ€™s a Dutch-speaking country, Wes Andersonâ€™s film was subtitled in Dutch, and before the screening a short film (from the Dutch film archives, a newsreel on winter skating in the canals from the 1960â€™s) was programmed, which wasnâ€™t subtitled in English. It was interesting to follow the imagery to try to glean some insight into what was happening, to hear the audience collectively laugh in parts and then attempt to figure out what was so funny.
Thatâ€™s something I wish Iâ€™d have tried more often in my travels â€” to see a film in the native language of whichever country I was in, without English subtitles. Of course, I can do that watching any international film on home video or online (just flip the subtitles off), but being in another country, surrounded by another culture different than my own, itâ€™s an entirely new experience. Itâ€™s an experiment in engaged watching and listening, itâ€™s an exercise in immersion. Conversely, watching an English language film amongst non-native speakers is interesting. You glean a different appreciation for humor, insight into drama receptiveness. Hearing the crowd, you can understand a different culture and what they appreciate through the visual art of cinema.
What I gleaned from this screening is that teenage romance is the same everywhere, and Andersonâ€™s humor and visual wit translate to mass appreciation from the Dutch.
After the film I went into the shop and bought three movie posters: Eraserhead, A Clockwork Orange, and The Shining. When I got back to my apartment I put them on the wall. I was making the place my own, I was finding the things that I could connect with and brought them home with me. The hanging of movie posters on a wall might seem cliche, but looking at those posters brought me comfort, familiarity, and knowing they were printed in The Netherlands made me feel a connection that people here also loved films.
Later on that summer, one day in June, as if casually, the gallery owner mentioned she had tickets to an opening exhibition but couldnâ€™t make it due to other plans. She asked if I wanted one, to which I asked, Whatâ€™s the exhibition?â€œItâ€™s the opening of the Stanley Kubrick exhibition at The Eye Film museum. Do you know who Stanley Kubrick is?â€ She asked.
In my mind I wanted to explode with the enthusiasm of a schoolboy ready to expound all of his knowledge of the filmmaker. Yes, I know all of his films. Iâ€™ve been watching and studying them since I was 13 years old. Iâ€™ve seen Barry Lyndon five times. Iâ€™ve even seen Fear and Desire! But I held my tongue and said,â€œYeah, I know who he is, 2001, right? Brilliant filmmaker.â€â€œYes, spectacular film. Would you want a ticket? I have two â€” â€â€œI can go,â€ interrupted Marie-Claire, the second intern Iâ€™d met that summer â€” a relatively young, lithe woman with bushy eyebrows and an intense stare.â€œGood. Here you go. The two of you together.â€ Said Annet, handing us our tickets.
So Marie-Claire and myself planned on meeting up to see the exhibition together. With Sam and Suzyâ€™s love story practically in my marrow, I tried not to over compensate and fetch for a summer love story.
We met outside, both of us dressed in black, and made our way into the auditorium, which was filling up very fast. As part of the Stanley Kubrick Exhibition, Eye Filmmuseum would be screening all of his films throughout the summer (save for Fear and Desire [1952], Kubrickâ€™s first film, which, at the time, could really only be seen in private screenings and was not as promoted as much as Killerâ€™s Kiss [1955], his second feature, for being of interest to view), but that evening, it was about the material. I didnâ€™t realize it at the time until Christiane Kubrick (Kubrickâ€™s widow) said it, but this was the worldwide opening of what would become a traveling show that toured for at least six years afterwards. A show that would include ephemera from Stanley Kubrickâ€™s life and filmmaking career: his film cameras, his Golden Lion Award from the Venice Film Festival, storyboards and script excerpts for all of his films behind cubes of glass, movie posters from a myriad of countries, props, miniatures, costumes, drawings, any and everything you could think of was displayed in a series of black rooms where the only blank walls were being projected clips from his films. The rooms full of sounds: Penderecki, Nelson Riddle, Also sprach Zarathustra, Wendy Carlos, Handel and Ligeti.
Marie-Claire and I sat next to each other and listened as the director of the museum introduced Christiane Kubrick and Jan Harlan (Kubrickâ€™s brother-in-law and producing partner for over 30 years), who soon gave a brief introduction, a quick Q&A after which we were presented with a short film trailer for the exhibition, as if to get us even more ready to view the collection.
When the exhibition opened up I was in awe. Marie-Claire and I kind of nodded to each other as if to say, This is cool, overwhelming, and we donâ€™t need to stick together if we want to, we can explore. All that in a nod, but we got it â€” this was a big deal, not only for Kubrick admirers, film fans, but the Amsterdam film scene, absolutely. I noticed how small Jan Harlan was when I said hello to him, after having only seen him in documentaries on DVDs when I was a teenager, it was surreal to be standing next to him. The exhibit was overwhelming, and it was so overwhelming that I went back two more times when I attended 35mm film screenings of Barry Lyndon (1975) and Eyes Wide Shut (1999).
When I wasnâ€™t working, I was wandering. I was exploring the city until it felt like home, walking and cycling, with some trips outside of the canal rings, Iâ€™d visit Haarlem and cycle up to Marken (an island village known for their wooden homes). Wandering around Amsterdam I came across a magnificent building, the PathÃ© Tuschinski. By chance Iâ€™d come across it after what looked like a premiere had happened and I snapped a picture. I made a mental note of where this place was in order to return soon.
I never found out what the movie was, but the building shook me to my core. A tall, bronze, golden, green art deco masterpiece. It stood out between the middling, unimpressive buildings beside it. I couldnâ€™t believe this was a movie theater. Iâ€™d heard of â€œmovie palacesâ€ before, and Iâ€™d thought that Iâ€™d been to a few, but this was unparalleled. Such grace, such attention to detail, such reverence for a place that screened films.
The theme of intimidation grows as I approach the Tuschinski Theater on tiptoes, careful not to offend, not to do the wrong thing. I found that my personality throughout my travels abroad was to never offend. To be just right, plain, interested and open, but never boisterous. The stereotypical American abroad I was not. I knew I was a guest, and as a guest I wanted to abide by my hostâ€™s rules and traditions. The concept of being that arrogant American persona never even entered my mind as I traveled. Perhaps it was my first experience in Russia, wherein I was somewhat familiar with the culture already, or maybe it was my upbringing and how I was taught to interact with the world, but to act as if I owned the fucking joint just because I was American â€” no, hell no, never, the idea that I could make someone else uncomfortable or feel bad was not in my purview. Perhaps, and this is a stretch, Minnesotaâ€™s claim as being â€œAmericaâ€™s Canadaâ€ played into my attitude in a different country. I just wanted to be nice to people.
So as I enter into the cinema and order my ticket, I buy a cup of green tea and wait in the opulent lobby for the auditorium to be opened. The film I was seeing wasnâ€™t particularly worthy of the cinema I was seeing it in, it was The Amazing Spider-Man (2012). I had no real interest in seeing this re-boot of another version of Peter Parkerâ€™s origin story at all, but itâ€™s all that was playing there, and I kind of wanted to experience this movie palace.
When the auditorium let out and we were allowed to go in, I felt like I was underdressed. Red and gold, amber lights, a stage with footlights and a golden curtain.
Like many movie palaces from the early part of the 20th century, its use was manifold â€” from indeed being a place to premiere and screen films, they were also used for musical performances. In The Tuschinski theatre, Marlene Dietrich, Edith Piaf, and Louis Armstrong all played on that stage. The surrounding architecture of the auditorium had the seats fanned out in an oval with multiple levels, in a design that is rarely seen or built these days.
One had to feel veneration sitting in a place like this if it were an uncommon visit, and the fact that PathÃ© were screening a superhero movie about a mutant spider-kid made it all the more strange. When the lights went down, the Grolsch bottles opened up. At first it annoyed me, those swing top bottles popping open with such a pronouncement, but after I realized what they were, and that people were relaxed enough here to have a beer in a movie theater, the noise grew endearing.
I donâ€™t remember much of the film I saw. I really wasnâ€™t paying that much attention to it, really. It was simply incredible to be in this space, and seeing an American movie, at that, was a bit like maybe putting a CD into a boombox and listening to The Prodigy inside The Sistine Chapel. Old and new. Elegance and loudness. Unfortunately, most of what they screened were new, American releases of films I had little interest in seeing. If only the films were up to the standards of the movie palaces, things wouldâ€™ve equalled out.
I became immersed in the world I lived in, and being there I forgot about America, and of course, at times I felt homesick, but not for anything specific, just a sense of a familiar culture. Moonrise Kingdom filled that void, and Eyes Wide Shut did, too, but in a way, not having easy access to communicate with people in The States was the best thing for me. I never wanted to be in two places at once, to feel that where I was was temporary. This was it, there was nothing else but that moment, be there and live it up and experience all there is to experience. Donâ€™t wish you were somewhere else, if only because you worked so hard to get here, may as well keep pushing your ambitions further.
My little experience of shedding some of America was disturbed that summer. The first inclination of how America was perceived from out of the country was the tragedy of a mass shooting inside a cinema during a screening of The Dark Knight Rises in the state of Colorado. Iâ€™d heard nothing about it, I wasnâ€™t paying attention to any news coming out of America and I loved it, until someone at the gallery mentioned this news story to me. The news headlines were on their computer and their response to me was one of concern, as if I should have an explanation for the event. I didnâ€™t. If any explanation came out at all, it was one of despair (America loves its guns and it will never change, itâ€™s a violent culture). It was tragic, unbearably violent and horrific, but I had no connection to the event or those people. It was depressing to have the impression put upon oneself that where I came from was a place of extreme, nonsensical violence. Maybe I was like that, too. How could I explain it? Was it my responsibility to be an ambassador for a place that huge, with a multitude of different cultures and ideals? I tried to just represent myself, alone, stoic, with my American English accent. Now people had to be concerned that the cinema was unsafe from terror. The world would become more violent, and every place one deemed safe was now being prepped for exit strategies and warned of suspicious activities.
Iâ€™d leave Amsterdam that year, Iâ€™d visit again five years later and yearn to stay. God how I want to work and live there, to forget all thatâ€™s behind me and forge a new life ahead, in a new land, but maybe not yet.
--
--

Remembering Amsterdam Houses
I wrote this essay nearly 30 years ago, drawing on interviews with my parents and research on Amsterdam Houses. I revisited it after reading some of the excellent history in The Legacies of San Juan Hill on the Lincoln Center website.
Although some of the information is now outdated (especially rental prices!) I resisted updating it. Iâ€™ve added footnotes in a couple of places, but thatâ€™s it.
Keep in mind this was written circa 1995.
The West Side I knew was just beginning its transformation.
There are time-machine moments in New York City, when something out of synch with the present comes into view and provides you with a glimpse of the past. It might be an odd, faded building sign, a storefrontâ€™s original wood frame, barely visible under decades of old paint, or the trolley tracks that relentlessly push through their tar graves. A sound can do it, powerfully, I discovered. Once, in an office where I worked on the far west side of 58th Street,[1] I could hear the brisk clopping sounds of horses making their way from a nearby stable. I knew the sound was connected to the horse and buggies that tourists love, but for a split second, I thought of how common that sound was a hundred years ago. It was probably a sound that my grandparents were familiar with when they arrived from Puerto Rico in 1918.
The far, west side of the city was always a congenial place for those encounters with the past. You can see the Hudson River without a man-made promenade from Amsterdam Avenue and other points along the west side in the 50s and 60s. Until recently, there wasnâ€™t a whole lot of building going on. Until recently.
If you walk along some parts of West End Avenue in the sixties, you can see the parade of new high-rises, including Trump Place, that block the cherished views and light of the older high-rises, such as Lincoln Towers. The New York Times has been diligent in covering some of the reverberations that have shaken â€œlongtime residents.â€ Their window views of sunlight, sky and their sliver of the Hudson are gone.
It may simply seem that people with money have been one-upped by other people with even more money. But when I visit the area, I feel a keen sense of loss for the neighborhood I knew, and the low-income families such as ours who thrived there. For example, on West End Avenue, there are people who have lost not just their view but, one can argue, the kind of neighborhood that was once congenial to their kind: not largely poor, not mostly white, but working families who were getting so close to the security of the middle class that they could almost taste and touch it. Those are the families who live in places like Amsterdam Houses, a low-income housing project, squeezed between Lincoln Center and Trump Place.
You may not have heard of Amsterdam Houses, or if you did, you may not have placed it as a neighbor to Trump Place. The area map posted on the Trump Place website does not show the housing project, which runs from 64th Street to 61st Street, from West End to Amsterdam Avenues. It does show other neighbors who are much farther east from the luxury towers: the Museum of Natural History, for example
And why would a developer cite a low-income housing project as a neighbor? No one gets credit for mixing rich and poor, black and white when it comes to housing. Itâ€™s not a draw for most people buying a home or renting an apartment.
It was a different time and place when my parents arrived at Amsterdam Houses. To trace their arrival at, and their departure from, Amsterdam Houses is to map what had once been a familiar journey for many families struggling to â€œmake itâ€ out of tenements and projects, into some kind of holy land of home ownership. That journey, with all of its twists and turns, not only defined their neighborhoods, it defined them as New Yorkers.
For my parents, as for many others, moving around the city was a game of hopscotch. Before obtaining their first Amsterdam apartment, they had already lived in several Manhattan neighborhoods. My motherâ€™s family, who arrived from Puerto Rico in 1945, rented various apartments first on the Lower East Side and Greenwich Village before moving to an apartment on 54th Street between 9th and 10th avenues. My father was born in Manhattan, at East 39th St., off 2nd Ave., and as an adult his first apartment when he came out of the Navy after the second World War, was on W. 66th Street, where Lincoln Center stands today. Later, he shared a room with his brother on W. 84th Street.
After my parents married in 1951, they stayed in the W. 54th St. apartment where her mother still lived. It was a back apartment, overlooking the backyards of newer buildings. A police station was across the street; a chocolate factory was down the block. When a family friend told her about Amsterdam Houses, she and my father immediately went to look at an empty apartment in the development. They were impressed: the unit had a new kitchen, and even if the rooms were small, there was storage space in the basement for strollers and carriages.
The New York City Housing Authority opened Amsterdam Houses for low-income families in 1948 on 10 acres between 61st and 64th streets, stretching from Amsterdam to West End avenues.
My parents moved into a two-bedroom apartment in the Amsterdam Houses at 248 West 62nd St. in 1952.
There were many World War II veterans and their families in Amsterdam at the time, my mother recalled, but they didnâ€™t stay very long. It is easy to imagine those families using the projects as a brief stopping off point, before purchasing a house in the suburbs. For others who followed, Amsterdam would be home for a longer while. When my parents needed more space, they chose to relocate to a larger two-bedroom in the projects, apartment 4D at 250 West 61st Street.
Home ownership was still years away. In the projects, there was still a newness that made it attractive. Amsterdam Houses was big and sprawling, the way a lot of low-income housing projects are, but there were parks, playgrounds and benches scattered around the grounds, and people congregated there and created community. My mother joined the other mothers who would sit on the benches and talk. She recalls that they were white, black, Puerto Rican, Cuban, Polish, Greek and Italian. In another small park, young men would bring their conga drums and jam on hot summer nights. When children played outside, it was underneath open windows, where a mother or older sister would look out every once in a while, to keep an eye on things. We could look up from where we played and see a familiar face.
A narrow park overlooking West End Ave. at 61st St. has no playground equipment but has more than 20 benches facing the river. The view itself was not spectacular: it was simply a sliver of the Hudson River and the New Jersey shoreline. What distinguished it was the amount of sky you could see, a release from the density of the tall brick buildings of Amsterdam Houses. My memories of Amsterdam will always be of playing double-dutch and other games under what seemed a spreading sky, not large by comparison to the rural sky, but large compared to what I saw in the rest of Manhattan. Those benches are a kind of testament to postwar optimism, New York City-style, a bread-and-roses approach to the needs of low-income families. Low-income housing is rarely conceived with those types of quality- of- life amenities.
Growing up in Amsterdam Houses, I took for granted the small parks, where I could mark the change of seasons by the color of leaves in the fall and the sound of conga drums in the summer. But change was already afoot by the mid-1960s. There was the constant drone of jackhammers and drills; the old tenements around the project were coming down at a fast pace, sidewalk sheds, made up of old, pastel painted doors and smelling of damp rooms went up. If it wasnâ€™t too unbearably hot, we kept the windows shut and the yellow parchment shades drawn against the early morning construction rattle.
We soon got a good look at what all the drilling and excavating was about. Lincoln Center opened its doors, although it showed its white marble back to Amsterdam Houses.
Thousands of low-income apartments were torn down for the cultural center, and never replaced. Grace Institute ran a small school for Catholic women but soon gave up its site for a new Fordham University campus. At St. Paul the Apostle School across the street, my classmates and I could monitor its progress. There was a slope of grass there one day, and the next it was gone. Losing Grace Institute and its grassy slope is one of my earliest memories of losing a personal landmark. While my classmates and I clapped erasers at arms length outside the window, or played in the cordoned off street, our neighborhood was changing forever around us, but we didnâ€™t know it.
Now the changes, large and small, obvious and subtle, are too numerous to count. On the east side of Amsterdam Ave., Power Memorial High School is long gone, replaced by a luxury high rise. On the west side of the avenue, just north of the Amsterdam Houses, there was once a Pioneer Supermarket and other affordable stores so critical to a communityâ€™s day-to-day life: a tailor, a shoe repair store, a variety store with odds and ends. Once, a person could shop at those stores, gradually walking uptown to 72nd St. and the crossroads of Columbus Ave. and Broadway. Today, two high schools â€” LaGuardia and Martin Luther King, Jr. â€” loom over the avenue where Pioneer once stood.
Trump Place is not the first luxury high rise development to touch Amsterdam Houses. Two luxury towers loom directly behind it, on West End Avenue. The rental office for the West End Towers issues business cards that say the buildings â€œoverlookâ€ Lincoln Center. Not quite. There are the 2,500 families in the 13 buildings of Amsterdam Houses standing between West End Towers, which opened two years ago, and Lincoln Center. The rents of the projects and the luxury towers occupy vastly different universes. At Amsterdam Houses, rents are tied to 30 percent of income, with the top rent somewhere in the low $600s. Tenants in the 1,000 West End Towers apartments are paying between $1,200 and $1,500 for a studio, $1,600 to $2,000 for a one-bedroom and $2,450 for a two bedroom. All of the 200 apartments set aside in West End Towers for working low-income families have been rented.
This is not nostalgia for a neighborhood Eden. My New York City is not the New York City of the 1940s or the 1950s, but the 1960s and 1970s, when things had seriously soured: people who could afford to, mostly, but not only whites, left the city in droves, jobs evaporated, and drugs seemed to be everywhere. That memory is still vivid to those of us who lived through it. There was the drug dealer who lived on the floor below us, and the night the police raided his apartment. Suddenly there was the smell of urine in the elevator. Something began to fray about the place, and the connections that made us feel strong seemed thinner. There were rumors about closing St. Paulâ€™s. And then the housing authority notified my parents that they made too much money to stay in the apartment. It was time to get out. They bought a house in Queens in 1969.
Suddenly when we looked back at â€œthe city,â€ as people in Queens called Manhattan, we wondered how we ever fit in. It looked more to us like a city of the very wealthy or the very poor, not the in-betweens that we were.
We were not used to feeling like outsiders in Manhattan. We had defined our community through the places where we shopped, played, and went to school, and those places were disappearing.
The narrow park overlooking West End Ave. is still there. But the view of the Hudson River is gone. Now the vista is blocked by the walls and windows of the West End Towers, where people are paying up to $2,450 for the light and sky that were once part of living in Amsterdam Houses. St. Paul the Apostle School was torn down for a luxury apartment building. In an improbable, small-town moment, I ran into Rev. Francis X. Ryan on 57th Street about 10 years ago. Father Ryan had been the pastor of St. Paulâ€™s parish when the last waves of students â€” mostly Puerto Rican, black and still some Irish â€” filed through. I recognized him immediately: he had changed little from the days when he scolded St. Paul students about jumping up â€” like kangaroos, he would say â€” from the altar rail after receiving Communion. â€œIt broke my heart when they closed that school,â€ he said. Not every child who lived in Amsterdam went to St. Paulâ€™s, and not all my friends were classmates there. But it was part of the diversity of the Amsterdam community, and something was lost when it closed.
The last time I saw many of my St. Paulâ€™s classmates was at an Amsterdam Houses Reunion.[2] The reunions were sporadic events over the years. I attended the 1985 reunion, in the playground of PS 191, right across the street from the projects on 60th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Some came from as far away as Puerto Rico and Atlanta; others were in Westchester or New Jersey. Some still had parents who lived in the projects. Others who never lived in the projects, but attended St. Paulâ€™s showed up, too. Some played softball, but most of us just hung out and caught up with one another. One of my former classmates and I walked over to where the school once stood. In its place was a luxury tower. She was a teacher in Puerto Rico, and it had been her dream to teach at St. Paulâ€™s some day. The new building abuts the Professional Childrenâ€™s School. Having a parochial school with mostly black and Latino students share a block with a school for child actors and models is the kind of neighborhood diversity that is becoming extinct in New York. When people talk about diversity, it is usually in terms of providing the poor, or the low-income or minority with a glimpse of how the other half lives. But diversity enriches in both directions. The erosion of New Yorkâ€™s liberal tradition may very well be traced to our isolation from one another, our lack of conversation with people different from ourselves.
Shutting St. Paul the Apostle school was another small rip in the fabric of that community, and it also settled an old score. When the school was open, 60th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam was closed off so that we could play in the street during recess. Swarms of girls in their rolled-up plaid skirts and boys in their white shirts and navy blue ties congregated in front of the school. It was there that we spied the students from the Professional Childrenâ€™s School next door. They were the misfits then, a school for performing artists in a very working-class neighborhood. But they have endured, and we have not. The saddest part is that our families are not missed, our contribution to the city not fully weighed and appraised. We are as out of synch with the West Side today as those horses I used to hear, dragging their carriages from west to east to ply their trade.
[1] The Caribbean Cultural Center, where I worked briefly in the early 1980s, is now located in East Harlem.
[2] The 1969 graduating class of St. Paulâ€™s had a great 25th reunion in 2004, thanks to our classmate and my Amsterdam Houses upstairs neighbor (now Florida resident) Lindsay Santos.
--
--
1
Former reporter and staff writer for newspapers and others, now writing essays about family, newspapers and other things.

Title: The best places for coffee shop coworking in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
8
Listen
Share
(Updated January 2020 â€” check out my new Paris guide!)
Iâ€™ve been calling Amsterdam my home for eight years now, and thereâ€™s still nothing quite like it. After 3.5 years at The Next Web, I recently switched to a freelance lifestyle â€” which means Iâ€™m often hanging out in a cafe.
Amsterdam has a great coffee culture â€” the city is riddled with amazing cafes. Unfortunately, it can be hard to find one thatâ€™s laptop-friendly. Iâ€™ve seen taped-off outlets, forced wifi resets and staff bluntly asking if you could just stop using your computer.
Itâ€™s hard out there for a freelancer, so Iâ€™ve curated the best spots to get some work done in Amsterdam. My selection is based on a few simple rules:
This list is continuously updated, dropping places that fail to meet the above criteria and adding newly opened gems. Found an incredible place Iâ€™ve missed in this guide? Reach out on Twitter!
A short ferry ride away from Central Station youâ€™ll find this breathtaking space thatâ€™s dedicated to the highest quality coffee, inventive lunch dishes and lightning-fast wifi. Donâ€™t forget to try the banana bread!
This stunning space serves fantastic coffee and has a great selection of pastries and lunch. Just a heads up â€” the table in the back is meant for working, so donâ€™t get too comfortable with your laptop in the front.
Not only does the shop in this four-story building sell beautiful clothing inspired by Scandinavian design, thereâ€™s also an impeccable cafe on the ground floor thatâ€™s perfect for working. Donâ€™t leave without trying their crumble.
In the east of the city youâ€™ll find this cozy, laid-back hangout thatâ€™s well known for serving incredible coffeeâ€”but maybe even more famous for its array of freshly baked pastries and cakes.
Hasnâ€™t even been open for a year and is already one of the best spots. Very speedy internet, decently priced coffee and incredible lunch make it a great place to hang out for a while.
Most stores of this ubiquitous Dutch chain are too crowded, but this one next to Central Station hits all the right spots. Lots of natural light and a spacious interior make for a perfect working environment.
In classic Dutch tradition, this cozy cafe gives you a small cookie with your drink â€” a most welcome addition. Watch out for a few clearly-marked tables where you canâ€™t put your laptop.
This place has a secret trick up its sleeve for making its milk-based coffees, which makes them the richest and creamiest in the business. In summer, the small terrace is shielded from the sun so you can easily bring your laptop outside.
This charming cafe in the west of the city has enough spots to land your laptop. Donâ€™t miss out on their signature spappelsap â€” a funky mix of sparkling water and apple juice. Fills up quickly on weekends, so come early or miss out.
This branch of the popular food market features a cafe thatâ€™s perfect for whipping out your laptop. Grab anything from the store, or order one of their stellar sandwiches.
Located on one of the cityâ€™s most beautiful canals, this hip hotel also houses a spacious restaurant and cafe. Follow the stairs to the first floor for the best working spots. Closes at 1AM, so perfect for getting in some work at the end of the day.
Another hotel! This oneâ€™s located in the east of the city, and especially well-equipped for working. To the right of the entrance youâ€™ll find rows of workstations, while the bar to the left caters to your every need.
I know â€” Starbucks sucks. But this oneâ€™s different â€”it combines a unique interior with copious amounts of space to work and plugs everywhere. As one of the few stores in the world with a Clover machine, the coffee isnâ€™t even that bad.
Found an incredible place Iâ€™ve missed in this guide? Reach out on Twitter, because I edit this post from time to time with the best tips.
Enjoyed this post? Donâ€™t forget to click the ğŸ‘ below to let me know!
--
--
8

Title: Five Different Things To Do In Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A few weeks ago we spent a great 48 hours in Amsterdam. As this wasnâ€™t our first time we decided to visit places we hadnâ€™t been before. So after youâ€™ve visited the amazing Rijksmuseum, Anne Frank House, Heineken Experience and picnicked in Vondelpark, then why not take a look at these five different things to do.
Hortus Botanicus is a beautiful greenhouse and botanical gardens, founded in 1638 itâ€™s one of the oldest in the world. This wonderful attraction has range of plants and flowers to explore, from cactusâ€™ to the Persian ironwood tree there is plenty to see, even some plants which are on the â€œdangerâ€ list!
We loved wandering around the greenhouse, from feeling like weâ€™re walking through a jungle at the bottom to viewing the tops of the trees from the rooftop bridge. Afterwards heading out into the fresh air and autumnal gardens, taking our time to appreciate the beauty and serenity!
Amsterdam has lots of stunning parks and open spaces, however Hortus Botanicus is definitely our favourite place to relax and escape the hustle and bustle of most tourist attractions in the city centre.
2. Bloemenmarkt
Amsterdam is known for itâ€™s flowers, especially Tulips, so where better to see them than the worldâ€™s only floating flower market?! Bloemenmarkt is a great place for any flower lover, from market stalls selling seeds, tulips, cactusâ€™ and more itâ€™s a great place to find Dutch trinkets to take home for friends and family. The bulbs even come customs ready so youâ€™ll have no problem getting them through security at the airport!
Furthermore, this stunning market runs along side a series of shops where you can find even more traditional Dutch goodies, including a delicious cheese shop! Now who doesnâ€™t love cheese?!
3. Moco Museum
The Museum Quarter is full of wonderful museums from the Rijksmuseum to the Van Gogh Museum, even the I Am Amsterdam sign. However, one smaller museum which is less well known on this square is the Moco Museum, and personally our favourite.
Moco Museum, which stands for Modern Contemporary, was a museum founded in an early 20th-century townhouse and holds a stunning collection of Banksy and Dali pieces in both the house and surrounding garden. Including works such as Banksyâ€™s â€˜The girl with balloonâ€™ this is one museum you cannot miss!
4. Foam
After visiting the Museum Quarter you may have had enough of walking around galleries and museums, but if we can weâ€™d definitely encourage you to visit just one moreâ€¦
Foam is a beautiful photography gallery situated in an canal house not to far from Bloemenmarkt. The gallery combines exhibitions from well-established photographers with the up and coming, giving those new to the scene a platform on which to exhibit their work.
If youâ€™re a photography lover then this is one you must visit! We loved the range of subjects this gallery had to offer, as well as some moving pictures thrown into the mix.
5. The Hoxton
Now Amsterdam has plenty, and we mean plenty of bars! But many of these will be found in the busier parts of the city, filled to the brim with tourists heading for a night out on the town. And if like us every now and then you just want to relax with a good crowd, glass of red wine or cocktail in hand, then Lottiâ€™s at The Hoxton is the place for you!
Lottiâ€™s at The Hoxton has a great buzz and atmosphere with an even better cocktail list! And if youâ€™re feeling a little peckish then the bar snacks we spied did look delicious.
To top it all off Lottiâ€™s has a great old fashioned Photo Booth and we have to be honest we canâ€™t resist a good Photo Booth!
There is so much to explore in Amsterdam and weâ€™d definitely encourage visiting the usual tourist hotspots, however if youâ€™re looking for something a little bit different then we hope weâ€™ve given you some inspiration.
--
--
Never try and calm itchy feet.

Content:
Sign up

Member-only story

Happy Blessed New Year everyone :) I hope the start of 2025 has been kind to all of you. ğŸ§¡
The last story that I wrote was on Christmas Eve. The next day, I had a flight out to Amsterdam. Although I wrote a few drafts on Christmas Day and the days that followed, I never got to editing them in order to publish it. Then a week passed and another, and I decided I might as well just take a long holiday break (away from work and writing and everything) and come back again in the new year. So here I am, back again :)
â¡ï¸ non-medium members can read from here ğŸ“–
My full three-week travels took me from Breda in the Netherlands to Milan, Maranello, Siena and Rome in Italy, and finally ending at Istanbul in Turkey. Today, I will write about an incident that happened to me while I was taking the train from Amsterdam to Breda.
I landed in Amsterdam on December 26 at around 7.30am. There wasnâ€™t much of a crowd when I landed, so I managed to clear immigration and collected my luggage and exited the arrivals by 8.10am. After which, it was time to buy a train ticket to Breda. I opted for the 8.44am train so that I didnâ€™t have to rush to the platform.
Boarded the train at exactly 8.44am and the scheduled arrival was 23 minutes later at 9.07am. However, 10 minutes into the ride, the train suddenly stopped. For what felt like the longest time.
