Title: Please read this before your trip to Amsterdam! My horrible edible experience.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
AK-47 or White widow? Shane asked, grinning as he pointed at a menu as if either one of us had any business dabbling in strong marijuana. We could barely handle cigarettes, let alone smoke any of those strains of weed, that sounded more at home on an MI5 terrorist watch list than in rolling papers. We eventually requested the weakest space cake they had and left to take in the rest of De Wallen.
Eight of us were in Holland for the Rotterdam carnival. As part of our package, we had a day trip to Amsterdam scheduled, and my O-my was it going to be a trip (pardon the pun) that none of us will ever forget. Getting high didnâ€™t appeal to Missy, Prince and Helen, so we (Shane, Ricardo, Carl, Jay and I) decided to split our group in two and meet back at the coach at the end of the day.
Now let it be known that De Wallen (where the red light district is situated) is a small enclave of Amsterdam and is probably one of the craziest sections of any city worldwide. With women in windows and weed, the word â€˜liberalâ€™ doesnâ€™t do it justice at all. Suppose De Wallen were a bike rolling down a hill, itâ€™d be brake-less, without a seat, stabilisers, or wheels â€” just a rickety old frame trundling at full speed into those fiendish red lights below.
Anywho, we had a good laugh throughout the day and were on the way back to the coach. Jay and I were deliberating on how the â€œweak space cakeâ€ was a little too weak. Unsatisfied, we happened upon, and decided to stop off at the most stereotypical edible peddlers I had seen there. So there are five of us squeezed-up in this weed takeaway shop, plastic inflatable palm trees everywhere, reggae beating over the speakers.
The guys behind the counter wore red, gold and green string vests and had locs. In true British fashion, I began small talk. I assumed they were Jamaican, and with me being of Jamaican heritage, I asked where in Jamaica they were from.
â€‹They both answered â€˜Barbadosâ€™. â€˜Ohâ€™, I replied â€” Now hereâ€™s where Carl swears I had doomed our expedition, for I went on to state â€” â€œSo you guys arenâ€™t real, Rastas then?â€ Carl reckons that on account of my faux pas, the brother going to get our order from the cabinet stopped in his tracks and looked back at me in complete disdain before selecting an entirely different batch of space muffins to those requested. Anyway, we paid and left. Carl, Shane and Ricardo had walked up ahead, opened their muffins, and ate them whole.
We had agreed to buy rum to drink back at the hotel before heading out for our evening meal â€” so we stopped off at a shop that had benches out front, and it was there that both Jay and I realised that the rest of the guys had accepted their seats on the maddest ride in Dam! The space muffin-coaster. The only catch was, it rode you instead.
Whilst outside the shop, Shane began to giggle. When I say â€˜giggleâ€™, I mean tears and uncontrollable fits of what I first thought was a joyful display of happiness (Boy, was I wrong). Ricardo took a seat outside the shop, slouched halfway down on a bench â€” both hands in his pockets, his eyes mere slits in his face whilst Carl, deep in silence, repeatedly walked between the seats like one of those deranged bears in captivity.
Shaneâ€™s giggle rapidly escalated to hysterical bouts of laughter. By now, these boys are starting to look crazy, and I have to ask if everyoneâ€™s cool? Ricardo gives me a look that I now know meant â€˜brother â€” right now Iâ€™m simply trying to keep my choo-choo on the tracksâ€™. Jay shook his head in disbelief, looked at me and said, â€œShit, how strong could those things be?â€ At that point, Shane comes up from behind and puts his arms around both of us and says, â€œTrust me, Iâ€™m waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay too high right now!â€ At that point, I donâ€™t know what part of Shaneâ€™s â€œway too highâ€ Jay didnâ€™t get, but he took his muffin and devoured it. Four down, one to go.
So Jay and I walked into the shop, chose a bottle of rum, placed it on the counter then split up to get individual items. Before picking up some wine gums and nuts, I walked around for a bit, then headed back to the till. When I got there, Jay had both hands on the counter, hovering over several bottles of water and a shelf-load of Pringles. I looked further and couldnâ€™t see the rum. So Iâ€™m like â€” â€œJay, thatâ€™s way too much crisps â€” bro, and whereâ€™s the rum?â€ Jay turned to me â€” Pringle crumbs falling out of his mouth as he spoke, â€œNah broâ€¦â€ â€” Shaking his head â€” â€œNahâ€¦we wonâ€™t be needing that rum tonight, trust me.â€ With that, he turned back towards the shopkeeper, purchased the Pringles he was eating, paid for the water and left the rest of the items he had gathered behind. The shopkeeper and I watched him clambering through the shop door; I was shocked at how fast he had gone under.
Getting back to the coach was a mission. A, we couldnâ€™t remember where we were meant to go and B, the rest of the guys were so high it was astounding. I liken the journey back to the coach to that of a Sheppard trying to keep sheep from going astray. By the time one was back on track, another had f@*ked off doing something else.
We finally made it, and I cannot describe how happy I was to see Missy, Prince and Helen. Prince frowned at their peculiar behaviour, â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with them?â€ He asked. I told him, and he just laughed. Carl, Shane and Jay went to the back of the coach, and I sat next to Prince. The coach set off, and all I could hear from the rear was Shane and Carl giggling with each other and other passengers. I looked over at them, and from where I was sat, it looked like they were over the worst and were now having a rip-roaring time without me â€” FOMO set in.
I took my muffin out and figured if I had three quarters and gave a quarter away, I wouldnâ€™t be hit as hard, so I offered a quarter to Prince â€” who took one look at the others and declined. So I turned and offered Missy the piece, she took it, and I had the rest. Five minutes had passed, and I felt nothing. Eventually, I fell asleep.
When I woke, we had arrived back in Rotterdam, and everybody was making their way off the coach. Prince had to haul me up, and immediately I knew something was off, really off. Edging my way out of the seats felt like an extraordinarily complex task. I walked the coach holding seat headrests for support, and when I got to the steps to disembark, I descended them as if I were seventy-five with bad knees and worn discs. When I took the final step off the coach, I heard (within my head) that weird sound the six million dollar man-made when he would jump off buildings or kick objects, and I knew right off I was in for one hell of a long night.
So now weâ€™re all stood in a huddle outside our hotel, discussing plans for the rest of the evening. Now, if I were completely honest, my sole goal was to keep all my marbles in their bag. Eventually, Prince, Missy and Helen got fed up with our random bouts of laughter â€” not to mention our inability to follow any single thread. Pissed off, they went up to their rooms, leaving us to our own devices. Oh boy!
We (the wasted) decided weâ€™d go into Rotterdam central to eat (How we were going to manage this, only God knew). Before I knew it, we were walking towards the train station, each randomly bursting out into unruly fits of laughter that would set everyone else off. My stomach muscles had begun to hurt so badly I thought I was going to keel over and die. Between laughing and walking in irregular patterns, we tried to hold regular conversations, but conversing whilst at that altitude is so mentally taxing, we opted to walk in silence, every one of us trying to hold on to the minuscule shred of sanity the muffins had left. Just shy of the train station, Jay turns to me and says, â€œMate, do ya reckon if I go hospital they erâ€¦they, can er. They can errr get rid of this feeling?â€ Now, if you knew Jay, youâ€™d know he was by far one of the most level-headed people you knew, and his question smacked of panic, which panicked me further. I stopped in my tracks and did the basketball time-out hand sign to their backs (I know, trust me, I do) and announced I was abandoning the mission and would be heading back to the hotel. Everyone agreed and followed suit.
I kid you not, on the way back, the theme music of the X-Men the animated series kept playing over in my head, and I began to believe we were characters from the show. Donâ€™t ask me shit about it; I have no idea why my brain would conjure such things. We returned to the hotel and walked straight towards the restaurant, which was oval-shaped with a bar and bartender in the middle, seats situated all around. Shane took a seat at one end, Jay on one side, Carl chose to leave and go up to the room, and Ricardo just stood swaying â€” hands in his pockets, cap pulled down over his eyes. What must that lady have thought? We had come in together but were seated so far apart youâ€™d have thought we were strangers.
My mouth suddenly felt like it was filled with sawdust and cotton wool. I ordered five one-litre bottles of water. At this time, Jay is so engrossed in his menu, youâ€™d have thought he was reading the Magna-carter. I look over, and Ricardo has gone. I look towards Shane, who is now ordering everything on the menu, and I mean everything! Wings, fries, pasta, salad, a bread basket (normally meant for a group), more wings and cake. As heâ€™s ordering, the visualisation of all that food makes me feel sick. The waitress also takes Jayâ€™s order and leaves to go to the kitchen. Shane then shouts from across the bar, â€œSomeone could punch me in the face right now, and Iâ€™d have to charge it ta the game.â€ I look at him and think â€” f@%k this, Iâ€™m going to bed. When youâ€™re that high, thereâ€™s no time for niceties like hi, bye, and howâ€™d you dos â€” you just get up and go.
I got up and took whatever bottles of water I could, the grand total of two of the five I had paid for, and began making my way to the lift. I looked back, and Shane is watching, waiting for me to react to his comment. In my head, Iâ€™m thinking â€” we are way too far in distance for us to engage any more. Secondly, I ainâ€™t got time for jokes, brother, Iâ€™m trying to keep my shit together, and youâ€™re not helping. I shuffle past reception and get in the lift but cannot remember how to use it or which floor Iâ€™m on. I ride that thing up and down at least four times, ground floor to the top and back. An older woman eventually joined me, and we looked at each other. I recognised her from the coach trip earlier; unfortunately, she shared the same look as me; I conclude that sheâ€™s obviously mashed as well. We both rode the lift, up and down, a further two times, swaying in absolute silence before she got off, and I eventually remembered my floor.
I opened my room door, and Carl is sprawled out on Ricardoâ€™s bed. I wanted to ask him how and why heâ€™s in our room but immediately came to the conclusion that I just didnâ€™t give a shit about the answer.
I lay down and the room goes wild! Spinning out of control, my heart started beating fast, I closed my eyes, trying to calm my body to sleep, but I begin to feel unwell. I looked up at the ceiling, and I kid you not, shadow animals are running on it â€” at that point, I was like â€˜Nope!â€™ donâ€™t like that, I need an ambulance â€” right now! I jumped up and called reception. I told them to get me an ambulance. Carl sprang up from Ricardoâ€™s bed and screamed, â€œNoooooooo! I donâ€™t need one, man!â€ I looked over at him, ignored his plea and continued. â€œYes, Iâ€™m in room 355; I need an ambulance please, in fact, you might need to order a fewâ€. The woman asked whatâ€™s wrong. I told her Iâ€™m incredibly high, and my heart is racing. She began to laugh. Looking back now, she was probably used to this from overzealous Brits coming back from Amsterdam. She told me to come down and wait in reception. Carl insists on coming with me.
Once down in the lobby, I glanced into the restaurant area and Shane and Jay are gone. A fellow guest from the hotel was trying to be helpful â€” and heâ€™s like, â€œMate, Iâ€™ve been there, you donâ€™t need a hospital, you need ta ride it out.â€ I looked at him like â€” brother, if I could raise my hands right now, you wouldnâ€™t have teeth.
Anyway, my ambulance arrived, I went to get in, and this random dude begins to walk with Carl and me; eventually, Carl gets annoyed with him and tells him to f@%k off.
I looked around outside, and there are two other ambulances, with patients from the hotel getting in. So now Iâ€™m sat in my ambulance with the doors slid open, and the paramedics are talking in Dutch whilst checking my blood pressure and vitals. They gave me sugar sachets to swallow, and Iâ€™m like, Ooo-kay, not sure this is it, guys, I was thinking more of an open heart surgery type solution â€” â€œbut heyâ€. Anyway, my heart rate wouldnâ€™t settle, so they decided it was best I go to the hospital to be on the safe side.
As we were about to leave, a man and his wife came over and began talking to my paramedics. I looked closer, and itâ€™s the woman from the lift earlier. Her husband stated, â€œMy wifeâ€™s had some of that funny cake, and I think sheâ€™s having a heart attackâ€. I know I should be ashamed to admit this, but all I could think was â€” Bro, thatâ€™s you and your wifeâ€™s businessâ€¦ Right now, I need all these guys on me. Your gonna have to get your own team.
I think they gave me a sedative, as the next bit is a complete blur. I woke up in the hospital; Carl is sitting in a seat. Nurses and doctors are in and out of the room, asking me questions and doing tests. They eventually gave me an injection, and things go black; my last thoughts were of my fiancÃ© and mother and how much I would miss them. My next memory is sharp, bright daylight, making the white hospital room glow. My initial thoughts wereâ€¦ Oh Lord, I didnâ€™t make it! The feeling of dread quickly subsided when a nurse came through my curtains with a breakfast trolley, her blonde hair humming under the sunâ€™s rays. She smiled, her face was warm and kind, and I felt at ease. I took the food and water on offer and awaited a doctor to come and check me over. The doctor came and gave me the all-clear â€” which I thank God he did, as I had to catch my return ferry from Calais that afternoon.
My friends had been calling, and after several missed calls they finally got through â€” and I explained I was on my way back.
When I arrived at the hotel, everyone was sitting in the restaurant area eating breakfast, looking like shit warmed up with raisins. Shortly after, we packed our bags, got on the coach and went home; that bad feeling from the muffin hanging around us like a bad smell.
It took me days to feel one hundred per cent again. A week after the trip, I emptied my trouser pockets to wash them and found the wrapper for that dreaded muffin and written clear as day on the packaging were the instructions for consumption â€” â€œDO NOT CONSUME MORE THAN A QUARTER A DAYâ€. I had to laugh. I threw it in the bin, vowing to never touch an edible again and guess what? I never have. We still laugh about it to this day. The story never gets old.
I hope you enjoyed the read. Please show your support by giving me a follow and a wave or two or three or even four!
Thanks in advance!
--
--
I am an author, father, husband and brother to all who carry the fire. I hail from London in the UK. I love writers who are economic with their prose. 1408.

I got to Amsterdam on a quick bus ride from Brussels, one of those trips short enough to avoid existential dread but long enough to feel like a soft reset. The moment I arrived, the city greeted me like it had nothing to prove. Clean air, standardized houses standing proud, and that effortless beauty that almost feels rude. It didnâ€™t need to win me over. It already had, love at first sight.
That first night, I made the classic mistake of letting hunger choose the restaurant. An overpriced place that served a perfect sirloin, without any sides. Just meat. As if to say, â€œYou came here for this and nothing more.â€ Fair enough. I washed it down with a pink grapefruit soda that tasted like someone whispered the word â€œfruitâ€ into a glass of carbonated nothing.
My first real day was spent at the Artis Zoo. I forgot how much I love giraffes. Tall clumsy creatures, thereâ€™s something almost ancient about the way they move, like they know theyâ€™re above the rest of us. Well, they are. I also spent way too long near the penguins, despite the stench. They wobble like drunk little gentlemen and I canâ€™t help but love them.
I did find out that Amsterdam in late October is magical. Being Brazilian, Iâ€™d never experienced proper seasons before. This was my first real autumn, the kind Iâ€™d only seen in movies. The streets were carpeted with red and yellow leaves and I took dozens of photos of my own feet because the ground looked like a painting. Every step felt like a poem.
The canals? Donâ€™t get me started. I took a boat tour with a guide so charismatic I considered proposing. Thereâ€™s a peacefulness in floating slowly past crooked houses and quiet bridges. I could do that for days. I want to be rich one day, but only for one reason, to own a boathouse in Amsterdam. Thatâ€™s the dream. Not yachts, not diamonds. Just a floating home and a view of still water.
I tried marijuana brownies and gummies, in an attempt to finally experience what everyone raves about. Yeah, I know, the most stereotypical and touristy thing to do in Amsterdam. Spoiler: nothing. My psychiatrist once explained that ADHD sometimes turns the brain into a dopamine black hole. So there I was, chewing overpriced weed sugar, waiting for a high that never came. Just me and my broken reward system. Fun.
When it comes to food, Amsterdam gave me two cravings I still havenâ€™t shaken off almost a year later. First, the bitterballen: crispy, deep-fried balls filled with a creamy meat ragout that somehow feels both luxurious and comforting; second, Rudiâ€™s stroopwafels, which deserve their own national anthem. Thin caramel-filled wafers that taste like joy. Iâ€™d fly back just for them.
I did a lot of walking in Amsterdam. How could I not? The streets felt like a canvas. At a local fair, I bought two belts that are still holding my life together, literally and figuratively, and a cashmere scarf that followed me across Europe, hugging my neck as the days grew colder. Funny how some objects start to feel like companions.
All the walking led me to a train that led me to Zaandam, a city close by. The architecture there is surreal, the massive hostel that looks like a stack of colorful fairy tale houses? Perfection. Itâ€™s like someone let a child with great taste design a building.
One night I joined a tour of the Red Light District, led by a former sex worker. She was brilliant! Sharp, warm, unapologetic. There was a roughness to her friendliness, hard to explain. The district itself is overwhelming, neon-lit and pulsing with voyeurism. Even as a little fag, I was impressed. The women behind the glass know how to hold power with a single look.
Speaking of shocking, I caught a screening of The Substance at PathÃ© Tuschinski, the most gorgeous cinema Iâ€™ve ever been to. I wouldnâ€™t be back in Brazil before the film left theaters, so I made the time. The Dutch subtitles were distracting, but the experience was unforgettable, especially the part where people started leaving during the bloodier scenes. Brazilians would never. Oh, and I may have stolen a tiny spoon they gave me for nuts. My only crime. My tiny metallic souvenir.
Museum-wise, I had only one priority: Van Gogh. I stayed for hours and cried more than once. His story has always cut deep for me and thereâ€™s so much vulnerability in his brushwork, in his letters, in his legacy. Seeing his strokes up close was like meeting his ghost. It was gentle. It stayed with me.
Now, Iâ€™ve tried not to make these travel pieces about the tattoo studios, I want to focus on the cities. But I have to make an exception for Hachi Ink. My favorite studio of the whole trip. Chikage made me feel at home like weâ€™d known each other for years. On the last day there was even homemade Japanese food. I left full: stomach, heart, everything.
After a week of scenic tram rides, stroopwafels, falling leaves and unspoken love for a city I barely knew, it was time to leave. Berlin waited with more leaves, more streets, more chaos and a couple love stories.
But Amsterdam? Amsterdam stays with me.
--
--
Tattoo artist, traveler, and a hopeless rambler

Title: How Amsterdam is Working Against Rising Sea Levels
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
During one of our tours, the guide mentioned how Amsterdam and the Netherlands in general is extremely vulnerable to rising sea levels. This made me wonder whether the canals had any role in helping the city avoid the crisis, but also what techniques had been invented. David had mentioned in one of our meetings that a portion of Amsterdam had been quite literally reclaimed from the sea. I wanted to know if there were more plans of doing this in Amsterdam, and if not, what they were planning instead.
In 1953, there was a flood in the city that killed upwards of 1,800 people. This was from a lack of reservoirs and space for the rainwater to go. To combat this, flood barriers such as dams and dikes to suppress and redirect the water. On the personal level, it has gotten to a point where children are even taught how to swim with shoes and clothes on in case there is ever a flood. With climate change, rising sea levels are decreasing the land of the Netherlands, as well as increasing the possibility for dangerous floods. Amsterdam is one of the most likely cities to flood by 2050. This means if action is not taken now to protect Amsterdam and slow the process of climate change, the city may not remain by the end of the century. A third of the Netherlands is below sea level, leaving a good chance to be severely affected by sea level rise. Because of this, Amsterdam has plans and innovations in which they can attempt to suppress the changes.
All these innovations are different, with some figuring out new ways to displace water, while others worry about how to adapt to saltier water levels. Water Squares were thought up as a way to have a reservoir during periods of large rainfall. This is an area that can be used for sitting and gathering, but instead of the square being on a flat plane, it is inset into the ground. There are steps to walk and sit on, but during periods of floods, the square can be used as a makeshift reservoir. Water flows into the square from gutters in sidewalks and would hopefully decrease the water surrounding residences and businesses. A technique for farmers is growing salt water tolerant crops. Some crops, such as potatoes, are being researched and genetically changed to become more salt tolerant. Researchers have been able to make a potato that is four times more tolerant than a regular potato. Some farmers decide to go a different route, growing crops like samphire, which is known as â€œthe poor manâ€™s asparagusâ€. This vegetable comes from the sea, meaning it will be able to grow within saltier conditions.
The Delta Programme is a program to constructing different infrastructure that will protect the city. This includes constructing and revamping dikes, using modern engineering of construction techniques, and proposing new management strategies. A map of climate projects is used to determine the weaknesses of different areas in the city and what can be done to aid these weaknesses. Currently, the programâ€™s main areas of research are figuring out how to incorporate fresh water supplies, flood mitigation, and flood-resistant urban planning. The idea of having man-made floating islands for housing has been suggested, but the issue arises of whether these islands are going to raise sea levels itself. However, there is currently a floating dairy farm in use. This farm raises dairy cows and was built in a sustainable and transparent way. The animals were moved onto a floating farm to increase housing space, but it may not be entirely plausible to do this on a larger scale.
Beaches in the Netherlands oftentimes must be replenished with sand every five years, as the additional sand is used as a storm barrier. The sand in these areas get dispersed and misplaced from storms and natural degradation, requiring dredged sand from the Delfland coast to fix what is lost over time. Now, a giant sandbar is being placed for wind and waves to gradually displace the sand. While this sounds like the exact same thing that was happening before, there is actually a larger amount of sand being dredged at once, but instead of it happening every five years, it can happen every twenty. This hopefully decreases the effect on surrounding wildlife and decreases how often the sand must be fixed. This creates a barrier for the surrounding area, keeping most of the water at bay with the sandbar.
The Dutch are leading experts in the world of sea level rise. While they have been able to figure out many ways to reduce or protect Amsterdam and the rest of the country from this part of climate change, they also know that sometimes itâ€™s more important to retreat from the issue than attack it. Some farmers have been moved to higher elevations so that they donâ€™t have to worry about the effects of flooding. Hopefully, in 2050 Amsterdam will still exist and still be thriving, but that depends on the innovations created and a potential slowing of climate change.
--
--

Title: One day at AWS Summit Amsterdam 2023, 01st June 2023
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Disclaimer: This is my personal point of view and I published it late because of my holiday.
AWS Summit is an event organized by AWS and sponsored by many tech companies. There AWS showcase their technologies and also companies have many presentations on their experience with AWS, and how AWS accelerated their work. It covers many aspects from basic to advanced and trendy such as security, governance, Data processing, Machine Learning, AI. What I found amazing is that this kind of AWS event is all FREE.
Last year in April I went to AWS Summit 2022 in Brussels. That was the first time AWS organized such an event after Covid time, also was the first time I joined AWS Summit, so it felt very special. This year I got familiar with the concept of the AWS Summit, so Iâ€™m more curious about the content, rather than the setup. Moreover, luckily this year it was in the Netherlands where I live so I did not have to travel that far.
This year, the main topics I found seemed to revolve around ML, AI, data, and security.
Highlights/ my note from the talks that I attended:
The use of Quantum technology is increasing. Many countries are increasingly investing in Quantum Technology. The map on trend shown by the presenter mentioned it. I found this is very good to raise awareness about what is happening with this technology. It is also good that they mentioned some other aspects such as Sustainability
AWS tech stack learnt: Quantum hardware: Amazon Braket
This talk was quite long and to me, the AWS presenter topics were a bit boring. It was more like a small version of Re:Invent where he mentioned, for this problem, you can use that AWS service to solve it or so. There was a more enticing talk though, was the Efteling presenter talking about using models to suggest the customers places to go. Efteling is an amusement park in the Netherlands and is in the top 5 amusement parks in Europe. It is nice to know how they used data to help the company's innovation. Also, the keynote hall is massive and looks very cool
AWS tech stack learnt: One thing the presenter mentioned is Zero ETL Future â€” for a data person like me, Iâ€™m curious to know more
Then came the lunch break in the big hall with variety of food.
The 4 days of ML training were very helpful to understand the part where AWS explained Fraud Detection. Therefore basically it was not new for me, except for the Graph-based approach to manage payment fraud. The graph-based approach detects fraud using relationships among entities and attributes. It uses SageMaker (Deep Learning Graph Library), Amazon Neptune
AWS tech stack learnt: Graph-based approach
The main hall was divided into 4 parts with 4 presentations. I like the concept of using headsets (looks like a silent disco) â€” but it was hurting my ears after I wear them for some time. Among other presentations, this is a more realistic version. It mentioned the journey of a big organisation to go to the cloud. Key points are the people, the mindset, and cooperation (they work with TCS)
Observability: To measure of how well you can understand a system from the work it does. Observability: a virtuous circle. Its 4 pillars are something basic that I mentioned also in EKS course: metrics, logs, traces, profiles (tracking function calls, CPU, IO, network to trace to the code)
Full stack o strategies:
outside in: from end-user
inside out: from backend application, measure internal performance
I know that this one might be too much detail and not so interesting, but I was still curious. This presentation showed the process from collecting hospital data with Amazon Health Datalake, or collecting third-party data with Amazon AppFlow until using Sagemaker to predict the waiting time when going to a hospital.
AWS tech stack learnt: Amazon Health Lake, Amazon AppFlow
The queue to get in was super long, but luckily it moved fast so it took me about 20 minutes to get inside the hall Amsterdam RAI.
I wanted to attend a talk at 9.30am but that was only when I arrived at the queue, so I missed it.
Experience for next year: I want to join some F1 racing or DeepRacer. I didnâ€™t prepare to bring my laptop. I will look into it next year, seems fun.
Food and drink last year was better, they had nice cocktails at the end of the day
While we were drinking wine and Heineken, a magician came and showed us some fun tricks with cards and coins. That was very fun. I still didnâ€™t get why I had a pen marker passing from the magician's hand to my handâ€¦
--
--
Right now want to write about things AWS, data, Python

Title: Amsterdam: Cookie Buildings ğŸª
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A city with buildings are like made from cookies, canals, bicycles, cheeses, tulips, wooden shoesâ€¦ A cultural heritage! Moreover, it is filled with freedom. Such a liveable, alive, peaceful place with young and old sides.
After having trips to many European cities, arriving in Amsterdam in late hours (11 p.m.) was making me nervous. I thought, the city would be in sleep and deserted. On the contrary, Amsterdam was awake! I felt completely safe.
We spent our first night relaxing and sleeping. The next morning started with a walking tour to Museumplein. Rijksmuseum is such a gigantic museum and we only have 2 days in Amsterdam, so we skipped.
Then, the museum of my dreams: Van Gogh Museum! Unfortunately, I have a story to tellâ€¦ My friend and I were so excited and we immediately bought a museum ticket. We had a message from the bank of the card that we made the payment, we didnâ€™t look for details and thought â€˜we succeededâ€™. Until our museum visiting hour, we sat on Vondelpark and ate something, wandered around Amsterdamâ€™s modern streets ( not that classic streetsâ€¦). After all of them, it was to visit Van Gogh. With cheerful faces, we went to ticket-control points. No. There was no ticket for us. It was really sad because all the tickets were sold outâ€¦ However, we didnâ€™t give up and bought tickets for another day. Such a reliefâ€¦
The museum was a-w-e-s-o-m-e. Feeling and seeing those paintings which I admire and choose for drawingâ€¦ It was unique. We also looked at painting from a microscope. It was not like what I expected. It was wild.
Also, the cafes in Museumplein were wonderful.
We wandered a lot in random streets. It was joyful! Exploring somewhere is why I love traveling.
While wandering, I tasted lots of cheese. Cheese heaven! Iâ€™ve never tasted cheeses with coconut, green pesto and lavender aroma before. They all were delicious.
We also went to Dam Square, Red Light District, Anne Frank House, Bloemenmarktâ€¦
Our dinner was fried potatoes in Manneken Pis with truffle mayo, peanut sauces. The sauces, potatoes all were EXTREMELY DELICIOUS! I definitely recommend it. We tried both potatoes with sauces and potatoes with separate sauces, I prefer the second one. Also, while eating delicious potatoes, looking at the canal view is such a core memory.
We couldnâ€™t buy the famous cookieâ€¦ The place was closed at 4.30 p.m. So sad :(
To explore and experience Dutch culture, we went to Zaandam. Because of a timing mistake, we only saw lego-like-buildingsâ€¦
Our Flixbus station was in Sloterdijkâ€¦ It was pretty far from the center and our hotel. When I think about the station, I just have goosebumps.
I really loved Amsterdam. I want to go again â¤
Overall
Amsterdam is not very suitable for a student budget. I want to visit Amsterdam again with a rich budget and that time I must have more cheeses, have van stapele cookies, have a canal tour, go to Zaanse Schans, visit Anne Frank house, attend Tulip and Kingâ€™s dayâ€¦
Regards, Ozlem.
14. 03. 2024
--
--
love traveling, science, movies, books. 22.

Title: Rollinâ€™ in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We exclusively publish memoirs: The creative stories unpacked from the nostalgic hope chests of our lives.

Member-only story
--
14
Share
The culturally bloated, artistic, and liberal city of Amsterdam, with its eight hundred thousand plus bicycle population, copious coffee shops, and infamous Red Light District, had us undoubtedly intrigued by its kooky character.
We were assiduous walkers during our two-day experience â€” and rightfully so. Much needed to be done for two tourists seeking refuge in Amsterdamâ€™s guilty pleasures.
The Goods:
After snoozing, and taking intermittent snack breaks on our four-hour train ride from Frankfurt, Germany, we arrived at the highly anticipated travel destination of the Netherlands.
Kathleen and I exited the Amsterdam central train station to the likes of some sunshine and brisk wind and began our foot journey to the hotel.
In a state of sensory overload from the cityâ€™s unique surroundings and busy tourist activity, we shuffled through the area of Dam Square, stopping every so often for a photo or to heave our overnight bag to my other shoulder: going against the advice of the hotelâ€™s tram ride suggestion was a great way to greet our new cultural friend.
Between the bickering over a Madame Tussaud building photo and my complaints over having to carry the â€œheavy stuff,â€ our patienceâ€¦
--
--

Title: Urban Planning in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam, the capital of the Netherlands, is renowned for its picturesque canals, historical buildings, and vibrant cultural life. With such a rich history, it is a place I have found stunning. However, its urban planning and architecture have evolved significantly over the past century, balancing preserving historical charm and embracing modern sustainability principles. This intricate dance has led to notable successes and challenges in creating thriving communities harmonizing with the city's natural geography and cultural ethos.
Amsterdamâ€™s urban planning has always been influenced by its unique geography. The cityâ€™s layout, characterized by concentric canals known as the â€œGrachtengordel,â€ was initially designed in the 17th century during the Dutch Golden Age. This historic planning emphasized functionality and aesthetics, creating a beautiful and practical cityscape. However, as the city grew, new challenges emerged, requiring innovative solutions to accommodate a growing population while preserving the area's historical integrity.
In the 20th century, Amsterdam faced significant urban development pressures. The post-war period saw a surge in modernist architecture, focusing on efficiency and functionality. However, this often came at the expense of the cityâ€™s historical character. The construction of high-rise buildings and large-scale infrastructure projects sometimes clashed with the traditional low-rise, dense urban fabric that defined Amsterdam.
One of Amsterdamâ€™s significant successes in urban planning has been integrating modern sustainable practices with historical preservation. The city has implemented policies prioritizing the adaptive reuse of old buildings, converting them into modern residential and commercial spaces while maintaining their historical faÃ§ades. This approach not only preserves the cityâ€™s cultural heritage but also reduces the environmental impact of new construction.
Amsterdamâ€™s Eastern Docklands is a shining example of how thoughtful urban planning can transform an industrial area into a vibrant, sustainable community. Once a bustling hub for maritime trade, the docklands fell into disuse by the mid-20th century, leaving vast expanses of derelict land. The redevelopment of this area in the late 20th and early 21st centuries showcases how innovative urban planning can successfully integrate historical elements with modern living requirements.
The Eastern Docklands project began in the 1980s to convert the obsolete industrial space into a mixed-use residential and commercial district. Unlike the high-rise developments in other parts of the world, the Eastern Docklands favored medium-rise buildings, typically between 3 to 7 stories, which complemented the traditional Amsterdam skyline. This approach ensured that new developments did not overshadow the historical city center and preserved the human-scale urban fabric characteristic of Amsterdam.
The planning process was highly inclusive, involving architects, urban planners, and the community. The result was a series of distinct neighborhoods, each with its unique architectural style yet harmoniously integrated into the overall urban landscape. The Borneo-Sporenburg area, for example, features innovative row houses with private gardens and public spaces that encourage social interaction. The Java and KNSM islands blend modern architecture with maritime heritage, creating visually striking and functionally diverse neighborhoods.
One of the critical successes of the Eastern Docklands redevelopment is its emphasis on sustainability and community-oriented design. Green roofs, solar panels, and energy-efficient building practices are standard in the new constructions, significantly reducing the area's environmental footprint. Public spaces, parks, and waterways were carefully integrated into the design, providing residents with ample recreational opportunities and enhancing the areaâ€™s aesthetic appeal.
The docklandsâ€™ design also prioritizes walkability and cycling, aligning with Amsterdamâ€™s broader commitment to sustainable urban mobility. Extensive cycling paths and pedestrian-friendly streets encourage residents to use bicycles and walk, reducing reliance on cars and contributing to a healthier, more connected community.
Furthermore, the Eastern Docklands redevelopment incorporated a mix of housing types, including affordable housing units, to ensure a diverse population. This inclusivity fosters a vibrant community where people from different socio-economic backgrounds can live, work, and socialize.
The success of the Eastern Docklands redevelopment lies in its holistic approach to urban planning. By respecting the areaâ€™s historical context, prioritizing sustainability, and involving the community in the planning process, the project has created a thriving, dynamic district that serves as a model for urban redevelopment worldwide. The docklands have become a sought-after residential area known for its quality of life, architectural innovation, and harmonious integration of the old and new.
The lessons learned from the Eastern Docklands can be applied to other urban redevelopment projects. Emphasizing mixed-use developments, sustainable practices, and community involvement are critical strategies for transforming underutilized areas into vibrant urban spaces. As cities worldwide grapple with sustainability and urban growth issues, the Eastern Docklands is a testament to what can be achieved through thoughtful, inclusive urban planning.
Another success story is the cityâ€™s extensive cycling infrastructure, which has been integrated into urban planning to reduce car dependency and promote a healthier lifestyle. Amsterdamâ€™s network of bike paths and cycle-friendly policies have made it one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world, significantly lowering urban pollution and enhancing the quality of life for its residents.
Brandevoort, a neighborhood in the Dutch city of Helmond, is a remarkable example of modern urban planning that successfully integrates traditional architectural styles with contemporary living standards. Designed to resemble a conventional Dutch village, Brandevoort blends the charm and aesthetics of historical townscapes with the functionality and sustainability required for modern urban living. This neighborhood has become a benchmark for new urbanism in the Netherlands, illustrating how thoughtful design can foster a sense of community and enhance the quality of life.
The development of Brandevoort began in the late 1990s with a clear vision: to create a new residential area that respects and reflects the rich architectural heritage of the Netherlands. The planners and architects drew inspiration from historical Dutch towns, incorporating features such as narrow streets, gabled roofs, and picturesque canals. This traditional aesthetic fosters a sense of familiarity and belonging among residents, attracting visitors who appreciate its quaint charm.
However, Brandevoort is not just about replicating the past; it seamlessly integrates modern sustainability practices into its design. The neighborhood includes energy-efficient buildings, green spaces, and robust infrastructure for cycling and walking, reducing reliance on cars. Using sustainable materials and renewable energy sources further underscores the commitment to creating an environmentally friendly community. These efforts not only enhance the quality of life for residents but also contribute to broader environmental goals.
One of the standout features of Brandevoort is its focus on fostering a strong sense of community. The layout of the neighborhood encourages social interaction and community engagement. Central squares, local shops, schools, and recreational facilities are strategically placed within walking distance for most residents, promoting a vibrant regional economy and a close-knit community atmosphere.
Integrating mixed-use buildings allows for a blend of residential, commercial, and recreational spaces, ensuring Brandevoort remains lively throughout the day. This mix of functions supports local businesses and provides residents convenient access to amenities, reducing the need for long commutes and encouraging local engagement.
Moreover, Brandevoortâ€™s urban design includes a variety of housing types to accommodate different demographics, from young families to retirees. This diversity enhances the community's social fabric, making it a dynamic and inclusive place to live.
Brandevoortâ€™s success lies in its ability to harmonize the old with the new, creating a nostalgic and forward-thinking community. The neighborhoodâ€™s design principles offer valuable lessons for urban planners and developers. Brandevoort demonstrates that modern urban developments can be functional and beautiful by prioritizing sustainability, community, and aesthetics.

Integrating mixed-use buildings allows for a blend of residential, commercial, and recreational spaces, ensuring Brandevoort remains lively throughout the day. This mix of functions supports local businesses and provides residents convenient access to amenities, reducing the need for long commutes and encouraging local engagement.
Moreover, Brandevoortâ€™s urban design includes a variety of housing types to accommodate different demographics, from young families to retirees. This diversity enhances the community's social fabric, making it a dynamic and inclusive place to live.
Brandevoortâ€™s success lies in its ability to harmonize the old with the new, creating a nostalgic and forward-thinking community. The neighborhoodâ€™s design principles offer valuable lessons for urban planners and developers. Brandevoort demonstrates that modern urban developments can be functional and beautiful by prioritizing sustainability, community, and aesthetics. This thoughtful integration of past and present and a commitment to sustainable living make Brandevoort a model for future urban developments, ensuring vibrant and resilient communities.
Despite these successes, Amsterdam has faced challenges and failures in its urban planning journey. One of the significant issues has been the tension between development and preservation. The drive for modernization and expansion sometimes led to the demolition of historically substantial buildings, sparking public outcry and resistance. For instance, the construction of the Bijlmermeer, a high-rise housing project in the 1960s, was initially hailed as a modernist triumph but soon became a symbol of urban failure due to poor design and social isolation.
The Bijlmermeer, commonly known as Bijlmer, was conceived in the 1960s as a utopian vision of modern living in Amsterdam. Designed by architect Siegfried Nassuth, Bijlmer was planned as a high-rise residential area to embody modernist architecture and urban planning ideals. Its innovative hexagonal layout and extensive green spaces aim to provide a harmonious, efficient, and socially integrated environment. However, the reality diverged sharply from these aspirations, leading to challenges and failures that ultimately transformed Bijlmer from a symbol of modern utopia to one of urban dystopia.
The design of Bijlmer was heavily influenced by the principles of Le Corbusier and the modernist movement, which emphasized clean lines, functional living spaces, and the separation of different urban functions. The area was planned with a clear distinction between pedestrian and vehicular traffic, vast open spaces, and high-density residential blocks meant to foster a strong sense of community. The high-rise buildings were intended to provide spacious apartments with ample natural light and views of the surrounding greenery.
Despite its innovative design, Bijlmer faced significant challenges from the outset. The timing of its construction coincided with changing housing preferences in the Netherlands. By the time Bijlmerâ€™s first residents moved in during the late 1960s and early 1970s, there was a growing preference for low-rise, single-family homes over high-rise apartments. This shift in housing demand led to difficulties in attracting residents to Bijlmer.
Moreover, the social and economic composition of Bijlmerâ€™s population deviated from the plannersâ€™ expectations. Initially intended to attract middle-class families, the area became home to a diverse population, including many immigrants and low-income households. The high concentration of disadvantaged groups, coupled with a lack of adequate social infrastructure and employment opportunities, contributed to social isolation and economic hardship.
Initially praised for its innovation, the architectural design soon revealed several practical flaws. While theoretically ideal for community building, the vast, monotonous concrete structures often felt impersonal and alienating. The separation of pedestrian pathways from road traffic, though meant to enhance safety, resulted in labyrinthine walkways breeding grounds for crime and vandalism. The large open spaces, initially envisioned as communal areas, needed to be more utilized and better maintained, further contributing to a sense of neglect and decay.
Maintenance issues exacerbated these problems. The sheer scale of the high-rise buildings made upkeep expensive and challenging. As the area aged, the lack of proper maintenance led to deteriorating living conditions, with frequent reports of broken elevators, water leaks, and general disrepair. This decline in the physical environment mirrored the social challenges, reinforcing a negative feedback loop that further stigmatized the area.
Bijlmerâ€™s failure can be attributed to a combination of design flaws, changing social dynamics, and inadequate planning for the socioeconomic realities of its residents. The high-rise utopia envisioned by its planners did not account for the human need for more intimate, human-scale environments. The grand, impersonal architecture failed to foster the sense of community it aimed for, leading instead to social isolation and alienation.
Extensive redevelopment efforts were undertaken in the 1990s and 2000s in response to these challenges. Many of the original high-rise buildings were demolished and replaced with low-rise housing, and significant investments were made in improving infrastructure, public spaces, and social services. These efforts aimed to address the underlying issues of social segregation and economic disparity while preserving some elements of the original vision.
The story of Bijlmer offers critical lessons for urban planners and architects. It underscores the importance of flexibility in urban design, the need to adapt to changing social preferences, and the necessity of integrating social and economic planning with architectural innovation. Bijlmerâ€™s experience highlights that successful urban environments must balance visionary design with practical, human-centered considerations. As Amsterdam continues to evolve, the lessons from Bijlmerâ€™s ambitious but flawed experiment serve as a cautionary tale and a guiding framework for future developments.
Social engineering in urban planning, particularly during the mid-20th century, often led to the creation of monolithic housing estates that did not cater to the social and cultural needs of the residents. These projects sometimes resulted in social segregation and failed to create cohesive communities.
Today, Amsterdamâ€™s urban planning is guided by sustainability, inclusivity, and community engagement principles. The city moves from top-down social engineering approaches towards more participatory planning processes. This shift recognizes the importance of working with nature and local communities to optimize urban living.
Modern projects focus on enhancing green spaces, improving public transportation, and creating mixed-use developments that combine residential, commercial, and recreational spaces. For example, the Zuidas district, also known as the â€œFinancial Mile,â€ is being developed as a mixed-use area with a strong emphasis on green buildings and sustainable infrastructure.
Amsterdamâ€™s urban planning reflects a delicate balance between preserving historical character and embracing modernity. By prioritizing sustainable practices and community-oriented development, the city continues to evolve in a way that respects its rich heritage while addressing contemporary needs. This approach ensures that Amsterdam remains a vibrant, livable city that harmonizes with its natural and cultural environment.

Title: Amsterdamâ€™s Sharing Cities Roundtable: Going Deeper
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Earlier this week Bloomberg published an article about a meeting of multiple cities in Amsterdam last month â€œto forge an alliance in response to Airbnb and Uber.â€ This headline misses the mark; it is both misleading and glosses over what actually happened. I should know: I was at the meeting.
The Global Sharing Cities Roundtable was conceived by the City of Amsterdam several months ago, as an opportunity for cities who are leading efforts to understand and promote the sharing economy worldwide. Participant cities ranged from Seoul, whose Sharing City initiative dates back to 2012 and includes everything from a city-owned space sharing platform to investment of public funds in more than 50 sharing economy initiatives, to Copenhagen, whose sharing economy strategy is linked to its goals for sustainability and the circular economy. Of course, Amsterdam played a leading role â€” as Europeâ€™s first self-declared sharing city, home to numerous sharing economy enterprises and a fresh approach to policy reform.
Airbnb and Uber were discussed at the roundtable. But to be clear: the roundtable was not â€œaboutâ€ them. The purpose of the roundtable was for cities to meet each other â€” the overwhelming majority of them had never been in contact before â€” and to engage in blue-sky thinking about the sharing economyâ€™s potential.
True, Amsterdamâ€™s innovative approach to policy reform for homesharing and short-term rentals was one topic discussed, due to popular demand by other cities. But it was only one topic. Dozens of other topics were also part of the agenda. Ridesharing and ridehailing were another popular topic, though ironically Uber itself barely came up. Rather, more time was spent on brainstorming how the sharing economy can link with waste reduction initiatives, serve to rethink delivery of public services, engage youth and elderly, and potentially help tackle a wide range of other social problems for cities worldwide. The Bloomberg article misses the mark in failing to detail â€” or even acknowledge â€” this much broader agenda.
I was honored to be invited as the only non-city employee. (For full disclosure, I have advised several of the cities in attendance.) Bloomberg reached out to interview me but did not follow through in doing so. Meanwhile, none of the people quoted in the interview were at the meeting. With all due respect, this falls short of what I would expect from one of the worldâ€™s most esteemed publications.
The sharing economy is about much, much more than Airbnb or Uber. We should know that. It is extremely frustrating to see the media focus disproportionately on what is but one piece of a much larger pie. It is increasingly easy to single out one or two companies, but by doing so, we are missing the forest for the trees â€” and missing a much bigger opportunity.
April Rinne is an independent advisor to sharing economy companies, governments, policy makers and investors worldwide. She is a Young Global Leader at the World Economic Forum and an inveterate globetrotter (93 countries and counting).

I have lived in the Netherlands for nearly four years now, the past two in Amsterdam. Because I moved here during the pandemic and then was sick quite a bit for the last year, I havenâ€™t done as many of the touristy things as I might have liked.
Starting August 1st, things are about to change.
My family lives on the same block as I do, but they are going away this year for August. That means I will be on my own in my beautiful apartment.
I have decided to pretend that I am in a beautiful vacation apartment in a city I donâ€™t know well and act like a tourist. I will visit museums and gardens, take a canal tour, and do anything that seems fun. I will probably even take some of my own advice:
medium.com
And, of course, I will regularly write about it, so stay tuned!

Title: From Bicycles to AI Agents: How Amsterdam Changed the Way I Think About AI
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
10
Listen
Share
Not long ago, I found myself in Amsterdam â€” one of those â€œI need a break, but letâ€™s call it inspirationâ€ kind of trips. I was wandering along a canal with a ridiculously good coffee from a tiny cafe that looked like it had been decorated by someone who really loved vintage postcards and didnâ€™t believe in chairs that match. I wasnâ€™t thinking about work. Or at least I told myself I wasnâ€™t.
At some point, I was standing at a crosswalk near Jordaan, watching bicycles zip past â€” one woman riding no-handed, coffee in one hand, phone in the other, somehow gliding through this chaotic mess of tourists and trams like it was nothing. And I just stood there, kind of stunned by how everything was working. No signs, no instructions, no one directing the flow. Just people navigating it together independently, but weirdly in sync. I donâ€™t know why, but it made me think of AI agents and the way they should work â€” fluid, reactive, quietly doing their thing without being micromanaged.
If youâ€™ve ever watched Amsterdam cyclists at rush hour, itâ€™s like a ballet â€” chaotic but balanced. Dozens of people moving independently, but somehow in harmony. There are no detailed instructions, no central planner shouting orders, and yet everyone knows where theyâ€™re going and how to get there.
Thatâ€™s exactly how we should think about AI agents â€” not as rule-bound bots waiting for step-by-step commands, but as autonomous systems capable of interpreting vague goals and getting things done. Rather than telling them exactly what to do, you provide a clear objective, like â€œDraft a user-friendly changelog from these commitsâ€, â€œFind three good flights next Friday that donâ€™t land before 10amâ€ or â€œClean up this spreadsheet and flag anything that looks off.â€ And the agent figures it out. It plans, makes trade-offs, calls tools, revises, and checks back when needed â€” all without being micromanaged. Just like a cyclist adjusting their route on the fly to avoid a crowd or take a shortcut.
Amsterdam cyclists donâ€™t know every street by heart. But they donâ€™t stop pedalling every time they hit a new neighborhood. They ask. They glance at signs. They check their phones mid-ride. They adjust without missing a beat.
Thatâ€™s exactly what Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) enables in AI. Traditional models rely on what they learned during training but that knowledge gets stale. RAG allows agents to â€œaskâ€ for updates from real-time sources: internal wikis, live documents, recent chats, or APIs. The model doesnâ€™t have to memorize everything; it just needs to know when and how to retrieve what matters.
Imagine asking an assistant, â€œCan you send the updated vacation policy to the team?â€ Without RAG, it might make something up or pull in outdated info. But with RAG, it actually retrieves the real policy from your Google Drive and shares the correct details. Itâ€™s like giving your AI access to your companyâ€™s memory, so it doesnâ€™t just sound confident, it is accurate.
Itâ€™s the difference between blindly guessing your route and checking the map mid-ride. Cyclists donâ€™t freeze up when theyâ€™re unsure â€” they adjust. Thatâ€™s the spirit behind RAG: staying curious, staying responsive, and rolling with the unknown instead of rigidly sticking to a script.
If you have ever ridden a creaky old bicycle through cobblestone streets, you know: even a good system needs upkeep. In Amsterdam, riders are always tweaking something: fixing a squeaky brake, tightening a loose seat. Youâ€™ll see tools everywhere like air pumps on the sidewalk, little repair stations on corners. Itâ€™s just part of keeping things rolling.
This is the dance of AI-for-code and code-for-AI.
On one side, tools like Copilot, ChatGPT, and Cody are transforming how we write software. They help generate boilerplate, catch bugs, write tests, and even explain complex code. Theyâ€™re like having a bicycle mechanic riding shotgun, tightening bolts as you move.
But on the flip side, code-for-AI is where the real infrastructure gets built. Itâ€™s where you define your agentâ€™s behaviors, their constraints, their tools, their norms. Itâ€™s how you make sure your AI doesnâ€™t veer into the wrong lane. You give it a frame, a drivetrain, a set of rules.
Whatâ€™s exciting is how the two are starting to build on each other: as AI gets better at coding, it becomes easier to create smarter, more dependable agents and those agents, in turn, help us write even better code. But itâ€™s not just about moving fast. Itâ€™s about holding up over time. You donâ€™t just want an AI that can sprint â€” you want one that can go the distance, and patch things up when they break along the way.
The magic of Amsterdam isnâ€™t just the bicycles â€” itâ€™s the unspoken rhythm everyone seems to follow. People just know when to slow down, where to ride, how to signal. Itâ€™s not about strict rules or endless signage. Itâ€™s something built into the culture. That shared understanding is what keeps everything flowing, even when the streets get packed.
Thatâ€™s what Model Context Protocol (MCP) does for AI. MCP defines how agents interact with tools, with other systems, and with users. It gives them structured context about whatâ€™s available, whatâ€™s off-limits, and how to behave in a given environment. Itâ€™s like a silent rulebook that all agents agree to follow. Without MCP, each agent is a rogue cyclist dropped into traffic with no map and no idea what a red light means. With MCP, every agent enters the environment already knowing the rules â€” not just for itself, but for the broader system itâ€™s riding within.
The future of AI isnâ€™t just about making individual models smarter. Itâ€™s about building shared standards and frameworks that let these agents work together smoothly and safely in real-world situations. Think of it this way: training the model is like teaching someone how to ride a bicycle, while MCP is like giving them a map and the rules of the road.
Watching a group of cyclists ride in sync, adjusting speed, spacing, and direction as one is kind of hypnotic. No shouting, no instructions, just quiet coordination. One slows down a bit, another speeds up, and they glide through a tight turn together.
Thatâ€™s what agent-to-agent collaboration can unlock. You donâ€™t need one giant all-in-one â€œsuper-agentâ€ doing everything. Instead, you want a bunch of smaller specialists who each focus on what they do best, communicate clearly, and work together smoothly. One handles the schedule, another puts together a proposal, and someone else makes sure everythingâ€™s following the rules. Itâ€™s like a group of riders on bicycles â€” each with their own job, but all moving in sync because theyâ€™re paying attention to each other When agents talk to each other i.e. when they can share state, delegate tasks, escalate decisions, and adapt dynamically they stop being tools and start becoming teammates.
Standing at that crosswalk, I wasnâ€™t thinking about AI. But somehow, AI found me anyway.
What really stuck with me about Amsterdamâ€™s bicycle culture wasnâ€™t just how charming or efficient it was â€” it was the independence. No one was waiting around for instructions. No hesitation. Just people who understood their surroundings, trusted their instincts, and moved with just enough awareness of others to keep things flowing.
Thatâ€™s the kind of AI worth building â€” not rigid scripts, not those bloated, do-everything systems that crumble when things get messy. Instead, itâ€™s about small, capable agents designed to think, fetch what they need, follow protocols, and work together. Tools built to handle the unexpected without constant oversight â€” to move, adjust, and ride.
Because the future of AI isnâ€™t some bullet train locked to a single track moving fast but missing the turns. Itâ€™s more like a fleet of bicycles â€” light, responsive, and always adapting. And if they can keep your coffee from spilling in the middle of the chaos? Thatâ€™s a win :)
--

Title: Beautiful Amsterdam, Built on Poles: Who would pay if it all fell down?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

TedxAmsterdam

--
Listen
Share
Beautiful Amsterdam / Built on Poles/ Who would pay if it all fell down?
â€“Old Dutch nursery rhyme translated
Since early times, the houses in Amsterdam have been built on wooden foundation piles[i] that are driven deep into the clay, peat, and water until they reach the first layer of solid sand. Even some of the trees in Vondelpark are supported on wooden piles to keep them from sinking into the marshy ground.
How long can a wooden pile remain in the ground before it has to be replaced?
300 years? 80 years? Until next week? The answer depends on many variables:
Quality of the sand layer
In Amsterdam, the first layer of sand lies approximately 12 meters below the surface. However, the quality of the sand layer is not consistent throughout the city. In some areas, the first sand layer is thinner than normal or missing entirely. As a result, the houses in these areas sink at an abnormal rate, and the foundations have to be replaced faster.
The top of the wooden foundation pile should be below the lowest expected water level. If part of the pile reaches above the water, it will be subject to insect attacks and decay. A problem is that the water level under Amsterdam isnâ€™t always stable. For instance, it can drop during long periods of drought. Or a sewer pipe can develop cracks, allowing the ground water to flow into the pipe and be carried away. As a result, the water level drops.
On the other hand, if the water level rises too high, as sometimes occurs after a heavy rain, the Amsterdam cellars and crawl spaces fill up like bathtubs.
Construction projects can also interfere with the water level. An example is the incident on the Vijzelgracht in 2008 during work on the new metro station. A leak in the dam wall at a depth of 60 meters caused water and sand to stream into the pit. Part of the sand layer that was supporting the wooden foundation piles of the nearby houses washed away, causing extensive damage to the structure of the houses.
Spruce is less vulnerable to damage from bacteria than pine. Since around 1970, piles made from pine are prohibited from use. Concrete and steel piles are often used in present day construction.
The visible signs are slanted floors, cracks in the walls, doors and windows that stick, and broken front steps. The charming crooked roofline of Amsterdam is actually a symptom of unstable foundations.
If a foundation that is in poor condition is not repaired in time, the wooden piles will need to be replaced. No homeowner wants to get this news. A new foundation can easily cost 100,000 euro. Furthermore, the floor may need to be opened up, thereby making the house unlivable for some time.
In recent years, the housing corporations have been replacing the wooden piles under their properties with concrete piles.[ii] For example, Ymere is replacing the decayed pine piles in the Van der Pek neighborhood â€” a costly investment. However many houses that are at risk are privately owned.
The condition of the old wooden piles will only worsen in the coming years, so the question is: who will pay?
[i] Referred to as poles in the nursery rhyme.
[ii] Palen onder Amsterdam verpulveren
Credits and Sources:
Gemeente Amsterdam Background on Foundations
The Challenges of Building Amsterdamâ€™s New Metro Line
Written by Barbara Austin.
Categorized as Amsterdam.
Tagged with amsterdam, Infrastructure.
Originally published at tedx.amsterdam on September 24, 2015.

Title: Top 10 Must-Do Activities In Amsterdam: Fall In Love With The Netherlandsâ€™ Capital City
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Hi there!
Welcome to a cityscape with unique merchant houses, intersected by numerous canals. Amsterdam is a lively city with a rich cultural scene and 800 years of history.
Forget about the typical tourist traps.
I will tell you the best things you can do for the first time there to feel fabulous.
Stay with me so you donâ€™t miss anything.
Here we go with the Top 10 Must-Do Activities In Amsterdam:
Cycling isnâ€™t just a mode of transportation in Amsterdam.
Itâ€™s a way of life!
With over 800,000 bicycles in the city â€” more than its human population â€” Amsterdam is often called â€˜The Cycling Capital of the Worldâ€™.This is owed to the cityâ€™s flat terrain and extensive network of bike routes.
Experience the city alongside locals on two wheels.
I am sure that you will love Amsterdamâ€™s cycling culture:
www.dutchamsterdam.nl
Grab your saddle and pedal through Amsterdamâ€™s bike-friendly streets.
You will enjoy passing by historic landmarks and picturesque canals.
Try to choose a sunny day or be prepared to cycle in the rain, as is often the case there!
The city of Amsterdam has a unique network of canals stretching to the west and south of the historic old town. The project was initiated during the late 16th and early 17th centuries.
It consists of the reclamation of swampland and the construction of concentric arcs of canals.
The canals, along with radial waterways and streets, showcase the cityâ€™s rich history. Now you have a chance to enjoy its beauty and heritage!
Find more information here:
whc.unesco.org
I had the opportunity to step into the evolution of Jordaan.
Once a humble working-class enclave, it has now transformed into Amsterdamâ€™s hippest neighborhood!
Here, you can stroll along streets lined with art galleries, vintage boutiques, and bars.
Amsterdamâ€™s Nine Streets, nestled behind the Royal Palace on Dam Square, attract both locals and tourists alike:
www.iamsterdam.com
Lose yourself along the cobblestone streets and peaceful canals of Amsterdamâ€™s historic district!
Now, get ready for a journey through time. In just 40 minutes, youâ€™ll zip through 400 years of history, starting from a swampy area.
The best part? This museum tells how Amsterdam, a city built on water, came to be:
grachten.museum
The museum itself is housed in a jaw-dropping building on the Herengracht.
Once youâ€™re inside, grab an audio guide and settle in.
Before you know it, the lights dim, and bam! Youâ€™re whisked back to 1600, smack dab in the middle of Amsterdamâ€™s golden age.
But wait, thereâ€™s more! This museum isnâ€™t just about history.
Itâ€™s also about the cityâ€™s vibrant life.
The dollâ€™s houses are straight out of the past and snippets from cult classic movies.
Yeah, itâ€™s that cool.
Ever wondered what itâ€™s like to live on a houseboat? Well, nowâ€™s your chance to find out!
Step aboard the Woonboot Museum, a cozy floating museum housed in a converted cargo ship from 1914:
houseboatmuseum.nl
You can sip tea and enjoy cake while lounging in retro armchairs.
But thatâ€™s not all â€” Amsterdamâ€™s houseboat scene is a unique way of life. Dive deeper into its story at the Boat Museum of the Canals.
Located on the famous Prinsengracht, this museum offers a glimpse into Amsterdamâ€™s aquatic past and present.
Learn about the evolution of houseboats, canal history, and more.
After all, where else can you get a firsthand look at life on the waterways?
Explore one of Amsterdamâ€™s most powerful historical sites, the Anne Frank House.
Enter the hidden annex where Anne Frank and her family sought refuge during World War II.
Here, youâ€™ll uncover the truths of the Holocaust:
www.annefrank.org
In this museum, you will see Anneâ€™s actual diary and other relics.
I was inspired by the lasting message of courage and hope.
Experience the world of art at the famous Van Gogh Museum.
You will see the largest collection of Vincent van Goghâ€™s masterpieces!
This museum provides a close look into the life and art of the iconic Dutch painter:
www.vangoghmuseum.nl
Admire his lively paintings, sketches, and personal letters, witnessing the journey of his artistic brilliance.
Dive into centuries of Dutch art and history at the legendary Rijksmuseum:
www.rijksmuseum.nl
Discover masterpieces by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and other masters, highlighting the richness of Dutch culture.
From stunning paintings to decorative arts and more, the Rijksmuseum invites you now.
As soon as I walked into the Heineken Brewery, the delightful aroma of hops surrounded me.
Exploring the breweryâ€™s vats and vintage equipment, I discovered the story of Heinekenâ€™s beginnings and their dedication to brewing excellence:
www.heinekenexperience.com
No wonder itâ€™s my favorite beer!
The tasting room was a highlight for me.
With every sip, I savored the essence of Heinekenâ€™s craftsmanship. Heineken truly deserves its high regard in the brewing world.
Do you enjoy this beer as much as I do?
As the sun dips below the horizon, Amsterdam ignites with exciting nightlife.
The Red Light District, famous for its legalized prostitution, is a must-see spot and that caught my eye too:
amsterdamtickets.tours
I wandered through lively streets with friends, enjoying its unique vibe.
But thereâ€™s more to see in the district than just its reputation. Amongst the buzzing nightlife, youâ€™ll discover a fascinating mix of history, culture, and cutting-edge experiences.
Explore cozy cafes, trendy bars, nightclubs, and live music spots.
Amsterdam offers endless possibilities for nighttime adventures.
Whether youâ€™re into groovy beats or prefer a chill night with locals, the city promises unforgettable experiences until the early hours.
Ready to dive in?
Photo by Boudewijn Boer on Unsplash
In conclusion, Amsterdam invites adventurers with its captivating mix of past, present, and excitement.
Whether youâ€™re gliding along its famous canals or diving into its rich art scene, this city has something for everyone.
So, what are you waiting for?
Get ready for an epic adventure through Amsterdamâ€™s beating heart!
What are some of the other best things you did in Amsterdam? Please share in the comments!

Title: Itâ€™s a spoiler. Amsterdam by Ian McEwan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Literature. Book Reviews. Essays.

--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam by Ian McEwan certainly isnâ€™t the first novel in the history of literature that deals with moral hypocrisy in a corrupted society, nor is it the last. But the way McEwan deals with it, the approach, the focus â€” it is all so fresh (even now, in 2015) and remarkable. The narrative instance doesnâ€™t criticize and doesnâ€™t even laugh at those characters. Instead, we, the readers, are encouraged to take the protagonists seriously. There is no bare sarcasm, only the finest irony, essential to characterization and plot. McEwan is a master of the free indirect style. We are in the charactersâ€™ heads, thinking their thoughts, afraid of their fears. We are worried that Clive will end up just like Molly. And there is Vernon with his feeling of non-existence, which is a postmodernist moment, for he certainly does not exist until someone reads the novel.
The introductory setting is hilarious. Two middle-aged guys are attending an ex-loverâ€™s funeral. The ex-lower was a kind of femme fatale clichÃ© of the XX century. The sound of the name, Molly Lane, somehow recalls Molly Bloom. There is, also, at least, one more ex-lover of hers, and her husband. They are all connected in various ways, but the existence of Molly deepens those connections. The first two guys are friends and, which is more important, they give us the first two points of view. They are the good guys. According to them, the husband is stupid and possessive. The third lover, a politician, is an enemy of the previous three.
The language of the novel is extraordinary. Characterization is delicate and minutious.
So, we have two bad, and two good guys. And then Vernon appears to be quite immoral and without human principles. Nevermind. There is Clive, with his moral superiority. He is the one who really loved Molly, who deeply misses her, and who doesnâ€™t even want Vernon to publicly humiliate the arch-enemy, by publishing his photos in women's clothes, taken by Molly, and provided by her husband. We also read a long and rather pathetic passage about how Clive had always been a so much better friend to Vernon than he was to Clive.
Just a few pages later, this morally superior guy goes hiking, in search of inspiration, and then witnesses an act of violence, perhaps a murder, and just walks away, because, for godâ€™s sake, he has the symphony to write!
After less than half of the novel, there is no good protagonist left for us to feel empathy for. But, instead of becoming boring, the novelâ€™s plot starts to accelerate, preventing you from letting it from your hands before youâ€™ve read the very last page of it.
The main plot triggers are behind us by now. Clive and Vernon have made a pact: if one of them gets ill the way Molly did, the other will arrange euthanasia abroad. After that, theyâ€™ve had the first, but crucial, argument in the history of their friendship. It is about embarrassing photographs of Foreign Minister, Julian Garmony, which were about to be published in the magazine that Vernon runs.
Now comes a deus ex machina â€” and the first spoiler to Vernonâ€™s plan. A new character, the Ministerâ€™s wife, gives a press conference, which turns things upside down. On the sudden, it is not the politicianâ€™s head urgently needed on a plate, but Vernonâ€™s.
Vernon and Clive are mad at each other, as they both feel betrayed. They start to hate each other and, in the end, mutually arrange a murder in Amsterdam, where the grand premiere of Cliveâ€™s symphony is about to be performed.
It is Mollyâ€™s husband who, followed by now ex-Foreign Minister, buries them all. The most of his wifeâ€™s former lovers are dead, and now he recalls memories of Vernonâ€™s wife, who used to be wild. He is about to call her for a dinner. So, who is laughing now?
We are. At this moment, I canâ€™t recall any other piece of prose in which the death of the main characters produces such a comical effect. It is even not morbid humor; it is just humor, and it is great.
Ian McEwan won the Man Booker Prize for Amsterdam in 1998.
--
--
