â€œYour body is not a temple, itâ€™s an amusement park. Enjoy the ride.â€
-Bourdain
The ferry dropped us off at the Amsterdam Centraal train station at 2pm, amid the most perfect spring day. It looked like a real-life Truman Show, the way everyone was smiling and laughing without a care. Even the pigeons looked happy, chilling by the canal, generously sharing food.
It made me wonderâ€¦
Are people happy because theyâ€™re in Amsterdam, or do happy people just gravitate there, making it so? Hard to tell. Sounds like a chicken/egg situation. Speaking of which, Iâ€™ve always wondered if people weigh more because of their genes or because their caloric intake is higher, and they work out less. Like, if you took two people who eat and workout the same amount but oneâ€™s family has been fat for generations (like mine) and the other skinny, would they end up weighing the same exact amount? I ask because Iâ€™ve always felt predisposed to fatness due to my dadâ€™s genes.
Before looking for a hostel, I wanted to get high, so I went in the first â€œcoffee shopâ€ I saw. Now would be a good time to describe the difference between coffee shops in America and coffee shops in Amsterdam. They look the same, except in Amsterdam, some sell weed. Pretty simple.
I ordered a pre-roll and a latte. If cocaine and heroin together is a speed ball, weed and coffee together is more like a curveball. Part of me felt demure, sitting there smoking a joint by myself in a cafÃ©. The other part though, was high as fuck, and VERY paranoid. The American penal system was so ingrained in me that my Pavlovian response to being high was an intense fear of the police. No matter how much I reassured myself that I wasnâ€™t breaking the law, I couldnâ€™t shake the fear of being arrested. You donâ€™t realize youâ€™re paranoid amidst the paranoia. If you did, you wouldnâ€™t be paranoid.
*
On my walk to find a hostel I couldnâ€™t stop laughing at the ridiculousness of the street names. I wrote some of my favorites down. I also made up some of my own. See if you can guess which are which. I canâ€™t even remember myself.
- Brouwersgracht
- Hosenlendinvein
- Princeneiland
- Amsterveenseweg
- Grunarpeilveg
- Einelpenilhar
- Brouwersgracht
The hostel I chose was a far cry from The Flying Pig, the â€œitâ€ place Iâ€™d read about in my research. The Flying Pig was the most popular hostel for people under 30 (still is) because it has a weed smoking section in the common area where they have pipes and bongs to rent. There was a communal element, one I was not looking for. I donâ€™t like being part of groups and try to avoid it whenever possible. I want to do what I want to do, not what â€œusâ€ wants to do. â€œUsâ€ is always some lame compromise. Instead, I went with an off-brand hostel, one that catered to an older, more laid-back crowd. When I booked it online from London, the picture made it look like a nondescript Holiday Inn Express. It was a little off the beaten path, but not too far from the action. It seemed clean, calm, and quiet, exactly what I wanted.
When I checked in, it did seem both clean and calm. But, to my surprise, I heard jackhammering. When I inquired, the manager told me there would be construction every day from 9am-5pm. I thanked him and went up to my room.
Thatâ€™s how I am, I thank people who inconvenience me. Iâ€™ve always been way too accommodating, even to my own detriment. I try to save the world one favor at a time. I could have very easily found another hostel that didnâ€™t have Jackhammering, but that, somehow, in my mind, would have been considered breaking a commitment. The hostel was probably struggling because of the jackhammering, and I wanted to help. I know, thatâ€™s crazy.
When I got up to my room, there was, in fact, a man jackhammering five feet from my window. It sounded like the gunfight from Heat. So, I turned right around and got out of there.
On my way down I saw the Manager again.
Manager: Sir, how is your room?
Me: Perfect. Thank you.
I still had an hour to kill before the jackhammering stopped, so I set out to buy weed, enough to last at least a week. After 5 minutes of walking, I stumbled upon a place called Coffee Shop Bob Marley. From the outside, it looked exactly like youâ€™d think it would, Jamaican flag, pictures of Bob, Wailers albums. It was corny, but it would do. Afterall, they had weed for sale.
When I entered, I was greeted by an old budtender who looked exactly like Willie Nelson, all the way down to the bandana. From his voice, I could tell he was an American ex-pat. He handed me a Trapper Keeper-style three ring binder. In it were plastic pages with little slots for what traditionally would have been baseball cards. Instead of cards though, each quadrant contained a nugget of weed, along with a description (e.g. purple haze: mellow, euphoric). It was the first time Iâ€™d seen such a professional setup, and it blew me away. Iâ€™d smoked weed daily for 5 years but had never dreamt of such a variety. Iâ€™d hit the motherload.
After much consideration, I selected 4 indica strains and paid Willie 60 Euros for the 14-gram purchase, an amazing deal anywhere in the world at that time.
Me: May I light up in here?
Willy: Of course. The smoking room is in back.
The smoking room was just a small, curtained off area with a few high-top tables. A Bob Marley music video played on the television hanging on the wall. I put my bag down and removed a grape White Owl cigar that Iâ€™d bought before leaving London. At the time I was still smoking blunts and I wanted to â€œrepresentâ€ my â€œcultureâ€ while in Europe. Ha. What I didnâ€™t consider, was that Iâ€™d barely smoked the previous two weeks in New York. And, though I smoked a few hash spliffs the night before in London, my tolerance was still lower than usual. Regardless, I went ahead and rolled a 2.5-gram monster of Afghan Kush.
There were two other people in the room with me, a couple, who both appeared to be in their 30â€™s. I couldnâ€™t hear their voices, but I assumed they werenâ€™t from America. I did that with everyone who wasnâ€™t traveling in a group. Thereâ€™s just something about Americans, we love traveling in guided groups. Very rarely did I see a duo of American travelers, let alone a solo one. When I dumped the guts of the blunt into a garbage bin near the wall, they stared in my direction. They didnâ€™t say anything, but I could tell they were interested in what I was constructing. I was proud of my blunt rolling skills and wanted to put on a show for them, so they could see how we did it in the states. I considered myself an ambassador.
After licking the blunt closed, I sparked my lighter, running the flame along the paper to dry it out. Then, I lit it, taking a deep drag and coughing slightly. The couple, again, glanced my way. I looked back at them, smiling like a cool dude.
About halfway through the blunt, I realized Iâ€™d made a huge mistake. I wasnâ€™t cool at all. In fact, I was sweating bullets and overcome with dizziness. I could tell the couple wanted to check on me, they just werenâ€™t sure if it was their place to do so. I mean, I mustâ€™ve known what I was doing, right? You donâ€™t just roll a blunt like that if itâ€™s your first time smoking weed.
My equilibrium was totally askew. I gripped the small, circular table like we were Greco Roman wrestling. I had to say something before it was too late.
Me: My name is Sam. Iâ€™m from America. If I die, my momâ€™s name is Audrey â€”
Then I passed out and fell off my chair.
When I came to, Bob Marleyâ€™s I Shot the Sheriff was playing on the tv. The couple was hovering over me, disturbed, their highs obviously ruined. Willie was concerned too, standing over me with a bottle of water. I didnâ€™t even know how long Iâ€™d been out.
Willy: We were scared, man. Glad youâ€™re ok. We donâ€™t even allow cigars in here.
Lady: That was so scary. Why would you try smoking that whole blunt?
Me: You know what blunts are?
Guy: Of course. Weâ€™re from America too.
*
On my way back to the hostel, I passed what looked to be the strangest food establishment Iâ€™d ever seen. It reminded me of a Grayâ€™s Papaya, a New York hot dog chain I loved, in that there was no seating inside. In fact, there was nothing at all inside. It was just an empty room, like an American check cashing place. Yet, it smelled like fast food. It was too weird to not investigate.
When I went in, I thought I was tripping out. I was still extremely high and woozy from the fall, but I was pretty sure I was standing inside a life-sized vending machine. The walls were lined with rows and rows of slots where hot food was kept. There must have been a kitchen in the back where everything was prepared, but I didnâ€™t see one, nor could I hear one. The only sign of human life was the hand of an employee replenishing the stock after a sale. I didnâ€™t love the impersonality of it all, but I had to admit it was ingenious.
My dad would have loved to have access to a place like that, where he could anonymously buy food without the judgement of a cashier. Itâ€™s just you and the food, no interaction whatsoever, perfect for an addict.
I was enjoying my burger on a nearby bench, when off in the distance I saw the glow of the Red-Light-District. Until that point, Iâ€™d thought the name â€œRed-Light-Districtâ€ just referred to the illicit activities that went on there, I didnâ€™t know it was a literal description of the place. It looked like a devilish carnival, the dope dealers being the carnies, and the ladies, the rides. Young adults, mostly backpackers, lined the outskirts, trying to get up the nerve to make the plunge. â€œHow pathetic,â€ I thought to myself. â€œI canâ€™t believe Iâ€™d wanted to do this.â€
*
March 26, 2006
After a wonderful night of stoned sleep, I woke up to my alarm at 8:45am, which left me the perfect amount of time to shower, eat, do laundry, and get to the Smart Shop right when it opened. They call places that sell mushrooms â€œsmart shopsâ€ the way they call weed stores â€œcoffee shopsâ€. Iâ€™ve always found that to be telling. Those are delicate, non-fear inducing terms. We donâ€™t have â€œsafety storesâ€ in America, we have â€œGun and Ammoâ€ shops. Rather crude, if you ask me.
Iâ€™d done mushrooms a handful of times before, with experiences ranging from spiritual bliss to utter madness, but Iâ€™d always learned something about myself in the process, and that was the most important part. Wait, thatâ€™s not totally true. Sometimes, I just spend 4 hours in the bathroom trying to wipe pee that isnâ€™t there off my pants. A psychologist would have a field day with that one.
When I entered the Smartshop, I was greeted by the kind of guy youâ€™d think would be running a psychedelic mushroom store, long hair, flannel shirt, monk vibes.
Clerk: How may I help you?
Me: Can you please advise me on which mushrooms I should take, and the quantity?
Clerk: Of course. That is exactly what I am here for. Have you done psilocybin before?
Me: Yes, maybe 20 times.
Clerk: Ok, let me walk you through what we have.
He took me over to a glass case with about 15 varieties of mushrooms, some wet, some dry, all of them unique in shape and color. He walked me through their different levels of potency and their array of effects.
Me: How about something in the medium-strength level?
Clerk: Sure. Would you like to see visuals?
Me: Yes, please.
Clerk: I suggest 1 to 2 grams of the High Hawaiian variety, dried.
Me: Will they make me laugh?
Clerk: Ooohhh yeah.
I paid him 25 Euros and exited the Smartshop with my mushrooms. Then, I walked over to the canal. There was a light mist, so I found an unoccupied bench and dried a small spot for myself. I took the mushrooms out of my bag, along with a banana Iâ€™d saved from breakfast and a bottle of water. Then I said my usual pre-hallucinogen prayer. â€œLord, please look after me during this trip. And please, please donâ€™t let me think I peed my pants.â€
Once I had the mushrooms down and the nausea passed, I sat back and read my book until the words no longer looked like words, maybe 30 minutes. Thatâ€™s when the laughing started. EVERYTHING was funny. I spent 10 minutes laughing at my shoes because they looked like chili dogs. Then it was the word â€œwanker.â€ I couldnâ€™t stop saying it. â€œOy ye wankerâ€, â€œAye wanker, quit ya wankingâ€, â€œBloody, scheming wanker.â€
Down the canal a few hundred yards away, I saw a tourist boat slowly approaching. There were about 20 or so passengers, all of them Asian. They looked so happy, with their big visors and smiling faces. I was overcome with the urge to connect with them. I stood up and waved my arms, yelling to them as they passed.
â€œHelllloooooo!!! Welcome to Amsterdam!!!â€
They waved back jubilantly, while I cry-laughed in the rain like a maniac, yelling in their direction as they passed by my bench.
â€œEnjoy your staaayyyy!!â€
I greeted 8 boats-worth of people over a 2-hour period. For nearly my entire trip, I worked as a volunteer civil servant for a city Iâ€™d just arrived in. You never know where hallucinogens will take you.
I walked back to the hostel soaked; my feet pruned from the rain. What I needed more than anything was a peaceful place to come down and dry off. When I got to my room, I was delighted to find none of my roommates there, a rare occurrence in a 4-person room. I toweled off and hung my clothes on the edge of the bunk before getting into my bed to reflect and relax. I couldnâ€™t have felt calmer, laying there. My heart was pure, and my thoughts, loving.
Then the jackhammering started up. Iâ€™d completely forgotten about it. And this time, because of the mushrooms, it sounded even louder and more menacing than before. My trip was turning dark, and I had to make a move. Either go down and watch the BBC in the lobby, which would inevitably end up in conversation, or spend the next hour showering.
I went with the shower.
*
March 27, 2006
I came to the next morning, feeling exfoliated, if nothing else. My clothes were dry, finally, so I set out to find an outdoor market where I could buy an extra pair of cheap pants in case I found myself in a similar situation again. In America, we call them swap meets. Theyâ€™re the same thing, just with a bad name.
When I was on my way out, I saw the manager.
Manager: Sir, how has your stay been?
Me: Perfect. Thank you. Is there an outdoor market where I can buy pants and food?
Manager: The Albert Cuyp Market would be the place.
To his credit, it was the place. Within 10 minutes of being there I bought a pair of cheap sweatpants, an onion and herring sandwich, and a crepe. I am perhaps the only person in history to purchase those 3 exact items at once. I wanted to experience the local delicacies though, and figured I could knock em out in one fail swoop. The meal brought back memories of my Bubbie, who I missed dearly. She loved herring and crepes (separately). Seeing me holding them at the same time wouldâ€™ve given her a good chuckle. Sheâ€™d probably ask, â€œWhat is it, my birthday?â€ My father loved crepes too, but the image of him eating 30 crepes is not a pleasant memory to conjure up.
After finishing my meal, I went in my pocket for dessert, 20mg of Adderall. My mom told me my Bubbie took uppers in the 60â€™s, when they prescribed it to housewives as a weight loss drug. I bet her grandma was a speed freak too, drinking that Coca Cola with actual cocaine in it.
I needed to charge up, and without sleep, Adderall was the best way to do that (even with sleep, for that matter). I was on a mission to find a bar that evening. And not just a bar for that night, but one I could call home in future visits. I still had a month or so left in my trip and knew Iâ€™d be back to Amsterdam, so I needed to have a reliable place to hang my hat. Bars are that important to me. I canâ€™t just go any old place to drink willy nilly. I need a home base, somewhere I feel comfortable, where they know my name. Like the Commonwealth.
I had no clue where I was going to find it, but I knew Iâ€™d know it when I saw it (the same way pornography was defined by the Supreme Court in 1964). It took some walking, but then I stumbled upon what was undoubtably the place. I was standing at the corner of Nieuwebrugsteeg and Warmoesstraat, right where Warmoesstraat turns into Sint Olofspoort. Iâ€™m serious. I looked up and there it wasâ€¦ The perfect bar. The sign under the awning read: â€œH. Murrayâ€™s Bar.â€ Next to it was a smaller sign that read â€œAnno 1619.â€ It looked to be more of a house than a bar. There was even a Golden Retriever in the window, standing with itsâ€™ paws on the sill. A bar dog is a surefire sign of a good bar. If itâ€™s good enough for a dog, itâ€™s good enough for me.
I entered like I was returning home.
Me: Hi. Iâ€™m Sam.
Neil: Hello, friend. Iâ€™m Neil. Thatâ€™s Lilly (pointing to the dog). And thatâ€™s Norman (pointing to the only other man sitting at the bar).
Me: Hello gents. May Iâ€¦?
Norman: Pull up a seat, Sam.
Me: Iâ€™ll have what Normanâ€™s having.
Always drink what the house drinks. It will endear you to the crowd. For me, that only backfires when the house drink is Sambuca. I hate Sambuca. It tastes like Christmas tree water. Or Malort. Donâ€™t even get me started on the Chicago bars that push that lighter fluid on their clientele. Monsters.
We got to talking and time got to flying, the way it does when youâ€™re around good people. Norman told me about his time in Berkley, about how he knew Tim Leary, Tom Wolffe and the Merry Pranksters, people Iâ€™d only known from books like The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test, and Hunterâ€™s Hells Angels. We shared the same sense of humor too. When he told me his favorite comedian was Steven Wright, I knew we were cut from the same cloth, only a generation apart.
Steven Wright is one of the more obscure, odd comedians; real dry, great word economy. He can make you laugh in less than 20 words.
â€œA lot of people are afraid of heights. Not me, Iâ€™m afraid of widths.â€
â€œI think itâ€™s wrong that only one company makes the game Monopolyâ€
I told him to look up Mitch Hedberg, but didnâ€™t bother telling him how Mitchâ€™s death contributed to my quitting stand-up, or that I even did stand-up at all. I couldnâ€™t have done that without crying, so I just listened and enjoyed being a guest.
I wish I remembered more of that night, but thatâ€™s how it goes sometimes. Iâ€™ve always found sacrificing memory for fun to be a fair trade. Not everything has to be remembered and documented with a picture. I canâ€™t recall most of the best times of my life and Iâ€™m just fine with that.
*
March 28, 2006
They started jackhammering bright and early the next day. Still half-drunk, wearing my clothes from the prior night, I darted down to the lobby to get breakfast before it ended. While scarfing down cold eggs and toast, I checked my pockets and counted the money I had. It was the same exact amount Iâ€™d gone out with the night before, along with a few grams of unfamiliar loose weed. John Mulaney has a joke about blacking out and coming home with more money than he left with, and thatâ€™s exactly what happened to me. Neil didnâ€™t even charge me. He mustâ€™ve denied my attempts at tipping too, because every dollar was still in my wallet. I couldnâ€™t recall his kind gesture, but I was sure I hadnâ€™t just skipped out on my tab. I mean, I was pretty sure. When Iâ€™m blacked out, Iâ€™m more inclined to try and pay twice than I am to skip out on the bill. One time in New Orleans, I paid my tab, then sat there trying to pay my tab again, four more times. The bartender eventually threw me out.
Some hair of the dog seemed in order. â€œHair of the dogâ€ means â€œAlcohol.â€ They used to rub it on dog wounds. The way itâ€™s colloquially used now is to say, â€œyou canâ€™t get hungover if you stay drunk.â€ I still had about an hour before the intense hangover would take hold, and figured a large quantity of Adderall and drinks could fend it off.
I found a nearby Irish Pub and ordered a shot and a beer. Realizing I was American, the bartender tested me before serving me.
Bartender: Do you like George Bush?
Me: Heâ€™s a cunt.
Bartender: Guinness and Jameson coming right up.
I drank and gobbled pills the whole afternoon and into the early evening, until I could hardly see straight. Bender mode, engage.
Letâ€™s talk about benders for a minuteâ€¦ During 24 hour-plus drinking benders, your brain swells to the point you can barely remember who or where you are. You become erratic, uncontrollable. For no reason at all, you push over garbage cans, rip signs out of the ground, and piss on walls. And youâ€™ll fuck anything with a pulse. You become possessed. And the choice remainsâ€¦ Give up and succumb to the impending hangover or continue on with disregard for all human decency. Either way, youâ€™re fucked.
I marched on. After leaving the bar, I bought a 20oz Heineken and brown bagged it on my walk to nowhere. At least I thought I was going nowhere. My subconscious had a different idea though. I didnâ€™t realize it at first, but I was retracing my steps from the previous day. My boozed soaked brain was leading me to the very place my sober brain found disgusting. I didnâ€™t even realize where I was going until I saw the glowing red lights.
*
I walked the entire length of the Red-Light District multiple times, prowling amongst my fellow creeps, trying to find the perfect lady. I have always been a very discerning shopper, that time being no different. I didnâ€™t just want any random lady; I wanted one who showed interest in me. God, thatâ€™s pathetic.
The women all had their own room where they sat, positioned toward the outer sidewalk. The ones who were â€œbusy workingâ€ had their large window covered with a red curtain. The others, who were â€œwaiting for work,â€ had their curtains drawn, allowing you to see the entire layout of the room. They were all similar; a bed in the corner, a small nightstand, presumably for keys or other knickknacks that may interfere with the coitus, and a few mirrors. Everything was red, the lights, the bed, the carpetâ€¦ Like white is the safest car color, I think red makes for the most fucking.
All the women were objectively gorgeous, much more gorgeous than the sex workers I patronized in Tijuana the prior summer. They were hideous. And they robbed me. I donâ€™t want to talk about that though. These ladies werenâ€™t beaten down, figuratively speaking. They looked confident, even proud, like hard working small-business owners. Some of them werenâ€™t even dressed scantily and gave off a â€œtake it or leave itâ€ vibe, which I dug. There were no pimps in sight either. Just the ladies and their red rooms.
With each trip down the corridor, I narrowed my selection, like I was hosting my own March Madness tournament, pitting lady against lady, with the winner advancing to the next round.
The eventual winner was white, with long, dark brown hair, and weighed about 150 pounds. She curled her index finger and invited me in, licking it between curls with the effort of a champion.
Inside, I met the pimp. He may not have been a pimp technically, but he held the money like a pimp does. And probably for the best. I gave him 50 Euros and he gave me a single condom. He didnâ€™t say a word. Then, he opened the door to the red room.
Tonya: Iâ€™m Tonya. Whatâ€™s your name?
Me: Iâ€™m Sam.
I forgot I could lie.
Her bubbliness left. Now she was working. Sheâ€™d already caught her fish; the rest was just fileting.
Tonya: Bed or standing?
Me: Uhhh, standing.
I feared I might pass out if I lied down
She turned around and faced the dresser, gripping the top of it with her hand. Pulling down her black, lace panties, she began to prepare herself with one hand, the other braced on the dresser. I took my pants down, following her lead.
Lady: Ok, ready.
I tore open the condom and put it on. Then, I inserted myself.
When she moaned, I gained confidence. I started to go faster, and she moaned more, my confidence growing stronger yet. I took my left hand and slapped her ass cheek.
Thatâ€™s when the pimp came bursting in.
Pimp: NO, NO, NO! NONE OF THAT!
He was pissed. I looked over at him to apologize for my lapse in judgment, and while doing so, ejaculated into the condom I was wearing. I knew I was jizzing. He knew I was jizzing. I knew he knew I was jizzing.
We both jumped back.
Pimp: Ok, thatâ€™s it youâ€™re done.
Me: But I didnâ€™t even cum.
He pointed to my shriveling dick.
Pimp: Yes, you did.
I had no recourse. There was jizz in the condom and I couldnâ€™t remove it in his presence, causing a smoking gun, â€œgotcha!â€ type of situation. So, I waited until he left the room, then I got dressed, alongside Tonya.
Me: So, Tonya. Thank you very much.
Tonya: (doing a crossword puzzle) Yeah, whatever.
Me: Have a good rest of your evening.
*
March 29, 2006
I woke up the next morning wreaking of vomit. Iâ€™d gone to a bar to cement my blackout after having sex with Tonya, but unfortunately, I wasnâ€™t able to drink enough to forget I came while looking into another manâ€™s eyes. I guess thatâ€™s the type of memory no amount of alcohol can erase. To this day, I still see his face . I like to think he still sees mine too and were forever cosmically connected through semen.
I knew Iâ€™d be back, but I had to get the hell out of Amsterdam, pronto. I needed a reset. I couldnâ€™t fall deeper into depravity so early in the trip. I had to pace myself if I wanted to survive another 2 weeks on the road.
After showering (I know, Iâ€™m disgusting for not having showered the night before. Get off me), I headed to the train station and looked at the big board to see what my options were. Paris was appealing but I wasnâ€™t mentally prepared to take an 8-hour train ride. That would have left far too much time to reflect on the previous night. So, when I noticed the option to take a 4-hour bullet train, I jumped at the chance and made a reservation for the 11am departure.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

Title: Going South From Amsterdam, Not Just by Latitude
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Adventures and misadventures as we travel the world. Are you a traveller looking for a home for your stories? Your true travel stories are welcome. Ask to become a writer.

Member-only story
--
15
Share
I heard the conductorâ€™s announcement as we approached Rotterdam train station â€” â€œWatch out for pickpockets!â€ We had nothing valuable in our pockets, I thought. The thieves would be disappointed if they picked OUR pockets.
We had barely arrived in Amsterdam two days prior, but we jumped right into action. There was too little time and too much to see. Our American employers werenâ€™t sympathetic to our desire to see the world, and our European or Aussie friends werenâ€™t helping when they flaunted their five-day stay at a place and uncertain departure. We heard that all of Europe shut down in August. What?! What if I got appendicitis?
Jet lag is for wusses and we are biased for action. We have to be. We got our bearings during the first evening in Amsterdam so upon our return from Belgium, we would have an optimized route to tackle our must-see list. The day before, we wandered through Delft and Leiden while keeping an eye on the watch. Thank goodness for the Netherlandsâ€™ robust train system and the manageable size of the country. Those little towns were charming even in the rain and vendors in the open market didnâ€™t complain, so why would we?

Title: My First Impression of Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The place where essays, journal prompts, reflections, day-to-day experiences, and deep thoughts are shared and celebrated. Diary writers from all walks of life, and every corner of the world tell their experiences one thought at a time, in a classic diarist style.

--
14
Listen
Share
Back in July of 2023, I flew into Amsterdam to start my new life. Amsterdam was going to be it for me. The magical canals, the tulips, the summer sun.
It was the place to be.
I understood there was a lot of weed in Amsterdam, Iâ€™m not a user but Iâ€™ve never been bothered by other peoples choices as long as thereâ€™s no pressure for me to partake.
I was excited â€” Iâ€™d heard so many good things about the Dutch culture, theyâ€™re friendly and community minded, they love flowers, and are some of the happiest people on earth.
I was convinced that I would step into Amsterdam and say, â€œthis is my home,â€ and live here happily for the rest of my life.
I know, I set very realistic expectations for myself.
I did not own a jacket. The wind whipped you like a smoothie, what more can I say, Iâ€™d just arrived from Spain and I was cold.
I ate a sausage roll and felt like I was back at home, then I was annoyed because right next door was a salad bar I hadnâ€™t noticed. I walked out the door, caught a taxi and asked them to drive me to my hostel.
They said, â€œThis is not a good area.â€
Iâ€™ve heard that so many times. Itâ€™s a tradition of mine to book a dodgy hostel the first night in a new country â€” never on purpose.
I hopped out of the taxi, payed the million bucks, and headed on in. The reviews had been good; they provided all meals if you wanted them too (and can pay for it), the common area was social with table tennis and pool and a bar.
All of this was true, and the staff were lovely. The only problem was everyone was buzzed. Is that the right slang?
Everyone checking in was out of it. Not like theyâ€™d taken a few puffs at a concert â€” they were not there at all. Had I walked into a hostel or a hospital?
The only problem was everyone was buzzed.
I checked in and was treated like I was also very out of it. I went to my hostel room, dumped my bag and decided to go exploring.
I enjoyed a walk through a lovely park, I was stopped by a guy who tried to get a lot of personal information from me and I assertively said, â€œIâ€™m going to leave now.â€ Which I was quite proud of myself for doing.
I found another lovely park but it was filled with homeless people, and people on drugs. I left pretty quick.
I sat down at a restaurant and tried to get some food in me, and a cool drink. It wasnâ€™t hot but sometimes you have to fake it till you make it.
Pro Tip: If youâ€™re ever alone and feel less than 100%, you need to eat. Even if youâ€™re not hungry, just pick at something.
So I ordered with a grumpy waitress, and tried not to cry as I thought about how all my dreams had been crushed in just a few hours. I was alone in a scary city. I had walked for about three hours and hadnâ€™t made it to the Anne Frank House like I wanted, instead I was tired, scared, and the most alone Iâ€™d ever felt.
While sitting at this cafÃ© fighting back tears I remembered I was in complete control of my life, choices, and actions. So I looked up hostels elsewhere. I had been told to go outside of Amsterdam and explore little towns, so I thought Iâ€™d do that.
I looked on booking.com and picked the cheapest hostel with at least an 8/10 rating. The place was advertised to be quiet, along a canal, and within walking distance to a conference centre. The complete opposite to my vibe but I was tired and I thought itâ€™d be worth a shot.
I caught a taxi back to my hostel, contacted home, and went to bed with a very early alarm set for the morning.
The next day was the start of my overseas adventure, I just didnâ€™t know it yet.
Have you ever been in a situation where you felt uncomfortable?
Have you ever felt unsafe in a new city?
Check out this weekâ€™s topic for my The Netherlands Diaries column too!
medium.com
Do you have something to write about you think would be welcomed here at The Diarist? Check out the submissions page â€” letâ€™s see it! Follow The Diarist for some griping diary entries, by your favourite Diarists.
--
--

Title: From Amsterdam to Budapest in Tesla
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
As a fanatic football fan, it is a dream to watch European Championship knockout match in the stadium. The championship was cancelled in the year 2020 due to pandemic. In 2021 it started with empty stadium and eventually with minimal capacity. Budapest is the only city which got permission to hold international matches with 100% capacity. Thanks to the circumstances that I got a ticket to one of the knockout matches. It was a ticket for Netherlands Vs Czech Republic for round of 16 Euro 2021 match, hosted in Budapest. Without any second thought, I booked tickets. Now during the COVID situation it is hard to travel via Aeroplane. So, that option had been discarded. Iâ€™m personally very passionate about drive. Often and regularly whenever I get chance, I go for long drive with my family. Why not in Car ?
As Google says, the distance between Amsterdam and Budapest is around 1400 KM. So, a round trip will be around 2800 KM and we need to complete the same within 72 hours. Challenging ? Isnâ€™t it ? I called my friend, Supratik, another fellow MDM expert, and tell about the plan. He was too very excited and was ready to hit the road.
I have a Tesla Model 3 Long Range AWD Model. As claimed by Tesla, with 100% full charge, it can go upto 580 KM. Off course, Iâ€™m not planning to challenge the claim. Even I can complete with scheduled Supercharging facility, Iâ€™m good. The plan is to start by Friday evening and end by Monday afternoon.
2800 KM in 72 hours. Fascinating journey. Route plan has been automatically created by GoAnywhere Tool available with Tesla. We are supposed to stop in the designated points. There are total 5 super charger points decided by Tesla Tool and I decided to abide by completely without trusting my own ability of making prediction for charging.
As Iâ€™ve approached towards the date, I prepared a mini bucket list to carry. 1. Toothbrush 2. Half Pant (1 extra) 3. T-Shirts (1 extra) 4. Netherlands Flag with Team jersey 5. My wife prepared a flux full of strong coffee and two plates of Noodles prepared in Indian style for the night 6. My laptop, phone and chargers 7. Credit card (For emergency). And 8. Passport and PCR Test result.
I called my Insurance company to check about the Travel Insurance. In order to travel in Germany, Austria and Hungary, three different autobahnvignet was required which I purchased two days before the travel date. PCR Test was mandatory, so we did the same and was expecting the result by 10 PM on the travel date. We decided that once we get the result, we should start.
25th June, 2021 Friday 10:00 PM : just received the PCR Test result for COVID-19 and it was negative. I was good to go. Finally the time came to say BYE to my wife and two daughters for the awaited travel. I started from Almere, Netherlands. Supratik, who was accompanying me, was waiting in Amersfoort. I took him and then started for Budapest.
1:00 AM in the morning. It was 26th June Saturday then when we reached our first destination. The first stop was at Westerwaldpark 4, 56587 Oberhonnefeld-Gierend, Germany. The distance we covered was 308 KM and it took me nearly 3 hours. The sky was clear and Full-Moon was visible like burned Indian Roti. The last time I saw this kind of moon was in my village when I was 7 years. Looking at the moon just reminded me those days. We were tempted to take some the pictures of Moon while the Tesla was getting charged. Supratik was carrying SLR Camera, he took some good photo of the red moon. I had my half portion of meal (prepared by my wife). It was a short break of around 20 minutes and the car was ready for another destination.
3:20 AM I stopped at HauptstraÃŸe 231, 63879 Weibersbrunn, Germany. The distance travelled so far was around 500 KM. I found myself little fatigue and took a break of 30 minutes with the strong Indian Coffee. Sipping the home-made coffee in the middle of the road was enjoyable. I feel loved.
7:00 AM stopped at JunkersstraÃŸe 3, 93055 Regensburg, Germany. The distance covered 870 KM so far. Took a break for 30 minutes. It was morning with super Sun shine. I really needed a coffee. Oh yeah !! before I forgot to mention, my fellow friend was sleeping from start, as I imagined he was actually dreaming with his seat belts on. I was so certain because, he had not even moved while I stopped, had a coffee and completed the charging.
10:00 AM RasthausstraÃŸe 3, 4300 St. Valentin, Austria. We crossed the Austrian border around 8:00 AM in the mornging. The distance travelled so far was 1050 KM. Took 30 mins break here.
2:00 PM GyÅ‘rÃºjbarÃ¡t M1 autÃ³pÃ¡lya, 119. kmsz, 9081 Hungary. The distance travelled so far 1300 KM. Unfortunately, I detour at Viena. The usual road shows the route bypassing the city of Viena. I took the road though the city. It was around 12â€“00 noon, the traffic was medium. That increased the travel time by 30 mins. At around 1:00 PM, I crossed border of Hungary and Austria. Once I reached the pre-defined Supercharger location, took 30 mins break. I was feeling Hungry. I had bread with Goulash soup.
3:30 PM Budapest. The distance travelled so far was 1400 KM. Total time of travel is approximately 17 hrs 30 minutes. It was hot outside around 35 degrees sunny. Dog tired.
Tesla is incredible. My highest speed was about 220 KM per hour in the Germany autobahn. There are plenty super charging facility available. So, you donâ€™t need to worry about it. GoAnywhere tool automatically determines the best available route for your journey. Return journey was around the same. We started from Budapest at 11â€“00 PM on Sunday 27th June. I returned Home (Almere, NL) at 5â€“00 PM Monday 28th June. It took me 16 hours to return. Faster though !!
--
--
MDM Architect | Blogger | DJ | Musician

Title: My sons were profiled by a racist predictive policing system â€” the AI Act must prohibit these systems
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
By Diana Sardjoe
When I found out my sons were placed on lists called the â€˜Top 600â€™ and the â€˜Top 400â€™ by the local Amsterdam council, I thought I was finally getting help.
The council says the purpose of these lists, created by predictive and profiling systems, is to identify and give young people who have been in contact with the police â€œextra attention from the council and organisations such as the police, local public health service and youth protection,â€ to prevent them from coming into contact with police again. [1]
This could not have been further from the truth.
These predictive systems assess and profile young people in Amsterdam to determine who is likely to commit crimes in the future; the â€˜Top 600â€™ profiles children over the age of 16, the â€˜Top 400â€™ profiles children under 16.
As a result of my sons being profiled by these systems, they were continually monitored and harassed by police. One was repeatedly accused of criminal activity along with other young boys he hung out with. Another time, I had to deal with police coming into my home. My son was arrested and I had to go and pick him up from the detention centre late at night. Other mothers I know were threatened with having their children taken away.
We had to deal with a system based on prejudice, with the weight of the authorities behind it. I was completely alone in this struggle, and there was nothing I could do. During this time, my sons withdrew further and further. I felt like a prisoner, watched and monitored at every turn, and I broke down mentally and physically, ending up on cardiac monitoring.
These events were an eye-opener for me, and it made me look for answers. How did my sons end up on these lists? What information do they use to decide this? How is it that it is always young, minoritised ethnic boys on these lists? How do the authorities have so much information on me and my family, and how is that justified? When does the monitoring start â€” and when does it end? I started a group for other mothers called The Mother is the Key, to share our stories, and start questioning and challenging the authorities.
So let me tell you the problems with these profiling systems.
First of all, the information they had about me and my family was inaccurate and prejudiced. The authoritiesâ€™ data collection on young people often starts in school, the Top400 system uses this information to profile children. [2] Maybe the child missed some days of school. Maybe they had to go to a different school. All this information is registered, and it is used by the Top400 system to profile a child as a future criminal.
Once these authorities make a negative report about you, and itâ€™s filed away in their system, youâ€™ll never get rid of it. This is the consequence of our database society: you no longer have control over your life. Every time you interact with an authority or agency, you notice that they are suspicious of you, that they hold some prejudice against you. Your data and these profiles and predictions are shared amongst different public authorities, and held against you forever.
Another piece of information the police use to profile young boys on these lists is â€˜contactâ€™ they have had with the police. [3] This contact is often purely the result of ethnic profiling. I once saw my son, aged thirteen, being stopped by police and asked for ID while he was walking home down the street. That was enough for him to be registered on the police database as having had â€˜contactâ€™ with them. In this way, racist policing becomes hard-wired in the police data, and young men from racialised backgrounds are of course unfairly over-represented within that data. The information that goes into these systems is the same as the information that comes out. If prejudice goes in, prejudice will come out.
These predictive and profiling systems used by police and criminal justice authorities always use this same racist data and produce the same outputs. They are based on the idea of what a â€˜criminalâ€™ is, what their background and profile is, something that in western countries is often tied to ethnic minorities. Anyone who fits this mould is considered a â€˜riskâ€™ and criminalised. The majority of young people profiled by the Top400 and Top600 are minoritised ethnic people, including people with Moroccan or Surinamese heritage, or from neighbourhoods and districts where there are many residents with migrant backgrounds.
I do not agree with the use of these predictive and profiling systems, and I think they should be banned. They are inaccurate and racist, and they label people as criminal, including children, before they have done anything wrong, often just based on their background. This is completely unjust, and we must act before it is too late.
Many groups in Europe have investigated and challenged the use of these harmful data-driven technologies. In the US, where many of these technologies were first implemented, community groups have advocated for and legislated to prohibit predictive policing systems and other invasive surveillance technologies, like facial recognition. We must prohibit them in Europe too.
The AI Act, a law which aims to regulate these types of systems, is currently being considered by the European Parliament. But this proposed law does not go far enough â€” yet. It should ban law enforcement and criminal justice authorities from using these predictive and profiling systems completely, to protect people like my sons from racism and injustice.
Tell you MEP to ban predictive systems in policing and criminal justice here. It takes less than one minute.
[1]https://www.amsterdam.nl/wonen-leefomgeving/veiligheid/top400/
[2]https://www.fairtrials.org/app/uploads/2021/11/Automating_Injustice.pdf
[3]https://www.amsterdam.nl/wonen-leefomgeving/veiligheid/informatie-top600/#h87a00c6d-a600-453e-aa2d-5298a596f56e
--
--
Fair Trials is an international NGO that campaigns for fair and equal criminal justice systems / fairtrials.org

Title: Firebase Dev Summit 2017 Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
After spending a great weekend in Amsterdam and an even better Monday in picturesque towns of Volendam, Zaanse Schans, and Haarlem, on Tuesday I attended the Firebase Summit held at the magnificent concert hall named Muziekgebouw aan â€˜t IJ.
At the entrance I was greeted by the Firebase team with a free ğŸ‘•. Afterwards, together with other Firebasersâ„¢, I had delicious breakfast ğŸ¥ğŸ§€ğŸª and some pitch-black â˜• (there was no milk ğŸ˜). While mingling with other people and strolling through the crowd, I was amazed by diversity of this yearâ€™s Firebase Summit. There were people from all over Europe, with all kinds of backgrounds, and all kinds of problems that Firebase was helping them to solve.
A bit later, doors of the mesmerizing Auditorium opened and the keynote began.
What we could expect from this yearâ€™s summit was presented to us by Sam Ramji, Francis Ma, and Kristen Johnson. There were a lot of new things that we were going to hear more about that day; Firebase Prediction, Firebase Crashlytics, Redesign of the console, new A/B testing framework, and much more.
The day was filled with great sessions, interesting ideas, and general positiveness ğŸ™Œ. In my opinion, the highlight of the summit was the session â€œActionable insights with Firebase Predictionsâ€ held by Jumana Al Hashal and Subir Jhanb. I had a great time being a lab ğŸ and choosing between ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡°, ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡², ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡´, ğŸ‘, ğŸ˜, ğŸ¦….
Firebase Predictions was by far the biggest announcement of the summit. This talk just scratched the surface of this topic and excited oneâ€™s imagination when it comes to all the new and undiscovered things that can be done using this powerful tool.
There were some great things to do between the sessions. You could go to the #AskFirebase lounge and speak with people who were behind all this Firebase magic. There, I had the opportunity to speak with Kat Fang and Jon Mensing about problems and new features of Firebase Android SDK as well as about the future of Firebase in general. Another way to kill the time between the sessions was to play AppShip3000.
Of course, you could go crazy in the photo booth.
After the closing notes, there was a crazy party that I had to miss in order to catch my bus ğŸ˜­. I hope that the next Firebase Summit will be at least as good as this one, and I also hope that I would be able to stay for the party next year.
If you are interested to see in detail what happened at the Firebase Summit 2017, recordings of all the sessions can be found in this playlist.
Thanks for reading! If you enjoyed this story, please click the ğŸ‘ button and share to help others find it! Feel free to leave a comment ğŸ’¬ below.Have feedback? Letâ€™s be friends on Twitter.
--
--

Title: Weekend 2: Amsterdam + Nomads and Awakenings
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I landed in Amsterdam pretty late, and then immediately took the wrong train from the airport. I doubled back and got on the right one, and then when I switched to the aboveground at Lelylaan station, I got on that going the wrong direction too. Thanks to GPS I realized this after just one stop, but once I got on the tram going opposite, my phone died.
I tried to pronounce the name of the stop to the conductor â€” Tramhalte Bilderdijkstraat (De Clercqstraat), and he laughed. He understood vaguely what I was saying, and let me know when we arrived, so I found a shop and they happily let me plug my phone in. They also helped me interpret my upside down google maps and told me where to walk.
Just as I left, a woman walked past me and when I looked at her, she SMILED AT ME.
Iâ€™ve been traveling for two weeks and I admire hundreds of people every day, I really canâ€™t get enough of the diverse beauty and style over here. Whenever someone notices me looking, I give them a big, genuine smile, because I appreciate them! Guess how many people have smiled back? I was absolutely overjoyed when this Dutch stranger grinned at me, and so even though my 15 minute trip from the airport took me over an hour, Amsterdam felt like the place to be already :]
Wendy was house-sitting for her friends who are on honeymoon. She told me to find the apartment by the pink flamingo in the window. Beautiful!
I think the first thing Wendy said to me was â€œso ehm, vodka?â€ I fucking love you Wendy! We had pizza and then her friend Sonja took us to to a special nightclub, MADAM. MADAM is a brand new venue at the top of Aâ€™DAM tower, a 360 degree observation deck, over 100 meters high in a city with an average building height of 30 meters. The view is astonishing. Itâ€™s the former Shell Oil tower, and I remember thinking, what a nice triumph of manâ€™s sheer will over good sense and modesty â€” my my, itâ€™s beautiful.
ADAM stands for Amsterdam Dance and Music, and we danced all night on the beautiful rooftop deck. The DJ put on Mike Dunn, Barbara Tucker, Adonis, all on 7â€³ vinyl which blew me away. Thereâ€™s an observation hole in the middle of the dancefloor, so you can look down and see the ground 100 meters below. Scary!
To get to the tower, we had just followed Sonja by bike, itâ€™s about a 30 minute ride to anywhere from anywhere in Amsterdam and the bike paths are amazingly well maintained. Everyone in Amsterdam rides a bike EVERYWHERE, itâ€™s perfect. Wendy has a super dutch yellow beach cruiser, and it has bars in back and front for passengers.
Wendy was wearing some amazing linen pants which really showed off her perfect bum, her jetpack pants she called them, and a very pretty little Dutch woman in all white told Wendy â€œyou are the most beautiful woman alive, I want to marry you!â€ The rest of the night, the woman kept telling Wendy how horny she made her, and Wendy went, guess Iâ€™m a lesbian tonight!
Thereâ€™s no bridge to ADAM tower, you have to take a ferry, which is full of bikes and scooters. After we danced till about 3am, we left and took the ferry back over for AIR nightclub. Itâ€™s an amazing techno club and has hosted some incredible acts judging by the posters on the walls, but this night was a hip-hop pre-party and after hearing tons of the best house music on earth, you donâ€™t really wanna hear Sean Paul. Wendyâ€™s lover woman came too, and continued to let Wendy know how sexy she is, which I thought was nice of her.
I do love old, sexy hip hop, but I also avoid hip hop clubs because in my admittedly narrow experience people there are aggressive, unfriendly, donâ€™t give too much of a fuck about the music anyway, and are there primarily to get laid.
Itâ€™s okay to want to get laid, but when that is everyoneâ€™s primary motivation for being somewhere, it makes the party shit for everything else. New hip hop also seems to celebrate ridiculous materialism and encourages people to treat others poorly, especially women.
House music celebrates love, inner beauty, helping each other and valuing diversity, and the people who love to go dance house music are amazing because they really seem to embody these attitudes.
We left AIR after about an hour for a gay club called NYX thatâ€™s meant to be incredible, but it was nearly closed when we got there so we went home.
SATURDAY
NOMADS IS THE BOMB!!!! The way itâ€™s been described to me, during Awakenings everyone and their mom comes from all over NL and the world to be one of fifty thousand people in a pitch black tent listening to Richie Hawtin whine, but the lovely people who actually live in Amsterdam get the heck out of the city and get to Nomads.
NOMADS
Wendy and I biked there, it rained lightly on us and took about twenty minutes. We arrived at 4pm and lots of people were chaining up their bikes, but once we got in, there was plenty of beautiful space to dance.
Festival mania is everywhere though, and within an hour the place was fucking PACKED, in the rain!
Robert Owens was jammin, and got on the mic and told us â€˜ainâ€™t nothin but house party baby, youâ€™re in the house with Robert!â€ Embarrassingly enough, I actually didnâ€™t recognize his face at first, and Joppe laughed when I asked who he was. I hate FILAS but Owens had on some pretty nice designer inspired sneakers Iâ€™d never seen before (No Rick).
The festival gave limited edition â€œNomadsâ€ slipmats to all the performers, with their names and some lovely artwork.
Moomin was straight Moomin, I love the guy. We spent a lot of time at his stage dancing, all the stages used d&b audiotechnik line arrays with massive infrabass stacks and the sound was INCREDIBLE. If youâ€™re putting together a club soundsystem, remember, sub harmonics are essential!
I bumped in to my old boy Dieuwer, and Vincent and Joyce from the Midnight City crew who I met exactly a year ago when they hosted thatmanmonkz. If youâ€™re in Amsterdam, look up Midnight City and pray they are doing something while you are around cause their parties are so good!! Itâ€™s very nice to see old friends :]
I also made lots of new friends, as wonderful Dutch people would come up to me up just to dance and talk and they told me about Dutch music, dance culture, fashion, designer drugs, festivals, love, drugs again, etc.
The Lumberjacks in Hell stage was non-stop fury. Marcel Vogel, Mr. Mendel, Rahaan, and Red Greg served up endless, impeccable disco. While Red Greg was playing, Rahaan was standing behind him and going wild at every mix, he couldnâ€™t contain his excitement, and the crowd absolutely fed off of it, everything was perfect.
After Moomin, Nick V, Titia, and Carlos Valdes went back to back. Everyone was wonderful, but every time Carlos came on he was simply next level. Itâ€™s a really interesting thing, DJing, because these guys are playing other peopleâ€™s music, theyâ€™re mostly selectors, but there are intangible qualities which make these guys immediately distinguishable from each other. Itâ€™s like, texture, presence, loudness, and MAGNETISM.
Mike Huckaby did a double take and started laughing when he saw me. Iâ€™d just caught him in Detroit and joked about how Iâ€™ve showed up in the weirdest places on Earth, ever since he took a video after his gig in Barcelona two years ago and I was in the front row getting loose. He was playing in Sicily the next weekend and I would have loved to have made it, but I had to get to Croatia!
SUNDAY
For Awakenings, you get to Amsterdam central station, and then thereâ€™s a shuttle for ten euros (bus #999, gasp!) which takes you fifteen minutes out to an industrial park in the middle of nowhere with some wind turbines. You get off, and then you have to walk about thirty minutes through the wilderness along a path to the festival entrance.
A kid got kicked off the shuttle right when we were about to leave the station, cause he snuck on without a ticket. The security guard took his drink, and then spilled it all over himself trying to throw it away.
I meant to get something to eat at Amsterdam central, but one ATM was broken so the line for the other was like twenty minutes, and by then I didnâ€™t want to waste any more time.
When I got to the entrance and gave my name for the guestlist, they told me I was actually on a paid list, and it would be fifty euro. I said single day tickets are fourty-five euro, what? The other lady behind the counter chimed in and said yeah, but with fees and everything.. I said so whatâ€™s the point of the list? They laughed, and then I paid the fifty euro. I waltzed in and immediately got a â€œpremium hot dogâ€, and then caught some of Damian Lazarus.
The festival grounds are HUGE, and the installations are pretty incredible, but after such a sexy, intimate experience at Nomads where everyone is chatting up everyone, where it feels like family, being lost in anonymity at Awakenings made me feel a bit lonely. Even by yourself at Nomads, the stages are small and you can climb up next to the DJ booth, so you feel like youâ€™re part of something and youâ€™re enjoying the music from the â€œinside.â€
At Awakenings, the stages are twenty feet off the ground, so itâ€™s just a bunch of DJ shows, you squint to see who is playing in most of the tents. There are some nice outdoor stages, I stayed and danced for most of Paco Osunaâ€™s set, and every time there was a big build or something, they shot fire and smoke from the stage.
I bumped in to the lady in all white who asked Wendy to marry her, and she told me that she was still horny. She was with her friends, all laughing hysterically, and she asked me if I like women or men and I said women, so she said letâ€™s hang out, and I said cool, but I had to go get something to eat though, and then we never bumped in to each other again.
I met a friend from Nomads the night before, and she took me with her friends in to the middle of the tent Maceo Plex was playing at. You couldnâ€™t see much, pitch black, techno I didnâ€™t really enjoy, and you just stood in your space and danced. I knew it was a shit question, but I asked a few people if they had ever come SOBER to stand in the middle of this crowd, and just listened to techno and dance silently. Everyone said â€œIâ€™ve never thought about that,â€ which was strange.
After the festival I walked back, through the fields, to the bus, to the tram. Wendy was at Bramâ€™s, and she sent me a photo with directions from her place. We had a drink and I found this place De Skool on Resident Advisor. The headlining DJ had a mix online which was just African drumming.
We got there, and some kids outside told us it was like trippy electro. I asked two guys who were leaving how the party was, and they said â€œitâ€™s shit, mate. they found pills on us and kicked us out. iâ€™d forgot I even had them.
De Skool is amazing. Itâ€™s an old primary school I guess, it has this campy front entrance like where youâ€™d imagine kids would have sat at recess, enormous long empty corridors, a beautiful park in the middle where vines and trees have overgrown the jungle gym, and when you take the stairs down to the dancefloor, the fun really starts. The basement is the size of the entire building, and itâ€™s completely filled with fog, so you can only see a few feet in front of you, but you can tell that off in the distance thereâ€™s music and movement. You walk through the fog like youâ€™re in outer space or something, and then eventually you come upon this insane, sweaty mob of Dutch kids, who happened to be going nuts dancing to acid house. Iâ€™ve never been a huge fan of acid before, and in this context, it was PERFECT, it sounded amazing and Wendy and I had a blast.
love ya Wendy, thanks Sonja, till the next time Amsterdam!
--
--
Ben is an engineer, an optimist about love, a record collector, a poser writer, and a goofy DJ who plays disco everywhere.

Title: From Portugal to the Netherlands
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Weekly blog posts by Creatives from VBAT, on different topics related to Retail, Branding, Packaging, Innovation and Design in and around Amsterdam.

--
Listen
Share
By Rita SilvestreCreative Intern at VBAT
OlÃ¡! Hello!
Iâ€™m Rita Silvestre, Iâ€™m from Porto, Portugal and Iâ€™m a new intern at VBAT. Iâ€™m really passionate about art, design and travelling! The name Rita, derived from Margherita, and Silvestre which means wild, like forest fruits or wild plants.
Two months ago, I graduated in Communication Design at the Fine Arts Faculty in Oporto University (FBAUP). Porto is the city where I was raised and lived until one month ago. Even though Iâ€™ve spent all my life living in Porto, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever get tired of it. From the river side to the beach side, from the little traditional corners of the city centre to the coast, Porto is a heart-warming, welcoming and cosy place. If I were you, I would probably book a flight right now to go there!
Many people ask why I decided to come to the Netherlands and leave such a beautiful country. Portugal is great for sure but not so much when it comes to work opportunities, salariesâ€¦ design and arts arenâ€™t so much recognized as an important work as here (now itâ€™s starting to get betterâ€¦I hopeâ€¦) but yes, our weather and food are amazing.
During my degree, I took part in the Erasmus+ Program and I went to Salford University in Manchester, an amazing experience where I acquired lots of knowledge and experienced a different culture and way of living. During my degree I was involved in many things, highlighting FBAUP Design Inc., a junior company created by students in my university. In this company I could be in touch with the real market, working with clients and developing real projects. I joined this company in my first year and stayed until my fourth year of university. I got the president position and I managed to juggle everything during my Erasmus+ semester in Manchester. Besides that, I was Secretary and Student Representative at Board of Regents in FBAUP, where we could discuss our position as students, our university/infrastructures conditions and what we could change for a better future in FBAUP. I think Porto University gave me the basic design tools but then it didnâ€™t prepare me so well for the outside world. However I am glad I worked at FBAUP Design Inc. and this helped with experience that the university didnâ€™t provide me with, I felt more ready to go out and tackle the world!
Before this internship at VBAT, I did a Summer Internship and a University Internship. I worked for SonaeMC in Porto where I developed all Continente Supermarketâ€™s plastic bags. It was a really good experience being in a huge company, working with different departments and not just within design.
The other internship was in Studio Eduardo Aires, a design studio in Porto that works primarily with editorial, branding and packaging. The studio has a particular design style, really clean, responsive and with a huge importance on detail. I worked in multiple projects, but my main project was developing brochures for the studio, presenting all the projects developed by them, including wine companies like Quinta das MurÃ§as, Porto City Identity, BolhÃ£o Market and so on. These brochures functioned as an individual project portfolio to show to their clients.
I always believed design to improve society and following this I have since always tried to develop projects that can have a message that carries forth into the future. All the projects that I choose to show you are the ones that I felt took me out of my comfort zone. The design field that I feel more comfortable to work in is editorial and typographic but the subject that I enjoy developing is illustration. In high school I specialised in textiles and since that time, Iâ€™m really passionate about textiles and everything surrounding the subject.
In illustration I found my own personal therapy. When Iâ€™m stressed I draw a lot in my sketchbook, mostly people or my routine for example.
Now Iâ€™m really interested to improve my skills in motion graphics and illustration. From this experience at VBAT, I want to learn everything possible, try different disciplines of design like packaging design or animation.
As a textile lover, I try sometimes to step away from the computer and work in traditional and analogue methods. This project is born from a reflection that I wrote about society and the way that people are living, with all the standards that often make us lose our personality and our paths. The main goal was to create images from words. These are three images of the whole project. I used colour and monochrome images that represent a bridge between our reality and our dreams/feelings, sewn to connect them. Even if you try to take the thread out, it will be always marked.
I have always been fascinated with Illustration, but I never invested a lot of time because I didnâ€™t have a lot of self-confidence. These illustrations were my first connection with the subject. I developed a zine about how the world could be, when humans were characters of the animal world. How would be our position and how would we interact with them if our worlds were inverted.
The next is a recent illustration, about the universe but in a way in which a person is recognized as a universe, and a unique individual.
This special work was dedicated for all cerebral palsy people in Porto City with the intention of demonstrating the capacity they have to choose and decide everything themselves. Porto doesnâ€™t have a lot of accessibility or acceptation and there is little incentive to make progress to change this, many people donâ€™t wish to dwell on the subject. With two types of software â€œGRID3â€ and â€œPCEYEâ€, I tracked the eye movements of two cerebral palsy persons during making some decisions on their computer. The movement has been drawn in a lower layout of the software from which I created the sketches and developed them into posters advocating the cause. As an answer to this problem, this posters illustration shows the product of their decisions, proving that it is something they can do.
Slightly closer to my comfort zone, I designed Sunny Sushi. An editorial project design answering to a proposal to make a cookbook according to a design style. I chose Japanese Design and my main goal was to show how sushi can be easy to make, in the same way itâ€™s easy to set an IKEA chair.
Now that you know a little more of me, I present to you Nando, my little desk cactus. He is super kind and gives really good advice. Feel free to say hello to the both of us anytime! Just drop a comment belowâ€¦
Best, Rita
Follow VBAT: Instagram | Facebook |Linkedin |Twitterwritten by Rita Silvestre, Creative Intern at VBATedited by Connie Fluhme, PR at VBAT

Title: Day 1: Heading to Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Iâ€™m starting my 4-weekish adventure today and Iâ€™m still not quite sure if Iâ€™m a excited about it. The thing is: Iâ€™ve been looking forward to this trip for a while now, yet my knees have been acting up lately and Iâ€™m very worried that they might deter me from completing this adventure. But, Iâ€™m just going to give it a try.
Hereâ€™s a quick overview of my current status and what Iâ€™m planning to do: I arrived in Germany on the evening of Saturday, August 3rd. I spent the next day packing my bags and in the evening Iâ€™d invited friends and family to celebrate my 45th birthday. It was a mild summer evening and there were about 20 of us. (Iâ€™m really lucky to have friends who just make time for me at the spur of the moment as Iâ€™d only announced this little gathering few days before.) For the next few weeks, the plan is to cycle from Amsterdam to Budapest (from point A to point B) via Hamburg, Berlin, Dresden, Prague, Vienna and Bratislava. Iâ€™ll be returning via the night train from Vienna.
Today, Monday August 5th, I got up early and headed to the train station bright and early. Another worry, on top of the worry about my knee, had planted itself in my head: while Iâ€™d bought a train ticket to Amsterdam, I didnâ€™t purchase the ticket for my bike. Shit! And my friends last night mentioned that recently theyâ€™ve had a really hard time to get reservations for their bikes. Shit! Itâ€™s so like me to forget essential things like this and it reminds me of what my mom used to tell me: â€œIf your head wasnâ€™t attached to your bodyâ€¦â€ (Speaking of my mom: 5 years ago, when I was starting my bike pilgrimage to Puglia, my mom still bid me goodbye in the morning. Itâ€™s now over two years that sheâ€™s gone and this morning I got a little sentimental about that.) Yet, as much as my head isnâ€™t always working properly, luck usually tends to be on my side and I ended up being able to book a separate bike ticket. Phew!
I know a lot of people dislike the Deutsche Bahn (German Rail) because of severe delays and cancellationsâ€Š, (â€Šnewsflash to my non-German friends: German trains are no longer in sync with stereotypes about my people) but today everything went super smooth! I even arrived in Amsterdam five minutes early and the conductor apologized for this â€œinconvenienceâ€ over the intercom. (Amsterdam is obviously not in Germany but the German Intercity train, originating in Berlin, brought me there.)
From the train station I headed straight to the hotel in a neighborhood called Weesperzijde. The hotel is very trendy: a mixture of hotel, co-working space, cafÃ©/bar and community hub. I feel way too old but the price was right. What surprised me a lot is that the hotel doesnâ€™t have a dedicated bike parking space. I mean: Amsterdam is such a bicycle-friendly city, yet I have to park my bike on the busy street outside the hotel.
After Iâ€™d freshened up, I ventured into the city center with my bike and let myself float through the narrow streets filled with tourists. Turns out it was Pride weekend just yesterday and it was quite a joy seeing the streets and shops still adorned with rainbow flags. This inspired me to mingle with the gays and I looked up where the next gay bar was: I was ready for a refreshing beer. I ended up at a pub called â€œThe Queenâ€™s Headâ€, which was refreshingly retro/vintage and not busy at all. I ended up sitting by the window with a view of the canal. Here, I caught up on messages and started writing this blog.
After a couple pints, I was sufficiently tipsy which led to the terrible decision to have McDonaldâ€™s for dinner. After that, I went back to Weesperzijde, where I sat by the canal and watched the sun set over the typical Amsterdam brick houses.
When I got back to the hotel, I turned into a bitch. I become one of those guests that I hated when I was working in hotels. Hereâ€™s the thing: I was still quite annoyed with the fact that the hotel didnâ€™t have any secure bike parking. As I was about to get into the elevator, I saw a sign â€œbike parkingâ€ and my Sherlock Holmes instincts kicked in. I followed the signs and eventually emerged in a huge bike parking garage. I â€œstormedâ€ to the front desk and asked the clerk if I could park my bike there. â€œNoâ€, he said, â€œ thatâ€™s employee bike parking and we park our rental bikes there.â€ I want to spare you the details of how I blew up, but suffice to say the clerk made an exception for me and allowed me to park my bike in the garage.
Day 2: Amsterdam
--

Title: Strangers in Amsterdam â€” Part 2
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Exactly two years ago, I met my oldest ever friend to date. The name and details of this star have been changed for privacy purposes. However, the memory is deeply etched in my mind forever.
I remember how I felt as I first walked to the bus stop and later as I waited, sat next to her. She reached for my gloves when they fell and handed them to me, a cute smile etched on her wrinkled face. It was early February, the coldest month of the year. The beautifully trimmed lawn glistened with frost, and the air was crisp and cold -3 degrees. I was shivering, feeling super chilly. I noticed she was in a long gray jacket, not wearing any gloves. I was amazed to see her all by herself, timid in some ways, but stronger and mightier with age. Clearly, the latter is just a number.
â€œItâ€™s koud,â€ she smiled and laughed heartily at me as I gloved up and tried to brace my body against the harsh wind.
â€œWat is jouw naam?â€
â€œAstrid. Mijn naam is Astrid,â€ she said adorably.
â€œMijn naam is Apurva.â€ I showed her my travel card to help her better.
â€œApurfaa?â€ she said, her wrinkles stretching with her voice. The skin around her lips moved as she read my name with ease and smiled. A kind one.
â€œHow old are you?â€ I asked in amazement. I normally donâ€™t intrude so much, but I couldnâ€™t help it.
â€œI am 92. I am old and wise,â€ she said, laughing cheerfully. â€œVery wise.â€
â€œOh wow! I am 29.â€
â€œOh, prima!â€
I observed her face closely, the wrinkled lips smudged with red lipgloss that opened to a smile encasing a false tooth set. Her thick hair was fashionably groomed and trimmed into a short bob that covered her head uniformly. The smile was really infectious.
â€œYou look happy. What is the secret to your happiness?â€
â€œI am healthy. I am alive. I have money. I have friends. I have a family. I donâ€™t look happy. I am happy,â€ she said in a kind but bold voice. Her English was perfect.
â€œSo happy to see you. You really made my day today.â€
â€œSo I did something good?â€ she inquired kindly.
â€œYou have no idea.â€
After a moment of silence, I added, â€œI am coming from my therapist.â€
She looked at me intently, a knowing look on her face. She said nothing, but I could swear I saw a small nod of understanding.
â€œAre you working?â€
Bam! She asked me an innocent, totally harmless question. But it was a trigger. Please, no. I will be truthful but answer safely without telling the whole story that I hadnâ€™t accepted myself back then.
â€œI used to. Now I am studying here.â€
â€œDo you live alone?â€
â€œI am married. I live with my husband.â€
Some more smiling. Looking around for the bus which was the reason we were here, we continued to talk.
â€œWhat is your lievelingseten (favorite food)?â€ I had translated the phrase using Google Translate and showed her my phone, because mijn Nederlands is niet zo goed back then.
â€œI eat everything. But I never skip salads. I eat salads every single day,â€ she said matter-of-factly.
â€œHave you always lived here?â€
â€œI have lived here all my life. For 92 years. In Zilver Windstraat.â€
â€œI live in Zilver Windstraat too.â€
â€œWhatâ€™s the huis number?â€
â€œI live in 118.â€
â€œWe are in 20!â€
â€œWow. We are buren (neighbours).â€ She looked really happy now.
â€œEveryone is taking their own car these days. Only one person in each car,â€ she said, pointing at the vehicles passing by as we waited patiently for our bus, grimacing and shaking her head in disagreement.
â€œDo you live alone?â€ Once again, my curiosity got the better of me.
â€œMy second husband died five years agoâ€¦â€ She spoke for a second into the distance, then looked at me briefly, smiling. â€œIt happens, you knowâ€¦â€ with a shrug and half-smile.
â€œI am going to visit a friend who is ill,â€ she continued. She was clutching her cover filled with clinking glasses. She proudly showed me her glass jar collection, filled with onion plants growing at various heights. She mentioned she couldnâ€™t move her left arm much, though that wouldnâ€™t stop her from being strong and getting things done. A trait I admire so much in the native Dutch. They are not made of sugar.
Each time a pair of headlights appeared around the corner, she got excited in the hope of finally getting into the bus. Then, in a matter of nanoseconds, she said, â€œNeeâ€¦â€ as the lights extended into a delivery van or, worse, a truck.
She laughed at a small Canta car waiting timidly by the road, its indicator on.
â€œKlein? (small)â€
â€œKleinâ€¦â€
â€œIk spreek een beetje Nederlands.â€
I showed her the Dutch lessons on my phone. She read a few of them and said, â€œHeel goed!â€ She had excellent eyesight and could read from my poorly backlit, almost-dying iPhone.
â€œWhy donâ€™t you drive a car yourself? You can get around anywhere so easily!â€
â€œNee, my children will not allow it.â€
She kept murmuring bits of Dutch here and there, and I, like a small child pretending to understand, responded with a confident, typical, and lazyâ€¦ â€œJaaaaaâ€¦â€
The bus was late as usual. Typical Dutch public transportation.
â€œI will start walking,â€ I signalled to her that I might leave now, half-heartedly.
â€œI will wait for the bus,â€ she said hopefully, glancing left every time to the corner of the road.
My patience was not the same. â€œI will call a taxi for us and ask the driver to drop you on the way.â€
â€œOh, that is not fair. You will pay for it. Oh noâ€¦!â€
â€œNee, geen probleem! It is totally fine. Where do you want to go?â€
â€œZiekenhuis Amstelland.â€ Then, after a pause, she added, â€œYou should come home for a coffee one day.â€
â€œI would have visited anyway. I donâ€™t need any favor returned.â€ I added, kindly.
She probably only heard the word visited. That registered as a yes, and she beamed happily.
I called an Uber. Hafez would arrive in two minutes. That was quick.
In no time, we scrambled into the old KIA. The driver greeted us in Dutch. Astrid took charge and converses fluently with Hafez, a kind man from South Africa. He proceeded to drive us toward her stop, barely 5 minutes away.
By mistake, Astrid poked her finger into the glass screen separating the driver from the passengers. It was so invisibly clean that she hadnâ€™t noticed it. She chuckled to herself for a while. The glass now bore a small fingerprint mark.
â€œNoooâ€¦â€ Ans wailed, looking lost and a bit down when Hafez took a wrong turn at the roundabout.
â€œNo, itâ€™s okayâ€¦ You can tell him where you want to go. He will drop you there.â€
Hafez quickly corrected his route and dropped Astrid off exactly where she wanted to go.
As she was getting out of the car, she looked at me and said, â€œDank je wel. Coffee is waiting for you,â€ with a wink and a twinkle in her eyes. She turned and walked away.
Hafez continued driving toward my destination.
â€œIs she your family?â€ he asked, peering through the rearview mirror.
â€œNo, I just met her at the bus stop half an hour ago.â€
â€œYou did a really kind thing there.â€
I rushed to the nearest cafÃ© after finishing my errand. I had to jot down this incident before it faded from my ever-busy, memory-laden mind.
Coffee is waiting for youâ€¦
She didnâ€™t look old â€” not one bit. So precious. She still had the fire of youth burning inside her, fighting within her. She made me feel hopeful.
As she wakes up every morning to another beautiful day in her life, I wondered what kept her going so positively.
Does she see each day as a blessing or another hurdle to pass?She probably knows her loved ones are waiting for her. That she will meet them when her time comes.But until then, she must go onâ€¦
I couldnâ€™t stop the flow of words as I furiously scribbled into my Remarkable, all while holding and pushing my almost-filled bladder to a dangerous extent.
While the incident replayed itself on a loop in my mind, one question bothered me the most.
Was her hair brown or blonde?
I couldnâ€™t recall anymore.
PS: I wanted to simply meet her again after a few months. And I did. This time, with my husband and some flowers. We rang the bell downstairs, hoping against hope that she would remember me. She answered, took the lift, and promptly came down to meet us, her face lighting up when she saw me. Dressed smartly, she took the flowers and went back up, inviting us over another time.
That was a year and a half ago. I tried multiple times to ring her bell again, but there was no answer. We really hope she is still happy and cheerful, wherever she is.
--
--
2
Chronicling life's journey one scribble at a time! https://www.apurvadivakaran.com
