Title: Itâ€™s a (Testing) trap! â€” Vue Amsterdam Conference 2022 Summary series â€” Sixth Talk
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Welcome! Happy to see you in the sixth part of my Vuejs Amsterdam Conference 2022 summary series, in which I share a summary of all the talks with you.
You can read my JSWorld Conference 2022 Summary series (in four parts) here, where I summarized all the first dayâ€™s talks. You can also find the previous Talks of the Vue Amsterdam conference 2022 in my blog.
After two and a half years, JSWorld and Vue Amsterdam Conference were back in Theater Amsterdam between 1 and 3 June, and I had the chance to attend this conference for the first time. I learned many things, met many wonderful people, spoke with great developers, and had a great time. On the first day the JSWorld Conference was held, and on the second and third days, the Vue Amsterdam.
The conference was full of information with great speakers, each of whom taught me something valuable. They all wanted to share their knowledge and information with other developers. So I thought it would be great if I could continue to share it and help others use it.
At first, I tried to share a few notes or slides, but I felt it was not good enough, at least not as good as what the speaker shared with me. So I decided to re-watch each speech, dive deeper into them, search, take notes and combine them with their slides and even their exact words in their speech and then share it with you so that what I share with you is at least at the same level as what I learned from them.
Everything you read during these few articles is the result of the effort and time of the speaker itself, and I have only tried to learn them so that I can turn them into these articles. Even many of the sentences written in these articles are exactly what they said or what they wrote in Slides. This means if you learn something new, it is because of their efforts. (So if you see some misinformation blame them, not me, right? xD)
Last but not least, I may not dig into every technical detail or live codings in some of the speeches. But if you are interested and need more information, let me know and Iâ€™ll try to write a more detailed article separately. Also, donâ€™t forget to check out their Twitter/Linkedin.
Here you can find the program of the conference:
www.jsworldconference.com
Ramona Schwering â€” Software developer at shopware
â€œItâ€™s a trapâ€ â€” a call or feeling we all might be familiar with, not only when it comes to Star Wars. Itâ€™s signalizing a sudden moment of noticing imminent danger.
This situation is an excellent allegory for an unpleasant realization in testing. Imagine having the best intentions when it comes to testing, but still ending up with tests failing to deliver you any value at all?
Tests who are feeling like a pain to deal with?
When writing frontend tests, there are lots of pitfalls on the way.
In sum, they can lead to lousy maintainability, slow execution time, and â€” in the worst-case â€” tests you cannot trust.
But it doesnâ€™t have to be that way. In this session, Ramona will talk about developersâ€™ common mistakes. And of course, on how to avoid them. Testing doesnâ€™t need to be painful, after all.
You might be sure that testing has many perks and advantages, but all of those wonderful things can be out shadowed by pain points caused by various reasons. All the things you did with the best intentions but in the long run or even earlier they turned out painful or exhausting.
For example, slow tests can kill the fun. Imagine you have your pull request and you want it to be merged, but you need to wait hours or maybe days for the pipeline to finally be completed.
Even worse are tests that are painful to maintain. You think about your past self and you ask: What did you do with this test? What was the purpose?! What did you think about that one? Or other team members who are asking you questions about what you did in the past and you have no clue.
But the worst pain point is those tests that give you new value and result because they are flaky. You have a build that sometimes passes and sometimes fails and you did nothing in between.
It doesnâ€™t have to be this way. One of the most important mindsets and golden rules in JavaScript testing best practices is Simple.
Tests should be designed plain and simple in every case. In unit tests, integration tests, and End to End tests, keep it stupid simple.
Our goal should be that one is capable to understand your test and get its intent instantly without thinking about it.
Try to aim for a flat test design, which means only testing as much as needed and using few to no abstractions at all.
Letâ€™s look at the first Trap.
It should throw an error if the deprecated plugin is in use.
When you look at the title â€” should throw an error â€” you donâ€™t know what it wants to accomplish. But the Golden rule says you should know instantly what itâ€™s doing.
We can make it more comprehensible with the â€œThree-Part Ruleâ€. The test title should contain three things:
With this rule in mind, this is what our test will look like:
The next Trap can be the test structure:
In this case, declarations, actions, and assertions are written all over the place without any clear structure. Especially in bigger tests, this can be a huge pain. We can make it more structured with AAA Pattern. You divide your test into three parts:
This is what our test looks like with AAA Pattern:
This looks much better!
But there is a problem. Think back to our test case. It is a context menu and it is hidden by default. So we need to open it to interact with it. But it means we need to do an assertion to make sure that itâ€™s open before the act. Doesnâ€™t it destroy the pattern?
If we are testing the DOM, we sometimes need to check the before and after states. So Letâ€™s take a look at this pattern from another perspective.
This is a pattern taken from behaviour driven development: Given â€” When â€” Then
Our prior test with the usage of this pattern:
Avoid using placeholders and use realistic naming as much as possible.
If you donâ€™t want to come up with thousands of names, maybe you can use faker or other tools to generate some dummy data, or if itâ€™s okay with the laws and your project, import it from the production state. Just make sure that your test stays comprehensible and easy to read and that you know what it does.
Letâ€™s take a look at the same test for the next trap, which is selectors.
If you refactor your application and change some classes â€” which is common â€” this could cause your test to fail, and in this case, the test failing without a bug present in your app â€” which is called a false negative giving no reliable report of your app because itâ€™s not broken, just your implementation changed.
Look at selectors you must! In other words, you shouldnâ€™t test implementation details. Instead, think about using things a user would call attention to and navigating your application. For example some text inside your page. Even better, use selectors which are not that prone to change, like data attributes. You can even call it for example for cypress data-cy=â€submitâ€ so one instantly know that it is meant for testing.
Last but not least, donâ€™t use fixed waiting times.
On one hand, that can slow down your test way too much if a test case will be executed so many times. It can be even worse when your application is being used on weaker hardware. In this case, you may need more than that fix 500ms.
There are some solutions for that, for example waiting for the changes in the UI, like a for loading spinner to disappear or an animation to stop or something to appear.
Or even better, wait for API Requests and Responses.
Tests are there as an assistant to you, not a hindrance. They should feel like a routine not like solving a complex mathematical formula.
I hope you enjoyed this part and it can be as valuable to you as it was to me.
Here you can find the next talk about animations.
--
--
Full-stack Web Developer

Title: Explore the Legacy of Amsterdam: Travel Recs for the History Girlies
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
In the mornings, there was still a slight chill in the air despite it being late June. In Amsterdam, the sun came up too early and went back down too late, and I was struggling to adjust to this new sleep schedule. By the time the sun went down completely at ten or eleven at night, it would be hours until I felt tired enough to actually sleep, and still would be up too early for comfort. This routine heavily affected my circadian rhythm.
Despite being the worldâ€™s sleepiest girl in Amsterdam, I could enjoy the slow living that the Dutch are accustomed to. I took long walks in the mornings around the canals, listened to Dutch language lessons while wandering residential neighborhoods, and got to explore the history of the quiet, bustling town I would definitely visit again.
For travelers obsessed with history like I am, Amsterdam is a place steeped in stories and lives you will love to learn from. Hereâ€™s some of my favorite places in Amsterdam to experience the legacy of â€œVenice of the North.â€
--
--
Educator & writer exploring history, travel, & culture abroad. Based in Barcelona, weaving past & present into stories that inspire & inform.

Title: Lost in Amsterdam
Content:

Sign up
Sign in

Travel publication for everything from travel tips to personal travel tales, grab a latte and join the journey around the globe with us!

Member-only story
--
10
Share
I walked into a cafe that looked unlike any other cafe I had visited.
Endless Moroccan lamps hanging from the ceiling, and strategically placed mirrors reflecting the lamps gives you an awe moment upon first stepping in to Lost in Amsterdam.
The bar was just gleaming with sparkling glasses hanging from the ceiling wine rack with brass and rich wood everywhere.
Candles provided an extra welcoming warmth.
I grabbed a U-shaped booth table covered in Moroccan cushions with lanterns and candles behind me. Even the ashtray next to the candle illuminated an exotic glow on my table.
I was travelling alone to Amsterdam, and I sat across from the bar to not feel so awkward. Besides itâ€™s was such a stunning vibe that I could spend hours just relaxing in that comfortable booth.
I ordered my drink, an amazing margarita, although they are famous for their milkshakes, with and without alcohol.

Title: Sunset in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
3
Share
Amsterdam, the Venice of the North. Risen from reclaimed marshland. The city of Rembrandt. The city with the harbor and the cruise ships. The port where the crowds buzz like a beehive. The city where dormant changes can suddenly rear their heads. The city with once the beating Jewish heart. Where once Jewish life flourished and vibrated. The heart brought to a halt by betrayal and murder.
I am sitting on a quiet terrace opposite the Museum Square, right next to Museum Square the Concertgebouw. The sun slowly begins to draw melancholy shadows from people and buildings. The birds of the city migrate over to find a safe roost in one of the surrounding parks. The cars, streetcars and cyclists roll silently by. The rush to be home is marked on the faces.
Amsterdam pulls up to the dinner table. People passing by carry with them a variety of food. Above them the hungry faces. The restlessness of the end of the workday is almost palpable. People and the city are getting ready for the coming evening and night. The poverty of the city is also visible in the form of vagrants, begging and trying to scrape together some money to get something to eat.
The terrace where I am sitting is not full. I like watching people. An sich, man is an evolutionary marvel. The Museum Square I am looking at is lined with museums: the Stedelijk, the Van Gogh, the Moco and a little furtherâ€¦
--
--

Title: Speciality Coffee in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Once you start buying beans from a speciality coffee roaster, there is no turning back. For some people the taste of speciality coffee is not like coffee and more like some aromatic tea. Some might not enjoy with this. Because the big coffee chains(hint: Starbucks) and supermarkets coded that burned taste into our tongues. They do this because they cannot sell as fresh as local roasters do and they have to sell the same consistent taste which is the burned coffee taste in this case.
(Originally posted on https://uludagcan.com/2023/01/13/speciality-coffee-in-amsterdam/)
But coffee can have multiple different flavors. There could be multiple factors that affects flavor of the beans such as where the bean grown, other plants around the coffee farm, drying methods and roasting processes. Thatâ€™s why you can see different tasting notes on the packaging of a speciality coffee product. Which is something great. Losing all these with over roasting is a huge shame.
Itâ€™s not cheap. We should admit that. Coffee is an expensive commodity and getting expensive each year. Due to that we can see the reflection on the prices. If you compare a cup of filter coffee or latte price at a speciality coffee house with the big coffee chain, you can see itâ€™s much more expensive at coffee roasters. Or if you compare 500g bag of coffee bean at a supermarket with the bag at roasters, again you can see the price differences. That comes from the quality and the effort that put into quality grown coffee. Those roasters cannot access coffee with cheap prices like big chains. Because of that they have to reflect it into prices. And the coffee farmers are the ones that suffer the most and earn the least in this equation. According to Moyee Coffee, 90% of the total coffee value disappears into the pockets of a handful of large multinationals, which we call Big Coffee. This means that the coffee farmers are left with only 10% of the value. Itâ€™s even worse, because there is nothing is added to this valueâ€“ only 2% of that amount is actual profit. So if you consider all, itâ€™s actually not that expensive.
Netherlands ruined the word â€œcoffeeshopâ€ for me. It is used to be one of my favorite word. â€œGoing to coffeeshopâ€, â€œworking from coffeeshopâ€, â€œgetting a takeaway latte from a coffeeshopâ€. I was using the word excessively. But â€œcoffeeshopâ€ means â€œdrug storeâ€ in the Netherlands. If you ask anyone on the road for the nearest coffeeshop, they will show you the place where you can smoke some weed and get high. So now itâ€™s â€œcoffee houseâ€. Or with a bit more hipster way, â€œcoffee roasterâ€. Iâ€™m getting used to it. If you are visiting Netherlands, especially Amsterdam and if your intention is not the drugs, keep that it in mind ğŸ˜‰
Amsterdam has a really good coffee scene. There are many good quality coffee roasters and coffee houses around. I think itâ€™s one of the two best speciality coffee cities in Europe. The other one is definitely Berlin. During my last two years in the Netherlands I created a list of my favorite coffee houses and roasters. Of course these are not all of them. Itâ€™s impossible to list all but these are mostly the ones that I visited and bought coffee. The ones that I enjoy and suggest with wholeheartedly.
Iâ€™m a bit biased with Bocca to be honest. Itâ€™s my first coffee roaster that I met in Amsterdam and the first one that I buy coffee beans. Even before moving to the Netherlands I bought beans from them. But objectively, they are one of the top coffee roasters in Amsterdam. Coffee is great and their store has a great atmosphere in the heart of the Netherlands. They also have great workshops for people who wants to dive into coffee brewing or making latte art. I took one of them and it was a great experience. Bocca is also selling many coffee making equipments. Even some unique tools like GINA Smart Brewer.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/tuQaThyreSvg8scU8
Even though I havenâ€™t sit and drunk coffee that much at the store, Lot61 is the roaster that I buy most of my beans for home brewing alongside with Bocca. I like the taste of roasting profile and also I found it the best value for money. Their regular blend coffee beans are perfect match for my daily filter coffee machine routine and espresso beans have rich, and bold taste.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/zSjNP1L5kDxkAgqd7
I cannot stress enough how much I like this place. They donâ€™t have their own roasted beans as far as I know. Last time I checked beans were coming from Berlin. But this cafe has small, cozy and warm vibe. Located very close to my favorite street Haarlemmerdijk. With good coffee, nice desserts, foods and hipster people profile, itâ€™s a lovely place. If you are around, definitely stop by Toki.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/8yfFc2qDWeH8vbWf7
Shining star of Bos en Lommerweg. This cafe was one minute walking distance away from my old house in Amsterdam. It was a great location for me to go and takeaway a coffee then walk in Westerpark. I always loved the vibe of FUKU. Nice cafe, good latte and tasty bites. And I know the name sounds like the F@$! word.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/EjcU18pEVL4hZ56V8
Another place where you can find good coffee at west. In between two beautiful parks of Amsterdam, Erasmus and Rembrandt park. I havenâ€™t bought coffee online from them for a while but I was happy with the coffee when I do. What I also like is the cozy interior space.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/Xt7CKBn6xQZPiF1CA
Iâ€™ve been into the store where located in Weteringstraat. Although I donâ€™t have strong opinions about the coffee at Back to Black, I liked the interior. Nice place to hang with friends. Take a cup of latte, eat a croissant, read your book and give some love to the cat that sleeps on the chair.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/a1LoUeBMcAknSyam7
Usually I search on maps before finding a new coffee roaster. But sometimes I just come across a cafe while walking on the streets of Amsterdam. Rum Baba is one of them. I was so happy when I find this roaster. Their colorful interior and delicious beans makes this place a great coffee house. There was not enough space to sit but since itâ€™s located on beautiful Elandsgracht, itâ€™s even better to take a cup coffee from there and walk in Amsterdam. I also recently learned that they have walk-in workshops. Keep following for new ones.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/B92xfJ3PSAYDQ81HA
Do you want Fika in Amsterdam? Then Scandinavian Embassy can be a right place for you. It has spacious and cozy interior. As you might imagine delicious Swedish desserts like cinnamon rolls and cakes. Combine it with coffee and relax. Location is also great. Near Sarphatipark and close to Albert Cuypmarkt.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/WmLKS5T6ZvTEWxvg8
This is another coffee house that I discovered randomly while riding my bike on the crazy traffic of bike lanes. Immediately loved the place. During my visit I enjoyed reading one of the Standart magazine on the shelf and drank my coffee. I remember that I liked the â€œpastel de nataâ€ tart that they serve. Good coffee companion.Location: https://goo.gl/maps/G6zpFncywpMj8RWU9
Almost every month, there is a transaction on my bank account for coffee beans. Itâ€™s one of my fixed costs. Since itâ€™s an expensive purchase, I look for the best value for my money. Along with coffee quality, the smooth online shop experience is also important for me. After trying multiple online stores, I decided on these four roasters for now. Bocca Coffee, Lot61, Wakuli, Manhattan Coffee Roasters. All have good online stores and delivery options. In terms of coffee, I canâ€™t say one is way better than the other but if you want me to pick two favorites, Bocca Coffee and Manhattan Coffee Roasters are the best. But also the most expensive ones. So not every month I can buy from them. I usually distribute my purchases amongst all four of these stores. By the way, I need to mention that Manhattan Coffee Roasters is not from Amsterdam. They are based in Rotterdam. Even though this guide is about Amsterdam, I have to mentioned their excellent quality beans. They are only online store and no cafe to visit so it suits my online buying section. I strongly advise to try.
Among those four, Wakuli is a bit different. They have the best subscription model and best price to be honest. You can easily start your subscription based on your preferred frequency. Weekly, bi-weekly or monthly itâ€™s up to you. If you have too much coffee at home, just skip next delivery. Or suddenly you ran out of coffee, then request for an emergency batch. And if you want to pause your delivery for a while, itâ€™s very easy and convenient to do that. Beautiful online shop, smooth experience. And it combined with good coffee. I highly suggest if you are looking for a coffee subscription service that you can manage based on your budget and schedule.
Of course there are more coffee houses and roasters in Amsterdam. Also in other cities like Utrecht, Rotterdam or Den Haag in the Netherlands. But these are just the ones I experienced and suggest without any hesitation. Please let me know if you know other coffee roasters in the Netherlands. Maybe we can update the guide next year.
--
--
Mobile developer | Former Co-Founder @ Peakode | Coffee geek | Street photography lover | https://uludagcan.com/me/

Title: Donâ€™t let your fear hold you back-one year in Amsterdam.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

My journey as a human being.

--
5
Listen
Share
â€œAre you driven by fear, or passion?â€
August marks the first year since I moved to Amsterdam to begin a new chapter in both my life and career. Reflecting on this journey has brought a flood of complex emotions. Everything seemed to happen in a flash â€” what began as chaos has gradually settled into a rhythm. Now, having gone through the full cycle of ups and downs, I finally know what to expect, both in life and at work.
â€œEverything happens for a reason.â€
I feel fortunate that, in June, a friend shared her experience with spiritual response therapy. After trying it myself, I noticed a significant shift in my energy, and more positive things began to flow into my life.
One of the first changes I noticed was at work, where I became more proactive and positive by making small adjustments in my approach.
While the typical practices â€” like meditation, reading, working out, and cold showers â€” have proven their value to many, myself included, Iâ€™ve found it essential to switch things up from time to time to keep things fresh and inspiring. So, hereâ€™s my updated morning routine
Beyond adjusting my routine, Iâ€™ve experienced a mental shift in how I approach work.
Work will never be done, but people and events come and go.
Inspired by one of my colleagues, Iâ€™ve started making an effort not to skip fun events when they appear on my calendar. Attending these has brought some wonderful moments, like being part of the biggest social event at my company.
â€œWhat are you afraid of? Donâ€™t let your fear hold you back.â€- one of my fav leaders said to me.
I now wanted to cry hahahah as I feel so lucky that Iâ€™ve met lots of incredible people that show me care and warmth and support.
Outside of work, Iâ€™ve also learned valuable lessons from personal relationships:
Hey, so, are you driven by fear or passion now?
Alrighty, a quick reflection.
If you are reading, applauses and comments can encourage me to share more my personal journey! :)
--
--
5
My journey as a human being.
Hi there :) I'm from Taiwan and moved to Amsterdam in 2023 to experience a different life. I write about my journey and reflections on work and life.

Title: Amsterdam-No car, no license, no problem
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I am finishing up a 3 month stint mostly living in Amsterdam as my mobility startup, Iomob completes our participation in the smart cities themed Techstars accelerator here. As a smart cities and mobility guy I have always paid attention to Amsterdamâ€™s efforts to be a smarter more liveable city, led in part by their CTO Ger Baron seek to blend tech-driven and citizen led approaches to transform itself.
After arriving I heard about Swapfiets which offers a bike as a service on a monthly subscription plan (less than 20 euros per month). Swapfiets has a booming business with more than 100,000 current subscribers. I was surprised to learn that many locals have even switched to SwapFiets since they offer full service of the bike included in the plan. I have found cycling around this city and the outlying areas with a great network of dedicated cycling lanes and amazing parks to be an awesome experience.
Having just finished a 24km bike ride out to the Ajax stadium and back to my apartment I began to reflect more on my time in Amsterdam and what life has been like in this bike-centric city and what it means for Iomob too.
While my American friends are still in shock that I havenâ€™t had a drivers license since I moved to Barcelona in 2015, I have not even noticed the lack of â€œindependenceâ€. On the contrary, living and working in Europe, I find owning and driving a car to be more of a burden than a benefit. Obviously I am not alone as the younger generation has been flocking to alternatives to car ownership in big ways, as this graphic from CBInsights demonstrates.
We have counted at least 22 different mobility services in Amsterdam across taxi and ridehailing, micromobility and public transit. This includes 13 micromobility services and scooter sharing services like Bird and Lime have not even arrived here yet as the city works to establish the regulatory environment for them.
Much has been made of Amsterdamâ€™s incredibly bike-friendly culture and the fact there are more bikes in this city than people. However, as my urbanist colleague Brent Toderian has expressed, there is an under-appreciated part of the story here which is how the city has helped transform itself from a car-dependent culture to a haven for cyclists through a range of strategies including an amazing array of dedicated cycling lanes, growing bike parking services and gradually decreasing the opportunity for driving and parking cars in the city center (e.g. last night I met another founding team from Techstars at a hopping food court with underground, free parking for bikes, but no parking for cars). Recently the city announced plans to remove 1100 parking spaces from the city center per year until 15,000 are removed.
Amsterdam could do more to promote this switch of course. I believe they need to further expand the non-car paths to support dedicated paths for different modes of personal mobility. For example many bike paths allow for motorized mopeds to share the paths with cyclists. A city like Amsterdam should continue to lead by supporting dedicated bike paths, dedicated cycling paths and dedicated micromobility vehicles (electric bikes, scooters, etc.).
And the city needs to embrace Mobility as a Service (MaaS) by supporting seamless access to those 22 and counting mobility services through one app which allows residents and visitors to route, book and pay for any of the mobility services in a simple intuitive way. This will further support the cityâ€™s shift from personal car dependence to greener shared and electric mobility services.
Yet, coupled with its vibrant arts, creative and entrepreneurial scene, Amsterdam is poised to become a leading light in the European smart cities scene through its innovative approach to embracing more active, less contaminating forms of mobility. This will help attract more innovators and urban entrepreneurs in the coming decades. Of course to do that, they will have to figure out there serious housing shortage and embrace co-living as promoted by another Techstars startup in our program, Kndrd.
About us:Iomob is working to decentralize and build the Internet of Mobility, by incentivizing and facilitating the use of alternative transport. By using the blockchain, iomob plans to minimize fees and allow mobility providers and end-users alike to connect on a peer-to-peer basis. In their own words: Iomob is â€œa system which produces a useful output at the lowest possible marginal cost.â€
Learn more about Iomob by connecting with us:
--
--
Boyd is a researcher and entrepreneur in smart, sustainable & entrepreneurial cities, HeÂ´s authored 3 books & is CEO of IoMob. boydcohen.impress.ly

Title: Techiesâ€™ meetup groups in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

random stories of my life

--
Listen
Share
I moved to Amsterdam two months ago. In the first weeks, I asked on twitter what meetup groups I should know in Amsterdam. I was mainly interested in tech, infrastructure, SRE, DevOps related topics. It got quite a few responses from the people in the area. I thought â€œwhy not collecting them in a blog post?â€
Thanks to all who helped me to compose this list by responding to my tweet. Hope to meet you sometime in the future at one of the events!
This is a list in no particular order. It is basically in the order of the responses I got. I am sure you will find the ones you like. :)
Software Circus
There are ~4K people in the group. Only for Feb; I see three evenings planned already! From their about page:
We are a motley crew of dreamers who are unhealthily obsessed with consuming information and changing ourselves and those around us. We love software, tech and anything (from any discipline) that is going to change the world. Apart from our wider focus, we believe that meetups should be a lot of fun where laughing out loud and meeting new people is built in, not an opt-in extra.
Docker Randstad
A lot of people in the group again!
Learn, Collaborate & Dockerize! Meet other developers and ops engineers in your community that are using and learning about Docker. Docker is an open platform that helps you build, ship and run applications anytime and anywhere. Developers use Docker to modify code and to streamline application development, while operations gain support to quickly and flexibly respond to their changing needs. Docker ensures agility, portability and control for all your distributed apps.
Meetinâ€™up at Picnic
Picnic is the company I work for. ğŸ¤“ It is an online supermarket who delivers groceries to your door in a sustainable way. Picnic has a meetup group that holds regular meetups in their office.
Interested in the latest technologies, sharing your passion for code, ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» or just looking for some drinks, ğŸº food, ğŸ• and good company? Youâ€™ve come to the right place! We host regular talks on all things programming with in-house speakers, in our offices, with our very own bar tap and kitchen. What else could you be asking for? ğŸ˜‰
Continuous Delivery Amsterdam
Looks like Amsterdamâ€™s meetup groups are huge!
This Group will bring software people together to share ideas and experience in the domain of Continuous Delivery. Continuous Delivery addresses the entire software delivery pipeline â€” from CI to testing to deployment to release â€” and addresses technology, process and organization. Anything within that domain will be in scope for our Group.
DevOps Amsterdam
Of course, there is one DevOps meetup group in Amsterdam. Surely, I will join them soon!
Bringing together developers and operations people united in a common goal: destroy silos and remove obstacle to deploy and maintain awesome software and reliable infrastructures. Monitoring, continuous integration, packaging and automated deployment will all be covered. Itâ€™s going to be fun too!
PyLadies Amsterdam
Hi PyLadies! ğŸ‘‹
We are a local chapter of PyLadies, we exist to promote diversity and inclusivity in the Python community.
What we do differently:â€¢ we use a hands-on approach: workshops, group discussions, talks about practical experience, mentorshipâ€¢ we go in-depth with one subject per eventâ€¢ we provide a safe community space for marginalized genders who is interested in Pythonâ€¢ we welcome members of all Python proficiency levels
Amsterdam.rb
The Amsterdam based monthly Ruby meetup! http://amsrb.org /@amsrb (https://twitter.com/amsrb)
Dutch Kubernetes/Cloud-Native Meetup
Meet other developers and users of Kubernetes. Kubernetes is Cloud Native Computing Foundationâ€™s orchestrator for containers at scale. It handles scheduling onto nodes in a compute cluster and actively manages workloads to ensure that their state matches the users declared intentions; runs on any cloud and any hardware. Any skill level is welcome; weâ€™re all new to Kubernetes and we want to create an open, welcoming environment for other Cloud Natives.
Elastic User Group NL
This group is for anyone interested in the Elastic open source projects (Elasticsearch, Kibana, Logstash, and Beats, http://www.elastic.co/products) and related topics. We cover search, logging, analytics & data visualization. We welcome talks on any aspect of data exploration.
Nulab Tech Talks Amsterdam
A series of events dedicated to all things tech. With subjects ranging from web development to Artificial intelligence and generative art, the aim of this Meetup group is to bring forward different technologies, perspectives and discourses from industry experts and passionate makers.
Site Reliability Engineering Amsterdam
This meetup is for everyone interested in SRE. We want to share what is SRE and how it fits into the DevOps way of working. How is reliability defined?Why is it an essential aspect of your IT landscape? We will share experiences and ways to integrate reliability in your application design and architecture.
.NET / dotnet Amsterdam meetup
Weâ€™re an Amsterdam based user group, with talks and events aimed at .NET developers. If youâ€™re a developer from Amsterdam, visiting Amsterdam or live close by Amsterdam, then it would be great to see you at one of our meetups.
This group will hopefully provide a hub for Amsterdamâ€™s diverse and thriving developer community to exchange ideas and keep up to date with the latest movements and shifts in software development.
DevSecOps â€” Netherlands
This meetup group is for anyone interested in securing a software development lifecycle (DevSecOps). To deliver secure innovations and shift security left, organizations must commit to changes in skills, culture, technology and processes.
AmsterdamPHP
A english-speaking group for PHP Developers in and around Amsterdam. Our goal is to grow the local community, search for new developers and spread knowledge and resources.
Amsterdam is a very active technology center for the Netherlands, many companies and people from various countries have chosen this area to settle down and start their companies. PHP has a big role in this and for that reason we created a User Group focused on this area and in doing activities in english to acommodate all of these developers.
GOTO Nights Amsterdam
GOTO Nights are free community events brought to you by the GOTO Conference team. GOTO runs Software Developer Conferences each year in four international cities â€” Amsterdam, Berlin, Copenhagen and Chicago.
Tech topics we are passionate about include Programming Languages and Frameworks (mostly back-end), Event-Driven Architecture, Microservices, Machine Learning, AI (& society), The Human Factor of Tech and IoT to name a few.
PyData Amsterdam
PyData is an educational program of NumFOCUS, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization in the United States. PyData provides a forum for the international community of users and developers of data analysis tools to share ideas and learn from each other. The global PyData network promotes discussion of best practices, new approaches, and emerging technologies for data management, processing, analytics, and visualization. PyData communities approach data science using many languages, including (but not limited to) Python, Julia, and R.
Certainly, there are still plenty of meetups that I havenâ€™t heard of. Feel free to answer to this post, I will gladly add them to the list. :)
Cheers,
Busra
--
--
random stories of my life
Note from 2025: A lot changed in my life but I'd like to keep this blog as it is. I now do my own thing called Humans in Systems. Find me at humansinsystems.com

Title: What did I learn at Employer Branding Day 2023 Amsterdam?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
They say never quit chasing the dream!
After two years of effort, I finally could be part of the worldâ€™s largest gathering of employer branding professionals organised by Brett Mitchingtonâ€™s Employer Branding College in Amsterdam (one of my favourite cities).
Employer and Talent Branding is ever-evolving, and the best way to learn is to connect with practitioners. After attending the conference yesterday, I could say this was worth investing time, money and effort. What a brilliant showcase of amazing case studies (no gyaan) of varied organisations and passionate EB professionals. Hereâ€™s a run-down on few of the key learnings I could share with you.
ASML Presentation: Collaboration is key
Nanci (Global Head of Employer Brand at ASML) shared the importance of collaboration in employer branding. While she sat in the comms function, she talked about her work with HR, business, internal comms and brand teams to be successful. Over 10k employees participated in the EVP process, and her key KPIs were brand strength/survey (Universum). She also showcased a good example of an internal career fair as a way to strengthen the brand internally.
Takeaways â€” 1) Collaboration 2) Measure against Key objective. 3) EB is a team play
Activision Blizzard Presentation: Get strategic yet creative
Activision Blizzardâ€™s presentation took us back to building a solid EB vision. Alex and Briana spoke about aligning it for the leadership and business objectives to people strategy. Employee advocacy is all about education, community, resources and gamification. The team shared the breakdown of their content elements and urged the community to build insights around what kind of content works for which TG.
An awesome example of creativity â€” Activision put in an in-game recruitment advertising. Makes sense since a lot of their users may be target candidates. Smart!
Lego Presentation: Playful and Employee driven
Legoâ€™s iconic brand still needed to build an employer brand targeted to the candidates. I loved their brand framework, which clarifies the overall brand strategy. Their EB team also creates various infographics/assets shared with the recruiters for candidate experience. Clicks from the Bricks program attracted user-generated content, which always attracts better engagement than corporate photos.
The crux for me was how aligned their employer brand was to the heart of what Lego stands for. Playful and fun! Kudos to Andrew and Sarah.
Indeed and Glassdoor: Well-Being Score
In the last few years, well-being has become integral to employee experience. Indeed has launched a new well-being score on employersâ€™ profiles, which assigns the scores based on employee reviews regarding Happiness, Purpose, Satisfaction and Stress-free experience. It provides a clear view to candidates if the organisation priortizes well-being and employees resonate with the promise.
More information â€” â€‹â€‹https://www.indeed.com/employers/work-wellbeing
Kaufland Romania: Innovation and Differentiation in EB
Esteraâ€™s presentation was truly differentiated as she passionately discussed diversity, inclusion and equity as part of employer branding. Beyond having created an ACCESS program to hire differently-abled talent, they hosted a hackathon to create an app for their target audience. Using TikTok influencers, they created a campaign to communicate and engage people with hearing impairments. They also opened a supermarket in a world-famous GTA5 game to attract candidates in-game applications. Both of these garnished wow among the audience!
DanceTalk â€” https://cariere.kaufland.ro/diversitate/kaufland-dance-talk.html
Siemens Presentation: Joint ownership of EB
Stefanie from Siemens started her presentation by sharing a long legacy and broad business range Siemens works for. One of the unique things she mentioned was that EB is a joint function between comms and HR. Their EB content always gets much better engagement than business content, which shows the power of peopleâ€™s content.
Impact Metrics â€” 2X time spent on the careers page. The content reached 3 million candidates.
Primark Presentation: Recruitment Marketing Unleashed
Steven and Neil shared some amazing examples of recruitment marketing done by Primark for retail roles. They have created unique job description pages and programmatic job ads for recruitment marketing. Neil also shared integrating employer branding across employee and candidate life cycles.
Mondelez Presentation: Mind the Gap of Internal Branding
Tedâ€™s presentation of Mondelez was one of the stand-out talks for me. Not only was he engaging, straightforward and no-BS, but he also shared an underrated element of employer branding for retaining top talent. He shared a very simple and useful method of measuring EB impact aligned to the external and internal objectives that include social engagement, eNPS scores, hiring/attraction measures and engagement index.
This slide is gold!
Haleon Presentation: Human Experience and Branding
A spin-off from another pharmaceutical giant, starting with no name or purpose. Itâ€™s a human-driven story to build the entire organisation ground up by leveraging human expectations and experience and co-build the org with them. Rhian and the team involved their employees in building the Haleon experience by using surveys and postcards to the leaders and leveraging the passion of their own employees while building the brand.
Power of Partnership CPO and CMO
For long, itâ€™s said that customer and talent are two different target audiences and needs, although this slide sums up why they are aligned in their expectations. Itâ€™s important that marketing and HR needs to align and treat them in equal measure. Simon shared this amazing insight.
How often do your CHRO and CMO talk?
Team LIDL: Candidate & Employee Surveys
Catherine and Antanio shared some nuggets about using candidate and employee surveys to build EVP pillars. They talked about measuring the perception vs reality and identifying gaps as part of EVP or Lidl VP. Itâ€™s an important step to find the balance between reality and inspiration.
EY Presentation: The Balancing Act
Matthew started the presentation by asking which shoes are we wearing. (Literally throwing the shoes as recruiters :D ). Recruiters need to stop self-congratulating themselves for things like hyper-personalized reach. Letâ€™s keep it real. EY, with over 400k employees and 170 EB specialists, have worked hard to build business cases to expand its capabilities. Along with him, Farrah shared various tech initiatives across recruiting and employee life cycles. I am sure Matthew Jefferyâ€™s passionate talk inspired many!
This is how EY leverages tech for talent.
EveryoneSocial: Prioritize Distribution
Cameron spoke about prioritising distribution over content creation. Thanks to the algorithms of big social media firms, distribution has become a big challenge. He shared an interesting case study of Amazon where, by using employee advocacy tools, they solved the distribution problem. He also mentioned that the organic reach is dead and we have to do targeted investing for distribution.
Two simple reasons: People engage with people. Networks prioritise peopleâ€™s content over the brand.
Short Video for Employer Branding: TikTok Tom
Since the rise of short videos, showcasing work culture and office videos has become a #WorkTok trend. Many companies have chosen this tool for engagement and a fun way to show their culture. Tom talked about some examples of organisations letting employees use this medium to share their stories.
Click here to learn more about #WorkTok.
(P.S. The emCee made Tom famous by calling him TikTok Tom)
Employer Branding Leaders and capability-building
In the concluding remarks, Brett talked about the need for employer branding leaders to take ownership of creating capabilities and work with leaders to build strong business cases to make this a full-fledged business function. This is one of the most exciting professions in the world, and responsibility is now with the leaders in the room to transform.
Hereâ€™s the quick framework to build a strong EB function and impact the business.
Huge shoutout to Brett for bringing passionate employer brand professionals under one roof and showing his vision for this profession. Employer Branding is no longer a side hustle TA folks would do, but more organisations are realising the value of employer (talent) brand to the business. After all, if people are the most important asset to the business, attracting and retaining them needs conscious efforts beyond operational talent management and acquisition. Also, a shout-out to Andrea for helping me in the process. I met some amazing folks, and this is my learning content from the conference â€” a real ROI of the trip!
It was lovely to meet you Google Dave!
I sincerely hope that this community grows globally and in India as well. I took a small step to create an EB community in India with over 30 employer brand professionals nationwide. Our conversations give us a sense of belonging and learning and help us to connect/grow together. This profession needs more leadership support beyond a nice-to-have IC person doing everything. If you are an employer branding professional in India, do get in touch with me.
Asta-la-vista #WorldEBDay! Bedankt!
(P.S) Some bonus fun nuggets from the conference where participants had a ball :D
youtube.com
--
--
1
Employer Branding Leader. I write everything about HR, employer branding & life :) Views are personal.

Title: Frontend Developers Love and Vue.Js Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Vuejs Amsterdam conference was amazing with over 1100 frontend developers and a screen of 180 degrees. It was amazing. The food was incredible, never seen such good catering at an event. They were very long days from 8:50 till 18:30 with 2 breaks of a half hour and a lunch break of an hour and a half. 12 talks per day. Very intense but very cool
The first day was all things frontend so not just Vue.js.
The future of JavaScript bundlers â€” Johannes Ewald â€” webpack core team
This was a great talk on what the future will be like and will we need things like webpack to make sure we can write code the right way and bundle it together. The browsers of course are not ready for this and that is why webpack is so necessary but in the future webpackâ€™s purpose will be different.
New Features of Webpack 5 â€” Sean T. Larkin â€” webpack core team
Sean talked about the changes we are going to see in webpack 5 and how it is going to be really boring as they are doing so much behind the scenes that we will not notice much changes but our build times will be much faster.
Elegance of Movement with reactive Angular Animations â€” Elena Gancheva
This was a nice talk on animations using angular and what not to do so as things come across as natural movements.
You donâ€™t know Microfrontends â€” Luca Mezzalira & Max Gallo
Interesting talk on breaking things down to create micro frontends.
Angular and Webcomponents â€” Ana Cidre and Sherry List
This was a really interesting talk on angular web components that just left everyone thinking oh my god angular why do you make things so complicated. Itâ€™s incredible at how many people dislike angular because itâ€™s just complicated for no reason at all. Still it was a good talk. I think it would put anyone off trying to choose angular over Vue.
Transforming your Web Application into a PWA â€” Why and How? â€” Gijs Weterings
This was a great and interesting talk on service workers and Progressive web apps which is something that is super important right now especially since google added it to the google store and it now has full browser support but it was good to see how easy it is to setup and how the notifications work and that you can only ask the user once to install it on their home screen so you have to time that properly. PWAâ€™s are interesting for the right project but are for sure worth looking into.
The Fresh Jest of Bel-Air â€” Rick Hanlon
This was a great talk on testing with Jest. Jest has come a long way since we started testing it out a year ago. Now I would for sure choose it over Jasmine, Mocha or Chai. Rick showed us some really cool things you can do with it to make your tests cleaner and for sure we should all be doing testing even though most people arenâ€™t as it takes time. Writing tests means less bugs later on. Also when people learn to write tests they think of things from a different point of view so itâ€™s always good to have a team working with tests.
Rest, GraphQL & gRPC â€” David den Toom
This was a great talk on graphQL. I love graphQL and would be so great to work with it. It basically just gives you back what you need from the JSON as opposed to giving you the full JSON like in Rest. Itâ€™s just nice. Perhaps we shall work with it in the future.
What is new with Gatsby.js â€” Kyle Mathews
This was an interesting talk on Gatsby by the creator of Gatsby and seeing how much it has improved. He has done a great job and itâ€™s pretty cool but itâ€™s for react based apps so something I wonâ€™t be using but good to know how it works etc.
What its like to be a full time open source maintainer â€” Evan You â€” Creator of Vue
This was interesting to see what Evanâ€™s life is like as an open source maintainer, how he explains to his family that he gives his work away for free and then people donate money to him so he keeps working on it. Also he talked about how it just happened and then decided to give up his full time job to maintain Vue.js full time.
Automated Scaffolding with Schematics (Angular) â€” Natalia Venditto
This talk left everyone thinking â€˜Seriously angular is there no better way?â€™ It was a good talk on schematics and I can see itâ€™s use case on certain projects so that you set up everything once and then install it so that all projects have the same folder setup and global styles etc but it is a lot of work and something I would really have to test out and play around with before going ahead and using it. Good but complicated but then again thatâ€™s Angular for you.
Day 2 â€” Vue conference
State of the Vuenion â€” Evan You â€” creator of Vue
This was a great talk on the future of Vue and what is being done to make it better. It was also good to see the statics. 700,000 weekly active users, 3.3 million downloads a month on NPM and 461 million hits a month on jsDelivr CDN. Evan also talked about web components in Vue and how the CLI supports building as native Web Components.
Hot Vue â€” Guillaume CHAU â€” Vue.js core team member
This talk was a last minute add in as Sara Drasner was ill and couldnâ€™t make it. It was a great talk on differences between server side rendering, single page applications and static pages and the benefits and differences between them all.
Vue.js for Lâ€™oreal, a case study- Tim Benniks
This was an incredible talk on how Lâ€™oreal are using Vue across all their brands. Their aim is that all brand websites will be on the same platform, will have the same technology stack and will adhere to the same KPIâ€™s. Lâ€™oreal Paris has 60 markets which all need localisations. They deal with RTL, non-latin fonts, different KPIâ€™s, different 3rd party integrations and local market adaptations. Lâ€™oreal Paris â€” no-js version, SEO, mobile first, progressively enhanced, async/lazy, fast. And to do all this they use Vue component files, vue devtools, vuex, vue-cli, cli-plugin-unit-jest, vue-test-utils, webpack wrapped by vue-cli-service, webpack-chain for configuration of site core helix structure, aslant â€” configured by vue-cli. Why Vue? Because it is simple to use.
NativeScript-Vue + ML = The Great MiniBar Challenge: MixoLogy â€” Jen Looper
This talk was really good fun from making cocktails to creating an app with nativeScript Vue and was interesting to see how easy it is to do.
GraphQL + Apollo + Vue.js = Magic â€” Sara Vieira
Great talk on GraphQL with Apollo and Vue. Really love GraphQL and how easy it is to query. For sure one day we will be doing stuff with graphQL.
Media for everyone â€” how to make your Vue Apps accessible for all users â€” Maya Shavin
Great talk on accessibility and how to make your apps more accessible. She showed us how we can use axe-core as a chrome extension to test our sites for accessibility with guidelines of how we can fix things. Also NoCoffee Simulator to test contrasts for people with vision problems.
Desktop Applications with Vue â€” Natalia Tepluhina â€” CTO at Vue Vixens
Interesting talk on how to build desktop applications using Vue. Not something I see us doing any time soon but good to know itâ€™s possible with Vue instead of just ionic.
Designing Components in Vue â€”Damian Dulisz â€” Vue core team member
Great talk on Vue components, how you shouldnâ€™t build them and how you should especially using slots and named slots. It was nice to see the contrast with how easy it is to create clean components and some great examples of slot uses.
Latest news on Vue Vixens
This was a mini talk on how vue vixens has grown ove the year. An initiative to try to get more women into programming by creating workshops etc
Latest news on CodeSandbox â€” Ives van Hoorne â€” Creator of CodeSandbox
This was a mini talk on what is happening next in CodeSandbox a tool for sharing code created by a 22 year old so he could share code with colleagues when he was working remote. Itâ€™s now a very successful project used by millions of people including me. Now he is working on it full-time with an amazing team to make it even better. He is amazing.
Full Stack Vue in the Era of Serverless Computing â€” Nader Dabit â€” Developer Advocate at Amazon Web Service
This was a really cool talk on how you can deploy to Amazon using aws-amplify and how you donâ€™t even need any backend developers because you donâ€™t need any servers. Really really cool.
Phenomenal design patterns in Vue using Vuex with Spiders â€” Jacob Schatz
This was a really cool talk on how to create your forms by building a form builder component kinda like creating your own form components that can be reused with different variations.
Day 3 â€” Vue
How to craft a Vue CLI Plugin â€” Guillaume CHAU â€” Vue Core Team
This was a great talk on how to create a plugin in Vue. Would be cool to do it one day and Guillaume showed us how it is actually quite simple to do.
Static Site Generation is Awesome â€” Alex Kyriakidis and Rolf Haug Vue School
This was a great talk on when you should use static pages instead of a single page application as it is easier to index and crawl and how hidden and visible content is available on initial render. They also talked about asyncData which runs before loading the page component and how to use the generate property to generate dynamic routes.
Everythingâ€™s a plugin: Understanding webpack from the inside out â€”Sean T. Larkin â€” webpack core team member
Sean did a great talk on webpack plugins and how weback is built from plugins, how it builds the graph and how a module gets to the browser with webpack. Really in depth behind the webpack scenes kinda stuff but very interesting.
Make your Vue apps Lighter by being lazy â€” Eduardo San Martin Morote â€” vue core team
This was a really cool talk where Eduardo explained what tree shaking was â€” dead code elimination and how webpack works to eliminate this dead code and how in general to make your apps lighter by lazy loading your routes for example or prefetching certain components.
Empowering Vue with TypeScript, Inversify, Vuex and some other super tools. â€” Quique Fdez. Guerra
This was a great talk by Quique and he really knows his stuff by I have no intentions of using typescript in Vue right now. Who knows in the future but for now I love Vueâ€™s simplicity and adding typescript is just not necessary. Backend developers need types as it is what they are used to and I can see the reasons behind it but am not sure if we all need to be going down that road. But he also talked about Nuxt and universal Vue applications and how they work. Also he gave us some great tips such as making small components, use linting, use conventions for names, doing tests, continuously improving your code and being ready to change everything.
Introduction to Nuxt.js â€” Nuxt explained Visually â€” Gregg Pollack â€” Founder of Vue Mastery
Great talk by Greg on how Nuxt works. I pretty much had already done this course and as I am creating a talk on Nuxt I knew all about this but was good to see how others were not so familiar and also good to know that I am doing everything right.
Nuxt.js 2019 â€” Donâ€™t miss the NEWS! â€” Sebastian Chopin â€” Creator of Nuxt
I had already had a sneak preview to what was coming up in Nuxt from my chat the previous night but was good to hear again and what was impressive was to see the companies that are trusting Nuxt, Adobe, Microsoft, Gitlab, Groupon, Yahoo, Lacoste, Fox News and many many more big companies.
Next Level Jest Testing with Vue.js â€” Roman Kuba
A great talk on testing with just in Vue with some great examples of testing async. Would love to have the time to deep dive into this and write more tests with jest.
Accessibility with Vue.js â€” Callum Macrae â€” Author of VueJS up and running
Great talk by Callum on accessibility by showing us what it was like for a blind person to use the web and how we can improve this and test things by using screen readers to see for ourselves. It really shows how important things like alt tags are or using the correct html semantics like a <button> for a button instead of an <input> or <a> tag for example.
Visualisations using SVG, Canvas, and WebGL in Vue â€” Chris Fritz â€” Vue core team
Really cool talk on using svgs and when you should be using them and what they can do and why you shouldnâ€™t be using CSS for something that an SVG can be used for.
I think I have managed to cover everything that happened during the 3 days in Amsterdam. It was action packed and my highlight was getting to hang out with all the amazing speakers and personally meet Evan You, such an amazing person and so friendly too. It was worth every penny and I will for sure be back at Vuejs Amsterdam and Frontend Developer Love next year.
--
--
1
Head Developer Advocate at Bit (bit.dev)

Title: How I spent three days â€” and 75,000 steps â€” in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A friend and I took this trip in February 2025. Enjoy!
DAY 1: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14th 2025
After checking into our hostel (THIS HO(S)TEL, Warmoesstraat 14) and dropping off our bags, we headed straight to Burgerbar Warmoesstraat, had a much-needed feast following a 05:00 wakeup, and planned the day ahead. BTW, the meal was sublime.
Next, we walked to De Negen Straatjes and ambled around Jordaan for the majority of the afternoon (which was noticeably quiet, maybe as it was a weekday), with a pitstop at La Tertulia, a coffeeshop with a gorgeous, calming, garden-style interior.
After returning to the hostel to freshen up and prepare for the evening, we decided to look for a Ramen restaurant for dinner. After visiting RAMEN-ISM & IMPOSSIBLE (fully booked) and Ramen-Ya (also fully booked), we ended up at Taste of Ramen which I must commend â€” their vegetarian ramen was tasty and extremely soothing!
Recommended by a local man on Hinge (lol), our next stop was Rembrandtplein for an evening of excitement. After perambulating the square, we decided to visit Cocoâ€™s Outback (a sports bar) for the evening. With its reasonable drink prices, lively tunes and excited energy, I would highly recommend it.
A couple of drinks down, the tiredness from the day hit, so we left Cocoâ€™s for the hostel â€” via the Red Light District. I had no expectations (probably as Iâ€™d never seen any photos (they are prohibited, take note)), but itâ€™s fair to say I was completely astounded by the scene. Truthfully, I didnâ€™t want to have an opinion on the trade until I learned some background/context regarding the circumstances in which these women work, so I planned to visit the Museum of Prostitution the next day.
DAY 2: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 15th 2025
We woke up early, eager to dabble in Dutch cuisine â€” with pancakes for breakfast. After scouring the internet for recommendations and stellar reviews, we settled on Pancake Company Amsterdam and ordered a plate of poffertjes with Nutella, strawberries, and whipped cream to share. As you may expect, it was *chefâ€™s kiss*.
Next up were Noordermarkt and Lindegracht Market, both pleasant markets with a strikingly local clientele.
For some time to rest, recuperate, and plan the rest of the day, we ordered a lovely vegetable pizza to share at Pizza Beppe Spui.
It became exceedingly apparent, upon reading various travel blogs, that a canal cruise is a non-negotiable addition to any Amsterdam itinerary. Taking this advice, we sought to book a slot within the next hour. Only at this point did we realise the scale of the Amsterdam canal cruise business and, concurrently, the myriad of providers we could book with. After 20 agonising minutes spent poring over Google reviews and cruise packages, we settled on the one-hour â€œcheese and drinksâ€ tour (â‚¬29) with Amsterdam Boat Trips, departing from a small dock at Oudezijds Voorburgwal 226. Oh, what a smashing choice we made. As our departure time grew nearer and nearer, we became surer and surer that we were the only people who had booked this tour. Wahey!
Iâ€™d give this tour a 6/5 review with a standing ovation (the extra star comes from the tour being unexpectedly private), and there are three key reasons why. It would be amiss not to open with the tour guide and captain; Ties and Huib were super knowledgeable and personable, and I came away with an array of trivia facts in my arsenal. Further, the tour covered various areas we had not yet explored, particularly on the eastern and southern sides of the city. Lastly, the cheese (Dutch gouda with a side of mustard) and drinks (I had one glass of prosecco, one of rosÃ© wine, and one of white wine) were a great addition to the journey and well worth the extra â‚¬9 versus the tour sans extras. We disembarked the boat in great spirits.
Continuing our cultural education, we visited the Museum of Prostitution (Red Light Secrets). Overarchingly, it was informative and provided a fair amount of â€œbehind the scenesâ€ insight. However, drawbacks included overcrowding (it is only a small museum) and the ticketsâ€™ steep price tag (â‚¬14.50). My highlight was definitely the wall at the end exhibiting visitorsâ€™ written sexual confessions.
After another brief break at the hostel, our next outing was an evening visit to the Anne Frank Huis. We had booked tickets including a 30-minute introductory talk about Anneâ€™s life. This was extremely well-presented and engaging, and instrumental in contextualising the subsequent information presented in the house tour. It was a highly effective and sobering reminder of the atrocities of the Holocaust.
Our last stop of the day was Nooch, a nearby Asian fusion restaurant. Even at ~21:15, we had to wait 10 minutes for a table to become free. Overall, the food was delicious and the low lighting created a pleasant ambience.
Again, we strolled back to the hostel via the Red Light District which, presumably as it was Saturday, was noticeably busier.
DAY 3: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 16th 2025
After picking up a couple of breakfast pastries from Dirk van den Broek (Warmoesstraat 157), we decided to take the ferry to Amsterdam Noord for a change of scene. There, we meandered around the tranquil Noorderpark and subsequently returned to the ferry via Van der Pekstraat, although most of the charming stores were shut.
It was lunchtime upon our touchdown in the city centre, so we headed to Omlegg (Nieuwebrugsteeg 24) where â€” surprise, surprise â€” we found ourselves in a queue forming down the street. Waiting in line was absolutely worth it, though, as my meal was scrumptious.
Re-energised, we walked to OBA Oosterdok, the central public library. I was particularly enthralled by the unique decor on the lowest floor, as well as the general spaciousness and airy feel of the building. The panoramic city views from the 7th floor are nice, however, glass barriers and an overhanging ledge cause some obstruction.
In need of a snack, we crossed Centraal Station to reach Fabel Friet (Nieuwendijk) and yes, these fries live up to the hype :).
With only a couple of hours of our trip remaining, we visited the Amsterdam Tulip Museum. Unexpectedly, and maybe owing to my lack of previous tulip-related knowledge, this was one of my favourite attractions!
With great reluctancy, we then packed up and made our way to the airport.
--
--
Jack of all trades... You know how it ends, don't you?

Title: Discover the Top 10 Must-See Museums in Amsterdam
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Amsterdam is a city brimming with history, culture, and creativity. From world-class art to fascinating science exhibits, the cityâ€™s museums offer something for every interest.
Whether youâ€™re an art lover, history enthusiast, or simply curious about the world, Amsterdam has it all. Hereâ€™s a guide to the Top 10 Museums in Amsterdam, ranked from the most famous down to the hidden gems.
Step into the world of Dutch art and history at the Rijksmuseum, one of the most iconic museums in the world. Home to masterpieces from the Dutch Golden Age, including Rembrandtâ€™s The Night Watch and Vermeerâ€™s The Milkmaid, this museum offers an unparalleled journey through the artistic and historical achievements of the Netherlands. A must-see for art lovers and history buffs alike.
The Van Gogh Museum is an essential stop for art lovers. It houses the largest collection of Vincent van Goghâ€™s work, from his early pieces to his later masterpieces like Sunflowers. This museum offers a comprehensive view of his artistic evolution and troubled life, making it one of the most visited art museums in the world.
The Anne Frank House is a deeply moving and poignant experience. Walk through the actual hiding place where Anne Frank wrote her famous diary during World War II. The museum offers a powerful look into the life of Anne Frank and the horrors of the Holocaust, preserving her legacy and inspiring future generations. Be sure to book tickets in advance as this museum is highly popular.
The NEMO Science Museum is a hands-on adventure that will ignite your curiosity. With interactive exhibits on everything from physics to engineering, this museum makes science fun and engaging. Located on a striking green building by the waterfront, NEMO is an exciting destination for families, school groups, or anyone fascinated by how the world works.
As a historic port city, Amsterdamâ€™s National Maritime Museum delves into the Netherlandsâ€™ rich maritime past. Explore a replica of a 17th-century Dutch East India Company ship, and engage with interactive exhibits that bring the stories of exploration, trade, and naval power to life. Perfect for history enthusiasts and families.
For cinema lovers, the Eye Filmmuseum offers a thrilling deep dive into the world of film. Located on the banks of the IJ River in a striking futuristic building, the museum showcases the evolution of cinema from its early film reel days to modern digital technology. With screenings, immersive exhibits, and a vibrant program of film events, this museum is a haven for film buffs.
Get a fascinating look inside the human body at Body Worlds Amsterdam. This museum features real, preserved human specimens, offering a unique perspective on anatomy, health, and human life. With detailed exhibits on how our bodies function, itâ€™s an eye-opening and educational experience that goes far beyond skin deep.
Located in the heart of Amsterdamâ€™s Red Light District, Red Light Secrets offers an unfiltered look at the world of legalized sex work. Through personal stories and interactive exhibits, youâ€™ll gain insight into the lives of sex workers, the history of the district, and the social dynamics of Amsterdamâ€™s famous red-light culture. A thought-provoking museum thatâ€™s as informative as it is unique.
Micropia takes you into a world most of us canâ€™t see: the microscopic world of microbes. With interactive displays and educational exhibits, Micropia explores the tiny organisms that shape our worldâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom bacteria and viruses to fungi and algae. This museum offers a fascinating, hands-on experience for anyone curious about the invisible forces at play in our everyday lives.
The Amsterdam Toy Museum is a delightful trip back in time, perfect for both kids and adults. This quirky museum features a vast collection of toys from the 19th and 20th centuries, including dolls, trains, and games. Whether youâ€™re revisiting childhood memories or sharing the experience with your little ones, this museum is a nostalgic and fun stop for all ages.
While these museums are fantastic, donâ€™t forget that Amsterdam itself is a living exhibit. Whether youâ€™re strolling along the iconic canals, wandering through historic neighborhoods, or simply savoring a stroopwafel at a local cafÃ©, the cityâ€™s rich history and vibrant culture are all around you. Even if you see all the museums on this list, thereâ€™s still so much to explore in this beautiful city.
Have you checked out any of these museums or discovered hidden gems of your own? Let us know in the comments belowâ€Šâ€”â€Šweâ€™d love to hear your recommendations!
ğŸ’¡Quick Tip: Donâ€™t forget to lock your while you explore the cityâ€™s museums!
--
--

Title: Amsterdam Revisited
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
The Uncanny is an attempt to look deeper at strange current events, ideas, and trends.
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
I revisited Amsterdam this past week and spent Easter Weekend, along with countless Spaniards, Italians and Germans, in the early spring sun. Last time I was in Amsterdam was in June of 2008 and I went alone for a conference. This time I went with my wife and we lived in a delicious and charming apartment in the Oud West, on Douwess Dekkerstraat, owned by the artist Patty Schilder.
[caption id=â€attachment_222" align=â€alignleftâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Oud West Apartment â€” looking toward Farmers Marketâ€]
[/caption]
From our balcony, looking out over the Buurtcentrum De Havelaar, we gazed at the Baarsjesweg Canal, especially beautiful in the evening when the sun sets and the large barges slowly make their way up and down after a long dayâ€™s work. Two blocks away, in the early morning, the farmers market gathers steam. Here, the true ethnic diversity of the Oud West comes alive â€” Middle Eastern women in their hejabs argue prices with their favorite vendors, breads and cheeses abound, fish and meats, too. The color and smells and sounds are soothing, seductive. There is no excuse here for not eating right. The food is fresh, beautiful. The difficulty is in buying only what you need, something the Dutch are very good at doing, it seems.
[caption id=â€attachment_223" align=â€aligncenterâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Oud West Apartment looking toward canalâ€]
[/caption]
The difference between this trip and my last one is the bicycle. The only real way to experience this culture is on the bike. Though a modern tool, the bike is the heart of Amsterdam. Many consider Amsterdam â€œthe biking capital of Europe.â€ Amsterdam bikers have the right of way, not pedestrians. The flow and energy of this city is dependent upon how well the biking moves the energy along. The Dutch are great bikers, they weave in and out of crowds, move effortlessly through traffic, grinning or smiling and never (apparently) frustrated. This is Amsterdam. Iâ€™ve seen youngsters txting and biking, talking on cells, with passengers, children, sometimes two, one in the rear, the other up front. Much of Amsterdamâ€™s life happens on the bike.
[caption id=â€attachment_224" align=â€alignleftâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Biking in the northâ€]
[/caption]
We rented our bikes from Bike City. The added bonus being that the only hint that this is a rental is written in small, elegant print on the black carry bag on the handlebars: Bike City. Otherwise, the bikes were like all others. Most rental bikes are loud reds or yellows and have huge insignias. Would you want to call attention to yourself like that? We didnâ€™t. We found the best bikes to rent are the 3 speeds with hand brakes. Theyâ€™re comfortable and sturdy. Our first trek took us through the city, to the ferry landing behind Amsterdam Centraal Railway Station, and up through the farmland of the north country all they way to Slot Ilpenstein. We biked through pasture land, in and out of canals. Sheep nearby. The famous Frisian horses, too. And we managed a glimpse of some drafts.
[caption id=â€attachment_225" align=â€aligncenterâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€I Am Amsterdamâ€]
[/caption]
From that day on, we rode everywhere, including another â€œout of the cityâ€ day trip to Haarlem, a municipality and a city in the Netherlands, and also the capital of the province of North Holland, the northern half of Holland. The bicycle lends for a particular order to things, a graciousness and decorum we like to call civilized or civilization. Itâ€™s interesting because if one examines the history of the Netherlands, we see that this living has come at great human cost. Many fell to the strength and power of the mighty Dutch will. The rise of the Dutch Empire is extensive and dramatic. Out of this, comes Amsterdam, an important port city and center of commerce. What we see in Amsterdam today is a result of this history so as we ride through the city and sit comfortably in cafes adjoining canals, we have to weigh the awesome power that began somewhere around the 1540s and that conquered so much. To the victor belongs the spoils is quite evident in Amsterdam. These spoils are Amsterdamâ€™s gift to humanity. But these spoils also bare an awesome responsibility that Amsterdamâ€™s inhabitants are trying to understand. The story is complex.
Perhaps this is why we can describe Amsterdam as an incredibly important human experiment thatâ€™s ongoing. And just maybe, this is why the moral structure of this great little city is experimenting with an unbound secularism founded on an unprecedented egalitarianism, which, in turn, depends upon freedoms of expression and a tolerance for difference. But this is the idealized version, the romantic view. Itâ€™s not surprising, then, that when the world is exhausted by the constant chimes of terror, from the Netherlands explodes the Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy. Itâ€™s also the place where Theo Van Gogh, the great-grandson of Theo van Gogh, the brother of painter Vincent van Gogh, was murdered by Mohammed Bouyeri, a Muslim extremist, after van Gogh, with collaboration from Ayaan Hirsi Ali, released the Anti-Islam film Submission.
[caption id=â€attachment_226" align=â€aligncenterâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Middle Eastern Women in the Oud West, after shoppingâ€]
[/caption]
Amsterdam is not without controversy. It is an extraordinary diverse place; however, diversity brings contention, even among the most enlightened. When differences are thrust together, the potential for an explosion is always present. Before 1965, the Netherlands were totally a monoculture â€” all white Dutch and no threats. This changed with a very liberal immigration policy. Effectively, the society is now segregated. On the streets, we can see the diversity, but where it counts â€” schools, neighborhoods, business and so on, we donâ€™t see it. There is resentment that what Dutch culture was is no longer â€” this is true. The monoculture safety net has been taken away. Now the struggle is different, particularly on religious grounds where the Christian and the Muslim, along with the Jew, have to live side-by-side in a society that is increasingly secular. What is Amsterdam turning into? What is it becoming?
I wonder whether Amsterdam today is the â€œnewâ€ Al Andaluz? It has the makings. Why not, why can it not be the â€œnewâ€ place where the three central religions, Christians, Muslims and Jews, live in relative peace and harmony? Only now we are called upon to protect the Muslim, not the other way around as it was when the Muslim protected the ahl al-dhimma (the people under protection). Maybe the tides have turned, though the challenges and the conflicts are as they were in the period between 711 and 1492. What we donâ€™t want is the devastation and the destruction brought about by the Christian King in 1492 â€” in the name of God and love! Al Andaluz was a beacon of learning, and the city of CÃ³rdoba became one of the leading cultural and economic centers in both the Mediterranean basin and the Islamic world. Why can this not be the fate of the Netherlands, Amsterdam leading the way?
The Amsterdam I see today is in transition, in flux, pained by both its past and its future. But itâ€™s how it negotiates its day-to-day where the mystery and awe exist. The seeds of tolerance are there â€” a young Muslim woman on a bike or a Vespa waiting for a light to change and waiting next to her is a tall Dutch blond, also on her bike, and they look at one another and smile. This is the new Amsterdam.
So perhaps the Dutch are such great bikers because they have been learning to negotiate obstacles all along. Whether by conquering territories for their wealth during the time of the Burghers or changing from a monoculture to an ethnically diverse culture, they have been challenging boundaries â€” national, ethnic and tribal, as well as economic and educational. Amsterdam could be the first small city that will evolve â€” or not â€” according to how well it enables those who reside in the margins of life to exist without threat; where once there was a singular uninterrupted culture, as is evident in the architecture and the museums, now there are only threads that are struggling to keep humanity together. And holding these threads are exiles. Amsterdam is a perfect example of a city of exiles, of histories that come from colonization, and newer ones that come along because they have been following the great human migration for survival, for subsistence.
[caption id=â€attachment_227" align=â€alignleftâ€ width=â€300" caption=â€Bikes, Canals, and their Bridges â€” the webâ€]
[/caption]
The Amsterdam of tomorrow will be built on the shoulders of mindfulness and tolerance. And if successful, Amsterdam, as Al Andaluz before it, will hold a noble place in the continuum of great histories that have given humanity, even if for a moment, a ray of hope that we can live together and relish in our differences.
--
--
